excerpts: We got the samusas, mango chicken, fish chowder, and tea leaf salad.
samusas.author: Leslie L.
samusas.review:
A few seats and a few selections from the menu to kick off a great night. I absolutely love Burmese food and every time I'm back in the Bay, it's on my list. While I would have normally gone full out at a larger sit down, Yamo was a perfect drop by and have a quick meal full of flavor. 

We got the samusas, mango chicken, fish chowder, and tea leaf salad. 

I will saw everything was exceptional with the exception of the fish chowder. In general, this is one of my top favorite dishes but it was just alright here. Otherwise, I'd still highly recommend for food, price point, and quickness.

excerpts: I ordered the fish chowder, and he ordered the house special noodle dish along with a side of samusas.
This was better than some other Burmese spots we've been to.
Both our foods came out quick as it was made to order.
Overall the food was alright.
We may/may not come back in the near future as there are other options around the hood' that we'd want to try.
samusas.author: Tracy C.
samusas.review:
Came here on Friday night, as my husband and I were randomly walking by looking for food options  for dinner. I had been here years ago with my sister and girlfriend, however had not remembered much about the food. 

Well, the husband and I decided to give this a try. I ordered the fish chowder, and he ordered the house special noodle dish along with a side of samusas. This was better than some other Burmese spots we've been to. Both our foods came out quick as it was made to order. Overall the food was alright. We may/may not come back in the near future as there are other options around the hood' that we'd want to try.

excerpts: The samusas were generic, they reminded me of deep fried hot pockets stuffed with a mild meat filling.
Based on its texture, the samuas was definitely a frozen food product and not homemade.
samusas.author: Felix L.
samusas.review:
Yamo is a "quick-fix" Burmese eatery with a limited menu, almost the opposite of Zagat-rated Burmese restaurants in the area like Mandalay and Burma Superstar. It's small, cramped, family-owned, not very sanitary, has an open kitchen, offers simple comfort food, and everything on the menu is under $10. Yamo fits all the criteria of a "hole in the wall". 

If you're lucky to find an empty spot on the 8 seat counter, go hang up your backpack on the wall, take a seat on the bar stool, read the sticky menu, and better order within a minute or else you will get on the bad side of Yamo's impatient waitstaff. Between three people, we shared the samusa, tea leaf salad, and a Yamo chicken house noodle. That's not enough food for a real meal here, so we got scolded by the waitress. If only she knew we chose to eat light because we had a dinner reservation 3 hours later...

The samusas were generic, they reminded me of deep fried hot pockets stuffed with a mild meat filling. Based on its texture, the samuas was definitely a frozen food product and not homemade. The supplied dipping sauce was the sweet and sour type that accompanies egg rolls. 

Tea leaf salad (lahpet thoke) was not very memorable. Actually, it tasted even worse than the ones I've eaten at Burmese restaurants in LA. Yamo's salad was overall crunchy which I found satisfying but the flavors were very very mellow. It sorely lacked the pungent and bittersweet flavors that I expected from mixing fermented tea leaves with other ingredients in the salad, which is what makes this Burmese salad so unique. Instead, the salad tasted sweet and garlicky more than anything else.

Finally, Yamo's house noodle was simplistic and ordinary, yet almost everyone else in this hole in the wall had a bowl in front of them. Egg noodles were boiled in some oily broth, then batched drained, served with some pan fried boneless chicken, peanuts, and green onions. What's so special about it? What's Burmese about it? Even after the chef drained the oil, the bowl of noodles was still a grease bomb. Not worth the $6.

As others have already mentioned, you won't find service here. The three ladies who prepare your meal are not very friendly, so it's best to eat fast and get out ASAP. The chefs appear to speak Taishanese, a Cantonese dialect, to each other and joke around. Well, the damage was $19 for this disappointing meal. Not worth it for the snack-size portions and uninspiring flavors, not worth a detour to come here. I would only recommend this place as a cheap introduction to Burmese food.

excerpts: Order: Beef house noodle, tea leaf salad, samusas, and curry prawn.
samusas.author: Jocelyn C.
samusas.review:
My Number One restaurant in SF. The place I recommend to all my friends & family if they're visiting SF. It's a true city experience.1600+ reviews really tells all. I'm not going to add to the noise, so take in my short, but sweet review. 

Order: Beef house noodle, tea leaf salad, samusas, and curry prawn. 

Why Go? The only place in the nation, at least from the places I've traveled to, where the workers speak 3 different dialects yet move like a symphony. You'll hear Burmese, Mandarin, and Cantonese all being thrown out to push orders out the door. The space allows for 11, all counter seats, as you watch the 4 women work head to toe and yakking at customers that order too slow or eat too slowly. You're almost guaranteed to wait at all peak hours, but people know to hustle so 25 minutes is the max. 

And....It's cheap, and just damn delicious.

excerpts: We grabbed the following to share for dinner: vegetarian spring rolls (4.50), vegetarian samusas (4.50), tea salad (6.25), and house noodles (6.25).
Everything was made in about 10 minutes and for under $25 for a solid dinner in the Mission that ain't too bad.
The dishes aren't huge, but for the price I think they are perfect.
Everything was super flavorful without being greasy or heavy like a lot noodles are at times.
Totally a place I'll be back to and make sure to grab a seat at the counter next time!
samusas.author: Kelsey B.
samusas.review:
New favorite take out spot in the Mission that won't break the bank!
Found Yamo while my fiance and I were out drinking in the Mission and wanted some delicious food to soak it all up.  Yamo had some vegetarian/vegan options so we decided to do some take out to share.  Walking up, this place is smalllll, a total hole in the wall with maybe 8 seats at the counter and always a line out the door (a good sign).  The menu is printed outside and the ladies workin here are quick to get your order and greet you with a smile. I like that you can watch what is goin on while you're food is being made and its a little entertaining while you wait. 
We grabbed the following to share for dinner: vegetarian spring rolls (4.50), vegetarian samusas (4.50), tea salad (6.25), and house noodles (6.25). Everything was made in about 10 minutes and for under $25 for a solid dinner in the Mission that ain't too bad. The dishes aren't huge, but for the price I think they are perfect. Everything was super flavorful without being greasy or heavy like a lot noodles are at times. Totally a place I'll be back to and make sure to grab a seat at the counter next time!

excerpts: A $20 tab for beef house noodles, tea leaf salad, samusas and two bottles of Coke
No alcoholic beverages and cash only!
It's location makes for great bar hopping to and from dinner.
If you're looking for authentic Burmese comfort food this is your spot.
One star off for service.
It's a simple get in, eat and get out kind of place.
samusas.author: Jenna M.
samusas.review:
Perfect for last night's rainy weather.  Yamo's atmosphere is simple and to the point.  No frills, no music just quality simple Burmese food at an amazing price point.  A $20 tab for beef house noodles, tea leaf salad, samusas and two bottles of Coke 
No alcoholic beverages and cash only!  
It's location makes for great bar hopping to and from dinner.
If you're looking for authentic Burmese comfort food this is your spot.  One star off for service.  It's a simple get in, eat and get out kind of place.

excerpts: The samusas were delicious though, at $4.25, potatoes had a great texture and flavor.
samusas.author: Maggie G.
samusas.review:
Food: upper 3.5 stars
Service: 2 stars

I'm not turned off by the lack of enthusiasm in service, but I think the lady was borderline offensive and I believe it's really a mutual relationship when we go to a restaurant, pay them, and get the food we want. The way she yelled "NO PICTURES OK" to my mom, idk.. why don't you post up a sign for no pictures then? 

On top of that, I don't think the food is great. I'm not comparing it to any other Burmese place, because I realize the take is a little different; more like a street vendor kind of food. However, the tea salad was $6.5, tiny, and did not have enough cabbage. Everything was good, not amazing, and on the salty side. The cold noodles were good, $6.5, spicy, oily. The house noodles were good, oily, also $6.5. Not really a lot to be said about their flavors except "it's not bad." The samusas were delicious though, at $4.25, potatoes had a great texture and flavor.

Anyway, I probably won't be back here unless it's a cold day and I want to try their chicken noodle soup, which looked really good. All their food would be awesome with beer but no alcoholic beverages are allowed in there.

excerpts: Samusas.
samusas.author: Nikki M.
samusas.review:
Tea Salad. House Noodles with Chicken. Samusas. $17. Yum.

We got take out since they have something like 8 stools and a line out the door. There are just 3 staff members working mighty hard so there can be a bit of a wait, but dang. Why did we wait so long to finally try what is both delicious and refreshingly affordable especially in comparison to other neighborhood haunts (see: artisanal chocolate/cheese/coffee/mustaches around the corner).

excerpts: They run out of the samusas so get there early!
samusas.author: Akshaya V.
samusas.review:
This is the best place to go for good food in the city! 

There is definitely a wait to get in but it's not too long. There are about 10 seats in the house...but it's worth it! Food is awesome! We had the spring roll, veggie garlic noodles, and veggie curry. So good! Definitely going back for more! 

They run out of the samusas so get there early!

excerpts: At least the samusas were good though.
samusas.author: Tina S.
samusas.review:
So disappointed.
For $6.25, the tea salad's portion was so small... not worth it. 

At least the samusas were good though. For $4.50, that's not bad.

The service was terrible. Communication was so unclear....

excerpts: Ordered samusas that tasted mediocre.
This place seems overhyped for me
samusas.author: Jiggy B.
samusas.review:
One of the ladies screamed at me to not take any pictures with my phone even though they had no sign that said to not take pics.
Ordered samusas that tasted mediocre. This place seems overhyped for me

excerpts: The samusas really stretched our jeans to their limits with the hearty potato and spice filling.
$16 bucks for 2 people and a jean waistband about to pop?
samusas.author: Joyce K.
samusas.review:
"It feels like an honor to eat here because it's like you're being invited into someone's kitchen" said the guy sitting next to us as his arm rubbed up against my friends in the crevice of a kitchen. 

And it is true, Yamo is a remodeled closet turned kitchen. The intimate space only allows for 8 diners at a time who are sitting elbow to elbow as we greedily wait for our food to arrive. While the menu is small, all on one page, it's a difficult choice to make as all the options sound good and are $6 and under per plate. From tea leaf salad to mohinga (fish) chowder and house noodles, the stomach can't help but to be dazed by the options.

The counter lady/chef who has "invited" you into her kitchen is sassy and snappy, and honestly a little indifferent to your needs. This is no loving mother who feels the need to heal all your emotional wounds with her food. She's just trying to get through the long day herself, so please don't expect a coddling mother, this is the mother who has literally been slaving in the kitchen all day, and doesn't have time for your shenanigans. 

The order of house noodles with pork came out in a sheen of heavy oil that can only mean heavy food coma later. But oh how FRESH those noodles were. We slurped up those slippery suckers in what seemed like mere seconds. We had debated on whether or not the tea leaf salad was a little too interesting for our tastes, but ended up getting it and we regret nothing. The tangy & spicy crunch was the perfect side dish that offered a refreshing lift from the heavy noodles. The samusas really stretched our jeans to their limits with the hearty potato and spice filling. $16 bucks for 2 people and a jean waistband about to pop? So worth it.   

So save your change (they are cash only) ladies and gentleman and you too could have a fine meal at Yamo like the 1299 who have come before you!

excerpts:
the samusas ($6.00)
3. house noodles with beef ($6.95)
samusas.author: Catherine C.
samusas.review:
Charming the first time around if you've never been to a hole-in-the-wall food stall in Asia, but I'll take takeout from here moving forward. If you don't like smelling like grease, take my advice. :)

If you like being  in the midst of all the action, then this place is for you - You'll hear the ladies working in the kitchen at Yamo chatter in Cantonese while they chop, dice, stir-fry and deep-fry your food in front of you. 

Yamo is a mom-and-pop Burmese home cooking joint in the Mission. It's a drastically different experience from the decidedly clean-cut vibe of Burma Super Star. With only bar seating and an exposed kitchen behind the bar, expect to rub elbows with other customers while you're eating and be prepared to come out smelling a little smoky. 

The food is decent if you just want some good old Asian comfort food to go. Nothing to write home about though.

These are the three essentials that I recommend ordering at Yamo: 
1. the tea salad ($4.25)
2. the samusas ($6.00)
3. house noodles with beef ($6.95)

You'll come out with your belly heavier and your wallet barely lighter!

excerpts: Based on these reviews, we decided on the tea leaf salad, some samusas, mango chicken, and house noodles.
The tea leaf salad was the highlight of the meal, and as good as I have had at other Burmese joints in the area.
The mango chicken combined an interesting amount of sweetness with some spice, and was also good.
samusas.author: Brent W.
samusas.review:
We had Yamo for takeout recently, and it was good, but I wouldn't say it was great. Based on these reviews, we decided on the tea leaf salad, some samusas, mango chicken, and house noodles. The tea leaf salad was the highlight of the meal, and as good as I have had at other Burmese joints in the area. The mango chicken combined an interesting amount of sweetness with some spice, and was also good. The noodles were ok but seemed a little overcooked and oily.

I think that I would try it again and give some of the other items a shot, but as it it I thought it was only ok.

excerpts: Got the samusas and the flavor reminded me of dirt... not very appetizing.
Boyfriend and I both got  rice dishes
(i'm sorry this was HELLA days ago
so I don't remember which..) and were not impressed with either.
Both were lacking in flavor and far from anything special.
After observing the people around us it seemed as though EVERYONE besides us ordered noodles
samusas.author: Melissa C.
samusas.review:
I was very excited to try this place but ended up being pretty disappointed... 

Yes, the ladies here are pretty fucking rude/obnoxious. It can be entertaining depending on your attitude... I wouldn't have minded if the food was actually good, i mean some of the most delicious food comes from terrible customer service - BUT from my experience it wasn't good so I didn't appreciate their disrespect... Also English not being their native language doesnt justify yelling at people to hurry up when they sat down for no more than 10 minutes. They're not stupid or "lost in translation", they just don't give a fuck. 

ANYWAYS

The place is pretty small and gets busy so don't count on eating in... I liked that aspect personally (the small divey feel). I liked the assembly line they had going on, was cool watching them prepare and cook everything.

Got the samusas and the flavor reminded me of dirt... not very appetizing.  Boyfriend and I both got  rice dishes (i'm sorry this was HELLA days ago so I don't remember which..) and were not impressed with either. Both were lacking in flavor and far from anything special. After observing the people around us it seemed as though EVERYONE besides us ordered noodles...opps?

I'll admit that maybe we didn't order the "right" things...probably should have went with the tea leaf salad, noodles and/or soup but our experience was so off putting that I had no desires in giving this place another chance... that and there's a Burmese place (Kyain Kyain) closer to where I live(d) that was SO much better both in food and customer service.

excerpts: We decided to get samusas, curry prawns, house beef noodles, and tea leaf salad.
The house noodles were very delicious although a tad oily.
The curry prawns were okay (more mushrooms than prawns).
The samusas had the right amount of spice and curry powder.
samusas.author: Sofia R.
samusas.review:
I was grabbing lunch with some friends who decided they wanted to get Burmese food because they'd never had it before. I decided to take them here because it's one of my favorite places and the prices aren't too bad.

The line was really long, but we decided to eat in. The place is really small, dingy, kinda grungy. You can feel the heat from the kitchen because you're sitting pretty much in front of it.

We decided to get samusas, curry prawns, house beef noodles, and tea leaf salad. The house noodles were very delicious although a tad oily. The curry prawns were okay (more mushrooms than prawns). The samusas had the right amount of spice and curry powder. The tea leaf salad was crunchy, tasty, and had great flavor (just kind of a small portion for the price).

We had grass jell drinks too. It comes in a can for $1. Not bad. Pretty refreshing after such a spiced up meal.

Great place!

excerpts: I would give the samusas 5 stars.
They are incredible.
I was expecting something a little more bold, like the samusas.
samusas.author: Alison H.
samusas.review:
The line is long, the space tiny, and the food is cheap.  

I would give the samusas 5 stars.  They are incredible. Delicious, flavorful, and unique. 

We also had the garlic noodles and mango chicken.  Mango chicken was pretty good, but didn't blow me away.  The garlic noodles were super bland. I think they've toned down some of the flavors to appeal to a broader audience.  I was expecting something a little more bold, like the samusas. 

Will come again and keep trying other things though.  Totally a great deal, if you're in the neighborhood.

excerpts: We got the Yamo house noodles with chicken and the samusas, both of which were very tasty.
It was pretty clear that their takeout business is strong, so since the place itself is so small I would definitely recommend getting takeout.
samusas.author: Amy Y.
samusas.review: This little hole in the wall is the definition of home cooking. The ladies that work here are adorable and it's great to see them cooking as you sit at the bar. We got the Yamo house noodles with chicken and the samusas, both of which were very tasty. It was pretty clear that their takeout business is strong, so since the place itself is so small I would definitely recommend getting takeout.

excerpts: Can't wrong house noddles and samusas.
samusas.author: Niaz K.
samusas.review: Never disappointed with food. This is my 2nd takeout. It is literally hole in the wall place. Food is fresh and cheap. Can't wrong house noddles and samusas.

excerpts: My first time trying samusas.
Will definitely not be my last.
samusas.author: Jennifer C.
samusas.review:
CHEAP and DELICIOUS. Nothing here is over $6 and there is such a great variety to choose from. 

I really enjoyed their tea salad. Just the right amount of spice and very appetizing. Their house noods are AMAZING. We got 2 orders. One beef and one pork. We also got their curry chicken and mango chicken. Both were delicious with the rice they came with.

Potstickers were big and juicy. My first time trying samusas. Will definitely not be my last. So good.

Place is ideal for to-go/pick-up. I want to try everything on the menu.

excerpts: Appetizers: $4.95 - only 3 choices: samusas, egg rolls and potstickers.
samusas.author: Joanna T.
samusas.review:
By chance, I noticed Yamo last week and now passing the place (with fast sinking blood sugar), I stopped and decided to give it a try.

First off, Yamo is a shoebox. But this place last week and tonight was full. Everyone sits at a counter on some funky, red vinyl covered stools. What caught my eye this time was a guy seated close to a door drinking from a straw that fed into a real coconut. I had to exam the menu in the window.

Appetizers: $4.95 - only 3 choices: samusas, egg rolls and potstickers. 
Salads:       $6      - tea leaf or chicken salad

Ahh, the samusa and tea leaf salad on the menu immediately screamed "Burmese" to me. 

Entrees: All $6 - choice of curry beef, chicken, curry prawns, curry tofu or curry fish. Everything goes over egg noodles or rice. Don't like curry? they make a house fried rice or a house pan fried noodle. You kind of get the drift that their repetoire is strictly enforced.

When I popped my head in, the main lady and the cook looked over the full row and then peeked over the counter and nodded me to the 1st stool right inside the door opposite the stoves. Umm, is this the best seat in the house? Or is this the worst seat?

I've got to say I like the fresh air coming into the door. Didn't like the closeness of the flames from the wok shooting up in the air from the stove.

Without being in a party, I chose only one dish: curry prawns with rice. I was fascinated watching the ladies' system. The head lady takes the orders, gathers ingredients and places items in a silver dish which she lines up by the cook and the cook stir-frys each dish up and gives it back to the head lady to deliver to the customer.

Back to the food: now dairy-based curry generally has a good sauce that goes good with rice. But when I was served up my dish, I found I had a reddish, oil based curry with the prawns. Foiled - not much sauce. The food was okay and definitely hot from the oven.

Other male diners (with bigger appetites!) went all out ordering potstickers, curry fish noodles and fried rice and curry tofu just for two people. Some couples took out an order of the tea leaf salad on their way out. Seems like a very popular dish.

It was really interesting to watch the interplay between the ladies busting themselves to get the food out. I watched the youngest of the ladies hack (with a cleaver) at the top of a fresh coconut to pierce the shell so a straw could be inserted. Amazing.

What else can I say? If in the area and hungry but on a budget, come for the food and stay for the show.

excerpts:
What to eat, to share with one other:
1) Samusas
2)
samusas.author: Susan L.
samusas.review:
Yamo is a hole in the wall run by dragon ladies.  What to expect: great food and kind of intimidating service! 
  
1) wait in a long line.  (although if you come 45 mins before prime dining times, the wait will be really short! 11am, 6pm)
2) sit on a rocky stool at a greasy countertop
3) get yelled at if you don't order within 3 minutes
4) eat elbow to elbow with your neighbors and hear everyone's conversations
5) possibly get yelled at again: "are you done??!", at which point you will pay a ridiculously awesome price for all the food you got with cash only.
6) smell really disgusting after, so bad you would stink up the entire cartrain on bart.

What to eat, to share with one other:
1) Samusas
2) Tea salad (so delicious, best thing on the menu! better than burma superstar's)  You may need two orders. nommms
3) Yamo House Noodles (I like it with pork)
4) Fish chowder noodle soup (my burmese friends say its really good here!)

excerpts: We decided to go with the house noodles and the mango chicken with an order of samusas.
The food is flavorful, very affordable, and came out reasonably fast (I mean they make it a few feet away and right in front of you).
The samusas came out after our main dishes and they were piping hot but just delicious when they had a second to cool down.
When we left, there was a fat line waiting outside to get in and eat/order to go.
samusas.author: Jerry Y.
samusas.review: There are maybe only 12 seats in the whole place. The GF and I beat the dinner rush and made it in and found out seats immediately. We decided to go with the house noodles and the mango chicken with an order of samusas. The food is flavorful, very affordable, and came out reasonably fast (I mean they make it a few feet away and right in front of you). The samusas came out after our main dishes and they were piping hot but just delicious when they had a second to cool down. When we left, there was a fat line waiting outside to get in and eat/order to go.

excerpts: My friend and I split an order of samusas (appetizer) and a mango chicken entree and garlic noodles with beef.
It was GOOD!
I'll be back to try some of the curry dishes.
The prices are super reasonable too--okay, actually more than reasonable for San Francisco.
Entrees are priced at $6, and appetizers are under $5.
Hit the ATM first--it's CASH
ONLY (but no tax).
samusas.author: Lisa N.
samusas.review:
Don't expect service with a smile--or really much of any service beyond the lady yelling at you to order from behind the counter (it's loud and chaotic). It is what is...and when you come to Yamo's it's pretty much what you should expect. 

The lines are long, but they move rather quickly. The menus are taped to the windows, so you can decide what you want while you wait. In lieu of tables there are bar stools at the counter, so you can cozy up to the random people who pile in. The rule is, once a stool becomes available, you plop yourself down and order. You're essentially eating in the kitchen (yes, it's that small). On the plus side, you get to see the wonderful food cooked right up in front of you. On the downside, it can get smoky inside and your clothes will have that funky Asian food smell afterward. 

The food? Delicious! Everything is cooked to order--very flavorful. My friend and I split an order of samusas (appetizer) and a mango chicken entree and garlic noodles with beef. It was GOOD! I'll be back to try some of the curry dishes. The prices are super reasonable too--okay, actually more than reasonable for San Francisco. Entrees are priced at $6, and appetizers are under $5. Hit the ATM first--it's CASH ONLY (but no tax).

excerpts: Samusas + shrimp spring rolls + tea salad + beef curry over noodles = can't lose!
samusas.author: Lorraine Y.
samusas.review:
What do you do when you want affordable Asian food in the Mission District and Mission Chinese is CLOSED ON A WEDNESDAY? As I found out go for Yamo (it must mean in "yummy" in Burmese)!

Samusas + shrimp spring rolls + tea salad + beef curry over noodles = can't lose!

My only worry is that they'll get too popular for their own good and jack up the very reasonable prices for current menu items. Oh well, I'll enjoy the heck out of this literal hole in the wall as long as I can!

Useful info:

- CASH ONLY
- line out the door so call in your order
- limited seating in a tiny space means you will walk out of there smelling like the food
- this part of the Mission looks a bit shady at night so go with a friend

excerpts:
We got: 
-Samusas (WAY better than Indian Food samusas)
-Tea
Leaf Salad
(so delicious...
samusas.author: Ellary C.
samusas.review:
This place is amazing. I drove/walked by Yamo a million times and there was always an insanely long line out the door and was too intimidated to check it out.

Today at 3:30 I was walking by and there was no line! I actually got to sit down at the counter with my boyfriend. 

-it was a sweaty beast in there...but totally worth it for the atmosphere...but trust me next time i'm doing TO GO for sure!


We ordered everything because I was afraid I would never get to go back bc of the lines!

We got: 
-Samusas (WAY better than Indian Food samusas)
-Tea Leaf Salad (so delicious...i would rather pay $6 than get ripped off at burma superstar)
-Cold noodles with chicken (AMAZE)
-their chicken noodle soup (yummy coconut broth mmm)

Pretty much we spent $25 (with out tip) and have leftovers for dinner!

I would recommend this place to everyone!! Cheap eats and way better than any other thai/asian/burmese place i've been in this city!

ps. i love the amount of cilantro they use. 

Super happy i got to try this little whole in the wall. YUM!

excerpts: We ordered their popular dishes: samusas, cold beef and chicken noodles, and tea leaf salad.
From my standpoint, I loved it all!
Reminds me of the type of dishes my boyfriend's mom cooks at home.
She's Chinese/Burmese.
Gotta say, this is by far,
one of my go-to cheap spots to eat at now.
Worst of all, that same day, I went back here after 3 hours because my drunk-a
** had a fat craving for their cold noodles.
How's that for being a foodie?!
FYI...
the women who run this business, don't be shocked or turned away by their speaking tones.
They're not trying to be rude.
I think that's how they speak to each other.
For those who admire Burma Superstar, maybe your palates got spoiled by fine dining, but you can't go wrong with hole-in-the-wall spots like this....especially when it's greasy food.
Duh people!
samusas.author: Fraulein C.
samusas.review:
I like spending money on expensive food, but I have a soft heart for inexpensive meals with a whopping price tag of $6!!! Read on Yelpers.
My friend Dan and I wanted to roam around SF for fun before we had to trek it back to SJ. He mentioned we should grab a quick bite at Yamo before continuing the rest of our day. Finally took the opportunity to check this place out after so many attempts and never actually dining here until now. I can't complain about this place, regardless if they only seat 8 people at maximum capacity. Yep! I said it. 8 people. Consider this a sit down, eat your food quick, and smell like grease after having food coma status.
Anyway, food costs between $4-$6. Yeah, right?! Cheap!! We ordered their popular dishes: samusas, cold beef and chicken noodles, and tea leaf salad. From my standpoint, I loved it all! Reminds me of the type of dishes my boyfriend's mom cooks at home. She's Chinese/Burmese. Gotta say, this is by far, one of my go-to cheap spots to eat at now. Worst of all, that same day, I went back here after 3 hours because my drunk-a** had a fat craving for their cold noodles. How's that for being a foodie?!
FYI...the women who run this business, don't be shocked or turned away by their speaking tones. They're not trying to be rude. I think that's how they speak to each other.
For those who admire Burma Superstar, maybe your palates got spoiled by fine dining, but you can't go wrong with hole-in-the-wall spots like this....especially when it's greasy food. Duh people! Get over yourself.

Am I a fan?! F*** yeah I am!!

excerpts: Me and a friend shared the yamo cold house noodles, the yamo hot house needles with beef, and the samusas.
Bursts of flavors all over the place.
My friend said that those three dishes were the ones to get.
I certainly agree.
samusas.author: April D.
samusas.review: So I have been out of the country for 2 years. And this is the 1st new restaurant I got try after returning to America. Me and a friend shared the yamo cold house noodles, the yamo hot house needles with beef, and the samusas. Bursts of flavors all over the place. My friend said that those three dishes were the ones to get. I certainly agree. Top it off with fresh coconut to drink. Fantastic. I could not ask for a better homecoming.

excerpts: We ordered the samusas, beef curry over noodles, and the tea leaf salad.
The samusas were great.
Not too big and oily, and very flavorful.
The tea leaf salad was good, but doesn't compare to the version at Burma Superstar.
Lastly, the beef curry over noodles was disappointing.
It might've been the fact that we didn't eat it until we got home 20-30 minutes, but it the noodles were dry, and the sauce was lacking.
samusas.author: Stan A.
samusas.review:
First of all, I thought this was a Korean place (for no reason in particular, just an assumption.) Secondly, every time I see this place I think of the quote from 40-Year-Virgin: "If I have to hear 'Ya-mo Be There' one more time, I'm going to 'Ya-mo' burn this place to the ground. Classic Paul Rudd.

I had no intention of eating here on this particular night, but after passing by the place with my girlfriend and seeing no line (there's always a line), we decided that it was a sign we should eat here. So we went across the street to buy some groceries from the market, only to return less than 10 minutes later...to a line!

Should've taken that as a sign that it wasn't the day for us to 'Yamo eat there,' but we already had our hearts set on it, so we waited it out.. for about a minute. Then we decided to order take out so we didn't have to wait in the cold City night.

We ordered the samusas, beef curry over noodles, and the tea leaf salad. The samusas were great. Not too big and oily, and very flavorful. The tea leaf salad was good, but doesn't compare to the version at Burma Superstar. Lastly, the beef curry over noodles was disappointing. It might've been the fact that we didn't eat it until we got home 20-30 minutes, but it the noodles were dry, and the sauce was lacking. Like I said, it most likely dried up on the drive home, but for now, I'm calling it like I see it, and for now, I'm not a fan.

I would like to try it again (and eat-in this time), as I feel this place has potential, and the prices are quite cheap, but only if I happen to pass by on an empty stomach and there's no line. But if I'm in need of my Burmese food fix, it's Superstar/B-Star FTW.

excerpts: We ordered the samusas  (this is how they were spelled on the menu), pot stickers, tea salad, and the curry fish.
samusas.author: V R.
samusas.review:
Visited for the 1st time last night and was pleasantly shocked how much I enjoyed it.  

Its tiny, only about a dozen seats at the counter and so I can imagine on a busy night there is fair wait, but we waited only about 10 min.  We ordered the samusas  (this is how they were spelled on the menu), pot stickers, tea salad, and the curry fish. Everything was super tasty and the bill came to whopping $20 and change, not bad at all!

Take-out seemed to be a popular option, which makes sense giving the limited seating. Honestly the only reasons I'm not giving it a 5 star is 1. No alcohol... a beer would have been great with that meal and 2. We came at the end of service and do to the limited space the staff was chopping up large volumes of onions next us in prep for the next day which was making my eyes water.  But let me just say, a little eye watering wouldn't deter me from going back!

excerpts: Two of the items that we both ate were the House Chow Mein with Chicken and the Samusas.

The House Chow Mein with Chicken that we ordered had so much Chicken in it (not that it's a bad thing, a good thing really), and the portion sizing was pretty good, and we had a good amount of Samusas.
So if you're ever feeling adventurous, and in the mood for Chinese food when you're in the Mission, check out Yamo's.
samusas.author: Jay A.
samusas.review:
Whenever visiting this place, please, please, PLEASE keep in mind that it is VERY very tiny. My girlfriend and I had to get our food to-go. I had no idea that this place was just a hallway. You've got a cooking area, and a row of chairs to sit in, and barely enough room behind those chairs to walk through. It was my first time trying this place out, and it definitely packs a punch. The prices aren't too bad, no tax, exactly the amount you see on the menu which is posted on the windows of the place.

Two of the items that we both ate were the House Chow Mein with Chicken and the Samusas. Everything they have is freshly cooked in front of you, all veggies and noodles prepped, and ready to get cooked up. They won't make it until you order it. The House Chow Mein with Chicken that we ordered had so much Chicken in it (not that it's a bad thing, a good thing really), and the portion sizing was pretty good, and we had a good amount of Samusas. So if you're ever feeling adventurous, and in the mood for Chinese food when you're in the Mission, check out Yamo's.

excerpts: Samusas... FREAKING HOT!!!!
samusas.author: Jinny K.
samusas.review:
Samusas... FREAKING HOT!!!!

This is a spicy place.  The only thing not spice is their house chow mein and mushroom plate.

This place is meant for people who love spicy food and are single.  Not for families.

excerpts: We quickly ordered the tea salad, mango chicken, samusas, along with 2 fresh young coconut drinks.
samusas.author: Solitaire M.
samusas.review:
One does not dine at Yamo for the customer service or ambience. But that's okay, I'm not that uptight/high maintenance. 

My friend and I came here on a weekday around 3 PM, parked in the secret cheap parking garage and walked down the charming Cornwall St. We only waited for a couple minutes, squeezed our way over to the counter and hung our items on hooks behind of us. We quickly ordered the tea salad, mango chicken, samusas, along with 2 fresh young coconut drinks. Using two hands, we clunked our coconuts together in light of the delicious meal we were about to devour.

The price is affordable in comparison to the other name Burmese restaurants in SF. I didn't think our food was greasy nor did I think the 3 women "threw" anything at us. I did notice one of the women serving two people next to us who kept asking for things and she kept saying "Yah, yah, yah," and looking annoyed. I thought she knew them, but I don't think she did haha! 

Yamo seems a good fit for singles or duos who are low maintenance, on a budget, are in the neighborhood and there is no wait.

excerpts: Samusas
- I like these better then
samusas.author: Wakako U.
samusas.review:
House special noodle with tofu - no broth, garlicky, saucy noodles.  Delicious!
Fish chowder soup with noodle - Good, but not as good as Mandalay.
Tea leaf salad - tossed with cabbage - better then Burma or Mandalay.
Samusas - I like these better then Indian samosas - smaller and in wanton wrappers.

All for $22.

excerpts: My friends and I shared samusas, the tea salad, and we each got our own entree dish (I got the curry fish with noodles)
Samusas were great, well seasoned with enough kick to give your tongue a tickle.
Tea salad was great too--a lot like the "tea leaf salads" you get at other Burmese restaurants, but this place is a bit more authentic.

Tea leaf salads traditionally are made with cabbage (which this one was)... but at most establishments like Burma Superstar or Pagan, they use romaine lettuce since we Americans eat more romaine than cabbage.
Curry fish was OK, but my friends who got the curry chicken and mango chicken loved theirs.
The curry fish, which had batter around it, wasn't deep-fried, but instead was panfriend, a lot like how my mom cooks it.
I would have preferred it to be deep-fried, that way the fish is a lot crispier. .
.so
instead, everytime I ate each bite of fish, it was like chewing into something kinda soggy...
samusas.author: Matthew L.
samusas.review:
What an interesting establishment!  

It was like going to a diner, but instead serving Chinese/Burmese food.  The food was pretty tasty, although on a little on the greasy side...but hey, that's restaurant food.  My friends and I shared samusas, the tea salad, and we each got our own entree dish (I got the curry fish with noodles)  Samusas were great, well seasoned with enough kick to give your tongue a tickle.  Tea salad was great too--a lot like the "tea leaf salads" you get at other Burmese restaurants, but this place is a bit more authentic.  Tea leaf salads traditionally are made with cabbage (which this one was)... but at most establishments like Burma Superstar or Pagan, they use romaine lettuce since we Americans eat more romaine than cabbage.  Curry fish was OK, but my friends who got the curry chicken and mango chicken loved theirs.  The curry fish, which had batter around it, wasn't deep-fried, but instead was panfriend, a lot like how my mom cooks it.  I would have preferred it to be deep-fried, that way the fish is a lot crispier. . .so instead, everytime I ate each bite of fish, it was like chewing into something kinda soggy...so that didn't sit too well on my palate, despite the good flavor.

Pricing of this food is really cheap--the appetizers are like $3.25 and entrees are like $5.25.  So you definitely get full way fast at such a low price.

The place is opened by 3 Chinese ladies.  Me being Chinese I couldn't help but listen in on their conversations.  I found their conversations to be quite entertaining!

Since this place only seats about 8-10 people, there is usually a line out ther door.  Last night, when my friends and I went...it was raining, but fortunately when we had gotten in, there were 4 seats for all of us.  There really isn't a "prime time" for eating dinner, since it's pretty crowded during all hours of dinner time.

excerpts:
- this was pretty tasty, but I prefer this dish at other Burmese restaurants
Samusas - actually really good and hot and fresh
Mushroom Tofu - ok, kind of lacking in flavor
Vegetable Curry over noodles - luke warm, but interesting -
I appreciated that okra was among the vegetables in the dish.
samusas.author: Rachana S.
samusas.review:
I was excited to try a hole in the wall Burmese restaurant and went with two other friends.  We waited maybe 10 minutes before being seated which wasn't bad at all.  As everyone else mentioned, it's super small, and you can watch all the food being prepared for you which is pretty cool.  But, the food was only ok to me.  I'm vegetarian so we ended up getting:

Tea-leaf salad - this was pretty tasty, but I prefer this dish at other Burmese restaurants
Samusas - actually really good and hot and fresh
Mushroom Tofu - ok, kind of lacking in flavor
Vegetable Curry over noodles - luke warm, but interesting - I appreciated that okra was among the vegetables in the dish.
Coconut Water - awesome, got to eat the coconut meat at the end as well, but not really special to Yamo
Green jelly drink - a canned drink that was ok

But, this place IS dirt cheap.  We got all of that for 25 bucks.  I wouldn't resist if someone wanted to come here for dinner, but I think I'd prefer most of the other Burmese restaurants around town (even if they're further out).

excerpts: We ordered samusas (kinda like triangle fried mashed potatoes) and man.. it was delicious!!
especially with the spicy sweet and sour red sauce...
samusas.author: Reyner T.
samusas.review:
I've been wanting to try out this new place for quite a while now and I went there for the first time today with a friend of mine.

It's Wednesday night around 7ish and we had to wait about 15 minutes to get seated for 2 people. Not bad... 

We ordered samusas (kinda like triangle fried mashed potatoes) and man.. it was delicious!! especially with the spicy sweet and sour red sauce... YUMMY!!

We also ordered 3 dishes to share: Yamo's pork house garlic noodle, mango chicken, and curry beef. All of the 3 dishes are amazing even though they are on the greasy side! My favorite one is their house garlic noodle with pork. The pork is so tasty and delicious!

The mango chicken is good but ehhh... it's alrite. It's more on the plain taste side.

THE PRICE IS SO FREAKING AFFORDABLE!

All of the appetizers are $3.25 & all of the main dishes is only $5.75 including ride and/or noodle!

Total paid for our meal is only $21.25 (excluding tips but including one Fanta and one Diet Coke for a buck each!)

I love this place!! I'll be back but this time I think I will just take it to go... I don't want the greasy food smell stuck in my clothes & my hair! LoL!!

excerpts: For 3 we ordered the tea leaf salad, samusas, house noodles, chicken curry soup, and curry prawns.

Everything was just okay - the portions are what you'd expect (they're definitely not huge), and the food came out one at a time since the three ladies behind the counter were swamped with take-out orders.
I was the most disappointed with the tea leaf salad since I expected it to taste amazing, but what gave it that satisfying crunch was mainly the store-bought fried garlic/shallots.
samusas.author: Leily P.
samusas.review:
Although in general I like Burmese food, the food here was really oily. The place is also really really tiny, and your clothes really come out stinking like the food you just ate. 

For 3 we ordered the tea leaf salad, samusas, house noodles, chicken curry soup, and curry prawns. Everything was just okay - the portions are what you'd expect (they're definitely not huge), and the food came out one at a time since the three ladies behind the counter were swamped with take-out orders.  I was the most disappointed with the tea leaf salad since I expected it to taste amazing, but what gave it that satisfying crunch was mainly the store-bought fried garlic/shallots.

excerpts: The SAMUSAS are great!!
Very flavorful!
It puts other samusas to shame.
samusas.author: Vivian H.
samusas.review:
There are about a total of 8 stools in this place.  You sit at the counter and watch the two ladies cook your food.  There is a very good chance that you will smell like grease afterwards.

The food is amazing cheap.  Everything is 5.25 and 3.50 for the appetizers.  However, portions aren't that huge and the bulk of it are noodles or rice.  I had the curry fish and it was SO GOOD, but very greasy.  The curry is actually spicy!  Make sure you pick the noodles, not the rice!  The mango salad was also amazing, the flavors were just right.  My boyfriend had the mango chicken and that was also really good.  The SAMUSAS are great!!  Very flavorful!  It puts other samusas to shame.  

And.. no tax?!!!

excerpts: We ordered the samusas (these were just OK), black bean fish, and the tea leaf salad (both were pretty delicious).
What didn't make sense was why the black bean fish and the tea leaf salad were both $6, but the portion of the salad was WAY smaller.
I'll be back to try some of there other dishes.
samusas.author: Cindy A.
samusas.review: Definitely not a place to bring a date, but DEFINITELY a place to get nomtastic, cheap food. Boyfriend and I came here yesterday and we were in and out the door in 30 minutes; the food comes out quick. We ordered the samusas (these were just OK), black bean fish, and the tea leaf salad (both were pretty delicious). What didn't make sense was why the black bean fish and the tea leaf salad were both $6, but the portion of the salad was WAY smaller.  I'll be back to try some of there other dishes.

excerpts: The Samusas were awesome.
Tons of flavor, they're taking taters to the max here.
Try popping them with your chopstick to vent.
samusas.author: Adam F.
samusas.review:
this place is is the quintessential hole in the wall with outstanding food. It's tiny... as in it seats about 10 people. You literally will stand outside during someone's entire meal, waiting for their seat. This is the only reason I'm not giving the place 5 stars. Granted, their entire restaurant is tiny, so they make do with what they have. They do have food to go, and will take your order ahead of people waiting for tables if you're on the move.

As for food, I'll start with appetizers. Tried the pot stickers, lots of flavor, perfectly cooked. not too crispy, not soggy. The spring rolls are large. you get two large ones with a nice peanut sauce. They're quite refreshing! The Samusas were awesome. Tons of flavor, they're taking taters to the max here. Try popping them with your chopstick to vent. mine were hot, and you won't want to burn your tongue and miss the flavor bonanza coming later. 

Chef selections: I tried the mango chicken and the beef curry with noodles. Quite different dishes, both were fantastic. The beef in my dish almost tasted as though it were marinated in marsala, I'm not sure if they did or not, but it was subtle and a really great flavor to compliment the rest of the dish. The curry was fairly light in quantity compared to other curries I've had, but this was a good thing. No one flavor dominated, it just tasted like a recipe that has been perfected over a long time. One of the other guys eating there said it best: you're about to have the sort of meal your grandmother would cook for you. The mango chicken was very refreshing. The mango pieces actually made me laugh out loud - they were that good. I'm not sure if they marinate those too, but wow. Something about the combo of mango and the lightly seasoned chicken, it was a great dish. 

Now for the best parts: PRICE. four of us ate appetizers and main dishes for $26. whaaaaat? yeah 26 bucks. granted two girls shared one dish, but seriously. It's almost not even fair. They got a big tip. And now for you more adventurous types - there is a powerful dishwasher under the far end of the bar seating. It was running during my meal and it shakes your seat like a washer/dryer. You haven't lived until you have Yamo curry on a washing machine.

excerpts: My friend and I each ordered a bowl of the house noodles, with sides of pot stickers and samusas and it was way way too much food.
One appetizer would be enough for 3 people to share.
samusas.author: Beth D.
samusas.review:
The food at Yamo is delicious, and the portions are plentiful. My friend and I each ordered a bowl of the house noodles, with sides of pot stickers and samusas and it was way way too much food. One appetizer would be enough for 3 people to share. This is definitely on the greasy comfort side of the food spectrum. 

The interior is tiny, one long, narrow counter, so unless you really want to smell like noodles all night (and wait for a spot) I'd suggest calling ahead and getting your order to go. The prize for eating inside is overhearing hipster girls reveal their plans to zomg go to every bar in the Mission. The prices were reasonable, our bill after all that food and 2 sodas came out to $18. Looking forward to getting regular take out.

excerpts: Get the samusas, tea leaf salad, and the chicken noodle soup...i'm drooling already... its super good and its worth the wait...even if the wait is an hour long in the mission...
I can wait..
samusas.author: Christine W.
samusas.review:
Little dirty hole in the wall with delicious burmese food...the way i like it!

Seriously this place is a diner counter with 10 seats, you have to wait your turn to get a seat or just order take out. 

Their menu is cheap! dirt cheap for delicious burmese food. Get the samusas, tea leaf salad, and the chicken noodle soup...i'm drooling already... its super good and its worth the wait...even if the wait is an hour long in the mission... I can wait..I love Yamos!!

Not an ideal date spot on account of the cramped space, but its part of its charm, its not the cleanest spot as well as you can see the two burmese ladies prepare your food right in front of you and you can see the dirty dishes piling up right in front of you.

I overlook these things as there food is too good for me to care :)

excerpts: Samusas are great as well as my all time fav - the fish chowder.
Four stars in lieu of five because of the limited seating.
samusas.author: Jen E.
samusas.review:
I LOVE THIS PLACE! 
The food is delicious Burmese/Chinese fusion without all that unnecessary glamour. You order fried rice, you get fried rice. Samusas are great as well as my all time fav - the fish chowder. 
Four stars in lieu of five because of the limited seating.

excerpts: tea leaf salad is outstanding, but everything else was ok (fish chowder, vegetable curry, samusas)
samusas.author: Cece L.
samusas.review:
tea leaf salad is outstanding, but everything else was ok (fish chowder, vegetable curry, samusas)

I saw the chef drop a broccoli on the ground, then toss it back into the pan.. YUCK!

excerpts: I ordered the tea leaf salad and samusas!
Both of the dishes are the bomb.
I love the nutinness and crunchiness of the tea leaf salad.
I was expecting greens; I was somewhat hesitant to order the salad because I was super hungry and because I didn't feel like eating leaves at that time.
Although the salad is small in portion, it is very rich and savory.
It was also a bit spicy but the spiciness added more kick.
The samusas were tasty
but I cant say they are the best tasting ones.
My friends and I also shared our meals.
The cold noodle was pretty standard yet
it was still delicious.
samusas.author: Anette N.
samusas.review:
I just moved to the Bay Area so I'm going to claim that this is probably the best Burmese food I ever had here. 

Definitely, a hole in the wall. And you know what that means? Delicious and cheap food!  The place is really small, they only seat around 9 people if you want to dine in. You will also smell of grease and smoke after dining in because the tight space and because they cook right in front of you. We opted to just order take out and eat at Dolores Park, a walking distance that is just a couple of blocks away. The wait was long but it was worth it. 

I ordered the tea leaf salad and samusas! Both of the dishes are the bomb. I love the nutinness and crunchiness of the tea leaf salad. I was expecting greens; I was somewhat hesitant to order the salad because I was super hungry and because I didn't feel like eating leaves at that time. Although the salad is small in portion, it is very rich and savory. It was also a bit spicy but the spiciness added more kick. The samusas were tasty but I cant say they are the best tasting ones. My friends and I also shared our meals. The cold noodle was pretty standard yet it was still delicious. The mango chicken was tasty as well but it wasn't one of our favorites. 

Would I go back again? Heck yeah. It's pretty cheap and I feel that the portions are about right. You will feel satisfied but you won't feel bloated.

excerpts: I also like the spring rolls and samusas.
I once ate here four times in a week and am still not sick of it.
samusas.author: Julie N.
samusas.review:
I LOVE this place. I feel like I'm in Southeast Asia when eat here. The ladies who work here are so gruff and tough, but I love it. It's definitely not about friendly service. You get in, eat, get out. The food isn't best quality but taste oh so great. I usually order the Chicken Noodle Soup in a curry broth. Practically everything on the menu is $5.25 or less so...

The Fish curry dish is good too. I also like the spring rolls and samusas.
I once ate here four times in a week and am still not sick of it.

excerpts: Mango chicken was delicious and the samusas were also great.
The food was spicy :)
I love watching the women chop veggies and cook with huge cast iron skillets.
This restaurant feels like a great secret...except that maybe it's not such a secret anymore.
samusas.author: Owl B.
samusas.review:
Yamo is amazing!! I stumbled into this great hole-in-the-wall and now I am a regular! After a trip to Burma 5 years ago, it feels great to get some down home Burmese food (theirs is especially influenced by the China border). It's cheap, great atmosphere (I love dives) and the food is great. Mango chicken was delicious and the samusas were also great. The food was spicy :)  I love watching the women chop veggies and cook with huge cast iron skillets. 
This restaurant feels like a great secret...except that maybe it's not such a secret anymore.

excerpts: I also got an order of the "samusas" which were just a little too deep fried, were only okay but came with a good sweet/spicy red sauce.
samusas.author: Andrew K.
samusas.review:
From some of the reviews from Yelp, as well as my roommate, i've been meaning to check this place out in my hood for quite a while.  Well, like an overly hyped movie, it just didn't match my hopes and was totally blah. 

We got take out here on a rainy Friday night, but it wasn't as busy as most nights.  I had the House Noodles +chicken, and the g/f has the curry vegetables.  Both were surprisingly bland, and my noodles just tasted like grease.  I also got an order of the "samusas" which were just a little too deep fried, were only okay but came with a good sweet/spicy red sauce.  

Not sure if I came here on an "off" night, but i really don't get what all the rage is about.  Others tend to cite the "hole in the wall" vibe, which it has...but in the end you still want to eat something with flavor and not sopping with grease. I'll try it again since its about 100 feet from me, but simply put I make better food in my own kitchen.

excerpts: Samusas were filled with potato and curry and were just ok.
The prawn & veggie curry had a deep sweet and sour colored sauce, with a light curry hint...
delicious.
We each took an order of house noodles to go after our meal and it was still only $32.
Will be back for sure.
samusas.author: Adrian S.
samusas.review: This place kicks ass. There's like 8 stools on a bar top or you can get take out. Waited 10-15 mins for seats and totally worth it. A unique experience with 3 little Burmese ladies staffing the "kitchen" behind the bar top and cook up simple burmese/chinese grub. The house noodles with chicken stole the show and only $6. The potstickers were plump and crispy on the outside. Samusas were filled with potato and curry and were just ok. The prawn & veggie curry had a deep sweet and sour colored sauce, with a light curry hint...delicious. We each took an order of house noodles to go after our meal and it was still only $32. Will be back for sure.

excerpts: the samusas were ok, deep fried, potatoey, and slightly spicy.
ordered a chicken curry--the curry had a lot of those soft fried potatoes.
the nice thing about it was that it wasn't sweet, more salty savory.
still a deal, but not something I'd be seeking out compared to other burmese options
samusas.author: Rob C.
samusas.review:
hole in the wall with an open kitchen and now a $6 menu for 2011.
order the tea leaf salad which barely had any tea leaf, but what can u expect for the price (it was a smidgeon)  however the take on this version was more tangy and slightly spicy.  the samusas were ok, deep fried, potatoey, and slightly spicy.  ordered a chicken curry--the curry had a lot of those soft fried potatoes.  the nice thing about it was that it wasn't sweet, more salty savory.  still a deal, but not something I'd be seeking out compared to other burmese options

excerpts: Also...curry chicken, potstickers and samusas....
samusas.author: Adrienne C.
samusas.review:
Yamo house noodles w/beef. For $5.25. Seriously. That's all you need to know.

Also...curry chicken, potstickers and samusas....YUMYUMYUM.

It's tiny, the wait is forever and there is no parking. Save yourself a headache and call ahead with your order for pick-up. Come in 30 minutes versus the 15 minutes they tell you, pick up the yummy, sesame oil-drenched noodle goodness and eat from the comforts of your home. You will be much happier if you do.

excerpts: I tried samusas and house_noodles with chicken, and ordered a shrimp_fried_rice to go.
I've seen long line in front of it earlier
but I got there early today and had great food without having to wait!!
samusas.author: A K.
samusas.review:
Yamo is yummy!! (& cash only)

For under 6 bucks you can get really really good noodles or fried rice with the experience of having it cooked in front of your eyes. Two ladies behind the counter are good at what they do. She gives you enough time to go over the menu but very prompt at taking the order. 

I tried samusas and house_noodles with chicken, and ordered a shrimp_fried_rice to go. I've seen long line in front of it earlier but I got there early today and had great food without having to wait!!

excerpts: We ordered fresh coconut, samusas and the mango salad.
I have gone back since and ordered the same.
I don't know much about Burmese
but I do know that this is a chiller spot!
It reminds me of Art's Cafe on Irving.
Cheap, tasy hole in the wall... and who run it?
Little Burmese women.
samusas.author: Janice K.
samusas.review:
A strange friend of mine took me on a foodie date and Yamo was our first stop. We ordered fresh coconut, samusas and the mango salad. I have gone back since and ordered the same. I don't know much about Burmese but I do know that this is a chiller spot! It reminds me of Art's Cafe on Irving. Cheap, tasy hole in the wall... and who run it? Little Burmese women. Girl Power!!!!!!!!!!!!

Oh by the way, there is a wait and it can be brutal at times... Try venturing out during the week at an odd hour.

excerpts: We ordered the samusas (potato and spice fried goodness) - you get 6 small triangles for $3.50.
Then we had the mango chicken and house noodles with beef.
It wasn't the most flavorful burmese food I've ever had, but it was still damn good for the price.
I wish the house noodles had some sauce.
Even after thoroughly mixing, it mostly just tasted like stir fried noodles with really good beef.
They should use whatever they marinate the beef with for the sauce.
samusas.author: Humaira M.
samusas.review:
Yum yum yum. Tried to come here two other times (once closed, once there was a line) and glad I finally made it. I thought there'd be a line Saturday at 1pm but there were at least three available stools. There are a total of ten bar stools, in case anyone was wondering. The menu items seem to range from $3.50 to $6ish. 

We ordered the samusas (potato and spice fried goodness) - you get 6 small triangles for $3.50. Then we had the mango chicken and house noodles with beef. It wasn't the most flavorful burmese food I've ever had, but it was still damn good for the price. I wish the house noodles had some sauce. Even after thoroughly mixing, it mostly just tasted like stir fried noodles with really good beef. They should use whatever they marinate the beef with for the sauce. They also have fresh coconut!! We ordered one ($2.50) and they cut it open and gave us a straw for the coconut water and a spoon to scoop out the coconut flesh. Dee-lish! All in all a very yummy satisfying meal, and the pre-tip total came to $16.50! Would def go back to try the other dishes on the menu.

excerpts: We had the spring rolls, samusas, mango chicken, some delicious crunchy salad thing, and 2 bottles of bottled coke.
(HELLS YES for bottled Mexican coke which always tastes like heaven!)
We only spent $20 on everything.
Great portions, great prices, great atmosphere.
samusas.author: Andrea F.
samusas.review:
Me amo Yamo.

A friend took me here yesterday and I fell in love.  
We walked in around 4pm on a Monday and magically there were 2 seats waiting for us.
It's a cute little hole in the wall with awesome red walls run by some crazy, crazy hard-working women yelling at each other about something.  (I'm convinced they were talking shit about me, but ya know....)

They only have about 6 stools at the counter to sit and you get to watch them cook up some delicious-ness.
We had the spring rolls, samusas, mango chicken, some delicious crunchy salad thing, and 2 bottles of bottled coke. (HELLS YES for bottled Mexican coke which always tastes like heaven!)
We only spent $20 on everything.  Great portions, great prices, great atmosphere.  AWESOME.

I would definitely come back here and hope that those 2 vinyl stools are waiting for me next time.

excerpts: "Samusas" were tasty though nothing like a samosa, and the yamo house special noodle with beef was absolutely delicious.
I can hardly wait to eat my way through the rest of the menu.
samusas.author: Adam Z.
samusas.review:
Holy flurking snit, Yamo - where have you three lovely ladies been all my life!!

"Samusas" were tasty though nothing like a samosa, and the yamo house special noodle with beef was absolutely delicious. I can hardly wait to eat my way through the rest of the menu. Cheap and hot and fresh as hell, plus you get a free cooking class while you wait.

Crazy that the best intersection in the city for foodies right now is 18th and Mission!

The atmosphere at Yamo makes me feel like I'm Harrison Ford as Decker slurping noodles in "Blade Runner."

Avoid the shrimp dishes because as Dwight Schrute says, "You know that line on top of the shrimp? That's feces."

excerpts: My boyfriend and I always order the house noodles with beef (always beef, it's garlicky and AMAZING), tea leaf salad (crunchy, spicy delicousness), and samusas.
samusas.author: Stacey J.
samusas.review:
Yamo is the kind of place that I don't want to review, because I don't want anyone else coming here!

I LOVE Yamo. It's a funky little no nonsense place with nothing but a counter that seats about 10 people. Walk up to order to go or wait in line until a spot opens up at the counter. 

Food is amazing, and I'd pick Yamo over Burma Superstar any day. My boyfriend and I always order the house noodles with beef (always beef, it's garlicky and AMAZING), tea leaf salad (crunchy, spicy delicousness), and samusas. Nothing on the menu is over $5.25, so our bill is never more than $20 for two people.

Minus one star just because there's not much customer service. The little ladies that work here are cute, but they're always barking at each other behind the counter, don't ever really make eye contact with customers, and almost always forget to bring me my beverage. Interior is funky, not terribly clean and cluttered behind the counter. I like that though, it gives it more character.

In sum, Yamo rules, but don't come here because I don't want to wait in line behind you.

excerpts: You might order the popular tea leaf salad, samusas, some curry, or whatever else you fancy.
What you get is appropriately greasy, appropriately delicious, and the perfect quantity for cheap.
samusas.author: Vrushali P.
samusas.review: Eating at Yamo is quite the experience. It is everything you dream of for a hole in the wall place. A tiny restaurant on 18th street with about 6 boor stools and one counter top, if you are lucky enough to get a seat, grab it! Inside, you are greeted with the slipping of some paper place mats and chopsticks on your little section of the counter and handed oddly sticky and greasy menus from which to make your selection of food items. You might order the popular tea leaf salad, samusas, some curry, or whatever else you fancy. What you get is appropriately greasy, appropriately delicious, and the perfect quantity for cheap. You eat your food while watching three little old ladies whipping up dishes for fellows patrons and the smoke rise and fill the poorly ventilated space. You might consider making today laundry day because you will definitely leave smelling a little too tasty for your own good.

excerpts: As we arrived, I was already dreaming of the "tea salad", samusas and curry.
While I read a few reviews raving about the tea salad and how it is so much better than Burma Superstar's version, I must WHOLEHEARTEDLY disagree.
There really is very little tea leaf in the Yamo tea salad.
The samusas were average, but nothing to go out of the way for.
The beef curry that I ordered was dripping with oil, lacked any flavor (no spice at all)
Yes, it is cheap (2 curry meals, 1 tea leaf salad, 1 order of samusas =
$19.20 w/o tip) and
it may be convenient for some, but I just can't imagine eating there again.
The food was pretty flavorless and just too greasy for me to handle a second time around.
samusas.author: Hiromi N.
samusas.review:
After reading many of the 4-5 star reviews of Yamo, the boyfriend and I were truly looking forward to having our taste buds treated to a great surprise tonight as we drove out to the Mission.  As we arrived, I was already dreaming of the "tea salad", samusas and curry.  

There were some positive things that I took note of right away:

94% inspection rating (hanging on the back wall)
Family owned and run
The ingredients looked fresh (as the ladies were peeling & chopping items right in front of us).
The young lady serving us was quite friendly and customer service oriented.

Yet, I must say that I was EXTREMELY disappointed with the food.  While I read a few reviews raving about the tea salad and how it is so much better than Burma Superstar's version, I must WHOLEHEARTEDLY disagree.  There really is very little tea leaf in the Yamo tea salad.  While tasty, it is almost comparable to campbell's "chicken" noodle soup, where the chicken flavor is there, but the chicken is MIA from the whole equation.  

The samusas were average, but nothing to go out of the way for.  The beef curry that I ordered was dripping with oil, lacked any flavor (no spice at all) and I just couldn't make myself finish it.

Yes, it is cheap (2 curry meals, 1 tea leaf salad, 1 order of samusas = $19.20 w/o tip) and it may be convenient for some, but I just can't imagine eating there again.  The food was pretty flavorless and just too greasy for me to handle a second time around.  :(

excerpts: At this point I was starting to wonder why we hadn't gotten our other appetizer, the samusas, yet.
samusas.author: Adam C.
samusas.review:
Yamo-goers beware, the operation of this place can be a bit confusing at first.  A line forms on the right of the entrance for seating.  A line forms on the left of the entrance for take out.  I was a little skeptical, at first, waiting without my name on a list, but it turned out alright.

I got there at exactly 7:34, on a Tuesday.  There were 6 people ahead of us, but considering the place seats maybe 10 total, that turned into an hour long wait.  I thought the wait at Burma Superstar was kind of absurd, so when 8:29 stuck and we weren't seated yet, I proclaimed: "Fuck." (We said we wouldn't do this.)

We decided to keep waiting and didn't have to wait much longer than that, thankfully.   Based on friends' reviews, we started with the tea leaf salad.  I thought it was very good:  a stab of spice mixed with the crunch of nuts and refreshing crisp of lettuce leaf.

Next came the Curry Beef with Noodles and I found them to be light on the oil, but full of flavor.  At this point I was starting to wonder why we hadn't gotten our other appetizer, the samusas, yet.  

They showed up to the party a little late and when I bit into one, I nearly spit it out, exclaiming, "Holy shit that's good!"  Luckily, for those around me, I managed to keep that sucker in my mouth, although I was surprised by how good it was.

We also tried those grass jelly drinks out of curiosity and they were okay.  They have bits of grass-flavored jelly(?) in the bottom to add texture to the drink, ie. you need a straw.

The shape and size of the place really reminded me of a small diner where I would get breakfast in my hometown.  Even though it was my first time there, it felt very familiar, and everything had the appearance of a home cooked dish.

At the end we were full, and it was 8 dollars each with a 20% tip.

excerpts: Samusas and fresh spring rolls as appetizers?
Yes please.
samusas.author: Blake E.
samusas.review:
This is now the third incarnation of Yamo's I've seen, and it took me too long to make it to part III of the trilogy. Last time, it was eclectic and visually amusing. Before it was Anna the Thai Soup Nazi who was good for endless entertainment as she showed you pictures of her nieces she wanted you to marry.

But now as a Burmese restaurant, Yamo satisfies as well as ever. Insanely cheap entrees ($5.25 each!), nice spices and ingredients, and well-crafted rolls rarely go together.

I had the black bean fish noodles. Make sure you get them or live to regret it. Our server-cook recommended against the curry prawns but they were pretty awesome, and they'll give you the spicy if you like. Samusas and fresh spring rolls as appetizers? Yes please. They even make the spring rolls in front of your very eyes.

Service is with a smile, and an occasional forgotten item. But then the smile comes again and you just go back to eating your plate of deliciousness.

excerpts: Then came the samusas which my friend claimed tasted like pizza rolls!
I think he meant the dough, which I do have to agree with.
samusas.author: Amy C.
samusas.review:
I'm sorry! I just don't understand the hype about this place! The food's not bad, but I wasn't wowed by it. Granted this is my first rendezvous with Burmese food, but if all Burmese food is like this, I might not be impressed.

I won't go into the details about the physical location of the restaurant since it's been covered in depth by others already.

We started off with the tea leaf salad which was delicious until about the fifth bite. After that your taste buds get kind of overloaded and the dish stops being tasty. Then came the samusas which my friend claimed tasted like pizza rolls! I think he meant the dough, which I do have to agree with. The curry filling was slightly spicy and well-seasoned.

The entree was the curry chicken over egg noodles. Is it me, or does it taste like a watered down version of Thai yellow curry? I guess I'm used to curries being more in-your-face, so Yamo's was a little boring for me.

 I would go back to try out the other menu items that people have recommended, just because I still have faith that I can like Burmese cuisine. Got to try some other places out now for comparison!

excerpts: I had Samusas and Chicken Chow Mein.
The best part about the noodles is that you can taste the flames.
samusas.author: Krystha B.
samusas.review: I went again last night. I called in my order this time - I got there and they handed it to me within 2 minutes of walking in the door. Amazing. I heart this place. I want to move to the Mission just to be closer to it. I had Samusas and Chicken Chow Mein. The best part about the noodles is that you can taste the flames.

excerpts: Since I'm vegetarian, I only tried the samusas and curry tofu, both rocked!
samusas.author: Swetha G.
samusas.review:
I would give this place six stars if I could.

Unbelievable service and excellent quality of food.

I walked into Yamo three days ago to place a rather large order for a meeting we were having at my office.  Since I work at a non-profit and our food budget is limited, I'm not too flexible with how much we can spend, but I still have to find a way to feed everyone.  I wanted to order a couple entrees on the party platter menu but the total was something that I knew my organization did not have room to cover.  So then what?  Well first of all the staff rocks and went above and beyond to try to accomodate our hiccup.  Judy was awesome and did everything she could to get her boss Joseph (the owner) on the phone since he wasn't in at the time.  When we were able to get a hold of him, he was incredibly kind and really tried to work with me on the price.  In the end I was able to stay within budget and placed the food order.

Fast forward to two days later and all I can say is if you haven't been to Yamo, don't walk, run!  The food was such a hit at the meeting that a couple of us, including myself, couldn't restrain ourselves and got second and third servings.  If there weren't others around I probably would've kept going!  Since I'm vegetarian, I only tried the samusas and curry tofu, both rocked!  Others who had the pork chow mein, mango chicken, and beef curry only had raves to share.

This place is a little hole in the wall that is easy to overlook, but if you do happen to stop and go in, I guarantee, you will NOT be disappointed!

excerpts: Spring rolls, veggie samusas, tea leaf salad, mango salad, beef chow fun, chicken cold noodle, and then what ever your friends are having.
samusas.author: Inbal R.
samusas.review:
That woman is a machine!!   Okay. Let me lay it out.   Spring rolls, veggie samusas, tea leaf salad, mango salad, beef chow fun, chicken cold noodle, and then what ever your friends are having.

Everything is like three to five bucks and there is no tax. The place is a lil' scrappy but you can always take it to the park. Seriously, Yamo is the answer to everything...except fine dining.

excerpts: The samusas are great and piping hot.
samusas.author: Stephen H.
samusas.review:
This is one of those hole in the wall gems that one can only find through friends or nowadays, through yelp.  Nice homestyle food in a unique small (dare I say cramped) restaurant, that is more like a hallway than a room.  Seating is only at the counter, but no matter, the food is great.  The samusas are great and piping hot.  The Yamo house dishes are great.

If only parking wasn't such a pain this would be five stars.

excerpts: the samusas were fine, but i was expecting a bit more spice and not simply potato.
samusas.author: Jon W.
samusas.review:
i enjoyed my meal, but i dont think yamo quite lived up to the hype.

the house noodles with pork was just fine, but there wasnt much else in the bowl besides noodles and pork. the samusas were fine, but i was expecting a bit more spice and not simply potato.

overall, i added more hot sauce to this meal than i wanted. also, it was a bit strange to serve me the appetizer second, but at a food counter with 8 stools, i think this is perfectly forgivable.

ill definitely be back because this is enjoyable and right in my 'hood and because there are other menu items to try [tea leaf salad, mango chicken, cold noodles], but next time ill have to remember to bring my lowered expectations as well.

on the plus plus side, yamo has to be the cheapest non-mexican meal in the mission.

excerpts:
We had the black-bean fish, veggie stir-fry, samusas & Chicken with cold noodles. 
Warning: Samusas are not quite like Indian samosas which I prefer (good ones are hard to find), but they are ok here.
samusas.author: Rooibos T.
samusas.review:
What's not to love ?

Food - Awesome - Just the right level of spice. Esp good after a few beers. We had the black-bean fish, veggie stir-fry, samusas & Chicken with cold noodles. 
Total bill - $24

Warning: Samusas are not quite like Indian samosas which I prefer (good ones are hard to find), but they are ok here.

Space - 8 bar-stools - figure out seating for urself

Atmosphere - Choy (Burmese owner) yelling away orders a feet away from you. Great place to chat up a conversation with ur neighbors. You WILL be rubbing shoulders & elbows with em anyway. Choy is 
awesome !

excerpts: The samusas are pretty good too, although if you opt to dine in they should be allowed to cool before you dive into them (after a healthy slathering of sweet spicy sauce, of course).
Also if you eat in be prepared to leave smelling like the food because the stoves are barely five feet away from where you'll be seated.
Just a warning for those considering making this joint Date Place #3.
samusas.author: Raffy E.
samusas.review: I heart Yamo. It's a place you expect to find in the Mission: dingy and run-down but worth it because of the food. Eats are cheap on top of the deliciousness, as most of the main dishes are under $6.
