The curry chicken is just the right amount of hot (none of this half-assed yellow-curry-is-only-mildly-spicy crap) and the house noodles with pork is ridiculously tasty. The samusas are pretty good too, although if you opt to dine in they should be allowed to cool before you dive into them (after a healthy slathering of sweet spicy sauce, of course). Also if you eat in be prepared to leave smelling like the food because the stoves are barely five feet away from where you'll be seated. Just a warning for those considering making this joint Date Place #3.

excerpts: shared the samusas as an appetizer, they were ...meh.
samusas.author: eric f.
samusas.review:
yelp fans, good call on this one!

the chicken noodle soup is RIDICULOUSLY amazing.  shared the samusas as an appetizer, they were ...meh.

$5.25 though for most dishes.  the dishes arent huge but good portions so you arent forced to over eat.  most definitely a good value!!

the wait sucks, and getting a spot for more than 2 is being a little hopeful, we did manage to squeeze in 3 though.

forget eating at the counter and call-in! you can temporarily enjoy the chaos inside when you pick up.  i'm calling in and taking to-go next time...

overall good food and unique experience.

excerpts: we ordered the tea leaf salad, samusas, yamo house noodles with beef, and black bean fish.
I would recommend the tea leaf salad if you're interested in a surprisingly crunchy and spicy salad.
the samusas are cute crispy mini-versions of samosas with a plum-chili(?) dipping sauce.

Yamo house noodles with beef were the prize-winning dish with great flavor moist beef and crisp veggies.  

to top it all off the price was better than most places in the mission as noted in articles on their door.
samusas.author: Marina K.
samusas.review:
it was soooo thrilling finding Yamo-  it was one of those times when you almost walk past the place because its so obscure you would never think to peek inside - barely any sign that its the place you were looking for - staking your hopes on a satisfying meal to this little door with a light on a dark street - then you poke your head in and see that there's a person on every stool along the narrow 12 foot counter.  so this might have some promise after all.  you walk in and pick up the menu and decide to wait it out and see if it is worthwhile - and so it was.

we ordered the tea leaf salad, samusas, yamo house noodles with beef, and black bean fish.  I would recommend the tea leaf salad if you're interested in a surprisingly crunchy and spicy salad. the samusas are cute crispy mini-versions of samosas with a plum-chili(?) dipping sauce.  Yamo house noodles with beef were the prize-winning dish with great flavor moist beef and crisp veggies.  

to top it all off the price was better than most places in the mission as noted in articles on their door.  worth the adventure to find it & now i will definitely go back.

*********
makes me want to sing a little song to a reggae tune: 
"yamo get some yamo~
yamo be alright~" :)

excerpts: , we shared the samusas, tea leaf salad, and the house noodles w/ tofu.
they can make everything vegetarian.
we were able to order before sitting down, so once we sat down, our food came right away.
everything was delicious, and you can tell it was really made w/ love.
i would definitely come back for authentic home cooked burmese food.
samusas.author: Helen T.
samusas.review:
this is a hidden gem in the mission!!  we wandered in here around 830 pm, and the dining area is just the kitchen w/ some bar stools.  you feel like you're eating at someone's home as the chef, her daughter (i think) and another relative take your order, cook, and serve you a great meal.  there are only about 10 stools in the whole place, but it moves quickly.  

b/t the two of us, we shared the samusas, tea leaf salad, and the house noodles w/ tofu.  they can make everything vegetarian.  we were able to order before sitting down, so once we sat down, our food came right away.  everything was delicious, and you can tell it was really made w/ love.  i would definitely come back for authentic home cooked burmese food.

excerpts: I'd skip the samusas (greasy, tasted like they'd been frozen) and get the fresh salad rolls instead.
My most prideful moment of the evening: getting a smile out of the head chef
(yes, she is soup nazi-esque, but with a heart of gold).
If they are busy, they'll suggest you help yourself to chopsticks on a shelf behind the counter.
This was oddly endearing, and reminded me of being a kid at an older aunt's house where I was both excited for the food and a little scared of the ambiance, too.
It's comfort food at its best, and will leave some extra cash in your pocket for that over-priced cocktail at any of the hipster joints in the area.
Moral: be polite, wait your turn and enjoy!
samusas.author: Sofia P.
samusas.review: There aren't too many hole-in-the-wall spots in SF, so trying one is always exciting. The place is tiny: about 8 spots at the counter, so expect to wait. I mean, this is a prime spot for people-watching anyways, so don't complain too much. The tea leaf salad is amazing. Small portion if you're sharing, but really flavorful and delicious. I liked it better than Burma Superstar's version, and the prices at Yamo can't be beat. The house noodles with beef are really simple, and delicious. Portions aren't huge, but it's $6, so again: don't complain too much. I'd skip the samusas (greasy, tasted like they'd been frozen) and get the fresh salad rolls instead. My most prideful moment of the evening: getting a smile out of the head chef (yes, she is soup nazi-esque, but with a heart of gold). If they are busy, they'll suggest you help yourself to chopsticks on a shelf behind the counter. This was oddly endearing, and reminded me of being a kid at an older aunt's house where I was both excited for the food and a little scared of the ambiance, too. It's comfort food at its best, and will leave some extra cash in your pocket for that over-priced cocktail at any of the hipster joints in the area. Moral: be polite, wait your turn and enjoy!

excerpts: When that, plus the black bean fish, house noodles with chicken, samusas, fresh coconut juice, and a soda costs you just over $22, you end up wondering if you're still in the city.
Not the best tasting ever, but still fresh, very tasty and cheap.
Love it.
samusas.author: Maximillian M.
samusas.review: Probably one of the most awesome hole-in-the-wall joints in the entire city! The tea leaf salad is particularly awesome. When that, plus the black bean fish, house noodles with chicken, samusas, fresh coconut juice, and a soda costs you just over $22, you end up wondering if you're still in the city. Not the best tasting ever, but still fresh, very tasty and cheap. Love it.

excerpts: Their samusas were very small, the type you can find frozen at Ranch 99 or Pacific Super.
samusas.author: Jessica M.
samusas.review:
The Place:
I had a bit of trouble finding the place. When I first saw it, I thought the restaurant was condemned and closed for business. The entire place consisted of a room about half the size of a classroom with a bar in the middle. On one side there's eight seats (good luck number for Chinese people), and on the other side there are the elderly chefs. They don't spend any money on making the place fancy. I went on a Monday at around 5:00, and all the seats were filled (but like I said, there aren't many seats).

The Service:
I went for an early dinner so it wasn't crowded. One lady took my order, and she conversed with us in Burmese. Unfortunately speaking in Mandarin (no, it's NOT Cantonese) or Burmese does not get bigger portions or special treatment. Darn. The food was quick, though not much attention was paid towards the customers.

The Food:
I don't consider Yamo's food real Burmese food, but then again I don't think Burma Superstar's food is real Burmese food. Yamo's food is cheap and is geared towards an American audience. It's very cheap ($3.50 for appetizers and $5.25 for entrees), but the food is nothing special. Portions could be bigger. Their samusas were very small, the type you can find frozen at Ranch 99 or Pacific Super. The Yamo House Noodles (or garlic noodles, as I know them to be called) could have used more flavor. The presentation was lovely, but the taste was lacking. The mango chicken wasn't anything special either. It's on about the same level as Panda Express. I was a bit disappointed with the food and the limited selection, but I figure the chefs are friends from temple who decided to go into a little business together.

All in All:
I didn't have very high expectations, but Yamo was decent. It was cheap and pretty good for the price. I don't think it's anything special, but I'm rather biased since I've grown up eating Burmese food. I feel like the only reason the restaurant is popular is because it's cheap and it's different. If you don't know what real Burmese food is supposed to taste like, I think you'd like Yamo. It's not bad, but not authentic or flavorful enough for my taste.

excerpts: Also, samusas and a tea leaf salad are pretty good (along with their chicken noodle soup).
Okay, so I'm basically just listing a ton of stuff now.
Try it out for yourself - you'll see!
For $5.25 they can't be beat!
samusas.author: Kimberly D.
samusas.review:
One of my favorite restaurants in the city! Soo good, and sooo cheap! (Plus, being of the 33 bus line is a plus!)

I recommend the cold noodles for sure! Also, samusas and a tea leaf salad are pretty good (along with their chicken noodle soup). Okay, so I'm basically just listing a ton of stuff now. Try it out for yourself - you'll see! For $5.25 they can't be beat!

excerpts: I thought we were done, but ended up ordering some Samusas to go.
The sauce provided definitely had a kick to it!
We thought a yogurt based sauce might go nicer, but they were still quite good.
I'm definitely coming back here though!
samusas.author: Allan H.
samusas.review: The GF & I decided to stop by here for lunch based on the glowing reviews (and the fact that we were out in the Mission already).  We almost walked right by the place - it's a hole in the wall place, meant in the best way possible.  The awning of the place was barely legible but we could roughly make out Yamo on there.  We stepped inside and take a seat at the counter.  Almost everything on the menu (aside from drinks) is priced at $5.25 and $3.50 for appetizers.  One of the ladies behind the counter suggested the Yamo Cold Noodles, so I got that and the GF got the Yamo House Noodles.  We also got an order of the freshly made spring rolls.  I personally love places where you get to see what's going on in the kitchen and in this joint, you definitely have a front row seat.  The spring rolls were tasty, big & fresh!  The noodle dishes were very good too.  The taste of the Yamo House Noodles reminded me of noodles I would make at a Mongolian BBQ place.  My Yamo Cold Noodles had just enough spicy kick to keep you wanting more.  I thought we were done, but ended up ordering some Samusas to go.  The sauce provided definitely had a kick to it!  We thought a yogurt based sauce might go nicer, but they were still quite good.  I'm definitely coming back here though!

excerpts: Their tea salad is also pretty good too!
tea salad.author: Christopher L.
tea salad.review:
There is usually a line here because the only seating they have is a bar which fits around 10 people, so it's pretty small. Your best chances of getting something from Yamo is if you get take out or if you come off peak eating hours.

The reason I love this place is because the value is really good for what you can get. I usually get the Yamo House Noodles which comes with a choice of chicken, beef, pork and something else. The house noodles are prepared in a simple manner. It is noodles, fried garlic, green onions with your choice of meat and is fried together really quickly. When you sit down, they have a variety of sauces to spice up your dish.

They serve various other noodle and rice dishes. Their tea salad is also pretty good too! I'd say this place is a mix of Burmese and Chinese food.

Yeah the prices are really good too, with most dishes costing less than $7 and they have appetizers for $3 - 5! So cheap! I come here when I want something quick, cheap and good to eat.

I've been here a few times and it used to be better before! I think it's gotten slightly worse since they've grown in popularity, but is still a decent place.

excerpts: We asked for the tea salad, fish chowder noodle soup, and yamo house noodles.
tea salad.author: Justin C.
tea salad.review:
I was told that this place had good, cheap food, but the people working there didn't speak English. I came by with my friends twice but there was a wait so we decided to come back the next day at 2pm... there was still a wait. After ten or so mins, the ladies working asked us what we wanted (in English) and were pretty friendly. So we put in our orders while we were still waiting which is pretty efficient of them. We asked for the tea salad, fish chowder noodle soup, and yamo house noodles. Each dish was $6.50. 

The only dish that stood out to me was the tea leaf salad. It was very fragrant. It's hard to describe but had two types of crunchiness one from some fried beans and some from the cabbage. The salad was slightly sweet, incredibly spicy but not too bad. There was a slight herbaciousness and had smokey Jasmine flavors. I really enjoyed this dish so extra stars for that. The others... not so much. I thought the house noodles were a bit bland but my friend really liked them. I remember it being a little light on the protein. The fish chowder soup had a weird flavor that I didn't quite enjoy nor could I place what was off about it. It was topped with some kind of crispy crackers? There was no actual fish in this dish. I wouldn't order this again

In all a pretty enjoyable experience but I wouldn't want to wait more than 10 mins for it... It really depends on how fast the people eat because this place is TINY. Hardly any space between the barline counter and the wall to exit the restaurant.

excerpts: It's been a couple months since I first tried this place and decided to go today for some beef-noods and tea salad.
Sat at the counter with a friend waiting for our order.
I decided to snap a photo of my food and a nice big flame from the wok.
So, Asian auntie decided to yell at me...
"HEYYYY
WHAT ARE YOU DOING?!!!?!
I casually and calmly respond..
Taking a picture" she gives me a mean mug for a good 30secs.
The old me would've fed into her anger and yell back
but, nah.
I just kept eating as I thought it was amusing you would get so heated over a photo ‍. Payed the bill and as my friend
tea salad.author: Glyde W.
tea salad.review: It's been a couple months since I first tried this place and decided to go today for some beef-noods and tea salad. Sat at the counter with a friend waiting for our order. I decided to snap a photo of my food and a nice big flame from the wok. So, Asian auntie decided to yell at me... "HEYYYY WHAT ARE YOU DOING?!!!?!" I casually and calmly respond.. "Taking a picture" she gives me a mean mug for a good 30secs. The old me would've fed into her anger and yell back but, nah. I just kept eating as I thought it was amusing you would get so heated over a photo ‍. Payed the bill and as my friend and I get up from the counter to exit the premises. She mumbles in anger and in a good volume tells us GET OUT!!  Ok! Bye, Felecia!! I guess I got the full dining experience LOL.

excerpts: We ordered the tea salad, yamo house noodles with beef, and curry chicken.
I am giving Yamo 2 stars for the food.
The tea salad was covered with too much sauce, so couldn't really figure out what I was eating with all the sweetness.
And it was a pretty small portion for tea salad.
The house noodles were a bit too stuck together, but the beef was pretty tasty.
And the curry chicken was a bit too bland for my taste.
But it was extremely cost affordable.
It was only $6 per dish..
so think it averaged $19?
So if you want a cost affordable meal, come here.
But if you want some good Burmese food, then I suggest going elsewhere.
Overall, a one time meal and will be getting my Burmese food elsewhere next time.
tea salad.author: Jackie C.
tea salad.review:
My friend and I were trying to find a cost-affordable take-out spot for our small group, and since Yamo was nearly, dropped by here. The seating area is small, so I would suggest take-out if you're a larger group. We were just coming to pick up food. We placed our order over the phone, and the lady was pretty abrupt with all our orders. Entering in, we saw that it was basically a two person show for taking orders and cooking, so can understand the abruptness especially during a busy dinner time.

We ordered the tea salad, yamo house noodles with beef, and curry chicken. I am giving Yamo 2 stars for the food. The tea salad was covered with too much sauce, so couldn't really figure out what I was eating with all the sweetness. And it was a pretty small portion for tea salad. The house noodles were a bit too stuck together, but the beef was pretty tasty. And the curry chicken was a bit too bland for my taste. But it was extremely cost affordable. It was only $6 per dish..so think it averaged $19? So if you want a cost affordable meal, come here. But if you want some good Burmese food, then I suggest going elsewhere. Overall, a one time meal and will be getting my Burmese food elsewhere next time.

excerpts: Best tea salad in San Francisco.
The other dishes are OK.
The cooks are priceless!
tea salad.author: Jamie T.
tea salad.review: Best tea salad in San Francisco.  The other dishes are OK.  The cooks are priceless!

excerpts: The tea salad is something I've never tried before, with crunchy pieces of what I believe were garlic cloves and shredded veggies.
The papaya salad is more standard but still very good.
tea salad.author: Urmila J.
tea salad.review:
Can't believe it took me 3 years in SF to try this. Yes, waiting to get a bar seat isn't so fun but dang those two ladies cook fast. I have never been happier to get yelled at to grab a seat. 

The tea salad is something I've never tried before, with crunchy pieces of what I believe were garlic cloves and shredded veggies. The papaya salad is more standard but still very good. We also ordered curry fish, which was not as flavorful to me, but the texture was soft and creamy. My friends seemed to really enjoy their red meat dishes.

All in all I hope to return ASAP. If you're in a rush, take out is quick!

excerpts: The potstickers were nothing to write home about, but the tea salad was excellent.
tea salad.author: Rachel G.
tea salad.review:
Tiny hole-in-the-wall delightful place (if you like holes in the wall) where I went for lunch on my last day in SF, because I am obsessed with tea leaf salad (laphet thoke), thanks to Burma Superstar. The potstickers were nothing to write home about, but the tea salad was excellent. The women next to me (who were Burmese-American) all ordered the chicken noodle soup and it looked and smelled delicious; they seemed to be really enjoying it. 

Next time I'd get the salad and soup. Always the salad!

excerpts: tea salad)
- CHEAP food
(everything was $6.75....
And tea salad was tasty with a kick to it.
tea salad.author: Raquel Y.
tea salad.review:
PROS: 
- good food (got the house special with pork, fish chowder noodle soup, and tea salad) 
- CHEAP food (everything was $6.75....WTF) 
- authentic 

CONS:
- rude Asian lady (but I'm sure she doesn't mean to be rude. That's just their culture)
- cash only 

The space is extremely small that can probably only seat like 11 people. I didn't know if it was a pro or con, because pro it gives it the Asian atmosphere of small hole-in-the-wall authentic restaurant, and con because well, it's tiny af. Hence, a wait. 

All the food was good and cheap though. I definitely liked how unique the fish chowder noodle soup was, never tasted anything like it. The house special noodles with pork tasted like typical garlic chow mein noodles, though the pork was bomb. And tea salad was tasty with a kick to it. 

If there's a long wait, probably best to get to go. And don't get offended if the Asian lady yells at you! That's just how she normally talks lol.

excerpts: The best dishes (4-star for me) are the yamo house special (delicious beef and chicken) and the tea salad (soo flavorful).
The fish chowder is weird--no real fish, lots of corn, and not very creamy or flavorful.
Cold noodle is not that spicy.
tea salad.author: Lydia Z.
tea salad.review:
Average fast-chinese food, great pricing (cash only), small venue (8 seats only), angry burmese grandmas(cooking with fire~).

Noodle-topping ratio is high unfortunately but noodles are very QQ and thicc. The best dishes (4-star for me) are the yamo house special (delicious beef and chicken) and the tea salad (soo flavorful). The fish chowder is weird--no real fish, lots of corn, and not very creamy or flavorful. Cold noodle is not that spicy. I'm afraid of trying their other dishes since they either "run out" or it just sounds like store-bought/microwavable options. 

Also, you gotta think on your toes, grab your order and run, don't be confused or else they'll yell at you.

excerpts: The black bean fish with noodles and a tea salad are hard to beat!
It is a very casual space and the women who work here make it a very homey atmosphere in a way where people are so comfortable with each other that they don't need to be polite.

If you bring outside beverages, sit too long (there's only a few bar stools and always a line of people waiting to sit), or do something else that isn't Yamo approved, then you will get yelled at to correct your behavior!
I personally love it and think they're doing a great job.
I always eat in vs getting take out to enjoy the experience.
The prices can't be beat for a big plate of tasty food.
tea salad.author: Annelise P.
tea salad.review: Love this spot, it is a go to quick meal in my neighborhood that never disappoints. The black bean fish with noodles and a tea salad are hard to beat! It is a very casual space and the women who work here make it a very homey atmosphere in a way where people are so comfortable with each other that they don't need to be polite. If you bring outside beverages, sit too long (there's only a few bar stools and always a line of people waiting to sit), or do something else that isn't Yamo approved, then you will get yelled at to correct your behavior! I personally love it and think they're doing a great job. I always eat in vs getting take out to enjoy the experience. The prices can't be beat for a big plate of tasty food.

excerpts: I started with the tea salad, and I was so surprised by the great flavors.
It's seriously one of the best tea salads I've had in the city.
I also ordered the house noodles with beef.
The big bowl of steaming noodles is carb heaven, but don't expect anything more than a kick of garlic in terms of flavor.
tea salad.author: Regina L.
tea salad.review:
I randomly stumbled upon Yamo one evening as I was looking for a quick bite in the area. Yamo is probably one of the few dive restaurants left in the city, and the experience does not disappoint. There are probably only 8 seats along a bar facing the "kitchen". It's seriously a hole in the wall. A few women are working behind the counter, and if you don't order when they come by, expect to wait another 5-10 minutes. Thankfully, I already knew what I wanted to order having stared at the menu during my 10 minutes in line. I started with the tea salad, and I was so surprised by the great flavors. It's seriously one of the best tea salads I've had in the city. I also ordered the house noodles with beef. The big bowl of steaming noodles is carb heaven, but don't expect anything more than a kick of garlic in terms of flavor. The dish is simple but satisfying. 

The restaurant is certainly not the cleanest, and the staff is definitely not the friendliest, but the price really can't be beat. It's a great spot for a quick meal or takeout. I will definitely come back to try other items on the menu.

excerpts: Tea Salad (2/5) - Burmese style salad mixed with fermented tea leaves.
Salad comes premixed.
The salad was more spicy and lemony than a typical Burmese tea salad, and peanuts were roasted/fried, but no longer crunchy.
tea salad.author: Janice K.
tea salad.review:
Chinese mom meets Seinfield's soup nazi. If you don't understand my Seinfield reference, go youtube this now. I assure you, it's hilarious. 

The Yamo experience is a mix of PTSD of every confusing childhood memory of being scolded combined with the pleasant memory of home cooked meals prepared by your Chinese mom. 

The food ranged from good to great (review below), but the experience of eating at Yamo was absolutely terrifying with a squeeze of comical. Upon entering the restaurant you'll be greeted by a very angry mama cook who seemly appears to yell at everyone: her daughter, the other mama cook and all patrons. Service is quick - you enter, you order your food while you wait to be seated - you get seated, and immediately the dishes you previously ordered are flung at you.  Yes, dishes are airborne for a few seconds before clattering loudly in front of you - maybe safe to have a napkin ready for the splash zone. 

Oh did you want to take a photo of your food? You better take it ninja style or ask permission to take "food photos only" because mama cook will scream at you from across the restaurant " NO PHOTOS". 

Did you want to enjoy your food over good conversation? Hopefully you've mastered the art of talking and inhaling food at the same time, otherwise, you'll get the stare down from mama cook if your chopsticks aren't forking food into your mouth while you're swallowing forcefully. Take a tip and skip the chewing because your bill will arrive in front of you shortly. After you pay - and remember cash only - you're thanked very loudly, but if you listen between the lines, mama cook's real thoughts are GTFO because you're holding up her business. 

We ate (each dish ~$6.25 pre tax): 

1. Tea Salad (2/5) - Burmese style salad mixed with fermented tea leaves. Salad comes premixed.The salad was more spicy and lemony than a typical Burmese tea salad, and peanuts were roasted/fried, but no longer crunchy. It was clear the salad was pre made and sitting in the fridge ready to be served. 

2. Mango Chicken (4/5) - Stir fried vegetables with mango and chicken, served with a bed of white rice. The "wok hei" or in english, "the breath of the wok"  was real- this dish had a complex smoky flavor that is only achieved by cooking fresh ingredients over extreme heat. The flavors of the chicken coated in sauce were deep, and the bell peppers and mango retained the textural crunch. Would have liked more than 3 pieces of chicken. 

3. Black Bean Fish (4/5) - Stir fried vegetables with black bean white fish, served with a bed of white rice. As above, the wok hei flavor was legit. Flavors were on deep and smokey. Texture was crunchy and crispy. Fish portion was could be larger. 

4. Yamo House Noodles (3/5) noodles mixed with garlic and a choice of beef, chicken or pork - ours was beef. Noodles were cooked almost al dante and heavily coated in oil, mixed with garlic and topped with a pinch of extremely salty beef crumbles. 

Overall: 

Food - 3.5/5 - Food here definitely has potential. On one hand the wok hei flavor is on point, on the other, portion sizes of protein is minimal and often too salty. Prices are cheap, which makes the value for food was a good bang for the buck in SF. 

Service 1/5- From my notes above, the experience at Yamo was conflicting. I was terrified from the moment I walked in, but also couldn't help uncontrollably laugh at the situation. There were some frequenters who came for take out and you can tell they've experienced the PTSD themselves and have learned better to just get take out. One after one, they'll come in and skip the banter, and just say the numbers of the dishes they wanted to order. Put down the money and with a slight bow retreat backwards out the door where they waited patiently until their meal was prepared. Pro tip: if you want to experience yamo without the PTSD, just come for take out. 

Environment 1/5- This rating is likely skewed from the notes above - but hard to enjoy a meal when you're feeling afraid. Minimal seating ~ 10, expect to wait 30+ mins if you come during regular meal hours. Definitely come on a pre laundry day because you'll walk out smelling like Yamo. 

Eat take out from here.

excerpts: The tea salad, while tasty, was small-- about the size of a fist.
Toppings for the house noodles were stingy.
It had a few pieces of beef, green onions, and nothing more.
The noodles were bland, but I did enjoy the taste of the beef, even if it was a little dry.
The chicken curry was probably my favorite dish of the night.
tea salad.author: Amy C.
tea salad.review:
Come for a meal if price is what matters most to you, because there will be trade offs in the quality and service. The dishes here are cheap, but remember that you always get what you pay for. 

The tea salad, while tasty, was small-- about the size of a fist. Toppings for the house noodles were stingy. It had a few pieces of beef, green onions, and nothing more. The noodles were bland, but I did enjoy the taste of the beef, even if it was a little dry. The chicken curry was probably my favorite dish of the night. I liked the sauce, but the dish would've been more aptly named "potato curry" because it was 80% potatoes, 10% chicken, and 10% everything else.

The service and cleanliness of the restaurant is the main reason why I won't be coming back. I was disappointed to see the lady behind the counter grabbing the cooked noodles with her bare hands-- the same hands that take cash from customers and clean up the dishes. Additionally, she throughout the entire meal, she kept on muttering "No talking, just eat" while I was trying to catch up with my friend. The restaurant is a bit too warm and cramped for comfort, but that aspect adds to the hole-in-the-wall experience.

excerpts: recently i came over to the city and carved out a special date with my go to tea salad and house noodle with beef.
these items were the dopest and made the hella mean asian lady (i'm asian.
don't get this twisted) tolerable.
WHY DOES THE TEA SALAD
ALWAYS GET TO ME
AFTER MY NOODLES??
tea salad.author: S S.
tea salad.review:
i used to hit up yamo at least twice a month when i lived in the city. LOVED this place. but now i live in oakland and don't get to go often. recently i came over to the city and carved out a special date with my go to tea salad and house noodle with beef. these items were the dopest and made the hella mean asian lady (i'm asian. don't get this twisted) tolerable. greasy kitchen like my mama's. 

but daaaang. meat portion and quality going down, flavor watering out, and WHY DOES THE TEA SALAD ALWAYS GET TO ME AFTER MY NOODLES?? you feel me, lady?! 

anyway. it's a popular local jaunt that has a cult following... but for me... RIP yamo.

excerpts: I've had the Tea Salad before and thought it was really good and different.
Today I decided to try other things.
First they opened 50 minutes late today.
tea salad.author: Mark T.
tea salad.review:
I pass this place every time I go to DP. I've had the Tea Salad before and thought it was really good and different. Today I decided to try other things. First they opened 50 minutes late today. Such is a small mom and pop place. 

I tried the Hot Ramen with Pork. I watched how everything was made. I noticed the noodles were heated very quickly and put in the to go container. It sat for 10 minutes while the rest was cooked. Thought that was weird. Tasted good but not close to warm when I ate it. 

I also had the egg rolls. A favorite everywhere I go I thought "let's see what they do". I watched as they took four egg rolls that were frozen and placed them in the deep fryer. Now I can't imagine why they would freeze their eggs roils. Of course they didn't make them as they were exactly like the next one. I'm very disappointed because I wanted to see something new, not something old. 

Pluses:

Tea a salad is really good
Noodles were tasty but cold, better eaten at the counter. 

Minuses:

Egg rolls were bought not made. 
They need a better way to keep food warm.

excerpts: We got the house noodles, chicken noodle soup, and tea salad.
Not as big or flashy as the other burmese titans in SF but just as good if not better.
Super fresh and flavorful noodles, soup, and meat.
The tea salad is somewhat small but still very good and something I'd totally get again.
tea salad.author: Charles M.
tea salad.review:
Definitely super late to the punch but I'll chalk up growing up in LA as defense for coming to Yamo so late. I need this bastion of cooking way more than it needs me. It's literally listed on Google Maps as cheap eats and I feel like that doesn't betray how good it actually is.

Small and intimate, it is a restaurant that focuses solely on the thing that ultimately matters: food and your love for it. There are no TVs to watch or live entertainment, rather just the display of aptitude and skill by the people who cook here and remind me of my iron chef grandmother. 

The food is at one time incredibly complex and simple. To them its just another day and the techniques they've mastered but to me it'd something easily screwed up. 
We got the house noodles, chicken noodle soup, and tea salad. Not as big or flashy as the other burmese titans in SF but just as good if not better. Super fresh and flavorful noodles, soup, and meat. The tea salad is somewhat small but still very good and something I'd totally get again.

We came on a Sunday at 3-4 and it was empty. Such a bittersweet joy that we made it in without a wait but that so many people were missing out.

excerpts: I always get chicken soup and tea salad .
Is small and crowded but I like it because has personality.
The food is authentic, and cheap.
Cash only but who care.
I love when the lady ask me: what do you want?!
tea salad.author: Érica T.
tea salad.review:
I always get chicken soup and tea salad .
Is small and crowded but I like it because has personality. The food is authentic, and cheap. Cash only but who care. 
I love when the lady ask me: what do you want?!

excerpts: Tea salad still rocked.
The service is still wacky.
And the price is still $6.25.
tea salad.author: Scott F.
tea salad.review: Well I tried the vegetable curry today & it is terrible here. The first dish I really don't like.  Tea salad still rocked. The service is still wacky. And the price is still $6.25.

excerpts: My go-to choice is delicious house noodle with pork and tea salad.
Happy customer everytime
I come out.
tea salad.author: Nadia S.
tea salad.review: Never fail.  My go-to choice is delicious house noodle with pork and tea salad.  Happy customer everytime I come out.

excerpts: I ordered a tea leaf salad and my friend ordered a mango chicken, but I was hungry enough that we ended up ordering a second mango chicken and splitting our tea salad.
The total came out to about $18, and we even had a bit left over.
The tea leaf salad was a smaller amount, but a good price for the ingredients - fragnant and nutty.
The mango chicken was tart, but smothered over rice, it felt like California comfort food.
tea salad.author: Heidi L.
tea salad.review:
I ordered a tea leaf salad and my friend ordered a mango chicken, but I was hungry enough that we ended up ordering a second mango chicken and splitting our tea salad. The total came out to about $18, and we even had a bit left over.
 
The tea leaf salad was a smaller amount, but a good price for the ingredients - fragnant and nutty. The mango chicken was tart, but smothered over rice, it felt like California comfort food.

excerpts: The tea salad was so heavily drenched in dressing, and the flavor was like some cheap sweet and sour sauce from Safeway.
tea salad.author: Jessica C.
tea salad.review:
This place could not be worse. The lady who does the cooking / greeting is EXTREMELY rude; it's unreal. Something straight out of kitchen nightmares.

And it's not one of those places where the food makes up for it in any way. The tea salad was so heavily drenched in dressing, and the flavor was like some cheap sweet and sour sauce from Safeway. The mixed vegetables and stir fried noodles were almost as bad, and VERY oily.

I live for places like this - the holes in the wall that have been around forever, and are known for their authenticity. But I recommend staying away from this place at all costs!

excerpts: We grabbed the following to share for dinner: vegetarian spring rolls (4.50), vegetarian samusas (4.50), tea salad (6.25), and house noodles (6.25).
Everything was made in about 10 minutes and for under $25 for a solid dinner in the Mission that ain't too bad.
The dishes aren't huge, but for the price I think they are perfect.
Everything was super flavorful without being greasy or heavy like a lot noodles are at times.
Totally a place I'll be back to and make sure to grab a seat at the counter next time!
tea salad.author: Kelsey B.
tea salad.review:
New favorite take out spot in the Mission that won't break the bank!
Found Yamo while my fiance and I were out drinking in the Mission and wanted some delicious food to soak it all up.  Yamo had some vegetarian/vegan options so we decided to do some take out to share.  Walking up, this place is smalllll, a total hole in the wall with maybe 8 seats at the counter and always a line out the door (a good sign).  The menu is printed outside and the ladies workin here are quick to get your order and greet you with a smile. I like that you can watch what is goin on while you're food is being made and its a little entertaining while you wait. 
We grabbed the following to share for dinner: vegetarian spring rolls (4.50), vegetarian samusas (4.50), tea salad (6.25), and house noodles (6.25). Everything was made in about 10 minutes and for under $25 for a solid dinner in the Mission that ain't too bad. The dishes aren't huge, but for the price I think they are perfect. Everything was super flavorful without being greasy or heavy like a lot noodles are at times. Totally a place I'll be back to and make sure to grab a seat at the counter next time!

excerpts: We had noodles and tea salad, and it made for a fantastic lunch.
Not the fanciest but Quick and Easy.
tea salad.author: Sara M.
tea salad.review: Great for takeout.  Blink and you'll miss it, but it is worth your time.  We had noodles and tea salad, and it made for a fantastic lunch.  Not the fanciest but Quick and Easy.

excerpts: like the tea salad is tasty and a great value, but to me the rest of the menu seems like a mix of Chinese style dishes.
tea salad.author: Leslie W.
tea salad.review:
I live in the neighborhood and a regular here. Yamo's is a bit polarizing with 1 star and 5 star reviews and I agree with both sides. But I think expectations should be set before coming here. 

1. If you're easily offended by rude service, this is not the place for you. The ladies are plain rude. I see some people refer to them as "sassy" and I think that's the absolute nicest way to put it. It's somewhat endearing in a way you uncomfortably laugh at racist jokes at a comedy show but to be frank, they are just rude. I don't even understand Cantonese and I know they were trash talking the customers. Don't expect small talk or really any conversation, if you get your food without them throwing it in your face, you're good. 

2. So cheap. My go to is mango chicken and it's $6.50 cash only (includes tax). 

3. Cuisine is mostly chinese. I see some Burmese items on the menu.. like the tea salad is tasty and a great value, but to me the rest of the menu seems like a mix of Chinese style dishes. 

4. It's a hole in the wall with 8 or so bar stools. First come, first serve. Can get smoky inside, space is small and woks usage is abundant. 

There really is no other restaurant like this in this neighborhood, especially in this price range. They are small business owners putting out good food at a good price and I respect that. The rudeness is not an issue for me whatsoever. Take out is also extremely popular and what we typically do now. Food comes out in under 10 minutes.

excerpts: Tea Salad are made with tea leave, cabbage, fresh tomato, onion, dried shrimp & variety of fried bean, nuts and sesame seeds.
- Super small dish but love the flavors.
It was really good
but I think way too much onions.
If you want more for the money, the other two salads are bigger in portion.
tea salad.author: Sandy B.
tea salad.review:
So glad I finally got to try this place. Small, definitely your "HOLE IN THE WALL", about 10 seats at the counter. As I was dining, I notice they mostly do take outs. FYI, if you expect good services, don't come here. Don't complain, they really don't care. I didn't think services is awful, well at least not to me. She smile once at me. They do charge you for everything when it's to go. Don't expect anything free here and it's CASH ONLY.  I wish I lived close by, it would be my go to restaurant. 

Food is YUMMY and you can't beat the price. Smaller portions but who needs super big ones anyways. Better for the waist. haha And you can try more things. I prefer more varieties anyways. "ASIA" style and I love it. 

**Potstickers are filled with pork, cabbage, and carrots. My friend was so amaze by them. Very soft and juicy on the inside. Not crispy, just a little to add in some texture. 
** Tea Salad are made with tea leave, cabbage, fresh tomato, onion, dried shrimp & variety of fried bean, nuts and sesame seeds. - Super small dish but love the flavors. It was really good but I think way too much onions. If you want more for the money, the other two salads are bigger in portion. 
** Yamo House Noodles made with noodles mixed with fried garlic, and a choice of meat. I got the BEEF. My favorite dish. It's like garlic noodles topped with beef for a good price. So YUMMY! I can eat that everyday. 
**Yamo Cold Noodles made with cold noodles mixed with house special flavor, onions, cabbage, cucumbers, and chicken. - FYI its not really cold noodle. Because they stir fry the chicken and veggies and place it on top of the noodles. Therefore making the noodles warm. I know but its so good. The sauce they use is amazing. And I notice lots of people do order that for take out.

I'm coming back for sure and try everything else. Everything I had was DELICIOUS! Drinks are like self serve, bottles and cans. $1.50 each. There can be a wait but not too bad because mostly everyone orders take out. It's hot inside and I went yesterday when it was 85 degrees at 730pm. I sat by the door but still hot. Can't wait to come back.

excerpts: My go to order is the house noodles with pork (chewy bouncy noodles, crispy roasted garlic, fresh generous cilantro), a tea salad (watch that spice), and a grass jelly drink to wash down the dryness of the food.
tea salad.author: Jenni H.
tea salad.review:
You know how certain establishments have developed certain themes? Hipster, luxurious, casual, romantic, etc. Yamo has fully embraced the theme of Rage. 

This thematic rage centers around the owner, who is an angry asian lady with a perma-furrow between her eyebrows and a sharp berating voice. You can quickly separate the crowd dining in: those who did not grow up in an asian household with looks of terrified confusion on their faces and those who don't bat an eye because they were raised by a doppleganger in the form of an angry tiger mother. 

Despite the dinginess of the cramped space and the uninterrupted din of an angry asian lady taking orders over the phone ("WHAT DO YOU WANT?!"), the food is a bang for the buck. Delicious noodles at ridiculously cheap prices. My go to order is the house noodles with pork (chewy bouncy noodles, crispy roasted garlic, fresh generous cilantro), a tea salad (watch that spice), and a grass jelly drink to wash down the dryness of the food. 

Make sure you stop at an ATM on the way - cash only. 

And 10 points if you can catch a rare chuckle or smile from Lady Rage herself before she remembers she's fury incarnate and puts her mask of anger back on.

excerpts: I'm a little disappointed that we didn't order the tea salad because that's what they're known for, but one of us had a peanut allergy.
tea salad.author: Nina H.
tea salad.review:
I am so glad we were able to grab takeout from this place. Like all the other reviews, Yamo is a hole in the wall joint with only about 6-7 seats at the bar? It's best to grab takeout if you don't want to wait in line.

I was in a group of 8, and we basically ordered almost one of everything on the menu since we were sharing family style. My favorites were the beef noodles, mango salad, and the stir fried vegetables. I'm a little disappointed that we didn't order the tea salad because that's what they're known for, but one of us had a peanut allergy.

Nevertheless, this place is a no-nonsense hustlin' bustlin' restaurant with really good and affordable food! The dishes are pretty basic, but they are tasty and worth checking out.

excerpts: Tea salad was good, noodles were tasty but very simple.
Mango chicken was a little weird.
For $6 a plate you can't really expect more, you get what you pay for and this place is mediocre.
tea salad.author: Jenna C.
tea salad.review: Place is super small and dingy hole in the wall.  Ladies working are not nice.  The food is ok.  Tea salad was good, noodles were tasty but very simple. Mango chicken was a little weird.  For $6 a plate you can't really expect more, you get what you pay for and this place is mediocre.

excerpts: Not like a true Burmese Tea Salad though, but not bad.
tea salad.author: L V.
tea salad.review:
I would come here to eat just to be in the company of the 2 most tough, "don't give a crap" genuine ladies working behind the counter, they were so hilarious and humorous. They definitely gave me their "tough love" attitude, and I respect that and them for what they do and all the folks they have deal with, its just their demeanor to this hole in the wall joint. Part of the authentic, no nonsense experience. 

House Noodles with chicken - good chewy noodles with tasty flavor and sauce, the chicken is white meat. 

Tea Leaf Salad - a bit too over dressed but the fried beans and nuts were good. Not like a true Burmese Tea Salad though, but not bad. 

   Can't beat the price, I'd come here often if I was close by. Their cold noodle salad also looks good. 

So don't be sensitive or thrown by the demeanor, it is what it is!

Thanks ladies of Yamo!

excerpts: However, the tea salad was $6.5, tiny, and did not have enough cabbage.
Everything was good, not amazing, and on the salty side.
The cold noodles were good, $6.5, spicy, oily.
The house noodles were good, oily, also $6.5.
Not really a lot to be said about their flavors except "it's not bad.
tea salad.author: Maggie G.
tea salad.review:
Food: upper 3.5 stars
Service: 2 stars

I'm not turned off by the lack of enthusiasm in service, but I think the lady was borderline offensive and I believe it's really a mutual relationship when we go to a restaurant, pay them, and get the food we want. The way she yelled "NO PICTURES OK" to my mom, idk.. why don't you post up a sign for no pictures then? 

On top of that, I don't think the food is great. I'm not comparing it to any other Burmese place, because I realize the take is a little different; more like a street vendor kind of food. However, the tea salad was $6.5, tiny, and did not have enough cabbage. Everything was good, not amazing, and on the salty side. The cold noodles were good, $6.5, spicy, oily. The house noodles were good, oily, also $6.5. Not really a lot to be said about their flavors except "it's not bad." The samusas were delicious though, at $4.25, potatoes had a great texture and flavor.

Anyway, I probably won't be back here unless it's a cold day and I want to try their chicken noodle soup, which looked really good. All their food would be awesome with beer but no alcoholic beverages are allowed in there.

excerpts: The tea salad and house noodles are definitely
a must try!
Seating is limited, so be prepared to wait, but take out is also available.
tea salad.author: Brody M.
tea salad.review: If you're interested in great food without the frills, then look no further. Yamo is great for quick Burmese food in the City. The tea salad and house noodles are definitely a must try! Seating is limited, so be prepared to wait, but take out is also available.

excerpts: Got a tea salad and their house noodles, each $6.25.
Tea salad turned out to be VERY small serving, probably a cup total, if that.
Would take two servings to have a meal, and for about $8-9 I'd have twice this amount at a place with much higher overhead, very surprising they serve so little.
As for taste, I'd say it was alright though much heavier on the sauce than it needs, and was gone in about 10 chopstick loads.
Much better places in town for this dish which is delicious when done well.
tea salad.author: T J.
tea salad.review:
Stepping in, it reminded me of many places in Southeast Asia. A cacophony of ingredients, cooking utensils, grease and darkness. Tight counters, and very disinterested and basic service. 

We were ignored for a while, though they had nobody else to serve and were just clearing plates. Finally asked our order and nothing in response. Watched the old lady a while and she appeared to be making our food, yeah! Got a tea salad and their house noodles, each $6.25.

Tea salad turned out to be VERY small serving, probably a cup total, if that. Would take two servings to have a meal, and for about $8-9 I'd have twice this amount at a place with much higher overhead, very surprising they serve so little. As for taste, I'd say it was alright though much heavier on the sauce than it needs, and was gone in about 10 chopstick loads. Much better places in town for this dish which is delicious when done well. They make other salads which are apparently 2-1/2 times the size for the same price which made no sense...

Also we had their house noodles. Good taste, a little more generous with the serving size, and my coworker said he'd return for it. At $6.25 this was probably a good deal. 

All-in-all it's not really a gem in the rough as I had been led to believe on Yelp. It's okay, probably worth at least one visit for nostalgia sake if you've done some down and dirty traveling. But I'd only return if I was nearby and really starving for something other than burritos or yuppie fare.

excerpts: The tea salad was below average, not worth getting.
tea salad.author: Rohenne L.
tea salad.review:
House noodles with beef. That is all you need to get! Other stuff is just okay. The house noodles are the best.

It's a hole in the wall place with really bad service, not the cleanest place but if you want a fast comfort meal this is the place! (Although there's so much fried garlic in the noodles you will taste and smell like garlic for a whole day)

The potstickers are not well done, definitely prefer Japanese gyozas. The tea salad was below average, not worth getting.

Don't expect anything from their service, the people are quite mean but no one cares, there's always people lining up out the door and people ordering for take out.

excerpts: We started with the Burmese samosas and the Tea Salad.
In all honesty, the wifey makes a better samosa but the tea salad was fantastic.
Great textures and crunch!
tea salad.author: Nadeem A.
tea salad.review:
I love me a good hole-in-the-wall establishment and sadly, working in the Financial District, I don't get to go to them nearly as often as I'd like. So, I was totally looking forward to my lunch at Yamo. Heck, we even got there right as they opened because I'd read the place only seated 8 at a counter.

Luckily, we were the first people there at 11:30am and found a seat with no problem. But hot damn, I wish I'd brought a paper fan because it s HOT in there. I was sweating from the warm day, my proximity to the kitchen, and blazing stove. We threw caution to the wind and just ordered everything that looked good.

We started with the Burmese samosas and the Tea Salad. In all honesty, the wifey makes a better samosa but the tea salad was fantastic. Great textures and crunch! The portion was a bit small but for being under $6, it was great

We then went with the famed Mango Chicken and the House Noodles with Beef. Both were kinda meh. The Mango Chicken tasted like Panda Express type "Chinese" food and the noodles in the House Noodles were way overcooked. The beef was good but after dousing food in soy and sriracha, anything tastes good.

The place definitely has a Soup Nazi vibe, and it's probably worth going to at least once, but the food is not worth a repeat visit.

excerpts: I ordered the tea salad and cold noodles.
Tea Salad - not sure where the tea part comes to play in this salad
but it is delicious!
Also spicy!
I'm not the best at spicy food
but I will definitely be ordering this again!
Cold Noodles - not what I was expecting.
The sauce is thicker so its not as refreshing as I had hoped
but it was still good!
tea salad.author: Renee W.
tea salad.review:
This place is the most "hole-in-the-wall" place I have been to and I'm sure I will be coming back quite often.

This place has 10 chairs max so if you come at a busy time, you may have to wait. The wait shouldn't be long, 15-20 min should get you a seat. Don't come here with a group of people, may be 2 or 3 max, because chances are you won't be able to sit together.

I ordered the tea salad and cold noodles.
Tea Salad - not sure where the tea part comes to play in this salad but it is delicious! Also spicy! I'm not the best at spicy food but I will definitely be ordering this again!
Cold Noodles - not what I was expecting. The sauce is thicker so its not as refreshing as I had hoped but it was still good! This was spicier than the salad so keep that in mind if you're not a spicy food type of person. 

Overall, this place is a good spot for a quick lunch lunch for one or two people.

excerpts: Tea Salad.
House Noodles with Chicken.
tea salad.author: Nikki M.
tea salad.review:
Tea Salad. House Noodles with Chicken. Samusas. $17. Yum.

We got take out since they have something like 8 stools and a line out the door. There are just 3 staff members working mighty hard so there can be a bit of a wait, but dang. Why did we wait so long to finally try what is both delicious and refreshingly affordable especially in comparison to other neighborhood haunts (see: artisanal chocolate/cheese/coffee/mustaches around the corner).

excerpts: For $6.25, the tea salad's portion was so small... not worth it.
tea salad.author: Tina S.
tea salad.review:
So disappointed.
For $6.25, the tea salad's portion was so small... not worth it. 

At least the samusas were good though. For $4.50, that's not bad.

The service was terrible. Communication was so unclear....

excerpts: My tea salad was good, but very small portion of just cabbage ($6.50), but the house noodle came with very little meat and the portion was also small ($6.50), but the problem is the sauce was so greasy and SALTY!!!
I asked if I could have some shredded cabbage to balance out the saltiness, she said "NO!"
- then I offered to pay for the cabbage, she just shook her head..
I was just laughing away..
tea salad.author: Tom V.
tea salad.review:
I like hole-in-the-wall restaurants, you get mom and pop's cooking and with good value.  I usually don't expect much of the service and ambience from places like this but I never seen bad treatment from the owner like this before (the owner was rude to everyone, not just me).   I happened to be near the area, decided to come in here because of 4 star review and decent pictures.    I sat down the counter and started to order, the owner face was frown and looks angry.  She took my order fine, then when I order the drink, she just told me to go get it myself.  At this point, I was still ok.  My tea salad was good, but very small portion of just cabbage ($6.50), but the house noodle came with very little meat and the portion was also small ($6.50), but the problem is the sauce was so greasy and SALTY!!! I asked if I could have some shredded cabbage to balance out the saltiness, she said "NO!" - then I offered to pay for the cabbage, she just shook her head..  I was just laughing away..    Next to my seat there was couple and after they paid, the owner was pushing their tea cups away to tell to pick it up!  That was just nut!  Looks like she just had a bad day, but please don't take it out on the customers!  I'm all supportive of small businesses but this lady should treat people nicer.  About the price, it seems like cheap, but you need to order a couple dishes - so it's better to go to a Vietnamese, Chinese or Mexican restaurant to get a decent size of food for about the same price.

Check out other 1 star reviews and you will see... This is beyond "don't expect 5 star treatment"...

excerpts: Their Tea salad is great.
Definitely recommend.
Me: Out of all their items, you recommend a salad?
Ordered their Tea salad (of course), yamo house noodles with pork, fish chowder noodle soup, and black bean fish for our group of 3.
Tea salad was really delicious.
It's comprised of a lot of deep fried onions, which gives the salad a nice crunch to it.
You really have to just try it out.
The dish is rather small
so I'd get one for myself next time.
tea salad.author: Mai K.
tea salad.review:
This is how my visit to Yamo went down. 

Friend: Their Tea salad is great. Definitely recommend. 
Me: Out of all their items, you recommend a salad? 
Friend: It's really good. 

So we wait about 30 minutes to get into this place because it's basically a hole in the wall that seats 8 people at any one time at a bar like setting We order a few things to try since their pricing is quite reasonable. $4-6 per item if I remember correctly. 

Ordered their Tea salad (of course), yamo house noodles with pork, fish chowder noodle soup, and black bean fish for our group of 3. Tea salad was really delicious. It's comprised of a lot of deep fried onions, which gives the salad a nice crunch to it. You really have to just try it out. The dish is rather small so I'd get one for myself next time. Yamo House noodles with pork was really simple. Just noodles with stir fried pork. There wasn't too much seasoning that I could see, but it was still rather tasty. Fish chowder noodle soup was probably my favorite. I don't know what was the crispy bit of the soup was, but it created a great texture contrast to the soup, which I loved. The black bean fish dish was probably my least favorite of the 4. It was good, but I think I'm used to the black beans not being so strong. I prefer a more subtle taste. 

Our four dishes totaled up to $24 and for $8 per person, that's a pretty sweet deal.

excerpts: The tea salad was great.
I loved the texture from the beans.
The crunch and spiciness made a great combination.
House noodles were good, but nothing rave worthy.
tea salad.author: Winnie T.
tea salad.review:
After reading such great reviews, I knew I had to try Yamo. I have to say I was kind of disappointed. The tea salad was great. I loved the texture from the beans. The crunch and spiciness made a great combination. House noodles were good, but nothing rave worthy. Chicken was dry too. 

I didn't enjoy the samosas or the curry. The curry, though filled with spices, just seemed... Off. I'm not quite sure how to describe it. The balance just wasn't quite right. 

Women working there were rude and abrupt. Food comes quickly though, which is great. Don't forget, this place is CASH ONLY. At such a cheap price, I'll probably come back. I just feel like this place has been overhyped.

excerpts: I love their tea salad and their house noodles
(Those are the only two dishes I've tried so far).
tea salad.author: Annie Z.
tea salad.review:
I love yamo! I've heard so many great things about it, but I didn't make an effort to stop by. When I finally did, I fell in love immediately. If you like comfort asian food, you'll love this place. The flavors are so homey and so delicious. I love their tea salad and their house noodles (Those are the only two dishes I've tried so far). I'll definitely be back for more! 

Things to note:  It is a tiny hole in the wall. Cash only, and they do take out. If you grab take out, make sure you eat it immediately. It doesn't taste the same once it gets cold. I recommend it eating it there when they're less busy. I stopped by once at around 3pm on a weekday and the little restaurant still had tons of business. There wasn't a wait though!

excerpts: The tea salad was also a let down.
I didn't even taste any lahpet in the tea salad!
tea salad.author: Xinxin W.
tea salad.review:
Personally, I don't mind being screamed at by old asian ladies. It makes me feel right at home. 

What disappointed me about Yamo was not the service (or lack of) but the food itself. Everything is around $6 bucks but the portions are sooo small that you definitely need two orders per person. Small portions aside, the proportion of meat to carbs is just way off. For example, the famous house noodles with beef comes with 5 tiny pieces of beef. The rest is just bland noodles without any toppings or condiments. The tea salad was also a let down. I didn't even taste any lahpet in the tea salad! It was more of a 3 ingredient chopped lettuce salad. 

2 stars for the price and convenience. I would rather pay a bit more at Burma Superstar/Burma Love.

Tip-- Make sure you don't come right when they're suppose to open. They're always late! I've waited outside for over 30 minutes before anyone came to open up shop.

excerpts:
Pickup is great, only takes 10m to make - just don't be surprised when they hangup the phone without saying goodbye when you place your order :p

Favorites are the Cold Noodle with Chicken, the Tea Salad, and the Curry Chicken.
tea salad.author: Tyler M.
tea salad.review:
Yamo gets five stars for nailing it over-all. The food is cheap, great and fast; the atmosphere is cozy, vibrant and fun. You aren't going to get the most authentic burmese, or the best, but the rest more than makes up for it. Pickup is great, only takes 10m to make - just don't be surprised when they hangup the phone without saying goodbye when you place your order :p

Favorites are the Cold Noodle with Chicken, the Tea Salad, and the Curry Chicken. House Noodles with Beef and Mango Chicken are pretty good too.

excerpts: We ordered the tea salad, house noodles with chicken, black bean fish, and fried rice.
For me, everything was on the salty and oily side, and left me feeling a little greasy afterwards.
There weren't really any flavors that stuck out to me from the food.
I did like that many of the dishes were pretty spicy, but this may not always work out for those who do not eat spicy food.
However, for the price, this place isn't bad.
tea salad.author: Karissa Y.
tea salad.review:
I found this no frills, hole in the wall place mediocre in terms of food.

As they only seats about 10 people, my family of 5 opted to takeout. As expected for this type of place, the service wasn't anything great. The ladies working are no nonsense and abrupt, and expected us to wait outside while our food was cooking (which was understandable, given that it was a bit cramped inside). They were also reluctant to give us the amount of forks that we needed. 

Aside from the service and ambience, the food was okay, but nothing amazing. We ordered the tea salad, house noodles with chicken, black bean fish, and fried rice. For me, everything was on the salty and oily side, and left me feeling a little greasy afterwards. There weren't really any flavors that stuck out to me from the food. I did like that many of the dishes were pretty spicy, but this may not always work out for those who do not eat spicy food. However, for the price, this place isn't bad.

excerpts: We had the house noodles, tea salad and mango salad.
The noodles were simple and hit the spot and the tea leaf salad - though tiny - was very flavorful.
Tea salad and mango salad were both spicy.
All three were oily but not necessarily in a bad way - it kind of fit the ambiance.
Seating is stools at the counter overlooking the kitchen.
Service is certainly not warm, but it's efficient.
We brought our three year old daughter.
tea salad.author: Teresa W.
tea salad.review:
This place is tiny and unpretentious.  We had the house noodles, tea salad and mango salad.  The noodles were simple and hit the spot and the tea leaf salad - though tiny - was very flavorful.  Tea salad and mango salad were both spicy.  All three were oily but not necessarily in a bad way - it kind of fit the ambiance.  Seating is stools at the counter overlooking the kitchen.  Service is certainly not warm, but it's efficient.  We brought our three year old daughter.  It's not a place that screams "kids" but it went fine and she loved the noodles and practicing with the chopsticks.

I left happy.  It's nice to eat at a place that's about the food instead of the trappings.  Cash only.

excerpts:
the tea salad ($4.25)
2.
tea salad.author: Catherine C.
tea salad.review:
Charming the first time around if you've never been to a hole-in-the-wall food stall in Asia, but I'll take takeout from here moving forward. If you don't like smelling like grease, take my advice. :)

If you like being  in the midst of all the action, then this place is for you - You'll hear the ladies working in the kitchen at Yamo chatter in Cantonese while they chop, dice, stir-fry and deep-fry your food in front of you. 

Yamo is a mom-and-pop Burmese home cooking joint in the Mission. It's a drastically different experience from the decidedly clean-cut vibe of Burma Super Star. With only bar seating and an exposed kitchen behind the bar, expect to rub elbows with other customers while you're eating and be prepared to come out smelling a little smoky. 

The food is decent if you just want some good old Asian comfort food to go. Nothing to write home about though.

These are the three essentials that I recommend ordering at Yamo: 
1. the tea salad ($4.25)
2. the samusas ($6.00)
3. house noodles with beef ($6.95)

You'll come out with your belly heavier and your wallet barely lighter!

excerpts: Tea salad -
tea salad.author: Anh P.
tea salad.review:
Hole in the wall, 8-9 stool counter with 3 Chinese ladies manning the fort. One cooking, two taking orders and making the cold dishes and one slaving away on the burners. Might be a better idea to stop by and order takeout. 

This place is a great lunch find! It also helps that 90% of the items on the menu are priced at $6 and the portion size is quite fair. 

Tea salad - I've had better and more authentic, skip out on this and get it at Burma Superstar. 

Yamo House Noodle with Beef - YUM! although, I don't think this is a Burmese dish, but it was still damn good. 

Chicken Noodle Soup (aka ohno kwautskwe) - also delicious, but a little overboard on the coconut cream 

Warning: if you do dine in, you will smell like oil and fried goodness after leaving, not to mention your breath will be as fragrant as a rose garden, not.

excerpts: Food is mediocre, their tea salad is good though
tea salad.author: Xinta B.
tea salad.review:
I never imagine that people can stand with the rudeness of the lady behind the counter.
She is so rude, I don't mind if they tell us no pic allowed in the nice way or you can even put the sign so we know.
We also witness she is so rude to other customer and also two customer walk out because she give them an attitude.

Food is mediocre, their tea salad is good though but I can skip that because their attitude, definitely will not come back again.

If that kind of marketing strategy( rudeness or no bs attitude) works for other customer then go ahead and try this place but this place is not my kind of plate.

excerpts: The best - tea salad & the house ...
Price is cheap ..about $6.50 ...
Portions / great for the ladies - small for the guys
...everything is sticky ..
The counter, the seat , the menus ...
but we like the ladies behind the counter.
Probably won't b bk unless we're low on cash ....
tea salad.author: Jay S.
tea salad.review: Really was excited to try this place ...potstickers were beautiful but cold inside. Curry was blah ... Not much curry flavor ... Very bland .. Darkish gravy ... Beef chow fun ... Very greasy ...samosa - nothing to brag about .... The best - tea salad & the house ... Price is cheap ..about $6.50 ... Portions / great for the ladies - small for the guys ...everything is sticky .. The counter, the seat , the menus ...but we like the ladies behind the counter. Probably won't b bk unless we're low on cash ....

excerpts: My partner started with the Tea Salad ( Tea leave, cabbage, fresh tomato, onion, dried shrimp & variety of fried bean, nuts and sesame seeds)
He said it was different than other Tea Salads he's had before, but we (I mean He) really enjoyed it.
It also had a spicy-vinegar sinus clearing quality to it.
It some conversation with a regular there, the talk of the place is supposedly the Chicken Noodle Soup (Coconut noodle soup with chicken, onions, and cilantro)
, so we promptly ordered some to go.
It's supposed to rain this afternoon
so I plan on cracking that baby open then.
I can say it was packed nicely though with the broth separated from the fixings in a separate container as to keep there freshness until use.
From what I can smell it's going to be awesome.
Portions aren't huge but either is the pricing, a fixed $6.25 [cash only] for all entrees and and $4 something for appetizers (when available).
I was denied both spring rolls and egg rolls but saw them being made later.
hmmmm.
I'll go again and if I can get a smile and a spring roll, I'll boost it a star.
tea salad.author: John W.
tea salad.review:
Walking in your first reaction is "oh Crap!"    This is a hole in the wall place with exposed walls, and plumbing.  You should plan to take your food to go or have a nice place to picnic in mind because seating is limited to a narrow counter with 6 or 7 stools crammed up to it. There is almost always a line, for both seating and take out.  We got there, coincidentally, as they opened.  Apparently if a good portion of the menu isn't available at the moment it's no big deal.  Eavesdropping is inevitable and tolerated because your so close knit with the other patrons.  This turned out to be a positive thing because foodie talk emerges and word of mouth is always the best know all.   The woman behind the counter is also stereo-typically charming (NOT), and location of the "establishment" is also in, I'll say, a more colorful part of The Mission.  
Now,  if you can put all that behind you....  Most SF Foodies can,  SF Foodies appreciate value, authenticity, and taste before all the fore mentioned.  Flavors are bright and spicy, as Burmese food should be.  I had the Chicken Salad (Chicken with a combination of cabbage, carrots, onions, tomatoes, and cilantro) ,  smoky quarter sized medallions of white meat that were grilled and somehow giving a real smoky flavor.  The salad had some kick to it too, with a spicy front-end heat that somewhat dissipated before the next. My partner started with the Tea Salad ( Tea leave, cabbage, fresh tomato, onion, dried shrimp & variety of fried bean, nuts and sesame seeds) He said it was different than other Tea Salads he's had before, but we (I mean He) really enjoyed it.  It also had a spicy-vinegar sinus clearing quality to it.  
It some conversation with a regular there, the talk of the place is supposedly the Chicken Noodle Soup (Coconut noodle soup with chicken, onions, and cilantro), so we promptly ordered some to go.  It's supposed to rain this afternoon so I plan on cracking that baby open then.  I can say it was packed nicely though with the broth separated from the fixings in a separate container as to keep there freshness until use.  From what I can smell it's going to be awesome.   Portions aren't huge but either is the pricing, a fixed $6.25 [cash only] for all entrees and and $4 something for appetizers (when available).  I was denied both spring rolls and egg rolls but saw them being made later.  hmmmm.  
I'll go again and if I can get a smile and a spring roll, I'll boost it a star.

excerpts: I ate the tea salad, egg rolls, chicken noodle soup, and the house beef noodles.
All impressed me.
The tea salad was spicey.
tea salad.author: Sophia T.
tea salad.review: Authentic Burma cuisine cooked right in front of you, served on an intimate counter top surrounded by 9 other patrons. I ate the tea salad, egg rolls, chicken noodle soup, and the house beef noodles. All impressed me. The tea salad was spicey.

excerpts: We ordered the tea salad, house noodles with beef, mango chicken, and potstickers- all for only $24.
The tea salad and the house noodles were especially good.
I would come back to order those again, in multiple portions next time.
tea salad.author: Michelle S.
tea salad.review: Great food. Very small portions. Cash only. My friends and I ordered to go to avoid the line because the restaurant, as you can see from pics, is literally a hole in the wall. We ordered the tea salad, house noodles with beef, mango chicken, and potstickers- all for only $24. To our surprise, when we got our food, each dish was going to end up being like a couple bites each for 3 of us. The tea salad and the house noodles were especially good. I would come back to order those again, in multiple portions next time.

excerpts: Just tea salad was good, the beef noodles and chicken and rice?
tea salad.author: Eric K.
tea salad.review:
Was initially excited to learn that a Burmese resto was in central SF vs. out in Richmond. Yes the prices are cheap ($6 entree) but when it's bland who cares? Would rather pay more and get something tasty. Just tea salad was good, the beef noodles and chicken and rice? BLAND!

Will never go back...

excerpts: But the Tea salad was one of the best I ever had at an eatery, the coconut noodle chicken soup better than some ramen places in the mission, and they sell $1 cokes....
DOLLAR SODA people.
Would not order the mango chicken again but definitely coming back.
You'll forget the economic doldrums once you make like a bandit with three courses for $20.
tea salad.author: Seira M.
tea salad.review:
Cramped seating, interested in seeing the food safety rating, and unfriendly service. 
But the Tea salad was one of the best I ever had at an eatery, the coconut noodle chicken soup better than some ramen places in the mission, and they sell $1 cokes....DOLLAR SODA people. Would not order the mango chicken again but definitely coming back. You'll forget the economic doldrums once you make like a bandit with three courses for $20.

excerpts: The cold noodles, tea salad, and chow mein are the way to go!
Great cheap eat, definitely don't go for the service.
tea salad.author: Shelby F.
tea salad.review: My husband and I visited Yamo on our trip to SF after reading about this hole in the wall on SF Eater. We liked it so much we came back a second night! The cold noodles, tea salad, and chow mein are the way to go! Great cheap eat, definitely don't go for the service.

excerpts: What I ordered: tea salad ($6) and Yamo house noodle with beef ($6).
The tea salad is nothing really "tea".
It is cabbage and onion and a variety of nuts.
First of all, the portion of the tea salad is WAY TOO SMALL.
I am not sure about dine-in portions because pictures on Yelp look big enough, but the to-go portion is absolutely too small for a $6 salad.
Taste is just a okay.
Nothing special.
Yamo house noodle with beef: nothing really special and just very average quality food.
Taste bland
tea salad.author: Lena H.
tea salad.review:
Found on Yelp this tiny restaurant when I looked for lunch around work, and went to Yamo for a to-go based on good reviews and a decent quantity of reviews. 

What I ordered: tea salad ($6) and Yamo house noodle with beef ($6). 

Food taste and quality: 
*The tea salad is nothing really "tea". It is cabbage and onion and a variety of nuts. First of all, the portion of the tea salad is WAY TOO SMALL. I am not sure about dine-in portions because pictures on Yelp look big enough, but the to-go portion is absolutely too small for a $6 salad. Taste is just a okay. Nothing special. 
* Yamo house noodle with beef: nothing really special and just very average quality food. Taste bland and I gotta use chili sauce to make it taste better.

Maybe other foods at Yamo worth a 4 star review, but I don't see how it could happen. 

Restaurant is run by several old ladies and a very tiny restaurant that sits maximum of 8-10 people. You have to sit at kitchen counter. If you just want something quick and fast, then grab and go because sitting there for lunch/dinner will make you smelly cuz of all the smoke inside. A run-down, small, crappy-looking place. 

Foods are Chinese foods, not really Burmese. 

I won't go back again! Keep looking if you want good foods and a comfortable sitting.

excerpts: The tea salad is still the best in town ( minus the small rock I had).
The service is "unique" but Judy, the owner, is a very nice person.
tea salad.author: Eric P.
tea salad.review: I have been going here since they opened and the food quality has diminished in quality.(although it does depend on the cook). The fried rice used to be a great example of the dish. Today at lunch I was served clumps of wet rice with the spices not blended in entirely throughout. The curry fish was over sauced and lacking the intensity of flavor that it should have. The tea salad is still the best in town ( minus the small rock I had). The service is "unique" but Judy, the owner, is a very nice person.

excerpts: Tea salad was a perfect texture, bites of crunchiness, very refreshing and a little spicy, just enough spice to entice your appetite.
Would recommend to go as this place is TINY, would go again for a weeknight dinner take out.
Overall delicious!
tea salad.author: Ingrid C.
tea salad.review: Amazing! The house noodles are perfectly flavored and reasonably priced. Tea salad was a perfect texture, bites of crunchiness, very refreshing and a little spicy, just enough spice to entice your appetite. Would recommend to go as this place is TINY, would go again for a weeknight dinner take out. Overall delicious!

excerpts: I had the yamo house noodles and tea salad.
tea salad.author: Sam G.
tea salad.review:
Phenomenal. I had the yamo house noodles and tea salad. Both are really good. 

The place is small and nothing fancy. The staff is pretty straight forward but the food is simply good.

excerpts: I ordered the Mango Chicken and a tea salad (both dishes were $6).
The menu said the tea salad comes with dried shrimp and tomatoes
so I was pretty excited
-- I do love some shrimp and the concept of a salad from tea leaves is incredible, right?
Well, the salad comes out
and it's a few tea leaves with some dried beans..
no shrimp or tomatoes.
I mentioned something and got yelled at that people didn't like the shrimp in the salad, so it no longer comes with it.
Okay, that's cool, but it would be nice to be told this before I place the order..?
I tried to ask for a few bucks off the Tea Salad at the end,
