So we wait about 30 minutes to get into this place because it's basically a hole in the wall that seats 8 people at any one time at a bar like setting We order a few things to try since their pricing is quite reasonable. $4-6 per item if I remember correctly. 

Ordered their Tea salad (of course), yamo house noodles with pork, fish chowder noodle soup, and black bean fish for our group of 3. Tea salad was really delicious. It's comprised of a lot of deep fried onions, which gives the salad a nice crunch to it. You really have to just try it out. The dish is rather small so I'd get one for myself next time. Yamo House noodles with pork was really simple. Just noodles with stir fried pork. There wasn't too much seasoning that I could see, but it was still rather tasty. Fish chowder noodle soup was probably my favorite. I don't know what was the crispy bit of the soup was, but it created a great texture contrast to the soup, which I loved. The black bean fish dish was probably my least favorite of the 4. It was good, but I think I'm used to the black beans not being so strong. I prefer a more subtle taste. 

Our four dishes totaled up to $24 and for $8 per person, that's a pretty sweet deal.

excerpts: Fish chowder noodle soup (my burmese friends say its really good here!)
fish chowder noodle soup.author: Susan L.
fish chowder noodle soup.review:
Yamo is a hole in the wall run by dragon ladies.  What to expect: great food and kind of intimidating service! 
  
1) wait in a long line.  (although if you come 45 mins before prime dining times, the wait will be really short! 11am, 6pm)
2) sit on a rocky stool at a greasy countertop
3) get yelled at if you don't order within 3 minutes
4) eat elbow to elbow with your neighbors and hear everyone's conversations
5) possibly get yelled at again: "are you done??!", at which point you will pay a ridiculously awesome price for all the food you got with cash only.
6) smell really disgusting after, so bad you would stink up the entire cartrain on bart.

What to eat, to share with one other:
1) Samusas
2) Tea salad (so delicious, best thing on the menu! better than burma superstar's)  You may need two orders. nommms
3) Yamo House Noodles (I like it with pork)
4) Fish chowder noodle soup (my burmese friends say its really good here!)

excerpts: I also really enjoyed the fish chowder noodle soup (mohinga) because it was very creamy and tasty.
The chicken noodle soup was good too
fish chowder noodle soup.author: Linh V.
fish chowder noodle soup.review:
Authentic Burmese food but very VERY small place (seats about 10 people at a time).  A lot of people like to use the term "hole in the wall" for a lot of SF restaurants but Yamo is literally just that.  But don't let that make you underestimate what they can do in such a tiny space.

Their tea leaf salad is the best I have had in the City yet.  It has great flavor and a good crunch.  It won't beat home style tea leaf salad but still the best you can get at a restaurant.  I also really enjoyed the fish chowder noodle soup (mohinga) because it was very creamy and tasty.  The chicken noodle soup was good too but IMO not as great as the mohinga.

It was a long wait but well worth it, especially considering the cheap prices they offer everything.  Yamo is a very good find!

excerpts: They have really good tea leaf salad, spring roll, fish chowder noodle soup, and fresh coconut drink.
They make everything fresh and the wait is short.
Be aware that they are cash only!
fish chowder noodle soup.author: Jacqui C.
fish chowder noodle soup.review: It's a small place that can be easily overlooked in the Mission. There's sometimes a line outside of people taking orders to go. The place is run by three Burmese women who are very interesting characters; they remind me of my grandmother . They have really good tea leaf salad, spring roll, fish chowder noodle soup, and fresh coconut drink. They make everything fresh and the wait is short. Be aware that they are cash only!

excerpts: We ordered the Tea Leaf Salad, Pot Stickers, Yamo House Noodles with Beef, and Fish Chowder Noodle Soup which were perfect for 2.
Every dish had its unique flavors and none of dishes tasted what I expected.
Even the pot stickers surprised me.
Their use of fried broad beans to give the crunchy element is smart and inexpensive which is probably how they keep their cost down.
The use of ginger is ingenious to give that spiciness you need, but not the norm of spicy you expect.
If you crave for spicier, sriracha and other hot sauce condiments are available, but I would not suggest putting them on until you try a few bites and let the original flavors kick in.
Their portion are not for a growing boy so you might want to order doubles if you are super hungry.
I want to go back this weekend to try the other dishes.
fish chowder noodle soup.author: Judy F.
fish chowder noodle soup.review:
It doesn't get diver than this. Mostly everything on the menu is $6 except for the beverages. It is a tax inclusive, cash only, and no frills place with 3 ladies slaving over and keeping the kitchen in order. They have their system of running the establishment and serving your orders so you will get your food, but you should don't expect the conventional restaurant etiquette. If you keep that in mind, your "dining experience" will go great.

The food is yummmmyy!! I am impressed by the lightness of the dishes, and yet, I felt comforted and satisfied after I ate. The food was flavorful and hearty but without the guilt. We ordered the Tea Leaf Salad, Pot Stickers, Yamo House Noodles with Beef, and Fish Chowder Noodle Soup which were perfect for 2. Every dish had its unique flavors and none of dishes tasted what I expected. Even the pot stickers surprised me. Their use of fried broad beans to give the crunchy element is smart and inexpensive which is probably how they keep their cost down. The use of ginger is ingenious to give that spiciness you need, but not the norm of spicy you expect. If you crave for spicier, sriracha and other hot sauce condiments are available, but I would not suggest putting them on until you try a few bites and let the original flavors kick in. Their portion are not for a growing boy so you might want to order doubles if you are super hungry. I want to go back this weekend to try the other dishes.

excerpts: We had fish chowder noodle soup and tea salad.
The portion of the tea salad is extremely small.
It's definitely tapas size appetizers and it costs $6 or $7.
As for the flavor... I have had better.
fish chowder noodle soup.author: Ricki H.
fish chowder noodle soup.review:
I went there with two of my girlfriends and we were not impressed. May be we didn't order their signsture dishes? We had fish chowder noodle soup and tea salad. 

The flavor of the soup is bland and the soup is not hot. It's warm. I think it's due to the fact that they use rice cooker to make the soup. It's definitely easier for customers to eat and makes the turnover faster. Unfortunately there's nothing memorable about the  noodle soup to us. 

The portion of the tea salad is extremely small. It's definitely tapas size appetizers and it costs $6 or $7. As for the flavor... I have had better. It's not bad but nothing memorable. 

It's a pity cuz this place appears to be one of those hole in the wall type amazing local restaurants for quick and awesome food. However, it is truly not it and the line is long and not worth it.

excerpts: I have tried the Potstickers, Tea Leaf Salad, Fish Chowder Noodle Soup, Mango Chicken, Black Bean Fish, Yamo House Noodles with Beef, Chicken Noodle Soup, Yamo Cold Noodles and the Curry Tofu
and they were all great.
fish chowder noodle soup.author: Joy L.
fish chowder noodle soup.review:
This is a great little hole in the wall. The space itself is tiny, and your food is literally cooked in front of you. The food is great and the service is no-nonsense, but that doesn't mean they are unfriendly, they are just busy. Your best bet is to call in ahead of time and order take out if you don't want to wait for a seat. Also - since the place is so teeny tiny, the ventilation is quite poor, so take out may be your best option in that respect as well.  

Reasonable prices and I have no complaints about the food. Their portions are a little on the small side, but you can't expect more than what they give you for the price you are paying. Their menu is not huge, but what they offer, they do well. I have tried the Potstickers, Tea Leaf Salad, Fish Chowder Noodle Soup, Mango Chicken, Black Bean Fish, Yamo House Noodles with Beef, Chicken Noodle Soup, Yamo Cold Noodles and the Curry Tofu and they were all great. All of their noodle dishes are excellent. 

This is a Mission gem - it encompasses everything I love about San Francisco: Tiny little hole-in-the-wall places with yummy but dirt-cheap food.

excerpts: I ordered the Tea leaf Salad, Yamo House noodles, the Yamo Cold Noodles, and the fish chowder noodle soup.
The Tea leaf salad was nice and spicy, make sure you have water to help with the spiciness.
My husband ate the Yamo cold noodles and the Yamo House noodles an thought they were nothing special and some of the sauces tasted like it was made with Ketchup.
I really liked the Fish Chowder soup- not too much of a fishy flavor and a mild curry flavor.
My husband ate the Yamo cold noodles and the Yamo House noodles an thought they were nothing special and some of the sauces tasted like it was made with Ketchup.
I really liked the Fish Chowder soup- not too much of a fishy flavor and a mild curry flavor.
fish chowder noodle soup.author: Lily L.
fish chowder noodle soup.review: I used to love this place and was introduced by a close friend of mine, but was not that impressed with this visit: some of the dishes I ordered and I'm wondering if it is because I ordered to go or I just ordered different dishes in the past. I ordered the Tea leaf Salad, Yamo House noodles, the Yamo Cold Noodles, and the fish chowder noodle soup.  The Tea leaf salad was nice and spicy, make sure you have water to help with the spiciness.  My husband ate the Yamo cold noodles and the Yamo House noodles an thought they were nothing special and some of the sauces tasted like it was made with Ketchup.  I really liked the Fish Chowder soup- not too much of a fishy flavor and a mild curry flavor.  I called ahead for my order and they said done in 15 minutes, by the time I got there the food was ready for me to pick up.  The have maybe 6-10 bar stools to sit and watch them cook,  and there is only 2 or 3 ladies working behind the small cooking area.  it is hard to get in so you usually will see people waiting outside the door to pick up their order or waiting for an open seat.  Cant beat the prices of their dishes though.

excerpts:
Fish Chowder Noodle Soup $5.25
 - 2 stars
 - Soup chowder with rice noodles, shredded fish, and onions, garnished with Fried Yellowbeans and Cilantro
 -
This wasn't bad, but it didn't strike me as very inspired.
The sauce was a thick reddish sauce reminiscent in texture of thick Chinese sauces poured over meats and rice.
Sorry, there should be a better explanation
but I can't imagine what it is.
The noodles were very very well cooked and watery, almost like pho noodles, only it didn't seem to be the way these noodles were supposed to be.
The taste was subtle...almost too subtle.
fish chowder noodle soup.author: Tetsu N.
fish chowder noodle soup.review:
Today was my very first experience eating Burmese food, and from what I'm told, everything here is very authentic, or at least authentic from the perspective that identically prepared delectable delights can be had over there.

Meeting a very old friend from back in NY who happened to be in town, we went to Yamo based on her SO's recommendation.

What a treat!  I love experiencing new kinds of food!

The restaurant itself is ridiculously small, with only some limited counter seating, maybe seating 10 or so.  The restaurant looks like it has been around for a while too, and was incredibly popular.  The line was constant and always out the door, tho luckily, it seems that most who get their food here have are well aware that getting takeout is a much wiser choice.  

And the prices!  Excellent prices for the cheap bastard in me.  My friend and I had three dishes, a coconut drink, and a soda for under $20.  For light eaters on a budget, one dish and a drink would be about $7 combined.  Big eaters won't go broke either.  

On to the food.

Tea Salad:  $5.25
 - 4.5 stars
 - Tea leave, cabbage, fresh tomato, oion, dried shrimp & variety of fried bean, nuts and sesame seeds.
 - Wow, by far my favorite dish of the day.  This taste and texture explosion is so good I wish they served it in meal portions, but alas, they only served it as a relatively small and light plate.  More like an appetizer.  It's got a variety of crunchy textures, including what feels like tiny croutons though with a saltier taste (I'm assuming it's the fried bean but might of been the dried shrimp), and the nuts (which I'm guessing may be peanuts), and the more raw veggie crunch of the cabbage.  There are also several software textures as well as the watery tomato texture.   And the taste?  Wow, there's a raw veggie tanginess to it, subtly to it, saltiness to it....Really, explosion is the only way to describe.  And it does this so cleanly and lightly that none of the tastes are overbearing.  This is a MUST ORDER at this small little hole in the wall.

Fish Chowder Noodle Soup $5.25
 - 2 stars
 - Soup chowder with rice noodles, shredded fish, and onions, garnished with Fried Yellowbeans and Cilantro
 - This wasn't bad, but it didn't strike me as very inspired.  The sauce was a thick reddish sauce reminiscent in texture of thick Chinese sauces poured over meats and rice.  Sorry, there should be a better explanation but I can't imagine what it is.  The noodles were very very well cooked and watery, almost like pho noodles, only it didn't seem to be the way these noodles were supposed to be.  The taste was subtle...almost too subtle.  Perhaps, tho, I'm being a little harsh because of the great tastes of the other dishes, but really, I wouldn't order this again.

Yamo Cold Noodles $5.25
 - 3.5 stars
 - Cold noodles mixed with house special flavor, onions, cabbage, cucumbers, and chicken
 - Pretty good dish.  The noodles are similar to chow mein noodles but without the glossy oiliness.  This was their spicy dish, but it's more tangy than spicy.  The chicken was covered in a thick, almost dry red sauce with lots of full sized peppers (like the dry peppers found in jars at the table at pizza restaurants).  This dish was also full of different flavors giving a nice complexity to the dish.  I would order this again.

Fresh Coconut $2.50
 - 4 stars
 - All my life, I thought coconuts had a stronger taste because coconut flakes used in cakes had such a strong flavor.  What a surprise to find the taste was so subtle, if you had told me it was a different fruit, I would have believed you.  So light, refreshing.  Loved it.  I also liked that it came in a full coconut rather than a glass.  It was fun to see, and we could scrape the inside for the thicker fruity part of the coconut.    Yeah, I'd order this again, just for the novelty of it.  

Grass Jelly drink $1.00
 - 2.5 stars
 - This is a can drink.  Not carbonated, with bits of jelly in it.  It's similar in taste to Chinese turtle shell gelatin desserts.  I'd drink it again if it was served, but probably wouldn't ever be my first choice.  Still, it tasted like it was probably a healthy drink.

Though we didn't order it, the customer sitting next to us order what I think (just guessing mind you) is the Yamo House Noodles.  That looked really good.  Basically several bite sized pieces of chicken (looking like it was cooked in a thick dark sauce) over a bed of the chow mein like noodles.  It sure as heck looked good.

All in all, this place was pretty good.  If I would have rated it a straight 3.5, I'd got to 4, but given that all the food combined average below a 3.5, I'll have to go with a 3 today.

Except...the price!  The price is so good, that adds a half star right there, pushing the average up and making this place an easy 4 stars.

So with that said, Yay!  I'm a fan!

excerpts: Their creamy Fish Chowder Noodle Soup with fried yellow beans and Tea Salad are definite reasons to return.
fish chowder noodle soup.author: Eva L.
fish chowder noodle soup.review:
I first saw the reviews on Bargain Bites so I thought that I should give it a try.  I didn't know what to expect.

This little family owned Burmese restaurant offers only bar seating for maybe a maximum of approximately ten guests.  Their creamy Fish Chowder Noodle Soup with fried yellow beans and Tea Salad are definite reasons to return.

excerpts: I would generously approve of their fish chowder noodle soup and possibly their pot stickers but... beyond this, I'm not entirely sure.

Still, it hardly warrants a large deduction; but, with Yamo's increasing popularity seating at their infamous tiny food bar has become near impossible and as such, weighs further on the negative scale with a full star deduction.

I still really enjoy Yamo, and I still laud it's accomplishments to any who will listen, but have to be fair and numb a bit of the excitement and state the simple fact: if you have a Burmese-Chinese craving, order out.
You will most certainly have a more satisfactory experience.
fish chowder noodle soup.author: Jessica L.
fish chowder noodle soup.review:
I still absolutely love Yamo. The deduction in star is a reflection of a more general view of Yamo's menu; having been a devotee of their tea leaf salad, noodle soups and Yamo House Noodles, I've discovered I'm not entirely enamored with anything else. I came by with my parents to introduce them to a more pure Mission dining experience and experimented with the beef curry, the mango chicken and... it was okay.
What? Only okay? I know, I have to be fair though and yes, I felt that past my exclaimed favorites mentioned in my first review, the rest of the menu is a bit lacking. I would generously approve of their fish chowder noodle soup and possibly their pot stickers but... beyond this, I'm not entirely sure.
Still, it hardly warrants a large deduction; but, with Yamo's increasing popularity seating at their infamous tiny food bar has become near impossible and as such, weighs further on the negative scale with a full star deduction.
I still really enjoy Yamo, and I still laud it's accomplishments to any who will listen, but have to be fair and numb a bit of the excitement and state the simple fact: if you have a Burmese-Chinese craving, order out. You will most certainly have a more satisfactory experience.

excerpts: If you're lucky and they have fresh coconut, be careful before you order it.
Seeing the little old lady hacking into it (and I mean HACKING into it) with a BIG f'ing cleaver left me with a mild case of PTSD.
Holy cow!!
fresh coconut.author: Paul D.
fresh coconut.review:
I just don't get here as often as I should....

I first came here quite a number of years ago on a date and it was my first experience with Burmese food. It got me hooked.

I've been here quite a bit and I've never been disappointed. The food is always excellent, and the price is ridiculously cheap. Two people can eat for under twenty bucks. The place is small and they cook right in front of you so, expect to smell like a kitchen for the rest of the night.

I love the ladies that run this joint. While the whiny types think they're rude the fact is, they are working hard, making tons of orders, inside and take out, and they're just plain no-nonsense.

If you're lucky and they have fresh coconut, be careful before you order it. Seeing the little old lady hacking into it (and I mean HACKING into it) with a BIG f'ing cleaver left me with a mild case of PTSD. Holy cow!! and, I served in the Army...

My favs:

* Tea Leaf Salad, the bomb
* Mango Salad, Spicy (very much so)
* Yamo House Noodles with Pork (Heaven)
* Curry Prawns? NO SHRIMP!!!!!

Eating in, you need to have some etiquette. The place is small, really small, I mean really really small (like, you probably have a closet bigger than this restaurant). So, be prepared to scoot over to make room for people coming in. And for crying out loud, be a good sport about it. It's a down home friendly place so, you should be too.

excerpts: Super thick and creamy catfish chowder was the perfect hangover cure along with fresh coconut juice:
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=iLuobb5t4WvdJ89NQsnZ7g#U99E-5MGgXTG8ayohEfeew
*CASH
ONLY
fresh coconut.author: Cherylynn N.
fresh coconut.review:
Guys say girls are frustrating. I beg to differ. Guys frustrate the sh*t out of me...

Q: "I'm NEVER eating out with you again...you're high maintenance...you pick all the bougie places and spend more time doing a food porn photo shoot than eating."
Me: "Fine, whatever..."  

ONE WEEK LATER...
 
Q: "Let's go eat."
Me: "Uhh, don't you remember what you said last week?"
Q: "Huh? Let's eat...you pick."
Me: "American ok? I can't have MSG because I'm allergic and I'm trying to stay away from carbs."
Q: "PHO!"
Me: "I can't have MSG because I'm allergic and I'm trying to stay away from carbs."
Q: "Turtle Tower!"
Me: "Dude!!!! I can't have MSG..."
Q: "Aww, why not? Pho at Turtle Tower!"
Me *B-R-E-A-T-H-E*: "Let's go to Yamo. It's a hole-in-the-wall, they don't use MSG, and they have soup for you."
Q: "Ohh, I like hole-in-the-walls."

*Arrives at Yamo*

Q: "It's so small and dingy and there's a line. It's all bok gwais here, not a good sign."
Me: "It's a hole-in-the-wall and we're in The Mission."

*Sits down*

Q: "It's so hot and tight in here."
Me: "Just order."

*Food comes*

Q: "Dayam, the potstickers are hella good...the house noodles...DAYAAAM..." *oil dribbles down mouth*

*3 minutes later*

Me *looks at empty plates*: "What the heezy, you're DONE already?!?!?"
Q *rubs belly*: "It's so hot and tight in here...I smell like grease."

WHO'S BOUGIE NOW?

OTHER NOTES:
*Cheap eats: appetizers - $4 and salad, soups, rice and noodle dishes - $6. NO MSG. 
*Rude and fast service.
*Expect a wait during peak hours. It was a 15 minute wait at 2 PM on a Saturday. 
*8 seats. 10 seats total if they decide to add two extra chairs at the edge of the counter that day.
*Most popular dishes:
-Tea Leaf Salad ($6): http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=iLuobb5t4WvdJ89NQsnZ7g#iLuobb5t4WvdJ89NQsnZ7g
-House Noodles ($6): No pic because someone prematurely dove in. Guys. No surprise. 
-Mohinga is the national dish of Burma. Super thick and creamy catfish chowder was the perfect hangover cure along with fresh coconut juice: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=iLuobb5t4WvdJ89NQsnZ7g#U99E-5MGgXTG8ayohEfeew
*CASH ONLY

excerpts: All entrees are $6 and you can get a fresh coconut for $3.50!
fresh coconut.author: Tiffany V.
fresh coconut.review:
Just came in today for lunch with my boss. I would only sit inside on a cold winters night. There are only around 8 stools against their counter facing their 100 degree kitchen that is constantly blowing smoke and steam at you. They also yelled at me for trying to take photos! Homph. It was so packed and stuffy inside my boss refused to come in! 

We ordered the tea leaf salad, mango salad, fish curry with rice, and their house special fried rice. Grand total was $24! The only thing I would reorder would be the two salads. They were so good!!! I would never order the fish curry and fried rice again. The shrimp were the super tiny kind and the curry was not much of a curry at all. 

There was a nonstop stream of people ordering at 1pm and they food comes out slow so be prepared to wait! I don't know why but they gave us like 6 pairs of chopsticks even though there was only enough food to feed two. Portions are definitely on the smaller side! All entrees are $6 and you can get a fresh coconut for $3.50! 

Street parking was pretty easy. Bring cash and be prepared for a long wait and to take it to go!

excerpts: I had received the tea leaf noodles, house noodles, samosas, and the fresh coconut juice.
I also came during dinner time and had to wait a bit
fresh coconut.author: Kaitlyn E.
fresh coconut.review:
I went here once before thinking it was the complete bombdiggity. I had received the tea leaf noodles, house noodles, samosas, and the fresh coconut juice. I also came during dinner time and had to wait a bit so maybe that's why I thought my first experience was just SOOO good. 

Came here again after forgetting the name of this hole in the wall and finally found it on yelp. I was SO excited to bring my boy here. 

Don't get me wrong, he actually loved this place. Or what he got at least (yamo house noodles chicken). The service however........

Is it because we came during lunch time rather than dinner when there was absolutely no line and ample seats for diners?

The service was just so mediocre. Everyone seemed sad, out of it, unattentive. Maybe it was just a bad day, but the food was good at least. Potstickers were a new try, wouldn't recommend. Also, didn't seem like they had an option to have the cut coconuts to drink from this time. But I didn't ask, they didn't offer sorta thang. So shrug. 

That's my take on it. I'd go again for a cheap quick delicious meal anytime. Just wasn't impressed this second time around.

excerpts: Oh, and they also serve fresh coconut juice.
They also provide a lot of vegeterian options which seems quite popular with a lot of the customers.
Can't beat that!
fresh coconut.author: Gina N.
fresh coconut.review: It's literally a small hole in the wall, and if u blink u will probably miss it, although there is a huge sign on top of it's door. It's in the heart of the mission and serves up some darn good burmese cooking! The place is really small, and there's only probably a dozen or so seats available. You can order to go if u don't want to wait, but I prefer to snag a chair and witness the 3 ladies in action, cooking up a storm. The food is really authentic and cooked fresh to order right off the grill. The house noodles is a must, and everything on the menu is $6 or less. Oh, and they also serve fresh coconut juice. They also provide a lot of vegeterian options which seems quite popular with a lot of the customers. Can't beat that!

excerpts:
Fresh Coconut Drink
Devour:
fresh coconut.author: Genevieve Y.
fresh coconut.review:
Date & Time:  Saturday November 21, 2009 @ 4:30pm
Company:  Michael
Crowd:  Neighborhood Peeps & Hipsters
Vibe:  Very Casual
Decor:  Hole-in-The-Wall w/ Counter-Seating
Service:  Nice & Efficient Asian Ladies 
Imbibe:  Fresh Coconut Drink
Devour:  Yamo House Noodles, Chicken Chow Mein & Curry
Total:  $20.75

excerpts: Definitely love the fresh coconut but felt sorry when they had to saw it through with a knife manually.
fresh coconut.author: T L.
fresh coconut.review:
(See pics) Review #1131. More of 4.3 stars. What happened when you have a heavy breakfast and skipped lunch? You are on a carb starving mode and all you can dream (crave) of was greased up Chinese food.

Totally hole in a wall and tiny, delicious tea salad was an appetizer and a palate cleanser. The popular noodles were wrapped with just enough amount of oil and the chicken was good crispy delicious. And I did finish the whole bowl  (not huge) very quickly.

Definitely love the fresh coconut but felt sorry when they had to saw it through with a knife manually.

And it's quite inexpensive.

Also love this kind of atmosphere, hot, cozy, a sense of style and super friendly service by the super sweet Asian women and other patrons.

Ah yes, there's a line but it moves rather quickly (15-20 mins) for dinner.

excerpts: If you're having a meal there, ask for fresh coconut.
fresh coconut.author: Moo C.
fresh coconut.review:
If you like eating in a closet, come here!  I've only eaten IN the resto a couple of times, preferring to call in and pick up my order.  It's definitely a tight squeeze and the wait can be long at times. If you're there for the first time with your sweetie to keep you warm as you stand in line...go for it (but I digress)...the food is really good.

It's amusing to watch the ladies behind the counter do their thang.  Shouts all around, but it's a graceful symphony that results in an absolutely happy tummy.

Prices are very reasonable, and the food is served to you very quickly.  All of the dishes I've tried here have been good, but some faves:
Chicken noodle soup
Tea leaf salad
Yamo House Noodles
Yamo Cold Noodles

If you're having a meal there, ask for fresh coconut.  As you sip on the juice of a baby coconut cracked open just for you, enjoy the tastes, smells and sounds this Burmese eatery.

Oh, don't plan on going anywhere after because those scents stick ;)

excerpts: I watched the youngest of the ladies hack (with a cleaver) at the top of a fresh coconut to pierce the shell so a straw could be inserted.
fresh coconut.author: Joanna T.
fresh coconut.review:
By chance, I noticed Yamo last week and now passing the place (with fast sinking blood sugar), I stopped and decided to give it a try.

First off, Yamo is a shoebox. But this place last week and tonight was full. Everyone sits at a counter on some funky, red vinyl covered stools. What caught my eye this time was a guy seated close to a door drinking from a straw that fed into a real coconut. I had to exam the menu in the window.

Appetizers: $4.95 - only 3 choices: samusas, egg rolls and potstickers. 
Salads:       $6      - tea leaf or chicken salad

Ahh, the samusa and tea leaf salad on the menu immediately screamed "Burmese" to me. 

Entrees: All $6 - choice of curry beef, chicken, curry prawns, curry tofu or curry fish. Everything goes over egg noodles or rice. Don't like curry? they make a house fried rice or a house pan fried noodle. You kind of get the drift that their repetoire is strictly enforced.

When I popped my head in, the main lady and the cook looked over the full row and then peeked over the counter and nodded me to the 1st stool right inside the door opposite the stoves. Umm, is this the best seat in the house? Or is this the worst seat?

I've got to say I like the fresh air coming into the door. Didn't like the closeness of the flames from the wok shooting up in the air from the stove.

Without being in a party, I chose only one dish: curry prawns with rice. I was fascinated watching the ladies' system. The head lady takes the orders, gathers ingredients and places items in a silver dish which she lines up by the cook and the cook stir-frys each dish up and gives it back to the head lady to deliver to the customer.

Back to the food: now dairy-based curry generally has a good sauce that goes good with rice. But when I was served up my dish, I found I had a reddish, oil based curry with the prawns. Foiled - not much sauce. The food was okay and definitely hot from the oven.

Other male diners (with bigger appetites!) went all out ordering potstickers, curry fish noodles and fried rice and curry tofu just for two people. Some couples took out an order of the tea leaf salad on their way out. Seems like a very popular dish.

It was really interesting to watch the interplay between the ladies busting themselves to get the food out. I watched the youngest of the ladies hack (with a cleaver) at the top of a fresh coconut to pierce the shell so a straw could be inserted. Amazing.

What else can I say? If in the area and hungry but on a budget, come for the food and stay for the show.

excerpts: They have really good tea leaf salad, spring roll, fish chowder noodle soup, and fresh coconut drink.
They make everything fresh and the wait is short.
Be aware that they are cash only!
fresh coconut.author: Jacqui C.
fresh coconut.review: It's a small place that can be easily overlooked in the Mission. There's sometimes a line outside of people taking orders to go. The place is run by three Burmese women who are very interesting characters; they remind me of my grandmother . They have really good tea leaf salad, spring roll, fish chowder noodle soup, and fresh coconut drink. They make everything fresh and the wait is short. Be aware that they are cash only!

excerpts:
She whack off a fresh coconut
With a carving knife
Did you ever see
Such a great whack in your life
fresh coconut.author: Nobu K.
fresh coconut.review:
Three Old Asian ladies,
Three Old Asian ladies,
See how they cook,
See how they cook,

They all ran & shout after
each other
She is rude bossy taking order
for every one
Have you ever seen
Such a manner in your life
As three Asian ladies

Three Old Asian ladies,
Three Old Asian ladies,
See how they cook,
See how they cook,

They all ran & shout after
each other
She cook most food so fast
With 3 hot burning pans
Did you ever see
Such a fast cooking in your life
As three Asian ladies

Three Old Asian ladies,
Three Old Asian ladies,
See how they cook,
See how they cook,

They all ran & shout after
each other
She whack off a fresh coconut
With a carving knife
Did you ever see
Such a great whack in your life
As three Asian ladies

---------------------

In case, if you don't know anything about the place, Yamo is small, only counter seats about ...... 11? yeah, I think 11 or 12 seats. And 3 old Asian women were working their ass-off like Non-Stop, because people are keep coming one after another.
The food is very flavorful Burmese dish, and really inexpensive.
I have to say,
GREAT REAL ASIAN FUSION.
YAMO HOUSE NOODLES w/ Beef, 6 bucks
Curry over egg noodle, 6 bucks
Pot sticker 8 for $4.50

This is the real super star of Burmese, THE BEST "HOLE IN A WALL" IN THE CITY!!!

excerpts: They also serve fresh coconut juice, right out of the coconut!!
fresh coconut.author: Chanel L.
fresh coconut.review:
I've never been here physically, but I have had this place for takeout multiple times. My friends are addicted to the curry potato samosas.  Every time they go, they bring back at least 20+ back.  If you love ginger, order the pot stickers.  You can taste the shredded ginger/meat in every bite. 

My favorite has to be the house noodles and also the fresh hand made shrimp spring rolls. They also serve fresh coconut juice, right out of the coconut!! I can only find those at Vietnamese restaurants in San Jose! 

I haven't been inside, but I can def imagine a person who sits in and eat will most def smell like grease afterwards.  You are eating inside a greasy kitchen! Take out FTW! 

My next try will be the tealeaf salad!

excerpts: Top it off with fresh coconut to drink.
Fantastic.
I could not ask for a better homecoming.
fresh coconut.author: April D.
fresh coconut.review: So I have been out of the country for 2 years. And this is the 1st new restaurant I got try after returning to America. Me and a friend shared the yamo cold house noodles, the yamo hot house needles with beef, and the samusas. Bursts of flavors all over the place. My friend said that those three dishes were the ones to get. I certainly agree. Top it off with fresh coconut to drink. Fantastic. I could not ask for a better homecoming.

excerpts: They also have fresh coconut juice and Cokes in glass bottles.
fresh coconut.author: Tina T.
fresh coconut.review:
This is seriously a hole-in-the-wall type of place. If you're looking for this place while driving, you may blink and miss it so make sure to look at the photo of the place before coming here. There are about 12 stools lined up along an open kitchen so you can see how they prepare and cook their dishes.

Highlight: Tea Leaf Salad ($5.25): smaller portion than Burma Superstar but so good. Similar in flavor with added onions and heat, if desired. I loved it spicy!

We also had the House Noodles with Chicken ($5.25). Soy-flavored noodles with juicy slices of chicken breast. It was very good but I couldn't help but think it tasted like any other decent Chinese restaurant. Same goes for the Mango Chicken with rice ($5.25). The sauce was very good with the rice but it wasn't anything too special. They also have fresh coconut juice and Cokes in glass bottles.

The ladies who work here are quick. I saw them use gloves to prepare spring rolls and salads so that's a big plus. It's not the most quiet place because those ladies are yelling out orders left and right. I heard them speak Cantonese and what I suspect to be Burmese since I couldn't understand it. 

Overall, great place for some good, cheap food. However, it is pretty much Chinese food so I would only come back for the tea leaf salad.

excerpts: To wash it down, enjoy a glass bottle of Coca-Cola or (my personal favorite) order coconut milk and one of the cooks will chop off the top of a fresh coconut and serve it to you with a straw and spoon.
One last tip, Yamo is cash
only so don't forget to hit the ATM before you go.
I usually spend under $20 bucks on a full meal for two here.
fresh coconut.author: Heather M.
fresh coconut.review:
I vote we change this restaurant's name to "Yummo" because the food here is extremely yummy.  I first tried Yamo a few years ago on a whim and it has become one of my favorite spots in the city. Don't be put off by Yamo's aesthetics, it looks very dingy and is  pretty much the size of a walk-in closet with very limited seating, and yes it is loud. There is usually a wait, but their coconut chicken noodle soup is SO worth waiting for, it tastes like a wonderful oniony yellow curry soup with hints of chilli and of course, creamy coconut. For the price, you really can't beat it. If you aren't in a soupy mood, try the spring rolls or mango chicken. To wash it down, enjoy a glass bottle of Coca-Cola or (my personal favorite) order coconut milk and one of the cooks will chop off the top of a fresh coconut and serve it to you with a straw and spoon. 
One last tip, Yamo is cash only so don't forget to hit the ATM before you go. I usually spend under $20 bucks on a full meal for two here.

excerpts: I'd also recommend getting a fresh coconut to sip on while you wait.
fresh coconut.author: Trevor U.
fresh coconut.review:
Yamo's food quality deserves 3 stars, but the experience in itself deserves 4 stars.  

There is always a line at Yamo!  It might be because the hole in the wall that Yamo calls home is comparable in size to a muni car.  And let's be honest, riding muni during rush hour sucks.  You can never get a seat at the bar and you're constantly rubbing shoulders with people to order.  Once you do get your opportunity to order, you better do it correctly or else the intimidating Burmese women might let you have it.  

For starters, I'd recommend hitting up Yamo during non-peak hours.  If you do manage to get a seat at the bar, I'd recommend sitting as far away from the door as possible.  I'd also recommend getting a fresh coconut to sip on while you wait.  

As far as food goes, I'm a huge fan of the Tea Salad, House Fried Chow Mein, and Yamo House Noodles.  Don't expect much from these dishes in terms of size as everything on the menu is only $6.  

I highly recommend Yamo because it is a unique experience.  You probably won't be able to absorb another experience like this one anywhere else in San Francisco. 

*If you're looking to eat and beat the line, call your order in and pick it up 15 minutes later.  It definitely beats the crowd on a cold San Francisco night.

excerpts: Fresh Coconut Juice: Drink it straight from the coconut shell.
fresh coconut.author: Sassy G.
fresh coconut.review:
Spring Roll (not the deep fried ones but the soft rolls): Good but I've had better elsewhere. Like more mint in mines.

Tea Leaf Salad: Crunchy!  All ingredients FRESH. Excellent!! Better than Burma Star.

House Noodle (Pork): Meat seared perfectly. Noodle consistency is chewy but not hard.

Cold Noodle: Same noodle as the House Noodle but mixed in with lettuce, carrots, cucumber, cilantro, onion. You mix it all together and it's almost like having noodle salad. Tip: to give it a kick, add jalapeno and vinegar (part of the condiment on the counter where you sit)  into this dish.  

Fresh Coconut Juice: Drink it straight from the coconut shell. Freakin' awesome.

Portions on the small side just like in all parts of Asia (except the Cold Noodle. That was a tad bigger).  

Total cost:  approx $28.00 (plus tax, $5) = $32.

Will be back to try their Crispy Egg Rolls and Curry Fish!

excerpts: At Yamo there is a short counter space at which you can plop down, the ambiance is hot Burmese kitchen and not hot SF hotspot, but the lovely ladies there cook up some gorgeous fresh plates of yumminess, AND they chop off the top of the fresh coconut entirely: so you can get at all the fresh coconutty goodness.
Some places don't do this...why I ask you?
It is like $2.50 for the coconut.
$5.25 for each entre.
fresh coconut.author: Maria D.
fresh coconut.review:
Yamo, Yamo where have you been all my life? So there are so many overpriced places in this town, and for the most part, they are not even close to being as good as this no-frills hole in the wall. So you put it on a fancy plate and serve it to me with a hot waiter in a crisp white shirt doesn't make the wallet assault any less insulting. 

At Yamo there is a short counter space at which you can plop down, the ambiance is hot Burmese kitchen and not hot SF hotspot, but the lovely ladies there cook up some gorgeous fresh plates of yumminess, AND they chop off the top of the fresh coconut entirely: so you can get at all the fresh coconutty goodness. Some places don't do this...why I ask you? It is like $2.50 for the coconut. $5.25 for each entre. I love the vegetable curry noodles. The veggies are cooked perfect (they are still somewhat crisp) and includes okra. Yumo. Flavors pop, appetizers rock. The tea salad, and fresh spring rolls. Go to Yamo and drink a coconut already. You will be glad you did.

excerpts: Order anything and get a fresh coconut.
fresh coconut.author: Brandi B.
fresh coconut.review:
I've been dying to go here, and finally last night CHECK off the list! 

I'm giving this place 3 stars, one for each of those short, loud, lovely little ladies working there butts off in that tiny little kitchen. 

You get what you expect. You see 8 worn, crowded bar stools in a Diner-like setting where if you fell off your stool you'd hit the wall behind you, hardly any decorations, and a fridge. If this is what you expected then you'll love it! If you wanted to kick up your feet, and lounge into plush booths with fancy stuff on the walls, then mosey on along.

What those fabulous ladies create in that kitchen is by no means masterpiece. But I left with a full belly and still full wallet. Sampled two apps, two noodle dishes, and a soup. I have a feeling that you could get anything and it would all taste the same without tasting at all the same. Each dish delicious, $5.50, pretty darn spicy, and with just enough oil to leave that slick in your mouth. Order anything and get a fresh coconut. Way to go Yamo. 

P.s. and If you don't want that dirty, awesome diner experience? Take it to go, and kick your feet up in your living room with your plush couch and fancy stuff on the walls.

excerpts: Get the fresh coconut drink for $2.50 only.
Same price in Mexico!
fresh coconut.author: Yvonne Y.
fresh coconut.review:
Tea salad:  Pretty good if you can handle all the dried beans and garlic.  That garlic was potent and looooooooonglasting.

Chicken noodle soup:  ramen, chicken, onions in a yellow curry coconut soup.  Fantastic.

Get the fresh coconut drink for $2.50 only.  Same price in Mexico!

excerpts: get the fresh coconut, the tea leaf salad, and anything with black bean sauce.
fresh coconut.author: Sean C.
fresh coconut.review:
exceptional food that you can't get just anywhere. price is there, too.

and the atmosphere? let me tell you: the ladies behind the counter are SO SURLY! getting them to even crack a smirk is a wonderful gift in itself.

setting is epically tiny - no groups! - and it seems like getting your to-go order requires muscling through the line/crowd at the entrance and demanding your food over the hustle of the place.

not normally my thing, but something about this place just WORKS. it's a go-to Mission/SF experience if you ask me. and an awesome date place. get the fresh coconut, the tea leaf salad, and anything with black bean sauce.

highly, highly recommended.

excerpts: Delightful to have a fresh coconut as beverage.
Probably need to come at strategic time to avoid long wait.
I am a fan!
fresh coconut.author: Kozmo C.
fresh coconut.review: Delicious cheap Burmese food in archetypal hole-in-the-wall eatery.  Oft grumpy-looking Asian ladies run the place very much like street food carts in Asia, where everything seems at once makeshift yet operated with ruthless efficiency.  Food is not as sophisticated as Burmese Superstar, but perfectly comforting and pack in that explosive savory Burmese flavor as you would expect.  House specialty noodles are superb, tea salad very good, and curry okay (it was just spicy and not much else to me).  Delightful to have a fresh coconut as beverage.  Probably need to come at strategic time to avoid long wait.  I am a fan!

excerpts: Three hard whacks and wallah, you got a fresh coconut to drink from.
On side note, I would never want to get into an argument with these ladies...
fresh coconut.author: Jim C.
fresh coconut.review: This place is the BOMB! Tiny hole in the wall, I think there's like 10 or so seats. The cooks, which seem to be 3 generations of Asian ladies, take no bull and deliver fast, hearty grub. The middle age lady butchers the shiiit out of fresh coconuts you order. Three hard whacks and wallah, you got a fresh coconut to drink from. On side note, I would never want to get into an argument with these ladies...

excerpts: I am also interested in their fresh coconut milk.
Oh they have not seen the last of Eric G.
fresh coconut.author: Eric G.
fresh coconut.review:
This has to be the best new discovery for me in a long time.

I have never had Burmese food until today. I met a friend and we were seated pretty quickly. This place is one long counter and the food is cooked right in front of you. 

On the massive recommendations, I tried the Mango Chicken with a Mexican coke while my friend had the tea salad. She mentioned that the salad "had a kick", and I would say the same for the Mango Chicken. My chicken came on a plate with white rice and crispy fresh stir fried veggies. Nothing was too oily, salty, or spicy. This dish was exactly what I hoped it would be. The big chunks of mango made this dish even better, as I love the taste of mango with chilies. 

The staff was so polite to us given the pace that they have to keep to make sure the line outside does not get too long. This place obviously is popular and for good reason.

Next time I plan to try some noodles because I sat and watched them make dish after dish of a noodle dish which just looked amazing. I am also interested in their fresh coconut milk. Oh they have not seen the last of Eric G.

excerpts: Have a fresh coconut drink to cool the spices.
fresh coconut.author: Tommy K.
fresh coconut.review: Good noodles, try the house noodles with pork. The fried rice was a bit spicy and we finished it all. The spring rolls were fresh with a great peanut dipping sauce. Overall, worth the wait to seat inside and inexpensive. Have a fresh coconut drink to cool the spices.

excerpts: Along with my yummy chow fun, I had fresh fresh coconut juice.
Mmm
..I'm making myself hungry.
If I only lived in the area, this would be by go to "to-go" spot.
The two women who cook, order, clean and own(?)
the place are non-stop and friendly.
I'd love to come back here and try more things on the menu!
fresh coconut.author: Empee P.
fresh coconut.review:
After getting over the extremely long lines at the SF St. Food Festival, my boyfriend and I, ventured down the Mission to Yamo. He'd been before and could not stop talking about their noodles. When we arrived, the place is literally a HOLE in the wall. It's the size of a medium sized kitchen! Literally only sits 8 at the counter and that's it! We waited for a bit but he insisted it was worth it! 

The prices are great with everything at about $5.25 or so. I opted for the house chow fun with beef which was soooo good. I finished the very generous plate. It was oily but what else can you ask for with a place like this. Along with my yummy chow fun, I had fresh fresh coconut juice. Mmm..I'm making myself hungry. If I only lived in the area, this would be by go to "to-go" spot. The two women who cook, order, clean and own(?) the place are non-stop and friendly. I'd love to come back here and try more things on the menu!

excerpts: The fresh coconut is interesting, but wasn't for me because of the aftertaste.
fresh coconut.author: Keith C.
fresh coconut.review:
Yamo is a great place to go for a casual date or by yourself.  Just don't bring an entourage because the place is essentially a hole in the wall that can fit approximately nine people at any given time.  

Food:  4 stars.  I definitely will come back to try more dishes, but thought that the chicken noodle soup was excellent, especially for the price ($5.25, are you out of your mind?).  The soup is a hearty blend of coconut noodle soup with chicken, onions, and cilantro.  it was very flavorful, but don't expect it to be spicy.  The fresh coconut is interesting, but wasn't for me because of the aftertaste.

Service:  4 stars.  Kudos to the charmingly busy yet funny Chinese ladies that work behind the counter.  It may be hard to get their attention at times, but they are fun to watch at work and are friendly with anyone who strikes up a conversation with them.

Atmosphere:  3 stars.  The hole in the wall aspect is a bit charming, but the place is definitely a bit dirty looking.  The crowd can be eccentric at times.  For example, someone waiting in line for a seat started practicing qigong, an internal Chinese meditative practice which uses slow graceful movements similar to tai chi.  

Hits:   Chicken noodle soup.

Misses:  The crowd can be creepy and they're kooky, mysterious and spooky.

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  Burma Superstar, Rangoon, Nan Yang, Mandalay.

excerpts: Wash down the grease with some fresh coconut juice.
And be thankful there are still a few establishments in the Mission that cater to the 'barely getting by' class.
fresh coconut.author: Regina A.
fresh coconut.review:
Think Soup Natzi from Seinfeld.

Check your ego at the front door. Enjoy a bowl of house noodles. Wash down the grease with some fresh coconut juice. And be thankful there are still a few establishments in the Mission that cater to the 'barely getting by' class.

excerpts: For $2.50 they open up a fresh coconut, which you can drink the refreshing water and then scoop out the luscious fresh coconut meat.
fresh coconut.author: Tigre T.
fresh coconut.review:
They know you and address you by your name. They remember my favorite dishes. They always welcome all my friends. All dishes are $5.25, large, colorful and great tasting. The tea leave salad, spring rolls are excellent apetizers. They have vegetarian dishes, house noodles, the large bowls of soups are a great and filling treat especially when the fog sets in. It is always busy and intimate...
Their Burmese kitchen is infused with Indian and Thai flavors. For $2.50 they open up a fresh coconut, which you can drink the refreshing water and then scoop out the luscious fresh coconut meat. 





Please read the street parking signs and don't get a ticket or worse get your car towed due to street cleaning while you're enjoying your affordable dinner.  Public Transportation is available  the #33, 49, 14 stop is right there and 16th St BART is two blocks away.

excerpts: Fresh Coconut Juice - $2.50, Pretty sure everyone has had one of these
but that doesn't make it any less tasty!
It's a real, young coconut with the top cut off served with a straw and a spoon
so you can dig into the coconut meat after you finish the juice.
I say it's way worth it since you could pay that much just for a coconut at the market.
I'm also too afraid of trying this at home again.
fresh coconut.author: Julia T.
fresh coconut.review:
3.5 stars. My friend and I were semi-wandering around the Mission looking for dinner since I already had a motive to try Yamo... When we were close, I excitedly said "ooo let's have some Burmese!" I'm slick like that. ;) As we approached the place, we realized it was probably cash only and I only had $3 in my wallet! Good thing there was an ATM close by. We were also lucky that someone seated by the only empty seat was leaving! We secured our spots and looked over the (VERY grimy) menu. The waitress if you'd like to call her that was very friendly and was patient with our indecisiveness. We ended up with:

Samosas - $3.50, This was actually the spiciest thing I had that night! It's fried right in front of you so it comes out fresh and hot. It's made with some kind of yam and spices but I honestly couldn't taste much because my tongue was in pain! 

Tea Salad - $5.25, It's cheaper but smaller than the ones you'd find in the Richmond District. It's also spicier. The ingredients weren't as colorful and fresh looking as I'm used to. I prefer more of the nutty taste so I was hoping for more sunflower seeds and peanuts. I'd probably skip this one next time.

Fresh Coconut Juice - $2.50, Pretty sure everyone has had one of these but that doesn't make it any less tasty! It's a real, young coconut with the top cut off served with a straw and a spoon so you can dig into the coconut meat after you finish the juice. I say it's way worth it since you could pay that much just for a coconut at the market. I'm also too afraid of trying this at home again. Coconut shells are like rocks!

Mango Chicken - $5.25, with your choice of house noodles or white rice. I got the noodles and they were quite tasty! They were eggy and chewy in the good way. My friend was surprised they had real mango chunks and they were big too! This dish also came with green peppers, bits of chili peppers (so more spice!) and big flavorful chicken chunks. It was good but this dish was also a bit greasy. 

I'm not a fan of spicy food, though I'm getting more tolerable. It helps when all your friends like spice and INSIST that THIS THE TIME I'm going to start liking it. Nope never happened. I still thought Yamo was above average but I wouldn't go out of my way to come back.

excerpts: Quick, tasty and wildly entertaining with tiny long cramped bar seating and bustling women with flaming frypans who'll serve you up a fresh coconut with an unimpressed attitude.
fresh coconut.author: Hemmie L.
fresh coconut.review: I love this place! it doesn't try to be anything that it's not. Quick, tasty and wildly entertaining with tiny long cramped bar seating and bustling women with flaming frypans who'll serve you up a fresh coconut with an unimpressed attitude.

excerpts: (You can also order fresh coconut drink, which they will cut up open for you on the spot!)
The mango chicken with rice was very good.
It didn't feel heavy in your stomach and the vegetables were pretty fresh.
fresh coconut.author: Faye F.
fresh coconut.review:
3.5 stars

I stumbled upon this restaurant when I was blog surfing. This past weekend, my boyfriend and I ventured down mission to find this hole in the wall. The food is absolutely delicious but you WILL have to wait awhile (depending on the number of cooks working and the line of customers) for it. When we arrived, there were 3 female cooks working their butts off for a small line. The place itself can hold maybe 10 sitting customers and the rest order to go. There's no order when serving their customers and it seemed like it's easy for them to forget your order, especially when there's a long line of customers. 

Anyway, my boyfriend and I hadn't eaten all day and we ordered the tea salad, mango chicken, and yamo house noodles with chicken. (You can also order fresh coconut drink, which they will cut up open for you on the spot!) The mango chicken with rice was very good. It didn't feel heavy in your stomach and the vegetables were pretty fresh. My favorite was the tea salad. I didn't see them make it but I think they have this mixture of nuts or something that goes really well with the salad. The house noodles were super garlicky and it was good! 

This is a good place to eat if you have a lot of patience waiting for food but I suggest not to go during lunch rush.

excerpts: doesn't matter...they won't charge you a couple of extra $ for seafood!), and top it off with fresh coconut juice?
fresh coconut.author: Shweta V.
fresh coconut.review:
My new favorite hole in the wall...right here in the Mission! Where else can you get  2 big fresh summer rolls with shrimp for $3.50, dinner entrees for $5.25 (fish/shrimp/tofu...doesn't matter...they won't charge you a couple of extra $ for seafood!), and top it off with fresh coconut juice? Plus, the food is cooked right in front of you, so you know you aren't eating thawed stuff! 

We tried the curry fish (fried fish pieces sauteed with veggies in curry sauce) and curry vegetables with noodles. Both tasted great - noodles were a tad oily though, and don't be surprised if the "curry" dishes have no curry in them (like Thai curries). I was concerned about the fish quality, but hey, I lived to write this review with no stomach upsets! Also, loved that the veg curry had okra. 

The place is small - it's like a little food bar - you seat yourself based on available space, and sit facing the chefs. The ladies who run the place look like they enjoy what they are doing, and IMO, that makes the food better! They are friendly though - make eye contact & smile, and you'll be surprised. However, don't expect much conversation with them...it may look like a bar, but they sure are not chatty. The food rocks, is served fast, and they will not rush you to finish, even though the line outside is a half block long.

excerpts: We ordered fresh coconut, samusas and the mango salad.
I have gone back since and ordered the same.
I don't know much about Burmese
but I do know that this is a chiller spot!
It reminds me of Art's Cafe on Irving.
Cheap, tasy hole in the wall... and who run it?
Little Burmese women.
fresh coconut.author: Janice K.
fresh coconut.review:
A strange friend of mine took me on a foodie date and Yamo was our first stop. We ordered fresh coconut, samusas and the mango salad. I have gone back since and ordered the same. I don't know much about Burmese but I do know that this is a chiller spot! It reminds me of Art's Cafe on Irving. Cheap, tasy hole in the wall... and who run it? Little Burmese women. Girl Power!!!!!!!!!!!!

Oh by the way, there is a wait and it can be brutal at times... Try venturing out during the week at an odd hour.

excerpts: They also have fresh coconut!!
We ordered one ($2.50) and they cut it open and gave us a straw for the coconut water and a spoon to scoop out the coconut flesh.
Dee-lish!
All in all a very yummy satisfying meal, and the pre-tip total came to $16.50!
Would def go back to try the other dishes on the menu.
fresh coconut.author: Humaira M.
fresh coconut.review:
Yum yum yum. Tried to come here two other times (once closed, once there was a line) and glad I finally made it. I thought there'd be a line Saturday at 1pm but there were at least three available stools. There are a total of ten bar stools, in case anyone was wondering. The menu items seem to range from $3.50 to $6ish. 

We ordered the samusas (potato and spice fried goodness) - you get 6 small triangles for $3.50. Then we had the mango chicken and house noodles with beef. It wasn't the most flavorful burmese food I've ever had, but it was still damn good for the price. I wish the house noodles had some sauce. Even after thoroughly mixing, it mostly just tasted like stir fried noodles with really good beef. They should use whatever they marinate the beef with for the sauce. They also have fresh coconut!! We ordered one ($2.50) and they cut it open and gave us a straw for the coconut water and a spoon to scoop out the coconut flesh. Dee-lish! All in all a very yummy satisfying meal, and the pre-tip total came to $16.50! Would def go back to try the other dishes on the menu.

excerpts: Seriously and fresh coconut juice...
I can eat here morning , noon and night..
fresh coconut.author: tramy n.
fresh coconut.review:
Literally a hole in the wall.  
My New Fav. hole in the wall.. Everything is fresh, make in front of you... The line if pretty long, but its worth the wait.. No need to get all dolled up for this place..=)

All you need to know is Yamo house noodles w/beef. For $5.25. Seriously and fresh coconut juice... 
I can eat here morning , noon and night..

excerpts:
Great diversity of dishes and flavors, and even have fresh coconut, opened old school style with a machete.
This place is always packed out the door...
No other place like it!
fresh coconut.author: Daood P.
fresh coconut.review:
One of my favorite local diners.
Small "mom and pop" venue...actually 2 sisters.
They work very hard , 7 days per week.
Great diversity of dishes and flavors, and even have fresh coconut, opened old school style with a machete.
This place is always packed out the door...
No other place like it!

excerpts: But when I actually sit down and eat here I like to treat myself to a fresh coconut drink too.
It's deeelishious!
I love all the curry dishes and they are so wonderful for take out.
This is an excellent go-to-place, quick fix and
anyone in the Mission will tell you, just a simple neighborhood good eats for everyday.
fresh coconut.author: Christina C.
fresh coconut.review:
Although the food is probably really only 4 stars ---  the 3 ladies who work until 10pm almost every night AND the awesome prices gives it the extra "happy i'm not broke if I eat here" star!  It really is good food and you can't beat $5.25! holla!

I don't know why everyone keeps comparing this place to Burma.  It's not really meant to be a sit down, let's chat and have wine kind of dinner restaurant.  It's more like a bar that serves Burmese food rather than alcohol. But when I actually sit down and eat here I like to treat myself to a fresh coconut drink too.  It's deeelishious!  I love all the curry dishes and they are so wonderful for take out.  This is an excellent go-to-place, quick fix and anyone in the Mission will tell you, just a simple neighborhood good eats for everyday.

excerpts: Speaking of coconuts, nothing soothes a throat full of Burmese spiced noodles like a fresh coconut, hacked open right in front of you by a sexagenarian who could definitely kick your ass.
fresh coconut.author: Melissa T.
fresh coconut.review:
Oh, Yamo... I fear you will continue to be an amazing deal on super awesome food until you are slowly overtaken by the masses as they crowd me out of your precious ten square feet of seating!

If you've ever been to Art's Cafe in the Inner Sunset, the setup is similar: twenty-odd feet of bar stool seating where you are served piping hot meals while you watch them being made, all for less than the price of a cocktail at one of the many hip new joints down the street.

The ladies who run Yamo are entertaining to watch as they hustle hungry diners in and out of the joint, coconuts and cold noodles flying all the while.  Speaking of coconuts, nothing soothes a throat full of Burmese spiced noodles like a fresh coconut, hacked open right in front of you by a sexagenarian who could definitely kick your ass.

The cold noodles are worth trying, but my vote would have to be for the mango chicken.  The spring rolls we ordered last night were on the bad side of average, but the entrees are delicious, generously portioned, and crazy cheap.  A meal for two will run you under $20 for both entrees, an appetizer, and two coconuts, with leftovers to spare, or you can grab a single entree for only $5.25.

The wait is never too long (for now...) but ordering to go is always a good idea, unless you're staying in the area for other reasons.  They're also open for lunch -- smaller crowd, no wait, and fresh coconuts on a hot summer afternoon -- What's not to love?

excerpts: I had Tea Salad without dry shrimps, on my request, veggie spring roll, like the peanut sauce and a fresh coconut.
fresh coconut.author: Yi Z.
fresh coconut.review:
I read all the review before I hit Yamo.
     Actually I looked for it about 6 months ago and did not find the place (I know, shame on me).
     I can see both sides of the story on Yamo.  So I let go of my high and low expectation and decided to simply experience Yamo as it is yesterday evening, when I was craving greasy noodles with lots of vegetables.

And I did enjoy it, the "Mommy" and Auntie made me Yamo noodles with vegetables and tofu, no even on the menu.  I had Tea Salad without dry shrimps, on my request, veggie spring roll, like the peanut sauce and a fresh coconut.  I cannot say for my ex for his Mango chicken with rice, but I did enjoy my share very much.

Love the little cave, smoke alarm going off from time to time, because it reminded me when I was cooking Chinese food in my own studio in Madison, WI.  

I guess it is more of a personal projection thing, I wanted mom made stir fried noodles, watching mom cooking and the feelings going with it.  And I got it all.  Seeing daughter and mom and aunts are busing preparing meal for you is comforting some times for some one.

So if this is what you are looking for, you may be very satisfied, like I was ;)

excerpts: Tea Salad, House Noodles with Beef and Broccoli and Chicken Soup (with coconut milk) and don't forget to get the whole fresh coconut as well.
fresh coconut.author: Anna C.
fresh coconut.review:
Yummy comfort food.  Like eating in your Aunt's kitchen.  

Favorites: Tea Salad, House Noodles with Beef and Broccoli and Chicken Soup (with coconut milk) and don't forget to get the whole fresh coconut as well.  Just try not to splash the person next to you with coconut juice while attacking the flesh like I did.  

 All of this would cost you less than $20.  How the heck do they make money?  I like Burma.

excerpts: peanut sauce is awesome), mango tofu, and fresh coconut juice!
fresh coconut.author: Suzanne S.
fresh coconut.review:
Yamo is not the best Burmese food around, but it's a great place for a no frills meal that is fresh, tasty, made to order, and *cheap*! It's a wonderful little oasis of tortilla-less cheap food in the mission.

The place is very unique, and some people may be turned off by the fact that it is literally a hole-in-the-wall.  For those people, I suggest taking it to go and eating it at home or in one of the nearby parks.

Despite the Tu-Lan-esque vibe, the food is always super fresh and not as greasy as you  might imagine (although I can't speak for meat dishes ) They make everything, even the fresh springrolls,  for you right in front of your eyes. And they've always agreed to make anything I've requested vegetarian for me, which means they fill it with a wonderful mix of familiar and unusual fresh veggies, herbs and/or tofu. yum.

Try: tea salad, black bean tofu, veggie curry, fresh spring rolls (peanut sauce is awesome), mango tofu, and fresh coconut juice!

All apps are $3.25 (and the spring rolls by themselves can be a great light lunch), entrees are $5.25. 

don't be turned off by the fact that it looks like it's closed or abandoned. it's definitely worth a try, especially if you live in the area.

excerpts: Fresh coconut juice (cut open right in front of you) and hot tea are nice accompaniments.
fresh coconut.author: Dave S.
fresh coconut.review:
Finding this restaurant only by walking by was a true statement of a "great find".

A small joint that has maybe a total of ten counter seats, its pumping with a mom & pop (its actually two sisters and a brother) vibe and just cranking out the food!

I can honestly say I've been here numerous times already and I have never been disappointed. Super-consistentcy is what Yamo has to offer. 

My personal favorite is the Black Bean Fish- white cod fish lightly battered and sauteed with bell peppers and onions in black bean sauce.You have your choice of egg noddles or steamed rice. 

Another great dish is the Curry Chicken- chunks of chicken, potatoes, onions and a mild spicy curry sauce that seeps into your rice so you can just lap your plate clean.

Other favorites I've tried, Chicken Salad- crispy cabbage with chicken, crispy garlic and some other secret spices and nuts. Samosas are very tasty but I did find they were frozen prior, but none the less its a small operation. Pot stickers are another good one if your just craving apps or adding it to your meal. Fresh coconut juice (cut open right in front of you) and hot tea are nice accompaniments.

My last suggestion is that Yamo should be part of a list of restaurants you have in mind trying, because the line could be out the door or they maybe not enough seats for your crew or date. Just keep this in mind, otherwise To-Go is your other option! 

Bon appetit!

excerpts: They also have delicious whole coconuts full of fresh coconut milk for $2.
fresh coconut.author: T.Z. R.
fresh coconut.review:
Yummy. Utilitarian. Cheap.

I am addicted to the tofu spring rolls. $3.50 for two enormous delicious food logs. Ask for extra peanut sauce because you need it. OM NOM NOM NOM.

They also have delicious whole coconuts full of fresh coconut milk for $2. When you close your eyes, they have the magical effect of transforming this narrow dingy place into Polynesian paradise.

Also, if you're vegetarian like me, don't feel too intimidated by their limited vegetarian options. They make most things to order, so you can request almost anything on the menu with tofu instead of meat.

excerpts:
Fresh Coconut $2.50
 - 4 stars
 - All my life
, I thought coconuts had a stronger taste because coconut flakes used in cakes had such a strong flavor.
What a surprise to find the taste was so subtle, if you had told me it was a different fruit, I would have believed you.
So light, refreshing.
Loved it.
I also liked that it came in a full coconut rather than a glass.
It was fun to see, and we could scrape the inside for the thicker fruity part of the coconut.
fresh coconut.author: Tetsu N.
fresh coconut.review:
Today was my very first experience eating Burmese food, and from what I'm told, everything here is very authentic, or at least authentic from the perspective that identically prepared delectable delights can be had over there.

Meeting a very old friend from back in NY who happened to be in town, we went to Yamo based on her SO's recommendation.

What a treat!  I love experiencing new kinds of food!

The restaurant itself is ridiculously small, with only some limited counter seating, maybe seating 10 or so.  The restaurant looks like it has been around for a while too, and was incredibly popular.  The line was constant and always out the door, tho luckily, it seems that most who get their food here have are well aware that getting takeout is a much wiser choice.  

And the prices!  Excellent prices for the cheap bastard in me.  My friend and I had three dishes, a coconut drink, and a soda for under $20.  For light eaters on a budget, one dish and a drink would be about $7 combined.  Big eaters won't go broke either.  

On to the food.

Tea Salad:  $5.25
 - 4.5 stars
 - Tea leave, cabbage, fresh tomato, oion, dried shrimp & variety of fried bean, nuts and sesame seeds.
 - Wow, by far my favorite dish of the day.  This taste and texture explosion is so good I wish they served it in meal portions, but alas, they only served it as a relatively small and light plate.  More like an appetizer.  It's got a variety of crunchy textures, including what feels like tiny croutons though with a saltier taste (I'm assuming it's the fried bean but might of been the dried shrimp), and the nuts (which I'm guessing may be peanuts), and the more raw veggie crunch of the cabbage.  There are also several software textures as well as the watery tomato texture.   And the taste?  Wow, there's a raw veggie tanginess to it, subtly to it, saltiness to it....Really, explosion is the only way to describe.  And it does this so cleanly and lightly that none of the tastes are overbearing.  This is a MUST ORDER at this small little hole in the wall.

Fish Chowder Noodle Soup $5.25
 - 2 stars
 - Soup chowder with rice noodles, shredded fish, and onions, garnished with Fried Yellowbeans and Cilantro
 - This wasn't bad, but it didn't strike me as very inspired.  The sauce was a thick reddish sauce reminiscent in texture of thick Chinese sauces poured over meats and rice.  Sorry, there should be a better explanation but I can't imagine what it is.  The noodles were very very well cooked and watery, almost like pho noodles, only it didn't seem to be the way these noodles were supposed to be.  The taste was subtle...almost too subtle.  Perhaps, tho, I'm being a little harsh because of the great tastes of the other dishes, but really, I wouldn't order this again.

Yamo Cold Noodles $5.25
 - 3.5 stars
 - Cold noodles mixed with house special flavor, onions, cabbage, cucumbers, and chicken
 - Pretty good dish.  The noodles are similar to chow mein noodles but without the glossy oiliness.  This was their spicy dish, but it's more tangy than spicy.  The chicken was covered in a thick, almost dry red sauce with lots of full sized peppers (like the dry peppers found in jars at the table at pizza restaurants).  This dish was also full of different flavors giving a nice complexity to the dish.  I would order this again.

Fresh Coconut $2.50
 - 4 stars
 - All my life, I thought coconuts had a stronger taste because coconut flakes used in cakes had such a strong flavor.  What a surprise to find the taste was so subtle, if you had told me it was a different fruit, I would have believed you.  So light, refreshing.  Loved it.  I also liked that it came in a full coconut rather than a glass.  It was fun to see, and we could scrape the inside for the thicker fruity part of the coconut.    Yeah, I'd order this again, just for the novelty of it.  

Grass Jelly drink $1.00
 - 2.5 stars
 - This is a can drink.  Not carbonated, with bits of jelly in it.  It's similar in taste to Chinese turtle shell gelatin desserts.  I'd drink it again if it was served, but probably wouldn't ever be my first choice.  Still, it tasted like it was probably a healthy drink.

Though we didn't order it, the customer sitting next to us order what I think (just guessing mind you) is the Yamo House Noodles.  That looked really good.  Basically several bite sized pieces of chicken (looking like it was cooked in a thick dark sauce) over a bed of the chow mein like noodles.  It sure as heck looked good.

All in all, this place was pretty good.  If I would have rated it a straight 3.5, I'd got to 4, but given that all the food combined average below a 3.5, I'll have to go with a 3 today.

Except...the price!  The price is so good, that adds a half star right there, pushing the average up and making this place an easy 4 stars.

So with that said, Yay!  I'm a fan!

excerpts: Some greasy noodles and a fresh coconut water = perfect hangover meal.
fresh coconut.author: Jason J.
fresh coconut.review: I was in town for a week or so and this place was awesome! Great Price, the noodles w/beef were my favorite and the salad was great too! A very small seating area but well worth the wait if there is a line. Some greasy noodles and a fresh coconut water = perfect hangover meal.

excerpts: No beer, so have a drink beforehand or better yet get a fresh coconut milk.
fresh coconut.author: Scott M.
fresh coconut.review:
I LOVE Yamo.  (Not sure why it's "Thai Kitchen" -- I thought it was Burmese?)

Anyhoo, you walk in to this 300sf, long, skinny place and you've got all you need: 8 stools at a bar that's 2 feet away from the kitchen where they're prepping the goodness.  

It's a family run place, and when I went in there tonight, I enjoyed talking w/some of the kids.  They were hanging out, playing cards, and helping prep.

Prices are cheap ($5.25 for amazing tea or mango salad), $3.25 for spring rolls, and $5.25 for main dishes like Yamo noodles (yum), chicken coconut soup, and all kinds of other goodness.  No beer, so have a drink beforehand or better yet get a fresh coconut milk.

I give them 3 months before they break their lease and move to bigger digs.  It's that good.  A cheaper, closer (if you live near the Mission), and just about as good version of Burmese Superstar.

excerpts: Oh, and fresh coconut.
fresh coconut.author: Judy P.
fresh coconut.review:
For a hole-in-the-wall place, the food was AWESOME! My two foodie best friends had mentioned this place twice before I actually ventured out to Yamo's with one of them. I must had been the end of lunch hour since it was packed when we got in there. You pretty much have to sit down and grab a seat right away. I ordered the Yamo House Noodles with chicken and it was exactly what I have been craving for a while. I love the type of noodles they used. Barely seen them in other places.  My friend got the chicken coconut noodle soup. Both dishes were very delicious and all for $5.25 each. We also got six samosas for $3.50. 

Another big thing is the tea salad. Didn't try it but might next time. Even though I hate bean sprouts.

Oh, and fresh coconut. Like an actual coconut. 

At these prices, I might be swayed to drive down there more often.

excerpts: We also got Tea Leaf Salad and fresh coconut.
My plate was not bad but really taste like chinese rather than burmese.
Curry prawn is ok.
GF likes the salad but for me, it's not enough tea leaf at all.
fresh coconut.author: Win S.
fresh coconut.review:
I was excited when my GF found out about this place since I am burmese and really love burmese food. Rating and review look good. So time to go try their food. We went there, the place looks ok. GF seems to like it. The food is not authentic taste of burmese food. Please don't be like Burma Super Star, all fusion food which was a little disappointing. The taste was adjusted for American pallet. 

I ordered Mango Chicken. GF ordered Curry Prawns. We also got Tea Leaf Salad and fresh coconut. My plate was not bad but really taste like chinese rather than burmese. Curry prawn is ok. GF likes the salad but for me, it's not enough tea leaf at all. Taste is good though. 

Overall, we enjoyed the food. For the price, it's pretty worth it and worth a visit.

excerpts: My brother had the fresh coconut, which I have to get next time when I come back for more tea salad.
Even fullness doesn't stop the craving for Yamo's goodness.
fresh coconut.author: Pat L.
fresh coconut.review: Good time.  Had a cold can of sweet grass jelly drink, and enjoyed this cave oasis on a hot saturday at noon, after hustling around the neighborhood in the sun doing my saturday morning biz.  My House Noodles with tofu instead of chicken came lightning-fast.  It was a simple meal and simply perfect.  My brother had the fresh coconut, which I have to get next time when I come back for more tea salad.  Even fullness doesn't stop the craving for Yamo's goodness.

excerpts: The Yamo house cold noodles with tofu with fresh coconut juice is my usual order, I've tried other dishes but this one is by far my favorite.
I love that nothing is over $5.25, sometimes there is a small wait
but its so worth it.
