The women behind the counter aren't very friendly but what do you expect that place is always BUSY!
So definitely come with patience and an appetite!
fresh coconut.author: Jen R.
fresh coconut.review: One of my favorite afternoon lunch spots! I have gone here numerous times and have never been disappointed. Their tea leaf salad is to die for, I constantly find myself craving it. The Yamo house cold noodles with tofu with fresh coconut juice is my usual order, I've tried other dishes but this one is by far my favorite. I love that nothing is over $5.25, sometimes there is a small wait but its so worth it. The women behind the counter aren't very friendly but what do you expect that place is always BUSY! So definitely come with patience and an appetite!

excerpts: Get house noodles with beef and a fresh coconut.
It can't be beat.
Never substitute, always say as little as possible.
Cash only.
fresh coconut.author: Laci W.
fresh coconut.review: Get house noodles with beef and a fresh coconut. It can't be beat. Never substitute, always say as little as possible. Cash only.

excerpts: You might have a hard time getting a water refill but everything else is cool--plus you're better off ordering a fresh coconut to sip on anyway--with these prices you can afford it.
fresh coconut.author: Justin G.
fresh coconut.review:
Grimy. Small. Hot. Tasty.

OK. I want to give this place five stars, because the food is incredible, affordable and the atmosphere is cool.

I've had almost everything on the menu and there's nothing I wouldn't rate as being anything less that 4/5. The Fish Chowder and the Tea Leaf Salad are unreal--so good.

The service is fairly prompt and the ladies are pretty nice. You might have a hard time getting a water refill but everything else is cool--plus you're better off ordering a fresh coconut to sip on anyway--with these prices you can afford it.

It's also the ultimate place for a cheap date. You'll probably drop less than $20 on two entrees, appetizers and drinks combined.

The only thing that drops my review down to four stars is the level of cleanliness here. It's totally filthy. The menus have a layer of grime on them that defies belief. Order your food and go was your hands, trust me. Also don't look at the knobs on the stove, concentrate on how rad your food is and the inevitable conversation you'll have with the person squished in next to you and you'll have a good time.

excerpts: Definitely try the tea-salad, house noodles, they also have fresh coconut-milk and coke in glass bottles.
Every entree is 5.25.
hot damn!
At one point, another woman came down a ladder out of the ceiling to help the main cook, without even a hint of irony...absolutely amazing.
fresh coconut.author: Carlisle H.
fresh coconut.review:
I created my yelp account because of this incredible establishment.  It's places like this that remind me of why San Francisco is such an amazing place to call home.  Yamo is the epitomy of Dive.  It is a beacon to which all dives should aspire.  
Everything about this place is perfect, dive-wise.  It scores 5 stars on every dive category: appearance, price, hours, service, quality, and memory-making.  It's the kind of place you would normally walk past and wonder 'christ on a bicycle, why would anyone eat here'.  But as they say, you can't judge a book by it's asshole.  Or is it, never lick a gift horse in the ass?  I can't remember, either way, the point being, get inside.  Once inside you get the picture.  No tables, only a counter with seating for about 10.  The cook/waitress/host/bus-girl was stellar.   Everything cooked right in front of you so you can see how they do it.  You'll wonder what the ingredients are and you'll want to try it out at home yourself, if only you had some of the stuff in those funny looking jars.  Definitely try the tea-salad, house noodles, they also have fresh coconut-milk and coke in glass bottles.  Every entree is 5.25.  hot damn!   At one point, another woman came down a ladder out of the ceiling to help the main cook, without even a hint of irony...absolutely amazing.

excerpts: When that, plus the black bean fish, house noodles with chicken, samusas, fresh coconut juice, and a soda costs you just over $22, you end up wondering if you're still in the city.
Not the best tasting ever, but still fresh, very tasty and cheap.
Love it.
fresh coconut.author: Maximillian M.
fresh coconut.review: Probably one of the most awesome hole-in-the-wall joints in the entire city! The tea leaf salad is particularly awesome. When that, plus the black bean fish, house noodles with chicken, samusas, fresh coconut juice, and a soda costs you just over $22, you end up wondering if you're still in the city. Not the best tasting ever, but still fresh, very tasty and cheap. Love it.

excerpts: ORDER A FRESH COCONUT to accompany your meal!
fresh coconut.author: Yvonne P.
fresh coconut.review:
talk about hole-in-the-walls.  this place is literally a hallway made into a restaurant!  against one wall is the kitchen.  against another wall is...well, your back b/c while you'll be sitting 5 feet from the 4 women cooking and serving you food, your back will be against the wall.  no, i am not exaggerating!  

with that said, this place can be uncomfortable and elbow room is hard to come by, but the yamo noodles made me forget that only two inches separated me and my stranger neighbor.  YUM!   

the tea leaf salad, as everyone else says, is delish, but not suitable for those who can't eat spicy (like me).  but there is a solution...ORDER A FRESH COCONUT to accompany your meal!

alas, there are cons:  not the cleanest place and definitely uses oil way too sparingly.  (check the plate after you've cleared it...not for those at risk of heart disease.)  lastly, small portions!! i'd rather pay a bit more for a bigger portion to really satisfy my tummy.

excerpts: follow that with a sweet fresh coconut and you are good to go.
fresh coconut.author: pizzazz g.
fresh coconut.review:
i found yamo accidentally, cruising up mission to country station. i had never even noticed it before, but there it was, a ghostly apparition. it was a hole in the wall for sure, and i immediately felt like i was back in asia, where food is cheap, well seasoned, and satisfying. the tea salad is definitely the standout dish, i order it every time i go there. with all its little crunchy, nutty surprises i could probably eat a few pounds of it before my mouth got bored. follow that with a sweet fresh coconut and you are good to go.

the ladies who work there are friendly and pretty fast. i've gotten there when it was full and thought, "oh, shit. this will take forever," but i've never had a really long wait like you would at the superstar. plus it's in my hood! and really, it is such a deal, you could order several dishes and totally pig out for less than $20. for two people! it's probably not for everyone, and it's definitely not gourmet, but it is good cheap eats.

excerpts: and they serve fresh coconut for your drinking pleasure.
It's sure well worth a try!
fresh coconut.author: Paola W.
fresh coconut.review: Yamo is not pretty...that's for sure! but they prepare some mean noodles for dirt cheap and they serve fresh coconut for your drinking pleasure. It's sure well worth a try!

excerpts: I loved the curry tofu over noodles, and the fresh coconut drink is always delightful.
fresh coconut.author: Pat E.
fresh coconut.review:
This is a bare bones place when it comes to decor and presentation, but as a lunch counter sort of joint, it does the job well.

I loved the curry tofu over noodles, and the fresh coconut drink is always delightful.

Prices are beyond reasonable - two people can eat for $20, and eat well.

excerpts: Fresh coconut milk for $2.50
and they cut it right in front of you.
Feels like a 1950's malt shop, only the super tiny Burmese version.
I love how small it is.
I feel transported to a simpler time with delicious food at reasonable prices.
I hesitate to even write this review, fearing that others will discover this secret delicious treasure.
But here I go anyway.
Yamo.
I love your food.
Go here, but keep it under your hat.
fresh coconut.author: m m.
fresh coconut.review: It is so delicious.  Also I like the small counter.  Feels very mom and pop. I've been ordering take out a lot lately because of the line running out the door.  Fresh coconut milk for $2.50 and they cut it right in front of you.  Feels like a 1950's malt shop, only the super tiny Burmese version.  I love how small it is.  I feel transported to a simpler time with delicious food at reasonable prices.  I hesitate to even write this review, fearing that others will discover this secret delicious treasure.  But here I go anyway.  Yamo.  I love your food.  Go here, but keep it under your hat. :)

excerpts: Total paid for our meal is only $21.25 (excluding tips but including one Fanta and one Diet Coke for a buck each!)
fanta.author: Reyner T.
fanta.review:
I've been wanting to try out this new place for quite a while now and I went there for the first time today with a friend of mine.

It's Wednesday night around 7ish and we had to wait about 15 minutes to get seated for 2 people. Not bad... 

We ordered samusas (kinda like triangle fried mashed potatoes) and man.. it was delicious!! especially with the spicy sweet and sour red sauce... YUMMY!!

We also ordered 3 dishes to share: Yamo's pork house garlic noodle, mango chicken, and curry beef. All of the 3 dishes are amazing even though they are on the greasy side! My favorite one is their house garlic noodle with pork. The pork is so tasty and delicious!

The mango chicken is good but ehhh... it's alrite. It's more on the plain taste side.

THE PRICE IS SO FREAKING AFFORDABLE!

All of the appetizers are $3.25 & all of the main dishes is only $5.75 including ride and/or noodle!

Total paid for our meal is only $21.25 (excluding tips but including one Fanta and one Diet Coke for a buck each!)

I love this place!! I'll be back but this time I think I will just take it to go... I don't want the greasy food smell stuck in my clothes & my hair! LoL!!

excerpts: but you'll miss out maybe sitting next to someone who says "Fahhhnta," instead of "Fanta.
fanta.author: Jon A.
fanta.review:
if this Indiana balcony I'm on was just a Spring retreat and not full-time living...it'd make me feel a whole lot better being 1,945 miles away from Yamo. From a place that makes me feel like I can walk in alone and feel like I did when I'd wander into my Grandma's kitchen as a kid. 

But my Granny ain't know nothin' 'bout this Tea Salad! 

If I ate too much of this fine, not-too-wet, not-too-dry, just enough peanut salad, I'd start yammering Burmese on the streets. 

Wait...maybe that's my destiny...eat enough of this tea salad to be inspired to overthrow the Myanmar government and restore Burma? 

Wait, then we wouldn't have Burmese refugees that open many a Yamo. A crux!

Most of the time...there was a line...but there are only what? 11 seats? Your match.com date will be queasy if you show any signs of indecision. But again...be prepared for a bit of wait...play Bear, Ninja Cowboy.

Keep your party 2 or less or you'll just be plain troubled and will end up ordering take out, which is well & good but you'll miss out maybe sitting next to someone who says "Fahhhnta," instead of "Fanta."

Chicken came off slightly dry but I expected such with the flash quick fry they gave it. 

Embrace the dive-feel the same way you embrace the dive feel of The Attic. 

Don't be afraid to chat up the cooks either...they're not as austere as you think...warm, really, just terse. And terse is good, because on with the Yamo food! On with the tea salad and Hot House Noodles! 

Wiley cheap too, as in $6 for dinner.

excerpts: When you sit down, they have a variety of sauces to spice up your dish.
up.author: Christopher L.
up.review:
There is usually a line here because the only seating they have is a bar which fits around 10 people, so it's pretty small. Your best chances of getting something from Yamo is if you get take out or if you come off peak eating hours.

The reason I love this place is because the value is really good for what you can get. I usually get the Yamo House Noodles which comes with a choice of chicken, beef, pork and something else. The house noodles are prepared in a simple manner. It is noodles, fried garlic, green onions with your choice of meat and is fried together really quickly. When you sit down, they have a variety of sauces to spice up your dish.

They serve various other noodle and rice dishes. Their tea salad is also pretty good too! I'd say this place is a mix of Burmese and Chinese food.

Yeah the prices are really good too, with most dishes costing less than $7 and they have appetizers for $3 - 5! So cheap! I come here when I want something quick, cheap and good to eat.

I've been here a few times and it used to be better before! I think it's gotten slightly worse since they've grown in popularity, but is still a decent place.

excerpts: but I had a pleasant experience with the woman who rang me up for my takeout.
She was smiley and kind
up.author: Hana S.
up.review:
A lot of these reviews seem lower than average because of the rushed service / not cheerful waitstaff but I had a pleasant experience with the woman who rang me up for my takeout. She was smiley and kind, I guess if you dine in they rush you but considering the wait I've seen outside you should be considerate that they're just trying to optimize for profits and feed as many hungry folks as possible. 

I got the house noodles with beef and was a little disappointed by the amount of beef I got, but $6.50 for a takeout order of noodles = one of the more affordable meals you can get in this area now.

excerpts: The little chicken pieces that were there were clearly just hacked up bits.
up.author: Gabriel H.
up.review:
This place is quite charming. It's like a tiny Asian diner. While the prices are cheap, it's mostly because there's not that much meat in dishes. 

The service here is really rude, but comically rude. Think Seinfeld Soup Nazi. Theres one mean lady that doesnt give a shit, she's the one that takes orders and serves you. The other lady is cooking, she's vaguely nicer but doesn't speak much English.

The House Noodle with Beef was actually very tasty. It was mostly egg noodles but it was very flavorful with garlic and soy. It tasted even better with pickled chilies!

Samosas were crispy and fresh out of the fryer. The filling and flavor were just alright.

The Chicken Curry was okay, bordering on mediocre. It was mostly fried potatoes in a basic curry sauce. The little chicken pieces that were there were clearly just hacked up bits.

I tried asking for a spoon in Mandarin, but the lady gave me a glare that made me think that they don't speak it. The strange thing was that they were alternating between Mandarin and Toisan/Cantonese. 

I'm not sure I'd come here again. I enjoyed the noodles, and the prices were cheap, but I do think I'd get more bang for my buck (and more protein) just getting a carne Asada Mission burrito.

excerpts: and I get up from the counter to exit the premises.
She mumbles in anger and in a good volume tells us GET OUT!!
Ok!
Bye, Felecia!!
I guess I got the full dining experience LOL.
up.author: Glyde W.
up.review: It's been a couple months since I first tried this place and decided to go today for some beef-noods and tea salad. Sat at the counter with a friend waiting for our order. I decided to snap a photo of my food and a nice big flame from the wok. So, Asian auntie decided to yell at me... "HEYYYY WHAT ARE YOU DOING?!!!?!" I casually and calmly respond.. "Taking a picture" she gives me a mean mug for a good 30secs. The old me would've fed into her anger and yell back but, nah. I just kept eating as I thought it was amusing you would get so heated over a photo ‍. Payed the bill and as my friend and I get up from the counter to exit the premises. She mumbles in anger and in a good volume tells us GET OUT!!  Ok! Bye, Felecia!! I guess I got the full dining experience LOL.

excerpts: We were just coming to pick up food.
We placed our order over the phone, and the lady was pretty abrupt with all our orders.
up.author: Jackie C.
up.review:
My friend and I were trying to find a cost-affordable take-out spot for our small group, and since Yamo was nearly, dropped by here. The seating area is small, so I would suggest take-out if you're a larger group. We were just coming to pick up food. We placed our order over the phone, and the lady was pretty abrupt with all our orders. Entering in, we saw that it was basically a two person show for taking orders and cooking, so can understand the abruptness especially during a busy dinner time.

We ordered the tea salad, yamo house noodles with beef, and curry chicken. I am giving Yamo 2 stars for the food. The tea salad was covered with too much sauce, so couldn't really figure out what I was eating with all the sweetness. And it was a pretty small portion for tea salad. The house noodles were a bit too stuck together, but the beef was pretty tasty. And the curry chicken was a bit too bland for my taste. But it was extremely cost affordable. It was only $6 per dish..so think it averaged $19? So if you want a cost affordable meal, come here. But if you want some good Burmese food, then I suggest going elsewhere. Overall, a one time meal and will be getting my Burmese food elsewhere next time.

excerpts: It's cheap, and that might be the only upside but definitely not cheap enough to make up for everything else.
up.author: Sarah G.
up.review:
Yuck!! Part of me feels horrible for writing this review but honestly I wish this review existed before I walked way too far for this.

Food is tasteless. Burmese is one of my favorite foods and I love it for its rich flavors. This place was so so so bland. 

Service is horrendous. The girl at the counter is flat out rude and dismissive, almost as if it's her schtick. But it's off putting and really not cute.

The place is filthy. I by no means have high standards for ambiance when there is good food involved (my favorite Burmese place is nothing fancy at all) but this place is dirty. You can watch them prepare all the food and I literally saw utensils being reused and put back in little nooks. THEN an exterminator came in and started doing a routine inspection and collection, so disgusting. 

It's cheap, and that might be the only upside but definitely not cheap enough to make up for everything else.

excerpts: You sit at a counter, elbow-to-elbow, with up to 8 other patrons; the food is made right in front of you; and the decor is, well, a mix of peeling paint and smoke stains.
up.author: Yves L.
up.review:
This place must accompany the dictionary entry for hole in the wall. You sit at a counter, elbow-to-elbow, with up to 8 other patrons; the food is made right in front of you; and the decor is, well, a mix of peeling paint and smoke stains.

But the food is probably some of the cheapest in the city. For $6.25 I had the House Noodles with Beef. (You have a choice of chicken or pork instead.) Filling with simple flavours: a combination of garlic, oil, and salt that will leave you wishing they didn't charge for bottled water. The meat portion is relatively small but the generous portion of noodles left me satisfied.

The service wasn't terrible so much as it was nonexistent. I felt largely ignored by the ladies working there... which was fine, since it let me focus on the food. I didn't experience being yelled at for having my phone out, as some reviews suggest, but I made sure to only take a photo of my food when their backs were turned.

Expect a 5-10 minute wait during lunch rush. Cash only.

excerpts: The lady (I am not going to call her a waitress), picks up the dirty dishes, uses the discarded napkins to kind of wipe some of the dribbles on the counter away.
I thought, "huh, she'll be back with a rag,
right?
Ah, no.
The next thing she said was What do you want?
We ordered.
She said, "That's all?
" yes.
We sat at the end of the counter, farthest from the door.
There was an open garbage bin near us, and it did not have a cover.
We could smell garbage our whole time there.
This paired with the rude service, dirty countertop, just had me saying, I'm not coming back here.
The way I figure, if they don't care about cleaning what the customer is eating on, it makes me wonder how much they care about cleaning things the customer may not see.
I don't care how cheap the food is, I'm not going back.
You can go if you're curious.
Don't take a date.
up.author: Jason P.
up.review:
I'm not afraid of germs. But even I noticed this would make most people say to themselves, "uh, where are we eating." Let's start with the good.

The food is cheap. You could get an entree for less than $7. The food is tasty. Not great, not bad. But it tastes fine. 

Now for the rest of the review: 8 seats at a counter. OK, I can deal with that. We sat down just as other customers left. So we saw their dirty dishes, their discarded, cheap napkins, and soup dribbles on the counter. that is understandable, they just left. The lady (I am not going to call her a waitress), picks up the dirty dishes, uses the discarded napkins to kind of wipe some of the dribbles on the counter away. I thought, "huh, she'll be back with a rag, right?" Ah, no. The next thing she said was What do you want? We ordered. She said, "That's all?" yes. We sat at the end of the counter, farthest from the door. There was an open garbage bin near us, and it did not have a cover. We could smell garbage our whole time there. This paired with the rude service, dirty countertop, just had me saying, I'm not coming back here. The way I figure, if they don't care about cleaning what the customer is eating on, it makes me wonder how much they care about cleaning things the customer may not see. I don't care how cheap the food is, I'm not going back. You can go if you're curious. Don't take a date.

excerpts:
Some things to note: 
-Super tiny hole in the wall, pretty easy to miss if you don't look up.
-Cash only!
The lady who works there explicitly said, "no money, then you can leave" as she waves her hand towards the door.
Pretty hilarious.
NO SHAME.
-Menu is pretty small, couple appetizers for $4.50 a plate, rice plates and noodles for $6.25.
Just a heads up to anyone who ventures in here, this place is run by two older ladies who speak just enough English.
They're not the best with manners and won't greet you with a welcoming hello, nor a friendly goodbye.
You will literally walk in, cramp yourself down at the bar, and order.
up.author: Ava F.
up.review:
Came here on a random day for lunch and was pleasantly surprised. 

Some things to note: 
-Super tiny hole in the wall, pretty easy to miss if you don't look up. 
-Cash only! The lady who works there explicitly said, "no money, then you can leave" as she waves her hand towards the door. Pretty hilarious. NO SHAME. 
-Menu is pretty small, couple appetizers for $4.50 a plate, rice plates and noodles for $6.25.
-They give good portions of noodles, but proteins they're pretty selfish with.

Ordered...
-Fresh spring rolls: 1 order comes with 2 full rolls. These were decent, nothing to rave about. The peanut sauce was a bit bland and lacked that thick, sweet yet nutty flavor. But for $4.50? Can't complaint that much.
-House noodles with beef: these were delicious, I'd order them again. Noodles were cooked perfectly, sprigs of cilantro and green onion for the fresh crunch. Beef was salty but paired really well with the plain noodles. I do have to point out that these are a bit on the oiler side, and the amount of beef they gave was nowhere near proportionate to the amount of noodles.

Just a heads up to anyone who ventures in here, this place is run by two older ladies who speak just enough English. They're not the best with manners and won't greet you with a welcoming hello, nor a friendly goodbye. You will literally walk in, cramp yourself down at the bar, and order. When you're done eating, they will shoo you away so that other customers can grab a seat. 

I didn't mind the nature of their actions. I came for the cheap delicious food, filled my stomach, and left.

excerpts: so it honestly ended up being kind of dry and flavorless.
But even at that price, and given the hype, the food really doesn't measure up and it doesn't merit a return visit for me.
up.author: Jason W.
up.review:
I heard the hype. Amazing food and terrible service. In the end, it was decent food and terrible service.

Like other reviews have mentioned, it's a no-nonsense lady who provides service and cooks. If you come here, come for the food and don't have any expectations for the service. Best to know what you want before you even walk in.

Food:
Mango Chicken: Honestly just a ton of rice with some snap peas, mango and chicken. The stir fry wasn't even that flavorful and there wasn't enough sauce to pair with the rice so it honestly ended up being kind of dry and flavorless. If you're looking for something really light to eat this is a good choice.

House Noodles with Beef: Now this dish actually has some flavor even though it's a bit on the salty side. The beef is seasoned well albeit there's very little of it and the noodles have a good bite too it. The oil it's tossed in is a good balance of smoky and savory. However, they do not hold back on the oil. By the end, I was quietly dabbing away at the pool of oil at the bottom of the bowl with a napkin. 

At $6.25, the dishes are quite cheap; there's no doubt about that. But even at that price, and given the hype, the food really doesn't measure up and it doesn't merit a return visit for me.

excerpts: Garlic noodles are what's up.
Limited seating and small space
, so you have to wait outside.
up.author: C Y.
up.review: This place is fast, cheap, and completely delicious. One of those hole in the wall places you dream of discovering in your neighborhood. Garlic noodles are what's up. Limited seating and small space, so you have to wait outside.

excerpts: The camera is going away but couldn't you at least put a sign up or something?
Not every picture taker wants to experience a Gordan Ramsay episode.
I took one anyway.
up.author: Stephen C.
up.review:
A hole in the wall, in every sense of the phrase. In a nondescript grimy alley you could unknowingly pass by a real gem of Burmese deliciousness. A tiny cave of a restaurant that sits about eight people directly in front of the kitchen.

All the food is inexpensive and tasty, especially the Yamo House Noodles! Juicy beef atop golden garlic noodles bursting with flavor! A little bit too much sodium but not a deal breaker. More than one customer ordered multiple servings of the house noodles while I was there.
The food comes ridiculously fast. Many people walked in, ordered to go, and left with their food in times that would put fast-food chains to shame.

A star gets docked for service. I suppose I shouldn't be too surprised that these ladies are only here to cook, serve, take your money, and move on. Don't expect a friendly demeanor. They are masters of the minimally civil passive aggressive attitude. "NO PICTURES!" the cashier screams deafeningly as I raise my camera to my food. The cook shrieks too, but not in any language I understand. All of the patrons in the restaurant and a passerby turn their focus to the commotion. Okay fine. Yes, chef. The camera is going away but couldn't you at least put a sign up or something? Not every picture taker wants to experience a Gordan Ramsay episode.
I took one anyway.

excerpts: After seats opened up, I asked the chef if I can eat inside
and she said yes.
Apparently I asked the wrong person as I was given the to go containers by the other lady and when asked if I can sit and eat, I was told to leave as I ordered to go.
The chef then asked to confirm if I already paid, and when I said yes, she suggested nicely for me to leave too.
I wished I took back my tip.
Same lady that told me to leave doesn't wash her hands after touching cash (cash only) and can be seen using hands to prepare the noodles...
up.author: Nicholas N.
up.review:
Horrible service. I initially ordered to go and already paid and tipped. After seats opened up, I asked the chef if I can eat inside and she said yes. Apparently I asked the wrong person as I was given the to go containers by the other lady and when asked if I can sit and eat, I was told to leave as I ordered to go. The chef then asked to confirm if I already paid, and when I said yes, she suggested nicely for me to leave too. I wished I took back my tip. Same lady that told me to leave doesn't wash her hands after touching cash (cash only) and can be seen using hands to prepare the noodles... Attention San Francisco Department of Public Health.

Mohinga (Fish Chowder Noodle Soup) isn't even that good. Burma Superstar is much much better!

excerpts: You know that one gif where Homer Simpson backs up into the bush and hides from the entire world?
THAT WAS ME!
up.author: Tiffany T.
up.review:
I was adventuring by myself around San Fran and stumbled upon this hole in the wall. Despite it only being 3.5 stars on Yelp, the place has a lot of reviews and looked like a really authentic place, so it appeared potentially promising. Key word: APPEARED. Because let me tell you, it really does deserve its not-so-spectacular rating.

The instance I walked in, I was not greeted, but rather, I felt a really tense and extremely unwelcoming vibe throughout the restaurant. The place is extremely small and probably only has about 7-8 high chair seats directly facing the kitchen where 2 Asian women are cooking. 

NOTE: Do NOT attempt to take a picture in the restaurant, especially a shot directly facing the women or else you will feel the wrath and rage from them. It was so awkward when the head lady yelled on the top of her lungs, "NO PICTURE"! You know that one gif where Homer Simpson backs up into the bush and hides from the entire world? THAT WAS ME! Trust me, I went through war and anxiety to take the picture of my curry chicken. 

Anywho, the food is very affordable and cheap, so the 1 $ on Yelp is very accurate. I asked the head lady what a good recommendation is and she was pissed at me. At that point, I felt like me breathing honestly pissed her off. I eventually decided on the Curry Chicken and it wasn't bad or anything, but it also wasn't amazing either. It tasted really buttery to me and there were barely any chicken pieces within the plate. Also, bottled water is $1 here if you ask them for some water too. 

Overall, I felt really weird at this restaurant and felt like I was being judged left and right. I could tell the other customers with me all felt the same.

excerpts: I had already been forewarned that the service here is subpar, so I knew I would just be coming to pick up the salad, pay the easy-on-my-wallet $6.25 and leave.
I don't think the cheap prices make up for the quality of food that you get.
I may return to try the noodles or other entrees, but I don't have high hopes at this point.
I will stick to what's tried and true and revert to the other much better Burmese establishments in SF where the flavors are really well-developed
and I leave feeling happy and satiated.
up.author: Sabina S.
up.review:
After reading reviews that the best tea leaf salad in the city is at Yamo, I decided I HAD to come check it out. I had already been forewarned that the service here is subpar, so I knew I would just be coming to pick up the salad, pay the easy-on-my-wallet $6.25 and leave. 

Fair warning: I've had the tea leaf salad at Mandalay, Burma Love, and Burma Superstar and I absolutely love how each place makes it, albeit a bit differently across. So, I guess I had high standards coming in to Yamo and expecting that beautiful tanginess from the fermented tea leaves and overall explosion of flavors from the crispy garlic to the jalapeños. 

I got home super excited and sat down on my couch, wide-eyed and ready to try this dish. I took a bite and my first feeling was of disappointment. This tasted nothing like tea leaf salad and really just had a strong onion taste from the large quantity of onion immersed in the dish. The flavors were just okay, but when you're expecting a tea leaf salad, this paled in comparison. If you guys have ever had Indian bhel (common street food snack), this salad kind of tasted like that. If I had ordered bhel, it would have been fine, but I hadn't. 

Overall, I wasn't impressed with Yamo. I don't think the cheap prices make up for the quality of food that you get. I may return to try the noodles or other entrees, but I don't have high hopes at this point. I will stick to what's tried and true and revert to the other much better Burmese establishments in SF where the flavors are really well-developed and I leave feeling happy and satiated.

excerpts: Straight up rude.
up.author: Coco J.
up.review:
Straight up rude. 

I first went here over five years ago- their salads and noodles used to be legit. One of my friends was even from Burma and always love to visit here when n SF. Not. Any. More.

I will never set foot n this place again. I was given a tea leaf salad that consisted garlic chips, shredded cabbage, a few nuts seeds and lots of sweet chili garlic sauce. No tea leaf to be found (she tried to tell us: it's a ground into the sauce- well I call BS!! Not to mention tea leaf salad is not made with chili sauce. Hipsters of the mission, believe me when I tell you this is not what tea leaf salad is supposed to taste like.

In fact it's one of the dishes I know I can safely order because it doesn't have chili in it. Chills make me break out in hives. When I had to return the salad I was confronted and mocked. Would you like some verbal abuse to go with your dinner? 

If you're looking for a soup Nazi type experience with declining food quality and portion sizes- look no further. Really disappointing and a little disgusted. Where do you go after you go this downhill...?

excerpts: After you pay - and remember cash only - you're thanked very loudly, but if you listen between the lines, mama cook's real thoughts are GTFO because you're holding up her business.
up.author: Janice K.
up.review:
Chinese mom meets Seinfield's soup nazi. If you don't understand my Seinfield reference, go youtube this now. I assure you, it's hilarious. 

The Yamo experience is a mix of PTSD of every confusing childhood memory of being scolded combined with the pleasant memory of home cooked meals prepared by your Chinese mom. 

The food ranged from good to great (review below), but the experience of eating at Yamo was absolutely terrifying with a squeeze of comical. Upon entering the restaurant you'll be greeted by a very angry mama cook who seemly appears to yell at everyone: her daughter, the other mama cook and all patrons. Service is quick - you enter, you order your food while you wait to be seated - you get seated, and immediately the dishes you previously ordered are flung at you.  Yes, dishes are airborne for a few seconds before clattering loudly in front of you - maybe safe to have a napkin ready for the splash zone. 

Oh did you want to take a photo of your food? You better take it ninja style or ask permission to take "food photos only" because mama cook will scream at you from across the restaurant " NO PHOTOS". 

Did you want to enjoy your food over good conversation? Hopefully you've mastered the art of talking and inhaling food at the same time, otherwise, you'll get the stare down from mama cook if your chopsticks aren't forking food into your mouth while you're swallowing forcefully. Take a tip and skip the chewing because your bill will arrive in front of you shortly. After you pay - and remember cash only - you're thanked very loudly, but if you listen between the lines, mama cook's real thoughts are GTFO because you're holding up her business. 

We ate (each dish ~$6.25 pre tax): 

1. Tea Salad (2/5) - Burmese style salad mixed with fermented tea leaves. Salad comes premixed.The salad was more spicy and lemony than a typical Burmese tea salad, and peanuts were roasted/fried, but no longer crunchy. It was clear the salad was pre made and sitting in the fridge ready to be served. 

2. Mango Chicken (4/5) - Stir fried vegetables with mango and chicken, served with a bed of white rice. The "wok hei" or in english, "the breath of the wok"  was real- this dish had a complex smoky flavor that is only achieved by cooking fresh ingredients over extreme heat. The flavors of the chicken coated in sauce were deep, and the bell peppers and mango retained the textural crunch. Would have liked more than 3 pieces of chicken. 

3. Black Bean Fish (4/5) - Stir fried vegetables with black bean white fish, served with a bed of white rice. As above, the wok hei flavor was legit. Flavors were on deep and smokey. Texture was crunchy and crispy. Fish portion was could be larger. 

4. Yamo House Noodles (3/5) noodles mixed with garlic and a choice of beef, chicken or pork - ours was beef. Noodles were cooked almost al dante and heavily coated in oil, mixed with garlic and topped with a pinch of extremely salty beef crumbles. 

Overall: 

Food - 3.5/5 - Food here definitely has potential. On one hand the wok hei flavor is on point, on the other, portion sizes of protein is minimal and often too salty. Prices are cheap, which makes the value for food was a good bang for the buck in SF. 

Service 1/5- From my notes above, the experience at Yamo was conflicting. I was terrified from the moment I walked in, but also couldn't help uncontrollably laugh at the situation. There were some frequenters who came for take out and you can tell they've experienced the PTSD themselves and have learned better to just get take out. One after one, they'll come in and skip the banter, and just say the numbers of the dishes they wanted to order. Put down the money and with a slight bow retreat backwards out the door where they waited patiently until their meal was prepared. Pro tip: if you want to experience yamo without the PTSD, just come for take out. 

Environment 1/5- This rating is likely skewed from the notes above - but hard to enjoy a meal when you're feeling afraid. Minimal seating ~ 10, expect to wait 30+ mins if you come during regular meal hours. Definitely come on a pre laundry day because you'll walk out smelling like Yamo. 

Eat take out from here.

excerpts: If you want someone to serve you and make you feel like a royalty, you better go somewhere where an entree is $20 and up.
For me, this place gives me what I pay for.
up.author: Kushal G.
up.review: It's funny that people are complaining about tiny stuff because for sure those ladies don't give a shit about what we say. But that is the whole vibe we want from hole in the wall (people who do not give a shit). You go, get your food and leave. This is not a place where you demand for a service or a nice gesture. Food is good, affordable price and that is that. If you want someone to serve you and make you feel like a royalty, you better go somewhere where an entree is $20 and up. For me, this place gives me what I pay for.

excerpts: When I go to the new place in town everyone's talking about, I normally end up giving it 3 stars.
What was it missing, character, ambiance, flavor?
It can get crowded and hot, I end up smelling like the place after I leave.
You might have to wait for the opportunity to smell like the place.
This lady cracks me up,
she's not trying to make my day
, she works hard and I respect that.
She takes pride in here work and that makes me happy.
The pride and the love she puts in to her work makes the food amazing.
Yamo has mad flavor.
It has more character
up.author: Ben M.
up.review:
How does a hole in the wall on 18th get 4 - 5 stars?

When I go to the new place in town everyone's talking about, I normally end up giving it 3 stars. What was it missing, character, ambiance, flavor?  All of that. 

It can get crowded and hot, I end up smelling like the place after I leave. You might have to wait for the opportunity to smell like the place. The noodles are delicious, the veggies are fresh and the fried foods arn't overly greasy. 

People have expectations that are unreasonable, make comparisons they shouldn't and fail to recognize authenticity. 

This lady cracks me up,  she's not trying to make my day, she works hard and I respect that. She takes pride in here work and that makes me happy. The pride and the love she puts in to her work makes the food amazing. 
Yamo has mad flavor. It has more character then any new resturant could ever hope for (with a couple exceptions) 

Places like this are the backbone of our city. The people who run them are my heroes.

excerpts: I met up with two friends who were eating there, but I was just planning to sit and chat with them.
They asked what I wanted to order, and when I said I wasn't eating, they told me to wait outside even though half the restaurant was empty.
The food isn't so good that it makes up for the terrible service.
It's greasy but cheap.
If I ever come here again, I'll be getting the food to go.
Not a fan of getting abused while eating, thank you very much.
up.author: Tim X.
up.review:
Decent garlic noodles and low prices save this hole-in-a-wall from a 1-star rating. 

I'm used to negligent service at small restaurants, but this place is downright rude. The owners more or less yell at customers rather than ask or serve them. Dishes are shoved or dropped in front of your face, and the folks working there act almost annoyed to be serving you. 

I've been here twice, and the treatment today was awful. I met up with two friends who were eating there, but I was just planning to sit and chat with them. They asked what I wanted to order, and when I said I wasn't eating, they told me to wait outside even though half the restaurant was empty. Thankfully, my friends had ordered three entrees, so I picked at a few bites and shared with them, all the while enduring dirty looks from the owners.

The food isn't so good that it makes up for the terrible service. It's greasy but cheap. If I ever come here again, I'll be getting the food to go. Not a fan of getting abused while eating, thank you very much.

excerpts: Bomb food, fast service, not much seating inside so call ahead and pick up.
Cheap prices too!
up.author: Parasto S.
up.review: Bomb food, fast service, not much seating inside so call ahead and pick up. Cheap prices too!

excerpts: don't be those people who show up with 6 others and take up all the seating...
up.author: Janessa H.
up.review:
**LIMITED SEATING***
*SERVICE BASICALLY NON EXISTENT*

However, food=yummy!!!

Came here since I was nearby, hungry, and hadn't had a tea leaf salad in awhile!!

$6.25 

Small plate, but def worth it!

Flavor is on point!

There's basically no service, besides what do you want to eat.... and pay... asked for restroom since sign said restroom for customers and the lady helping me mumbled something along the line of no.....?  

Not sure however I would be back if in the area, this place is good for solos, or groups of 2 MAX 3 don't be those people who show up with 6 others and take up all the seating... 

Everything is pretty cheap on the menu, would possibly try other items but the tea leaf salad was great so might just stick to what I already know won't disappoint. 

Btw: salad is at a medium / hot spicy level depending on your tolerance. I'd say around medium but others might say pretty spicy

excerpts: It's a hole in the wall with two older (Burmese) ladies working the small kitchen to whip up quick, friend meals.
There are about six stools at the counter of the kitchen that keep you up to date with the status of your meal - and a fridge in the back with bottled beverages.
Wait time when the restaurant is full is about 15 - 20 minutes for your food.
up.author: Qurat K.
up.review:
* Cash only; supermarket across the street has an ATM. $7 per dish. One dish per person is enough. 

Yamo is a San Francisco classic in the Mission. It's a hole in the wall with two older (Burmese) ladies working the small kitchen to whip up quick, friend meals. There are about six stools at the counter of the kitchen that keep you up to date with the status of your meal - and a fridge in the back with bottled beverages. Wait time when the restaurant is full is about 15 - 20 minutes for your food. Food comes to the counter, as it's ready. 

The best options, of the 10 on the menu, are noodles and friend meats. Rely less on options like the Burmese salad (or adding in meat, if you're a snob about quality). Each dish had a unique flavor palate 

Stick to noodles and friend foods here, and rely less on options like Burmese salad. Also, if you're a snob about meat quality - then this isn't your place either. There are about ten options, of the four I've had, all were fantastic. Each dish was flavorful and unique.

excerpts: I was disappointed to see the lady behind the counter grabbing the cooked noodles with her bare hands-- the same hands that take cash from customers and clean up the dishes.
Additionally, she throughout the entire meal, she kept on muttering "No talking, just eat" while I was trying to catch up with my friend.
The restaurant is a bit too warm and cramped for comfort, but that aspect adds to the hole-in-the-wall experience.
up.author: Amy C.
up.review:
Come for a meal if price is what matters most to you, because there will be trade offs in the quality and service. The dishes here are cheap, but remember that you always get what you pay for. 

The tea salad, while tasty, was small-- about the size of a fist. Toppings for the house noodles were stingy. It had a few pieces of beef, green onions, and nothing more. The noodles were bland, but I did enjoy the taste of the beef, even if it was a little dry. The chicken curry was probably my favorite dish of the night. I liked the sauce, but the dish would've been more aptly named "potato curry" because it was 80% potatoes, 10% chicken, and 10% everything else.

The service and cleanliness of the restaurant is the main reason why I won't be coming back. I was disappointed to see the lady behind the counter grabbing the cooked noodles with her bare hands-- the same hands that take cash from customers and clean up the dishes. Additionally, she throughout the entire meal, she kept on muttering "No talking, just eat" while I was trying to catch up with my friend. The restaurant is a bit too warm and cramped for comfort, but that aspect adds to the hole-in-the-wall experience.

excerpts: i used to hit up yamo at least twice a month when i lived in the city.
LOVED this place.
but now i live in oakland and don't get to go often.
up.author: S S.
up.review:
i used to hit up yamo at least twice a month when i lived in the city. LOVED this place. but now i live in oakland and don't get to go often. recently i came over to the city and carved out a special date with my go to tea salad and house noodle with beef. these items were the dopest and made the hella mean asian lady (i'm asian. don't get this twisted) tolerable. greasy kitchen like my mama's. 

but daaaang. meat portion and quality going down, flavor watering out, and WHY DOES THE TEA SALAD ALWAYS GET TO ME AFTER MY NOODLES?? you feel me, lady?! 

anyway. it's a popular local jaunt that has a cult following... but for me... RIP yamo.

excerpts: She's an evil person that is rude, un clean and the food is Major un-healthy with cake up grease that's just been sitting in a jar for days and weeks !!
Not to mention the same spinach and egg noodles all sitting in a card board box touching each other while she uses her bare hands to pick up food and then wipes on her dirty clothes!!
This place is un sanitary!!
She will never get a dime of my $$$----RACISTS!!!!
up.author: Mr. Q.
up.review: I just came from this place again because I was in the area and hungry and thought I give it another chance big mistake on my part!!! The elder Asian lady was rude as can be and made me wait after everyone else to get my food after I set down before four other people, as I mentioned before she treats blacks different than her Asian or White customers and it's sad that discrimination still goes on in America let alone SF. My food was cold and missing normal vegetables that come with the meal my second order I canceled because she acted like I wasn't even at the table waiting for my food.. As I ask about my food and to see what was going on she curse me out in her language and told me to sit down! I explained to her I'm not a child I'm a grown man and you need some show some respect! She's an evil person that is rude, un clean and the food is Major un-healthy with cake up grease that's just been sitting in a jar for days and weeks !! Not to mention the same spinach and egg noodles all sitting in a card board box touching each other while she uses her bare hands to pick up food and then wipes on her dirty clothes!! This place is un sanitary!! She will never get a dime of my $$$----RACISTS!!!!

excerpts: The same applies here, so please don't be worried about waiting a long time as it always seems to clear out just as quickly as it fills up.
The ladies who work there are tough, can appear short tempered, and are usually in a rush.
This is not to be mistaken as rude, for they greatly care about the product they're delivering.
They will usually smile and chat
should you ask them how they're doing.
It took close to a year for the lovely ladies there to remember me, and to be honest
I'm proud
I earned their trust.
up.author: Michael L.
up.review:
I have lived here in SF for almost 2 years now, and this is by far my favorite place to eat. Tucked away behind a rather loud smoke shop on Mission st & 18th is Yamo, a cozy Burmese eatery that I have come to love. From the moment you see their sign to the moment you leave smiling, this experience is one you will soon not forget. The menu is small, the prices are beyond reasonable, and the taste is unmatched. There is little seating available and it won't always seem welcoming, usually due to people crowding the door and not being bold enough to have a seat. Do not hesitate to ask to sit down, they definitely value people who take initiative. 

In my dealings with SF and food, usually the more packed a spot is, the better. The same applies here, so please don't be worried about waiting a long time as it always seems to clear out just as quickly as it fills up. The ladies who work there are tough, can appear short tempered, and are usually in a rush. This is not to be mistaken as rude, for they greatly care about the product they're delivering. They will usually smile and chat should you ask them how they're doing. It took close to a year for the lovely ladies there to remember me, and to be honest I'm proud I earned their trust. So keep smiling and remember your manners. 

I have only ever ordered the House Special Noodles with Beef/Chicken/Pork. Each one of the meat choices are different, and taste simply amazing. I have taken everyone of my friends there and they all leave astounded. It will truly open your mind as well as your eyes to a different culture. 

This place makes me feel like a bootleg version of Anthony Bourdain, discovering some hole in the wall halfway across the globe that's probably run out of someone's home. The meal is simple, tasty, and above all cheaper then $7. I highly recommend trying this place out. Believe me when I say that you will not leave disappointed in the slightest.

excerpts: but I'll chalk up growing up in LA as defense for coming to Yamo so late.
I need this bastion of cooking way more than it needs me.
It's literally listed on Google Maps as cheap eats
To them its just another day and the techniques they've mastered but to me it'd something easily screwed up.
up.author: Charles M.
up.review:
Definitely super late to the punch but I'll chalk up growing up in LA as defense for coming to Yamo so late. I need this bastion of cooking way more than it needs me. It's literally listed on Google Maps as cheap eats and I feel like that doesn't betray how good it actually is.

Small and intimate, it is a restaurant that focuses solely on the thing that ultimately matters: food and your love for it. There are no TVs to watch or live entertainment, rather just the display of aptitude and skill by the people who cook here and remind me of my iron chef grandmother. 

The food is at one time incredibly complex and simple. To them its just another day and the techniques they've mastered but to me it'd something easily screwed up. 
We got the house noodles, chicken noodle soup, and tea salad. Not as big or flashy as the other burmese titans in SF but just as good if not better. Super fresh and flavorful noodles, soup, and meat. The tea salad is somewhat small but still very good and something I'd totally get again.

We came on a Sunday at 3-4 and it was empty. Such a bittersweet joy that we made it in without a wait but that so many people were missing out.

excerpts: We took a seat at the bar set up.
The room is just about 8 chairs lined up right against a bar.
Two women were manning the counter.
One of them was the cook making noodles right in front of us.
The air in the room is sweltering hot.
You are pretty much incased in smells of the food the entire time.
I got my noodles with the tofu and it was really well done tofu.
Right as I get my food a firefighter walks in and says, "hey did anyone get punch in the eye here that needs help?
The woman behind the counter replies, "no there was someone punch in the eye, but he left" Firefighter replies, "oh awesome.
Okay, bye."  and walks out.
up.author: Cynthia G.
up.review:
I went here last night to have dinner with a friend. We got the house noodles and the samosas. This is the most hole in the wall place I have ever been too. As we were walking to door there was a group of cops outside talking to some guy bleeding from the face. We took a seat at the bar set up. The room is just about 8 chairs lined up right against a bar. Two women were manning the counter. One of them was the cook making noodles right in front of us. The air in the room is sweltering hot. You are pretty much incased in smells of the food the entire time. I got my noodles with the tofu and it was really well done tofu. Right as I get my food a firefighter walks in and says, "hey did anyone get punch in the eye here that needs help?" The woman behind the counter replies, "no there was someone punch in the eye, but he left" Firefighter replies, "oh awesome. Okay, bye."  and walks out. Kind of awesome and horrific at the same time?

Food was amazing. Those garlic noodles are delicious. Super cheap too, every plate is around 6 bucks. Cash only though. I like the girl behind the counter. She's spunky sweet sass. 

Definitely coming back.

excerpts: That about sums up the place, if you can deal with the old ladies yelling at you about your order for the delicious food then you have yourself a solid lunch/dinner option.
Also the restaurant is the definition of hole in the wall and cleanliness could be better.
However it reminds me of eating good food in Asia
up.author: Sean S.
up.review:
Food 5/5 stars 
Service 2-3/stars

That about sums up the place, if you can deal with the old ladies yelling at you about your order for the delicious food then you have yourself a solid lunch/dinner option. 
Also the restaurant is the definition of hole in the wall and cleanliness could be better. However it reminds me of eating good food in Asia so I'm not complaining. 

All the food here is mostly under $10 and is scrumptious. 
I'd highly recommend the tea leaf salad and Yamo house noodles!

excerpts: If you're a guy one bowl of noodles probably won't fill you up however.
up.author: Tom P.
up.review:
Don't get any of the appetizers (the tea leaf salad didn't have any actual tea leaves in it, and the samosa was overcooked and nothing special). Just go straight for what their known for which is the house noodles with beef. It looks really bland without flavor but trust me it's really tasty. The meat is also very tender and has no fat on it. If you're a guy one bowl of noodles probably won't fill you up however. Might need to head somewhere else after or order two bowls.

Pro-tip: Bring cash as this is a cash-only place.

excerpts: Growing up on Burmese food my whole life, I say they are legit.
Better than all the fancy Burmese restaurants I've been to out here (Burma Love, Rangoon Ruby, Burma Superstar, etc).
Closest it's come to spice/heat in terms of authentic Burmese cooking.
The women/cooks there seem rude, but that's just the culture.
I hear them speaking (Asian yelling) to each other.
Lol
They're talking about orders and getting food out the quickest.
They're actually really sweet when they're not busy hustling to get food out.
up.author: Priscilla S.
up.review: Cheap and cash only. Growing up on Burmese food my whole life, I say they are legit. Better than all the fancy Burmese restaurants I've been to out here (Burma Love, Rangoon Ruby, Burma Superstar, etc). Closest it's come to spice/heat in terms of authentic Burmese cooking. The women/cooks there seem rude, but that's just the culture. I hear them speaking (Asian yelling) to each other. Lol They're talking about orders and getting food out the quickest. They're actually really sweet when they're not busy hustling to get food out.

excerpts: I was picking up a to-go order but asked them if I could take a seat till I was waiting and the lady screamed at me saying "No".
up.author: Disha S.
up.review:
Extremely rude service! I was picking up a to-go order but asked them if I could take a seat till I was waiting and the lady screamed at me saying "No". She then angrily told me to wait outside instead. 

When I reached home I found that they gave me a wrong order. And the food was very average. This place does not deserve 3.5 stars. I've had much much better cheap Asian food at other places.

excerpts: This is a wake up call for all the people hyping this place up.
Not worth such high reviews on Yelp!
up.author: Hoyan L.
up.review:
Incredibly HORRIBLE service. I walked in for lunch and the small place was packed. The old lady asked me if I want to eat in or to go. I asked how long the wait would be for eat in and she proceeded to yell at me. Saying "I ask you a question and you answer! Not ask me a question!" She then proceeded to continue to say bad things in cantonese which I can understand. I wanted to leave at that point really!! WHAT HORRIBLE ATTITUDE. 

The noodles took forever to make and they were nothing special. A few pieces of beef and the noodles were trenched in oil. She also threw our take outs at us and gave us a glare.

I will NEVER be back. $6 for a small bowl of noodle is not even that cheap! This is a wake up call for all the people hyping this place up. Not worth such high reviews on Yelp!

excerpts:
The lady at the register didn't follow up with us and took three other people that came in after us 
When we first sat down and only took 5min.
to decide what we wanted
up.author: Asmara V.
up.review:
Customer Service was poor
The lady at the register didn't follow up with us and took three other people that came in after us 
When we first sat down and only took 5min. to decide what we wanted 
Once we ordered we looked over to see if our food was ready- to our dismay our order wasn't being cooked and canceled our order-  will not be back

I understand the small setting but if you're going to have an intimate small setting make sure your employees have strong customer service skills - the kitchen is right behind you, like less than a foot no need for communicating by projecting your voice a couple feet away 
Not a good environment for what was thought to be a calm meal with a bowl of warmth

excerpts: another woman came in to pick up her phone in order.
i bring that up because it appears this place is a neighborhood favorite.
up.author: cindy c.
up.review:
a regular little place. seats 7? at a, small counter. completely no  frills place... i saw two people waiting food so i walked in,  unsure if I'm getting anything just yet.  after i walked in,  someone else walked in to sit.  another walked in also to sit.  i ordered.  someone walked in to order a take out order.  a woman walked in to sit.  another woman came in to pick up her phone in order.  two people were waiting to sit as i left.  

i bring that up because it appears this place is a neighborhood favorite.  i didn't order spring rolls but i might need to,  since it sold out as i was there.  

i was a little sad to see they removed chow fun from their menu,  as I'm poultry intolerant.  as in i could stop breathing if ingested,  so rice noodles are safer than chow mein noodles. 

i ordered the mushroom tofu. i liked the flavors. it was very well prepared.  can't complain about the food at all,  served with rice,  $6.50. what a bargain! no wonder the neighbors flock here...

i would recommend you watch how they cook your food if you have any allergy.  i didn't mention mine but next time i certainly will. the cross contamination is a possibility with the chef using the same utensils on all the orders.  at the time i was there,  2 chicken orders!  but my tofu was simmering on its own and didn't use that cooking utensil,  yikes!

I'm forever wary of new places but i think I'll be back,  as long as i tell the chef about my allergy...

i liked the food.  i just need to tell the chef.  I'll be back.  4 stars for this little hidden find!

excerpts: I ordered a tea leaf salad and my friend ordered a mango chicken, but I was hungry enough that we ended up ordering a second mango chicken and splitting our tea salad.
The total came out to about $18, and we even had a bit left over.
The tea leaf salad was a smaller amount, but a good price for the ingredients - fragnant and nutty.
The mango chicken was tart, but smothered over rice, it felt like California comfort food.
up.author: Heidi L.
up.review:
I ordered a tea leaf salad and my friend ordered a mango chicken, but I was hungry enough that we ended up ordering a second mango chicken and splitting our tea salad. The total came out to about $18, and we even had a bit left over.
 
The tea leaf salad was a smaller amount, but a good price for the ingredients - fragnant and nutty. The mango chicken was tart, but smothered over rice, it felt like California comfort food.

excerpts: The mother daughter combo cook up a storm and absurdly cheap offices.
Hidden gem of the Mission!
up.author: Sumeru C.
up.review: This place is an absolutely amazing, hole-in-the-wall place by 17th and Mission. The mother daughter combo cook up a storm and absurdly cheap offices. Hidden gem of the Mission!

excerpts: It's one thing to mess up an order - but then to refuse to correct it.
No.
up.author: Tay H.
up.review:
I'm all for awesome hole-in-the-wall spots.  I can overlook indifferent to bad service for amazing food.  This place couldn't deliver on almost any of its promises.

After waiting 30 minutes on a Tuesday at 8:30pm for two seats at the bar, we had pretty high hopes.  The restaurant doesn't look or smell clean, and you'll definitely walk out reeking of cooking oil....but that can all be forgiven for an amazing meal.  This was not an amazing meal.  

We started with the tea leaf salad, which was quite good.  It's certainly very different than the Westernized versions you'll get at Burma Superstar and others, but not in a bad way.  I'd eat either style for different reasons and be happy.  HOWEVER, our main course is where it fell apart.

I ordered the house noodles with pork.  My boyfriend ordered the same, but with beef.  I was served a bowl with chicken.  Then, this real conversation happened:

Me: "Oh, excuse me, I think maybe I got someone else's order?  This is a chicken bowl; I ordered the pork."
Grumpy Waitress/Cook: "Oh ok."
*PAUSE*
Grumpy Waitress/Cook: "No pork.  Eat."
Me: "Um, no I think this is chicken."
*WAITRESS WALKS AWAY*

So, I proceed to try it.  My boyfriend proceeded to try it.  It's chicken.  Like, no question.  She refused to come back over and speak to us, so I decided to just eat it - I mean, it's wrong ok, but how bad could the dish be?  Bad.  It was just so, so bad.  

The couple next to me ordered this dish and there was sauce and good stuff coating the noodles and pooling at the bottom of their bowls when they were done.  Mine had literally none of that.  My boyfriend's had some, but not nearly so much.  My bowl was literally just gummy, very starchy-tasting noodles, a few green onions, and a handful of WAY over-salted pieces of chicken (maybe a chicken thigh-worth).  I ate the chicken and left the rest.

I definitely won't come back here.  It's one thing to mess up an order - but then to refuse to correct it.  No.

excerpts: If you're lucky to find an empty spot on the 8 seat counter, go hang up your backpack on the wall, take a seat on the bar stool, read the sticky menu, and better order within a minute or else you will get on the bad side of Yamo's impatient waitstaff.
Between three people, we shared the samusa, tea leaf salad, and a Yamo chicken house noodle.
That's not enough food for a real meal here, so we got scolded by the waitress.
up.author: Felix L.
up.review:
Yamo is a "quick-fix" Burmese eatery with a limited menu, almost the opposite of Zagat-rated Burmese restaurants in the area like Mandalay and Burma Superstar. It's small, cramped, family-owned, not very sanitary, has an open kitchen, offers simple comfort food, and everything on the menu is under $10. Yamo fits all the criteria of a "hole in the wall". 

If you're lucky to find an empty spot on the 8 seat counter, go hang up your backpack on the wall, take a seat on the bar stool, read the sticky menu, and better order within a minute or else you will get on the bad side of Yamo's impatient waitstaff. Between three people, we shared the samusa, tea leaf salad, and a Yamo chicken house noodle. That's not enough food for a real meal here, so we got scolded by the waitress. If only she knew we chose to eat light because we had a dinner reservation 3 hours later...

The samusas were generic, they reminded me of deep fried hot pockets stuffed with a mild meat filling. Based on its texture, the samuas was definitely a frozen food product and not homemade. The supplied dipping sauce was the sweet and sour type that accompanies egg rolls. 

Tea leaf salad (lahpet thoke) was not very memorable. Actually, it tasted even worse than the ones I've eaten at Burmese restaurants in LA. Yamo's salad was overall crunchy which I found satisfying but the flavors were very very mellow. It sorely lacked the pungent and bittersweet flavors that I expected from mixing fermented tea leaves with other ingredients in the salad, which is what makes this Burmese salad so unique. Instead, the salad tasted sweet and garlicky more than anything else.

Finally, Yamo's house noodle was simplistic and ordinary, yet almost everyone else in this hole in the wall had a bowl in front of them. Egg noodles were boiled in some oily broth, then batched drained, served with some pan fried boneless chicken, peanuts, and green onions. What's so special about it? What's Burmese about it? Even after the chef drained the oil, the bowl of noodles was still a grease bomb. Not worth the $6.

As others have already mentioned, you won't find service here. The three ladies who prepare your meal are not very friendly, so it's best to eat fast and get out ASAP. The chefs appear to speak Taishanese, a Cantonese dialect, to each other and joke around. Well, the damage was $19 for this disappointing meal. Not worth it for the snack-size portions and uninspiring flavors, not worth a detour to come here. I would only recommend this place as a cheap introduction to Burmese food.

excerpts: I also had to run out to pick up cash (
yeah
I was that person, my bad) and
the lady shouted at me:
No I will not watch your things!
up.author: Cindy W.
up.review:
3.5 stars for food. Tea leaf salad was perfectly delicious but for $6, I got what was a $3 portion. Grumble grumble but okay... 

The fish chowder portion size is generous but served lukewarm.... okay.... :-/

But what really turned me off was the service. Ugh... the two ladies serving me were so rude and told me I couldn't take pictures (of my food ... really???). I also had to run out to pick up cash (yeah I was that person, my bad) and the lady shouted at me: No I will not watch your things! (Did I even ask you?)

Yeah -- definitely not a great customer service experience if you're about that but hey it's cheap, it's decently good.

excerpts: And it's not one of those places where the food makes up for it in any way.
up.author: Jessica C.
up.review:
This place could not be worse. The lady who does the cooking / greeting is EXTREMELY rude; it's unreal. Something straight out of kitchen nightmares.

And it's not one of those places where the food makes up for it in any way. The tea salad was so heavily drenched in dressing, and the flavor was like some cheap sweet and sour sauce from Safeway. The mixed vegetables and stir fried noodles were almost as bad, and VERY oily.

I live for places like this - the holes in the wall that have been around forever, and are known for their authenticity. But I recommend staying away from this place at all costs!

excerpts: You better know what you're getting when you order to-go, and be there when it's time to pick up!
There is limited seating, but it's so worth it.
up.author: Bonnie E.
up.review: I LOVE YAMO! You better know what you're getting when you order to-go, and be there when it's time to pick up! There is limited seating, but it's so worth it.

excerpts: I'm not only talking yelling, and being crude, they talked shit behind me and my boyfriend's back when we walked into the restaurant (they were talking in Cantonese) and gave us the biggest up-and-down look.
I'm sorry, you can be crude, but commenting about the guests thinking they don't understand?
up.author: Connie T.
up.review:
Bad food, unhygienic, and rudest staff. If you want Burmese food, go somewhere else. This is San Francisco, and there are plenty other choices, don't feed your money to this place. 

Unhygienic: the ladies use her bare hands to deal with money notes (at the cashier, with receipts and changes) then turned to put RAW food (including raw meat and raw salad) to the bowl so the chef can cook them. For godsake, this restaurant needs to get inspected by the city/govt!!!

Service: I understand you have a different expectations in terms of service while going to some Chinese restaurants, but this is just plain rude. I'm not only talking yelling, and being crude, they talked shit behind me and my boyfriend's back when we walked into the restaurant (they were talking in Cantonese) and gave us the biggest up-and-down look. I'm sorry, you can be crude, but commenting about the guests thinking they don't understand? That's a whole new level.

Food: super cheap, but you are paying for MSGs and salt, period. I ordered 90% of the menu and honestly this is an insult to Burmese cuisine. Everything was salty, and the ingredients were defo not fresh. Portion was not decent at all. 

Save yourself some time. Never left such a place feeling so angry.

excerpts: and I were out drinking in the Mission and wanted some delicious food to soak it all up.
Yamo had some vegetarian/vegan options
so we decided to do some take out to share.
Walking up, this place is smalllll, a total hole in the wall with maybe 8 seats at the counter and always a line out the door (a good sign).
The menu is printed outside and the ladies workin here are quick to get your order and greet you with a smile.
I like that you can watch what is goin on while you're food is being made and its a little entertaining while you wait.
up.author: Kelsey B.
up.review:
New favorite take out spot in the Mission that won't break the bank!
Found Yamo while my fiance and I were out drinking in the Mission and wanted some delicious food to soak it all up.  Yamo had some vegetarian/vegan options so we decided to do some take out to share.  Walking up, this place is smalllll, a total hole in the wall with maybe 8 seats at the counter and always a line out the door (a good sign).  The menu is printed outside and the ladies workin here are quick to get your order and greet you with a smile. I like that you can watch what is goin on while you're food is being made and its a little entertaining while you wait. 
We grabbed the following to share for dinner: vegetarian spring rolls (4.50), vegetarian samusas (4.50), tea salad (6.25), and house noodles (6.25). Everything was made in about 10 minutes and for under $25 for a solid dinner in the Mission that ain't too bad. The dishes aren't huge, but for the price I think they are perfect. Everything was super flavorful without being greasy or heavy like a lot noodles are at times. Totally a place I'll be back to and make sure to grab a seat at the counter next time!

excerpts: It's like North Korea in there, no taking pictures, no follow up questions allowed.
up.author: Jomilyn T.
up.review: The best Burmese food but be ready to leave your dignity behind before entering their door. It's like North Korea in there, no taking pictures, no follow up questions allowed.

excerpts: I walked up to Yamo and tried to take a picture.
Immediately I get snapped at by one of the employees, yelling "NO PICTURES!".
I looked at my girlfriend
and she just laughed (she used to be a regular here).
From the minute I tried taking the picture, to the minute I left, that same employee just stared daggers at me.
To be honest, I thought it was kind of entertaining, especially knowing how old, foregin asian women can be sometimes.
Also, it's a hole in the wall...
you should expect weird, quirky behavior, right?
up.author: Stephen L.
up.review:
4 stars, mainly because I'm really confused on how I'm supposed to feel after leaving. Let me explain.

I love the hole in the wall atmosphere. This place is maybe 6 feet wide and 15 feet deep, only able to sit 9 people on a bartop. I walked up to Yamo and tried to take a picture. Immediately I get snapped at by one of the employees, yelling "NO PICTURES!". I looked at my girlfriend and she just laughed (she used to be a regular here). From the minute I tried taking the picture, to the minute I left, that same employee just stared daggers at me. To be honest, I thought it was kind of entertaining, especially knowing how old, foregin asian women can be sometimes. Also, it's a hole in the wall... you should expect weird, quirky behavior, right? (This is me justifying why they are so angry).

Then we order and the food comes out - delicious! Noodles, curry, apps... you can't go wrong here. Love me some cheap asian food. 

But then, as I was eating, I kept thinking to myself, "eat faster, people are waiting". So I then start shoving the food in my mouth and swallowing without even chewing. Again, girlfriend just laughs.

So you see why I was so confused. Food - great. Atmosphere - confusing. Service - confusing. Let's just say that when you come here, expect the unexpected. Except for the food, cause that was really good.

excerpts: The claustrophobic environment where you only have 10 seats on a counter, the humidity in the air along with the high temperatures, and the "friendly" ladies who make your food all make up this wonderful experience in the middle of San Francisco.
It's not bad, but don't get your hopes up; it won't "blow your mind" because it isn't supposed to be something that does.
It's a nice compliment to any meal.
Yamo just creeps up on you.
up.author: Bryan W.
up.review:
The real travesty is that even after all the times I've been to Yamo, I never gave this hole-in-the-wall the proper review. But I'm glad it's not too late.

Yamo is one of those unique food shops in the Mission district that give you that wonderful street food vibe. Right when you walk in you will feel like you've been transported out of California and into Asia. The claustrophobic environment where you only have 10 seats on a counter, the humidity in the air along with the high temperatures, and the "friendly" ladies who make your food all make up this wonderful experience in the middle of San Francisco.

I understand that some people might not like Yamo. You may have crossed the cooks at the wrong time or you aren't into the whole idea of waiting to sit at the counter. But if you're willing to open your senses to a different eating experience, Yamo is for you.

Food 
Contrary to what a lot of people say, the food at Yamo is amazing in every right. 

House Special Noodle: 5/5
For 6$, you will NOT be able to find a noodle dish so simple yet so tasty. I actually dare you to bring me an equivalent. Though the portion size is small, every bite is filled with garlicky goodness. I can eat this every day of my life.

Tea Leaf Salad: 3.5/5
Tea leaf salad here is a lot different than what you would expect. Please don't come here thinking you're gonna get some Burma Superstar dish; if you haven't noticed, Yamo isn't that type of "restaurant." The tea leaf salad is much simpler here. In fact it reminds me of Vietnamese Goi. It's not bad, but don't get your hopes up; it won't "blow your mind" because it isn't supposed to be something that does. It's a nice compliment to any meal. It's not something you get as a standalone.

Mango Leaf Salad: 4/5
This one actually resembles more of the Viet salad I eat at home. It's a lot spicier so beware. I do prefer it over the tea leaf salad because of the extra ingredients and the extra kick. Like the tea leaf salad, this is supposed to go hand in hand with another dish.

Cold Noodle: 5/5
Another steal! Who knew that eating cold noodles would actually taste great? Well Yamo knows how to do it right. Be aware that it is kinda spicy for those who don't have a tolerance. Id get the house noodle over this, but this still deserves great praise. 


Atmosphere 
The environment at Yamo is unforgettable. I get why people may think that the cooks are cranky all the time, but really? When you're working all day and night in a small room, it's very hard to stay positive. Trust me, I've gone on days where the ladies are sweethearts and have come on days where they seemed pissed off. But that's the type of service you'll get at any food location. 

I'm the type of person who doesn't mind sitting closely with strangers in a tight location. Yamo is that one place where you get in. Talk to some people while you wait, and get out. It's like a transaction with random surprises here and there. 

Oh yah, the ladies will try to get you in and out as soon as possible too. This is very helpful to customers since it can get cramped and people are always busy. 

Location
Place is on 18th and Mission right across from the Asian supermarket. You'll miss it if you walk too fast. Yamo just creeps up on you.

excerpts: You can quickly separate the crowd dining in: those who did not grow up in an asian household with looks of terrified confusion on their faces and those who don't bat an eye because they were raised by a doppleganger in the form of an angry tiger mother.
up.author: Jenni H.
up.review:
You know how certain establishments have developed certain themes? Hipster, luxurious, casual, romantic, etc. Yamo has fully embraced the theme of Rage. 

This thematic rage centers around the owner, who is an angry asian lady with a perma-furrow between her eyebrows and a sharp berating voice.
