You can quickly separate the crowd dining in: those who did not grow up in an asian household with looks of terrified confusion on their faces and those who don't bat an eye because they were raised by a doppleganger in the form of an angry tiger mother. 

Despite the dinginess of the cramped space and the uninterrupted din of an angry asian lady taking orders over the phone ("WHAT DO YOU WANT?!"), the food is a bang for the buck. Delicious noodles at ridiculously cheap prices. My go to order is the house noodles with pork (chewy bouncy noodles, crispy roasted garlic, fresh generous cilantro), a tea salad (watch that spice), and a grass jelly drink to wash down the dryness of the food. 

Make sure you stop at an ATM on the way - cash only. 

And 10 points if you can catch a rare chuckle or smile from Lady Rage herself before she remembers she's fury incarnate and puts her mask of anger back on.

excerpts:
* no, DELICIOUS food (including noodles of various thicknesses tossed with said fresh produce and topped with savory meats and flavorful sauces and fresh garnishes)
* efficient attention (my water glass was constantly filled immediately, and for being cooked up literally right before my very eyes, it didn't take long to be fed)
I saw an informative and glowing write-up on Yamo in the paper this week, and knew exactly what kind of experience to expect: an awesome one.
I don't need frills.
I don't need you to remember my soda order, especially when you bring me endless free water.
I don't need a "smile" or any kindnesses or creature comforts.

I need food that makes me weep inside at its perfection, and I need it to be unpretentious in price and execution, and I need it to exist long before I got there, long after I leave, and to give exactly zero forks as to whether I was ever there at all.
This is Yamo.
up.author: Austin J. A.
up.review:
Here are the things for which you don't go to Yamo:

* spotlessness (the counter was dirty, and so were our paper placemats)
* ambiance (there are eight counter seats total and you will have to squeeze your body between them and the bare wall to get inside)
* frills (small menu, no alcohol, no so-called "service with a smile")

Here are the things for which you do go to Yamo:

* cheap food ($4-8 per menu item, exclusive of drinks)
* delicious food (including freshly-cooked, freshly-chopped fresh produce and meat)
* no, DELICIOUS food (including noodles of various thicknesses tossed with said fresh produce and topped with savory meats and flavorful sauces and fresh garnishes)
* efficient attention (my water glass was constantly filled immediately, and for being cooked up literally right before my very eyes, it didn't take long to be fed)
* did I mention that you just don't underestimate the amazing food!?

I saw an informative and glowing write-up on Yamo in the paper this week, and knew exactly what kind of experience to expect: an awesome one. I don't need frills. I don't need you to remember my soda order, especially when you bring me endless free water. I don't need a "smile" or any kindnesses or creature comforts. I need food that makes me weep inside at its perfection, and I need it to be unpretentious in price and execution, and I need it to exist long before I got there, long after I leave, and to give exactly zero forks as to whether I was ever there at all. This is Yamo. Little joints like this are my life, and if I could give them a basket of stars every day, I would. 

Please don't let the three stars of my review mislead or misguide you. Please. It wouldn't be fair for me to write an inaccurately-starred review, and after all, Yamo has its shortcomings in a traditional sort of scale. Think of my three stars as a way of letting you know that you need to go into Yamo prepared, fully aware of the kind of experience you're about to have, and that if you anchor your expectations appropriately, you'll have an unbelievable taste adventure. Like me, you'll probably be glad that it's the kind of place where you can drink noodle sauce right from the bowl (or you'll be glad that you don't care about manners when the payoff is so tasty). Or just get take-out and bring Yamo somewhere more highfalutin. 

I got #15 (Yamo house special hot-as-in-temperature noodles with pork) and #17 (chicken chow mein). The pork was ridiculous, so perfectly cooked with its slightly-crispy edges and its heady marinade aroma and its prolific appearance throughout my soba-thick noodles. #15 was garnished with crushed peanuts and chopped cilantro, and the slender slices of cooked green onion were beautiful as well as tasty against the thick sauce. #17 was appropriately-oiled, resplendent with half-mushrooms, carrots, and bok choy. The chicken was soft, in contrast to the pork, which had some appropriate tooth, and the chow mein noodles were spaghetti-thick. These were goodly-sized portions and yet not a speck of food remained behind on my dishware. Nothing about the food here feels superfluous; not one element traveled over the barrier of necessity. As in, let's reiterate that I cleaned my PLATES.

One thing that was atmospherically intriguing about Yamo was that the ceiling was high and the pendant lights were low to the counter, making the steamy, griddle-smoky space between them seem infinite. An observation born from being drunk on noodles? Possibly. Possibly. Or, more likely, a brief and touching communion with the noodly infinite.

excerpts: Not completely giving up on Yamo but doubt I'll be in a hurry to rush back.
I get the overall hype for the price and hipster-dive appeal but flavor trumps both in my opinion and it begins with salt.
up.author: Jon L.
up.review:
I get that it's a dive, and that it's cheap, but there are still some fundamentals that you can't ignore. Like salt. 

Was really excited to finally try Yamo out for myself but left feeling pretty disappointed. The curry beef noodle was incredibly bland. I never thought I would ever describe a curry as being bland but it lacked spice, heat, and even salt. It's also a pretty greasy dish to boot so overall a letdown. The samosas were ok but forgettable. Like before, they lacked salt and spice but at least they were crispy. My friend had the house noodles and while they weren't the complete failure that my curry noodles were, they still left much to be desired flavor wise.  

Not completely giving up on Yamo but doubt I'll be in a hurry to rush back. I get the overall hype for the price and hipster-dive appeal but flavor trumps both in my opinion and it begins with salt.

excerpts: I don't have much to add other than to highlight that it's cash-only, definitely order the house noodle (small portion, I ended up splitting another order with said friend) + tea leaf salad, and expect to wait as this place is teeny tiny.
up.author: Corrina S.
up.review:
YAMO IS YUM-O! Hehe, had to do it. Stopped by last night based on a friend's recommendation. Really delicious - asian comfort food at its best. I don't have much to add other than to highlight that it's cash-only, definitely order the house noodle (small portion, I ended up splitting another order with said friend) + tea leaf salad, and expect to wait as this place is teeny tiny. 

P.S. The picture on the back of the menu is the most adorable. Look for it! ;)

excerpts: On the up side, food comes out fast especially if you order takeaway.
My bf and I ordered the garlic noodles w/ chicken and mango chicken.
The noodles were definitely the winner.
The dish was really tasty and a decent portion for $6.
up.author: Sophia H.
up.review:
This was definitely one of the cheapest eateries I've tried in the city so far. It is a TINY hole in the wall with very few seating. Cash only as well.

On the up side, food comes out fast especially if you order takeaway. My bf and I ordered the garlic noodles w/ chicken and mango chicken. The noodles were definitely the winner. The dish was really tasty and a decent portion for $6. My only slight complaint might be that it's also very oily.

The mango chicken was decent too, but way too spicy and we weren't expecting it. I wish they made a note of how intense the spice is for that dish. It was pretty average overall and also pretty oily.

Overall I'd definitely like to return to sit in and try some of the noodle soups they have. It was a bit harder to order than with take out.

excerpts: Cheap food, sign me up!
We came on a Thursday night so there was a bit of a wait
but we talked to our line neighbors
and I definitely felt like I was in SF with all the quirky characters around.

As is mentioned in all the reviews, they are not friendly here, we got shooed for talking too much during our meal, but that is part of the ambiance and what can you expect for a place that only seats 6 people at a time.
I enjoyed my house noodles- tasted home made and delicious.
The tea leaf salad was very very spicy but enjoyable.
I would definitely come back.
Cash only!
up.author: Vivian D.
up.review: Cheap food, sign me up! We came on a Thursday night so there was a bit of a wait but we talked to our line neighbors and I definitely felt like I was in SF with all the quirky characters around.  As is mentioned in all the reviews, they are not friendly here, we got shooed for talking too much during our meal, but that is part of the ambiance and what can you expect for a place that only seats 6 people at a time. I enjoyed my house noodles- tasted home made and delicious. The tea leaf salad was very very spicy but enjoyable. I would definitely come back. Cash only!

excerpts: The first bite left my mouth dry from the unneeded salt, my stomach grumbling from the excessive grease, and expectations hoping that the next bite might live up to the hype.
Overall, the noodles were nothing exceptional, in terms of flavor, fullness, or bang for buck.
Not sure where all the hype is coming from, maybe my palette is a bit too sensitive to the greasiness-- don't think I'll be returning.
up.author: Sharath R.
up.review:
When I came here, I went in knowing that it was a small, hole-in-the-wall place, known for its angry, old chefs/owners, unclean kitchen, cramped bar seating, but most of all, it's apparently delicious and authentic Burmese noodles. All of these expectations were met in terms of service and ambience; however, the food was downright mediocre. For the price, it isn't terrible, but I wouldn't go in with high hopes. 

I tried the house noodles-- they were quite simple, noodles quickly sauteed in a mix of sauces and oil with some chicken and veggies thrown in. The first bite left my mouth dry from the unneeded salt, my stomach grumbling from the excessive grease, and expectations hoping that the next bite might live up to the hype. Overall, the noodles were nothing exceptional, in terms of flavor, fullness, or bang for buck. Not sure where all the hype is coming from, maybe my palette is a bit too sensitive to the greasiness-- don't think I'll be returning.

excerpts: Dishes are whipped up posthaste, and come out fresh, if a little small.
up.author: Casey S.
up.review:
Yamo is totally a hole-in-the-wall. I love how they keep the rolling street cans behind the counter without a care in the world. The health inspectors probably got paid off.

Cleanliness notwithstanding, I can totally dig the vibe of this place. With just a few stools and a long counter, it's real intimate. Dishes are whipped up posthaste, and come out fresh, if a little small. But that's ok - everything is around $6!

This is one of those places you go to when you're broke, not when you want Foreign Cinema 2.0.

excerpts: I grew up in an Asian household so noodles and rice is a staple in our culture, but Yamo's house special noodle and fried rice were way too greasy for my taste.
To wrap up my subpar dining experience, our server was terrible and utterly rude.
She glared at us for requesting to throw away the used chopsticks from the previous customers or when we asked for an extra plate to share our food.
The worst was when she muttered how we were too "talkative" and too "slow" under her breath.
Luckily we knew Cantonese
up.author: Michelle T.
up.review:
I've never written a review, let alone a bad one, but my experience at Yamo left me dissatisfied enough to write my first bad review. 

I grew up in an Asian household so noodles and rice is a staple in our culture, but Yamo's house special noodle and fried rice were way too greasy for my taste. If you want to skip the hour wait and still get the same quality food, go to Panda Express. 

To wrap up my subpar dining experience, our server was terrible and utterly rude. She glared at us for requesting to throw away the used chopsticks from the previous customers or when we asked for an extra plate to share our food. The worst was when she muttered how we were too "talkative" and too "slow" under her breath. Luckily we knew Cantonese so we caught on to this horrible display of customer service. 

It's safe to say that you definitely get what you pay here...both in food and service.

excerpts: There are only about 10 seats at the counter, and you can watch the ladies cook up your meal while you wait.
Unfortunately, you'll end up smelling like grease afterwards, but it's totally worth it.
up.author: Allen T.
up.review:
Yamo is literally a greasy hole in the wall that serves delicious food, and it's really cheap!  There are only about 10 seats at the counter, and you can watch the ladies cook up your meal while you wait. Unfortunately, you'll end up smelling like grease afterwards, but it's totally worth it.

I really like the house noodles with beef, which is essentially Chinese egg noodles topped with beef and a lot of fried garlic. It's very simple, delicious, and cheap. 

The chicken noodle soup is really unique and is probably their best dish. It's served in a coconut broth which makes it super rich and creamy. Absolutely delicious!

The portions are on the smaller side, but a single entree is satisfying, without making you feel stuffed -- the perfect size for a lunch.

excerpts: (if you come with a party of more than 3-4, you're stupid and crazy) and wait for seats to open up on the counter.
The counter seats about 8 people.
And that's pushing it!
You get to watch one person cook, another prepare the dishes to be served, and another "man the counter".
She may not always be friendly, but you can tell she tries.
up.author: Aaron Y.
up.review:
Definitely my favorite Burmese spot in town (and around). I've been here twice (visited a few other Burmese spots more than once as well) and can honestly say that the food here is off the hook! Portions on some dishes aren't too big, but the price is just right! You've gotta get the tea leaf salad. Without question, this is my favorite tea leaf salad in the Bay. Their house noodles are super good and the catfish stew is pretty good, if you like catfish.

You basically wait in line outside (if you come with a party of more than 3-4, you're stupid and crazy) and wait for seats to open up on the counter. The counter seats about 8 people. And that's pushing it! You get to watch one person cook, another prepare the dishes to be served, and another "man the counter". She may not always be friendly, but you can tell she tries. As long as you're not a jerk to her and wait for her to tell you when to sit, you should be good! 

I won't name other Burmese places that I've had that I didn't like or didn't like as much, but Yamo will give you more bang for your buck for sure. And there's one other place in particular that is always super packed, was featured on food network, and is probably 3rd on my list of Burmese restaurants. Yamo takes the cake on this one folks!

excerpts: Next up, the tea leaf salad.
We ended up getting gelato and drinks after and apologized for being smelly to the people we hung out with.
Your eyes will also burn for the duration of your stay since there's no ventilation
but...it's all worth it, especially watching the barking staff yell at you and everyone who wants to eat their food.
WHAT YOU WANT??
This is America, no one puts up with crappy customer service.
But trust me!
up.author: Shereen A.
up.review:
Came here last night because I was trying to find something that would hit the spot. Luckily there were only 4 people ahead of us and two wanted take out. We asked how long the wait was, got a cold stare and no response. Okay then!! We waited for about 25 minutes for a seat.

Let me put this into perspective. There's 8 bar stools in a cramped little location almost the size of a long hallway. There's more kitchen space than there is seating (which is understandable). So as we are waiting, we are literally standing behind other people that are eating, hovering, really.

As we waited for a table, we placed our order so once seated they could start cooking right away. 

So let's chat about something else while we wait to be seated. Service. I could not stop laughing at the way these ladies bark and yell at people. SERIOUSLY! Someone walks in and asks to place a to go order, "WHATYOUWANT?????" Lady taking the order writes down whatever sloppily then YELLS the dollar amount. No smile, no thank you, nothing. You don't come here for customer service. They are just outright rude, totally curt, and I find it hilarious. Forget special treatment, no one here gets any treatment! 

In the meantime, there's one stool available and this guy dining on his own asks if he could take it. Sure, we are waiting for 2 stools anyways. As soon as he sits down, another barking lady yells at him to get out and wait in line because there are others in front of him (even though everyone in front of him is ordering takeout). He's finally seated when he gets to the front of the line.

Also, there's some kind of sticky dripping substance that falls from the ceiling periodically. If it falls into your hair, pretty much plan on cutting it. I'm not joking. After repeated hair washing, it's still stuck (and this is many hours later). I'll have to cut it for him once he gets back from work.

We finally sit down, and samosas follow within ten or so minutes. So freaking delicious. I'm not a huge fan of the chunky samosas filled with globs of potato and peas. The thin, crispy, perfectly folded triangles are my favorite. They were served HOT HOT HOT with some sweet and spicy chili sauce. I could have eaten double the order!

Next up, the tea leaf salad. While not as good as Burma Superstar (a bit sweeter) it was still delicious and had an awesome crunch. 

Black bean tofu didn't really do much for me, meh. I prefer the Burmese food here more than the Chinese.

The house noodles were my favorite. Such a simple dish, yet insanely flavorful, I couldn't stop eating it (and yes, we were sharing). Fresh noodles, garlicky, light, saucy, what more can you ask for? 

Didn't try any meat dishes this time around but if the vegetarian options are THIS good, I can't wait to come back and stuff my face with some fish, beef, and chicken.

Since you're practically sitting IN a kitchen, you will smell like grease when you leave, and for hours later. We ended up getting gelato and drinks after and apologized for being smelly to the people we hung out with. Your eyes will also burn for the duration of your stay since there's no ventilation but...it's all worth it, especially watching the barking staff yell at you and everyone who wants to eat their food.  "WHAT YOU WANT?? RAAAAA"

There's no shrimp, clearly indicated by the cartoon shrimp pictures hanging in three locations. If you ask for it, you will be yelled at, "NOSHRIMP!!!!!!! BAAH!! NOO SHRIMP!!!!"

This is America, no one puts up with crappy customer service. But trust me! Here, you will, it's such a scene!

"CASH ONLY, RAAAAAAAAAA!!!!"

excerpts: If you grew up in a city, you know where/how to find the good inexpensive spots.
Yamo is one of them.
Run by three women who don't give a f
* if you are there or not.
Never idle, they are always cooking and tending to the stove and kitchen.
The results are glorious.
If good food is your number 1 determinant, I highly recommend Yamo.
If you are bothered by "poor" service, well, there are other places in the mission for you.
up.author: Ashley C.
up.review: I tire of hearing "Food in San Francisco is so expensive". If you grew up in a city, you know where/how to find the good inexpensive spots. Yamo is one of them. Run by three women who don't give a f** if you are there or not. Never idle, they are always cooking and tending to the stove and kitchen. The results are glorious. If good food is your number 1 determinant, I highly recommend Yamo. If you are bothered by "poor" service, well, there are other places in the mission for you.

excerpts: The way she yelled "NO PICTURES OK" to my mom, idk.. why don't you post up a sign for no pictures then?
up.author: Maggie G.
up.review:
Food: upper 3.5 stars
Service: 2 stars

I'm not turned off by the lack of enthusiasm in service, but I think the lady was borderline offensive and I believe it's really a mutual relationship when we go to a restaurant, pay them, and get the food we want. The way she yelled "NO PICTURES OK" to my mom, idk.. why don't you post up a sign for no pictures then? 

On top of that, I don't think the food is great. I'm not comparing it to any other Burmese place, because I realize the take is a little different; more like a street vendor kind of food. However, the tea salad was $6.5, tiny, and did not have enough cabbage. Everything was good, not amazing, and on the salty side. The cold noodles were good, $6.5, spicy, oily. The house noodles were good, oily, also $6.5. Not really a lot to be said about their flavors except "it's not bad." The samusas were delicious though, at $4.25, potatoes had a great texture and flavor.

Anyway, I probably won't be back here unless it's a cold day and I want to try their chicken noodle soup, which looked really good. All their food would be awesome with beer but no alcoholic beverages are allowed in there.

excerpts: I grew up eating authentic Burmese food.
up.author: Alias A.
up.review:
I grew up eating authentic Burmese food. This place was an utter disappointment if what you're looking for is authentic Burmese cuisine. 

Food--The fish chowder soup here barely had fish--or onion, ginger, lemongrass etc that are key Burmese ingredients. Instead it's thickened with corn starch which I have never noticed in all the other times I've had this dish elsewhere. Also the noodle salad is a JOKE. Authentic Burmese noodle salad has dried shrimp and Chana bean and tamarind at the very least. You get diluted chili sauce on your noodles here instead. You get what you pay for here. I would've gladly paid 2x for something closer to Burmese food. 

Service--I don't ask a lot in terms of service. I'm used to Chinese restaurants, where service is run ok different standards than American ones. But here? The woman really is rude. I understand Burmese and can hear her curse customers in Burmese. She literally cursed about a customer who called to change his order. Maybe it's an insecurity because her English is limited, but the day I was here, she seemed pretty upset and was taking it out on customers. Someone asked for more cabbage in her tea lead salad because it was too spicy for her and the woman behind the counter literally said "no."

excerpts: I highly recommend you order for pick up, the service is 0 stars because it's non existent and the place is really dirty (just watch them cook and handle ingredients, and then take a look at their sad excuse of a kitchen).
I honestly don't even know why people bother tipping someone like her.
That's just validating her terrible attitude towards people who pay HER for food and service.
up.author: Claudia C.
up.review:
I officially cannot stand the angry Asian lady with the fro and refuse to patron here again. She completely ignored us purposely when we sat down at the bar area because she got pissed off that we wanted to wait for a couple to finish eating so we could sit in their seats. Completely unprofessional and rude. We literally sat there for half an hour as she took other people's orders and not ours. We patiently waited for her this entire time, but she willfully ignored us and scowled. Needless to say, we walked out. I'm not expecting good service at a hole-in-the-wall that has been due for renovations a decade or two ago, but I do expect basic human courtesy for your customers. So disappointing.

I highly recommend you order for pick up, the service is 0 stars because it's non existent and the place is really dirty (just watch them cook and handle ingredients, and then take a look at their sad excuse of a kitchen). I honestly don't even know why people bother tipping someone like her. That's just validating her terrible attitude towards people who pay HER for food and service. Ridiculous! 

If you must come here for food, you do get what you pay for. The only reason I used to come here was for the prices (seriously unbeatable), but again you get what you pay for. If something seems too good to be true, it probably is.

excerpts: But do not bother calling because they do not pick up the phone.
The lady here is like a soup nazi.
I tried to order extra noodles but she refused.
She hurts your feelings by yelling at you.
I tried speaking Chinese to get better treatment but the lady behind the counter is indiscriminate.
One star ding for how cramped and mean it is when she raises her voice.
Another star dinged for the lady using her bare hands to pull the noodles from the colander.
Unfortunately I do not think I will be back.
up.author: Carina L.
up.review: Food is delicious and cheap as heck for SF restaurants. Be prepared to wait in line for a seat, sit in a cramped hallway and try not to bring a big backpack. Order to go to make it quick. But do not bother calling because they do not pick up the phone. The lady here is like a soup nazi. I tried to order extra noodles but she refused. She hurts your feelings by yelling at you. I tried speaking Chinese to get better treatment but the lady behind the counter is indiscriminate. One star ding for how cramped and mean it is when she raises her voice. Another star dinged for the lady using her bare hands to pull the noodles from the colander. Unfortunately I do not think I will be back.

excerpts: Had high expectations coming into this place after all the hype... and it definitely met up with my expectations!
If you go into your meal mentally prepared that the service would be horrible..
it's actually not too bad and kind of funny.
Only about 8 seats in the whole restaurant and 3 old ladies working.
up.author: Janet L.
up.review:
Had high expectations coming into this place after all the hype... and it definitely met up with my expectations! If you go into your meal mentally prepared that the service would be horrible.. it's actually not too bad and kind of funny. Only about 8 seats in the whole restaurant and 3 old ladies working. One cooked, one cut vegetables and the other one (lady with the fro) is the one that like to yell at everyone for being slow and telling people they are "annoying" in Burmese ( I only understood because it's similar to Cantonese) as she takes the orders and quickly cleans the tables... 

As for the food, I ordered 2 entrees... (and got yelled at for ordering 2 because the lady thought I wouldn't be able to finish both... which I did :) )
I got the Yamo House noodle with pork which was absolutely AMAZING! the noodles were perfectly chewy and the roasted garlic gave it such a simple but flavorful taste. ($6.50)
I also ordered the black bean with fish over jasmine rice dish which was good but nothing to rave about.

The House Noodle though... sooo good that I had to get one TO-GO to bring to my mom in Los Angeles tomorrow. I got lucky as they are cash only and I only brought a 20 dollar bill.

excerpts: I ordered the chef selection noodles that stated to be $6... as well as the spring rolls being $4.. and the bottled coke soda to be $2.... how does all this add up to $13?!
suppose to be $12...
Despite all this being said they also have people wait for at least 15+ minutes after you're done eating to hand you the bill....
LIKE
I SAID, IF YOU WANT GOOD GREASEY FOOD COME..
BUT IF YOU WANT SERVICE AND
CLEANLINESS......
DO NOT COME!!!
I was just very dissappointed and had a very crappy experience..
Please don't think of this as an exaggeration..
This was my experience every single time I come here to dine....
up.author: Wayne C.
up.review: If you're looking for good greasey food then Yamo is the place to dine at, BUT if you're looking for good service and cleanliness then Yamo is not the place for you. I LOVE coming here to eat but the service and cleanliness makes me think twice everytime I come here... The two older ladies that work there always greet people in but they NEVER clean or wipe the counter when guests come to dine in.... NASTY.. I always have to wipe the counter down when I come in to eat because they never do... Another thing I DISLIKE about Yamo is that they do false advertising on their menus.. even if it is .25 cents... still... they should correct that and put the new prices in.. I ordered the chef selection noodles that stated to be $6... as well as the spring rolls being $4.. and the bottled coke soda to be $2.... how does all this add up to $13?! suppose to be $12... Despite all this being said they also have people wait for at least 15+ minutes after you're done eating to hand you the bill.... SO.... LIKE I SAID, IF YOU WANT GOOD GREASEY FOOD COME.. BUT IF YOU WANT SERVICE AND CLEANLINESS...... DO NOT COME!!! I was just very dissappointed and had a very crappy experience.. Please don't think of this as an exaggeration.. This was my experience every single time I come here to dine....

excerpts: Having grown up in China, I've eaten bugs from street vendors and intestine skewers at the dirtiest restaurants, but my stomach had always emerged the champion.
However, as I hunched over the toilet, perspiring profusely, it dawned on me that no king rules forever.
up.author: Joshua Z.
up.review:
As endless streams of brown chunks flew from my mouth into the toilet, I couldn't help but taste the fish chowder I had earlier in the day from Yamo. Having grown up in China, I've eaten bugs from street vendors and intestine skewers at the dirtiest restaurants, but my stomach had always emerged the champion. However, as I hunched over the toilet, perspiring profusely, it dawned on me that no king rules forever. I finally had food poisoning. 

Spending the whole day in bed had reminded me how fragile life can be. Thank you the sassy ladies of Yamo for teaching me humility in life, and reminding me of my mortality.

excerpts: This place is perfect if you want to pick up good quality good portioned food for a budget, especially if you know what to get.
The place had very limited seating and doesn't seem too comfortable
up.author: Charles M.
up.review:
This place is perfect if you want to pick up good quality good portioned food for a budget, especially if you know what to get. The place had very limited seating and doesn't seem too comfortable so I opted for takeout.

Some of the items I've had:
1. Curry chicken  ($6.25 , 5 stars) over rice. This plate came with potatoes peppers and other vegetables with a delicious sauce. Tied with the chicken noodle soup, it's a great deal for your buck.
2. Chicken noodle soup ($6, 5 stars) this soup came in 2 sewers mate containers, one with the broth and the other with the ingredients.
3. Tea leaf salad ($6, 3 stars) it was very small and as expensive as an entree. It was good but I'd pass if you're looking for value.
4. Mango chicken($6.25,3 stars) over rice. a lot of people give great reviews on the mango chicken so despite it sounding weird I tried it. It was ok but I'm not a fan of sweets and missed the delicious potatoes in the curry chicken!

excerpts: The woman there is straight up mean.
Maybe she's sick of cooking and serving all these years and needs to retire.
up.author: A L.
up.review:
There's bad service (unintentional) and then there's mean service (intentional).  The woman there is straight up mean. Maybe she's sick of cooking and serving all these years and needs to retire. But I'll take my money elsewhere. 

Food is just so-so, yeah prices are cheap, but definitely not good enough to overcome the vitriol of this woman.

excerpts: Chubby lady doesn't even look up but proceeds to cook with a dirty look on her face, she says angrily,"No.
You already said to-go!
We were just as shocked as the customer eating in front of her.
So my friend and I laugh it off and accept it.
Once our noodles were done, we pay.
I asked another lady for some hot sauce and she slams ONE dinky container on the counter and rolled her eyes at me.
up.author: Laura T.
up.review:
This place is disgusting. 

We ordered the house noodles to go (from the chubby lady with curly short hair) since there were no seats available. As we were waiting for our food to be cooked, we see a couple leave their seats. So we immediately asked the cook (the one who took our order) if we could dine in instead. Chubby lady doesn't even look up but proceeds to cook with a dirty look on her face, she says angrily,"No. You already said to-go!" We were just as shocked as the customer eating in front of her. So my friend and I laugh it off and accept it. Once our noodles were done, we pay. I asked another lady for some hot sauce and she slams ONE dinky container on the counter and rolled her eyes at me. As we walked out slowly, the cook gives us the world's UGLIEST, DIRTIEST, REPULSIVE, GRUESOME look ever.

Now for the house-noodles. They were drenched in oil and barely had any meat. It was like having Chinese chow-mein noodles. If you want real Burmese food, I suggest you make a trip to either one of these restaurants: Burma Cafe, Burma Super Star or B-Star.

excerpts: Spice it up with their side vinegar-ed, mini, chopped jalepenos and it will be smacking delicious!
up.author: Tiffany D.
up.review:
Undeniably a hole in the wall that seats about 8-10 people for yummy, homely cooked Burmese entrees!  Just bring one other person with you!  It's impossible to fit a group together in here.

I felt like a compacted sardine while dining here at this grub spot, but the food was worthy to try!

The food is so cheap here - more or less 6 bucks each for appetizers or entrees.

I love their Tea Leaf Salad!  It was crunchy, tasty and unique.  Too bad the proportion of this salad is small.  It teased my palate.

Their Stir-Fried Black Bean Fish with Rice was good.  Spice it up with their side vinegar-ed, mini, chopped jalepenos and it will be smacking delicious!

As for their Yamo House Noodles with your choice of beef, chicken or pork, it was slurping good.  

My friend and I couldn't stay a bit to chat ever more after we finished our meals- we felt rushed with the fair line waiting outside!

excerpts: She suggested Yamo so we decided to call in an order for pick-up.
Alex rattled off a couple items and then asked a question about the third.
The lady on the other end yelled "Yeah!" and hung up.
Baffled, we called a Chinese takeout place instead.
Without pulling out my phone to Yelp something I've tried and loved, Yamo popped up from the vault deep in my memory of things to try, so off we went.
4 stars on Yelp and 1200 reviews...
what could go wrong, right?
It's a suuuper small place with a bar that seats less than ten.
Your food is prepared literally right in front of you.
It looked like a mother-daughter duo behind the scenes, and one of them told me very quickly that there is no photography allowed.
up.author: Olivia V.
up.review:
For the record, I really thought I would like Yamo. I've been asked "Have you ever been to Yamo?" by fellow foodies countless times over the past several years. A few months ago, my friend Alex and I were hanging out at her place and we had to figure out what to do for dinner. She suggested Yamo so we decided to call in an order for pick-up. Alex rattled off a couple items and then asked a question about the third. The lady on the other end yelled "Yeah!" and hung up. Baffled, we called a Chinese takeout place instead. I wrote off this incident as a combination of the language barrier/how busy they are and vowed to step foot into Yamo one day and give them a try. 

That day was today. My buddy and I were hungry after an adventure at Heath Ceramics. Without pulling out my phone to Yelp something I've tried and loved, Yamo popped up from the vault deep in my memory of things to try, so off we went. 4 stars on Yelp and 1200 reviews...what could go wrong, right? It's a suuuper small place with a bar that seats less than ten. Your food is prepared literally right in front of you. It looked like a mother-daughter duo behind the scenes, and one of them told me very quickly that there is no photography allowed. Oh well, at least she apologized. 

Mo Hinga was alright. The house noodles with beef were also just okay as well, but rather salty. The coconut chicken noodle soup was better than the other two but it was super oily. Each dish was bathing in MSG, for which I have a genuine disdain. I am still thirsty after eating here in the early evening. We walked out the door paying about $20 for three items, so it is on the inexpensive end of the spectrum as far as eats go in the gentrified Mission area. As the old adage goes, however, "You get what you pay for", and in this case, it is small portions. You may pay $10 a dish at popular, albeit overhyped, Burma Superstar on Clement Street, but you get $4 more worth of food. You also don't get the urge to swallow the entire Pacific Ocean after a meal at Burma, so there's that.

excerpts: What's up?
What's up?
What do you want?
Laughable service as all the other reviews have mentioned.
up.author: Fiona M.
up.review:
What's up?

That is literally how you'll be greeted by one of the staff at Yamo. No matter if they know you or they don't, standard "greeting" goes. What's up? What do you want? Laughable service as all the other reviews have mentioned. I went in expecting that so it was all good.

Been there a couple of times and I can't seem to stay away from their house noodles. Garlicky noodly goodness. Both beef and chicken options are good. Didn't care for their samosas though. Will be back to try their other dishes if I have the willpower.

excerpts: Don't expect anything from their service, the people are quite mean but no one cares, there's always people lining up out the door and people ordering for take out.
up.author: Rohenne L.
up.review:
House noodles with beef. That is all you need to get! Other stuff is just okay. The house noodles are the best.

It's a hole in the wall place with really bad service, not the cleanest place but if you want a fast comfort meal this is the place! (Although there's so much fried garlic in the noodles you will taste and smell like garlic for a whole day)

The potstickers are not well done, definitely prefer Japanese gyozas. The tea salad was below average, not worth getting.

Don't expect anything from their service, the people are quite mean but no one cares, there's always people lining up out the door and people ordering for take out.

excerpts: but I'd try and hit it up at off hours b/c you can only seat like 10 people in there
and it gets hot especially if you are seated towards the back.
I typically get the House Noodles and the Tea Leaf Salad and that's super filling.
The ladies that work here take no crap and you might have to speak up to get your order taken
but they know what they are doing with the eats!
up.author: Gene X.
up.review: What I haven't reviewed Yamo?  Love this place!  Cheap, quick and dirty!  It might not look like much but I'd try and hit it up at off hours b/c you can only seat like 10 people in there and it gets hot especially if you are seated towards the back.  I typically get the House Noodles and the Tea Leaf Salad and that's super filling.  The ladies that work here take no crap and you might have to speak up to get your order taken but they know what they are doing with the eats! :)

excerpts: It is simple but flavorful and fills you up.
The only thing that I did not like here is that it is really small and a bit cramped.
You sit on stools and eat at the counter in front of the kitchen.
It is kind of cool because you can watch them cook everything while you are waiting.
I came at that awkward hour between lunch and dinner
so I got in right away.
However after I finished eating, there was a long line waiting to get in.
You get your own drinks in their refrigerator.
I would recommend getting soda because both the soda can and water bottle cost a dollar.
up.author: Dang L.
up.review: I had high expectations from this place because it was recommended to me from an elite yelper friend.  Yamo definitely met those expectations.  Cheap for the quality and quantity of food that you get.  I really like the Yamo House Noodles.  It is simple but flavorful and fills you up.  The only thing that I did not like here is that it is really small and a bit cramped.  You sit on stools and eat at the counter in front of the kitchen.  It is kind of cool because you can watch them cook everything while you are waiting.  I came at that awkward hour between lunch and dinner so I got in right away.  However after I finished eating, there was a long line waiting to get in.  You get your own drinks in their refrigerator.  I would recommend getting soda because both the soda can and water bottle cost a dollar.

excerpts: As a result, we got impatient and just decided to order take-out - for that you can basically skip the line and go up to the counter to order.
These had a really thick skin, and several of them had opened up.
up.author: Ziyan C.
up.review:
My bf's favorite dinner spot in the Mission, so of course I've gotta try it! Very hole-in-the wall, very small and crowded. 

There were several people at the door waiting to get in at about 6:30pm on a Friday night that got much larger in the next 30 minutes or so that we were there. Part of the issue was there was a group of four (and I think the entire restaurant seats about 8), and even though there were 2 or 3 empty seats already, they wanted to wait until they had 4 consecutive seats together to go in. There were several groups of 2 behind them that could easily have sat down, but no, those empty seats went to waste.

As a result, we got impatient and just decided to order take-out - for that you can basically skip the line and go up to the counter to order. It took maybe 15-20 minutes, and please note that it's CASH ONLY!

For Burmese food, I generally expect it to be like Chinese but with much more intense and exotic flavors. I didn't really get from my meal - for Chinese food, it is solid and dirt cheap - great bang for your buck! But for Burmese, it let me down somewhat. Maybe my expectations were off.

* Tea Leaf Salad - 4 stars
Pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yamo-san-francisco?select=b3DnX-N0JKwiWh_YqX2wnw#r0xprnCxEQGkuXWpDldz5A
Best dish of the night for me. Pretty spicy! I liked the mung beans and peanuts, which added a great crunch. This was definitely a unique dish. It could've been more fresh (it seemed kind of limp/squashed into the bottom of the takeout container - kind of sad-looking - but maybe that's because we got it to go, had to run to get cash, and then walked the 3 or 4 blocks home).

* Beef noodle - 3.5 stars
Pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yamo-san-francisco?select=b3DnX-N0JKwiWh_YqX2wnw#b3DnX-N0JKwiWh_YqX2wnw
The noodles were soft, the beef tender. Good but overall this could've used a lot more flavor.

* Tofu/veg - 3 stars
Pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yamo-san-francisco?select=b3DnX-N0JKwiWh_YqX2wnw#vXwjYx5d1Tu-BZJPImZcmQ
My bf's favorite dish, and I have a hard time understanding why. This was not bad but I found it really plain and lacking in flavor. The tofu was soft and chewy, the skin chewy (not so much crispy).

* Dumplings - 3.5 stars
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yamo-san-francisco?select=b3DnX-N0JKwiWh_YqX2wnw#f0DbxFv2Sh1UcV5tdApunQ
These had a really thick skin, and several of them had opened up. The filling was packed really tight, so that it made its own little densely packed ball with a lot of open space between it and the skin.

Menu: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/yamo-san-francisco?select=zo-creEoZpyOcqTp5dE_Pw#zo-creEoZpyOcqTp5dE_Pw

excerpts: Lastly, chat it up with the waiter because she really was sassy, but in a good way!
up.author: Kevin C.
up.review:
I am so glad that I found this hole-in-the-wall from Yelp; this place really did not disappoint. First tip, it is Cash Only so make sure you bring enough but you can really get a lot of food for very cheap prices. Another tip, there really isn't much seating so I would recommend getting there early before the actual time you plan to eat or take it out. Lastly, chat it up with the waiter because she really was sassy, but in a good way!

We ordered some great dishes, everything we tried was good; some to name was the curry dish, the tea leave salad, and the house noodles. The portions are great and I was glad I came with a group of people so we ordered a number of dishes that we shared. One thing that I liked about Yamo is that it truly felt like I was eating in someone's home; the employees there were really friendly and it was truly unexpected. The food comes out really quick and it all tasted real good. Definitely will come back when I'm in the area.

excerpts: all lined up at the counter facing the chefs, so you need to stand in line outside the door on the sidewalk.
up.author: Rica Z.
up.review:
The wait for lunch on Saturday was about 15-20 minutes. Not too bad. It is a very small space with maybe 10 chairs total all lined up at the counter facing the chefs, so you need to stand in line outside the door on the sidewalk.

1) Cash only
2) No photos (the ladies will yell at you if you try to take photos of them)
3) Most dishes are only $6.25!! Awesome deal for delicious food

My friend recommended the house noodles and basically every photo on Yelp is of the house noodles so I decided to try them. I love the dish because the noodles are flavorful yet so simple at the same time. It's basically noodles, chicken, cilantro, and garlic. The chicken is also super tender and delicious even though it is chicken breast meat.

excerpts: I have yet to try Burma Star, but will let you know how that one stacks-up once I know
up.author: Stephanie T.
up.review:
There's Burma Love, which is a pricey hipster amazing Burmese place in the Mission. A few blocks away: Burma Love's uglier, greasier, but cheaper sister. 

Cash only.
$19 for Yamo house noodles, tea leaf salad, and black bean tofu (all enough to feed 2 people).

This hole-in-the-wall spot is tiny, with just a few places to sit, making it ideal for a solo traveler wanting to get in/out, but more likely will suit the likes of take-out peeps. 

Get ready to blot your mouth (grease) and add some Sriracha (it's pretty mild) but as far as Burmese goes, this is definitely second-place to Burma Love. I have yet to try Burma Star, but will let you know how that one stacks-up once I know :)

excerpts: So...you end up eating raw slices of onion in a soup that's too mild to cut the bite.
up.author: Melissa W.
up.review:
Been here twice - the first time, they forgot to put tea leaf in my tea leaf salad. The second time, they talked sh*t about a customer who didn't have cash. The chicken noodle soup was just ramen noodle, stir fried chicken (not shredded), raw shallots and raw green onion. With coconut soup poured on top that's not hot enough to cook the shallots and onion. So...you end up eating raw slices of onion in a soup that's too mild to cut the bite. 

Cheap for SF but half the quality of any decent place in LA.

excerpts: With those in mind, we expected amazing authentic Burmese/Chinese food to make up for the lackluster ambiance and service.
What we experienced was salty Chinese food that didn't taste Burmese at all.
The potstickers were way too gingery, the curry noodles were so salty (by the way, the lady refused to give us water to wash it down), and the stir fry veggies were a salty, soy saucey mess.
There are far better and more authentic Burmese restaurants in SF and the Peninsula.
Please save yourself and skip this restaurant.
I really hope this place closes down.
up.author: Leslie F.
up.review: This place is terrible! The food is disgusting and the owner is mean, which made the whole dining experience painful. My friend and I came here knowing full well it was a hole-in-the-wall with a less-than-friendly owner lady. With those in mind, we expected amazing authentic Burmese/Chinese food to make up for the lackluster ambiance and service. What we experienced was salty Chinese food that didn't taste Burmese at all. The potstickers were way too gingery, the curry noodles were so salty (by the way, the lady refused to give us water to wash it down), and the stir fry veggies were a salty, soy saucey mess. There are far better and more authentic Burmese restaurants in SF and the Peninsula. Please save yourself and skip this restaurant. I really hope this place closes down.

excerpts: House noodles - not sure about authenticity here, but it did remind of oiled up Shan noodles and however YAMO seasons and cooks their beef is working for them and for their customers.
I totally get why this is a best seller
up.author: Priti K.
up.review:
Oh Yamo, I'm beyond happy you exist. Having spent 3 weeks in Burma and some time along the Thai border I was so excited to try this little hole-in-the-wall.  I have not had tea leaf salad since my blissful backpacking days. 

Tealeaf salad - The flavor is surprisingly and deliciously spot on. My only complaint is the portion size. They go really light on the beans - wouldn't hurt to throw some more crunchiness on there. Nonetheless, there is a restaurant within 2 miles of me that sells tea leaf salad that's not only passable, but freakin' amazing! The punch in flavor is exactly what I miss. It's not too sour, it's the right salty. It's the best!

House noodles - not sure about authenticity here, but it did remind of oiled up Shan noodles and however YAMO seasons and cooks their beef is working for them and for their customers. I totally get why this is a best seller and I can't wait for my next time.

Other things to remember. This place is REALLY small. There's almost always a wait. Don't try to save a seat for a friend, you'll get shooed aside quickly. But people are in and out and don't linger, so be patient!

excerpts: Since we already started eating we ended up with both dishes.
Next up a odd couple comes in one singing and the other just kinda being loud with her request.
Some how her pot sticker sauce wasn't right for her.
Think she was expecting some type of sweet and sour sauce.
So she asked for another sauce, but basically told no.
Then she asked for the chili sauce calling it the sweet and spicy sauce and told no that's not sweet!
Then this is when It gets good.
Then all the sudden she tells the lady at the counter there was a hair on the pot stickers.
Oh the look on the ladies face behind the counter.
She grabs the dish throws it out and says "No more!
up.author: Nick J.
up.review:
Came in sat down to order while the bf went to the atm.  I was told to wait outside as soon as I told them we were a party of 2.  Luckily he came back from and we grabbed some seats.  We  ordered the tea leaf salad, Yamo house noodles, and mango chicken.  All tasted really good even though the mango chicken seemed off. 

Then we noticed that we were actually eating the girl next to us cold noodles, which were actually not cold. Since the girl next to us complained she received the wrong dish they slam the mango chicken on the counter next to us. Since we already started eating we ended up with both dishes. Then it got really awkward as the girl glares at us while we eat and they take forever to replace her food. 

Next up a odd couple comes in one singing and the other just kinda being loud with her request.  Some how her pot sticker sauce wasn't right for her.  Think she was expecting some type of sweet and sour sauce.  So she asked for another sauce, but basically told no.  Then she asked for the chili sauce calling it the sweet and spicy sauce and told no that's not sweet!  Then this is when It gets good. Then all the sudden she tells the lady at the counter there was a hair on the pot stickers.  Oh the look on the ladies face behind the counter.  She grabs the dish throws it out and says "No more!"  Tried so hard to keep it together.

We hurry get the check and notice we were charged for the dish we did not order, but we just decided let it go. So end of story really tasty food, angry service, very tight space, and I wouldn't recommend making any complaints.

excerpts: Next to my seat there was couple and after they paid, the owner was pushing their tea cups away to tell to pick it up!
That was just nut!
Looks like she just had a bad day, but please don't take it out on the customers!
I'm all supportive of small businesses but this lady should treat people nicer.
up.author: Tom V.
up.review:
I like hole-in-the-wall restaurants, you get mom and pop's cooking and with good value.  I usually don't expect much of the service and ambience from places like this but I never seen bad treatment from the owner like this before (the owner was rude to everyone, not just me).   I happened to be near the area, decided to come in here because of 4 star review and decent pictures.    I sat down the counter and started to order, the owner face was frown and looks angry.  She took my order fine, then when I order the drink, she just told me to go get it myself.  At this point, I was still ok.  My tea salad was good, but very small portion of just cabbage ($6.50), but the house noodle came with very little meat and the portion was also small ($6.50), but the problem is the sauce was so greasy and SALTY!!! I asked if I could have some shredded cabbage to balance out the saltiness, she said "NO!" - then I offered to pay for the cabbage, she just shook her head..  I was just laughing away..    Next to my seat there was couple and after they paid, the owner was pushing their tea cups away to tell to pick it up!  That was just nut!  Looks like she just had a bad day, but please don't take it out on the customers!  I'm all supportive of small businesses but this lady should treat people nicer.  About the price, it seems like cheap, but you need to order a couple dishes - so it's better to go to a Vietnamese, Chinese or Mexican restaurant to get a decent size of food for about the same price.

Check out other 1 star reviews and you will see... This is beyond "don't expect 5 star treatment"...

excerpts: Our four dishes totaled up to $24 and for $8 per person, that's a pretty sweet deal.
up.author: Mai K.
up.review:
This is how my visit to Yamo went down. 

Friend: Their Tea salad is great. Definitely recommend. 
Me: Out of all their items, you recommend a salad? 
Friend: It's really good. 

So we wait about 30 minutes to get into this place because it's basically a hole in the wall that seats 8 people at any one time at a bar like setting We order a few things to try since their pricing is quite reasonable. $4-6 per item if I remember correctly. 

Ordered their Tea salad (of course), yamo house noodles with pork, fish chowder noodle soup, and black bean fish for our group of 3. Tea salad was really delicious. It's comprised of a lot of deep fried onions, which gives the salad a nice crunch to it. You really have to just try it out. The dish is rather small so I'd get one for myself next time. Yamo House noodles with pork was really simple. Just noodles with stir fried pork. There wasn't too much seasoning that I could see, but it was still rather tasty. Fish chowder noodle soup was probably my favorite. I don't know what was the crispy bit of the soup was, but it created a great texture contrast to the soup, which I loved. The black bean fish dish was probably my least favorite of the 4. It was good, but I think I'm used to the black beans not being so strong. I prefer a more subtle taste. 

Our four dishes totaled up to $24 and for $8 per person, that's a pretty sweet deal.

excerpts: There's only about 10 counter-bar seats so you can imagine how quick this place could fill up during normal eating times.
up.author: Amy X.
up.review:
This is for sure one of my favorite hidden gems in SF. Brought a friend from out of town to try and I think he was pretty impressed. He said he felt like he was eating in Asia. Can't really get this type of hole-in-the-wall experience elsewhere in city. 

Best time to come is the weird hour. Between lunch and dinner (3-4pm) so you don't have to wait. There's only about 10 counter-bar seats so you can imagine how quick this place could fill up during normal eating times. 

Order #5, the tea leaf salad and #15, the Yamo House noodles with beef. These noodles are the best! My comfort food! And then afterwards, walk over two blocks to Bi-Rite and wash it down with the best ice cream in the city!

excerpts: I had the chicken noodle soup and with some sprucing up with the spices and soy, this dish is a hands down winner.
No doubt about it I would get it if I was sick in bed or out on the streets getting flashy, great price, flavor and authenticity to its region.
The place has a great vibe that could only be known to locals in the city.
Wait the line to get in its worth it!
Btw CASH
ONLY
up.author: Brittany C.
up.review: This place is a whole in the wall that will transport you to another land for the duration of your meal. As soon as you step in you are yelled at to sit by the three bad ass women that run this foundation. They are sassy and I'm loving all of it. They let you know when they are ready for your order and by the looks of the intimate chats and steaming dishes you best order when you get the chance to. I had the chicken noodle soup and with some sprucing up with the spices and soy, this dish is a hands down winner. No doubt about it I would get it if I was sick in bed or out on the streets getting flashy, great price, flavor and authenticity to its region. The place has a great vibe that could only be known to locals in the city. Wait the line to get in its worth it! Btw CASH ONLY

excerpts: These three gals know what's up.
Before writing my review- I wanted to read some of the bad reviews...
To get a chuckle..
Face it...these three women have to deal with all the assholes the pretentious the crazies the over entitled .
You name it.
I hear people making reviews about omg
it's only 8 seats..
She's mean to me..
(hey whatever
up.author: Chris L.
up.review:
When it comes to Burmese good... These three gals know what's up. Before writing my review- I wanted to read some of the bad reviews... To get a chuckle.. Face it...these three women have to deal with all the assholes the pretentious the crazies the over entitled . You name it. I hear people making reviews about omg it's only 8 seats.. She's mean to me..(hey whatever sometimes I'm afraid to ask for a refill of water) 

BUT

You all wait.
You all bring new people here.
You all order Tea leaf salad.
And you all are thankful that the prices are low and the food is flavorful. 

They are some extremely hard working women--and Yamo is a SENSATION. 

To you three women I will  always keep coming back. 

You rock.

excerpts: Food was 3.5 stars for me but the awesome (low) prices makes me round up!
up.author: Jean L.
up.review: First time here and I ordered the tea leaf salad, mango salad, house noodle with chicken, and black bean fish. I liked the salads for their potent flavors, though I thought they were sort of drenched in their sauces. I've had black bean fish/clams/veg at lots of places and I thought this version was a little mild and bland - maybe it needed more garlic and more fermented beans? The noodles were homey and simple. Food was 3.5 stars for me but the awesome (low) prices makes me round up!

excerpts: It feels like an honor to eat here because it's like you're being invited into someone's kitchen" said the guy sitting next to us as his arm rubbed up against my friends in the crevice of a kitchen.
We slurped up those slippery suckers in what seemed like mere seconds.
We had debated on whether or not the tea leaf salad was a little too interesting for our tastes, but ended up getting it
and we regret nothing.
The tangy & spicy crunch was the perfect side dish that offered a refreshing lift from the heavy noodles.
up.author: Joyce K.
up.review:
"It feels like an honor to eat here because it's like you're being invited into someone's kitchen" said the guy sitting next to us as his arm rubbed up against my friends in the crevice of a kitchen. 

And it is true, Yamo is a remodeled closet turned kitchen. The intimate space only allows for 8 diners at a time who are sitting elbow to elbow as we greedily wait for our food to arrive. While the menu is small, all on one page, it's a difficult choice to make as all the options sound good and are $6 and under per plate. From tea leaf salad to mohinga (fish) chowder and house noodles, the stomach can't help but to be dazed by the options.

The counter lady/chef who has "invited" you into her kitchen is sassy and snappy, and honestly a little indifferent to your needs. This is no loving mother who feels the need to heal all your emotional wounds with her food. She's just trying to get through the long day herself, so please don't expect a coddling mother, this is the mother who has literally been slaving in the kitchen all day, and doesn't have time for your shenanigans. 

The order of house noodles with pork came out in a sheen of heavy oil that can only mean heavy food coma later. But oh how FRESH those noodles were. We slurped up those slippery suckers in what seemed like mere seconds. We had debated on whether or not the tea leaf salad was a little too interesting for our tastes, but ended up getting it and we regret nothing. The tangy & spicy crunch was the perfect side dish that offered a refreshing lift from the heavy noodles. The samusas really stretched our jeans to their limits with the hearty potato and spice filling. $16 bucks for 2 people and a jean waistband about to pop? So worth it.   

So save your change (they are cash only) ladies and gentleman and you too could have a fine meal at Yamo like the 1299 who have come before you!

excerpts: Heads up though-
The tea leaf salad is great but SUPER spicy!
I had to give mine away.
up.author: Sophia B.
up.review: Very solid little place. It is a joke in the wall and anyone expecting fine dining out of this place is just silly. It is however the exact kind of good old Chinese food that isn't really Chinese but you love it because it satisfies that craving but also is crazy fresh (unlike Panda Express type places where food was frozen and cooked hours ago. Heads up though-The tea leaf salad is great but SUPER spicy! I had to give mine away.

excerpts: ******actually THREW UP later that day).
up.author: Chapstiq G.
up.review:
Really, C'mon People.

Foiled by the Hipsters again!

I was so disappointed. I didn't even finish my meal & stomach has been upset ever since (******actually THREW UP later that day).


*I do give a shout out for the ladies for producing the food...'cause they sure stay busy!
-***but need to give the people what they want.  The guy sitting next to me offered to pay more for extra meat in his noodles and they refused..   In that sense the food was mechanically cranked out w/ little care for the end result.


Tea Leaf Salad--  What is all the fuss about?  
Indistinguishable sweet, Indistinguishable tart...the only flavor I tasted was Onions.
Will folks just stop w/ the sensationalist obsession w/ the so-called "Exotic".  SOOO tired. PLEASE!

Fish Noodle Stew--- Where was the fish?  Cause all I got in MY bowl was a watered down, unseasoned broth with shreds reminiscent of catfish.  Really people? Really???

Also--REALLY need to fix the ventilation.  Halfway through the meal my eyes were ON FIRE & BLOOD SHOT from all the smoke (good thing I packed my eyedrops).  Couldn't even finish eating if I wanted to (And this Is coming from a person that has previously lived in air-polluted Beijing!)

Needless to say Cheaply priced. True...but TASTELESS (felt like I was gnawing on air & styrofoam)  & NOT worth the tummy ache

excerpts: I was going to give one star, but they've kept the prices down for the most part - pricing all the $6 dishes up to $6.25, and perhaps they're just misguided
so I will give two for old time's sake.
Please allow me to offer some advice.
Raise the prices to whatever you need to raise them to, so that the food can be like it was a year or two ago.
I wouldn't go there again for the food I had last night even if it were free.
up.author: Steven P.
up.review:
How the mighty have fallen. This food is a salty, pallid insult to the fine cuisine this establishment used to create. I got three dishes last night, the tea leaf salad (devoid of tea leaves as the previous reviewer noted), the house noodles with beef (too salty, no curry flavor and missing most of the beef), and the cocoanut chicken noodle soup (best of the three but not good like in the past).
I was going to give one star, but they've kept the prices down for the most part - pricing all the $6 dishes up to $6.25, and perhaps they're just misguided so I will give two for old time's sake. 
Please allow me to offer some advice. Raise the prices to whatever you need to raise them to, so that the food can be like it was a year or two ago. I wouldn't go there again for the food I had last night even if it were free.

excerpts: The Yamo House Noodle is everything an definitely lives up to the hype.
So simple but so freaking good.
It's just noodle + meat + dried garlic.
And that's really all you need.
up.author: Emily C.
up.review:
OH HELL YEAH. I'm so happy I finally got to try this place.

The Yamo House Noodle is everything an definitely lives up to the hype. So simple but so freaking good. It's just noodle + meat + dried garlic. And that's really all you need. I believe it's $6.

Small hole in the wall place - I think 8-10 seats. But since the menu is so small and it's not really a place to hang out, turnover is fairly fast. OR, get take-out. If you sit down, you'll probably smell like food anyway because the stove and kitchen is right in front of you.

CASH ONLY.
Defiiiiintely going to come more often when I'm around the Dolores Park area.

excerpts: I've waited outside for over 30 minutes before anyone came to open up shop.
up.author: Xinxin W.
up.review:
Personally, I don't mind being screamed at by old asian ladies. It makes me feel right at home. 

What disappointed me about Yamo was not the service (or lack of) but the food itself. Everything is around $6 bucks but the portions are sooo small that you definitely need two orders per person. Small portions aside, the proportion of meat to carbs is just way off. For example, the famous house noodles with beef comes with 5 tiny pieces of beef. The rest is just bland noodles without any toppings or condiments. The tea salad was also a let down. I didn't even taste any lahpet in the tea salad! It was more of a 3 ingredient chopped lettuce salad. 

2 stars for the price and convenience. I would rather pay a bit more at Burma Superstar/Burma Love.

Tip-- Make sure you don't come right when they're suppose to open. They're always late! I've waited outside for over 30 minutes before anyone came to open up shop.

excerpts: I left smelling like oil and grease and still a bit hungry, but thankfully Bi-Rite Creamery is just up the street!
up.author: Mengo Z.
up.review:
I am huge huge fan of Burma Superstar and Burma Love, and even enjoy the food at Rangoon Ruby in Palo Alto, so I was excited to see what Yamo had in store when I visited for the first time last week.  My BF and I were lucky to snag a seat after only about a 5-minute wait at 6pm Friday evening.  I had heard that Yamo is a hole-in-the wall, so I tempered my expectations on cleanliness, courtesy and comfort accordingly and we squished in on the bar stool.

As we placed our orders - tea leaf salad, mango chicken, and house noodles with beef, we glanced around anxiously to see what everyone else had ordered, and were glad that we had chosen correctly.  However when the food came back, I was a little disappointed in the portions.  Don't get me wrong, $6.25 for a dish in SF is a steal, but the portions are probably half of what you would get at a standard Chinese take-out place, and none of the dishes were particularly savory.  Especially the tea leaf salad which was like cabbage and onions doused in sweet sticky sauce; I couldn't even taste a hint of the tea leaves.  Because it is all pre-mixed before it comes to you (I'm used to this dish being separated when presented tableside), you have no idea what is in it. 

The mango chicken was fine, but is more like sweet and sour chicken.  The best dish was the house noodles with beef, and the beef portions were minuscule (as with all the other meat portions) and the noodles slippery and greasy. Since we were still hungry after the 3 dishes, we also got the curry chicken soup - there were maybe 5 tiny slivers of chicken and the broth was very bland.

I have trouble categorizing this as Burmese food.  It seemed like an oily, not-as-flavorful variation of Chinese food from your typical Chinese takeout restaurant on the corner, and I didn't think it warranted any comparisons to the other more well-known Burmese establishments in SF.  Props to the older ladies behind the counter who cranked out the dishes; one of them was even wearing a wool beanie as she stir fried everything as if she could do it blindfolded.

$30 for dinner for two isn't bad, but I would definitely prefer to spend 2x more on quality REAL Burmese food any other day, and eat at home the rest of the time.  I left smelling like oil and grease and still a bit hungry, but thankfully Bi-Rite Creamery is just up the street!

excerpts: You aren't going to get the most authentic burmese, or the best, but the rest more than makes up for it.
up.author: Tyler M.
up.review:
Yamo gets five stars for nailing it over-all. The food is cheap, great and fast; the atmosphere is cozy, vibrant and fun. You aren't going to get the most authentic burmese, or the best, but the rest more than makes up for it. Pickup is great, only takes 10m to make - just don't be surprised when they hangup the phone without saying goodbye when you place your order :p

Favorites are the Cold Noodle with Chicken, the Tea Salad, and the Curry Chicken. House Noodles with Beef and Mango Chicken are pretty good too.

excerpts: Wasn't disappointed after a lot of build up from friends/review stalking!
up.author: Erica D.
up.review:
Delicious food, big portions, cheap prices (cash only), 9 stools in a tiny hole in the wall joint. Wasn't disappointed after a lot of build up from friends/review stalking! Got some sass, but still good service.

House noodles with beef: flavorful and oily as expected, crispy beef and garlic added good textural contrast to the noodles. Only complaint is they were stingy with the beef, I had more than half the noodles left when I finished the beef. Will be coming back for this!

Chicken noodle soup: huge portion! Broth was delicious with coconut and onions, but again they skimped on protein- I probably got just 3 small pieces of chicken in my large bowl of noodle soup. 
Noodles also were in a large clump and hard to separate.

excerpts: before I knew it she was gone, she just hung up.
She walked up to me with dirty hands, snatched the $7 from me, counted 7 dollar bills and then slapped $.50 down on the counter.
She then proceeded to go back and start preparing food.
Didn't wash her hands, reached right into a bowl of noodles!!
up.author: David H.
up.review:
I've known of this place for a long time but never wanted to wait in the long line. So today I called in a to go order and was "greeted" by a very rude lady. I gave her my order and before I knew it she was gone, she just hung up. 

Not given the chance to ask how long it would be, I arrived 15 minutes later and was ok if I had to wait. I walked in and was once again "greeted" by this rude lady (apparently the owner) She looked at me with a scrawl on her face and actually said "what do you want?" I told her I called in and then she barked $6.50. 

I had the opportunity to watch her work, bare hands as she prepared everyone's food. I'm fine with bare hands as long as the servers wash in between. She walked up to me with dirty hands, snatched the $7 from me, counted 7 dollar bills and then slapped $.50 down on the counter. She then proceeded to go back and start preparing food. Didn't wash her hands, reached right into a bowl of noodles!! Yuck! 

If they don't care about the basic in sanitation/hygiene, can you just imagine how they process, prepare, and store, their food! 

No restaurant is with the stomach pain and hours on the toilet! I'll pass. Keep my $6.50 and just know I will never eat at or recommend your restaurant!

excerpts: Expect to have them hang up on you.
You can order on the phone but don't expect to have it ready when you get there.
As far I know, they don't actually start making your food until you get there.
up.author: TayZar S.
up.review:
I would give this place ZERO Star if my rating was based on customer service. To future customers; if you are coming here with expectations of good customer service, you're in it for big surprise. I don't know if the ladies are rude or that's just how they interact with others without knowing it. Expect to be yelled at. 

I gave it three stars because the food is legit and the prices are reasonable. Like other yelpers said, it's cash only. I've been to this place a few times in the past and never had good customer service. But I keep coming back because of the food. It's the closest thing to Burmese street food in San Francisco that I can think of. 

As for the place itself and the atmosphere, I've always gotten take out from here because I'm not comfortable eating in their presence. Plus, the place is really small. So expect to wait a long time. 

Phone orders. Expect to have them hang up on you. You can order on the phone but don't expect to have it ready when you get there. As far I know, they don't actually start making your food until you get there. So if you've ordered on the phone, just cut the line and tell them about your order. 

I don't know if the owner or the manager of this place going to read this. I just want to say a few things. You guys can make SO MUCH more money if there was decent customer service. I don't mean like you have to kiss ass or smile or whatever. Just treat customers like normal human beings without the yelling. The fact that you have 4 stars DESPITE the worst customer service (not an exaggeration) says a lot about the potential of this place. Just my two cents.

excerpts: i phoned in to order for pick up, she hung up on me.
i arrived and ready for pick up and she yelled at me saying its ready
but she's not ready at all.
so i kindly said well...i'm ready when you are.
just saying those cunts rude arse eff.
if you don't have a passion for what you do, do everyone else a favor and quit!
cunt, please don't kill my vibe 'cause you have a massive stick up your arse.
thank you asshole!!!
oh...
and the food was tasteless
, even the amount of hot sauce i mixed it with, can't even save it.
what a waste of time and money spent on my first experience with them.
up.author: Rose L.
up.review:
if i can give less than 1 star, i would. i don't even care about how their food taste anymore. i phoned in to order for pick up, she hung up on me. i arrived and ready for pick up and she yelled at me saying its ready but she's not ready at all. so i kindly said well...i'm ready when you are. just saying those cunts rude arse eff. if you don't have a passion for what you do, do everyone else a favor and quit! cunt, please don't kill my vibe 'cause you have a massive stick up your arse. thank you asshole!!! oh...and the food was tasteless, even the amount of hot sauce i mixed it with, can't even save it. what a waste of time and money spent on my first experience with them. never again.

A piece of advice: If you don't see any Asians eating at an 'Asian' restaurant, save yourself - don't do it.

excerpts: So that is my disclaimer up front.
up.author: Sara H.
up.review:
I know different people have different personal formula for how they would rate a food joint. Some people believe that the quality/taste of food should mostly dictate the rating - I'm one of those people who rate based on the entire experience of waiting, ordering, dining, and paying. So that is my disclaimer up front.

My friend was visiting me from out of the country and we accidentally stumbled on this place (we actually tried to go to Ken Ken Ramen but they were closed). After waiting for ~15 min on a weekday during lunchtime, we were able to sit down. The entire place seats maybe 10-12 people at the counter, tops. There was a constant line of people either ordering takeout or waiting for a seat the entire time I was there. 

The food was really good actually, and it is very cheap - we all know that it's pretty much impossible to get lunch for $7 these days. My friend ordered the mango chicken and I got the house noodles with beef. I thought the mango chicken was excellent, and the noodles were a bit oily/heavy but in a delicious way. We didn't get any appetizers or salad, but it was a good lunch portion even with just the entree. 

The reason why I would probably never come here again to dine in is because of how rude these ladies are to their customers. As I sat and waited and ate, I saw them yelling at so many customers (someone was taking a long time to decide, and she yelled "WHAT DO YOU WANT??" to him... there was another instance where she yelled "NO PICTURE!" with dagger eyes at a customer and the entire place just fell silent for a moment because we were all so shocked) and making customers feel uncomfortable by very obviously giving them long hard stares after they were done eating and shoving the bill in their face before the plate was half empty. I mean, I get it, you are a business and want to get customers in and out efficiently... but at what cost?!?! 

Maybe I will revisit Yamo if I'm in the area and I have a craving for greasy, cheap Burmese food on the go. But I don't ever plan on dining in again, and I won't feel like recommending this place to anyone (but then again, those ladies don't seem like they give a f*** about something like a negative Yelp review, ha).

excerpts:
cleanliness - you smell like oil after eating inside

.25/.5 ambiance - cramped, but can be considered quaint because it's a "hole in the wall"

Up to +/-1 bonus stuff - +1 for value!

Overall rating 3.25 stars


Not an expert, but I grew up in more a Burmese culture than most (dad is Chinese raised in Burma)
up.author: Ian C.
up.review:
My scale on 3 trips

1/2 - food - they offer traditional Burmese dishes though a small menu they stick to the basics. Not that good but value meals

0/1 - service - bare minimum service. Known to not give a #%^* with this

1/1 value - amazing place for budget food

0/.5 cleanliness - you smell like oil after eating inside

.25/.5 ambiance - cramped, but can be considered quaint because it's a "hole in the wall"

Up to +/-1 bonus stuff - +1 for value! :D
