Overall rating 3.25 stars


Not an expert, but I grew up in more a Burmese culture than most (dad is Chinese raised in Burma) so I have some credibility :)

Worst mohinga I've had, the other dishes were ok. Nothing stood out as a go to dish. 

Overall - feed your belly with Burmese food on a budget. You know what you're getting into with this place. I'd go back if there's no wait and I absolutely craved Burmese food nearby.

excerpts: Ended up in Mission for dinner.
The place seemed promising on Yelp, except when my friend and I got there, there were no seats.
The food spoke for itself; there was enough heat from the wok to give it that smoky flavor, as well as a good portion from meat/veggie/noddle to fill me up, even though it was a small portion.
up.author: Tom T.
up.review:
Ended up in Mission for dinner. The place seemed promising on Yelp, except when my friend and I got there, there were no seats. Because of that, we decided to order our food to go, and find some random place to eat instead.

I did find it funny how when I was placing my order in Cantonese, the younger waitress asked what kind of meat, and I responded "pork", and she said, "what kind of meat is that?" Uh, you just spoke Chinese to me, and you don't know the difference between pork, chicken and beef? (And this was one of the rare times I order pork, because everyone else was eating pork.)

Overall, my experience with the house noodles was pretty good, granted we did wait 45 minutes for our food. The food spoke for itself; there was enough heat from the wok to give it that smoky flavor, as well as a good portion from meat/veggie/noddle to fill me up, even though it was a small portion.

My last thought about this place? Don't mess with Mom. I saw a few people try to come in a little after 9. Yelp claims that the place is still open, except the young waitress flat out said, "we close when Mom says so." So, planning to get a cheap eat here, come earlier than what Yelp says, or find some other place.

excerpts: To sum it up, I can't wait to come back!
up.author: Nicole S.
up.review:
Cheap and yummy Burmese food!

After passing by Yamo after our Mission Chinese Food fail, my friend mentioned he wanted to try this place.  Two friends and I came here last Tuesday around 7pm and waited about 20-25 minutes to be seated.

WHAT TO KNOW:
*CASH ONLY!
*Hole in the wall place that seats only about 10 people 
*Bar seating so come with one or two people at max (if more, it'll be too difficult to seat everyone together)
*Entrees come with an option of noodles or rice
*Cheap! (6 dishes came out to $15/person including tip!)
*Expect your food to be greasy 

FOOD:
*Potstickers - Pass.  They're a bit doughy and tasted like Costco Ling Ling potstickers.
*Yamo House Noodle w/Beef - A must try and my favorite dish of the night!!  You have the option for pork, chicken or beef placed on top of somewhat oily noodles topped off with fried garlic and green onions.
*Mango Chicken - Good.  The flavorful dish consisted of chicken, snow peas, carrots, and onions and had diced mangos that added a slight sweetness to the dish.
*Mushroom Tofu - Delicious!  It's not only for vegetarians.  I love tofu and mushrooms and to have it together with saucy goodness was great.  

SERVICE:
Okay I guess. It's an Asian restaurant, stellar service isn't their focus.

PARKING:
Street parking which at most times is horrible. 

To sum it up, I can't wait to come back!

excerpts: Now, Yamo isn't Thai, I understand, but something about it reminds me so much of the friendly lady cooking up the best meal I had in my travels at her namesake restaurant, Mama's.
Maybe it's strong female presence here.
Maybe it's the authentic northern Southeast Asia smell that washes over you as you hang up your jacket and squeeze in.
up.author: Ben H.
up.review:
Finally got a seat here. 

Step inside this no BS hole-in-the-wall and I'm transported back to rural Thailand, where I biked around for two days down every street and alleyway to find what can only be described as the best curry and stir-fry in all of Thailand. Now, Yamo isn't Thai, I understand, but something about it reminds me so much of the friendly lady cooking up the best meal I had in my travels at her namesake restaurant, Mama's. Maybe it's strong female presence here. Maybe it's the authentic northern Southeast Asia smell that washes over you as you hang up your jacket and squeeze in. Maybe it's the freshly chopped ingredients and subsequent deliberate mixing of said ingredients to create a simple, yet intense infusion of flavour in every dish. 

I never thought I'd say this, but I wish they'd raise their prices already. At $6.25 a dish, I'd be here even if the food is half as good it is. But given the high quality and low price? Economists are readily ripping their hairs out over the extreme consumer surplus here.

excerpts: but they cook up a good meal.
I had mango chicken and it was just the way I liked it hot and spicy !!
Will come back to try their varieties of salad  and the other dishes!!!
After all these years I never new that this was a restaurant cause that's how small they are !!!
But looking forward to come back to bring some special people here.
up.author: Gracelove C.
up.review:
The funny thing about this place is that I passed and waited for the bus right in front of it. Till I finally notice and looked inside so I sat down to eat with my girl and her lover my food came fasst since they cook it right in front of you and I all I have to say it was 
Sooo F'n yummy !!! A small place but they cook up a good meal. I had mango chicken and it was just the way I liked it hot and spicy !! Will come back to try their varieties of salad  and the other dishes!!! After all these years I never new that this was a restaurant cause that's how small they are !!! But looking forward to come back to bring some special people here.

excerpts: The noodles, which take up the largest section of the menu, were alright.
I expected them to be a lot better.
The fried spring rolls were fine too.
up.author: Rebecca G.
up.review:
The menu has expanded. We got the curry prawn dish and you have the option of getting it with rice or noodles. There's a few more curry dishes and rice plate options including a tofu dish. 

This place gets a 5 stars for the Chicken Coconut Noodle Soup! It's probably my favorite dish in all of San Francisco. It's a must try!

Previous review:
The Chicken Coconut Noodle Soup is dream-worthy! It is seriously one of the best soups I've ever had... and I'm still thinking about it! 5 Star Soup!

The menu is very small, the place is small, and all the items are all very inexpensive! There is only about 10 spots to sit at the counter, so you may have to wait to take a seat there. There also isn't very much standing room for take out orders either. You might be waiting out in the cold for your order. The service is quick and fast though. The water glasses are super tiny though, and I felt awkward asking for a refill. 

We also ordered the Beef House Noodles and Fried Spring Rolls. The noodles, which take up the largest section of the menu, were alright. I expected them to be a lot better. The fried spring rolls were fine too. Neither of these items were spectacular, but they were cheap.

Seriously, have the soup! The soup is worth a visit and will keep you coming back! Yum Yum!

excerpts:
Prices have gone up 25 cents... 
oh no! 
Nahhhht, slightly less than $7 can get you a full  and satisfying dish, an anomaly to both restaurants and food trucks in the city.  
With prices like that you need to pump people in and out.
Don't be that person who tries to linger with their date.
Don't be that person who tries to probe them for backstories. 
Don't be that person who spaces out, takes a million seconds to decide and expects to be pampered.
up.author: Maggie S.
up.review:
Prices have gone up 25 cents... oh no! Nahhhht, slightly less than $7 can get you a full  and satisfying dish, an anomaly to both restaurants and food trucks in the city.  
With prices like that you need to pump people in and out.
Don't be that person who tries to linger with their date.
Don't be that person who tries to probe them for backstories. 
Don't be that person who spaces out, takes a million seconds to decide and expects to be pampered.
No it's not like that, they'll make your food, you'll eat it then leave and smell like oil (which is better than urine which is sometimes the predominant smell outside.)

I like the house noodles, cold noodles, soups and tea leaf salad. Eating here too frequently would prove to be too umami, but every once in a while the flavor profile of oil, fish sauce, soy sauce, lime etc., is nice.

excerpts: You should plan to take your food to go or have a nice place to picnic in mind because seating is limited to a narrow counter with 6 or 7 stools crammed up to it.
There is almost always a line, for both seating and take out.
We got there, coincidentally, as they opened.
Apparently if a good portion of the menu isn't available at the moment
it's no big deal.
Eavesdropping is inevitable and tolerated because your so close knit with the other patrons.
This turned out to be a positive thing because foodie talk emerges and word of mouth is always the best know all.
The woman behind the counter is also stereo-typically charming (NOT), and location of the "establishment" is also in, I'll say, a more colorful part of The Mission.
Now,  if you can put all that behind you....
Most SF Foodies can,  SF Foodies appreciate value, authenticity, and taste before all the fore mentioned.
Flavors are bright and spicy, as Burmese food should be.

I had the Chicken Salad (Chicken with a combination of cabbage, carrots, onions, tomatoes, and cilantro) ,  smoky quarter sized medallions of white meat that were grilled and somehow giving a real smoky flavor.
The salad had some kick to it too, with a spicy front-end heat that somewhat dissipated before the next.
up.author: John W.
up.review:
Walking in your first reaction is "oh Crap!"    This is a hole in the wall place with exposed walls, and plumbing.  You should plan to take your food to go or have a nice place to picnic in mind because seating is limited to a narrow counter with 6 or 7 stools crammed up to it. There is almost always a line, for both seating and take out.  We got there, coincidentally, as they opened.  Apparently if a good portion of the menu isn't available at the moment it's no big deal.  Eavesdropping is inevitable and tolerated because your so close knit with the other patrons.  This turned out to be a positive thing because foodie talk emerges and word of mouth is always the best know all.   The woman behind the counter is also stereo-typically charming (NOT), and location of the "establishment" is also in, I'll say, a more colorful part of The Mission.  
Now,  if you can put all that behind you....  Most SF Foodies can,  SF Foodies appreciate value, authenticity, and taste before all the fore mentioned.  Flavors are bright and spicy, as Burmese food should be.  I had the Chicken Salad (Chicken with a combination of cabbage, carrots, onions, tomatoes, and cilantro) ,  smoky quarter sized medallions of white meat that were grilled and somehow giving a real smoky flavor.  The salad had some kick to it too, with a spicy front-end heat that somewhat dissipated before the next. My partner started with the Tea Salad ( Tea leave, cabbage, fresh tomato, onion, dried shrimp & variety of fried bean, nuts and sesame seeds) He said it was different than other Tea Salads he's had before, but we (I mean He) really enjoyed it.  It also had a spicy-vinegar sinus clearing quality to it.  
It some conversation with a regular there, the talk of the place is supposedly the Chicken Noodle Soup (Coconut noodle soup with chicken, onions, and cilantro), so we promptly ordered some to go.  It's supposed to rain this afternoon so I plan on cracking that baby open then.  I can say it was packed nicely though with the broth separated from the fixings in a separate container as to keep there freshness until use.  From what I can smell it's going to be awesome.   Portions aren't huge but either is the pricing, a fixed $6.25 [cash only] for all entrees and and $4 something for appetizers (when available).  I was denied both spring rolls and egg rolls but saw them being made later.  hmmmm.  
I'll go again and if I can get a smile and a spring roll, I'll boost it a star.

excerpts: I was very excited to try this place but ended up being pretty disappointed...
Also English not being their native language doesnt justify yelling at people to hurry up when they sat down for no more than 10 minutes.
up.author: Melissa C.
up.review:
I was very excited to try this place but ended up being pretty disappointed... 

Yes, the ladies here are pretty fucking rude/obnoxious. It can be entertaining depending on your attitude... I wouldn't have minded if the food was actually good, i mean some of the most delicious food comes from terrible customer service - BUT from my experience it wasn't good so I didn't appreciate their disrespect... Also English not being their native language doesnt justify yelling at people to hurry up when they sat down for no more than 10 minutes. They're not stupid or "lost in translation", they just don't give a fuck. 

ANYWAYS

The place is pretty small and gets busy so don't count on eating in... I liked that aspect personally (the small divey feel). I liked the assembly line they had going on, was cool watching them prepare and cook everything.

Got the samusas and the flavor reminded me of dirt... not very appetizing.  Boyfriend and I both got  rice dishes (i'm sorry this was HELLA days ago so I don't remember which..) and were not impressed with either. Both were lacking in flavor and far from anything special. After observing the people around us it seemed as though EVERYONE besides us ordered noodles...opps?

I'll admit that maybe we didn't order the "right" things...probably should have went with the tea leaf salad, noodles and/or soup but our experience was so off putting that I had no desires in giving this place another chance... that and there's a Burmese place (Kyain Kyain) closer to where I live(d) that was SO much better both in food and customer service.

excerpts: ) Put yourselves in their shoes and imagine how pissy you'd get from slaving all day in a cramped, smoke-filled kitchen at $6.25 a plate, right up in your customer's faces.
up.author: Inigo M.
up.review:
As authentic as the thick cloud of greasy smoke rising from the stoves and deep fryer (the exhaust hood doesn't work). When dining in, expect to leave smelling like Asian mom's cooking (worse than a Chinese restaurant).

Otherwise the food is analogous to the kind of fare you'd get from a typical side-street mom-and-pop enterprise in the neighborhoods of Bangkok--cheap, tasty, and down-home.

Good: Chicken curry plate, mango salad
Bad to average: Egg roll

CASH ONLY. Very limited seating.

To the First World babies bitching about the staff:

1) Shut your entitled, privileged mouths.

2) Travel, especially to a Third World country.

3) Put yourselves in their shoes and imagine how pissy you'd get from slaving all day in a cramped, smoke-filled kitchen at $6.25 a plate, right up in your customer's faces. 

4) Lyft/Uber your lazy asses one street over to Valencia (or the Marina), pick any restaurant, and get served "properly" at $16+ a plate.

excerpts: (I think they actually recently bumped it up to $6.25....
but still, it's a bargain!)
What more could you ask for?!
Don't be intimidated by its exterior (or interior for that matter...)
appearance - this place serves great food at a great price!
up.author: Aaron W.
up.review:
Believe me when I say that this place is a legit hole in the wall. There's only approximately 10 seats at the counter, so you might have to wait at times. In spite of the cramped space though, Yamo seriously knows how to produce some delicious food. The women who work here know how to run this place efficiently, cost-effectively, and most importantly, deliciously. 

The food here is nice and incredibly flavorful (and oily). The tea leaf salad is a great starter. Although it's a little on the small side, it has great flavor and it's different from your typical tea leaf salad. My two favorite entrees are the Yamo House Noodles and the Mango Chicken. The noodles are very greasy and filled with tons of flavor and a light sauce. The meat is also always tender and cooked very well. The mango chicken also has tons of flavor, as there is nothing better than mixing the rice with the sauce and chicken. The chunks of fresh mango within the dish are generous and add a nice sweetness to the dish.

Yes, you may not be getting the best service nor the cleanest services, but it all adds to the unique hole-in-the-wall-type vibe. It always amazes me to see how fast they are able to cook despite the lack of space and dim lighting. Even more, all the dishes here are no more than $6! (I think they actually recently bumped it up to $6.25....but still, it's a bargain!) What more could you ask for?! Don't be intimidated by its exterior (or interior for that matter...) appearance - this place serves great food at a great price!

excerpts: To our surprise, when we got our food, each dish was going to end up being like a couple bites each for 3 of us.
up.author: Michelle S.
up.review: Great food. Very small portions. Cash only. My friends and I ordered to go to avoid the line because the restaurant, as you can see from pics, is literally a hole in the wall. We ordered the tea salad, house noodles with beef, mango chicken, and potstickers- all for only $24. To our surprise, when we got our food, each dish was going to end up being like a couple bites each for 3 of us. The tea salad and the house noodles were especially good. I would come back to order those again, in multiple portions next time.

excerpts: Pretty refreshing after such a spiced up meal.
up.author: Sofia R.
up.review:
I was grabbing lunch with some friends who decided they wanted to get Burmese food because they'd never had it before. I decided to take them here because it's one of my favorite places and the prices aren't too bad.

The line was really long, but we decided to eat in. The place is really small, dingy, kinda grungy. You can feel the heat from the kitchen because you're sitting pretty much in front of it.

We decided to get samusas, curry prawns, house beef noodles, and tea leaf salad. The house noodles were very delicious although a tad oily. The curry prawns were okay (more mushrooms than prawns). The samusas had the right amount of spice and curry powder. The tea leaf salad was crunchy, tasty, and had great flavor (just kind of a small portion for the price).

We had grass jell drinks too. It comes in a can for $1. Not bad. Pretty refreshing after such a spiced up meal.

Great place!

excerpts: But what is disgusting is the ladies picking up the phone, taking down orders, then digging their hands into all the ingredients without washing their hands.
This isn't something that happen once, it happened throughout our dinner.
So try toughen up and don't get emotional about it.
up.author: Michael S.
up.review:
How dare you call yourself a tea leaf salad. Where are the tea leaves?

Mango Chicken was very disappointing, the chunks of mango tasted disgusting, would have been better without them. What kind of mango are you? Canned? 

Of course we were attracted by the large lines and crazy reviews. Yes, we have to admit the prices are cheap and it's true we get what we pay for...sometimes. 

I know its not the cleanest place, asian places rarely are. But what is disgusting is the ladies picking up the phone, taking down orders, then digging their hands into all the ingredients without washing their hands. This isn't something that happen once, it happened throughout our dinner. They have tons of phone orders, but still, have someone who isn't touching the food do it. 

Also the ladies may see rude, but they just don't speak English very well and the way they talk is normal in their own language. So try toughen up and don't get emotional about it.

excerpts: Small leafs of romain chopped up, topped with grilled chicken, green onion, cilantro, carrots, rice crisps, all covered in a refreshing sweet light vinaigrette dressing.
my friend got the classic house noodles.
she said it was a little on the salty side.
good thing i got the grass jelly to wash everything down with.
it was a sweet fruit drink
up.author: Lia B.
up.review:
the hole in the wall magic just adds the the flavors in the food. i got the chicken salad and it's deliciousness was packed with flavor and spices. Small leafs of romain chopped up, topped with grilled chicken, green onion, cilantro, carrots, rice crisps, all covered in a refreshing sweet light vinaigrette dressing. my friend got the classic house noodles. she said it was a little on the salty side. good thing i got the grass jelly to wash everything down with. it was a sweet fruit drink but once i got to the chunks of "grass" ekk me no likey. 

im def about to go back and order the noodles. thats where its at!!!

oh yeah and its cash only. dont worry each dish is only like $6.50! :)







@devour_sf 
#devourthat

excerpts: Try it before you load up on the chili sauce/soy.
Will be back -
the lady who runs the joint is funny.
She was laughing after she turned a customer away, hahaha
up.author: Jeff M.
up.review: Solid, cheapish eats. Beef and chicken noodles were pretty damn good. Try it before you load up on the chili sauce/soy. Will be back - the lady who runs the joint is funny. She was laughing after she turned a customer away, hahaha

excerpts: But for me and my sis, who grew up in south east asia and had our burmese grandma cooked for us, we loved the food.
It's not salty but enough to make you thirsty.
up.author: Bianca N.
up.review:
I'm lovin' the foods! Had vegetable curry and fish noodle soup there. Idk why people said they tasted bad. But for me and my sis, who grew up in south east asia and had our burmese grandma cooked for us, we loved the food. It's not salty but enough to make you thirsty. well, my tummy is satisfied!

Yes, the ladies were rude. Trust me, they were actually not that rude. We talked to one of them and she smiled often when responding to us.
Tip: don't take pictures there. They gonna be mad. Cash only, better give final amount and don't expect change.

excerpts: Get very hot up in here.
My go to for cold noodles.
up.author: Sam T.
up.review: Divey, cheap, fast.  Recommend taking it to go as there's only counter seating close to the cookin range.  Get very hot up in here.  My go to for cold noodles.

excerpts: It's in the heart of the mission and serves up some darn good burmese cooking!
The place is really small, and there's only probably a dozen or so seats available.
You can order to go if u don't want to wait, but I prefer to snag a chair and witness the 3 ladies in action, cooking up a storm.
The food is really authentic and cooked fresh to order right off the grill.
The house noodles is a must, and everything on the menu is $6 or less.
up.author: Gina N.
up.review: It's literally a small hole in the wall, and if u blink u will probably miss it, although there is a huge sign on top of it's door. It's in the heart of the mission and serves up some darn good burmese cooking! The place is really small, and there's only probably a dozen or so seats available. You can order to go if u don't want to wait, but I prefer to snag a chair and witness the 3 ladies in action, cooking up a storm. The food is really authentic and cooked fresh to order right off the grill. The house noodles is a must, and everything on the menu is $6 or less. Oh, and they also serve fresh coconut juice. They also provide a lot of vegeterian options which seems quite popular with a lot of the customers. Can't beat that!

excerpts: Followed up with piping hot mango chicken with juicy chunks of both fruit and poultry, the dish was tempered by a side of fluffy white rice.
The house noodles with pork were also spot on with chewy intensely garlicky noodles and bright fresh herbs.
Together, it was a flavor explosion of awesome.
I'm usually one to add tons of sriracha and chili
garlic sauce on 99% of my meals but this one needed no extra spicy lovin'.
I gulped down plenty of H2O
up.author: Faith Y.
up.review:
I don't know what I can add that hasn't already been said but hot diggity, I'm all about $6 menu items. I may not be a math whiz but I can easily multiple by sixes, yessirree. I've always seen a long line snaking out the door and at 7 pm on a Tuesday, it was a small blessing that only the bar seating was full sans line. 

Burmese food in the city tends to cost an arm and a leg and after a particularly hangry (albeit first world) experience waiting three hours for Burma Superstar, this was the complete opposite end of the spectrum. It seems to be operated by a family of brisk, no-nonsense women. The menu hits all of the right notes from salads to curries to soup and noodles along with a selection of appetizers. Portions are modest but filling. 

The Tea Leaf Salad was crunchy, savory and spicy - all of my favorite things. Followed up with piping hot mango chicken with juicy chunks of both fruit and poultry, the dish was tempered by a side of fluffy white rice. The house noodles with pork were also spot on with chewy intensely garlicky noodles and bright fresh herbs. Together, it was a flavor explosion of awesome. I'm usually one to add tons of sriracha and chili garlic sauce on 99% of my meals but this one needed no extra spicy lovin'. I gulped down plenty of H2O but I was a very happy camper.

Cash and minimal 8-person bar counter seating only. Don't expect super friendly service besides taking your order but that's not what you're here for now is it?

excerpts: You sit up at the counter to order and they cook the food in front of you.
up.author: Lauren G.
up.review:
Yamo was an easy and quick dinner to grab on a Friday evening! I came here around 6pm and there were only a couple orders ahead of me. I ordered food to go, and it looks like you can also call ahead. I was warned that this restaurant was "divey" and greasy, but I thought it looked clean. You sit up at the counter to order and they cook the food in front of you. It smells like food/oil, but I would feel fine eating at the bar for dinner.

We ordered the tea leaf salad, house noodles with beef, and cold noodles with chicken. I loved the tea leaf salad - it was small, but perfect for two. The noodles were chewy and really delicious, and I really enjoyed the house noodle dish. The beef was tender as well, although there wasn't a lot of beef with the noodles. The cold noodles are spicy! Plenty of red pepper on top, chicken, noodles and some veggies. I expected the food to be greasy, and it was not at all.

For two people, we had some noodles left over and spent less than $20! Except some delicious and budget-friendly food, this is not Burma Superstar. I recommend coming to eat here if you are a party of 1-2, there really isn't much room for more. It's fun to watch the women cook and make the food while you wait. Take-out took about 10 minutes, and was an easy option.

Cash only!!!

excerpts: so I suggest you order to go and head up to Dolores Park to enjoy your meal unless you really really want the counter experience.
up.author: Eddie W.
up.review:
Definitely a Hole In the Wall! 

Seating is quite limited so I suggest you order to go and head up to Dolores Park to enjoy your meal unless you really really want the counter experience.

I don't think food is bad but I certainly don't think its that amazing either. The problem I have with Yamo is that there food is too greasy. I find that after I am done eating, my mouth is coated with an oily film. That aside, the flavors are one note at best and leaves me wanting a little more. 

I have tried their fried rice, chow mein, egg rolls, curry shrimp and etc so I have a good sense of what Yamo can deliver. I really wanted to like this place but I have to disagree with all the 4 star raves.

I will admit that the price and portions are enticing but its not enough for me to give Yamo any higher than a two star. 

Overall Thoughts

I love Hole in the Wall places but sadly I do not love Yamo.

excerpts: The noodles tasted so good but every time I slurped some, I would end up feeling like I put on oily lipstick.
That aside, the beef was perfect and as a whole the dish was bursting with flavor but not too salty... yum.

The portions are a bit on the smaller side and you shouldn't end up with leftovers so if you come here with a buddy or a date, my suggestion is get 3 entrees and eat it family style or try a bit of each other's.. or get 2 entrees and an appetizer.
up.author: Lauren K.
up.review:
How can you beat $6 entrees that's delicious, fast, and CHEAP. My favorite!

It really is a "hole in the wall" and you walk in to bar seating. Grab a seat and put your order in. There's 3 ladies working one manning the stove that has about 3 pots on top. I can't help but laugh and think of "Cooking Mama" (for those of you who play Nintendo DS games).

I ordered the house noodles with beef which was super good. The noodles tasted so good but every time I slurped some, I would end up feeling like I put on oily lipstick. That aside, the beef was perfect and as a whole the dish was bursting with flavor but not too salty... yum. The portions are a bit on the smaller side and you shouldn't end up with leftovers so if you come here with a buddy or a date, my suggestion is get 3 entrees and eat it family style or try a bit of each other's.. or get 2 entrees and an appetizer. The spring rolls looked pretty good.

No complaints about service. There are only about 11 bar stools and with 2 waitresses/chefs/servers right in front of you, they won't forget if you ask for a refill on tea or an extra order.

excerpts: Showed up at 11 am or opening time, and the gate was closed and the door was shut but someone was inside, and they noticed me.
After waiting for at least 10 minutes, I left and went elsewhere.
Later on, I came back and sat down to eat at one of the 7 or so barseats.
The fish curry was so-so and pretty bland overall, but my neighbor ordered garlic noodles and he offered me a bite, and they were delicious.
The main problem is the service is terrible.
The ladies working there think they are doing you a favor for serving you.
The food was good, but not out of the world, as it should be for putting up with the seating/service/etc.
up.author: Kelly M.
up.review: Showed up at 11 am or opening time, and the gate was closed and the door was shut but someone was inside, and they noticed me. After waiting for at least 10 minutes, I left and went elsewhere. Later on, I came back and sat down to eat at one of the 7 or so barseats. The fish curry was so-so and pretty bland overall, but my neighbor ordered garlic noodles and he offered me a bite, and they were delicious. The main problem is the service is terrible. The ladies working there think they are doing you a favor for serving you. The food was good, but not out of the world, as it should be for putting up with the seating/service/etc.

excerpts: We noticed a smattering of veggies and various other things falling on the ground, and being then picked up to only be put back in place without washing or replacing.
Our salad was made with a bunch of yummy things, but it was tossed with part hand, part glove and we noticed money was handled with the same!
OK
up.author: Jennifer Y.
up.review:
Really A-OK taste (ate, got full, felt like finishing each dish), price ($6/dish, incl. tax), and efficiency (you get in, order, eat, pay, and you're out asap). 

I like the homey-ness of the service and I dig the hole-in-the-wall atmosphere but unlike a Chinatown restaurant, you can see all the action.

By seeing all the action, I mean the good, bad, and the unsanitary.  We sat at the back of the restaurant by the fridge and the third/last prep station.  This was where all the cold drink, big veggie-cutting, curry or rice scooping, and utensil/iced water pouring was happening.  The Aunty that was at this station was really very nice, telling us to shout our order to the other lady-- "she's not deaf!"--and giving us priority service.  We noticed a smattering of veggies and various other things falling on the ground, and being then picked up to only be put back in place without washing or replacing.  Our salad was made with a bunch of yummy things, but it was tossed with part hand, part glove and we noticed money was handled with the same! OK so I wasn't born yesterday and other places do these things too, but most times, please lie to me and don't show this side.

Anyway, tips--
1 Order at the front
2 Cash only it seems, no tax, but it's nice to tip
3 Close your eyes during food prep
4 Chicken noodle soup, tea leaf salad, house noodle-beef were solid choices
5 Water cups are small, order a canned drink& get a straw (they have soy milk, grass jelly, and guava juice!)
6 Speak Cantonese and you are taken care of
7 Be prepared to smell like oil afterward

excerpts: Yamo is an overrated hole in the wall joint in an up-and-coming neighborhood.
Portion is super tiny, quality / sanitary is questionable
but they've got some serious devotees (as you can tell by the line going around the block especially during busy lunch times).
Service is non-existent, as expected from this kind of places.
I'd only recommend Yamo as a mid afternoon snack (to go, not for dine-in) for those who'd like to get a taste of Burmese.
Don't forget to bring some cash as this place is cash only, although you can probably get some cash back from Duc Loi Supermarket across the street.
up.author: Effie G.
up.review: Yamo is an overrated hole in the wall joint in an up-and-coming neighborhood. Portion is super tiny, quality / sanitary is questionable but they've got some serious devotees (as you can tell by the line going around the block especially during busy lunch times). Service is non-existent, as expected from this kind of places. I'd only recommend Yamo as a mid afternoon snack (to go, not for dine-in) for those who'd like to get a taste of Burmese. Don't forget to bring some cash as this place is cash only, although you can probably get some cash back from Duc Loi Supermarket across the street.

excerpts: But you don't get that without giving up something in return.
That something is your time (wait for a seat, wait for your noodles), and good customer service.
The noodle matron is a grumpy old broad who just wants to hear your order, serve it to you, and get you gone.
Decide what you want on the menu at the door, or quickly at the counter.
Don't ask her how long it will take.
Don't make unusual requests.
Think of this like place the soup place in that famous Seinfeld episode, only noodle style.
I'd have given it five stars, but the potstickers sucked and I love me some potstickers.
up.author: Arthur G.
up.review: Okay look - it's $6.25 for a bowl of delicious noodles. But you don't get that without giving up something in return. That something is your time (wait for a seat, wait for your noodles), and good customer service. The noodle matron is a grumpy old broad who just wants to hear your order, serve it to you, and get you gone. Decide what you want on the menu at the door, or quickly at the counter. Don't ask her how long it will take. Don't make unusual requests. Think of this like place the soup place in that famous Seinfeld episode, only noodle style. I'd have given it five stars, but the potstickers sucked and I love me some potstickers.

excerpts: I almost threw up even.
up.author: Wen C.
up.review:
I was so excited to have my first Burmese food experience at this renowned hole in the wall or at least they say. I was so disappointed.

I had the Yamo House noodles with beef. it was completely lackluster. No sauce on the noodles except for some fried garlic and scallions. The beef wasn't even marinated in anything and tasted like it was going bad. I almost threw up even.

The catfish chowder was completely unsatisfying. I couldn't even taste the catfish. There were not even chunks or bits of fish. The flavors didn't grab me.

I definitely got what I paid for, all $12 of it. I should of just saved it for So wings and black bean noodles. They need to open before 4.

excerpts: Every dish is bursting with flavor and very reasonably priced, while filling up with just the right portion sizes.
I had the cold noodles, which were served with vegetables, chicken, and a lot of spicy sauce.
Every bite had chewy noodle, crunchy vegetables, and the extremely spicy but delicious sauce that was reminiscent of both Thai and Chinese cuisine.
We also tried the spring rolls, which were rolled right in front of us with fresh shrimp and mint.
You can't go wrong with anything here, as everything is prepared in a no-nonsense manner, letting the ingredients and the authentic flavors speak for themselves!
up.author: Ashley T.
up.review: Yamo literally embodies "hole-in-the-wall," with a row of counter seats facing the open kitchen and breathing in the hot air and grease from home-cooked Burmese cuisine. Every dish is bursting with flavor and very reasonably priced, while filling up with just the right portion sizes. I had the cold noodles, which were served with vegetables, chicken, and a lot of spicy sauce. Every bite had chewy noodle, crunchy vegetables, and the extremely spicy but delicious sauce that was reminiscent of both Thai and Chinese cuisine. We also tried the spring rolls, which were rolled right in front of us with fresh shrimp and mint. You can't go wrong with anything here, as everything is prepared in a no-nonsense manner, letting the ingredients and the authentic flavors speak for themselves!

excerpts: and yet Yamo's dishes match up in taste and quality thus far.
up.author: Krystal Nina L.
up.review:
Great Burmese food at a fair price!

It's not usual to find a budget eat with such fresh food.  I ordered the mango chicken with rice.  They have an option to pair your food with noodles in case you're not feeling rice.  I must say that the noodles are so tasty!  I'm going to make sure to order that for my next visit.

Fair warning, this place truly is a hole in a wall.  My friend describes it as "an extension of their personal kitchen".  There are no tables and seating is at one counter bar where people sit side by side to eat.  It's definitely well worth the wait, which there usually is a short wait.  You can also order your food to-go in case you can't find street parking (all metered but their meters take credit cards as well).

One thing I really want to try for the next time I visit is the tea leaf salad.  I've tried it at an overpriced Burmese place in the East Bay (the kinds of places where you pay for the ambiance) and yet Yamo's dishes match up in taste and quality thus far.

excerpts: Drinking coffee, ringing people up, taking orders, throwing menus, and tearing up lettuce in a 4 foot radius without any hand washing makes for a very high incidence of projectile vomit from immunodeficient customers.
I don't know, maybe I can't blame them..
the line is constantly out the door...
what am I saying?
up.author: Rosavida C.
up.review:
My OCD tendencies, Food Safety Manager/nutritionist instincts are rendered useless here. I believe that either the sheer thickness of the caked on layers of grease and grime that adorn the walls are so overwhelming that it literally paralyzes me. It's either that or the food.

Can I just say one thing? This place is one of the dirtiest places I've ever eaten at in my entire life... and I'm from the NYC area. Like, damn.

You can see for yourself - the women that run this place mean well; they treat the restaurant kitchen like home. A very dirty, grimey home. Drinking coffee, ringing people up, taking orders, throwing menus, and tearing up lettuce in a 4 foot radius without any hand washing makes for a very high incidence of projectile vomit from immunodeficient customers. I don't know, maybe I can't blame them.. the line is constantly out the door... what am I saying? There's no excuse for poor hygiene.

Unless of course that excuse is Burmese noodles, specifically from Yamo.

God. I'm going to regret this.

The noodle dish that I ordered, smelled, consumed, made sweet foodie love to... has long since been unmatched. I dined here months ago. While my germ-ophobia prevents me from returning, my imagination runs wild at the recollection of fond memories of savory umami flavors, tingling spice, and complete palate satisfaction.

Case and point. Dine if you dare. I, personally, have dared and been delighted.

Bring some hand sanitizer, bottled water, and an appetite. Good night, and good luck.

PS - there are like 8 stools in there so the line gets pretty long.

excerpts: You are on a carb starving mode and all you can dream (crave) of was greased up Chinese food.
up.author: T L.
up.review:
(See pics) Review #1131. More of 4.3 stars. What happened when you have a heavy breakfast and skipped lunch? You are on a carb starving mode and all you can dream (crave) of was greased up Chinese food.

Totally hole in a wall and tiny, delicious tea salad was an appetizer and a palate cleanser. The popular noodles were wrapped with just enough amount of oil and the chicken was good crispy delicious. And I did finish the whole bowl  (not huge) very quickly.

Definitely love the fresh coconut but felt sorry when they had to saw it through with a knife manually.

And it's quite inexpensive.

Also love this kind of atmosphere, hot, cozy, a sense of style and super friendly service by the super sweet Asian women and other patrons.

Ah yes, there's a line but it moves rather quickly (15-20 mins) for dinner.

excerpts: prices have gone up by $0.25 on every menu item.
sooo the salad looks quite sizeable on yelp photos, but in real life it's tiny.
i thought i could eat it like an entree -
no go - but
it was pretty good even in a takeout box with all dressing mixed in.
service is basically non existent and the lady taking your order is quite rude...
but.
i will be back a few more times to try the rice and noodle dishes.
not ready to give up on this spot just yet!
up.author: Christina L.
up.review: this place has been on my list for ages and ages, and since my client is now in the mission, i tried the tea leaf salad for lunch. prices have gone up by $0.25 on every menu item. sooo the salad looks quite sizeable on yelp photos, but in real life it's tiny. i thought i could eat it like an entree - no go - but it was pretty good even in a takeout box with all dressing mixed in. service is basically non existent and the lady taking your order is quite rude... but. i will be back a few more times to try the rice and noodle dishes. not ready to give up on this spot just yet!

excerpts: Place is ideal for to-go/pick-up.
I want to try everything on the menu.
up.author: Jennifer C.
up.review:
CHEAP and DELICIOUS. Nothing here is over $6 and there is such a great variety to choose from. 

I really enjoyed their tea salad. Just the right amount of spice and very appetizing. Their house noods are AMAZING. We got 2 orders. One beef and one pork. We also got their curry chicken and mango chicken. Both were delicious with the rice they came with.

Potstickers were big and juicy. My first time trying samusas. Will definitely not be my last. So good.

Place is ideal for to-go/pick-up. I want to try everything on the menu.

excerpts: I've only eaten IN the resto a couple of times, preferring to call in and pick up my order.
It's definitely a tight squeeze and the wait can be long at times.
up.author: Moo C.
up.review:
If you like eating in a closet, come here!  I've only eaten IN the resto a couple of times, preferring to call in and pick up my order.  It's definitely a tight squeeze and the wait can be long at times. If you're there for the first time with your sweetie to keep you warm as you stand in line...go for it (but I digress)...the food is really good.

It's amusing to watch the ladies behind the counter do their thang.  Shouts all around, but it's a graceful symphony that results in an absolutely happy tummy.

Prices are very reasonable, and the food is served to you very quickly.  All of the dishes I've tried here have been good, but some faves:
Chicken noodle soup
Tea leaf salad
Yamo House Noodles
Yamo Cold Noodles

If you're having a meal there, ask for fresh coconut.  As you sip on the juice of a baby coconut cracked open just for you, enjoy the tastes, smells and sounds this Burmese eatery.

Oh, don't plan on going anywhere after because those scents stick ;)

excerpts: I see a lot of people ordering for pick up.
There are also hooks for coats and bags on the walls behind the seats, so you can make yourself comfortable.
Would definitely recommend.
up.author: Lisa V.
up.review:
I had the tea leaf salad and house noodles with beef.   They both were bursting with flavor. The tea leaf salad was so good, I almost wanted to order a second. Their menu was simple, which I liked.

This place is affordable, each dish I ordered was $6.25. Most other dishes where about the same price. It really is a hole in the wall--there are literally only 8 or 9 seats so there's usually a line. I see a lot of people ordering for pick up. There are also hooks for coats and bags on the walls behind the seats, so you can make yourself comfortable. Would definitely recommend.

excerpts: Some lady picked up on the 7th ring and barked, "wah u want?

" 
Mango chicken and House noodles?
"15 minutes
up.author: daphne w.
up.review:
Okay, I'm all for a hole in the wall, "authentic", greasy spoon joints. I don't  mind the sass or broken English - as long as food is worth it! 

Since the place is small we called to place our orders around 3pm. Some lady picked up on the 7th ring and barked, "wah u want?" 
Mango chicken and House noodles? 
"15 minutes" Click!

When we got there, 3 older ladies milled about.  5 minutes of standing attention, one of them finally asked "wah you order?"  She got the bag, "13 dolas"!  So the price is friendly enough.

It'd all be rather charming if food is as tasty as some of these reviews claim.  Oily and salty seem to be the flavor, and if that's the aim, they've succeeded for sure.  Once is enough for us.

excerpts:
If you Google hole-in-the-wall, I wouldn't be surprised if this establishment pops up. 

All those years of greasy build up from the walls to the ceiling and electrical cords all adds to the experience.
up.author: John G.
up.review:
The epitome of a hole-in-the-wall. 

If you Google hole-in-the-wall, I wouldn't be surprised if this establishment pops up. 

This tiny place is grungy, sticky and greasy; yet it all makes sense and adds to its charm. All those years of greasy build up from the walls to the ceiling and electrical cords all adds to the experience. 

There's a kitchen then a counter that seats less than a dozen people at any time run by an all-female crew that takes no nonsense and lacks a little bit of customer service....in a charming way. They either have none or limited English, but you can easily communicate with them with basic English...and maybe some pointing and nodding here and there. (OK...I'm exaggerating, but you get the drift) 

There's no frills here, and you come here just for the food experience. If you have to use the restroom.....ummm.....good luck? 

But the food here is delish. Everything is lovingly and expertly prepared by an old, Asian lady that could probably beat an Iron Chef on any given day. She's fast, efficient, a bit grouchy but knows what she's doing behind the kitchen. And what she turns out is similar to a good, homemade cooking similar to what grandma used to make. They even offer vegetarian dishes and the Tea Leaf salad is on the spot. 

I love hole-in-the-wall places that serve good and inspired food. Yamo is definitely that place.

excerpts: Plus you might just strike up a convo with random strangers grabbing eggrolls and tealeaf salads next to you and find out you both speak Mandarin with a Beijing accent and appreciate Dolores Park on a sunny afternoon.
up.author: Jackie G.
up.review:
Perfect spot for lunching solo, it's like hanging at your mama's kitchen and eating while she cooks.

Plus you might just strike up a convo with random strangers grabbing eggrolls and tealeaf salads next to you and find out you both speak Mandarin with a Beijing accent and appreciate Dolores Park on a sunny afternoon.

excerpts: only 8 or so stools at the bar, all facing the kitchen where they cook and serve up your dishes.
Their house noodles were all they were built up to be.
Filling and delicious!
up.author: Lily B.
up.review:
Dug it.  

Went during the week so there wasn't a wait.  Intimate seating -- only 8 or so stools at the bar, all facing the kitchen where they cook and serve up your dishes.

Their house noodles were all they were built up to be.  Filling and delicious!  And all for $6!  

Tried a bite of my friend's Cold Noodles -- awesome chili sauce!

Loved the dry garlic bits sprinkled on top.  Definitely added to the awesomeness.
In all, I'll definitely be back.

excerpts: As for me, I usually drop in after the lunch hour and go up to the counter and order my house noodles with chicken or pork to go then pay my 6 bucks and wait outside (unless you like hot smoke blowing in your face), people watch, and get asked if I'm waiting for the bus to which I kindly reply "no" to about 5 different strangers for about 5-10 minutes, depending on how busy it gets.
Easy process
and you get one of the best noodles in the city.
I've developed a habit of getting my Yamo noodle fix every week due to its proximity to my work.
Even if I didn't work in the area I'd try to make a trip out here to satisfy my craving.
It's that good.
up.author: Leslie K.
up.review:
Let me say first that the complaints about service shouldn't even be an issue. The whole takeaway from the Yamo experience is knowing what you want to get before you go inside, getting your food order in once they address you, pay for it, and go or if you decide to sit at the counter, dig in. Y'all want some conversation and a smile? Go talk to your neighbor next to you because these ladies are too busy making quality food and don't give a shit, which I kind of admire.

As for me, I usually drop in after the lunch hour and go up to the counter and order my house noodles with chicken or pork to go then pay my 6 bucks and wait outside (unless you like hot smoke blowing in your face), people watch, and get asked if I'm waiting for the bus to which I kindly reply "no" to about 5 different strangers for about 5-10 minutes, depending on how busy it gets. Easy process and you get one of the best noodles in the city. I've developed a habit of getting my Yamo noodle fix every week due to its proximity to my work. Even if I didn't work in the area I'd try to make a trip out here to satisfy my craving. It's that good.

excerpts: Keep on rockin' in the free world, and serving up the best noodles OF MY LIFE!
up.author: Serena Q.
up.review:
Dear Ladies of Yamo,

Thank you for all you do. Thank you for being yourselves: Alpha Females feeding us healthy, hot, delicious food for a reasonable price. Thank you for reminding us that the customer is NOT always right (the sense of entitlement in this city is disgusting at times...you're reminding people that they don't always get their way and sometimes they have to wait, and you know what, sometimes they don't get noodles at all if they ladies of Yamo are too tired or simply just over it). 

I love you. Keep on rockin' in the free world, and serving up the best noodles OF MY LIFE!

xoxo
Serena

excerpts: mix it up with the noodles and ENJOY!
up.author: Kathy Y.
up.review:
WOW. I had no words but WOW when I took my first bite into the tea salad. After a few bites of WOW'ing and nodding, I asked... whaaaat is that crunchiness in every bite I take?! (mystery yet to be discovered)

We also got the house noodle with beef. We learned from our neighbors that it also comes with a small bowl of veggies. ASK FOR IT! mix it up with the noodles and ENJOY!

The mango chicken was pretty good, but probably 3rd ranked out of the items we ordered. Don't get me wrong.. it's still good. It has a nice sweetness to it with a slight spiciness.

I left full. Happy. and with $9 in my pocket for dessert. oh, and not to forget... onion breath. ALL WORTH IT.

Sit on the far right side when facing the kitchen. Not only do you get bombdiggity food... you get a butt massage from the vibrating dishwasher! WOOOOOT WOOT! hahaha. Such a great hole in the wall place. Literally. There are probably like 10 stools available.

oh yes, one last thing- PARKING SUCKS.

excerpts: I think he finally realized to shut the hell up and just enjoy his damn noodles.
Poor guy.
up.author: J C.
up.review:
Been coming here for a few years- and we usually get "decent" service, but that is because you have to operate by a code.

1: Know what you want and order simple. 
2: Don't ask questions.
3. Don't look the 3 Raw Burma Mamas in the eyes.
4. Enjoy your meal as quick and best as you can while packed like sardines in a can.
5. Don't mind the grease and smoke.
6. This is a place to eat and go. This is not a place to linger or lounge/conversate.
7. Always have cash.

The last time I was here- this poor naive chap broke all the rules.  He started with asking what was in the dish when all the ingredients are listed right there on the menu. Scowl #1 from the cook plus a big fat WHAT DO YOU MEAN.  Next, he proceeds to ask her how to pronounce a word in Vietnamese. Scowl + Death Look #2.  I cringed as I was sitting next to him.  This very naive guy continues to make a point that he googled it and proceeds to pronounce his newfound Vietnamese vocabulary word.  Burma Mama #2 looks at him and yells OK! with Scowl #3.  I about died inside for him. I think he finally realized to shut the hell up and just enjoy his damn noodles.  Poor guy.  You don't go ordering soup from the soup Nazi and try to be his friend.

These ladies may be RAW but the food is cheap and good.  It's a certain kind of hole in the wall experience. (8 seats to be exact)

Our favorites always comes down to the House noodles with beef and Tea Leaf Salad (although there isn't really any fermented tea leaves inside) it's still good.

Follow the Code and you will avoid the Death Looks with laser beams that want to incinerate you.

excerpts: Didn't like the closeness of the flames from the wok shooting up in the air from the stove.

The head lady takes the orders, gathers ingredients and places items in a silver dish which she lines up by the cook and the cook stir-frys each dish up and gives it back to the head lady to deliver to the customer.
But when I was served up my dish, I found I had a reddish, oil based curry with the prawns.
Foiled - not much sauce.
up.author: Joanna T.
up.review:
By chance, I noticed Yamo last week and now passing the place (with fast sinking blood sugar), I stopped and decided to give it a try.

First off, Yamo is a shoebox. But this place last week and tonight was full. Everyone sits at a counter on some funky, red vinyl covered stools. What caught my eye this time was a guy seated close to a door drinking from a straw that fed into a real coconut. I had to exam the menu in the window.

Appetizers: $4.95 - only 3 choices: samusas, egg rolls and potstickers. 
Salads:       $6      - tea leaf or chicken salad

Ahh, the samusa and tea leaf salad on the menu immediately screamed "Burmese" to me. 

Entrees: All $6 - choice of curry beef, chicken, curry prawns, curry tofu or curry fish. Everything goes over egg noodles or rice. Don't like curry? they make a house fried rice or a house pan fried noodle. You kind of get the drift that their repetoire is strictly enforced.

When I popped my head in, the main lady and the cook looked over the full row and then peeked over the counter and nodded me to the 1st stool right inside the door opposite the stoves. Umm, is this the best seat in the house? Or is this the worst seat?

I've got to say I like the fresh air coming into the door. Didn't like the closeness of the flames from the wok shooting up in the air from the stove.

Without being in a party, I chose only one dish: curry prawns with rice. I was fascinated watching the ladies' system. The head lady takes the orders, gathers ingredients and places items in a silver dish which she lines up by the cook and the cook stir-frys each dish up and gives it back to the head lady to deliver to the customer.

Back to the food: now dairy-based curry generally has a good sauce that goes good with rice. But when I was served up my dish, I found I had a reddish, oil based curry with the prawns. Foiled - not much sauce. The food was okay and definitely hot from the oven.

Other male diners (with bigger appetites!) went all out ordering potstickers, curry fish noodles and fried rice and curry tofu just for two people. Some couples took out an order of the tea leaf salad on their way out. Seems like a very popular dish.

It was really interesting to watch the interplay between the ladies busting themselves to get the food out. I watched the youngest of the ladies hack (with a cleaver) at the top of a fresh coconut to pierce the shell so a straw could be inserted. Amazing.

What else can I say? If in the area and hungry but on a budget, come for the food and stay for the show.

excerpts: but if it's all like this, I will need to set up a vacation to Burma.
Of course, business is bustling so can't really expect them to slow down and chat it up with the customers.
up.author: Jonathan L.
up.review:
AMBIANCE: Classic hole-in-the-wall! It fits about 10 people so either expect to wait or order to go (definitely the better option when it's crowded). The place reminds me of a grimy and tiny diner. Everyone is seated on stools, facing the kitchen where the magic happens.

FOOD: Wow! I haven't been exposed to too much Burmese food but if it's all like this, I will need to set up a vacation to Burma. We had three dishes, each unique and wonderful in its own way. 

Of course, we had the tea leaf salad. This is much better than Burma Superstar. The leaves are crunchy and are a good balance with the rest of the dish. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=UH3Aa9I4CdvqwvYpxekSRg)

Second item was the House Noodle with Beef. Nice, tender meat over chewy noodles. Lots of good flavors. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=4gV5_ohdBe_bMKtFMn2AiA)

I'm having a brain fart and can't remember the name of the last dish. Just click on the picture and guess what it is. I'm going to take a stab at it and assume it's the Mango chicken over rice. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=GKQ1fPAOdH1Fv-Y2WO5pCQ) 

PRICE: Very very reasonable! Less than $10 per dish. 

SERVICE: Run by a couple Asian ladies. They work fast and are very business-like. Just order your food and move on. Of course, business is bustling so can't really expect them to slow down and chat it up with the customers. On the bright side, the food comes promptly and without complaint from us.

THE BOTTOM LINE: 5 stars. Duh. It must be good. Check this place out if you're in the area. Or don't so that others can take your spot. =)

excerpts: This is a hole-in-the-wall place that serves up decent home-cooked food.
I had the Mango Chicken with Rice.
The mangos were sweet, and the sauce was pleasant.
It's the kind of street food you'd get anywhere in Asia.
The three SASSY BURMA MAMAS who take your order and whip up the dishes in front of you.
They do so while chattering in a high-pitched Chinese dialect and laughing at each others' inside jokes.
It was a true joy watching them at work.
I've heard complaints about their attitudes, but really, they're not trying to be rude-
they just make no effort to be polite.
Because they're fearsome beasts of efficiency who just want to get you your food as quick as possible.
mostly because it made me happy seeing those three ladies holding no airs, doing their thangg serving up good food at a cheap price, and not letting entitled customers ruffle their feathers.
up.author: Joel K.
up.review:
You know a place sells authentic South-East Asian food when they use those bowls with a rooster painted on the side.

This is a hole-in-the-wall place that serves up decent home-cooked food. I had the Mango Chicken with Rice. The mangos were sweet, and the sauce was pleasant. It's the kind of street food you'd get anywhere in Asia. Yes it's legit, but it's really nothing to shout about. 

What makes this place worth coming back to is:
1. THE PRICE. $6 (after tax) for a meal in the city is a pretty sweet deal.
2. The three SASSY BURMA MAMAS who take your order and whip up the dishes in front of you. They do so while chattering in a high-pitched Chinese dialect and laughing at each others' inside jokes. It was a true joy watching them at work. I've heard complaints about their attitudes, but really, they're not trying to be rude- they just make no effort to be polite. Because they're fearsome beasts of efficiency who just want to get you your food as quick as possible. If you don't co-operate, prepare to get yelled at.

I left the restaurant with a smile, partly because of the savings, but mostly because it made me happy seeing those three ladies holding no airs, doing their thangg serving up good food at a cheap price, and not letting entitled customers ruffle their feathers.

excerpts: 6) smell really disgusting after, so bad you would stink up the entire cartrain on bart.
up.author: Susan L.
up.review:
Yamo is a hole in the wall run by dragon ladies.  What to expect: great food and kind of intimidating service! 
  
1) wait in a long line.  (although if you come 45 mins before prime dining times, the wait will be really short! 11am, 6pm)
2) sit on a rocky stool at a greasy countertop
3) get yelled at if you don't order within 3 minutes
4) eat elbow to elbow with your neighbors and hear everyone's conversations
5) possibly get yelled at again: "are you done??!", at which point you will pay a ridiculously awesome price for all the food you got with cash only.
6) smell really disgusting after, so bad you would stink up the entire cartrain on bart.

What to eat, to share with one other:
1) Samusas
2) Tea salad (so delicious, best thing on the menu! better than burma superstar's)  You may need two orders. nommms
3) Yamo House Noodles (I like it with pork)
4) Fish chowder noodle soup (my burmese friends say its really good here!)

excerpts: I ended up ordering the Mango Chicken, House Noodles and spring rolls.
The total came out to under $18 for those three items which is pretty cheap for being in SF.
I liked it a lot
, I would definitely go back there again!
up.author: Gabriela S.
up.review: I went here over the weekend to grab some take out food. I thought the flavors and ingredients used were pretty good, I liked that the chicken dish I ordered had mango in it and a little kick of spiciness.  I ended up ordering the Mango Chicken, House Noodles and spring rolls. The total came out to under $18 for those three items which is pretty cheap for being in SF. I liked it a lot, I would definitely go back there again!

excerpts: You can't mess this up right ?
up.author: Jorlyn W.
up.review:
This place is dirt cheap, and I was excited but then you get what you pay for.  

I'm Burmese myself and at any Burmese restaurant the tea leaf salad and cold noodle is essential to any Burmese establishment.  So why not order it ? You can't mess this up right ? 

well apparently you can!!! 

The house noodles were bland, the cold noodle was the same as the house noodle but with chili sauce onions garlic and cilantro, the tea leaf salad barely had any tea leaves in it, and just didn't taste right at all!

Best Burmese food hands down is Burma superstar or Burma cafe, and after Burma superstar had that case of ecoli, Burma cafe is definitely the place to go!

excerpts: but if you are finishing up at Anchor Steam and headed towards checking out the murals nearby or Yamo is a great stop to make in between those two destinations.
We left and two others happened to show up right then and there.
If your experience isn't as lucky, it'd be worth waiting outside the front door (which is welcomingly left open) for someone to leave.
up.author: Megan F.
up.review:
Stumbled upon this little hole in the wall after taking the 10 am Anchor Steam Brewery tour and after the 2-3 free beers we drank food was our number one priority. I don't know how many of you readers will be in the same tourist-y boat as I was that day but if you are finishing up at Anchor Steam and headed towards checking out the murals nearby or Yamo is a great stop to make in between those two destinations.

And that's about all I have to add that's new info. I was sold on this place because who doesn't want to try Burmese food and you put tea and salad together in any kind of cuisine and I'm there. So, to reiterate what others have said, the tea leaf salad did not disappoint! As I'm writing this review I'm reminded I gotta start experimenting with adding tea leaves to salad...

Only reason that fifth star is missing is cause it seemed like we kinda got stiffed part of our salads (photos looked was plumper) and the mango chicken dish was pretty unmemorable. 

Also, I don't know how it happened but despite there only being 8 seats at the counter (and pretty much all were full the entire time) magically no one had to wait. We approached right as two people were leaving. We left and two others happened to show up right then and there. If your experience isn't as lucky, it'd be worth waiting outside the front door (which is welcomingly left open) for someone to leave.

excerpts: Just about 10 seats around the "bar", looking straight at the kitchen, where three loud ladies put up a very good cooking+yelling show.
up.author: Flora T.
up.review:
I'm usually not a "hole in the wall" fan, but this place is not JUST a little, minimal eatery - it has an amazing atmosphere of travels, adventures and Asian chaos, which reminded me of Thailand. Just about 10 seats around the "bar", looking straight at the kitchen, where three loud ladies put up a very good cooking+yelling show. So it's 5 stars for the FUN factor.

The food is good, but I think it tasted even better because of the great price - garlic noodles with crispy, perfect beef for 6$? Sure! The house rice, with tiny shrimp, also delicious, and so is the tea leaf salad a friend passed over to me because it was too spicy. His loss! The only thing I would pass on are the potstickers - I've had better, but don't let this minor detail bother you. Go, stand in line, enjoy!

excerpts: The prices also went up but not for much
so it's still a cheap meal.
I went with my girlfriend and we spent $17 on three dishes
so it's not bad at all.
Keep in mind that it does get very busy and it might take you some time to get a seat
so I recommend to go early in the day.
up.author: Antonio C.
up.review: If you're a local you know that this place is the place to go if you're craving good food. The place is small with around 7 seats, it also however provides take out so if you're not in the mood to wait just order to go. The little old lady's that work there are not the most friendliest ppl in the world but they get work done so I don't mind. The prices also went up but not for much so it's still a cheap meal. I went with my girlfriend and we spent $17 on three dishes so it's not bad at all. Keep in mind that it does get very busy and it might take you some time to get a seat so I recommend to go early in the day.

excerpts: Expect a line even when you call for pick up because the space doesn't occupy a lot of people and it's always super pack.
It's worth the wait though!
up.author: mimay M.
up.review: For the price point the garlic noodles with beef is an AMAZING deal. It's my fiancé go to when we need a quick fix. Expect a line even when you call for pick up because the space doesn't occupy a lot of people and it's always super pack. It's worth the wait though!

excerpts: If you are looking for very good Burmese-Chinese food with real SE Asian experience (ie old mamas yelling the orders, whipping up one meal after another, tiny crowded place), then Yoma is the go-to place.
up.author: ASIANDIVAH A.
up.review:
4 Stars for very yummy, true blue Asian homecooking for dirt cheap price. This is what we had for $28: 
1. Tea leaf salad!! I have been to a few Burmese restaurants here in the Bay Area & I can safely say this one beats them all! I thought Burmese Kitchen in Larkin St got the crown but Yamo beats it hands-down! 

2. Fish Chowder Noodle: every sip brings me back to SE Asia!! Home sweet home!! I almost forgot to share it to my date :) A perfect blend of saltiness & spiciness. 

3. Spring Rolls : very fresh & I love watching one of the ladies make it from scratch in front of us:) 

4. Yamo house noodles: yummy!!!!!!!! It's like yakisoba but Burmese style! The chicken is so good! 

5.Mango Chicken: we both agreed that while the house noodles is yummy, this one is Yummier!! 

I find it ridiculous that ppl write poor reviews based on "ambiance"... Oh come on bitches! You expect five-star service for $6???? Now that is down-right stupid & self entitlement! 

If you are looking for very good Burmese-Chinese food with real SE Asian experience (ie old mamas yelling the orders, whipping up one meal after another, tiny crowded place), then Yoma is the go-to place.  

This is officially my new fave place here in Mission!

excerpts: Don't shower before you come here because you'll just end up smelling like food and grease afterwards and have to shower again!
up.author: Theresa D.
up.review:
Once you see this place, you'll see that it's a true hole in the wall. There's exactly 8 bar stools for seating. I would not suggest coming with more than 2ppl in your party. Seating is tough as you can imagine. You're basically sitting at the chef's counter in the kitchen. The whole restaurant is one room. 

Expect that Asian service! But with that service comes authentic Asian food, cooked in a wok, in a room where the windows are caked in grease. Yum.

Don't shower before you come here because you'll just end up smelling like food and grease afterwards and have to shower again! 

The tea salad was exceptional, spicy and flavorful. It's definitely too salty to eat by itself but leaves your mouth wanting more. I would probably eat this with rice next time. The portion was teeny tiny! Maybe they were factoring in the takeout box? Think of this as an expensive Asian coleslaw.

excerpts: Prices have slightly gone up since I first came here in 2010.
My favorites are the tea leaf salad and cold noodles.
up.author: Alison L.
up.review: I love this place! I try to visit whenever I'm in the Bay Area. I love the semi-angry ladies. They make me feel like I'm at home jk :) Prices have slightly gone up since I first came here in 2010. My favorites are the tea leaf salad and cold noodles.

excerpts: God bless these Burmese ladies putting up with us and each other, just doing what they know best.
up.author: Kai H.
up.review:
God bless these Burmese ladies putting up with us and each other, just doing what they know best. 

Home style cooking (basic noodle and rice dishes) in an 'intimate' setting that feels like a neighborhood joint in Asia. And don't forget the tasty salads!

excerpts: When I read reviews from people saying the service was rude, I just sort of chalked it up tot
he fact that they've probably never worked a service/serving job.
My order was put in correctly, she was fast, and was just pleasant enough.
I'm sort of trying to reach for adjectives other than "good" but am coming up blank, so
I'm sorry.
up.author: Jordan B.
up.review:
Yamo by far was one of my favorite dining experiences that I have ever had.

I came here on a recommendation from a friend. My partner and I were lucky as we came after the lunch rush. This place is small and I loved it. It's more of a hallway and there is only bar seating where 3-4 women work harder than I've ever worked in my life. When I read reviews from people saying the service was rude, I just sort of chalked it up tot he fact that they've probably never worked a service/serving job. My order was put in correctly, she was fast, and was just pleasant enough. I think in this particular setting I would have been put off if she was sugary sweet. 

This isn't a restaurant; it's a dining experience. 

My partner and I shared a few dishes. Most of what we ate were recommendations from Yelp and we weren't set astray. It was all pretty excellent (and quite different than anything I've had before).

We tried the curry fish which was really a gut bomb (in the best way possible). It was pretty oily but in a good way an exactly what I was craving at that moment. Everything was seasoned nicely and it tasted great. The tea leaf salad was also excellent and very different than anything I've tasted before. I'm sort of trying to reach for adjectives other than "good" but am coming up blank, so I'm sorry. Just get it :)

My prescription for after you eat Yamo? a solid 45 min to an hour nap.

Oh and the prices were great. We got four large dishes and our check was something like $22. Yes.

excerpts: A friend asked that I pick up the phone order made to Yamo.

Yamo - getting the food

Seeing the line, and not wanting to cut in, I asked one of the diligent and hungry diners if they were waiting to pick up food or sit down.
Saying I was picking up a phoned in order, she thought I was placing an order and she grabbed a small tablet of paper.
I said it again and motioned like I was talking on a phone.
She got it.
The Yamo phone rings, she grabs it and starts speaking, loudly, and scribbling on the small pad.

She looks back at me and says something resembling "what did you order", I knew this was the key to getting the goods, since my friend said that they didn't ask or give time for a name when the order was called in.
I read from my own scribbled list of 7 dishes.
Half way through she determined it was the recipient of the stack of 'to go' containers in front of her.
And starts adding it up.
I had a brief thought of what if it isn't what was ordered.
up.author: Matsuo U.
up.review:
A friend asked that I pick up the phone order made to Yamo. Warning me a bit of what to expect, my interest was piqued, in an uncomfortable way. 

I learned that no one can help you understand what an 'alternate reality' is like, it must be experienced to understand.

Yamo - The Place

For many it would not be a comfortable place to be. A place that does not consider the delicate "feelings" and "sensibility" a middle class upbringing cultivated. A place that is so uninviting to dine in, I was amazed that all the 10 seats were filled and there were maybe 8 people in outside on the sidewalk.  A place that doesn't care if you are dining there, and doesn't care if you ever return. A place that didn't give 1 second of thought to the comfort of anyone eating there. 

Yamo - getting the food

Seeing the line, and not wanting to cut in, I asked one of the diligent and hungry diners if they were waiting to pick up food or sit down. All sitters. Went to the front of the line and squeezed into Yamo. Got the attention of the woman who seemed in charge.

Saying I was picking up a phoned in order, she thought I was placing an order and she grabbed a small tablet of paper. I said it again and motioned like I was talking on a phone. She got it. The Yamo phone rings, she grabs it and starts speaking, loudly, and scribbling on the small pad.  She looks back at me and says something resembling "what did you order", I knew this was the key to getting the goods, since my friend said that they didn't ask or give time for a name when the order was called in. I read from my own scribbled list of 7 dishes. Half way through she determined it was the recipient of the stack of 'to go' containers in front of her. And starts adding it up. I had a brief thought of what if it isn't what was ordered. Quickly concluded, that what ever was in those sturdy looking containers was going with me. 

Yamo - The Food

Fish curry, House noodles w/ beef, mango fish, samosa (like) appetizer etc. was all good. 

Yamo - The Diners

Standing in front of the cash register which is just behind a women who is in front of 3 large woks sizzling on high heat, and 3 other pans also on high heat. The heat was almost unbearable. Like being in Las Vegas in mid August with a down jacket on. The alternate reality took over. The 10 or so folks at the counter were seemingly enjoying themselves. One person scooping out the innards of  a coconut that had a hole hacked in the top, clearly enjoying the fruits of their labor. Another couple trying to figure out their new smart phone, which they acknowledged was smarter than them. The noise, the heat, the cramped quarters, the shouting woman, no sensible person would be comfortable and unaffected by the environs. Yet, they went on eating and cavorting as if everything was as it should be, as they expected and as they have accepted. Thats it. The 'alternate reality' thing that I kinda think Burning Man brought to the 60,000 folks that "experienced" it this year.

excerpts: I can't believe people line up for this shit.
I can't believe people put up with bullshit service.
F this place and the hipsters that swoon over it.
I wouldn't eat here again if someone paid me to.
up.author: Rich L.
up.review:
How the F does this place have four stars??????????? 

This was barely passable as human food. I had the chicken curry over egg noodles, which was horribly greasy, salty, and didn't taste like curry. My girlfriend had the fish chowder which was just strange -- it had the consistency of snot and lacked flavor.

I can't believe people line up for this shit. I can't believe people put up with bullshit service. F this place and the hipsters that swoon over it. I wouldn't eat here again if someone paid me to.

excerpts:
My thoughts: 

Are people really lining up for this food?
up.author: Anthony R.
up.review:
Ate here tonight. My thoughts: 

Are people really lining up for this food? Really? Ah, El Mission.

Okay, I get it. $6 is cheap these days. "Broke" people who can't cook need to eat somewhere!

The food: very ordinary. Battered fish tossed with black bean sauce and awkwardly shaped veggies. "House Noodles" tossed with soy sauce, scallions and grease (plus crispy fried garlic, which was tasty). Also got the pot stickers. Not horrible, but nothing memorable by a long shot. The kind of food you could most likely throw together at 1:30 a.m. after a bong rip and a 12 pack of Miller High Life.

Perhaps sitting at a stool in a grease-stained hole-in-the-wall while the brusque waitress burns a hole through your epidermis with her glare is a touch charming but let's be honest: there's a boat load of dive-y spots around the city with far more inspired dishes for the same price. Location, location, location...

excerpts: We were quoted a 10 min wait, but it ended up being closer to 15 min.
The place was packed when we arrived due to the limited seating, and 4-5 more people arrived for take-out shortly after we did.
up.author: David L.
up.review:
Food: 4
Decor: 2
Service: 3

Came here with some friends to grab take-out for a weekday dinner.

1. Tea leaf salad, 6
~Pretty good.
