2. Mango chicken with rice, 6
~Pretty good. Somewhat generic, but decent overall. Sauce had a bit of a kick to it.

We were quoted a 10 min wait, but it ended up being closer to 15 min. The place was packed when we arrived due to the limited seating, and 4-5 more people arrived for take-out shortly after we did.

excerpts: When I went to pick up the order, she refuse to change the order to the right items, and said too bad.
No apologies.
No compromise.
When I protested, she yelled back at me.
I've had bad experiences before, but this was one of the worst.
If you want to be treated with some semblance of respect, do not go here.
You won't find any.
up.author: Tony D.
up.review:
I have never written any review, but felt compelled this one time.
Never tried their food. Never got there because THE SERVICE AND ATTITUDE SUCKS.
I called in an order. The lady got it wrong. When I went to pick up the order, she refuse to change the order to the right items, and said too bad. No apologies. No compromise. When I protested, she yelled back at me. I've had bad experiences before, but this was one of the worst.
If you want to be treated with some semblance of respect, do not go here. You won't find any.

excerpts: Seating is very limited as it's just a bar-like area where you face the three ladies who cook up your meal to-order.
You have to try the house garlic noodles.
The noodles are very flavorful and the meat is well-seasoned and tender.
I've heard very good things about the tea leaf salad, but haven't tried it.
You try it and let me know!
up.author: Kevin H.
up.review: Cheap, oily, and fast - just how I like it. This hole-in-the-wall joint is heavenly. It's quite hidden along the lines of dirty, rundown storefronts so make an effort to look for this place...you won't be disappointed. Seating is very limited as it's just a bar-like area where you face the three ladies who cook up your meal to-order. You have to try the house garlic noodles. The noodles are very flavorful and the meat is well-seasoned and tender. I've heard very good things about the tea leaf salad, but haven't tried it. You try it and let me know!

excerpts: Watch out #2: There's maybe around 10 seats in the whole place, so be ready to get it to go if you show up during high demand times.
up.author: Brian M.
up.review:
The food is great, but the service is awful, BUT awful in the most entertaining way.

Let's start with the food. House noodles with beef - delicious and cheap. Tea leaf salad - delicious and cheap. There isn't anything on the menu that costs double digits so it's a great place for a cheap date. (Note: if you're date brings you here, he/she is a cheapo but you won't notice because the food is good).

The service...hilariously bad. This place is run by a bunch of small cranky asian women who have very thick accents and often-times sassy attitudes. My favorite past time when eating here is watching newbies try to order food from them and seeing the reactions of the customers. They will ignore you initially and can be fairly rude if you catch them at a bad time. 

Just remember that they're all business - they just care about your order and that you pay. One time I remember I had to yell my order because she asked what I wanted when she was on the other side of the restaurant. Tip: if you want to pay, just put your money down on the counter and wait for your change. Sometimes they like to ignore you if they're busy, but they won't ignore money on the counter so they usually get to it right away.

Watch out: Cash Only. There's one of those sketchy ATMs on the corner if needed.

Watch out #2: There's maybe around 10 seats in the whole place, so be ready to get it to go if you show up during high demand times.

5 stars!!!!!!!

excerpts: but tonight she messed up my order.
I ordered chicken noodle soup without cilantro, she realised she forgot and started picking out stuffs from the bowl and ended up removing onion instead of cilantro.
I didn't want to bother her
so I picked out the cilantro myself and asked for some onion, that's when she got mad and started cursing in Chinese or Burmese
, I could tell because of her facial expressions and hand gestures, and if it had not been anything rude she would have just said it in English.
Anyway, I'm not saying I would never go back because the food was nice and cheap, but I would always check if she was in before walking in next time (chubby with short curly hair, very small curls).

Oh, and one more thing, the area isn't safe, tonight there was a homeless person walking in asking for food and ended up having a fight with some guy in the shop, that same counter lady had to call the police.
My boyfriend, who was with me tonight, said he had been troubled by a homeless person once in the same place another time.
So, keep that in mind and be extra careful when you're in the area.
up.author: Veronica P.
up.review: Nice tasting food but the lady at counter today was rude. The first time we were there, about a week ago, she wasn't in and other staffs were nice but tonight she messed up my order. I ordered chicken noodle soup without cilantro, she realised she forgot and started picking out stuffs from the bowl and ended up removing onion instead of cilantro. I didn't want to bother her so I picked out the cilantro myself and asked for some onion, that's when she got mad and started cursing in Chinese or Burmese, I could tell because of her facial expressions and hand gestures, and if it had not been anything rude she would have just said it in English. Anyway, I'm not saying I would never go back because the food was nice and cheap, but I would always check if she was in before walking in next time (chubby with short curly hair, very small curls). Oh, and one more thing, the area isn't safe, tonight there was a homeless person walking in asking for food and ended up having a fight with some guy in the shop, that same counter lady had to call the police. My boyfriend, who was with me tonight, said he had been troubled by a homeless person once in the same place another time. So, keep that in mind and be extra careful when you're in the area.

excerpts: Otherwise, wait for seats to open up on the far right side of the counter.
up.author: Douglas G.
up.review:
4 1/2 stars for the food, 1 1/2 stars for the aural punishment. The chef/head lady carries on non-stop conversation at steamwhistle intensity with the women at the inside end of the place. If you don't mind having a ballpeen hammer slammed against your eardrum while munching tea leaf salad, sit anywhere. Otherwise, wait for seats to open up on the far right side of the counter. Your hearing and sanity depend on it.

You're welcome.

excerpts:
Stop by Duc Loc supermarket and pick up beer.
Stroll across 18th and politely excuse yourself past the line waiting for food/seats.
Pick up and pay.
up.author: J L.
up.review:
How to be cooler than the line of hip hipsters...

1. Call your order in 15 min ahead.
2. Stop by Duc Loc supermarket and pick up beer.
3. Stroll across 18th and politely excuse yourself past the line waiting for food/seats.
4. Pick up and pay.
5. Casually saunter out of the door with your goodies.

It's pretty simple.

Cheap, no nonsense service, bare decor.
From the items I've tried...

Not to miss:
-samosas
-mango salad
-house chow fun w/beef
-house fried rice

Get next time:
-tea leaf salad
-house noodles w/chicken

Save your $6:
-black bean tofu

excerpts: This is the smallest restaurant that I have ever been in and what it lacks in size it makes up in quality.
There are zero tables and you eat at the counter approximately two feet away from the hot action.

It took a good 10-15 mins for everything to finish as everything is made to order, we kicked it outside and you see random after random people walk by as they think a building fire is taking place, i would say half of them ended up going in a grabbing something to eat.
up.author: David N.
up.review:
There is a closet fire in the mission district is what I thought when passing by this place, yet no is moving away from it. Confused much? Yes!

This is the smallest restaurant that I have ever been in and what it lacks in size it makes up in quality. There are zero tables and you eat at the counter approximately two feet away from the hot action. It was full when we got there and my friends and I scoured the mission district for something that would hit the so called spot.

I stood at the door and shouted over two eating patrons, it was somewhat rude but i could neither move any closer nor could she without running to a hot wok! so we made it wok (cheezy i know) I ordered the samosas along with the house special fried rice with skirmps  and my friends ordered the yamo noodles, one chicken and one beef.

It took a good 10-15 mins for everything to finish as everything is made to order, we kicked it outside and you see random after random people walk by as they think a building fire is taking place, i would say half of them ended up going in a grabbing something to eat. 

The samosas were light crispy and spicy but not overpowering, the fried rice gave me a watermelon smile! that damn good! every grain of rice was individually covered in spices, after every bite i wanted more.

The women in the kitchen were nice, I have no complaints nor do i expect good service in any any asian restaurant because emphasis is not on service but food so people who complain about these women should go to... rhymes with smell.  

One thing i have to mention is we found a place on the street to eat our meal and a couple literally stopped in their tracks and asked us where the food came from because of how good the smell was.

The food was so perfect and makes me a sad panda that I can't eat here whenever i so please.

excerpts: I saw my order come up and sit on the bar while the lady who takes orders and is generally the most unpleasant, took a walk-in togo order.
By the time my food was delivered the chicken was cold.
Two bites in
and I had to spit out a piece of chicken because it was so rubbery
I thought it was raw.
I brought this to her attention, only to be told that it was the knuckle part of the chicken and that I should eat it.
Not only that I got my appitizer halfway through my main course and water halfway through my meal....
It's safe to say that I am more than willing to put up with bad service for good food,
But if I am getting sub-par food and terrible service
I think it's time to find somewhere else for a cheap fix.
up.author: Lauren Y.
up.review:
So if you eat at Yamo you know that the service is lacking. You go for the delicious cheap food. I have been eating here for years now dispite the terrible service but my experience last night was probably the worst I've had there. I order what I usually get, the cold noodle salad with chicken and a tea leaf salad as an appitizer . I saw my order come up and sit on the bar while the lady who takes orders and is generally the most unpleasant, took a walk-in togo order. By the time my food was delivered the chicken was cold. Two bites in and I had to spit out a piece of chicken because it was so rubbery I thought it was raw. I brought this to her attention, only to be told that it was the knuckle part of the chicken and that I should eat it. Not only that I got my appitizer halfway through my main course and water halfway through my meal....It's safe to say that I am more than willing to put up with bad service for good food, But if I am getting sub-par food and terrible service I think it's time to find somewhere else for a cheap fix. Sorry Yamo I won't be back after being treated like SH#$%

I forgot to mention that part of their over stove hood had water pouring down it....I'm pretty sure that must be against some health standard somewhere...just saying.

excerpts: You're the kind of hole-in-a-hole place that people brag about, so keep up the good work!
I mean, you're basically waiting for the opportunity to stand up in a kitchen!
Expert move: call ahead, pick up 15-20 minutes later (bring CASH or risk embarrassment of being yelled at and an ATM fee), and take it to a quiet street or Dolores Park.
up.author: DJ D.
up.review:
Oh Yamo... You haven't ceased to amaze me. Few places ACTUALLY qualify as hole-in-a-wall, and I'll admit I throw that term around lightly on occasion, and you're one of them. You're the kind of hole-in-a-hole place that people brag about, so keep up the good work! 

Now to the people reading this. You're a fool to wait in line and eat inside of the hole called Yamo. I mean, you're basically waiting for the opportunity to stand up in a kitchen! Expert move: call ahead, pick up 15-20 minutes later (bring CASH or risk embarrassment of being yelled at and an ATM fee), and take it to a quiet street or Dolores Park. Just don't wait in line to eat in. 

Now, about the food. It's hot, wet, and greasy. Garlic plays in heavily to many of the dishes (note: I like garlic a lot). There's a good mix of crunch and soft chewy with the House Noodles (I recommend. Get it with pork if possible). The potstickers are good. The tea leaf salad is straight funky... But then again I don't particular like that dish at other Burmese places so don't take my opinion too seriously there. The curries will disappoint, I think. The mango chicken is good though. 

Be careful with the women serving. It's a hot kitchen and they have little patience for anything other than cooking and taking your money. and whatever you do (and who would ever do this?!) don't suggest that they can increase their prices by, like, 30% and still have a line out of the door every night. Because it's only of the few cheap, good spots left in this city! 

Enjoy.

excerpts: In lieu of tables there are bar stools at the counter, so you can cozy up to the random people who pile in.
The rule is, once a stool becomes available, you plop yourself down and order.
You're essentially eating in the kitchen (yes, it's that small).
On the plus side, you get to see the wonderful food cooked right up in front of you.
up.author: Lisa N.
up.review:
Don't expect service with a smile--or really much of any service beyond the lady yelling at you to order from behind the counter (it's loud and chaotic). It is what is...and when you come to Yamo's it's pretty much what you should expect. 

The lines are long, but they move rather quickly. The menus are taped to the windows, so you can decide what you want while you wait. In lieu of tables there are bar stools at the counter, so you can cozy up to the random people who pile in. The rule is, once a stool becomes available, you plop yourself down and order. You're essentially eating in the kitchen (yes, it's that small). On the plus side, you get to see the wonderful food cooked right up in front of you. On the downside, it can get smoky inside and your clothes will have that funky Asian food smell afterward. 

The food? Delicious! Everything is cooked to order--very flavorful. My friend and I split an order of samusas (appetizer) and a mango chicken entree and garlic noodles with beef. It was GOOD! I'll be back to try some of the curry dishes. The prices are super reasonable too--okay, actually more than reasonable for San Francisco. Entrees are priced at $6, and appetizers are under $5. Hit the ATM first--it's CASH ONLY (but no tax).

excerpts: My friends and I showed up and placed our orders at 7:20.
Waited outside.
30 minutes in, still no sign of our order,so my friend went to the counter to say we're still waiting.
No explanation, they keep working it.
50 MINUTES LATER, we finally received our food.
No apologies, no explanations.
People who had ordered a half hour after us had been served first.
We were so hungry, we opened up the order at a bus stop... only to find 3 of our 5 dishes had no sauce of any kind.
My curry chicken had no curry.
up.author: Argonaut A.
up.review:
Ugh. TERRIBLE.

My friends and I showed up and placed our orders at 7:20. Waited outside. 30 minutes in, still no sign of our order,so my friend went to the counter to say we're still waiting. No explanation, they keep working it. 50 MINUTES LATER, we finally received our food. No apologies, no explanations. People who had ordered a half hour after us had been served first. We were so hungry, we opened up the order at a bus stop... only to find 3 of our 5 dishes had no sauce of any kind. My curry chicken had no curry. Tasted like steamed chicken and noodles with a couple spices thrown in. 

Ridiculous wait, awful service, food that tastes like butthole. yamo more like yeah, no.

excerpts: You should sit down, but if its full when you get there, you only have to wait like 10-15 for a seat to open up.
up.author: Allison H.
up.review:
Mango salad. Get it or feel your life isn't complete. 

Go with the flow at this place. You should sit down, but if its full when you get there, you only have to wait like 10-15 for a seat to open up.

excerpts: Again, I emotionally can't deal with this kind of chaos, which is why my boyfriend picks up the takeout.
He has... actually, SIGNIFICANTLY less patience than me, and yet, he's a much better provider.
up.author: Rebecca P.
up.review:
I don't typically do fantastic hole-in-the-walls like Yamo because, even though the food is slimygreasyspicygood and dirt cheap, I can't take massive crowds plus bad service without having an anxiety attack. 

However, I can do phone orders with takeout windows! The service is still crappy because they don't take your name over the phone, meaning you have to recite your order precisely as you did on the phone if you want your food... and they will still ignore you when you get there, and your food will still take a bit of time. But, whatever. At least you get to eat house noodles, curry, coconut soup, and whatever other dishes you didn't order but they accidentally put in your bag and didn't charge you for.

Again, I emotionally can't deal with this kind of chaos, which is why my boyfriend picks up the takeout. He has... actually, SIGNIFICANTLY less patience than me, and yet, he's a much better provider.

excerpts: This place maybe fits up to 8 people and all counter seats.
Cash only, bring more than you think you need!
up.author: Yumi H.
up.review: Inexpensive, amazing, hole-in-wall Burmese place in the Mission. Mango chicken, tea leaf salad, house noodles with pork/beef/chicken, it's all yumz. This place maybe fits up to 8 people and all counter seats. Cash only, bring more than you think you need!

excerpts: There's better places to eat at, so pass this one up.
It's cheap if you're on a budget.
up.author: Jonathan M.
up.review: Food was mediocre and service was horrible. My friend and I felt like we were in a seinfeld episode of the soup nazi. Haha. There's better places to eat at, so pass this one up. It's cheap if you're on a budget.

excerpts: My only worry is that they'll get too popular for their own good and jack up the very reasonable prices for current menu items.
up.author: Lorraine Y.
up.review:
What do you do when you want affordable Asian food in the Mission District and Mission Chinese is CLOSED ON A WEDNESDAY? As I found out go for Yamo (it must mean in "yummy" in Burmese)!

Samusas + shrimp spring rolls + tea salad + beef curry over noodles = can't lose!

My only worry is that they'll get too popular for their own good and jack up the very reasonable prices for current menu items. Oh well, I'll enjoy the heck out of this literal hole in the wall as long as I can!

Useful info:

- CASH ONLY
- line out the door so call in your order
- limited seating in a tiny space means you will walk out of there smelling like the food
- this part of the Mission looks a bit shady at night so go with a friend

excerpts: The ladies are grouchy to a point where it tickles me -- apparently the hipsters all like it too as they line up for this place.
If you don't want to deal with the attitude, lines, hipstery crowd, and smoke, order  takeout.
Food is mouthwatering, but loaded with MSG.
up.author: Soysizzle t.
up.review:
The ladies are grouchy to a point where it tickles me -- apparently the hipsters all like it too as they line up for this place. If you don't want to deal with the attitude, lines, hipstery crowd, and smoke, order  takeout. Food is mouthwatering, but loaded with MSG. Prices are cheap like any good asian food should be.

House Noodles are simply amazing.
Mango Salad is refreshing and bright, as are the spring rolls.
Everything else I've had is good too, but nothing in particular is registering at the moment.

excerpts: just said "oh yes" mumble mumble mumble and went back chopping stuff up.
We were not very happy at that point.
up.author: Novalina N.
up.review:
I gotta downgrade Yamo to 3 stars. The portion is becoming smaller and I think some of the dishes are kinda bland. Me, being a chili queen, almost finish 1/3rd of the chili oil they had.

At some point I asked where the drinks are and this girl (with very bad English) just said "oh yes" mumble mumble mumble and went back chopping stuff up. We were not very happy at that point. Although, they seem to always mess the drink order, it's very strange.

Yummy, oily good stuff, but need more seasoning + better service.

excerpts: it fills you up.
if there is no line, totally go for it.
but if there is a long line out front, ill pass.
up.author: Andy Z.
up.review:
lunch

food: fish chowder noodle. this doesnt taste fishy at all. as in i wouldnt have known it was a fish chowder if you didnt tell me, which can be a good thing for some. it was thick and creamy. the noodles and the toppings add some texture to it or else it feels like eating mush. they have some crunchy stuff on top that i couldnt figure out what it was, but i liked it. either fried lentils or corn or something. ***4/5

service: its a pair of asian ladies working the joint. one primarily cooks and the other handles the customers and prep. they do a splendid job with the number of customers they have. she took my order fast, but it took awhile for orders to come out. like i said, only one person cooking the food. ***4/5

atmosphere: this is a hole in the wall. i walked past it and didnt realize it. the front isnt fancy and reminds me of street food stands in asia. the place is extremely small and narrow. fits maybe 8 people? i got lucky and got in before the crowd hits. they do to go orders too and a line of people were waiting outside. TIP: dont go in big groups. 4 is big in my opinion. ***3/5

value: 6 bucks for a bowl of noodles and it fills you up. if there is no line, totally go for it. but if there is a long line out front, ill pass. ***4/5

excerpts: I had a mediocre tea leaf salad a few years ago and gave up on you.
I hoped things had improved and tried the house noodles today.
up.author: Jim J.
up.review:
sorry Yamo.  I had a mediocre tea leaf salad a few years ago and gave up on you. I hoped things had improved and tried the house noodles today.  Terrible. 

Oily noodles with ok pork and almost non-existent flavor. It gets worse. 
The predominant flavor is either grease or fuel or greasy fuel.  Even with some fish sauce and chili sauce, the fuel flavor was heavy. If it's not fuel, than it's some god awful cooking oil. I hate to give anyone a one star review, but all of these 5 stars are from kids who wouldn't know good food if it kicked them in the face.  I can make ramen and pork in 5 minutes (for $1 dolla!) that would be exquisite compared to what I just experienced.

excerpts: There are about 12 stools at the bar, and the entire time you're eating, you're facing three Asian women cooking up a storm.
How they manage to cook that much good food, so quickly, in such a small space impresses me to no end.
They do it
up.author: Vivian C.
up.review:
4.5 stars, I'm very close to giving this a 5.  

Another great place for good eats for the young, fabulous, and broke.  It really is like walking into your Asian momma's kitchen.  There are about 12 stools at the bar, and the entire time you're eating, you're facing three Asian women cooking up a storm.  How they manage to cook that much good food, so quickly, in such a small space impresses me to no end.  They do it WELL.

Every entree on the menu is $5.25, and all appetizers are $3.50.  Affordable, and good portion sizes!  On a weekday around 6:00pm, we came and ordered the samosas, the tea leaf salad, the mango chicken, and the coconut chicken noodle soup.  All for only $19.25 total.  Great value!

Of all the dishes, I liked the tea leaf salad the best.  Great textures, especially with the crisps and crunches, a bit of a spice kick, and very fresh.  Excellently made = highly enjoyable.  The coconut noodle soup was creamy, slightly spicy too, and highly recommended.  I had a small bite of my friend's mango chicken with rice dish, and I thought that was fine, but it didn't stand out to me.  Also, they give you a good amount of samosas for the price - 6 hot, hearty pieces for $3.50!  

A coupla final notes and conclusions:
+ Not so crowded when we arrived at 6pm on a Wednesday night, but I noticed that a small line started forming around 6:30pm, so get there early if you want to avoid a line.
+ Cash only
+ If you're going to get ONE dish, gotta make that the tea leaf salad.

excerpts: This place was legit, straight up ghetto interior.
A tiny hole surrounded by good bars, hustlers, bike thieves, some OGs and hoodlums, and yet I felt at home, safe and cozy.
It's big enough for 6-7 people tops, unless you're a midget don't bring your whole squad there and make a scene.
I covered mine up with real home made chilly sauce, none of that sriracha tomato paste.
Don't get me wrong, there isn't anything wrong with sriracha, but it DOES NOT go with EVERYTHING, and it aint hot, so don't call it a hot sauce.
up.author: Alvin D.
up.review:
This place was legit, straight up ghetto interior. A tiny hole surrounded by good bars, hustlers, bike thieves, some OGs and hoodlums, and yet I felt at home, safe and cozy. It's big enough for 6-7 people tops, unless you're a midget don't bring your whole squad there and make a scene. Its fucking inconsiderate to wait on that many all at once, go there 1-3  at a time, you and the other human beings will be rewarded by the universe.

The food was good, if you don't like it for being too oily, just tell them to add less oil! If they yell at you, enjoy it! Welcome to the real world you bunch of spoiled, sugar coated brats! 

I loved it. Had the house noodle with beef, was delicious. I covered mine up with real home made chilly sauce, none of that sriracha tomato paste. Don't get me wrong, there isn't anything wrong with sriracha, but it DOES NOT go with EVERYTHING, and it aint hot, so don't call it a hot sauce. When you have the choice of a superior chill sauce in front of your ignorant face, dip that shit in, if u don't add the chill, you'are missing the point! 

Ordered the tea salad. Theres no tea in it. But was delicious though. Full of onion and vinegar, seems would go well with rice porridge too, it's got that Chinese pickle vibe to it, Chinese pickle is better than Kimchi Da Truth!

excerpts: This quality/taste of the food definitely isn't equivalent to burma superstar or mingalaba (in Burlingame) but for the price you pay.. it gives it a HUGE boost up there!
YAY!
up.author: Melody T.
up.review:
Burmese seems to be the "it" thing for now, and I'm on the bandwagon.

This quality/taste of the food definitely isn't equivalent to burma superstar or mingalaba (in Burlingame) but for the price you pay.. it gives it a HUGE boost up there! YAY! :)

For $19 we were able to do takeout and walk away with: tealeaf salad, chicken curry with rice, beef chow mein, and an order of potstickers - wowzas.. we are... IN SF RIGHT???

Love love love that you can get Burmese for the price of ...... meh, I don't know .. something that no longer exists in the city where your standard price for a soy latte is $4?

I am happy to have finally gotten around to trying this place - definitely on the list of takeout places when we're looking for cheap and ... greasy.

excerpts: Order up pan fried dumplings as an appetizer and black bean fish with rice as a main.
I bet the dumplings don't come till you finish the fish.
So fucking what?
The food is so good.
Quit your whining.
up.author: Ivan L.
up.review:
Yamo is one of my absolute favorites in the city. I don't know how I haven't reviewed it already.  This is superstar Burmese food.

Other reviewers have mentioned how small the counter is. So fucking what? The food is so good.
Other reviewers have mentioned the wait. So fucking what? The food is so good. 
Other reviewers have mentioned surly service from women old and young. So fucking what? The food is so good. 
Other reviewers have mentioned the yelling, the hot oppressive steam, and the dirty counters. So fucking what? The food is so good.

Quit your whining. Order up pan fried dumplings as an appetizer and black bean fish with rice as a main. I bet the dumplings don't come till you finish the fish. So fucking what? The food is so good. Quit your whining.

excerpts: Since you're right up next to the cooks there's lots of smoke and heat blowing in your face, but I think it kind of adds to the atmosphere of the place.
The service was quick and to the point.
Don't expect any overly chatty servers.
The food was delicious, but not unlike other Chinese/Burmese spots.
Ordered the Tea leaf salad, Chicken soup, House noodles and spring rolls.
I would suggest ordering take out because the place is so tiny.
up.author: Rose D.
up.review: It's a pretty small place. You eat at the counter and watch your meals being made. Since you're right up next to the cooks there's lots of smoke and heat blowing in your face, but I think it kind of adds to the atmosphere of the place. The service was quick and to the point. Don't expect any overly chatty servers. The food was delicious, but not unlike other Chinese/Burmese spots. Ordered the Tea leaf salad, Chicken soup, House noodles and spring rolls. I would suggest ordering take out because the place is so tiny.

excerpts: We killed it and with all that food I was expecting a nice bill, but these ladies are literally like family because they hook you up!
up.author: Edith G.
up.review:
I walked in with a friend and instantly knew that the food was going to be the bomb dot com. How, you ask? First these ladies are rocking that grey hair that lets you know cooking, and making good food is nothing new and don't you dare ask if the food is good, because it is totes amaze!

One thing you got to have before you sit down is time, or call in ahead of for a to-go. These ladies are in their cooking zone and I couldn't even be mad, you wouldn't rush your mom's delicious food would you? 

This place is literally a hole in the wall, okay a hallway with an island that separates you from their greatness (aka: cooking, skills, & speed)

I started with the Spring rolls, end result BOMB. Then I ordered the Garlic chicken, they call it something else but shit was off the hizzy my nizzy! Again, BOMB! My friend ordered the Chicken Chow mein, I died. Soooooo good! To end the meal I ordered the Pot stickers... You know when you eat too much you lose interest in food right after, well I took a bite of the pot stickers, instant smile and all of the pot stickers were gone.

We killed it and with all that food I was expecting a nice bill, but these ladies are literally like family because they hook you up! I gave her an Andrew Jackson along with some George Washington's to give her a generous tip.

3 Things that make it to the top of my list:
1. College student cheap
2. The bomb dot com, & 
3. Generous size servings.

excerpts: It's like a bar set up and only about....
10 seats inside so expect to potentially wait in line depending on the time of day.
up.author: Moises L.
up.review:
Price & Quality-  This is my favorite place to eat in San Francisco hands down. The prices here are ridiculously (and beautifully) low. For about $6 you will get a yummy and just downright delicious meal. My mouth waters just thinking of their delicious food.  That being said, I recommend you get some sides and a coke... yummy.

Service- This place is run by a couple of hardworking women who are no bullshit. It's like a mom's kitchen of sorts. The women here are always busy so they don't have the time to be smiling and caring for your every need although they will bring what is needed to you in a timely manner.

Vibe- This place is super small, and I mean super small. It's like a bar set up and only about....10 seats inside so expect to potentially wait in line depending on the time of day. It should be noted that this place is frequently , not always but frequently, busy. 

Will I come back? Yes yes & yes. Anytime i'm in the neighborhood, I gotta go get a quick bite here although I don't go as much as I'd like since their food is super oily and that's really a turn off. However their food is just THAT delicious that it's like a treat to me every time I do go. If you haven't gone, go go go!

excerpts:
- old women yelling at each other makes my blood pressure go up
- still hungry after eating 3 dishes :(

Avoid eating inside this tiny hole-in-the-wall.
If you do plan to order food from here I recommend calling them to place your order, picking it up, and then eating it at home.
They run out of a lot of things towards the evening.
Sitting at the small counter and watching these old ladies yell at each other in their native languages made my blood pressure go up!
Watch out for Albert Einstein-haired lady, she likes to yell a lot!
O_O
I guess many of the other customers found it quite entertaining and just laughed in amusement.
Untidy kitchen, small sink, etc.
I quickly lost my appetite as soon as I saw the black garbage can within 6 feet.
up.author: CeCe C.
up.review:
Yamo is sadly not yummo. It's YUCKO :(

- question the sanitation of this restaurant
- greasy residue on their plates =\ ew
- there's a black garbage can within viewing distance INSIDE O_O BIG nono
- small food portions for $5, especially the tea salad!
- old women yelling at each other makes my blood pressure go up
- still hungry after eating 3 dishes :(

Avoid eating inside this tiny hole-in-the-wall. If you do plan to order food from here I recommend calling them to place your order, picking it up, and then eating it at home. They run out of a lot of things towards the evening. So go early!!!!

I really wanted to like this place, but I just didn't like the quality of food here. My Mom can make better food than this. I felt the food portions were a bit small for being around $5 a dish. Maybe they thought my friend and I were small and had smaller stomachs? We noticed that the other people around us got larger portions... -.-

Sitting at the small counter and watching these old ladies yell at each other in their native languages made my blood pressure go up! Watch out for Albert Einstein-haired lady, she likes to yell a lot! O_O I guess many of the other customers found it quite entertaining and just laughed in amusement. Untidy kitchen, small sink, etc. I quickly lost my appetite as soon as I saw the black garbage can within 6 feet. O_O

They buy their coconuts from the market, Duc Loi, across the street for 1/2 of their selling price. I wonder if I can be ghetto next time and buy a coconut at Duc Loi, but have Yamo cut it open for me! bwahaha j/k

** Note: Enter at your own risk! **

excerpts: Why do people out put up with such poor services with ok food?
Cheap prices?
Tradition?
And the customer shuts up.
up.author: David L.
up.review:
Why do people out put up with such poor services with ok food?  Cheap prices? Tradition? The new proprietors have took on the bad attitude of the previous owner. 

A jovial customer comes in and ask: Do you miss me? Reply: no. And the customer shuts up.

excerpts: We placed to go orders and ended up waiting 1.5-2 hours.
up.author: Margaret R.
up.review:
I've been wanting to eat here for a while since whenever I pass the place, it either has a long line or is closed. Once, I after asked someone in line what was good, he replied, "Everything." I left with high expectations.

This place only has 8 or so booths so we realized that we probably wouldn't be able to get seats anytime soon since there was five of us. We placed to go orders and ended up waiting 1.5-2 hours. 

We ordered a bunch of dishes...and all I can say is "Ehhhhhhhhhhhhh." It's just cheap greasy Chinese food. Not even good greasy Chinese food. I think the only thing that made me think of Burmese food was the tea leaf salad, which was aiite. If I was drunk or hungover, I would think this place was awesome. However, I wouldn't come here again with such a long wait time.

excerpts: If you order over the phone just go up to the counter and tell them what you ordered (no need to wait in the often massive line outside).
up.author: Ryan S.
up.review:
Cheap, quick, tasty. For vegetarians, #14 with noodles is the best. 

Cash only. If you order over the phone just go up to the counter and tell them what you ordered (no need to wait in the often massive line outside).

excerpts: If you don't speak up, then you might be waiting a very long time.
Knowing a bit of Cantonese also helps, if you can order in Cantonese; you're golden.
up.author: Amy L.
up.review:
Yamo is cheap, tasty and busy. There is literally only about 8 seats inside and its facing the cook area. I don't know why anyone would want to 'dine in'... you are literally bathing in heat and oil. Unless you want to come out smelling like frying oil, be my guest. 

The menu is relatively simple, nothing fancy. Considering it looks like a 3 person operation; everything will have some form of curry, tofu, mango or protein. 

Now there are only about 3 ladies working there and they are masters at multi-tasking, taking orders, prepping food, handling money....not sure if this translates to the cleanest food but you literally cannot complain when the food is so cheap. 

Things to try: Samosas (fried and filled with curry and potatoes). Personally the dipping sauce is not that impressive, just a simple sweet and sour red sauce. Wished it was more light and yogurt-y (like its Indian counterpart) 
Curry beef: delicious, oily and salty! 
Mango Chicken: more delicious-ness and oily-ness
Noodles: taste like chow Mein 

Wait: is dreadful when its busy. You literally have to wave down one of the lady to grab their attention. They are not the type to ask you 'if you're ready to order'. If you don't speak up, then you might be waiting a very long time. Knowing a bit of Cantonese also helps, if you can order in Cantonese; you're golden.

excerpts: So if I tally up the above, I'd have to give it negative 3 stars (+1-4).
But since I cannot, I'll give it +2, 'cuz
up.author: J K.
up.review:
(1) First off the food here is cheap. Very cheap.

(2) It's also very dirty. You get what you pay for.

(3) Service is also rude and curt. Again, you get what you pay for.

(4) The food here is meh. Being a lover of all things divey, I really wanted to like this place, but I can't get over how mediocre it is. Yet again, you get what you pay for.

(5) There's always a line during dinner. Which leads me to conclude that either:
Yamo customers are cheap and/or broke, and/or Yamo customers have very low standards, foodwise.

So if I tally up the above, I'd have to give it negative 3 stars (+1-4). But since I cannot, I'll give it +2, 'cuz I've most definitely experienced better.

If the line at Yamo weren't so ridiculous, I might consider it on occasion. The food isn't *that* bad, in fact it's somewhat decent, in an Asian street food kind of way. But I cannot justify wasting my precious time for this food, especially when there are much better options in the Mission and nearby 'loin.  Even if it were cheaper (if that's even possible) and/or cleaner and/or more welcoming.

excerpts:
One look in the place and you kinda give up all hope anyway.

In between arguing with each other and confusing the customers with their angry, shouted instructions, they managed to screw up our order of three dishes twice.

Don't look around too much, definitely not up past the black, greasy lights toward the black, greasy ceiling. 
You'll start to wonder exactly what's ending up in the food.
up.author: Josh H.
up.review:
Absurdly awful. So bad it would have been funny except that we had to pay for the crap food and the sad attempt at service, and trust me... we weren't expecting much. One look in the place and you kinda give up all hope anyway.

Food was either greasy, bland and tasteless or greasy, over-salted, and over-vinegared. I don't know exactly what they're trying to prepare here (frankly, I don't think they know or care, either) but it sure isn't Burmese food. Bad Chinese at best, and these poor ladies know how to AIM LOW. In between arguing with each other and confusing the customers with their angry, shouted instructions, they managed to screw up our order of three dishes twice.

The hood over the burners stopped working decades ago so the place has a seriously impressive coating of grease, the kind that makes everything sticky including you and your clothes. If you do choose to sit at the counter, don't wear anything that you're too fond of, it'll reek of rancid oil by the time you're done. Don't look around too much, definitely not up past the black, greasy lights toward the black, greasy ceiling. You'll start to wonder exactly what's ending up in the food.

I have no idea what people see in this place; I guess they think they're getting some kind of authentic experience, but it's a total waste of time and money and a complete joke.

excerpts: First of all, I was surprised by how small the thing was, I guess the close up pics on yelp made it look much bigger.
Secondly, where are the tea leaves?
I didn't see nor taste any tea flavor.
I do, however, like the assortment of nuts they put in the salad.
I also tried some of my friend's chicken curry.
It was bland.
I also ordered the spring rolls.
Once again, it was average and the peanut sauce was, you guessed it, bland.
up.author: Alice W.
up.review:
I had the tea leaf salad. First of all, I was surprised by how small the thing was, I guess the close up pics on yelp made it look much bigger. Secondly, where are the tea leaves? I didn't see nor taste any tea flavor. I do, however, like the assortment of nuts they put in the salad. I also tried some of my friend's chicken curry. It was bland. I also ordered the spring rolls. Once again, it was average and the peanut sauce was, you guessed it, bland. Considering the price, I would give the food 3.5 stars. 

Now, here's the kicker -- the server was extremely rude. I get take out from Chinatown often and am well acquainted with bad service, but even I was shocked. I asked for prawns on my salad and the lady said OK. When my salad came, there were no prawns in sight and I asked her about it. She told me that it has dried shrimp. I told my server that I would pay for some prawns added to the salad. The lady literally yelled "NO!" at me. I was stunned. Maybe it was the language barrier thing, but there was absolutely no excuse to treat a customer like that, especially since I didn't argue with her and was courteous.

excerpts: We bellied up to the bar and almost immediately was asked what we wanted, like regulars.
up.author: Caitlin T.
up.review:
Divey yet charming hole-in-the-wall spot in the Mission that offers quick, decent food and a great price.  They go heavy on the oil though despite the array of fresh, delicious vegetables on the counter.

The place is tiny with a small wait for the handful of bar seats available.  There's not a lot of personal space, so we quickly befriended our neighbor.  We bellied up to the bar and almost immediately was asked what we wanted, like regulars.  Food came out quickly.

The house noodles with chicken and pork potstickers were tasty.  The curry noodles with shrimp were not very flavorful and while I enjoyed them, I would not order them again.  The meals were greasy, so I want to come back for their lighter options.

The girl next to me order the chicken coconut soup and it looked delicious so it's next on my list.  The salads also seemed very popular.

excerpts: this place is chaotic and most of the time i call ahead my order to pick it up.
but even then, it can take awhile.
but it 's tasty and not expensive!
one of my new "go to's".
up.author: Clara H.
up.review:
YES. i heart the chicken noodle soup here. it's basically their house noodles, with chicken in a coconut curry broth. totes comfort food! i also ordered the tea leaf salad, which was a great side meal to the soup. 

skip the mango chicken. 

also ordered the house noodles with beef. greasy, but still tasty. 

this place is chaotic and most of the time i call ahead my order to pick it up. but even then, it can take awhile. but it 's tasty and not expensive! one of my new "go to's".

excerpts: Was very excited, but ended up very sad and disappointed when our food (house noodle, curry, fish chowder) was greasy and flavorless.
Yes the environment feels authentic, but the food was not good and definitely not worth the wait.
up.author: Ryan K.
up.review:
Waited 45 minutes for take out that we'd called ahead for. Was very excited, but ended up very sad and disappointed when our food (house noodle, curry, fish chowder) was greasy and flavorless. Yes the environment feels authentic, but the food was not good and definitely not worth the wait. Too much hype from other reviewers*.

*hipsters

excerpts: If they gave the place a good scrubbing and a fresh paint job I'd gladly bump them up to four stars.
up.author: Manny F.
up.review:
It seems like the wave of yelp influenced hipsters that made this place nearly impossible to get into for months has moved on to Ike's and I couldn't be happier. Now I can eat here after only a reasonable wait.

I finally tried their tealeaf salad and loved it; of course their fish noodle chowder is as good as ever.

If they gave the place a good scrubbing and a fresh paint job I'd gladly bump them up to four stars.

excerpts: Hole in the wall (seats around 10) popular place between Mission and Valencia usually gets crowded later in the evening with people waiting to pick up take out orders.
Tealeaf salad, was amazing.
Average vegetarian options.
Spice level bit above average.
up.author: Sandeep M.
up.review: Hole in the wall (seats around 10) popular place between Mission and Valencia usually gets crowded later in the evening with people waiting to pick up take out orders. Tealeaf salad, was amazing. Average vegetarian options. Spice level bit above average.

excerpts: I suggest ordering ahead for pick up because getting a seat here will be impossible.
up.author: Lisa T.
up.review:
Ok this place is small as hell. Like hole in the wall in an open kitchen. I suggest ordering ahead for pick up because getting a seat here will be impossible. 

I wanted to like this place because it was owned by 3 Burmese ladies working their butt off with the hot wok. But I just felt like the portions were super small and nothing wowed me. It is cheap (according to sf standards) but my native friends said Chinatown is cheaper. 

My favorite was the tea leaf salad. I never had anything like it so I went to my local Burmese market to hopefully get a replacement haha. 

They give pretty durable Tupperware for their takeout orders! Totally reusable.

excerpts: I placed an order to go for myself and one other person (a friend laid up with a messed up leg, since you asked).
For my two orders of noodles and one order of potstickers I waited an entire hour, while people who ordered after me got their food and left.
Then, when I got the food home, I found that they hadn't even seasoned our food!
So I waited an hour for plain white rice with a bland assortment of chicken and vegetables on top.
up.author: Aaron Y.
up.review:
It pains me to do this. I love Yamo more than suburban moms love their gifted children. When I could barely afford to go out, Yamo was there for me, a cramped, steamy little treasure of a restaurant where I could get an amazing hot meal and still have quarters left over for my laundry. 

But yesterday I had one of the worst restaurant experiences of my life, and it was at Yamo. I placed an order to go for myself and one other person (a friend laid up with a messed up leg, since you asked). For my two orders of noodles and one order of potstickers I waited an entire hour, while people who ordered after me got their food and left. Then, when I got the food home, I found that they hadn't even seasoned our food! So I waited an hour for plain white rice with a bland assortment of chicken and vegetables on top. I would have been better off going to the supermarket and buying a frozen dinner, and that makes me sad. 

I still love this place, but I won't be coming back during dinner rush again, because I don't think they know how to handle their ever-increasing volume of admirers. Mango chicken, tea leaf salad, samosas, you will be missed.

excerpts: Didn't see any washing of hands after handling money or touching the register (which is wrapped in plastic...) and then picking up a handful of noodles to prep to-go order boxes.
up.author: L C.
up.review: Greasy, oily house noodles. Was nauseous for the rest of the day. Tea leaf salad was good but there is a lack of sanitary procedures here. Didn't see any washing of hands after handling money or touching the register (which is wrapped in plastic...) and then picking up a handful of noodles to prep to-go order boxes.

excerpts: Like I said, it most likely dried up on the drive home, but for now, I'm calling it like I see it, and for now, I'm not a fan.
up.author: Stan A.
up.review:
First of all, I thought this was a Korean place (for no reason in particular, just an assumption.) Secondly, every time I see this place I think of the quote from 40-Year-Virgin: "If I have to hear 'Ya-mo Be There' one more time, I'm going to 'Ya-mo' burn this place to the ground. Classic Paul Rudd.

I had no intention of eating here on this particular night, but after passing by the place with my girlfriend and seeing no line (there's always a line), we decided that it was a sign we should eat here. So we went across the street to buy some groceries from the market, only to return less than 10 minutes later...to a line!

Should've taken that as a sign that it wasn't the day for us to 'Yamo eat there,' but we already had our hearts set on it, so we waited it out.. for about a minute. Then we decided to order take out so we didn't have to wait in the cold City night.

We ordered the samusas, beef curry over noodles, and the tea leaf salad. The samusas were great. Not too big and oily, and very flavorful. The tea leaf salad was good, but doesn't compare to the version at Burma Superstar. Lastly, the beef curry over noodles was disappointing. It might've been the fact that we didn't eat it until we got home 20-30 minutes, but it the noodles were dry, and the sauce was lacking. Like I said, it most likely dried up on the drive home, but for now, I'm calling it like I see it, and for now, I'm not a fan.

I would like to try it again (and eat-in this time), as I feel this place has potential, and the prices are quite cheap, but only if I happen to pass by on an empty stomach and there's no line. But if I'm in need of my Burmese food fix, it's Superstar/B-Star FTW.

excerpts: We came at the end of service and do to the limited space the staff was chopping up large volumes of onions next us in prep for the next day which was making my eyes water.
But let me just say, a little eye watering wouldn't deter me from going back!
up.author: V R.
up.review:
Visited for the 1st time last night and was pleasantly shocked how much I enjoyed it.  

Its tiny, only about a dozen seats at the counter and so I can imagine on a busy night there is fair wait, but we waited only about 10 min.  We ordered the samusas  (this is how they were spelled on the menu), pot stickers, tea salad, and the curry fish. Everything was super tasty and the bill came to whopping $20 and change, not bad at all!

Take-out seemed to be a popular option, which makes sense giving the limited seating. Honestly the only reasons I'm not giving it a 5 star is 1. No alcohol... a beer would have been great with that meal and 2. We came at the end of service and do to the limited space the staff was chopping up large volumes of onions next us in prep for the next day which was making my eyes water.  But let me just say, a little eye watering wouldn't deter me from going back!

excerpts: There are about 12 stools lined up along an open kitchen so you can see how they prepare and cook their dishes.
up.author: Tina T.
up.review:
This is seriously a hole-in-the-wall type of place. If you're looking for this place while driving, you may blink and miss it so make sure to look at the photo of the place before coming here. There are about 12 stools lined up along an open kitchen so you can see how they prepare and cook their dishes.

Highlight: Tea Leaf Salad ($5.25): smaller portion than Burma Superstar but so good. Similar in flavor with added onions and heat, if desired. I loved it spicy!

We also had the House Noodles with Chicken ($5.25). Soy-flavored noodles with juicy slices of chicken breast. It was very good but I couldn't help but think it tasted like any other decent Chinese restaurant. Same goes for the Mango Chicken with rice ($5.25). The sauce was very good with the rice but it wasn't anything too special. They also have fresh coconut juice and Cokes in glass bottles.

The ladies who work here are quick. I saw them use gloves to prepare spring rolls and salads so that's a big plus. It's not the most quiet place because those ladies are yelling out orders left and right. I heard them speak Cantonese and what I suspect to be Burmese since I couldn't understand it. 

Overall, great place for some good, cheap food. However, it is pretty much Chinese food so I would only come back for the tea leaf salad.

excerpts: Everything they have is freshly cooked in front of you, all veggies and noodles prepped, and ready to get cooked up.
They won't make it until you order it.
up.author: Jay A.
up.review:
Whenever visiting this place, please, please, PLEASE keep in mind that it is VERY very tiny. My girlfriend and I had to get our food to-go. I had no idea that this place was just a hallway. You've got a cooking area, and a row of chairs to sit in, and barely enough room behind those chairs to walk through. It was my first time trying this place out, and it definitely packs a punch. The prices aren't too bad, no tax, exactly the amount you see on the menu which is posted on the windows of the place.

Two of the items that we both ate were the House Chow Mein with Chicken and the Samusas. Everything they have is freshly cooked in front of you, all veggies and noodles prepped, and ready to get cooked up. They won't make it until you order it. The House Chow Mein with Chicken that we ordered had so much Chicken in it (not that it's a bad thing, a good thing really), and the portion sizing was pretty good, and we had a good amount of Samusas. So if you're ever feeling adventurous, and in the mood for Chinese food when you're in the Mission, check out Yamo's.

excerpts: Be prepared to bump elbows with your neighbor, and don't bring in too many bags/jackets, as that takes up the aisle space well.
up.author: Shikha K.
up.review:
You want hole-in-the-wall? This place has you covered. It is 10 seats max, and if it's at capacity (which it nearly always is), it is crowded. Be prepared to bump elbows with your neighbor, and don't bring in too many bags/jackets, as that takes up the aisle space well.

Space aside, the food is good and extremely affordable. Their salads are a must - tea leaf and mango are awesome and the best things I ate there. Chow fun noodles are good with veggies, but I like my food spicy so I added a lot of chili sauce on them. I wasn't a fan of the curry fish - very salty, even when mixed with rice and/or noodles, and not appetizing.

Overall, you get a bang for your buck (my four dishes cost me $24 and I was suitably full). This is a no-frills place, so don't expect much in terms of service or space, and come early (before 8pm), to avoid a long wait.

excerpts: I ordered the cold noodles with a tea salad and it was whipped up in just a matter of minutes!
I gave this place only four stars because the service is eh, kinda iffy.
On a side note ordering in advance and picking up your order seems like the best way to a) cut interaction with "angry" cooks and b) enjoy your meal in the comfort of your own home.
up.author: Amy Y.
up.review:
One word, and one word only - DELICIOUS!

This was my first but definitely not last experience at Yamo. So it's a hole in the wall restaurant, ya-da-ya-da-ya-da... however their dishes are just bursting with spices and unique flavor. I ordered the cold noodles with a tea salad and it was whipped up in just a matter of minutes! I gave this place only four stars because the service is eh, kinda iffy. Okay, yes I'm aware of different cultural norms - but if this is your first time ordering and the lady is yelling at you for not brining cash, sheesh I would be a bit thrown off.

Regardless, I will be back and just as a suggestion - I wouldn't recommend this as a place to get a quick bite! Every time I've stopped by the line is out the door. On a side note ordering in advance and picking up your order seems like the best way to a) cut interaction with "angry" cooks and b) enjoy your meal in the comfort of your own home.

excerpts: I think I'd be a little cranky too if I had to put up with the hipster invasion in the mission...just saying.
KIDDING...put the apple device down you crazies...
no comments necessary.
up.author: Mariko S.
up.review:
Hands down best worst kept secret in SF. This place has GREAT food AND entertainment if you're willing to wait...

Almost everything on the menu is $6, and the portions are healthy for that price. I always order the same thing...house noodles with chicken, no cilantro. After being a regular about 5 times--they FINALLY stopped putting cilantro on my noodles! Not a big deal, worth picking it out for a yummy piping hot made to order bowl of noodles, chicken and crunchy garlic. Other favorites include tea leaf salad (you can't get anything like it anywhere else), samosas and egg rolls. 

The women who work the place are all friends and own the place together...they are hard working women who make their living a $6 dish at a time--so if you think they are rude, it's just that they want you to eat and get out so they can turn the seat for another customer! That being said, if you take the time to get to know them during slow times, they are really great and funny! 

Bottom line--this place is worth the wait. If you haven't tried it yet, what are you waiting for? Just be sure you know what you're going to order, or you might get the stink eye.

I think I'd be a little cranky too if I had to put up with the hipster invasion in the mission...just saying. KIDDING...put the apple device down you crazies...no comments necessary.

excerpts: You'll have to submit to a fiery attitude to pick up a menu, and don't even think about showing up twenty minutes before they close.
They've been slaving in front of a hot grill for hours, and they'll let you know about it.
Just watch one of them yield an enormous machete and hack up a coconut
up.author: Brandon C.
up.review:
This place is an excellent hole in the wall. In as few words as I can put it: it is bargain exhibition Burmese and it feels so authentic. 

1. You're in for an experience: the kitchen is literally in front of a bar with 8 seats. This is the exhibition: and no this isn't Benihana's. These lady's give a performance that is a bit more eclectically appreciated. You'll have to submit to a fiery attitude to pick up a menu, and don't even think about showing up twenty minutes before they close. They've been slaving in front of a hot grill for hours, and they'll let you know about it.  Just watch one of them yield an enormous machete and hack up a coconut and you won't press the issue.  


2. You won't feel cheated: everything is about $6 and it's good. Of course if you're looking for Burmese cuisine, as in the best ever:  Don't pay $6.

excerpts: I never ate a single salad in my life up until I was 27.
Just never was my thing.
That said, the tea leaf salad at Yamo was absolutely effing amazing.
up.author: Tommy P.
up.review:
I'm not a salad guy at all. I never ate a single salad in my life up until I was 27. Just never was my thing. That said, the tea leaf salad at Yamo was absolutely effing amazing. Definitely the best I've ever had (although I'm admittedly not an expert).

Noodles were awesome too, but damn that salad is crackin and super cheap too. Definitely gonna become one of my regular spots.

excerpts: They were closing up, and we were the last customers.
up.author: Shanna G.
up.review:
Yamo is excellent! My friend and I shared one dish, which was a little greasy but that's how I like it. The women who work there are precious beyond belief. They were closing up, and we were the last customers. When we left to wait for the bus they hauled us back inside and made us sit down, gave us water, and doted on us. 

Cheap, awesome, and the food is goddamn delicious. Thanks for taking care of us Yamo 
 I'm coming back the next time I don't feel like another Mission burrito/super nachos.

excerpts: For a few bucks more I recommend ordering the dumplings and loading them up with the various accouterments of spices and relishes offered at every seat.
up.author: Andy H.
up.review:
So, sure, this may not be the place you'd go on a  first date, or where you'd take a fancy client. But this place does belong in the club of restaurants that as seen as stepping off the street and in to, you forget for a moment that you're in San Francisco. 

The tiny place seats about 8 at most, and once you're in, things move quick. The old women that run the place don't mess around making your order and getting right to it. You feel like you're in a family's kitchen, rather than a restaurant's. 

For only 6 bucks (a rarity in this city) you can get just about any heaping bowl of noodles. I went with the chicken curry, and it was delicious. For a few bucks more I recommend ordering the dumplings and loading them up with the various accouterments of spices and relishes offered at every seat. 

Bring cash, sit down, get in, get out, and enjoy the little slice of culture and flavor this place has to offer.

excerpts: Ridiculously cheap fares....and would reasonably fill you up without causing a fatal fluctuation on your health.
up.author: Jesada P.
up.review:
You eat there, you shall eat like a conformist Asian.  Step in, sit down, order, then wolf down all the way - no talking! Just slurp their goopy noodles and chug down the residual broth. That's the whole Yamo experience which made it an exceptional dining canteen!

Ridiculously cheap fares....and would reasonably fill you up without causing a fatal fluctuation on your health.

excerpts: You'll probably have to ask for water and it'll come after your meal does, but suck it up because it's worth it.
The tea leaf salad is a must -- tea leaves, dried shrimp, peanuts, cabbage, beans, tomatoes -- and
I also had the mango chicken.
The mango chicken isn't overly sweet, which is good.
The mangos are firm, so maybe their secret is to use under-ripe mangos...kudos to you Burmese ladies, kudos to you.
Also had the fish and bean dish, which has the fish lightly fried in a flavorful batter.
It's a tad greasy,
up.author: Myra S.
up.review:
This place is a tiny hole-in-the-wall that you'll be happy to crawl into.  There's only about 8 seats total so depending on your arrival time, you'll be waiting, but not too long.  These ladies are quick and no muss no fuss about taking your order and getting you in and out.  That said, they're not rush-y, just efficient.  You'll probably have to ask for water and it'll come after your meal does, but suck it up because it's worth it.  The tea leaf salad is a must -- tea leaves, dried shrimp, peanuts, cabbage, beans, tomatoes -- and I also had the mango chicken.  The mango chicken isn't overly sweet, which is good.  The mangos are firm, so maybe their secret is to use under-ripe mangos...kudos to you Burmese ladies, kudos to you.  Also had the fish and bean dish, which has the fish lightly fried in a flavorful batter.  It's a tad greasy, but oh so tasty.  

Dear Burma, I'm sorry your health care and economy sucks, but your food is fantastic!

excerpts: As people finish up, one of the 4 ladies behind the counter will ask you what your order is.
Once people leave, you can scoot in and take your spot.

The ladies are probably too busy cooking to notice that you've finished eating, so wave your money at them, they'll check it with your order slip, take your money, and you can free up some space for the next customers.
My sister and I, starving at around 8:30pm, waited for 15-20 minutes for spots to open up.
The wait can be worse, she said.
Near the end of the salad, the pieces were too small for me to grab with my chopsticks, so I (shamelessly) picked the plate up and shoveled every last bit into my mouth.
up.author: A.L. H.
up.review:
TIP: The seating is basically one bar with 8-10 seats. If it's full, wait right outside. As people finish up, one of the 4 ladies behind the counter will ask you what your order is. Once people leave, you can scoot in and take your spot. Your food will be ready in minutes!

TIP #2: If you need water, just ask for it. The ladies hear you and will give you a cup of water shortly. Don't expect any other service, really! The ladies are probably too busy cooking to notice that you've finished eating, so wave your money at them, they'll check it with your order slip, take your money, and you can free up some space for the next customers. 

Delicious and just the right amount of food. My sister and I, starving at around 8:30pm, waited for 15-20 minutes for spots to open up. The wait can be worse, she said. We ordered the tea salad, mango salad, and house noodles with chicken. They were $6 each. Portions were just right. 

The tea salad was the star of the meal, at least for me! Such interesting flavors, satisfying crunch from fried peas and fried peanuts, spice from chilis and fried garlic. Near the end of the salad, the pieces were too small for me to grab with my chopsticks, so I (shamelessly) picked the plate up and shoveled every last bit into my mouth. 

The mango salad was tangy and refreshing. Again, the melding of flavors and textures--slightly sweet and spicy, smooth mango and crunchy toppings--worked together beautifully. 

The house noodles were a bit bland. The chicken was nicely cooked, but the noodles themselves lacked flavor (and had a pretty good layer of grease). I had to use some chili hot sauce to put some life into it, but it came out steaming and fresh. 

We watched the ladies work their magic, efficiently and elegantly managing 3-4 pots and pans at once. Mesmerizing. It is what it is--bare bones service, delicious satisfying food that comes out fast, an unforgettable and unique experience.

excerpts: It's pretty hilarious watching 2 ladies cooking fervently to keep up with the madness--they get lots of phone in orders.
It's perfect, hits-the-spot food, esp after grabbing early drinks in the Mission.
It's a shame
up.author: Ly T.
up.review:
Great tiny, hole-in-the-wall joint that literally can feed only about 8 ppl on the counter. Expect nothing fancy and everything greasy. Eat in if you can, the portions are bigger and can you bring home the scent du oil for free! 

It's pretty hilarious watching 2 ladies cooking fervently to keep up with the madness--they get lots of phone in orders. It's perfect, hits-the-spot food, esp after grabbing early drinks in the Mission. It's a shame it's not open until much later, they'd prolly make a killing!

Can't really say its authentic Burmese food, maybe more so Chinese food with a southeast flair. I always get the cold noodles, which I feel are better than the house noodle that everyone raves about. It's tangy, spicy and very filling. Potstickers were standard, but also good. 

Go ahead and get some today, worry about your arteries another night! Did I mention it's hole in the wall prices?! AWESOME!!

Please stay open later and open another/bigger location!!

excerpts: I've seen people come in for pickup and they don't really understand the system for picking stuff up (because there isn't one), and the ladies have openly mocked them, which is pretty awesome.
You just have to trust that they heard you
and they'll get your stuff done quickly.
And it will definitely be delicious.
up.author: Justin S.
up.review:
Love this place so so so much. As others have said, tea leaf salad is great, and I'm a particular fan of House Noodles -- they strike the not overly flavorful but darn good balance I'm always looking for. The tofu is really good and the way they cook it is pretty great.

The ladies who work here are super stank -- when you order from them, they don't really acknowledge that they heard your order or look at you while you're speaking. I've seen people come in for pickup and they don't really understand the system for picking stuff up (because there isn't one), and the ladies have openly mocked them, which is pretty awesome. You just have to trust that they heard you and they'll get your stuff done quickly. And it will definitely be delicious.

excerpts: I showed up at 7 pm exactly and there were 5 seats available.
At 7:15, there was a line out the door.
up.author: Betty C.
up.review:
Came back for the fish chowder. Always great.

Ordered my fave samosas as well. Just the way I remember them.

My friend ordered the fried rice (nothing special) and the mango salad (delicious!).

Always wonderful here. Be prepared for yelling in very accented Cantonese. I showed up at 7 pm exactly and there were 5 seats available. At 7:15, there was a line out the door. This was a Tuesday. 

Had the hot tea. Served in a water glass. Green tea available. 

BTW, this is a dry establishment. No booze whatsoever. I know. I was shocked as well. But it's still so tasty and cheap! 2 appetizers and 2 entrees and a tea and it was only $19.75. 

I'd order the entire menu to go. I love it so much.

excerpts: Then she opened up a rice cooker and dipped a ladle inside, bringing out the coconut chicken broth with her.
up.author: Johanna L.
up.review:
If you don't care about service with a smile and, quite frankly, not a ton of flavor, then come to Yamo. We got there early enough to sit at the counter without having to wait and ordered 3 items:

Tea Leaf Salad - Tons of texture and flavor, but not a large portion. I'd almost order 2 of these. The fried bean and nut variety? Ingenious. 

Chicken Noodle Soup - This isn't Campbell's noodle soup. We almost thought they forgot about our order until I noticed one of ladies placing chicken, red onion, and cilantro into a bowl. Then she opened up a rice cooker and dipped a ladle inside, bringing out the coconut chicken broth with her. Ahh, that was unexpected.

Yamo House Noodle - Alright, the noodles are the star here. I was disappointed by the flavor of the beef (or lack thereof), but the egg noodles tasted fresh and I almost wished there were more doled out for us.

I respect the assembly line happening here - 1 chef who clearly runs the show, with 3 sous chefs diligently taking orders, cutting vegetables, and making sure mama chef has everything she needs. It wouldn't hurt them to smile every 10 minutes or so, but hey, you don't come to Yamo for the service. You come to Yamo for cheap Burmese eats. If they added more flavor, that'd be great, but I guess that's why we have chili sauce.

excerpts: Tiny, narrow restaurant that you can either pick up from or eat at the counter.
up.author: Rachel R.
up.review:
Totally random stop in here and was a nice surprise.

Tiny, narrow restaurant that you can either pick up from or eat at the counter. While tiny, it seems like the seat turnover is fairly quick.

Recommendation - get the house noodles with pork! Super tasty and flavorful. However, we also got the black bean tofu and I was not very impressed with that dish.

Each main dish is $6 and that apparently includes tax - hurray!

P.S. I have the feeling this place is cash only. Lucky for you, you probably need no more than a $10 or a $20 if you feel like a banquet :)

excerpts: After a friend raved about eating really good Burmese food in SF, I looked up the best Burmese joint and ventured out late one night to try it.
They were near closing and still had a full house, or rather bar because the place only had about 8 or so seats in total.
So we still had to wait what seemed quite a long time.
As we took our seat, more people kept coming but the owner wouldn't let them in (this was about 30 min to closing time).
Even though I wasn't particularly hungry, I still could finish the tea leaf salad and house noodles because they were pretty tasty, especially the noodles.
up.author: Lucy X.
up.review: After a friend raved about eating really good Burmese food in SF, I looked up the best Burmese joint and ventured out late one night to try it. They were near closing and still had a full house, or rather bar because the place only had about 8 or so seats in total. So we still had to wait what seemed quite a long time. As we took our seat, more people kept coming but the owner wouldn't let them in (this was about 30 min to closing time). Even though I wasn't particularly hungry, I still could finish the tea leaf salad and house noodles because they were pretty tasty, especially the noodles. The curry fish however, was a disappointment, because it tasted nothing like curry. Overall I think it'd be a good place to grab a quick bite or especially take out.

excerpts: So after waiting for probably 15 minutes a bunch of seats opened up
and we were seated.
We were great-ed by a very friendly lady and handed some menus.
I really like the style of this place...
so small and busy, it really reminds you of being in Asia at a little family run place.
up.author: John S.
up.review:
Got taken here by a bunch of friends after a nice time in Dolores park.
The place is tiny... like 12 seats tiny and we had 5 people with us.... 
So after waiting for probably 15 minutes a bunch of seats opened up and we were seated. 
We were great-ed by a very friendly lady and handed some menus.
I really like the style of this place... so small and busy, it really reminds you of being in Asia at a little family run place. My favorite part of this place has to be the sounds though... food cooking and hissing, people chatting and the cook staff talking to each other all combines into a very special cacophony.

On to the food. The Samosas and tea leaf salad were amazing, best versions of the dishes I've ever had. If I lived anywhere near here I would be a vegetarian because I wouldn't need anything else. The mango chicken was pretty tasty, nothing special really, and the Yamo noodles with beef was really good as well. Also, this place is cheap.. really cheap... I left feeling stuffed like a turkey on thanksgiving for 25 bucks. I love this place and will return whenever I am in the area. 

tip: you know a place is good when it looks like a hole in the wall and there is a line out the door.

excerpts: I give it a big thumbs up!
up.author: Karen Y.
up.review:
I'm ecstatic to have found a Burmese hole-in-the-wall restaurant in my neighborhood. It's like a dream come true...AND the awesome ladies who run the place speak Cantonese which is perfect for me so I can chit-chat with them!

I've heard nothing but great things about Yamo so figured it was time to give it a try for dinner one night. It's diner-style with an tiny open kitchen (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=CWKicY2EvYWZccR0tNePjA) and a narrow counter space as the eating area that seats maybe a max of 10 people so expect to get cozy with your neighbor! Luckily, my friend Audrey L. got there a little earlier and was able to nab 2 seats towards the back. I was starving (and the portions are decent) so here's what we ordered:

spring rolls ($3.50) - 2 gigantic rolls loaded with basil, shrimp, vermicelli, and lettuce with a side of peanut dipping sauce. This wasn't the greatest and kinda bland...I would stick to getting spring rolls at Vietnamese places.

tea leaf salad ($5.25) - This was by far my favorite dish...don't be fooled by its mild appearance because it's spiiiicy! It contains a mixture of tea leaves, cabbage, onion, cilantro, and various fried beans and seeds to provide crunchiness. The combined tangy and spicy flavors ignite on your palate and are oh-so-delicious! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=fbZj28B92VTTWV1jwGrSNA) 

Yamo house noodles with chicken ($5.25) - If you like garlic, you will love this dish. It's pretty much just egg noodles (similar to thick ramen noodles in texture) covered with fried garlic pieces, chicken, and topped with green onions. It's a greasy and simple bowl of food but has that bite from the abundance of garlic. Yum! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=oIhBcY34GoprtwED1BuaNQ)

curry prawns with noodles ($5.25) - We saw the girls next to us order this and it looked so good, we couldn't resist getting it! They ran out of the flat rice noodles (choice of also rice or the egg noodles) so we chose the latter. It is stir-fried with mushrooms, onions, green bell peppers, spices/curry...a well-rounded dish with layers of flavor/heat and textures. The jumbo prawns were cooked and seasoned perfectly too. I give it a big thumbs up! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=aAuG0KHwIMTJFTegFcSjXg)

I want to come back very soon!!

excerpts: I've only been fortunate enough to eat here once, I normally call and order ahead to pick up.
The entrees ("Chef Selections") recently went up from $5.25 to $6, but it's still as cheap as it gets for some freshly made, consistently tasty asian dishes in the Mission.
up.author: Chris G.
up.review:
Yamo is one of the first places I was recommended to try, since it was nearby and on the cheap side, as unemployment made that a priority. Since then, I try and go whenever I'm in the area on an empty stomach. Talk about consistency!

Tiny spot, basically a long hallway with ~10 counter-seats. I've only been fortunate enough to eat here once, I normally call and order ahead to pick up. I recommend doing the same!

Tasty food. My favorites include the House Noodles with Beef, Mango Chicken, and House Fried Chow Mein with Chicken. Made with fresh ingredients, the simple combinations create light but pleasing flavors. 

The entrees ("Chef Selections") recently went up from $5.25 to $6, but it's still as cheap as it gets for some freshly made, consistently tasty asian dishes in the Mission.

excerpts: It seemed that most people called their orders in and picked it up, but this place was still uber packed the entire time we were there.
We ordered a plethora of plates, but the standouts were the tea leaf salad (dare I say better than Burma Superstar?), house fried rice, and the house noodles with beef.
up.author: Norm U.
up.review:
