A place so smokey, that simply sitting at the counter waiting to order makes your eyes water.  Food so greasy and rich that I actually felt my heart stop not once, but twice during my meal.  Little Burmese/Chinese women anywhere between the age of 25 - 60 (seriously, I can never tell with Asian women) that scare the bejesus out of me.  In a word:  heaven.

This place is TINY - I think I counted 10 seats at the counter.  It seemed that most people called their orders in and picked it up, but this place was still uber packed the entire time we were there.  We ordered a plethora of plates, but the standouts were the tea leaf salad (dare I say better than Burma Superstar?), house fried rice, and the house noodles with beef.  And the best part:  all of the dishes were only $6!

If you're looking for good & cheap eats and aren't too concerned about eating healthy, this is your spot.  I'm actually glad that I don't live too close to here as the temptation to eat most of my meals and shorten my life by a few years in the process would be too great.

excerpts: but it cracked me up.
The lady was nice
but she was yelling to her cooks for another order.
This place always have 10-15 hipsters waiting outside while their meals are being prepared.
So much flavor is put into their dishes that you can't go wrong with whatever you decide to order.
Just be ready to wait
and I would take the meal to go.
The bar is all they have as far as space goes and that goes quick.
up.author: Kevin J.
up.review: This place is ridiculous.  I called ahead to place my order and was yelled at over the phone but it cracked me up.  The lady was nice but she was yelling to her cooks for another order.  This place always have 10-15 hipsters waiting outside while their meals are being prepared.  So much flavor is put into their dishes that you can't go wrong with whatever you decide to order.  Just be ready to wait and I would take the meal to go.  The bar is all they have as far as space goes and that goes quick.

excerpts: The crunchy fried beans over chopped up cabbage tossed with tea leaves in that slightly sweet & tangy dressing, and a touch of chili paste is divine.
It comes in a much smaller portion than the other dishes.
Unfortunately I wasn't crazy about the house noodle with chicken as it was simply a greased up yellow noodle with dry lackluster chicken pieces.
There was nothing else on it to give it more interest, texture, err flavor?
My friend's vegetarian house noodle looked better with all the colors.
Another time I tried the curry prawn and got more greasy noodles.
Yah, I've cooked better noodle dishes even when I screwed up.
up.author: Rina W.
up.review:
Yamo? More like Ya-meh for me. I see why people rate it high. Their dishes at no more than $6 a plate are super cheap so there is the allusion of getting a bigger bang for your buck. However, as soon as you get your food you realize the portion is adjusted to the price. Still a cheap eats joint and I'd still drop in once in a blue moon. But by no means should you go out of your way to check it out, especially considering the line it always has. But if you're on a budget, add this to your list.

The place is super small and may seat as many as ten along a bar in a narrow 3.5' hallway (that's seating and circulation space my friend). The kitchen is just on the other side of the bar, completely open to the diners and filled with three or four ladies shuffling tightly around each other. You see everything you don't want to see... scratching of scalp, nibbling of food, etc.  It reminds me of restaurants you'd find while traveling in some small Asian cities, but you're actually in an the international city of San Francisco. It's like going for an adventure. You will definitely smell like the food you eat if you opt to dine in. yucko!

I kindaaaa like Yamo's food. To be exact, I like one of their foods. The tea leaf salad is more flavorful than when I had it at Burma Superstar and I love it. The crunchy fried beans over chopped up cabbage tossed with tea leaves in that slightly sweet & tangy dressing, and a touch of chili paste is divine. It comes in a much smaller portion than the other dishes. Unfortunately I wasn't crazy about the house noodle with chicken as it was simply a greased up yellow noodle with dry lackluster chicken pieces. There was nothing else on it to give it more interest, texture, err flavor? My friend's vegetarian house noodle looked better with all the colors. Another time I tried the curry prawn and got more greasy noodles. Yah, I've cooked better noodle dishes even when I screwed up.

Give it a try if you must. Worse comes to worse, it's only a few bucks of disappointment.

excerpts: I love what Yamo is about.. 3 little lady entrepreneur cooking up some grub, they don't care about your experience..
you wait, you eat, you pay, you go.
up.author: Maggie L.
up.review:
I love what Yamo is about.. 3 little lady entrepreneur cooking up some grub, they don't care about your experience.. you wait, you eat, you pay, you go.  In a sea of Mexican fare, and "hipster" restaurants Yamo has pretty good home cooked Asian fare.

Best times to go is from 2-6 (after lunch/before dinner). Or order togo.

excerpts: I've been here twice now and the food straight up didn't taste good.
Not even remotely close.
I'm not an overly anal reviewer like a lot of people on here.
I once rated a restaurant 4 stars after a homeless man smoked crack next to me inside.
Yamo sucks.
It's cheap and that's about all it's got going for it.
Go to Burmese Kitchen if you want bomb, relatively cheap Burmese food.
up.author: Rik R.
up.review: This place is god awful. Truly blown away that it's rated so well. Normally 4 star yelp rated spots are slam dunks for consistency and quality. I've been here twice now and the food straight up didn't taste good. Not even remotely close. I'm not an overly anal reviewer like a lot of people on here. I once rated a restaurant 4 stars after a homeless man smoked crack next to me inside. Yamo sucks. It's cheap and that's about all it's got going for it. Go to Burmese Kitchen if you want bomb, relatively cheap Burmese food.

excerpts: I gave up on hoping they will brown rice.
I don't like seeing all these multi million dollar restaurants popping up.
All I want is good clean food.
up.author: Sunny O.
up.review:
ok, YAMO, DON"T change a thing.  

 I now eat tofu black beans chow fun.   I gave up on hoping they will brown rice.

YAMO DOn't change your decor, don't buy fancy furniture.   Stay low prices, low overhead then you maintain your low prices.

The students and other low income folks enjoy your food.   

I don't like seeing all these multi million dollar restaurants popping up.   All I want is good clean food.   That's the best atmosphere around...

When some of these fancy restaurants closes, they have to tear down all their fancy decors for the next restaurant.   Not eco at all.

excerpts: My friend suggested we try it, and I'm glad I left that decision up to her.
She loves trying out new and random places, as there is so much to experience within the city.
(I walked back to Luna Park and cancelled my reservation, but told them I'll be back.)
After another 15 minutes of waiting in line, it was our turn to take a seat.
Given the open kitchen in proximity to the countertop, I sat about four feet from the stove and could feel the radiating heat.
I caught a glimpse of quite a bit of what was being dished out to the other patrons from my vantage point.
Looking at the menu, practically every entree was under ten bucks.
I guess he didn't look up to see that there are several signs above the food preparation area... stating that no alcohol is allowed.
up.author: Cuong T.
up.review:
While walking towards my comfort food mainstay (Luna Park) in the Mission from where my friend parked her car, we saw a growing line of people standing outside of this truly hole-in-the-wall eatery on 18th Street, just west of Mission. Peered inside and saw no more than about 10 people perched on barstools, savoring the asian fare along the counter.

My friend suggested we try it, and I'm glad I left that decision up to her. She loves trying out new and random places, as there is so much to experience within the city. (I walked back to Luna Park and cancelled my reservation, but told them I'll be back.) After another 15 minutes of waiting in line, it was our turn to take a seat. Given the open kitchen in proximity to the countertop, I sat about four feet from the stove and could feel the radiating heat. I caught a glimpse of quite a bit of what was being dished out to the other patrons from my vantage point. Looking at the menu, practically every entree was under ten bucks. There are so few places that I've been that are under that price point.

Onto the food... quite delicious indeed. We ordered the mango chicken and the house noodles (with beef) along with a samusa appetizer. Besides trying to get a handle of the semi-round shape of the samusa via disposable bamboo chopsticks (by which my friend and I experienced a degree of difficulty of doing such) the curry and potatoes were balanced out by the neither sweet or spicy dipping sauce provided. The mango chicken had kind of a kick to it, balanced out by the other vegetables from within. The house noodles were good, albeit ordinary as it was stir fried with thin, tender slices of beef. All of the food was quite delicious nonetheless... and served with no MSG added, which is awesome for me.

Andrew Jackson would have approved... as the two entrees plus appetizer cost less than one of those bills.

While savoring the delicious life, some dude walked in and asked if he could drink his bottled beer along with his meal. I guess he didn't look up to see that there are several signs above the food preparation area... stating that no alcohol is allowed.

Please take note:
1. This really is a hole in the wall. I'm quite surprised this restaurant can operate in such a small space.
2. You'll smell like asian food afterwards, given less than adequate ventilation, but a lot of love and joy that goes into the food.
3. Sitting next to the door would ordinarily give you some more breathing room, but the stove is right there too, so it really doesn't make much of a difference.
4. CASH ONLY. So don't be that person who after finishing their meal, asks people if they've got some money.

excerpts: It's a cozy set up--a counter then four little ladies behind it, cooking their hearts out.
up.author: Kai C.
up.review:
It's a cozy set up--a counter then four little ladies behind it, cooking their hearts out.  

Me and my friend walked in to a packed place of about 6 people (it really is a hole in the wall).  We didn't have much time, so I asked how long the wait would be.  She scowled and barked out, "How many!"  After hearing the lady's response, I was left wondering whether I said something wrong, or maybe the lady was just having a bad day. I figured she was stressed, and something was lost in translation, so I just placed our order and watched them cook our food.  The service leaves a lot to be desired, but there's something to be said about seeing the ladies cook your food in front of you.  I bet the other customers would agree.  As a couple left, one of them said, "Thank you!  That was excellent as usual!"  That prompted a grunt from one of the cooking ladies.  

Me and my friend got the Mango chicken, which we thoroughly enjoyed.  Would I go back?  I sure would!!!

excerpts: Prices have gone up a little from $5.25 to $6.00, but it is so worth it.
The three ladies that run the place don't smile much but if you are polite and use an icebreaker, you will be one of the lucky few that will get a smile with your meal.
My favorite dish is the pork/beef Yamo noodles.
Heads up: This place is tiny so call to place your order and take it to go.
up.author: Mui Anne C.
up.review:
In this part of Mission, you get sun and cheap eats.  Upon my return to SF after 17 months of being away, I craved for this.  Prices have gone up a little from $5.25 to $6.00, but it is so worth it.  The three ladies that run the place don't smile much but if you are polite and use an icebreaker, you will be one of the lucky few that will get a smile with your meal.  My favorite dish is the pork/beef Yamo noodles.  The chicken is good, but not as flavorful.

Heads up: This place is tiny so call to place your order and take it to go.

excerpts: Please~ don't come here with a posse of more than 2 and then sit like you have an hour to catch up and look through pictures of their dog/kid/ trip to Europe.
The set up when it's busy goes like this.
up.author: Wendy L.
up.review:
Everything on the menu is $6.00.  Cash only. Please~ don't come here with a posse of more than 2 and then sit like you have an hour to catch up and look through pictures of their dog/kid/ trip to Europe. The set up when it's busy goes like this.

1. Stand in line
2. Order at the counter while waiting and standing in line.
3. Sit down and promptly served
4. Eat (served water) . Eat (ask for water). Eat. Eat ( ask for some more water).
5. Pay Bill/ Ask for to go boxes
6. Leave. 

Follow this and you'll enjoy a great cheap meal. I would get the mango salad or the tea salad to balance the oil in the food. I don't think I've had Burmese food that's been this heavy. It is a bit greasy, especially the noodles- but the house noodles are really tasty. The beef is so soft and tender ~ it's similar though to beef in Chinese beef chow fun, but more tender and tasty. The curries are more salty, less creamy, but with slight hints of tumeric and curry powder~ don't expect heavy Thai or Indian curry flavors. 

II would definitely go back again and wait in line to try their other dishes and order their house noodles again.

excerpts: While we waited for our food, I just sat and watched in awe at how the three of them dealt with taking orders, cleaning up the counter, wrapping spring rolls, collecting customers' tabs, yelling out dishes to the chef lady, preparing ingredients for the chef lady to cook, packing up to-go orders, and answering the phone.
up.author: Diane L.
up.review:
Wow, talk about a hole-in-the-wall establishment!  If Yamo doesn't epitomize hole-in-the-wall, I don't know what does.

There are normally 8 counter seats in this very narrow and tiny restaurant.  But sometimes there are 10, because 2 of them are pseudo counter seats right by the doorway.  It's really not a counter for eating, but a counter for ordering takeout.  But when you're hungry for cheap and good Burmese food, sitting anywhere is fine.  Even if it means sitting right in front of the open kitchen, making it much easier for your hair to smell like grease.  But it's all good because that means you have the best seat in the house to watch the chef lady bust out her multi-tasking culinary skills.

There were two older women and one young girl working the night we came here.  The SO and I were delighted to hear them talking to each other in Cantonese, so we bust out our Canto and made friendly conversation with everybody in our native tongue.  While we waited for our food, I just sat and watched in awe at how the three of them dealt with taking orders, cleaning up the counter, wrapping spring rolls, collecting customers' tabs, yelling out dishes to the chef lady, preparing ingredients for the chef lady to cook, packing up to-go orders, and answering the phone.  Even more amazing was that they did it with finesse.

Appetizers are $3.50 each, and all salads, soups, noodle soups, and entrees are $5.25.  The SO and I ordered fish curry with rice, Yamo house noodles with beef, and Yamo cold noodles with chicken.  We finished it all, as the portions weren't that big.  Or maybe we're just pigs.  The noodle dishes were great and we especially loved the tasty and tender beef slices that came with the House Noodles.  The food is on the greasy side, but it's real homecookin' you'd find in your Burmese friend's mom's kitchen.

excerpts: Order via phone and pick up in you're in a rush.
Most dishes are $6.
The tea leaf salad is my favorite.
You must try it.
One of my favorites for cheap eats!
up.author: Rex C.
up.review: Tiny place hidden in the shadow of Mission Street.  The place holds around 12 guests and the wait can be long.  Order via phone and pick up in you're in a rush.  Most dishes are $6.  The tea leaf salad is my favorite. You must try it.  One of my favorites for cheap eats!

excerpts: Wait your turn, these Burmese mamas are cooking up a storm in this cozy space!
I wonder if their children know how many people in SF admire their moms ... tastes like home cooking for little in the pocket.
up.author: Andrea M.
up.review: "Woohoo! As good as it gets!" is absolutely right! Wait your turn, these Burmese mamas are cooking up a storm in this cozy space! I wonder if their children know how many people in SF admire their moms ... tastes like home cooking for little in the pocket.

excerpts: There are too many other well priced food places in the city to get caught up on this one.
up.author: Skye W.
up.review:
This place is definitely over-rated.  Helps that they are small and cheap and located in hipster central.

I got there at 850pm on  Tuesday and waited for about 20 minutes to get seated with my bf.  I got the house noodles with chicken and veggie.  It reminded me of the mongolian station at my dining hall in college.  I wasn't sure if I would be able to digest all of the grease, but so far my stomach has been okay.  We shared the tea leaf salad which was a TINY portion but good.  My bf got the chicken noodle soup that is in a curry like broth, it tasted good.

We both left reeking of stir fly and oil on our skin, in our clothes, and all through our hair. EEEEEK.

This place isn't really burmese food, it's more like chinese with a twist.  There are too many other well priced food places in the city to get caught up on this one.

excerpts: Like a lot of Burmese people, the two ladies behind the counter are actually Chinese people who grew up in Burma.
This tiny hole in the wall can fit up to 10 people and it's all counter seating
up.author: Shannon L.
up.review:
This place is excellent... one of the most authentic you can get and you could never tell that by the outside.  I heard about them through an article in the SF Chronicle and decided to give them a try.  Like a lot of Burmese people, the two ladies behind the counter are actually Chinese people who grew up in Burma.  

This tiny hole in the wall can fit up to 10 people and it's all counter seating so you can see them cook your food right in front of you.

To start off, I had samosas and young coconut juice.  The samosas were nice... not too overpowering in the curry flavor or too spicy.  Young coconut juice.... well you can't really control how this will turn out because it depends on the coconut.  

We then continued with some sauteed garlic noodles which were amazing.  Just like how my Burmese mama made them when I was young!  The noodles were soft and full of garlic flavor.

I can't remember the exact name (as you can tell in many of my posts) of the dish but we had a curry beef dish that was also amazing.  It was a burst of sweet and spicy flavor in your mouth.

Tea Leaf salad was just ok.

excerpts: But this is where Yamo's charm comes from and the fact that there are a few ladies behind the counter whipping up all the food.
up.author: Andrew Christian C.
up.review:
After hearing a great things about Missions very own burmese treat, I was joyed that I could have some of this delicious fare on the cheap.  

I had Yamo on my second attempt, the first time I opted not to enter cause of the overwhelming crowd formed outside its small gate.  

On the second occasion the place was pretty empty and we are talking a very very small restaurant, to the point of cute, with only about 6 seats on a very small counter.  

But this is where Yamo's charm comes from and the fact that there are a few ladies behind the counter whipping up all the food.  

I ordered to go as there wasn't enough space at the time.  Ordered tea leaf salad, samosas and a few noodle dishes.  They all smelled amazing.  When I got home I was a bit let down, the portions were pretty small and the flavor I was used to from places like Mandalay and Burma Superstar just weren't there.  

While it was WAY cheaper than the Burmese restaurants I am used to, it just wasn't worth cutting the cost in the end but a fun attempt.

excerpts:
they were really good and filled me up just right! 
-Entertainment, and descent cheap food
I came out happy but that line was stupid long for ok food.
I gave them a extra star for making me crack up.
up.author: Karen T.
up.review:
-Stand in Freezing Cold at 8pm..wait..wait..
-8:30pm sitting at the tip of the booth where I can see everything and I had the most space to stretch out in this tiny place.
-Beef Yamo Special noodles and Samosas ordered, friend ordered cold chicken noodles
-Then the entertainment begins! This is when I was so happy to understand Cantonese, these ladies were HILLARIOUS!! It was like watching a funny youtube show. They were cussing each other out, yelling at each other about how messy each writing is, "I wrote Chicken Chowmein!!, Mushroom?? can you read? I did not write that! You are RETARDED! RETARDED! I can write English better than you, you can't read!" Then she says to the customer, chicken chowmein right?? He said yes, I don't care feed me anything! haha. Then she continued asking me to read the ticket, she insisted it was clear (uh..I just saw scribble and laughed and nodded). Some customer left and shorted them, then she started screaming RETARDED White person! I said $21 not $12 Retarded! Retarded! 
Note to everyone: BRING A Translator and you would have the best time here ever! 
-Ok back to the food, the beef tasted like the beef in beef and broccolli, nothing exciting, but it was tender. The noodles were very tasty but oily, but still good. $6 later I was still hungry, Samosas came out cold in the middle so they had to fry it longer. Happy I got the Samosas they were really good and filled me up just right! 
-Entertainment, and descent cheap food I came out happy but that line was stupid long for ok food. I gave them a extra star for making me crack up.

excerpts: so we ended up getting:
up.author: Rachana S.
up.review:
I was excited to try a hole in the wall Burmese restaurant and went with two other friends.  We waited maybe 10 minutes before being seated which wasn't bad at all.  As everyone else mentioned, it's super small, and you can watch all the food being prepared for you which is pretty cool.  But, the food was only ok to me.  I'm vegetarian so we ended up getting:

Tea-leaf salad - this was pretty tasty, but I prefer this dish at other Burmese restaurants
Samusas - actually really good and hot and fresh
Mushroom Tofu - ok, kind of lacking in flavor
Vegetable Curry over noodles - luke warm, but interesting - I appreciated that okra was among the vegetables in the dish.
Coconut Water - awesome, got to eat the coconut meat at the end as well, but not really special to Yamo
Green jelly drink - a canned drink that was ok

But, this place IS dirt cheap.  We got all of that for 25 bucks.  I wouldn't resist if someone wanted to come here for dinner, but I think I'd prefer most of the other Burmese restaurants around town (even if they're further out).

excerpts: At the end of the day, dining here is a good conversation topic both while dining inside the restaurant (people watching while you wait and people watching while others wait for you to hurry up and finish) and after.
up.author: Ghia G.
up.review:
I went here with a group of 6 at the suggestion of one of our friends. We got here at a good time because parking was easy to find and the wait wasn't bad. The 6 of us actually all got to sit next to each other at the very end of the restaurant, very cramped though. Everyone else eating was very cordial about moving around so couples or groups can sit next to each other. I believe my boyfriend and I shared one curry dish and one other chicken dish-- but whatever it was, the food was very oily and I had a stomachache the next day. That's the kind of result you can expect from anywhere with cheap food though. I can see what the allure of this place is for a lot of people, but I'm not eager to return since it's a bit out of the way for food I consider slightly above mediocre. At the end of the day, dining here is a good conversation topic both while dining inside the restaurant (people watching while you wait and people watching while others wait for you to hurry up and finish) and after. The staff is friendly, a bit hard to understand, entertaining and very busy with to-go orders.

I'll definitely need to venture out for better and possibly fresher/healthier Burmese options.

excerpts: Just called for a pick-up order and when I was done reciting my order, she just hung up on me; despite all of this, I'll be back, again and again.
up.author: Aaron A.
up.review: The food is delicious but the people who work there hate you soooo much. Just called for a pick-up order and when I was done reciting my order, she just hung up on me; despite all of this, I'll be back, again and again.

excerpts: And their pork potstickers, all gingery and meaty and oily, soak up all your bad thoughts.
Love Yamo forever.
up.author: Laura M.
up.review:
I knew this day would come. Yamo finally raised their prices to a whopping $6 for all main dishes. INSANE. Mind blowing.

After all these years, I still love the surly waitresses, the fact that they always forget to bring you water after you've asked for it 9 million times, the cramped space and of course the grub. When it's cold out I always get the coconut chicken noodle soup, but my new favorite is the house cold noodles with chicken. Oh my god, people. Best under-$10 dish in the city. And their pork potstickers, all gingery and meaty and oily, soak up all your bad thoughts.  Love Yamo forever.

excerpts: Please, just expect to be confused about when/how to pick up your order.
Then you won't be upset.
up.author: Heidi H.
up.review: Who knew I could get so excited about mushrooms and tofu? Yes, it's true! I feel like I'm stealing from them because the prices are so low. Please, just expect to be confused about when/how to pick up your order. Then you won't be upset. :)

excerpts: Until the next day...today when I was woken up at 6am with food poisoning literally.
I have been sick from this all day until late into the afternoon.
I do not suggest you go here regardless of the tast unless you are used to eating in 3rd world country type restaurants where the ingredients and hygiene status are questionable.
up.author: Michelle D.
up.review: Poor poor hygiene to the point that I was a little shocked with myself for eating here but I had heard raves about the food being delicious. The women there do not wash hands, I witnessed one put her hand inside a jar of seasoning after scratching herself with that same hand. (after this i still ate here...wow me) However the food was good a bit greasy but I will give them that. Until the next day...today when I was woken up at 6am with food poisoning literally. I have been sick from this all day until late into the afternoon. I do not suggest you go here regardless of the tast unless you are used to eating in 3rd world country type restaurants where the ingredients and hygiene status are questionable.

excerpts: Some people called in orders and when they showed up to pick them up, the woman at the counter had no idea what they were talking about.
If you can tolerate the madness then you might enjoy this place.
up.author: Blond E.
up.review:
Here's the deal. The food here is pretty good. It's flavorful and fresh. The price is right. But MAN, is this place disorganized! I had to wait for over 45 minutes for a simple noodle dish. There was no rhyme or reason to the way they prepared or served the dishes. People who came in after me were served before me. I kept reminding the woman of my order but she kept forgetting to ask the chef to make it. Some people called in orders and when they showed up to pick them up, the woman at the counter had no idea what they were talking about. If you can tolerate the madness then you might enjoy this place. For me, it was a little too much.

Bottom line:

Food: 3.5 stars 
Service: 0 stars

excerpts: For starters, I'd recommend hitting up Yamo during non-peak hours.
If you do manage to get a seat at the bar, I'd recommend sitting as far away from the door as possible.
If you're looking to eat and beat the line, call your order in and pick it up 15 minutes later.
It definitely beats the crowd on a cold San Francisco night.
up.author: Trevor U.
up.review:
Yamo's food quality deserves 3 stars, but the experience in itself deserves 4 stars.  

There is always a line at Yamo!  It might be because the hole in the wall that Yamo calls home is comparable in size to a muni car.  And let's be honest, riding muni during rush hour sucks.  You can never get a seat at the bar and you're constantly rubbing shoulders with people to order.  Once you do get your opportunity to order, you better do it correctly or else the intimidating Burmese women might let you have it.  

For starters, I'd recommend hitting up Yamo during non-peak hours.  If you do manage to get a seat at the bar, I'd recommend sitting as far away from the door as possible.  I'd also recommend getting a fresh coconut to sip on while you wait.  

As far as food goes, I'm a huge fan of the Tea Salad, House Fried Chow Mein, and Yamo House Noodles.  Don't expect much from these dishes in terms of size as everything on the menu is only $6.  

I highly recommend Yamo because it is a unique experience.  You probably won't be able to absorb another experience like this one anywhere else in San Francisco. 

*If you're looking to eat and beat the line, call your order in and pick it up 15 minutes later.  It definitely beats the crowd on a cold San Francisco night.

excerpts: I didn't get what all the hype was about because my co-worker, who loves this place, journeyed all the the way here by Muni to pick up lunch.
I thought the curry was disappointing.
up.author: Sam T.
up.review:
The first time I tried Yamo, I had the curry chicken to go. I didn't get what all the hype was about because my co-worker, who loves this place, journeyed all the the way here by Muni to pick up lunch. I thought the curry was disappointing. Maybe because I had not developed a taste for Burmese food yet.

So, I decided to give Yamo a second try. This time, I ordered the Fish chowder soup and the Mango chicken to go.

Again, after the first few bites... not impressed. The flavor and spices seemed odd. But then it started to click. I found myself cramming down all the food. I really enjoyed the spiciness of the mango chicken. Though, the dish was kinda greasy, I liked the flavors and the perfect amount of heat, which gave this dish a nice kick.

The Fish chowder soup was just as good. Unfortunately, I ran out of noodles to go with the soup... But, the soup did go well with a package of ramen the next morning. That was a tasty breakfast.

So, I'd be back for take-out the next time I'm around the Mission. Space is really small... kinda dirty... prices are good.

As Paul Rudd would probably say... If ya mo be in the Mission... ya mo be there.

excerpts: The tea salad is whats up!
Its delicious and spicy (though yes, small but c'mon
it's 6 bucks).
Would definitely go again!
up.author: Ivy M.
up.review: Awesome for a solo diner. The tea salad is whats up! Its delicious and spicy (though yes, small but c'mon it's 6 bucks). Would definitely go again!

excerpts: Located in mecca of hipsters, the Mission District, I drove to Yamo and picked it up and only paid less then $6!!!
Went home and indulged myself in dinner and was truly satisfied.
The taste of the chicken was tender, not too spicy and the noodles had enough flavor and not greasy at all.
In addition to the chicken, I also got vegetable samosas, which were also appetizing
but I felt the sauce that accompanied
it was a bit too spicy for my taste!
Overall, I will be a returning a customer!
up.author: C M.
up.review:
Count me in as a follower! I totally agree with most reviewers of this place that although the long wait and the lack of seats is off putting for some, the affordable and most importantly, the delicious, Burmese/Chinese food is worth the sacrifice.

I went here after my sister had recommended it. I called ahead and placed an order for the mango chicken and noodles to avoid the lines as I was advised. Located in mecca of hipsters, the Mission District, I drove to Yamo and picked it up and only paid less then $6!!! Went home and indulged myself in dinner and was truly satisfied. The taste of the chicken was tender, not too spicy and the noodles had enough flavor and not greasy at all. In addition to the chicken, I also got vegetable samosas, which were also appetizing but I felt the sauce that accompanied it was a bit too spicy for my taste! Overall, I will be a returning a customer!

excerpts: It's just about time Yamo will come up in "Hot on Yelp" box.
Be prepared not to wear fancy clothes or your expensive shirt will ended up smelly.....in a good way.
you can smell that yummy food all day long !
LOL
up.author: Jazzleen H.
up.review:
It's just about time Yamo will come up in "Hot on Yelp" box.

"Special house noodle with beef and tofu, please."

Alrighty, the aunties will go directly cook the dishes in front of you. Next thing you know, you feel full, satisfied and feel the desire to tip bigger since the food itself cost no more than $6. 

Be prepared not to wear fancy clothes or your expensive shirt will ended up smelly.....in a good way. you can smell that yummy food all day long ! LOL

excerpts: We were four, and sat initially as twosomes separately and then as people got up to leave, we scooted to sit altogether.
up.author: Sapna E.
up.review:
How awesome is this place. Your typical divey joint, with two screaming women, shouting your order. By the end of your meal you are definitely slightly deaf and also smell like you bathed in some burmese food :)

The only seating option is the bar and you have to wait maybe ~20minutes. But its definitely worth it.

We were four, and sat initially as twosomes separately and then as people got up to leave, we scooted to sit altogether. 

We got the,

tea leaf salad - really good and definitely different from Burma Superstar
Potstickers - didnt try (pork) but I dont think it was that good because they were not wiped out
Curry Shrimp with Noodles
Curry Fish with Noodles
Chicken Yamo - to go
Stir Fry Vegetable with Rice


super cheap and really good food! perfect for a low key evening. Also, vry popular as a "to-go" option. As expected, this is a cash-only joint!

excerpts: The poor guy ended up standing outside the restaurant eating his food.
Anyways, I sat there with my boyfriend for half an hour watching people that ordered after us get their food first.
Few minutes later, I saw that they had just started cooking our food
and I was completely fed up.
I got up and left.
I walked into the place in a very good mood and walked out extremely irritated.
up.author: Karen C.
up.review:
This is the most awful place I've ever set foot in. I still cannot understand how the health department hasn't shut it down yet. I gave it a chance even though the place is a complete dump and that was a HUGE mistake. Besides the rusty kitchenware, sticky menus, and lack of ventilation, the service was the WORST I've ever seen. The lady taking orders was the RUDEST person I've ever met. Not only did she rush me to order, she kept pushing the check in my face when I didn't even get my food yet and I was eating there. Another guy ordering to go asked if he can eat his food there and she flat out said "NO, it's too late." The poor guy ended up standing outside the restaurant eating his food. Anyways, I sat there with my boyfriend for half an hour watching people that ordered after us get their food first. Few minutes later, I saw that they had just started cooking our food and I was completely fed up. I got up and left. I walked into the place in a very good mood and walked out extremely irritated. I've never felt the need to write a bad review about any restaurant before (even though I have had bad experiences), UNTIL NOW.

DO NOT EAT HERE! IT IS COMPLETELY DISGUSTING, THE SERVICE IS TERRIBLE AND THE FOOD DOES NOT LOOK GOOD AT ALL.

excerpts: Heads up, if you plan on eating here there may be a wait.
The place can only seat a total of 9 people, so beware of a line.
I suggest calling ahead and order to go.
Aside from that, the food is cheap and super delicious!
Go here!
up.author: Tom T.
up.review: Great food here. Heads up, if you plan on eating here there may be a wait. The place can only seat a total of 9 people, so beware of a line. I suggest calling ahead and order to go. Aside from that, the food is cheap and super delicious! Go here!

excerpts: I just use it as a condiment and hype up the flavors of my dish.
I love Yamo
and I think I crave it maybe at least 1 every 2 weeks for sure.
Wait can be long or short just depending on luck.
Support the hard working girls there.
Love you Yamo..
up.author: Lia N.
up.review:
Fast food ,great ,tasty yummy $6 small portion tea leaf salad. I just use it as a condiment and hype up the flavors of my dish. I love Yamo and I think I crave it maybe at least 1 every 2 weeks for sure. 
Wait can be long or short just depending on luck. Support the hard working girls there. Love you Yamo..

excerpts: I usually only order this because it fills me up
and I can't seem to get myself to order anything else.
However, I have also tried the Mango Chicken, Curry Beef, and House Noodles once....still delicious, but I gotta have that soup!
Also did I mention all of the entrees are just $6?
Great tip - order on the phone and pick it up to avoid the line out the door, and have a picnic in Dolores Park!
up.author: Vanessa P.
up.review:
OMG, love this place. Ever since I came here on a date over a year ago, I can't get enough. FYI - it doesn't really have an intimate date feel, as you're sharing bar seating with 10 other customers over the counter that the awesome ladies are cooking at. However, it's one of my favorite hole-in-the-wall finds.

You gotta try the Chicken Noodle Soup. It's so freakin' delicious. It has a coconut curry broth with noodles, chicken, and some veg toppings. I usually only order this because it fills me up and I can't seem to get myself to order anything else. However, I have also tried the Mango Chicken, Curry Beef, and House Noodles once....still delicious, but I gotta have that soup! Also did I mention all of the entrees are just $6? Can't beat that price.

Great tip - order on the phone and pick it up to avoid the line out the door, and have a picnic in Dolores Park!

excerpts: Mango salad is my go to back up.
up.author: Mariele A.
up.review:
529 reviews, talk about redundant. 

Yamo is the quintessential SF/foodie dining experience. Small musty restaurant that serves tasty and unique flavors for $5. The obvious go to dish is the tea leaf salad, duh.

I fell in love with tea leaf salad a few months ago. I come back to see him as often as I can.  But, before I commit to the best salad ever, I tried the Mango salad. Equally delicious, but doesn't slap you with the smokey, garlicyy, and nutty flavors tea leaf has going on. Mango salad is refreshing with a zing of spice. Mango salad is my go to back up. ha. 

I was reluctant to order the warm noodle dish with beef. I thought it would taste like any other asian noodle dish. I was wrong. It had an interesting kick. Supposedly they don't add MSG, but whatever seasoning is in that noodle dish is worth it! Everything on the menu is worth $5 and more!

If you don't like making new friends, too bad, you're basically holding hands with the person next to you. 

YUMO!

excerpts: I once ordered something like 5 tea leaf salads to pick up for friends, and when I showed up at the restaurant, the ladies made fun of me for ordering so many.
It's fantastic.
I do think it's better to order food for pickup, since the location is kind of small and smokey.
But eating there can be fun too if you have 2 or 3 people.
Definitely check it out.
up.author: Justin P.
up.review: This place is one of my favorites! Try the tea leaf salad, house noodles, and mango chicken. Probably the best tea leaf salad in all of San Francisco, IMHO. The ladies who run it are pretty awesome as well, they're all business. I once ordered something like 5 tea leaf salads to pick up for friends, and when I showed up at the restaurant, the ladies made fun of me for ordering so many. It's fantastic. I do think it's better to order food for pickup, since the location is kind of small and smokey. But eating there can be fun too if you have 2 or 3 people. Definitely check it out.

excerpts: But dare not forget the soup spoon so you can slurp up that broth.
Next up:
Beef Curry.
I've had plenty of asian curries over the years,
one of my comfort foods.
This one was very good and on par with any others I've sampled.
up.author: Jefferson L.
up.review:
What I learned from reading reviews about Yamo:

Some Yelpers don't know Burmese food from Chinese food.
Some Yelpers think gritty, urban eateries can only rate an "eww!"
Some Yelpers are adverse to eating in restaurants that have garbage cans. Garbage cans! Oh, the frickin' humanity!

What I learned from eating at Yamo:

The Chicken Noodle Soup broth is sublime, like some sort of magical elixir that bathes you in warm sunshine and happiness and love. It's creamy, unlike pho broth, spicy and just a tad sweet--coconut milk, no doubt. The noodles and chicken are plentiful. Eat them, yes. But dare not forget the soup spoon so you can slurp up that broth. Over and over and over again.

Next up: Beef Curry. I've had plenty of asian curries over the years, one of my comfort foods. This one was very good and on par with any others I've sampled. I liked the spicy kick it had, tempered by warm scoops of white rice.

We also ordered the Mango Salad, House Vegetables and House Noodles w/Chicken. All tasty(the dressing on the salad is lovely,) all fresh and all absolutely filling. 

With drinks, our bill was just over $31. When they say more bang for your buck, they're speaking of Yamo.

What YOU'LL learn when arriving at Yamo:

It's tiny--a restaurant built into a hallway. And you'll most likely stand in line with others outside the door, waiting for one of the eight barstools to be vacated. You could order to go but why not stay and enjoy the dingy sidewalks, loud cars and fresh-faced city-dwellers passing by. Participate in real urban living. Stand in line. Meet your fellow San Franciscans. Make new friends. 

Just watch out for the garbage can!

excerpts: I called ahead for my order and they said done in 15 minutes, by the time I got there the food was ready for me to pick up.
The have maybe 6-10 bar stools to sit and watch them cook,  and there is only 2 or 3 ladies working behind the small cooking area.
it is hard to get in
so you usually will see people waiting outside the door to pick up their order or waiting for an open seat.
Cant beat the prices of their dishes though.
up.author: Lily L.
up.review: I used to love this place and was introduced by a close friend of mine, but was not that impressed with this visit: some of the dishes I ordered and I'm wondering if it is because I ordered to go or I just ordered different dishes in the past. I ordered the Tea leaf Salad, Yamo House noodles, the Yamo Cold Noodles, and the fish chowder noodle soup.  The Tea leaf salad was nice and spicy, make sure you have water to help with the spiciness.  My husband ate the Yamo cold noodles and the Yamo House noodles an thought they were nothing special and some of the sauces tasted like it was made with Ketchup.  I really liked the Fish Chowder soup- not too much of a fishy flavor and a mild curry flavor.  I called ahead for my order and they said done in 15 minutes, by the time I got there the food was ready for me to pick up.  The have maybe 6-10 bar stools to sit and watch them cook,  and there is only 2 or 3 ladies working behind the small cooking area.  it is hard to get in so you usually will see people waiting outside the door to pick up their order or waiting for an open seat.  Cant beat the prices of their dishes though.

excerpts: The cooks are all women that are experts in dishing up fast food Burmese food.
2 thumbs up for some yum Burmese cuisine.
up.author: Elaine S.
up.review:
Yeah, it's a hole in the wall kind of place. In fact, I think there are only like 5 stools along a bar table in the whole restaurant. I normally order to go ... there's really no seats or space available whenever I visit. The cooks are all women that are experts in dishing up fast food Burmese food. I've tried to ask for less spicy, milder tea leaf salads and mohinga (cat fish chowder), but have been responded with disapproving looks and remarks of how it tastes better with the burning sensation in the mouth. 

Burmese food is hard to find and the places that do sell some of this amazing food overprices like I can't believe. Yamo is decently priced - a huge plus for a hungry college kid like myself. 2 thumbs up for some yum Burmese cuisine. 

Tip: The cooks speak Chinese AND Burmese... that might be helpful.

excerpts: No loitering, not that that was said, but for the lack of space and seating, it'd be rude to stay and chat while others line up outside.
I was definitely in & out within 15-20 minutes.
up.author: Kris B.
up.review:
Yamo is definitely one of those "hole in the wall" treasures. The place is barely a hallway & probably seats less than a dozen customers. The stools and everything else were all pretty close together; its literally: you, counter, kitchen. But aside from the tiny area the food definitely had a huge flavor. I had the house noodles and inhaled it when it was cool enough for me to eat. Not only was the place tiny, the prices reflected it as well. My delicious noodles were ONLY $5.

The food was great but this is one of those "in&out" places. No loitering, not that that was said, but for the lack of space and seating, it'd be rude to stay and chat while others line up outside. I was definitely in & out within 15-20 minutes.

excerpts: Not an ideal date spot on account of the cramped space, but its part of its charm, its not the cleanest spot as well as you can see the two burmese ladies prepare your food right in front of you and you can see the dirty dishes piling up right in front of you.
up.author: Christine W.
up.review:
Little dirty hole in the wall with delicious burmese food...the way i like it!

Seriously this place is a diner counter with 10 seats, you have to wait your turn to get a seat or just order take out. 

Their menu is cheap! dirt cheap for delicious burmese food. Get the samusas, tea leaf salad, and the chicken noodle soup...i'm drooling already... its super good and its worth the wait...even if the wait is an hour long in the mission... I can wait..I love Yamos!!

Not an ideal date spot on account of the cramped space, but its part of its charm, its not the cleanest spot as well as you can see the two burmese ladies prepare your food right in front of you and you can see the dirty dishes piling up right in front of you.

I overlook these things as there food is too good for me to care :)

excerpts: *Note: This review is coming from somebody who grew up in a Burmese family and has mucho experience in the world of Burmese cuisine.
up.author: Ron T.
up.review:
*Note: This review is coming from somebody who grew up in a Burmese family and has mucho experience in the world of Burmese cuisine.

I'll give it 4 stars for a few reasons:

1) This place truly defines the whole "hole in the wall" home-style comfort food image. 

2) Price to portion ratio is great. It's uncommon in SF to find good tasting food at a friendly price, but this little hole in the wall definitely delivers. 

3) The food actually tastes good! When I went the restaurant was packed with people ordering the house noodles and cold noodles, so we went with the crowd favorite. They do not dissapoint, the flavoring on the noodles is just right (a little greasy, but that's how it's supposed to be) and you can have them with your choice of beef, chicken, fish or vegetarian (tofu/mushroom I believe).

Now, a couple of things to look out for, the main thing being that this restaurant is extremely small and compact. It seats about 10 people (bar style) at most so most likely if you drop by you're going to have to wait. The cook and waitresses also do not speak English very well, but they are VERY friendly, so I'm sure you'll get by just fine! They seem rude (at least I thought so when I was waiting and observing) but once I sat down I was pretty much family to them.

In terms of authenticity it's not too far off from actual Burmese cuisine. Sure it's tweaked a little bit for the American taste (I mean, come on... Burma (Myanmar) is a third world country, so they don't have the luxury of putting so many ingredients into their dishes). However, the seasonings for the noodles are pretty spot on.

If you just want to come here for delicious noodles, over-rice dishes, pot stickers, samosas (pronounced samUsa in the restaurant because that's how you say it in Burmese) or egg rolls then this is a place that will not let you down!

However, if you want to try authentic Burmese food, definitely grab an order of Tea leaf salad, or either of the two soups. I'm not a fan of fish chowder (not Yamo's fish chowder, just fish chowder in general) but the Chicken Noodle Soup (uses coconut based broth) is definitely a favorite of mine! And the house & cold noodles are also authentic to Burmese cooking, so give any of those a try to experience Burmese food (especially the Tea leaf salad). I only actually tried the house noodles because my parents can make everything else at home (and they do! very often...), but I'm just telling you what to try if you want authentic Burmese food.

excerpts: Then mix it up and get your Yamo on.
You won't be disappointed.
And even if you are, you won't really be.
up.author: nick w.
up.review:
if you love watching ladies bicker with each other behind the counter while they cook your super cheap, super delicious, super homemade food, then you'll love this place.

Somehow the lack of service, long wait and small menu only make this place more charming, and I'm not even a hipster.

Are you tired of your go-to taqueria every time you feel poor and need to eat for under $6?  Then mix it up and get your Yamo on.  You won't be disappointed.  And even if you are, you won't really be.

excerpts: Sitting crammed together at the bar with strangers and the sink and stove and fridge all right there and rubbing up against you and the single window
all fogged up makes you feel you've discovered something secret and special.
up.author: Dana S.
up.review:
Sitting crammed together at the bar with strangers and the sink and stove and fridge all right there and rubbing up against you and the single window all fogged up makes you feel you've discovered something secret and special. 

Everything is made to order--the fresh spring rolls go together right there on the counter while noodles sizzle in woks--which means they can vegetarianify pretty much the whole menu full of fantastic Burmese flavors.  

We stuffed ourselves silly for less than $10 a person.

excerpts: Tip: you can call in order and place it ahead of time for pick up and is usually ready in 10-15 minutes.
Parking is hard so its always a team effort to picking up dinner....drop off as your driver circles the block and by the time you pick up order your driver is just coming around the corner.
up.author: Christine M.
up.review: Yamo is my go to place when I'm craving noodles.  The beef or chicken over house special noodles is always good. But now my favorite is the fish curry over rice or noodles.  This place is super small and they only except cash but the good thing everything is like 6 bucks. Tip: you can call in order and place it ahead of time for pick up and is usually ready in 10-15 minutes. Parking is hard so its always a team effort to picking up dinner....drop off as your driver circles the block and by the time you pick up order your driver is just coming around the corner.

excerpts: At Yamo there is a short counter space at which you can plop down, the ambiance is hot Burmese kitchen and not hot SF hotspot, but the lovely ladies there cook up some gorgeous fresh plates of yumminess, AND they chop off the top of the fresh coconut entirely: so you can get at all the fresh coconutty goodness.
Some places don't do this...why I ask you?
It is like $2.50 for the coconut.
$5.25 for each entre.
up.author: Maria D.
up.review:
Yamo, Yamo where have you been all my life? So there are so many overpriced places in this town, and for the most part, they are not even close to being as good as this no-frills hole in the wall. So you put it on a fancy plate and serve it to me with a hot waiter in a crisp white shirt doesn't make the wallet assault any less insulting. 

At Yamo there is a short counter space at which you can plop down, the ambiance is hot Burmese kitchen and not hot SF hotspot, but the lovely ladies there cook up some gorgeous fresh plates of yumminess, AND they chop off the top of the fresh coconut entirely: so you can get at all the fresh coconutty goodness. Some places don't do this...why I ask you? It is like $2.50 for the coconut. $5.25 for each entre. I love the vegetable curry noodles. The veggies are cooked perfect (they are still somewhat crisp) and includes okra. Yumo. Flavors pop, appetizers rock. The tea salad, and fresh spring rolls. Go to Yamo and drink a coconut already. You will be glad you did.

excerpts: Keep your party 2 or less or you'll just be plain troubled and will end up ordering take out, which is well & good
Don't be afraid to chat up the cooks either...
they're not as austere as you think...
warm, really, just terse.
And terse is good, because on with the Yamo food!
up.author: Jon A.
up.review:
if this Indiana balcony I'm on was just a Spring retreat and not full-time living...it'd make me feel a whole lot better being 1,945 miles away from Yamo. From a place that makes me feel like I can walk in alone and feel like I did when I'd wander into my Grandma's kitchen as a kid. 

But my Granny ain't know nothin' 'bout this Tea Salad! 

If I ate too much of this fine, not-too-wet, not-too-dry, just enough peanut salad, I'd start yammering Burmese on the streets. 

Wait...maybe that's my destiny...eat enough of this tea salad to be inspired to overthrow the Myanmar government and restore Burma? 

Wait, then we wouldn't have Burmese refugees that open many a Yamo. A crux!

Most of the time...there was a line...but there are only what? 11 seats? Your match.com date will be queasy if you show any signs of indecision. But again...be prepared for a bit of wait...play Bear, Ninja Cowboy.

Keep your party 2 or less or you'll just be plain troubled and will end up ordering take out, which is well & good but you'll miss out maybe sitting next to someone who says "Fahhhnta," instead of "Fanta."

Chicken came off slightly dry but I expected such with the flash quick fry they gave it. 

Embrace the dive-feel the same way you embrace the dive feel of The Attic. 

Don't be afraid to chat up the cooks either...they're not as austere as you think...warm, really, just terse. And terse is good, because on with the Yamo food! On with the tea salad and Hot House Noodles! 

Wiley cheap too, as in $6 for dinner.

excerpts: Like close up scenes of plunging genitals and nasty cream pies.
No one said a word to him.
up.author: Shawn L.
up.review:
Food here is the bomb!  The pots n pans are seasoned and aged and worked in.  This is like eating and your mom is cooking for you.  Place holds like maybe 11 people.

I once saw a guy in there at the counter looking at a porno magazine eating a salad.  it was HARD porno too.  Like close up scenes of plunging genitals and nasty cream pies.  No one said a word to him.

excerpts: Please come to my studio, which will remind you of your cooking space at Yamo because it's approximately the same size, and stir-fry up some of your house noodles with fried garlic and beef.
up.author: Christy J.
up.review:
Dear Ridiculously Hard-working Ladies Who Work At Yamo, 

Please be my new moms.  Don't get me wrong, I love mine a lot, but she simply lacks the kitchen prowess to turn out bomb-ass mango chicken or mushroom tofu.  I'm willing to make the switch.  Please come to my studio, which will remind you of your cooking space at Yamo because it's approximately the same size, and stir-fry up some of your house noodles with fried garlic and beef.  I could eat it all day, every day.  

Thank you very much.

- Christy

excerpts: If you're looking for a cheap fill-up, it's not a bad choice at $6 per dish.
If you're looking for taste, you'd be better off licking the sidewalk.
up.author: Railroad T.
up.review:
Popular likely due to an overrated hipster obsession with the authentically terse woman who takes orders.

I've tried the curry, mango, and noodle dishes. All were edible, but extremely bland and greasy.

Pot stickers are tasty. Tea leaf salad is good, but unfulfilling.

If you're looking for a cheap fill-up, it's not a bad choice at $6 per dish. If you're looking for taste, you'd be better off licking the sidewalk.

excerpts: If you wanted to kick up your feet, and lounge into plush booths with fancy stuff on the walls, then mosey on along.
Take it to go, and kick your feet up in your living room with your plush couch and fancy stuff on the walls.
up.author: Brandi B.
up.review:
I've been dying to go here, and finally last night CHECK off the list! 

I'm giving this place 3 stars, one for each of those short, loud, lovely little ladies working there butts off in that tiny little kitchen. 

You get what you expect. You see 8 worn, crowded bar stools in a Diner-like setting where if you fell off your stool you'd hit the wall behind you, hardly any decorations, and a fridge. If this is what you expected then you'll love it! If you wanted to kick up your feet, and lounge into plush booths with fancy stuff on the walls, then mosey on along.

What those fabulous ladies create in that kitchen is by no means masterpiece. But I left with a full belly and still full wallet. Sampled two apps, two noodle dishes, and a soup. I have a feeling that you could get anything and it would all taste the same without tasting at all the same. Each dish delicious, $5.50, pretty darn spicy, and with just enough oil to leave that slick in your mouth. Order anything and get a fresh coconut. Way to go Yamo. 

P.s. and If you don't want that dirty, awesome diner experience? Take it to go, and kick your feet up in your living room with your plush couch and fancy stuff on the walls.

excerpts: Pay up front, and expect immediate action by those magicians behind the counter.
I once asked the lady how fast it would take to make a tea leaf salad.
She said, "Gimme money, I make.
I said, "But how long will it take?"
She responded, "Gimme money, I say, I make."
up.author: K P.
up.review:
Have you seen the "Soup Nazi" episode of Seinfeld? 

Well, that's what some of the cooks are like here. Pay up front, and expect immediate action by those magicians behind the counter. I once asked the lady how fast it would take to make a tea leaf salad. She said, "Gimme money, I make." I said, "But how long will it take?" She responded, "Gimme money, I say, I make." Within 1 minute there was a beautiful tea leaf salad in my hands, to go.

The food is AMAZING. The space is a hole in the whole. The cooks are impatient, and even rude, but it's all worth it. I promise.

I recommend you get the tea leaf salad and the fried fish. Everything is good. 

You'll be lucky to eat in as there's no space, so TO GO is likely better.

excerpts: if you dont speak up they'll forget you!
everything is under 6.
it's cool dude.
I love it.
it's fast, it's easy its good.
but be careful theres no place to sit.
it's just a kitchen and some stools.
for Burmese food
this ROCKS MY SOCKS!
I started ordering their one appetizer, I can't remember the name it's a little triangle, fills with good instead.
it's really good
you have to try it.
plus it won't even break the bank its only 3.25!
up.author: Carolyn Y.
up.review:
HOUSE NOODLES! 
COLD HOUSE NOODLES! 
ALL NOODLES! 
I'm a regular at this place but I can never find the check in button, I can only remember it so often. lolol. it's cheap its easy but lines are long, food takes a while to make while waiting in the cold. if you dont speak up they'll forget you! everything is under 6. it's cool dude. I love it. it's fast, it's easy its good. but be careful theres no place to sit. it's just a kitchen and some stools. for Burmese food this ROCKS MY SOCKS!
I started ordering their one appetizer, I can't remember the name it's a little triangle, fills with good instead. it's really good you have to try it. plus it won't even break the bank its only 3.25! :]

excerpts: Maybe if I was a "yelp elite" member, I'd be too stuck up to dig you.
up.author: Leon K.
up.review:
What can I say about Yamo that others haven't said?  Perhaps I'll just reply to the review of Lisa W, who so kindly provided me with a convenient format.  

You're just that YAMO.

Maybe if I were more Asian, I'd like you even more. Also, if I were an attractive Asian girl I'd have tons of "funnies" and "cools".

Maybe if I was a "yelp elite" member, I'd be too stuck up to dig you.

Maybe if I had super mutant tastebuds that were as hard as sandpaper, yet as discerning as that of a piggy, I'd love you all the more.

But let's face it, I'm none of those things, but Yamo, I do love you.

xoxo,
Leon

excerpts: If you like grumpy ladies who give you water if you're polite and they feel like it and who can cook up a mean plate of noodles, you will love this place.
For some reason I REALLY loved it here
but I couldn't tell you why.
The food was excellent, and the service (or lack thereof) only added to my experience.
up.author: Rika Y.
up.review:
This place has character. You won't like it if you're one of those needy customers I used to have when I was a waitress- if you need your water to constantly be topped off, and for someone to ask you how your food is several times during the course of the meal, you probably won't like it here. 

If you like grumpy ladies who give you water if you're polite and they feel like it and who can cook up a mean plate of noodles, you will love this place. For some reason I REALLY loved it here but I couldn't tell you why. The food was excellent, and the service (or lack thereof) only added to my experience. I will be back as often as I can manage! 

Oh, and try the dumplings. DELICIOUS.

excerpts: The catfish chowder has a savory aroma that will make you want to lift the bowl up directly to your mouth like you were drinking the remaining milk from a cereal bowl and with its great flavor it is absolutely worth a try.
up.author: Raphael C.
up.review:
Conveniently located next to the 33-bus line stop at 18th and Mission, this literal hole in the wall serves some of the most flavorful food in the city at unbelievably affordable prices. 

The place is run by, three angry looking Asian grandmamma chefs.  Hard to tell if they are really mad or if they are just concentrating really hard on cooking the food.  Eyebrows are permanently fixed in the upset position.             

The small menu pairs together time tested traditional ingredients with simple dish concepts to create food that is surprisingly complex in flavor.  In a few words... this place may not look like much, but everything taste delicious.  
   
The Tea Leaf salad is as good as or better than any other in the city (including Burma SuperStar and Mandalay) and at half the price.  Ultimately, in a battle of tea leaf salads, I'd put my money on this horse to win, because at the end of the day good restaurants are defined by their VALUE.  (Quality to price ratio) 

The catfish chowder has a savory aroma that will make you want to lift the bowl up directly to your mouth like you were drinking the remaining milk from a cereal bowl and with its great flavor it is absolutely worth a try.  Good for casual soup cravings and fantastic if you have a cold (or the h1n1 virus.)  

The house noodles with beef was off the charts tasty delicious and is definitely a must.  The beef is very tender and explodes with flavor... I'm talking fireworks in the mouth good.  The noodles are cooked to a perfect texture and absorb the components of the sauce very well.   
 
Parking situation is horrendous, that is if you plan on driving to this place.  You are definitely better off taking the bus, biking, or walking if you do not live in the surrounding area.  

Simple counter-style dining that can only accommodate 10-12 people at any given time.  Meaning long lines and long waits.  Go before or after peak dining hours and you will not have any problems snagging one of the few counter stools.  Take-out is also easy and convenient with temporary illegal parking available in the back alley.    

A meal for two will set you back no more than $15-$20.  In the value department it is always a great option and does not leave you with that heavy/greasy feeling often associated with this type of cuisine. 
  
YAMO eat at this restaurant whenever I'm in town. 

Recommended

excerpts: Luckily, we had perfect timing and was able to snatch up the last two seats at the counter (out of about 10 spots).
up.author: Christine A.
up.review:
I love hole-in-the-wall restaurants and Yamo is everything of that. 

Luckily, we had perfect timing and was able to snatch up the last two seats at the counter (out of about 10 spots). 

We were enchanted by sporadic flames from the wok, the swinging lights above, and the 3 women behind the counter and their methodical ways of taking orders, cooking, and serving; these women have it down to a T. 

We ordered two appetizers, two dishes, and a soda all coming out to ~$16. What a deal! No wonder the line was out the door and the take out orders kept the phones ringing. Not only was the food cheap, but it was flavorful and it was hot off the stove.

excerpts: The noodles have the perfect texture and delightfully soak up the light yet savory sauce.
Ahhh..
Pure bliss.
up.author: Sarah L.
up.review: I feel like i'm on a busy street in an asian country! Yamo's noodles really hit the spot and not because the space is tiny and unusual (i prefer clean bright space...). The noodles have the perfect texture and delightfully soak up the light yet savory sauce. Ahhh.. Pure bliss.

excerpts: A wafer like fried to crunchy type thing with bits of fried corn in it are broken up over the surface.
It tastes a bit like a wheat cracker and I ask one of the women what this is.
"I don't know!
She spits out, "I'm just the cook!"
She grins a massive grin laughing wildly and returns to hacking the tops off young coconut with a massive cleaver.
Her speed and precision are astonishing.
I return to me meal.
I'm getting quite full
so I offer my dumplings to the couple beside me.
The thank me and finish the plate.
I feel the onset of a food coma
and I know I have to get to my feet and move soon.
I had noticed a little bar called the Elbo Room around the corner and a pint was exactly waht I needed.
My food and a bottle of water was $12 with tax n' tip.
Nothing on the menu was over $6 and it was totally worth the wait.
up.author: Christopher N. W.
up.review:
Arrived in SF from Vancouver by way of LA. Famished. Having stashed and stowed my luggage and what-not I headed out to find a meal. It was near 8pm and I had to cross town to the Mission in this vast new city in order to get dinner at Yamo which closes at 9:30. Authentic Burmese food. Colour me intrigued. I walk through the Tenderloin District toward the Civic Centre BART station. This area of town is akin to Vancouver's Downtown East Side and the poverty is apparent everywhere. I come to an elevator and stupidly get in to take it down to the station.

I am standing in a urinal. It's like I am actually immersed in a giant toilet. I press the button to go down and the slowest elevator in the universe begins it's descent. I touch nothing and can't decide whether to breathe through my nose and smell it, or mouth and OH FUCK... I can taste it. Urine and human filth. Puddles of piss and other unidentifiable stains keep me locked in one spot and I swear I will never ever take the lazy way out again.

I arrive on the platform, efficient and easy the BART - essentially a subway - takes my 30 blocks or so in about 5 minutes. Nice. I get out and play the fun traveller game of re-orienting myself, of course this involves walking a block the wrong way as I don't like to ask people for directions. I circle around and go a block past where I need to be. I chuckle at my stupidity.

I track down Yamo and the line is out the door. I'm about the fifth person back from the door. Inside 3 Asian woman work the line bellowing at each other in what I assume is Burmese but given that there are over 100 languages spoken in Burma I'm not sure. It's Cantonese-y sounding... The place is narrow and small. The hood vents don't seem to work and there is a layer of grey grease and dust on the walls and some surfaces. The open line is chaotic but seems clean enough. I guess. The place only seats 10 people and right now they are all young hip white people in their twenties and thirties. I fit right in. Usually at a place like this it's nice if everyone is of the ethnicity of the food but while I trust that I also trust faux-poor hipsters in their ability to find good cheap eats. 15 minutes and I'm in and seated at the end. It's cramped and I have to move my leg when one of the cooks needs to access the dishwasher. I really do love eating like this. The service is harsh and abrupt. Usually a good sign. Her English is limited but I just point to what I want. A traditional catfish noodle chowder and some dumplings. She get's to work. Everyone eating is friendly and chatting and I engage the couple to my left in conversation while on my right I avoid being hit by the door of the dishwasher which is causing my stool to vibrate in a delightful manner. My and my dinner companions chuckle about this. My food arrives. The dumplings aren't made in house which is a let-down. I saw her pull them from a bag in the freezer. Expectations low I take a bite. They are pretty good, boiled and then pan fried making one side delightfully crisp. A nice cabbage to pork ratio and heavy on the ginget which I like. They are served with a dipping sauce much like Vietnamese Nuoc Cham, sweet vinegary fishy. Yum..

My chowder arrives. It's thick and hot. The fish is in small chunks interspersed amongst thick egg noodles. It is pleasantly fishy and deliciously thick. A wafer like fried to crunchy type thing with bits of fried corn in it are broken up over the surface. It tastes a bit like a wheat cracker and I ask one of the women what this is.
"I don't know!" She spits out, "I'm just the cook!" She grins a massive grin laughing wildly and returns to hacking the tops off young coconut with a massive cleaver. Her speed and precision are astonishing. I return to me meal. I'm getting quite full so I offer my dumplings to the couple beside me. The thank me and finish the plate. I feel the onset of a food coma and I know I have to get to my feet and move soon. I had noticed a little bar called the Elbo Room around the corner and a pint was exactly waht I needed. My food and a bottle of water was $12 with tax n' tip. Nothing on the menu was over $6 and it was totally worth the wait.

excerpts: Ever had a big fight with your significant other then 10 minutes later had some amazing make up sex?
That's how I feel about this place.
After waiting in the sun outside for 20 mins and having the chef yell, " what you want to order!".
I was thinking why was I coming here again?
And its cramped (hole in the wall)?
Duh!
THE COMIDA.
House noodles with chicken.....
So many textures at once.. fried garlic, al dente noodles, grilled chicken.
It was crunchy, soft, chewy all at once.
And the sauce...
Boo Yah!
Hit the spot.
Pot stickers had a lot of ginger which I like, and thick wrapper.
Awesome!
Went with my friend, and the bill is usually what i tip.
So let's see, full, satisfied, and have money left?
Now this makes me think, If only my girlfriends could do the same.
up.author: Q L.
up.review: Ever had a big fight with your significant other then 10 minutes later had some amazing make up sex? That's how I feel about this place. After waiting in the sun outside for 20 mins and having the chef yell, " what you want to order!". I was thinking why was I coming here again? And its cramped (hole in the wall)? Duh! THE COMIDA. House noodles with chicken..... So many textures at once.. fried garlic, al dente noodles, grilled chicken. It was crunchy, soft, chewy all at once. And the sauce... Boo Yah! Hit the spot. Pot stickers had a lot of ginger which I like, and thick wrapper. Awesome! Went with my friend, and the bill is usually what i tip. So let's see, full, satisfied, and have money left? Now this makes me think, If only my girlfriends could do the same.

excerpts: But honestly speaking, I think a $6 burrito will definitely fill you up more than a $6 bowl of noodles.
up.author: Jennifer W.
up.review: I come here from time to time, but I would refuse to stand in any line more than 4 people. It's not worth my time when there is good food aplenty in the neighborhood. The crowded times are very centralized, so you can easily get a coveted seat inside right before or after noon. Never plan to sit inside though and it certainly would not happen if your group is more than 3 people. Even though you'd think there'd be a commotion in the kitchen, those ladies actually cook at a pace not close to a flurry. And the service isn't even friendly. As for the food, the house noodles is the favorite here. I love that it had a buttload of garlic and a little bit of spicy, but nothing spectacular otherwise. I like the tea leaf salad a lot, which has a ton of crispy parts like deep fried fava beans. But that is one tiny dish. The fish curry noodle soup was good. The fish was nicely fried and the broth was milky. Though the prices are cheap, they are only cheap relative to everything else around. But honestly speaking, I think a $6 burrito will definitely fill you up more than a $6 bowl of noodles.

excerpts: My father ended up chowing down on my sis' mango chicken because he was waiting by the street corner while we ate.
I love how karma works.
up.author: Kenneth L.
up.review:
I'm glad to be the 600th reviewer of this hole in the wall. 
I was in the bay area for a family trip and decided to trek down here after the reviews from my fellow yelpers. My father was so pissed off that he decided to storm off before even trying the food. Well, he missed out. The House Noodle with Beef was the best damn noodles i had in SF. I wolfed down the bowl of cilantro beefy goodness in no time. The tea salad was also a must have. Make sure you have something to drink along with this salad. My sister had the Mango Chicken. The mango chicken was okay at the very best. 

There are about 9 stools, one chef, and 2 waiters in the place. Make sure you don't come in groups and prepare to wait for a long time. The price was reasonable. Our bill came out to be about 24 for 3 people including tips. Just order take out.
The dishes looked like they were mish mash together. Don't expect any heartfelt stories from this place.  The chef was this tired 50 yr old woman. She told us a chef made all the sauces and prep everything. All she had to do was put it together. She recommended the House Noodle and the Fish Chowder Noodle.

My father ended up chowing down on my sis' mango chicken because he was waiting by the street corner while we ate. I love how karma works.

excerpts: I put up with it week after week, out of fear that if I retaliate the lady who runs the grill will 86 me for life.
The chicken noodle soup has saved me when I've had bronchitis and death gripped me so hard I could only make it that one block to find nourishment.
The tea leaf salad is one of the most amazing things that I've ever eaten.
I love taking dates here, as it only seats like seven people, so it makes it all intimate and cute.
Watching the ladies yell at each other and at bewildered customers is a fun show to watch.
Cash only.
When I call my order in I never know if it's really going to be ready in twenty minutes or they might not even begin my order until I show up twenty minutes later to pick it up.
Either way, I'd never complain, because let's face it, those ladies do not give a fuck.
Also, for the love of Christ don't  ask for anything to be altered (like added vegetables) you will definitely get yelled at.
up.author: Vanessa B.
up.review: Dag yo, I come in here once a week and I still get hella verbal abuse! I put up with it week after week, out of fear that if I retaliate the lady who runs the grill will 86 me for life. The chicken noodle soup has saved me when I've had bronchitis and death gripped me so hard I could only make it that one block to find nourishment. The tea leaf salad is one of the most amazing things that I've ever eaten. I love taking dates here, as it only seats like seven people, so it makes it all intimate and cute. Watching the ladies yell at each other and at bewildered customers is a fun show to watch.  Cash only. When I call my order in I never know if it's really going to be ready in twenty minutes or they might not even begin my order until I show up twenty minutes later to pick it up. Either way, I'd never complain, because let's face it, those ladies do not give a fuck. Also, for the love of Christ don't  ask for anything to be altered (like added vegetables) you will definitely get yelled at.

excerpts: The main lady that takes phone orders, to-go orders, and most eat-in orders will strike up a conversation, that is if only the line is not out the door and around the corner onto Mission Street.
up.author: Cipriano G.
up.review:
These women are BOSS!!

They work quick, efficientlly, AND have great costumer service.

The main lady that takes phone orders, to-go orders, and most eat-in orders will strike up a conversation, that is if only the line is not out the door and around the corner onto Mission Street. 

Yamo is the epitome of a hole-in-the-wall diner in SF. I have missed this place a numerous of time while searching for parking because in a blink of an eye, you can miss it. But their are the massive letters out front, "YAMO."

Every time I've eaten here, I have gotten the house noodles with beef only OR in addition to another plate (mango chicken over rice). BOTH are great and cheap. Mamosas are delicious, just not right after they were taken out from the deep fryer. Potstickers are good too.

A 9pm closing time may be discouraging at first, but once you see how efficient these ladies work ALL DAY, you will understand and even want to help them get through the day.
