seating is SUPER MINIMAL, I believe a max of 9-10 seats. Personally, I have refrained from inviting a lot of my usual eat-out friends just because I know we all won't get a seat at the same time. (sorry everyone). Maybe keep your party at most 4 people.

The usuals that eat here are also super nice. They'll recommend something that you haven't had yet. They'll know if you haven't eaten here if it takes you more than 2 minutes to decide what to eat. :D

excerpts: Edgar and I came here as a thank you for me for picking him up from SFO.
There wasn't much heat, so sauce it up accordingly.
Don't get me wrong, it was good, but there were other things on the menu that looked great, but Edgar and I were looking to carb up.
Definitely am coming back here for the samosas, salad, and mango dishes!
Everything was like 6 buck
up.author: Marc T.
up.review:
Edgar and I came here as a thank you for me for picking him up from SFO. He suggested this place because there aren't many Burmese food places in the city, its cheap, and its good (high flavor/cost ratio).

This place is insanely small.. and there was a line out the door. Lucky for us, somehow everyone in the restaurant finished at the same time and we got in before the next rush.

House Special Fried Rice - this was very good. The rie had great texture and the satay flavors were good. There wasn't much heat, so sauce it up accordingly. There also was a good amount of small shirmps in the dish, which added some fill to it, but if anything the satay makes the dish.

House Noodles with Beef - garlicky and tender beef is all I could think of. This is the Asian equivalence of Peruvian Beef and Noodles, but without the tomatoes... at least to me it was. The noodles were a nice al dente, so obvious plus points for that. The steak was ultra tender, and the deglazings from the pan were used for the sauce of the dish, which was amazingly flavorful. I don't know if cilantro is growing on me, but it again worked on this dish, as the freshness cut through the oiliness and saltiness of the sauce (this saltiness and oiliness is far from a bad thing when it comes to sauce/delgazing/gravy, at least to me). And the garlic. A good amount of fried garlic and the garlic oil added to the dish. That put me over the top. This garlic was crisp and had a good amount of spice to probably also counteract the additional freshness of the cilantro that overwhelms me. Additionally, its not so overpowering to mute the rest of the dish. This dish was very home style and so good. I honestly should have split this into 2 meals.

I probably would order something over the house special fried rice the next time around. Don't get me wrong, it was good, but there were other things on the menu that looked great, but Edgar and I were looking to carb up. Definitely am coming back here for the samosas, salad, and mango dishes! Everything was like 6 buck

excerpts: It came up to something around $11.
A lot of food for that price.
All of it was quickly prepared, well seasoned.
up.author: ryan s.
up.review:
Yamo is fast, cheap and out of control delicious. It's an unsuspecting hole-in-the-wall, that you might have walked by before without giving it a thought. I've done that several times.

I had the chicken soup, delicious spring rolls and coconut water. It came up to something around $11. A lot of food for that price. All of it was quickly prepared, well seasoned. Coconut water came in an actual cococut - an awesome perk.

Be warned, if you sit near the door (where the kitchen is), you'll smell of the kitchen after you leave.

excerpts: The place is a grubby little hole in the wall, but really sweet ladies behind the counter (what is up with me and the "really sweet ladies" phrase in my reviews?!), attentive, and it just has this nice and homey feel to it.
They cut up whole vegetables and then cook them and give them to you on a plate.
up.author: Martin W.
up.review:
Fresh, excellent, cheap:  Asian food kicks your ass again!

Also: good selection of condiments.

The place is a grubby little hole in the wall, but really sweet ladies behind the counter (what is up with me and the "really sweet ladies" phrase in my reviews?!), attentive, and it just has this nice and homey feel to it.

And it's definitely scruffy in there.

But it's soooo fresh.  They cut up whole vegetables and then cook them and give them to you on a plate.  That sounds simplistic, but it's something special to see a whole zucchini disassembled and turned into food right before your eyes.

No idea how authentically Burmese the food is, but it's Asian-ish, light on the oil, and tasty-cakes, baby... TASTY-CAKES.

And cheap.  I swear they don't charge much more than the raw cost of the ingredients.

excerpts: And I've caught one cook skimming from people's orders: She cooks it up but doesn't put it all in.
She puts a big spoonful in a separate little bowl and eats it herself.
Another way they're cheating us i guess.
up.author: Lake Y.
up.review: Not a great experience. The food is good, but I wonder how sanitary it is. And it takes SOOO LONG! The women who run it are a bit gruff. They always charge me more than the posted prices. (Either update your menu or charge that price!) And I've caught one cook skimming from people's orders: She cooks it up but doesn't put it all in. She puts a big spoonful in a separate little bowl and eats it herself. Another way they're cheating us i guess.

excerpts: Which is how I ended up standing directly in front of the exhaust vent scarfing down veggie chow mien.
up.author: Allyson S.
up.review:
By far my favorite Chinese/Burmese restaurant in the neighborhood. (despite one very bad run in with a pidgin while reading the menu). This is one of those places that at first glace, I would never consider eating at, but some nights when hunger has taken over any coherent thoughts you may have once possessed, it will happen. Which is how I ended up standing directly in front of the exhaust vent scarfing down veggie chow mien. It was the most amazing thing at the time, subtle yet spicy. 

Since then I have been back on a few occasions, both for take out and eat-in. I would recommend both, but only the latter for small parties as the place can only seat 8-9 people max and always has a line.

excerpts: Also, if you're done eating, get your ass up and get out the door because some other hongry fools are waiting to get their grub on!!!
Only 10 seats and a long line out the door every day!!!
up.author: Rex D.
up.review:
5 stars for the OH SO CHEAP price and the quality of the food. The two of us ordered Beef Curry and Mango Chicken with a spring roll appetizer (which is actually a summer roll - cold salad wrapped in rice paper). 

The beef curry was very basic with potatoes and VERY succulent beef pieces. The flavor was perfect, tasty and spicy. My friend's Mango Chicken was white meat chicken stir-fried with fresh mango chunks, bell pepper, sugar snap peas, carrots and onions. He's Venezuelan, so he loved his mango dish, but I really preferred my curry. The spring rolls were actually summer rolls, so we were kinda thrown off when they were served. If you want the real spring rolls, then you should order the egg rolls from the menu. The guy next to us ordered the potsticker appetizer and there were 6 savory, meat filled dumpings on his plate. Next time, I will def try those bad boys!!!

Since there are only 10 or so counter seats, there is always a line to get in. We went late, close to 10pm so there were only 2 people ahead of us in the line to get seated. My friend had gone before, so he knew to order our food while we were standing in line to get seated. So, when we did sit down, our appetizer came right out and our entrees were about 4 minutes behind. 

Now, if you go to restaurants because they are clean and sanitary with exceptional service, then Yamo is not the place for you. This place is one of the grimiest dive restaurants that I've seen outside of Southeast Asia. The 3 older ladies that were working (one cooking, one taking orders / chopping the veggies, one doing the dishes) were working so hard with their tasks that it's hard to get any extra service besides ordering your food and getting your check. If you want water or a soda, you might have to ask each of the ladies twice before you get your drink. In fact, it might be smart to bring your own water or soda so you don't have to worry about asking (bothering) the super hard workin ladies. There is an no alcohol policy so don't try taking in any booze. 

Also, if you're done eating, get your ass up and get out the door because some other hongry fools are waiting to get their grub on!!! Only 10 seats and a long line out the door every day!!!

excerpts: I was a little thrown off at first, but I had so many people recommend Yamo that I couldn't pass it up.
I ordered the house noodles and the pot stickers!
This place is only 4 blocks from my work.
I will be back often!
up.author: Chase L.
up.review: I am from the midwest. We don't really have little hole-in-the-wall restaurants like this place. I was a little thrown off at first, but I had so many people recommend Yamo that I couldn't pass it up. I ordered the house noodles and the pot stickers!  This place is only 4 blocks from my work. I will be back often!

excerpts: The food is great and the atmosphere is really fun, with intense cooking and conversation behind the counter, as your food gets whipped up in a no frills kind of way by the three ladies working there.
Walking in is like being transported to a different time and place, and the food is delicious.
Definitely recommended!
up.author: David B.
up.review: This place is a gem.  It reminds me of some of my favorite establishments in NYC and has so much hole-in-the-wall character.  The food is great and the atmosphere is really fun, with intense cooking and conversation behind the counter, as your food gets whipped up in a no frills kind of way by the three ladies working there.  Walking in is like being transported to a different time and place, and the food is delicious.  Definitely recommended!

excerpts: Pet peeve is that I dislike eating at restuarants that look...well not so sanitary, but I can put up with this one.
For some old school asians, they say the dirtier the place, and the  greasier the food...thats when it tastes the best.
Overall, good food for the price.
up.author: Hubert H.
up.review:
Our first time here and we were taking it out...but BOY! it was confusing! There was just a lot of people(both waiting to be seated or just waiting for their takeout) and the place was small. They should at least have numbers to call out for costumers.
The food was oily, but delicious. Pet peeve is that I dislike eating at restuarants that look...well not so sanitary, but I can put up with this one. For some old school asians, they say the dirtier the place, and the  greasier the food...thats when it tastes the best. 
Overall, good food for the price.

excerpts: Why don't they have ice cubes when asked by customers, instead scooping it up from an iced pitch water?
I guess you get what you pay for.
Will not go there again.
The food is mediocre, and you leave there with a disgusting after smell!
up.author: Megan S.
up.review: The beautiful country of Burma would be disappointed. Why is there trash cans underneath the counter where food is being prepared? Why are they swearing and cursing at one another in front of customers? Why don't they have ice cubes when asked by customers, instead scooping it up from an iced pitch water? I guess you get what you pay for. Will not go there again. The food is mediocre, and you leave there with a disgusting after smell!

excerpts: 3 plates barely fills up 2 people.
$$ might add up since you will be ordering more food because of the small portions.
up.author: Jannifer H.
up.review:
I only thought this place was ok...

Seats only like 8-10 people. Might have to wait long. Better to order takeout. 

I thought the 3 old Chinese ladies working there were really cute. They kind of reminded me of my mom and her friends. Btw i find it interesting how Cantonese speaking ladies were cooking Burmese food. 

Tried the tea leaf salad. That's the only dish I liked so far. 

Tried house noodles and stir fried noodles. They were ok.. Quite oily. Also reminds me of regular Chinese food.

The portions they give you here is quite small. 3 plates barely fills up 2 people. 

The price is ok.. $$ might add up since you will be ordering more food because of the small portions.

excerpts: We ordered over the phone and had our ordered screwed up when we arrived.
Either that or talk very, very slowly when you call.
up.author: Corbin C.
up.review:
My friend recommended this to me and I have to say it's alright. It definitely has its (really) tiny restaurant charm and the prices are very reasonable. However, I felt that the food was just middle of the road. Not bad, not great. 

The Curry Chicken and Mango Chicken were decent. However, this is the first Burmese place I've ever tried so maybe I just don't like the dishes in general.

I would recommend ordering in person. We ordered over the phone and had our ordered screwed up when we arrived. Either that or talk very, very slowly when you call.

excerpts: It may be hard to get their attention at times, but they are fun to watch at work and are friendly with anyone who strikes up a conversation with them.
up.author: Keith C.
up.review:
Yamo is a great place to go for a casual date or by yourself.  Just don't bring an entourage because the place is essentially a hole in the wall that can fit approximately nine people at any given time.  

Food:  4 stars.  I definitely will come back to try more dishes, but thought that the chicken noodle soup was excellent, especially for the price ($5.25, are you out of your mind?).  The soup is a hearty blend of coconut noodle soup with chicken, onions, and cilantro.  it was very flavorful, but don't expect it to be spicy.  The fresh coconut is interesting, but wasn't for me because of the aftertaste.

Service:  4 stars.  Kudos to the charmingly busy yet funny Chinese ladies that work behind the counter.  It may be hard to get their attention at times, but they are fun to watch at work and are friendly with anyone who strikes up a conversation with them.

Atmosphere:  3 stars.  The hole in the wall aspect is a bit charming, but the place is definitely a bit dirty looking.  The crowd can be eccentric at times.  For example, someone waiting in line for a seat started practicing qigong, an internal Chinese meditative practice which uses slow graceful movements similar to tai chi.  

Hits:   Chicken noodle soup.

Misses:  The crowd can be creepy and they're kooky, mysterious and spooky.

If You Like This Place, You'd Probably Like:  Burma Superstar, Rangoon, Nan Yang, Mandalay.

excerpts: For $2.50 they open up a fresh coconut, which you can drink the refreshing water and then scoop out the luscious fresh coconut meat.
up.author: Tigre T.
up.review:
They know you and address you by your name. They remember my favorite dishes. They always welcome all my friends. All dishes are $5.25, large, colorful and great tasting. The tea leave salad, spring rolls are excellent apetizers. They have vegetarian dishes, house noodles, the large bowls of soups are a great and filling treat especially when the fog sets in. It is always busy and intimate...
Their Burmese kitchen is infused with Indian and Thai flavors. For $2.50 they open up a fresh coconut, which you can drink the refreshing water and then scoop out the luscious fresh coconut meat. 





Please read the street parking signs and don't get a ticket or worse get your car towed due to street cleaning while you're enjoying your affordable dinner.  Public Transportation is available  the #33, 49, 14 stop is right there and 16th St BART is two blocks away.

excerpts: and I grew up with homecooked Burmese food.
up.author: Geneva X.
up.review:
All I gotta say is that if you want authentic Burmese food, THIS IS THE PLACE, BABY! 

My whole family is from Burma and I grew up with homecooked Burmese food. Tried it, Love it. 

Get it TO GO because the place is small and seating is competitive.

excerpts: I can see how it can fill up quickly, though.
up.author: Keau K.
up.review:
This is my kind of place.... a total hole in the wall with just a counter to sit at and two ladies cooking hot fresh food. Amazing! This is the reason why I live in a city like San Francisco.

Yamo is a great take out option, and I  love it since it's a great Asian option that's close to my house. 

I've only been here once, and it was on a Monday afternoon so the place was empty. I can see how it can fill up quickly, though.

I had the tea leaf salad, house noodles with chicken and mango chicken. The tea leaf salad and mango chicken were great, but the house noodles weren't anything special. I will definitely be going back to check out the rest of the menu.

excerpts:
We ended up with:

Samosas - $3.50, This was actually the spiciest thing I had that night!
up.author: Julia T.
up.review:
3.5 stars. My friend and I were semi-wandering around the Mission looking for dinner since I already had a motive to try Yamo... When we were close, I excitedly said "ooo let's have some Burmese!" I'm slick like that. ;) As we approached the place, we realized it was probably cash only and I only had $3 in my wallet! Good thing there was an ATM close by. We were also lucky that someone seated by the only empty seat was leaving! We secured our spots and looked over the (VERY grimy) menu. The waitress if you'd like to call her that was very friendly and was patient with our indecisiveness. We ended up with:

Samosas - $3.50, This was actually the spiciest thing I had that night! It's fried right in front of you so it comes out fresh and hot. It's made with some kind of yam and spices but I honestly couldn't taste much because my tongue was in pain! 

Tea Salad - $5.25, It's cheaper but smaller than the ones you'd find in the Richmond District. It's also spicier. The ingredients weren't as colorful and fresh looking as I'm used to. I prefer more of the nutty taste so I was hoping for more sunflower seeds and peanuts. I'd probably skip this one next time.

Fresh Coconut Juice - $2.50, Pretty sure everyone has had one of these but that doesn't make it any less tasty! It's a real, young coconut with the top cut off served with a straw and a spoon so you can dig into the coconut meat after you finish the juice. I say it's way worth it since you could pay that much just for a coconut at the market. I'm also too afraid of trying this at home again. Coconut shells are like rocks!

Mango Chicken - $5.25, with your choice of house noodles or white rice. I got the noodles and they were quite tasty! They were eggy and chewy in the good way. My friend was surprised they had real mango chunks and they were big too! This dish also came with green peppers, bits of chili peppers (so more spice!) and big flavorful chicken chunks. It was good but this dish was also a bit greasy. 

I'm not a fan of spicy food, though I'm getting more tolerable. It helps when all your friends like spice and INSIST that THIS THE TIME I'm going to start liking it. Nope never happened. I still thought Yamo was above average but I wouldn't go out of my way to come back.

excerpts: My boyfriend just ended up eating all the chicken and left everything else which is surprising because he is a huge fan of noodles.
My chicken noodle soup was mediocre also.
The coconut soup was really light and it was actually pretty boring to eat after a couple bites.
We left unsatisfied and with terribly rude customer service.
up.author: Syd T.
up.review:
I came here upon a friend's recommendation. He raved about this place saying it had the best chicken noodle soup and warned me that it was a hole in the wall place. 

When I got here, I realized that I can now say that I literally have been to a hole in the wall restaurant. The seating area is a bar right in front of their kitchen and prep area, so you feel all the heat and oil on you as you wait and eat. You have to wait in line and then grab a seat whenever someone leaves. When we sat down, I waited 5 minutes before asking one of the 3 ladies for a menu. She rudely threw it at us. We decided to order the cold noodles, chicken noodle soup, tea leaf salad, and spring rolls. The spring rolls were given to us with plates and utensils rudely thrown at us after. They were okay and the sauce was interesting. The tea leaf salad was really interesting and quite tasty & spicy. The cold noodles were spicy and was not good at all. My boyfriend just ended up eating all the chicken and left everything else which is surprising because he is a huge fan of noodles. My chicken noodle soup was mediocre also. The coconut soup was really light and it was actually pretty boring to eat after a couple bites. We left unsatisfied and with terribly rude customer service.

excerpts: A unique experience with 3 little Burmese ladies staffing the "kitchen" behind the bar top and cook up simple burmese/chinese grub.
The house noodles with chicken stole the show and only $6.
The potstickers were plump and crispy on the outside.
up.author: Adrian S.
up.review: This place kicks ass. There's like 8 stools on a bar top or you can get take out. Waited 10-15 mins for seats and totally worth it. A unique experience with 3 little Burmese ladies staffing the "kitchen" behind the bar top and cook up simple burmese/chinese grub. The house noodles with chicken stole the show and only $6. The potstickers were plump and crispy on the outside. Samusas were filled with potato and curry and were just ok. The prawn & veggie curry had a deep sweet and sour colored sauce, with a light curry hint...delicious. We each took an order of house noodles to go after our meal and it was still only $32. Will be back for sure.

excerpts: Most people call in to order, then walk over in 10-15 mins to pick it up.
It's just not comfortable to eat there.
up.author: C L.
up.review:
So-so Burmese food, but über greasy

Combined review from two visits.

DISHES:
Tea leaf salad
$6
It looked like a small wad of spicy salad toppings. Was there suppose to be lettuce or greens in it? If so, the ladies forgot that part. Everything was heavily fried, and I couldn't discern the tea leaves. All I tasted was fried garlic and crunchiness that oozed oil.

House noodles with chicken
$6
Noodles are thick chow mein noodles like those in the Shanghai fried noodle dish. Chicken was fine, not dry for slices of white meat. Also had onion, but not much else. So oily... 

Mango chicken
$6
Nicely cooked chicken slices, some chucks of mango paired with rice. Pretty spicy, but not detracting from the dish. This seemed less greasy than the other dishes


AMBIANCE: Hole in the wall with Chinese-speaking ladies, quickly taking orders and cooking in parallel. Limited stool seating facing them. Most people call in to order, then walk over in 10-15 mins to pick it up. It's just not comfortable to eat there. I bet it gets miserably hot during warm weather too.

SERVICE: So-so. It's slightly confusing to order, because you have to flag down a lady. Feels like placing an order at a bar, getting the bartender's attention over people seated at the bar.

VISIT DETAILS: Take-out dinner with a friend most recent time, seat-down the previous time (probably took 20-30 mins wait to get two seats during dinner time)

excerpts: I love their noodles and curries, and my mom (who grew up in Burma) says their Catfish Chowder is some of the best she's tasted since she moved to the States...
up.author: Lucinda W.
up.review:
It's not the classiest joint, or the quietest, but the food is sooo yummy you'll want to keep coming back despite any other deterrents.  I love their noodles and curries, and my mom (who grew up in Burma) says their Catfish Chowder is some of the best she's tasted since she moved to the States...

In summary: really delicious Burmese food.  I'm sold.

excerpts: The door opens up into a narrow "hall" that is only wide enough to let one person (I'm talking about a size10 max person... well below the US weight/size average of 163lbs/size14) to squeeze past, bounded by a wall on the right, and a narrow counter top/seats lining the left.

Three Burmese ladies man the kitchen space, which is immediately behind the counter: One is in charge of all wok related cooking, one takes orders and prepares ingredients for the wok lady, and the last one takes orders and cleans up after patrons.
You wait for a spot to open up, order your food from a limited (but extremely cheap) menu, watch your food being cooked, chow down, pay the bill, and leave.
I highly doubt that it is authentic Burmese food... it tastes very Chinese to me.
However, it IS very much homestyle cooking, which is nice, especially since nothing costs over $6.
Pictured below is the "Yamo noodles"... regarded quite highly on yelp, but turned out to be a bit of a bland disappointment.
If I lived in the Mission, I would probably return to Yamo for it's cheap and easy eats.
up.author: Susanna W.
up.review:
Literally a hole in the wall "Burmese" eatery. The door opens up into a narrow "hall" that is only wide enough to let one person (I'm talking about a size10 max person... well below the US weight/size average of 163lbs/size14) to squeeze past, bounded by a wall on the right, and a narrow counter top/seats lining the left. Three Burmese ladies man the kitchen space, which is immediately behind the counter: One is in charge of all wok related cooking, one takes orders and prepares ingredients for the wok lady, and the last one takes orders and cleans up after patrons.

Yamo is very simple and straight forward. You wait for a spot to open up, order your food from a limited (but extremely cheap) menu, watch your food being cooked, chow down, pay the bill, and leave. I highly doubt that it is authentic Burmese food... it tastes very Chinese to me. However, it IS very much homestyle cooking, which is nice, especially since nothing costs over $6. Pictured below is the "Yamo noodles"... regarded quite highly on yelp, but turned out to be a bit of a bland disappointment. If I lived in the Mission, I would probably return to Yamo for it's cheap and easy eats.

excerpts: Don't be too intimidated by the gruff, unsmiling trio of ladies that whip up the food in no time.
Yamo is a no frills, good eats at a good price, type of place.
You could tell that by the number of broke looking, trust fund Mission hipsters that pick up their to-go orders.
Time it right
and you can find one of ten seats in the place.
We happened to go on a weekday around 12:15.
I guess everyone waited to avoid the lunch crowd.
Sucks for them b/c they all showed up at 1pm!
up.author: Erick K.
up.review:
Don't worry about the divey appearance or the fact that a soccer team would have trouble getting seating.  Don't be too intimidated by the gruff, unsmiling trio of ladies that whip up the food in no time. Yamo is a no frills, good eats at a good price, type of place. You could tell that by the number of broke looking, trust fund Mission hipsters that pick up their to-go orders.  Time it right and you can find one of ten seats in the place.  We happened to go on a weekday around 12:15. I guess everyone waited to avoid the lunch crowd. Sucks for them b/c they all showed up at 1pm! 

As for the food, it's all about the house noodles. I tried the pork (good, but the beef looked like it had that glazed, salty, saucy appearance I always crave) and my friend asked for the noodles and tofu (not on menu). The noodles are perfectly cooked and textured from wherever they bought them (I assume - they were uniformly piled in stacked bowls). The resulting broth/gravy/sauce that hits the bottom is heaven's nectar.  Watch the cook seamlessly mix the dozen or so ingredients (topped by some fried garlic flakes! Yow!). Just don't look too closely if you're paranoid about Health Department scores (I don't recall seeing one...). Let's put it this way: it was good food, at a great-for-SF price, I didn't get sick, and I enjoyed the experience.

excerpts: Quick, tasty and wildly entertaining with tiny long cramped bar seating and bustling women with flaming frypans who'll serve you up a fresh coconut with an unimpressed attitude.
up.author: Hemmie L.
up.review: I love this place! it doesn't try to be anything that it's not. Quick, tasty and wildly entertaining with tiny long cramped bar seating and bustling women with flaming frypans who'll serve you up a fresh coconut with an unimpressed attitude.

excerpts: Yamo be there...up and over" (random Michael McDonald reference...always wanted to quote him on Yelp!)
up.author: Susan L.
up.review:
"Yamo be there...up and over" (random Michael McDonald reference...always wanted to quote him on Yelp!)

I may have found a time that Yamo isn't AS crowded as usual...Tuesday night at 5:45...when its raining...and BART is having service issues...and the stars are perfectly aligned...

Yes, Yelpers love this place.  Its cheap.  The food is amazing.  Tealeaf salad. House noodles.  Done and done.  

Don't come if you're claustrophopic, get sketched out by a poorly lit closet masquerading as a kitchen, expecting stellar service, unwilling to wait, want a place to have long drawn-out conversations with friends.  

Grab your food, scarf it down, and go...make room for the rest of us...

(minus 1 star for the 36-hour heartburn afterwards...so worth it...)

excerpts: (You can also order fresh coconut drink, which they will cut up open for you on the spot!)
The mango chicken with rice was very good.
It didn't feel heavy in your stomach and the vegetables were pretty fresh.
up.author: Faye F.
up.review:
3.5 stars

I stumbled upon this restaurant when I was blog surfing. This past weekend, my boyfriend and I ventured down mission to find this hole in the wall. The food is absolutely delicious but you WILL have to wait awhile (depending on the number of cooks working and the line of customers) for it. When we arrived, there were 3 female cooks working their butts off for a small line. The place itself can hold maybe 10 sitting customers and the rest order to go. There's no order when serving their customers and it seemed like it's easy for them to forget your order, especially when there's a long line of customers. 

Anyway, my boyfriend and I hadn't eaten all day and we ordered the tea salad, mango chicken, and yamo house noodles with chicken. (You can also order fresh coconut drink, which they will cut up open for you on the spot!) The mango chicken with rice was very good. It didn't feel heavy in your stomach and the vegetables were pretty fresh. My favorite was the tea salad. I didn't see them make it but I think they have this mixture of nuts or something that goes really well with the salad. The house noodles were super garlicky and it was good! 

This is a good place to eat if you have a lot of patience waiting for food but I suggest not to go during lunch rush.

excerpts: Save yourself a headache and call ahead with your order for pick-up.
Come in 30 minutes versus the 15 minutes they tell you, pick up the yummy, sesame oil-drenched noodle goodness and eat from the comforts of your home.
You will be much happier if you do.
up.author: Adrienne C.
up.review:
Yamo house noodles w/beef. For $5.25. Seriously. That's all you need to know.

Also...curry chicken, potstickers and samusas....YUMYUMYUM.

It's tiny, the wait is forever and there is no parking. Save yourself a headache and call ahead with your order for pick-up. Come in 30 minutes versus the 15 minutes they tell you, pick up the yummy, sesame oil-drenched noodle goodness and eat from the comforts of your home. You will be much happier if you do.

excerpts: C'mon, my grandma can cook up better food than this joint

Great place to rub elbows with strangers, profess your love of cock sauce to the whole table, watch the women behind the counter cook up a fire and hear them yell in Cantonese (not Burmese as someone else stated) about how the bills are all mixed up.
up.author: Emily Y.
up.review:
What is wrong with you people?! Four stars?! C'mon, my grandma can cook up better food than this joint and she's not even that great! 

Came here with my boy toy and lucky us we didn't have to wait for 2 out of the 8 seats there total. This is truly a hole in the wall eatery. I love it! Great place to rub elbows with strangers, profess your love of cock sauce to the whole table, watch the women behind the counter cook up a fire and hear them yell in Cantonese (not Burmese as someone else stated) about how the bills are all mixed up. 

The lady recommended we get the mango chicken. A MISTAKE! Everyone knows that one of the basic rules in cooking is to season the food. What I got was a plate of uber blandness. At least the chicken was tender. I was tempted to pour soy sauce all over my dish and mind you, I rarely do such a foolish thing. 
Where was the spice in our spicy curry tofu?! Where was that rich, the extra kick in flavor that usually accompanies curry? It wasn't there. It was all forgettable. Took me almost an hour to even remember what we ordered...
The only good thing that I got out of it was how I paid under $15 for the entire bill. If you're solely looking for a cheap-eat place, this is it. If you're looking for real 'Asian' cuisine, try some place else. 

I'm a believer in second chances, I might give this place another shot and try their fish soup as someone else mentioned...

excerpts: I suggest calling ahead for pick up.

This tiny place gets packed
and the wait can be upwards of 20 minutes.

Any of the above items
are great for takeout.

But while all of the curry noodle dishes
are great eaten in the restaurant, but sometimes they lack enough
sauce and can be on the dry side when ordered to go. . .
up.author: Kia B.
up.review:
I'm such a fan of this place.
It's like a  on-again-off-again lover you keep 
them on the DL for a bit. Sometimes you swear off
carbs, or cut back on extra fats,
But  you always come back for more.
They know exactly what you like and you're never disappointed.
It's a little messy sometimes, maybe even greasy but you always 
leave satiated. The saucy ladies that run the place, take their 
time to come to you  they yell at each other and maybe even 
at the customers. No harm intended, just the way it is, as if they 
are yelling at children in their living room. And that's exactly how it 
feels, like you are sitting in the living room at the house of your 
Burmese auntie waiting for a home cooked meal. 
My faves:
tea leaf salad(spicy sour/salty goodness)
catfish chowder(spicy, brothy yum)
curry fish w/rice(yummy, yum,yum)

I suggest calling ahead for pick up. This tiny place gets packed
and the wait can be upwards of 20 minutes. Any of the above items
are great for takeout. But while all of the curry noodle dishes
are great eaten in the restaurant, but sometimes they lack enough
sauce and can be on the dry side when ordered to go. . .

excerpts: I actually had to add soy sauce to punch up the flavor, and I'm not one of these salt monsters that have to add salt to everything, often even before they take a first bite.
It just wasn't that impressive.
A+ ambience though.
You may call it smoky, cramped, and a little bit dirty, but that, friends, was my favorite part.
up.author: Elise T.
up.review: Not sure what all the hype is about. Yes, the prices are amazing ($6 for a square meal in the city, whaaat.) Yes, it has that tiny, grungy vibe of a cool, under-the-radar spot in New York. Yes, it has the requisite grouchy proprietors (all the cool places do.) But the bottom line is, the food wasn't great. I had the house noodles with beef, and my bf had the mango chicken and tea leaf salad. The only above average part of our meals was the beef in the noodle dish. It was perfectly seasoned and shockingly tender. But the noodles themselves were too soft and not very flavorful--like overcooked instant ramen before you add in the flavor packet. I actually had to add soy sauce to punch up the flavor, and I'm not one of these salt monsters that have to add salt to everything, often even before they take a first bite. It just wasn't that impressive.  A+ ambience though. You may call it smoky, cramped, and a little bit dirty, but that, friends, was my favorite part.

excerpts: I passed by it about 4 times expecting a restaurant to show up before I realized that the 10 stools at the counter was the extent of it.
up.author: Nick H.
up.review:
What a great little hole in the wall! I passed by it about 4 times expecting a restaurant to show up before I realized that the 10 stools at the counter was the extent of it. 

The food is pretty good and fresh, but not amazing. What is amazing is the fact that lunch for two including 2 appetizers came out to $21 after a good tip!

excerpts: The windows of the door are posted up with newspaper clippings and awards.
In the back is a little crevice with a wooden ladder leading up to who knows where.
One regular refrigerator sits in the corner and another window refrigerator sits across from the counter.
It's a very basic eating experience that is perfect for a quick eat; however, not for the wheelchair bound, children, dog owners, or people who can't sit up on bar stools.
They said that a sign was supposed to be put up during winter break but the "guy" didn't come around.
Regular customers don't want the sign to go up so they can have the place all to themselves.
Selfish pigs!
up.author: Michael H.
up.review:
Discovered this place while listening to NPR with Broke-Ass Stuart S. talking about the best places to eat.  Cheap?  Good eats?  I'm there.

Trying to find Yamo is like trying to find a door into the fourth dimension.  You walk to the correct cross section.  Peer out for any signs.  Circle around in place.  Finally you head back to the starting place assuming that you just missed it.  Then you ask yourself, "Does this place even exist?"

As I stood scratching my head in confusion I peered at a little craggily black storefront that looks to be condemned.  The windows of the door are posted up with newspaper clippings and awards.  Oh wait, I found it!

After observing the business hours, I entered Yamo with curious eyes.  Just how "hole in the wall" is this place?  Well on a meter of 10 it's probably an 8.  I've been to worse but this isn't Gary Danko's.

The restaurant is essentially one part long counter with bar stools, one part open kitchen -- that's it.  In the back is a little crevice with a wooden ladder leading up to who knows where.  One regular refrigerator sits in the corner and another window refrigerator sits across from the counter.  It's a very basic eating experience that is perfect for a quick eat; however, not for the wheelchair bound, children, dog owners, or people who can't sit up on bar stools.

I was the only customer here yet it was a quite loud.  The refrigerator or something made a long thumping sound and stopped after awhile.  The two ladies talk to each other in yelling pitch cantonese.  It's kinda funny how loud this place is after you get used to it.

I asked for a recommendation and the lady advise me to have the "Cold Noodles".  The dish is like a spicy noodle salad served with temperature hot chicken.  It also has spring onion, cilantro, cucumber, carrots, and bean sprouts.  The dish isn't as fire hot as I expected yet it was just spicy enough that I could still taste my food while getting a kick.  Even so, if you don't like spicy food don't get this dish as my nose started to run profusely and I needed to resort to my can of 7-Up constantly.  Portions are just right.  I wasn't too stuffed but rather on the verge of being so.

Talking to the staff was fun.  They're really friendly and open for chit chat.  They said that a sign was supposed to be put up during winter break but the "guy" didn't come around.  Regular customers don't want the sign to go up so they can have the place all to themselves.  Selfish pigs! lol

My dish was really good but not out of the ballpark great.  It tastes like good ol' home cooking, nothing wrong with that.  I think I've only had Burmese food a couple other times so it was good finding another place.  The staff recommends the soup and curries as some of their most popular dishes.  I asked myself, "Then why am I eating 'cold noodles'?"

___

I'd definitely come back to try out more of the fairly priced menu.

excerpts: What's up with the lemming hipsters???
up.author: Aaron N.
up.review:
Seriously? What's up with the lemming hipsters??? Though claiming to be Burmese, this is basically greasy Chinese food at its worst. 

Yeah, it's cheap, yeah it's got character (it's really popular with the hipsters).  But for those of us who like to enjoy tasting good food, I cannot recommend this restaurant. Pay a few bucks more at another Burmese restaurant and get 100% better food. 

We tried a few dishes that people recommended to get a broad sampling. All were awful. As a friend of mine joked: "they use seven spices and they're all salt and pepper."

excerpts: My house noodles were sort of bland but perked up when I added some hot sauce.
The cooks were generally inattentive and the service was fairly slow.
up.author: Daniel M.
up.review:
Came here last Saturday because my girlfriend wanted to try it. It's just a few blocks from the BART station but we had to walk through a pretty dirty and smelly portion of the Mission. I'm not sure I would have found it if I hadn't seen a picture of it before we came. Anyway, we arrived around 3pm and didn't have trouble finding a couple stools at the bar (there's only 10). 

Ordered the tea salad, mango chicken and Yamo house noodles with chicken. The tea salad was the standout of the three dishes. Nutty and crunchy. My house noodles were sort of bland but perked up when I added some hot sauce. The cooks were generally inattentive and the service was fairly slow. But you can't beat the $5.25 price for entrees!

Summary: 3.5/5 stars rounded down
+Tea salad
+Price
-Slow service
-Limited seating

excerpts: Each bite packs a punch, so don't be surprised if you start tearing up.
up.author: Connie C.
up.review:
Yamo is the hole in the hole in the wall. Yes, it's so small you'll probably miss it if you blink. Nicole and I probably walked a good 2 blocks past it when we were trying to go there.

It's greasy, spicy, probably high in fat and cholesterol Burmese fast food, but it's yummy! The ladies that work there speak little English, and the cheap menu is no nonsense. If you can score one of the 8 seats at the counter, enjoy watching them prepare your food in minutes. Call ahead for take-out in case the place is packed. 

I had the Yamo house noodles with chicken and had some of the tea leaf salad. Each bite packs a punch, so don't be surprised if you start tearing up.

excerpts: They only have about 6 stools at the counter to sit and you get to watch them cook up some delicious-ness.
up.author: Andrea F.
up.review:
Me amo Yamo.

A friend took me here yesterday and I fell in love.  
We walked in around 4pm on a Monday and magically there were 2 seats waiting for us.
It's a cute little hole in the wall with awesome red walls run by some crazy, crazy hard-working women yelling at each other about something.  (I'm convinced they were talking shit about me, but ya know....)

They only have about 6 stools at the counter to sit and you get to watch them cook up some delicious-ness.
We had the spring rolls, samusas, mango chicken, some delicious crunchy salad thing, and 2 bottles of bottled coke. (HELLS YES for bottled Mexican coke which always tastes like heaven!)
We only spent $20 on everything.  Great portions, great prices, great atmosphere.  AWESOME.

I would definitely come back here and hope that those 2 vinyl stools are waiting for me next time.

excerpts: I am all for cheap too, now that I have proverbially shoved it up the mans ass and gone for a more rewarding non-profit gig.
That is why I am giving this place 3 stars.
Price x Quality/Competition = Rating.
Damn, I am, like, some sort of Einstein or something.
But lets not get crazy here kids.
up.author: Drue C.
up.review:
This place has the same yelp rating at Mandalay? Bitch, puuuullllleeeease!!!! Are you people so cheap that you cannot see past the price to the quality of the food? 

Sure, its cheap eats. Yippee. I am all for cheap too, now that I have proverbially shoved it up the mans ass and gone for a more rewarding non-profit gig.  That is why I am giving this place 3 stars. Price x Quality/Competition = Rating. Damn, I am, like, some sort of Einstein or something. But lets not get crazy here kids. The food, though a great value for the money, is by no means 5 star cuisine.

Lets examine this a bit, shall we? The place is referred to as a Chinese/Burmese diner, yet the OWNERS have printed on their menu "Thai Kitchen"? If that ain't a sign of some good home cooked ethnic confusion I don't know what is!! 

The narrow space with the 8 seat counter does not even allow you to walk behind someone without knocking into them, and forget about just stepping in to place a to go order. You could walk out violated, but, hey, if you are into that well hee haw!! 

I don't know what the hell I am saying here. I am preaching to an audience who gave the Bacon Dog Cart one of the top marks of this site for weeks on end. Let me rewrite this review.......

Go here, you will love it!!

excerpts: Walk up to order to go or wait in line until a spot opens up at the counter.
up.author: Stacey J.
up.review:
Yamo is the kind of place that I don't want to review, because I don't want anyone else coming here!

I LOVE Yamo. It's a funky little no nonsense place with nothing but a counter that seats about 10 people. Walk up to order to go or wait in line until a spot opens up at the counter. 

Food is amazing, and I'd pick Yamo over Burma Superstar any day. My boyfriend and I always order the house noodles with beef (always beef, it's garlicky and AMAZING), tea leaf salad (crunchy, spicy delicousness), and samusas. Nothing on the menu is over $5.25, so our bill is never more than $20 for two people.

Minus one star just because there's not much customer service. The little ladies that work here are cute, but they're always barking at each other behind the counter, don't ever really make eye contact with customers, and almost always forget to bring me my beverage. Interior is funky, not terribly clean and cluttered behind the counter. I like that though, it gives it more character.

In sum, Yamo rules, but don't come here because I don't want to wait in line behind you.

excerpts: I'm pretty woozy while the bus is leaving the Richmond, but I somehow wake up by the time I hit the Mission.
I went home, looked Yamo up to see what kinda food it served and went there one day after work armed with tips I got from fellow Yelpers.
My bf and I showed up on a Wednesday at around 5pm, the place was empty and the Yamo ladies were still prepping for the dinner crowd.
After a few minutes of sitting around and feeling awkward, food just started showing up in front of us.
, they'll know what's up.
I'm bumping this up to 5 stars because I've had 4 more dishes from here
and it's really the fricken bomb!
up.author: Faffy L.
up.review:
Every morning, I board the 33 and sit on the left side of the back of the bus. I'm pretty woozy while the bus is leaving the Richmond, but I somehow wake up by the time I hit the Mission. I've seen Yamo and their red awning with fancy disco type (I think a designerd fan donated some graphic design skillz to this joint) through the window a bunch of times, but I never figured out what the hell it was until a month ago, when I squinted really hard and saw people sitting at the counter eatin' one afternoon.

I went home, looked Yamo up to see what kinda food it served and went there one day after work armed with tips I got from fellow Yelpers.

My bf and I showed up on a Wednesday at around 5pm, the place was empty and the Yamo ladies were still prepping for the dinner crowd. We sat down at the counter, and quickly decided what we wanted: samosas, tea salad, house noodles with chicken.

After a few minutes of sitting around and feeling awkward, food just started showing up in front of us. 

Samosas: Careful! Might burn your mouth!! Light and crispy is right, but the flavor is good, but not really special or anything. OH! They give you like 8pcs, so even 3-4 people can share.

Tea Salad: Yum! Definitely on par, if not better than anything that Burma Stupidstar serves. They can easily slap this on a fancy plate and charge $15 for it.

House Noodles: I was anticipating more of a garlicky flavor, but it was very tasty anyway. The chicken is well marinated and the cold onions/cucumbers you get is great to balance out the grease.

Going to Yamo totally feels like barging into a neighbor's house and just sitting down and getting fed, sans the southern hospitality. The Yamo women are tough and can't be bothered. One of them reminds me of my grandma. If you are ready for the bill, don't sit there and ask for it. Pack yo bags and head to the register, they'll know what's up.

Our bill with a drink was maybe just like $15.

I don't think you need to be THAAT adventurous of a eater to go there. It's not like they serve rabbits or anything, ya know what I mean?? Even if they do, I'd definitely go back. =D

(Originally) 4.5 stars!

5/23/07 I'm bumping this up to 5 stars because I've had 4 more dishes from here and it's really the fricken bomb!

excerpts: The other dishes was not as flavorful as the salad though and ended up tasting a little bland because I started with the salad.
up.author: Natalie S.
up.review:
Teensy tiny and you can walk right by it on 18th without even noticing that you have passed it. However, when seeing people peering inside the screened window and waiting, you know you are there.  There are like 9 seats at the bar which faces the open kitchen. FYI, I was inside for 5 minutes and I could smell the food on me.  I got it to go and avoided more food smells in the clothing seepage. The prices are incredibly reasonable, $5.25 for most dishes! 

The tea leaf salad was very flavorful. The stir fry and curry dishes come with rice on the side. The other dishes was not as flavorful as the salad though and ended up tasting a little bland because I started with the salad. Maybe I need to ask for extra spicy Rangoon style next time.

They pack the food in a nice little container to go and it was prepared really quickly so at this price, I highly recommend it if you're in the mood for getting quick Asian food to go in the mission. I've always been a fan of Burmese food after trying Burma Superstar (which continues to be my favorite Burmese restaurant). But now that I've tried 2 good Burmese restaurants, I can say conclusively that I like Burmese people. Go Burma!

excerpts: Waits are long, usually up to 1.5 hours.
If your not a fan of Valencia St. Hipsters being ironic by eating $6 noodles while wearing $50 t shirts - don't eat here or get your food to go and take it to the park.
This place is over run with Hipsters.
up.author: Raf A.
up.review:
Positive: good cheap Chinese Burmese food. My favorites are the imperial rolls, Garlic Noodles with Chicken, the Samosas and the fresh coconuts. A bowl of noodles with chicken and a coconut will only set you back about $10 with a tip. 

Negative: The place is small, actually a dive/hole in the wall - Literally. they can only seat 10 maybe 12 at their counter. Waits are long, usually up to 1.5 hours. If your not a fan of Valencia St. Hipsters being ironic by eating $6 noodles while wearing $50 t shirts - don't eat here or get your food to go and take it to the park. This place is over run with Hipsters.

excerpts:
Tea Leaf Salad

Call ahead and pick up your order
Service is slow, but you can't get mad at the 3 little ladies working in their limited amount of space while chopping and cooking up fresh ingredients two feet in front of you!
Your patience will be rewarded with yummy food for $5.25!
Oh, and if you do get a seat at the counter, be prepared to smell afterwards, but not as bad as Korean BBQ!
up.author: Linda C.
up.review:
HOLE IN THE WALL GOODNESS!!!

Favorites:
- Yamo House Noodles
- House Special Fried Rice
- Tea Leaf Salad

Call ahead and pick up your order because chances are, you won't be able to get one of the 8 seats at the counter. Service is slow, but you can't get mad at the 3 little ladies working in their limited amount of space while chopping and cooking up fresh ingredients two feet in front of you! Your patience will be rewarded with yummy food for $5.25! Oh, and if you do get a seat at the counter, be prepared to smell afterwards, but not as bad as Korean BBQ!

excerpts: It is super small--either expect to wait or come early or late or as I do pick up and take home (prefer eating my order at home to enjoy with beer or wine).
No beer or wine license and strict warning about bringing your own.
Very spice and the potatoes pick up the flavor of the spicing quite well and together don't become a filler but a great accompaniment.
up.author: Jaime Patricio M.
up.review:
Yamo is a good place for a lot of food that is quite easy on the wallet.
This tiny counter sitting is compelling in the restaurant experience that you may be seeking.   It is super small--either expect to wait or come early or late or as I do pick up and take home (prefer eating my order at home to enjoy with beer or wine).  No beer or wine license and strict warning about bringing your own.  It could be a perfectly sunny day and yet inside it is dark and reddish.

I am fascinated by the three cooks working what seems to be nearly effortless work but upon closer inspection is a careful and learned way of cooking.  This must be brutal work--cooking and waiting all at the same time.  It looks like it must be super hot with the gas burner cooking all day.  

I enjoy the curry chicken--Burmese style--hence no coconut milk or tomatoe or cream.  Very spice and the potatoes pick up the flavor of the spicing quite well and together don't become a filler but a great accompaniment.

So when you think this might be a Burma Superstar Jr. it isn't but presents a much simpler fare.  I do like coming here for  inexpensive takeout but for several reasons it is not my destination restaurant to bring family and friends.  A great place to watch an amazingly orchestrated cooking experience.

excerpts: You eat your food while watching three little old ladies whipping up dishes for fellows patrons and the smoke rise and fill the poorly ventilated space.
You might consider making today laundry day because you will definitely leave smelling a little too tasty for your own good.
up.author: Vrushali P.
up.review: Eating at Yamo is quite the experience. It is everything you dream of for a hole in the wall place. A tiny restaurant on 18th street with about 6 boor stools and one counter top, if you are lucky enough to get a seat, grab it! Inside, you are greeted with the slipping of some paper place mats and chopsticks on your little section of the counter and handed oddly sticky and greasy menus from which to make your selection of food items. You might order the popular tea leaf salad, samusas, some curry, or whatever else you fancy. What you get is appropriately greasy, appropriately delicious, and the perfect quantity for cheap. You eat your food while watching three little old ladies whipping up dishes for fellows patrons and the smoke rise and fill the poorly ventilated space. You might consider making today laundry day because you will definitely leave smelling a little too tasty for your own good.

excerpts: What the place lacks in style it makes up for in character and authenticity.
up.author: Joshua S.
up.review: Great to have an inexpensive, vegetable-filled alternative to Mexican fare close to home. What the place lacks in style it makes up for in character and authenticity.

excerpts: Noodle dishes are slightly smaller than filling, but the rice plates are better portions and will fill you up.
- Service is ehhh...
The ladies will yell at you for your orders.
If you're willing to compromise less service for cheap dishes.
Here's your place.
up.author: S c.
up.review:
Went to dinner around 7:30PM on a Friday night 

- Very Hipster-y, the holey-ist of all walls 
- Seems to always have wait, so allocate an extra 20 minutes to your meals
- Prices are cheap. 6.00 for entrees and 4-something for appetizers 
- The place is crammed in there and slightly grimey, so prepare yourself to be knocking elbows when eating
- Food comes fast, but you should also eat fast and not linger for conversation because people are waiting
- Portions are the usual.  Noodle dishes are slightly smaller than filling, but the rice plates are better portions and will fill you up. 
- Service is ehhh... The ladies will yell at you for your orders.  If you're willing to compromise less service for cheap dishes.  Here's your place.  Don't expect so much as a smile. 

Recommendations: Chicken Noodle Soup (Warms the soul.  Not the boring soup out of a can. Real tasty).

excerpts: No need to get all dolled up for this place..=
up.author: tramy n.
up.review:
Literally a hole in the wall.  
My New Fav. hole in the wall.. Everything is fresh, make in front of you... The line if pretty long, but its worth the wait.. No need to get all dolled up for this place..=)

All you need to know is Yamo house noodles w/beef. For $5.25. Seriously and fresh coconut juice... 
I can eat here morning , noon and night..

excerpts: Up-side: at least I won't have to moisturize or use conditioner for the next week.
I have enough oil on me for the EPA to send out auditors.
up.author: Mortiche W.
up.review:
The safety training officer said, "Always trust your instincts- they are right 99.9% of the time." Damn right he was. When I walked in here the first thought in my mind was, "Hello Susie's on 7th and Townsend!" Susie's is a greasy spoon cafe run by two Chinese women. You SMELL like grease even if you just poke your head inside for 2 seconds. 

Undaunted and confident that my Yelpers wouldn't lead me wrong I orderd two standards- tea leaf salad and the cold noodles with chicken. 15 minutes the little lady behind the counter said. 

I stood just inside the door secretly wishing I could prop it open, and watched as the two ladies ran a bumbling and inefficient orchestra of food preparation. One would do something- i'm not quite sure what, but it wasn't very purposeful- causing the other to fall behind on whatever she was doing. One was fishing out some fried egg rolls from the fryer and the other mumbled to her that she should get my order finished and out the door since I had been there for more than 15 minutes and my food had been sitting in it's containers for at least 5, waiting for lids. 

I managed to escape the grease pit and drove back to work with my windows all the way down the entire way, trying to shake off the lingering tell-tale scent of a greasy spoon joint; much like a hooker's cheap perfume marking a travelling business man's shirt.

So how was it? The tea salad was a heap of disappointment. Highly salty and spicy hot, it contained a TON of little fried crunchy things. Fried onions, fried garlic, fried pumpkin seeds, fried lentils, fried batter bits; you get the picture? Oh, it had a small amount of shredded cabbage too, thinly sliced red onion, peanuts, sesame seeds and trace amounts of green onion, but by far the prevailing theme here was oil and drenching things in them. The crowning glory was that it was toped with cilantro. Shoot me now.

Deciding I had enough disappointment/torture, I moved on to the cold noodles with chicken, and this was an odd dish because given the name, one might be led to believe that the dish is actually cold. Oh, no my friend. This it is not. The chicken was cooked in a mildly spicy chili/onion oil/sauce. Have I mentioned the oily mess yet? If I didn't twirl the noodles perfectly, it would flick oil. Onto my face, my clothes, my desk. It was like noodle oil bukkake. Not only was I smothered in it from the inside out, but now I'm being bathed in it too. 

After a few more bites of coating my arterial walls, I claimed surrender and put a lid on the offending meal. I felt as if I had cooking oil poured over me, and have had an uncontrollable desire to take a long, hot showers with industrial strength Dawn since then. Just because a place is inexpensive, doesn't mean it needs to be greasy.

Up-side: at least I won't have to moisturize or use conditioner for the next week. I have enough oil on me for the EPA to send out auditors. Exxon-Valdez ain't got nothin' on me.

Instinct says: Don't trust good Burmese cuisine to come from a place that smells NOT like cooking and food, but of grease, run by two Chinese women.

excerpts: I had to eat before I met up with my friend
and I'm glad I did.
I was suppose to eat at Sycamore but my body told me that it could not wait for 1 1/2 hours.
Worth it.
The wait was non existent this time around.
It was about 5:30 but it soon gained a line by 6pm when I left.
It was nice to eat and read alone with the cook/waitress yelling/placing an order over the phone.
up.author: Ashley I.
up.review: Like a crack addict, I keep coming back.  I had to eat before I met up with my friend and I'm glad I did.  I was suppose to eat at Sycamore but my body told me that it could not wait for 1 1/2 hours.  Worth it.  The wait was non existent this time around.  It was about 5:30 but it soon gained a line by 6pm when I left.  It was nice to eat and read alone with the cook/waitress yelling/placing an order over the phone.

excerpts: They showed up to the party a little late and when I bit into one, I nearly spit it out, exclaiming, "Holy shit that's good!"
up.author: Adam C.
up.review:
Yamo-goers beware, the operation of this place can be a bit confusing at first.  A line forms on the right of the entrance for seating.  A line forms on the left of the entrance for take out.  I was a little skeptical, at first, waiting without my name on a list, but it turned out alright.

I got there at exactly 7:34, on a Tuesday.  There were 6 people ahead of us, but considering the place seats maybe 10 total, that turned into an hour long wait.  I thought the wait at Burma Superstar was kind of absurd, so when 8:29 stuck and we weren't seated yet, I proclaimed: "Fuck." (We said we wouldn't do this.)

We decided to keep waiting and didn't have to wait much longer than that, thankfully.   Based on friends' reviews, we started with the tea leaf salad.  I thought it was very good:  a stab of spice mixed with the crunch of nuts and refreshing crisp of lettuce leaf.

Next came the Curry Beef with Noodles and I found them to be light on the oil, but full of flavor.  At this point I was starting to wonder why we hadn't gotten our other appetizer, the samusas, yet.  

They showed up to the party a little late and when I bit into one, I nearly spit it out, exclaiming, "Holy shit that's good!"  Luckily, for those around me, I managed to keep that sucker in my mouth, although I was surprised by how good it was.

We also tried those grass jelly drinks out of curiosity and they were okay.  They have bits of grass-flavored jelly(?) in the bottom to add texture to the drink, ie. you need a straw.

The shape and size of the place really reminded me of a small diner where I would get breakfast in my hometown.  Even though it was my first time there, it felt very familiar, and everything had the appearance of a home cooked dish.

At the end we were full, and it was 8 dollars each with a 20% tip.

excerpts: no matter, pack it up to go and walk to the park!
up.author: Laura F.
up.review:
BEST cheap eats since the tamale lady.  

I am a self-proclaimed noodle-and-dumpling-whore.  I first discovered Yamo thanks to a girlbuddy who lives around the block, and we met for lunch one afternoon: The menu is definitely in line with my carbo-lust.

We sat at the counter and slurped noodles and coconut.... but the BEST part for me, without question, were the potstickers.  They are steamed and FULL of fresh ginger, which is one of nature's perfct foods (after bacon).

Now that I am aware of it's existence, I always see a line out the door here-- no matter, pack it up to go and walk to the park!  

Nothing on the menu is more than ~$6, so it's a guilt-free indulgence that everyone should treat themselves to.  Seriously!

excerpts: This place feels like a grundgy, slapped together noodle shop you could find down some back alley in SE asia with enough grease built up on the front window to make a meal of if you were brave enough to lick it off (and I mean this in a good way).
I love the simplicity of the menu, all noodle dishes, the same price.
So what if you want chicken, beef, shrimp or veggies, same same same same.
up.author: Adrian L.
up.review:
I've been to Yamo a couple of time now and, though I can't say the food blows, or even knocks, my socks off, I can see myself returning here for many more meals.  First of all, the food is good, like I said, not lick my plate or bowl clean great, but solid.  I've had the Yamo house noodles with beef, and though i was looking for a bit more flavour, the beef was nice and tender and I like the texture of the noodles.  I also had their curry with shrimp and noodles.  Likewise it was pretty good, needed to add some pepper oil for spiciness, but I had no problem finishing this dish.  I have also eaten the potstickers and samosas, both OK.

What I love about this place is it's third world charm and simplicity.  I love restaurants that you walk into and feel like you've left the the country.  OK so you could say you feel like you've left the country just walking down Mission to 18th St.  This place feels like a grundgy, slapped together noodle shop you could find down some back alley in SE asia with enough grease built up on the front window to make a meal of if you were brave enough to lick it off (and I mean this in a good way).  I love the simplicity of the menu, all noodle dishes, the same price.  So what if you want chicken, beef, shrimp or veggies, same same same same.   And finally, that price is cheap!  

Summary: CHEAP, GOOD, and I'm sure there's one other thing I could annoyingly capitalize.

excerpts: Inside: one long bar smashed up against the counter and absolutely NO STANDING ROOM.
Super-hip clientele.
up.author: Danyell K.
up.review:
I don't understand, but I guess I should make note that I'm a vegetarian.

Not many options on the menu if you are....curry vegetables seems to be the cake. There was a tofu dish, but...meh. Kinda over tofu.

Fair enough. I like curry and vegetables. 

It was $5.95 for the meal and the rice. That is this place's ONLY redeeming quality.


Yeah, yeah, yeah. I see what you're doing here. Hole-in-the-wall "ethnic" place with no sign outside or anything to note what it's called - such style - but the line out-the-door for GUSTO. Inside: one long bar smashed up against the counter and absolutely NO STANDING ROOM. Super-hip clientele. (It IS in-between Mission and Valencia.)


And the food wasn't that good. Crazy spicy, "eh" rice, and some vegetables. Sure, it's cheap....but that's the case with the flavor, too.

excerpts: Sure you leave smelling something of recycled grease, but the flavorful food and very friendly people behind the counter more than make up for it.
up.author: Xtina C.
up.review:
I love nothing better than little ethnic hole-in-the-floor joints with great food for practically nothing.  Thus is Yamo.
Sure you leave smelling something of recycled grease, but the flavorful food and very friendly people behind the counter more than make up for it.
Make sure to try the tea salad (so many crunchy goodies mixed in).  The cold noodles are delish, the black bean fish was good and the curries are nice and spicy.
And for such a no-frills place, it's nice that they have an array of condiments.

excerpts: For some background, I grew up eating Asian food, I shop at Asian markets in San Francisco, own about a dozen Asian cookbooks (Chinese, Vietnamese, Thai) and cook Asian foods most days of the week.
This place doesn't suit my tastes but it appears to suit the taste of many others.
I think that if you cook a lot of Asian foods you may find this place wanting.
up.author: Mike N.
up.review:
What we ordered:

Tea Leaf Salad - Good tea leaf salad, splits well as a starter for two people, would recommend
Fish Chowder- came filled with over cooked rice noodles, ate less than 1/4 of the bowl
Curry Prawn over noodles - egg noodles with diced mushrooms, bell peppers and onions, was ok but not really a curry. 

I'm not a professional chef so my standard for good food is simply if it is better than what I could make myself at home.  The Tea Leaf salad was certainly better than ones which I've made.  The Fish Chowder and Curry Prawn noodle weren't though.  The Fish Chowder was almost inedible due to the overcooked, sludgy rice noodle and the Curry Prawn wasn't a curry in any of the Indian/Thai-sense of the word so I'm not sure why they call it curry.  I was disappointed after waiting for 15 minutes outside for a spot at the bar to eat very mediocre food.  On the upside their menu is very simple and most items are $6 which is reasonable.  Unfortunately that $6 could be put to better use at many other Mexican restaurants in the area.  I can't recommend other Asian restaurants in the Mission but if you can make it to the Chinatown, the Richmond, or Sunset you'll be sure to find better Asian food for $6.  

Whether you like this restaurants depends mostly on yours tastes.  I'm not Burmese but all the places I've had Burmese food in San Francisco have been better.  For some background, I grew up eating Asian food, I shop at Asian markets in San Francisco, own about a dozen Asian cookbooks (Chinese, Vietnamese, Thai) and cook Asian foods most days of the week.  This place doesn't suit my tastes but it appears to suit the taste of many others. I think that if you cook a lot of Asian foods you may find this place wanting.

excerpts: Just FYI - the potatoes in the curry look like they're pre-fried earlier in the day then boiled when you order curry to heat them up.
up.author: Joann C.
up.review:
Very cheap, yet tasty.  I had the tea salad, chicken curry over rice, and house noodles with chicken.  The tea salad had great flavor to it and was more memorable to me than Burma Superstar's.  The house noodles were also very tasty with the fried garlic on top.  The chicken curry over rice was good, but I think next time I'll order over noodles.  I don't know if it's just an illusion, but it looked like if you order noodles they give you more.  I saw other people with the veggie curry and it looked great. 

The food here is greasy.  It's not for people looking to lose weight or count calories.  It's for a good quick meal that's extremely easy on the wallet.  The other reviewer is right.  All the noodles are coated in oil as is all the vegetables in the curry.  Just FYI - the potatoes in the curry look like they're pre-fried earlier in the day then boiled when you order curry to heat them up.  

(Also, ideally you'd go to the bathroom before coming here.  It's not unusable, but it's not a pleasant experience.)

excerpts: I'm mostly writing this review just to give a heads up to all the friends that left me and went up north.
up.author: Bryan R.
up.review:
To be completely honest, it's been so long since I've been here that I don't even remember what I ordered.  (I live in SoCal),  I'm mostly writing this review just to give a heads up to all the friends that left me and went up north.

Although I don't remember what I ate, I do remember it was delicious and I was really impressed with the place.  I think it's changed a little since I dined there.  For one, there were no ladies working the counter as everyone has mentioned.  It was some "rock n roll" asian dude.  He simply did not give a fuck.  If we wanted something to drink, we were instructed to come behind the counter and grab it ourselves.  We gave him an order and he fixed us "something like that", with his own delicious personal touches.  The sign displaying the hours were "If the door is open, we're open.  If the door is closed, we're closed"

The one thing I remember is they served black rice, and I wasn't expecting that.  It was great though.  Next time I'm in the area I'd definitely like to try it again and see if it's as good as I remember.

excerpts: One customer came in and picked up her phoned-in order.
You'll end up smelling of food while waiting for your order.
Forget about privacy.
Save your racy stories for dessert somewhere else.
up.author: Leah E.
up.review:
I would have never found this place in a gazillion years if not for Yelp!  Thanks, Yelpers!!!

(Now I am in big trouble after finding this place!! I go to meetings around the corner from Yamo few times a week.  It will be hard to skip the place.  I just have to remember to bring cash everytime.)



Date:  November 25, 2008 at 11:58 AM

Occasion: Lunchbreak. Food to go.

Venue: The place is cute:  like a grandma's kitchen in Asia kind of cute.
              The whole place is a kitchen with counter seatings for 9.
              Think Asian, rustic version of the Mario Batali Kitchen.
 
Decor: None. Rustic. Simple. Basic
             Stove, pots and pans
              One long counter seating.

Social Scene:  I was the only person at the place aside from the two old ladies cooking.  I had the best seat in the house and was very much entertained watching them cook.  One customer came in and picked up her phoned-in order.

Taste:  I ordered "Curry fish with steam rice"  Spicy. Fish was fresh and melt in your mouth. YAMOLICIOUS!!! Get it? ;)

Future Taste:  Tea Salad
                           Mango chicken
                           Everything on the menu which is a short-list.

Tab:  $5.25 ( no tax/no tip jar in sight)

Skip:  Dining at Yamo if you are claustrophobic like me.  This place is good for meals to go.  Otherwise, you will be eating elbow to elbow with the person right next to you.  

Downside:  Cash only.
                      You'll end up smelling of food while waiting for your order.
                      Forget about privacy. Save your racy stories for dessert somewhere else.

excerpts: If you can find this mysterious Burmerse haven, then By ALL MEAN EAT UP!
up.author: J J.
up.review:
If you can find this mysterious Burmerse haven, then By ALL MEAN EAT UP! 

The Tea Tree Salad is worth a 2 mile hike.

excerpts: Don't get me wrong, I'm totally into the gritty cheap eats experience and am way down with the hard-workin' ladies serving it up homestyle, but at a certain point in life (after 30?)
up.author: Prattle P.
up.review:
Don't get me wrong, I'm totally into the gritty cheap eats experience and am way down with the hard-workin' ladies serving it up homestyle, but at a certain point in life (after 30?) you realize that some things are worth paying the extra couple bucks for - furniture, electronics, clothes, and pork.

I've been to this greasy spot more times than I can count and have always kept it veggie because quite frankly, I'm scared of their meat as I've yet to figure out where they might keep the fleshy items refrigerated. 

Last weekend my Special Lady Friend and I stopped in for a late lunch and to my dismay she ordered the House Noodles with pork. I know she has a much heartier eastern Euro constitution than I so I say nothing. By the time I'd cleared through my mushrooms and veggies she'd managed to suss out the noodles leaving behind an entire bowl of greasy pig bits. Huh? She claimed it was suspect and her tummy notso hotso, so we paid the $11 check and slipped out just as the smoke alarm set off screeching - a sound cue so aptly timed and suggestive it could not have been written into a script. 

Our flat is not far from Yamo, relatively speaking, but we could not get home quick enough. Comprende?

Advice: If you're way mega broke and not expected to leave your toilet for the next 24 hrs then by all means, throw the dice. Otherwise spend the extra five bucks and get yourself to a place with refrigeration and a visible health code rating.

excerpts: and I love the simple set-up.
I really felt like I was back in the Philippines at times.
up.author: Lance D.
up.review:
This place is such a trip.  When I poked my head in here after finding this place on Yelp I was really blown away.  I definitely felt like I stepped into a different world. I hope they never renovate because SF definitely needs places unique places like Yamo to contrast the glitsy pretentious restaurants out there.  I definitely like this place and will go back again, I mean hey can't beat the prices but I can't really give it more than 3 stars.  Potstickers were pretty bad and I love potstickers...springrolls were also eh but better than the potstickers. Mango chicken was not nearly as good as I expected it to be since previous yelpers had reviewed it so glowingly. It was super spicy and I really had hoped they would have wanted more chicken with my plate of mango.  The black bean fish was pretty tasty though. 

So definitely check it out and keep going...decent enough food and I love the simple set-up. I really felt like I was back in the Philippines at times.

excerpts: I've never went in and sat down for a meal, but I like to call ahead, order, and pick it up 10 minutes later.
salad I ordered once which was super tiny and didn't fill be up.
Other than that, it's been a regular stop for me!
up.author: Anna Y.
up.review:
Whenever I'm in the mission and not in the mood for a burrito (weird, I know but it happens!) and only have $6, I always give Yamo a call! I've never went in and sat down for a meal, but I like to call ahead, order, and pick it up 10 minutes later. So cheap and easy! 

One star off for the tea leaf salad I ordered once which was super tiny and didn't fill be up. Other than that, it's been a regular stop for me!

excerpts: And it's not like anything I ever ate up and down the Burmese border.
I'm just sayin.
up.author: kt s.
up.review:
Not sure what all the hype is about, frankly. Unless it's from folks who really like to get their hole-in-the-wall fix on, bc yes, Yamo is that. So go if you miss cramped, intimate little spots - it's on par with all the holes we miss overseas (and NY). And yes, the 3 old ladies are adorable.

But I have a hard time advising anyone to go for the food itself. I don't even have to be a foodie to say that. It's mediocre at best, and bad / gas-producing at worst. And it's not like anything I ever ate up and down the Burmese border. I'm just sayin.

excerpts: My friend took us here for a final bite to eat before we left SF and though we had to wait since the whole counter was taken up, I was truly satisfied with my bowl of Burmese noodles and chicken and garlic and
*drooool*.
I also tried the chicken curry and some other fish noodle thing (sorry, I don't really memorize the menu), and everything was just perfect.
So yummy in my tummy that the only conceivable thing you can do next is curl up and take a nap in your mommy's bed.
up.author: Moye I.
up.review:
Oh, Yamo. How come you don't exist down in LA? 

My friend took us here for a final bite to eat before we left SF and though we had to wait since the whole counter was taken up, I was truly satisfied with my bowl of Burmese noodles and chicken and garlic and *drooool*.
