I also tried the chicken curry and some other fish noodle thing (sorry, I don't really memorize the menu), and everything was just perfect. So yummy in my tummy that the only conceivable thing you can do next is curl up and take a nap in your mommy's bed. Unfortunately, my parent's house was nowhere near, so I just cried instead.

Asian comfort food 4 life!

excerpts: He wasn't kidding-within moments after we sat down at the bar, there were a number of people lining up behind us.
To be perfectly honest, I was skeptical about "atmosphere".
The decor reminded me to crack den chic-dark sloppy painted walls, archaic ripped vinyl bar stools, a grime encrusted grease hood...
up.author: Monica L.
up.review:
A fellow Burmese food enthusiast invited to lunch at Yamo. "You have to get there by 11:30", he warned. He wasn't kidding-within moments after we sat down at the bar, there were a number of people lining up behind us. 
To be perfectly honest, I was skeptical about "atmosphere". The decor reminded me to crack den chic-dark sloppy painted walls, archaic ripped vinyl bar stools, a grime encrusted grease hood... Toto, we are not in the St. Regis anymore. 

We started with the tea leaf salad-I would have preferred some more acid in the salad or some rice to cut the overwhelming richness. Next we tried the mango salad which was much more to my liking. I liked the interplay of the sweet mango with the pungent vinegary dressing. 

I would never in a million years ordered the Chicken Noodle soup but I'm so glad my friend did. The "broth" was thick and creamy with coconut milk and curry. The chicken breast slices were stir-fried to perfection and the egg noodles were fresh and springy. A perfect dish. 

The cold egg noodles were a bit of a disappointment after the perfection of the chicken noodle soup but were tasty nonetheless. 

At $5.25 for an entree this place is a considerable value and I would definitely order to go in a heart beat.

excerpts: Five stars for the simple fact that I went in with VERY low expectations and ended up practically licking my plate clean.
up.author: Tara B.
up.review:
Five stars for the simple fact that I went in with VERY low expectations and ended up practically licking my plate clean.

What the hell? 

My friend and I had just gone to the Found Magazine event at The Dark Room and he wanted to grab a bite to eat. He lives in the Mission, I didn't, and he suggested we wander over to Yamo.

I was skeptical, of course. A small greasy spoon serving curry? But oh... how I love curry. So I couldn't resist. So I ordered the chicken curry dish with rice. And I was not disappointed. At. all.

Obviously, with 118 reviews already, this place isn't exactly a secret. But I had to put my two cents in.

The downsides? One of the ladies behind the counter was really skilled at avoiding eye contact until she was ready to take our order, which took a few minutes. And they accidentally gave my friend rice instead of the noodles he had ordered. Which they quickly corrected by bringing him a plate of noodles. So, no real problems, so much as quirks.

excerpts: Suck in your belly, find a seat at the counter, and wait for the Three Ladies to whip up some seriously tasty (and, according to a friend who has visited Burma many times, authentic) dishes.
Holes-in-the-wall are by definition not quirk-free, but the food at this one more than makes up for it.
up.author: andy d.
up.review:
Yamo is very much like a walk-in closet, except there's no room for your clothes because there's a kitchen in it. Suck in your belly, find a seat at the counter, and wait for the Three Ladies to whip up some seriously tasty (and, according to a friend who has visited Burma many times, authentic) dishes.

I am a pot sticker connoisseur and can't remember having had better ones recently. We also got a chicken curry -- which was aggressively spicy, but in a good way -- and pork chow fun. No bland portions here: everything was really rich and really good.

Gotta mention the cons: the air in there is THICK with smoke/oil from the fryer. A little more ventilation would keep people there a little longer...although with only like ten seats, maybe they want high turnover. In any case, you've been warned. As other yelpers have noted, getting the attention of the ladies, even in a place this small, was challenging; but you sort of feel like you're flagging down someone in their own kitchen, which is pretty much what's happening, and that's rude. Still -- gotta ding them one star for barely breathable air.

That said, do not fail to visit Yamo. Holes-in-the-wall are by definition not quirk-free, but the food at this one more than makes up for it.

excerpts: But it doesn't matter,  the food comes out fast and not a place for chatting it up.
Well...you're not gonna want to talk but eat and eat and eat.
up.author: Claude C.
up.review: A delicious mix of Burmese and Chinese food - honestly prepared! This is just the right place to eat at after work (lunch is advisable too if you don't mind the lingering smell of sauteed onions in sesame oil on you).  Tried their mushroom tofu dish with noodles and their black bean dish..YUM! It's slightly oily but one will forget about that once the flavor kicks in the mouth. The menu is simple...prices are extremely fair. The place is small-bar stool seating. But it doesn't matter,  the food comes out fast and not a place for chatting it up. Well...you're not gonna want to talk but eat and eat and eat.

excerpts: You won't even know where it is unless you look for the torn up awning above the front  door.
The walls outside have graffiti leading you to belive that it may not be safe to even eat inside at all!
up.author: Andy P.
up.review:
I love Yamo both for the no-frills selections and bargain price!

Except for very few  items, all dishes are for only $5.25 or less..and that includes the tax!

I have tried several including the chicken curry and noodles...and each one comes in a healthy portion and taste excellent for the price you are paying.

This place is very small located in a somewhat shady neighborhood so it really is best if you go during daytime just a bit before or after lunch to avoid lines.  You won't even know where it is unless you look for the torn up awning above the front  door.  The walls outside have graffiti leading you to belive that it may not be safe to even eat inside at all!  However, you can also look for this place just by looking for people waiting outside.

As you go in, you will only see a long counter with about 10 stools on one side.  The other side is the kitchen where you will see the 3 sisters preparing, cooking and serving you.  

The only negative I would say about this place is that the sisters are not that attentive especially when it gets busy.  They get so busy chopping, preparing, taking orders by phone, etc., they would forget to refill your glass of water.  At times, you have to shout a bit louder so they can hear you asking for more water or your check.

I go back to this place whenever I can, but I do not always expect great service each time.

excerpts: So pick up and get it to go.
up.author: Cathy H.
up.review:
When the pocket book is hurting, and I am too lazy to cook, I ride over to Yamo's for food to go. The place has a simple entree formula. 

Entree = curry + choice of fried or sauteed veggies/meat/seafood/poultry + rice/egg noodles

Fried fish curry with egg noodles is a staple. I wash down the yummy inexpensive goodness with the well stocked grass jelly drink. Am I the only person who orders this?

If you see a line 4-people deep, just get your food to go. It is not worth the hell hole wait. Nope you do not go here for ambiance. Not for a date. Definitely not to take in the open kitchen unless you like to reek of curry for the rest of the night. Plus the bickering about how things should be done amongst the 4 ladies gets old. Given the place, you let a lot of the pet peeves pass: getting your appetizer after your entree or someone else getting their food before you even though they ordered after you. So pick up and get it to go. 

Unfortunately Yamo is not opened on Sunday nights, when I need it the most after an intense weekend.

excerpts:
Somewhere on 18th street, in a small dark closet that has a doorway, a couple of Burmese ladies are busting their butts serving up fresh and tasty food.

She promptly ordered up the Tea Tree Salad and the Chicken Noodle soup.

I ended up ordering the Tofu Curry, they ask if you want it over noodles or rice.
up.author: Jess R.
up.review:
Somewhere on 18th street, in a small dark closet that has a doorway, a couple of Burmese ladies are busting their butts serving up fresh and tasty food.

I was fluctuating between three and four, but the more I thought about it, the more I liked about this place than not.

As everyone has said, yes.  It is small.  I ventured in at 130 on a Saturday (actually, 138 because i was late...) and there were plenty of seats available for us.  

The first thing I did notice when I walked in was the heavy smell of oil.  I knew I was going to stink after I left which bummed me out because I was heading back to a party after...  Grr.

Anyhow, the menu had several options.  All of the dishes were under $6?!?  That's my kind of place!!!!

My friend who I came with was the professional...  She promptly ordered up the Tea Tree Salad and the Chicken Noodle soup.

I ended up ordering the Tofu Curry, they ask if you want it over noodles or rice.  I chose the noodles, and I'm glad I did!!!

I tried some of my friends Tea Tree salad and it was DELICIOUS.  I wish I just ordered three of them and had that as my meal.....

Her soup looked delicious, and my curry tofu was just okay....  It didn't have a whole lot of taste to it, but the noodles underneath it were DELICIOUS....

This place was definitely a good find.  The women working their are nice, and efficient!!!  She realized they had put my tofu over rice instead of the noodles before she even handed it to me and within only 2 minutes, problem remedied!!!

I look forward to trying a few more things they have to offer, and hopefully they can throw some tofu in their chicken noodle soup instead of chicken.  I would like that.  I also enjoyed watching them work.  Her wrapping a spring roll was the BEST!

excerpts: Thumbs up to Yelp because without their iphone app we never would have discovered this hidden gem.
Quick, tasty and cheap.
And all of my Burmese friends tell me its very authentic.
House noodles and tea leave salad are souper.
up.author: Michael N.
up.review: Thumbs up to Yelp because without their iphone app we never would have discovered this hidden gem.  Quick, tasty and cheap.  And all of my Burmese friends tell me its very authentic.  House noodles and tea leave salad are souper.

excerpts: People were lined up four deep
and you hadn't even opened yet.
A victim of your own success, I sped by . . .
never to return.
Plus, what up with doubling your prices?
I mean, you got the goods,
no doubt about that, but sheeeeeeeet.
Back to Yamo's . . .

the tea leaf salad is a crunchy, spicy delight; the spring rolls and peanut sauce are simple and tasty; and the house curry with beef, chicken or prawns over rice or noodles was sublime, although a little greasy.
When the bill came I did a doubletake - where am I?
Is there an exchange rate?
How could dinner for two be THIRTEEN DOLLARS?!?
Believe it.
Go!
up.author: Jefferson C.
up.review:
Well, it ain't no first date place - between the cafeteria ambience, buzzing fluorescents, white noise from the fan, no alcohol policy, and gritty neighborhood, you're not going to win friends and influence people by bringing them here.

UNLESS.  Unless they only care about the food.  Because the food is very good, and ALMOST FREE.

I'm sorry, Burma SuperStar.  I came to the party early, I loved you, you rocked my very soul, and then came the day a few short weeks ago when I went by at 5:30 on a Sunday expecting to waltz in the door and sit down at my favorite table and THE ENTIRE KNOWN UNIVERSE was waiting outside.  People were lined up four deep and you hadn't even opened yet.  A victim of your own success, I sped by . . . never to return.  

Plus, what up with doubling your prices?  I mean, you got the goods, no doubt about that, but sheeeeeeeet.

Back to Yamo's . . . the tea leaf salad is a crunchy, spicy delight; the spring rolls and peanut sauce are simple and tasty; and the house curry with beef, chicken or prawns over rice or noodles was sublime, although a little greasy.  When the bill came I did a doubletake - where am I?  Is there an exchange rate?  How could dinner for two be THIRTEEN DOLLARS?!?

Believe it.  Go!

excerpts: I usually take it to go because seating is limited and I end up smelling like fried food if I am there longer then 10 minutes, but the place is great and you can't beat the price.
up.author: Rositsa K.
up.review: Love Yamo! Awesome chicken soup and house noodles. I usually take it to go because seating is limited and I end up smelling like fried food if I am there longer then 10 minutes, but the place is great and you can't beat the price.

excerpts: and when I called back to get a replacement and drive the 5 mile round trip, they hassled me really bad and were so jerky that I was afraid to pick up the "replacement".
I was on the phone for 5 minutes while they argued, loudly about weather or not to make me a replacement.
up.author: Freud R.
up.review:
I used to love this place until... they put chicken in my food which I took home and when I called back to get a replacement and drive the 5 mile round trip, they hassled me really bad and were so jerky that I was afraid to pick up the "replacement". I was on the phone for 5 minutes while they argued, loudly about weather or not to make me a replacement. Whaaa?

Seriously, not worth it at any price. I am so bummed, my memories are tarnished and I will not go back.The sad thing is that I have eaten there 50+ times over the years, and maybe 40 of those times were really great. But this last one was so bad...

Two stars because of the previous decent experiences.

excerpts: We were still standing outside when they started our order and had our food served up by the time we got to our seats.
up.author: Aim B.
up.review: How have I never been here before??  I *LOVE* hole in the wall places like this with counter only seating and brusque service.  Efficiency at its best!  We were still standing outside when they started our order and had our food served up by the time we got to our seats.  Tea salad. YUM! House Noodles--pretty tasty, as well!  Spring rolls, too? Our bill was ridiculously small considering how much food we had.  Perfect meal after a monster workout, too! :)

excerpts: Not great for big parties or parties of any time unless you are lucky to show up with ample seating.
I had a party of 5 and we were able to score the last 5 (in a row)
seats around
6:45pm on a Wednesday, just 5 minutes before a rush of people showed up.
up.author: David C.
up.review:
Burmese food that make family can be proud of!  

It's as good as it gets without paying for more or higher quality ingredients and fillings.  

Fantastic and cheap!  I recommend the Catfish Chowder, the Chicken Coconut noodle soup, the tea leaf salad and the curry beef.  Also for those of you who enjoy samosas but don't like the indian ones because the wrapper is too thick, you'll love the burmese samosas as the use the think crispy won ton/ spring roll skins.  

Unfortunately it seats only about 10 and it's counter seating only.  Not great for big parties or parties of any time unless you are lucky to show up with ample seating.  I had a party of 5 and we were able to score the last 5 (in a row) seats around 6:45pm on a Wednesday, just 5 minutes before a rush of people showed up.  

They seem to be popular with the takeout crowd so if you can find somewhere else to eat, get it to go and avoid the wait!

excerpts: Three women are in constant motion behind the bar, cooking up a storm, cleaning, chopping, prepping, taking orders, handing out deliveries, sassin' to each other....
I felt bad staring at them, but it's such a small place that there's really nowhere else to look and, well, it is kind of entertaining.
The crowd was a mix of hipsters and homeless.
The waitress let me know that she was ready to take my order by yelling something and throwing a placemat down in front of me.
I took this as a good sign.
I ordered the prawn curry and...it was horrible.
Why?
No flavor, just grease.
The noodles were mostly steaming hot with ramdom cold, uncooked clumps.
The veggies were fresh, but they were covered in this gross bland grease.
I was really hungry but only ate half of it because I was too scared of the grease puddle at the bottom.
Here's something Yamo related to cheer you up: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7HbbM-FG8lQ
up.author: M M.
up.review:
Seeing only one person in line at Yamo this afternoon, I quickly seized the rare opportunity to grab a seat.  Three women are in constant motion behind the bar, cooking up a storm, cleaning, chopping, prepping, taking orders, handing out deliveries, sassin' to each other....I felt bad staring at them, but it's such a small place that there's really nowhere else to look and, well, it is kind of entertaining. The crowd was a mix of hipsters and homeless. The waitress let me know that she was ready to take my order by yelling something and throwing a placemat down in front of me. I took this as a good sign.
I ordered the prawn curry and...it was horrible. Why? No flavor, just grease. The noodles were mostly steaming hot with ramdom cold, uncooked clumps. The veggies were fresh, but they were covered in this gross bland grease. I was really hungry but only ate half of it because I was too scared of the grease puddle at the bottom. I really wanted to like Yamo, but the food is just bad. 

Why is this place busy? Whyyyy? Because it's cheap? Because it's fast and convenient? You're in the mission! Go get an amazing burrito or sandwich or something, dummy.

I feel bad being so negative about this place because it's got a really raw vibe that I'm into and the ladies who work there seem really dedicated. But no. Just no.

Here's something Yamo related to cheer you up: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7HbbM-FG8lQ

excerpts: Sit at the counter while the elderly Asian women cook up your meal.
You'll bump elbows with the person next to you, but that's the charm of this place.
up.author: Sanjeev B.
up.review:
Is this Burmese?  I have no idea.  Is it tasty?  Yes.

Sit at the counter while the elderly Asian women cook up your meal.  You'll bump elbows with the person next to you, but that's the charm of this place.  You'll see all the ingredients being chopped, the oil cooking away, and customers wait outside for their to-go orders.

I can't remember what I ordered, but it was all pretty good.  It's the kind of hole-in-the-wall you want to call home.

excerpts: The real action is behind the counter, where three middle aged Burmese women scurry about--taking phone orders, chopping up salads, spooning heaps of spices onto colorful plates, working the 6-burner stove, and every once in a while, pausing from their frenetic activity to fulfill a customer's request.
up.author: Catherine O.
up.review:
Oh Yamo, how I worship thee. You are my favorite bargain eatery.

If you're into discovering a hole-in-the-wall place with a bit of grit then Yamo is the place to be. The real action is behind the counter, where three middle aged Burmese women scurry about--taking phone orders, chopping up salads, spooning heaps of spices onto colorful plates, working the 6-burner stove, and every once in a while, pausing from their frenetic activity to fulfill a customer's request. 

After taking our appetizer order on a small deli style-notepad, our "waitress" abruptly crooned "number 1"; and, waddling away from us, grabbed some cabbage out of the fridge, delivered said cabbage to the stove chef, and then calmly returned to finish taking our entrée order. 

After the spring rolls (which I felt could've used a bit more edginess) came my friend Eirene's House Noodles, which were fantastic. The pork was tenderized and well spiced, while the soupy noodles were flavorful and perfectly cooked. When my shrimp curry entrée arrived, a few minutes later, Eirene took the opportunity to remind the ladies that we were still waiting on our other appetizer, the tea leaf salad. "Oh right!" was the response followed by a falsetto three-part harmony chorus of "Tea Leaf Salad"! Seconds later, it seemed, the salad was in front of us. Served cold, it bombards you with an array of flavors, textures and spices. It is truly a hearty salad, with nuts, beans, shrimp, cabbage, tomato, and sesame seeds. Simply put, it is deliciousness--not to be missed. 

Oh, but did I neglect to describe the shrimp curry? Its got a mountain of red and green pepper jewels, whole shrimps and mushrooms, all smothered in a savory curried sauce. Served with your choice of noodles or rice, this dish is excellent. If all this hasn't sold you, the prices will. Actually, please never go there, because I'll never be able to get a seat.

excerpts: The food is so good that I often stand and watch the lady cook, hoping to pick up some of her secrets through some kind of underhanded osmosis technique.
up.author: Chris C.
up.review:
This place may look grungy from the outside, but don't let that fool you.  The food is so good that I often stand and watch the lady cook, hoping to pick up some of her secrets through some kind of underhanded osmosis technique.

Yamo noodles with beef all the way!  Their samosas are pretty spicy too, and delicious.  

Getting a seat can be a pain however, so I usually just order takeout and take it back to my place a few blocks away.  

Oh, and they have real sugar Coca-Cola. :)

excerpts: The price is so good, that adds a half star right there, pushing the average up and making this place an easy 4 stars.
up.author: Tetsu N.
up.review:
Today was my very first experience eating Burmese food, and from what I'm told, everything here is very authentic, or at least authentic from the perspective that identically prepared delectable delights can be had over there.

Meeting a very old friend from back in NY who happened to be in town, we went to Yamo based on her SO's recommendation.

What a treat!  I love experiencing new kinds of food!

The restaurant itself is ridiculously small, with only some limited counter seating, maybe seating 10 or so.  The restaurant looks like it has been around for a while too, and was incredibly popular.  The line was constant and always out the door, tho luckily, it seems that most who get their food here have are well aware that getting takeout is a much wiser choice.  

And the prices!  Excellent prices for the cheap bastard in me.  My friend and I had three dishes, a coconut drink, and a soda for under $20.  For light eaters on a budget, one dish and a drink would be about $7 combined.  Big eaters won't go broke either.  

On to the food.

Tea Salad:  $5.25
 - 4.5 stars
 - Tea leave, cabbage, fresh tomato, oion, dried shrimp & variety of fried bean, nuts and sesame seeds.
 - Wow, by far my favorite dish of the day.  This taste and texture explosion is so good I wish they served it in meal portions, but alas, they only served it as a relatively small and light plate.  More like an appetizer.  It's got a variety of crunchy textures, including what feels like tiny croutons though with a saltier taste (I'm assuming it's the fried bean but might of been the dried shrimp), and the nuts (which I'm guessing may be peanuts), and the more raw veggie crunch of the cabbage.  There are also several software textures as well as the watery tomato texture.   And the taste?  Wow, there's a raw veggie tanginess to it, subtly to it, saltiness to it....Really, explosion is the only way to describe.  And it does this so cleanly and lightly that none of the tastes are overbearing.  This is a MUST ORDER at this small little hole in the wall.

Fish Chowder Noodle Soup $5.25
 - 2 stars
 - Soup chowder with rice noodles, shredded fish, and onions, garnished with Fried Yellowbeans and Cilantro
 - This wasn't bad, but it didn't strike me as very inspired.  The sauce was a thick reddish sauce reminiscent in texture of thick Chinese sauces poured over meats and rice.  Sorry, there should be a better explanation but I can't imagine what it is.  The noodles were very very well cooked and watery, almost like pho noodles, only it didn't seem to be the way these noodles were supposed to be.  The taste was subtle...almost too subtle.  Perhaps, tho, I'm being a little harsh because of the great tastes of the other dishes, but really, I wouldn't order this again.

Yamo Cold Noodles $5.25
 - 3.5 stars
 - Cold noodles mixed with house special flavor, onions, cabbage, cucumbers, and chicken
 - Pretty good dish.  The noodles are similar to chow mein noodles but without the glossy oiliness.  This was their spicy dish, but it's more tangy than spicy.  The chicken was covered in a thick, almost dry red sauce with lots of full sized peppers (like the dry peppers found in jars at the table at pizza restaurants).  This dish was also full of different flavors giving a nice complexity to the dish.  I would order this again.

Fresh Coconut $2.50
 - 4 stars
 - All my life, I thought coconuts had a stronger taste because coconut flakes used in cakes had such a strong flavor.  What a surprise to find the taste was so subtle, if you had told me it was a different fruit, I would have believed you.  So light, refreshing.  Loved it.  I also liked that it came in a full coconut rather than a glass.  It was fun to see, and we could scrape the inside for the thicker fruity part of the coconut.    Yeah, I'd order this again, just for the novelty of it.  

Grass Jelly drink $1.00
 - 2.5 stars
 - This is a can drink.  Not carbonated, with bits of jelly in it.  It's similar in taste to Chinese turtle shell gelatin desserts.  I'd drink it again if it was served, but probably wouldn't ever be my first choice.  Still, it tasted like it was probably a healthy drink.

Though we didn't order it, the customer sitting next to us order what I think (just guessing mind you) is the Yamo House Noodles.  That looked really good.  Basically several bite sized pieces of chicken (looking like it was cooked in a thick dark sauce) over a bed of the chow mein like noodles.  It sure as heck looked good.

All in all, this place was pretty good.  If I would have rated it a straight 3.5, I'd got to 4, but given that all the food combined average below a 3.5, I'll have to go with a 3 today.

Except...the price!  The price is so good, that adds a half star right there, pushing the average up and making this place an easy 4 stars.

So with that said, Yay!  I'm a fan!

excerpts: Just a straight up coconut with a straw.
What a treat!!
I'm usually not into the greasiness that some of these dishes would usually have, but for once I didn't feel too full and gross once I left.
Thanks Yamo, perfect afternoon find.
up.author: Elyse S.
up.review: After wandering through the Mission looking for something "reasonably priced" and decent to eat, my friend who lives in the area mentioned she just wanted to cruise by and check out the menu.  Once I saw a list of items at $5.25 (the most expensive) we knew we were in. Total hallway-style sit down, which is cozy but sometimes I'm not in the neighbor-elbow-bumping mood.  Friendly service, fun to watch them prepare, and they serve COCONUTS!!! Just a straight up coconut with a straw.  What a treat!!  I'm usually not into the greasiness that some of these dishes would usually have, but for once I didn't feel too full and gross once I left.  Thanks Yamo, perfect afternoon find. :)

excerpts: Although I ended up getting something pretty greasy (which I can't stomach most of the time) the food isn't all that great like people are making it out to be.
Not bad, just overrated.
up.author: Winton W.
up.review:
Although I ended up getting something pretty greasy (which I can't stomach most of the time) the food isn't all that great like people are making it out to be.  Not bad, just overrated.  Maybe it's good to white people or Americanized Asians.

I'm close to giving 2 stars like Emily Y. did but I'd like to give it one more chance since there were others that sounded refreshing and good.

excerpts: You can call ahead and pick up 15 minutes later.
You have to check your order though, since this place gets busy and sometimes they don't remember everything you ordered.
up.author: Julie C.
up.review:
Being that my family is half Burmese, I'm always on the search for authentic Burmese food. Yamo is your definition of an authentic "hole in the wall". $5 for every plate, delicious, and dirty. There are only 10 or so seats so it could definitely get crowded on a busy night. We prefer to get take out on a weeknight. You can call ahead and pick up 15 minutes later. You have to check your order though, since this place gets busy and sometimes they don't remember everything you ordered. This place is pretty authentic for the city, but doesn't necessarily have all of the offerings of true Burmese cuisine.

Our favorite menu items are: tea leaf salad, samosas, beef curry with rice, and Yamo house noodles with pork, and a coconut drink. 

Great place to dine on a budget and provides authentic food at an affordable price.

excerpts: because you've had your expectations built up?
up.author: Sharon W.
up.review:
You know when you're told about something that's suppose to be SUPER AWESOME and AMAZING and WONDERFUL, yadda, yadda, yadda, then you experience it yourself and it's not so great because you've had your expectations built up? Well, I wish that was the explanation behind my experience at Yamo yesterday.

Although the prices were decent (you don't get very much food for your 5.25) and the service was fairly quick, I wasn't so impressed with the food.
I was so excited to have a coconut juice straight from the coconut, but it wasn't very fresh - it was on the verge of turning and the flesh inside was lavender colored. Eegh!
I ordered the house noodles with beef because of all the Yelp recommendations. The noodles were delicious, but the beef... it was crispy and EXTREMELY salty! I wish the beef tasted like somethings other than salt. And, of course, it was all pretty greasy. At least I was pleasantly surprised by the little bits of fresh green onion and cilantro.

excerpts: Still, the whole meal was $12 and made me not feel so guilty for letting my sweet, starving artist of a companion pick up the bill.
up.author: Summer T.
up.review:
I was so tickled to be brought to this place after an afternoon at the MOMA. It was the perfect antidote to high art. 
Yamo is a small, cramped hole in the wall-- counter seating only. The service is sub-par (I think it gets better if you go often) but it's cheap and fast and clearly a local favorite. They were out of chow fun so I got pork chow mein; I was craving noodles. My friend got the mango chicken. My meal was fine but I could see on the plates and in the bowls around me that I had clearly ordered the wrong item. 
The woman on my side had the fish curry soup which looked creamier and was a lighter yellow than other Burmese fish noodle curry soups I've seen/tasted. The guy on our other side had the most beautifully constructed pot stickers. I will definitely be ordering those next time. Still, the whole meal was $12 and made me not feel so guilty for letting my sweet, starving artist of a companion pick up the bill.

excerpts: They finally have a new sign up outside, so you can figure out where it is, instead of getting lost to find this amazing joint without a name.
up.author: j. k.
up.review:
Yamo, Yamo, hole in the wall, who's the greatest of them all?

The ladies there are definitely a kick to watch. The place is tiny, lots of regulars, awesome prices, tasty food... 

They finally have a new sign up outside, so you can figure out where it is, instead of getting lost to find this amazing joint without a name.

excerpts:
all the people lined up.
I like the fish dishes.  
Great place to take a friend, by yourself, or if you want to have a fun cheap date you can talk to the cooks and the servers easy.
Yum!
up.author: Andre G.
up.review:
Great local hole in the wall 
Cheap filling eats, nothing fancy but a warm atmosphere!  
Pretty quick considering the small space and all the people lined up.
I like the fish dishes.  
Great place to take a friend, by yourself, or if you want to have a fun cheap date you can talk to the cooks and the servers easy.
Yum! :)

excerpts: i enjoyed my meal, but i dont think yamo quite lived up to the hype.
up.author: Jon W.
up.review:
i enjoyed my meal, but i dont think yamo quite lived up to the hype.

the house noodles with pork was just fine, but there wasnt much else in the bowl besides noodles and pork. the samusas were fine, but i was expecting a bit more spice and not simply potato.

overall, i added more hot sauce to this meal than i wanted. also, it was a bit strange to serve me the appetizer second, but at a food counter with 8 stools, i think this is perfectly forgivable.

ill definitely be back because this is enjoyable and right in my 'hood and because there are other menu items to try [tea leaf salad, mango chicken, cold noodles], but next time ill have to remember to bring my lowered expectations as well.

on the plus plus side, yamo has to be the cheapest non-mexican meal in the mission.

excerpts: Picked up some take-out.
tea leaf salad ( super small
and I think they forgot the tea leaves!), house noodles with beef and curry chicken( both nothing special).
I am always disappointed whan seemingly authentic asian places use all white meat chicken.
overall, a disappointment but the pics of teh noodle soups look good
so i may atill give it another try for those items since  its rare to find a good mohingna in the city.
up.author: Amina B.
up.review: Bummed- I've been wanting to try this place for a while.  Picked up some take-out.  tea leaf salad ( super small and I think they forgot the tea leaves!), house noodles with beef and curry chicken( both nothing special). I am always disappointed whan seemingly authentic asian places use all white meat chicken.  overall, a disappointment but the pics of teh noodle soups look good so i may atill give it another try for those items since  its rare to find a good mohingna in the city.

excerpts: The ladies working there are wonderful, it's like watching that long lost burmese grandmother/aunty of yours whipping up a meal after you've gotten back from school.
up.author: mike o.
up.review:
Yamo is my favourite place to eat in the city.

With
Out
Doubt!

The food is amazing. The service is homely. The price is excellent. I leave this place feeling a bit more burmese (I started at 0%) each time. The ladies working there are wonderful, it's like watching that long lost burmese grandmother/aunty of yours whipping up a meal after you've gotten back from school. 

Yup, I need to eat here again within the next week or I might turn into a frog.

excerpts: Greasy and bland sums it up.
There are better things on the menu.
up.author: She-Ra ..
up.review:
This is a 3.5 star review.  I rounded down since there are so many high ratings.  
Long story short, I really enjoyed my meal and will go back.  The pros?  Very cheap, cool vibe.  I liked the tea leaf salad quite a bit, but it wasn't the best I'd ever had.  (Good spice and crunch to it.)  The chicken noodle "soup" was also very good, but I'd hesitate to call it soup.  It was more like chicken and noodles in a thick sauce.

Everyone here is raving about the garlic noodles, but I honestly had to take away stars for it. Greasy and bland sums it up.  There are better things on the menu.  (like the coconut drink which I loved).

The restaurant just feels dirty - result of being so small and so much grease floating around.  We asked for water and never got it, so service could be better, but at these prices its hard to complain too much.  

On the plus side you see your food being prepared and you get to talk to the chefs!

excerpts: You can order a bunch of stuff--drinks, appetizers--and still never run up a high bill!
Dining at Yamo has pretty much always been a gratifying experience for me.
Except for the one time this guy was smoking pot outside and the smoke drifted in, and another time, there was just this other unidentified god-awful smell coming in, in waves, from the street.
But that stuff technically has nothing to do with Yamo, per say, so
it's all good.
The control freak in me also loves getting to watch them make the food before my very eyes...
up.author: Shannon R.
up.review:
Yamo rocks. It's definitely on the greasy/spicy side, but when I get in the mood for that, I AM THERE! I'm all about the fish curry over noodles. And I'm also all about the prices at Yamo! You can order a bunch of stuff--drinks, appetizers--and still never run up a high bill! Dining at Yamo has pretty much always been a gratifying experience for me. Except for the one time this guy was smoking pot outside and the smoke drifted in, and another time, there was just this other unidentified god-awful smell coming in, in waves, from the street. But that stuff technically has nothing to do with Yamo, per say, so it's all good. The control freak in me also loves getting to watch them make the food before my very eyes...it's very nice to know just what's going into your dinner!

Oh yeah...and a recent hour-and-a-half long wait over at Burma SuperStar most fondly re-kindled my adoration of Yamo, to say the least!

excerpts: Yamo is like flying home to Vancouver, visiting my mom, and having her whip up a quick bite to eat.
up.author: Marcus W.
up.review:
Yamo is like flying home to Vancouver, visiting my mom, and having her whip up a quick bite to eat.

The menu is simple: four appetizers (samosas, spring rolls, egg rolls, and potstickers), three salads (shrimp & tea leaves, mango, chicken), and 15 entrees (five vegetarian options).    Everything is $5.25 except for the appetizers, which are $3.50.

I had the Yamo House Noodles with beef (also available with chicken or pork).  One of the women fried the beef with garlic and noodles, while the other thinly sliced red and green onions, cucumber, and cilantro into a small bowl.  Because the counter overlooks the prep and cooking area, they make it all right in front of you.

I'm telling you, it was heaven in a bowl.  The noodles were perfect and it was all nice and garlicky.  The raw veggies, which you mix in when they serve you, were still nice and crunchy.
 
If counter seating, cash-only, and dirty windows scare you, go some place else (since all of these yelps mean this place is probably hella busy at dinner, especially with a total of 9 seats).  But if you want a inexpensive, tasty meal, go to Yamo.

excerpts: You're up close and personal with EVERYONE in this narrow little dive, but the food (and prices!) make up for it.

The mango chicken was a little disappointing, but the tea leaf salad was awesome, as was our "server" who was super friendly (but in a nice, small restaurant kind of way, rather than a "Hi, I'm Marcia, and I'll be your server today!!!
kind of way), and patiently explained things on the menu to us.
Props for being family owned too!
up.author: J C.
up.review:
I'm kind of amazed that a tiny hole in the wall with 9 counter seats has over a hundred reviews on Yelp -- but it just goes to show you how far good, cheap, interesting food with friendly service can take you in this city.

Don't come here if you're claustrophobic, or like to believe that food magically appears on your plate from behind some mysterious door. You're up close and personal with EVERYONE in this narrow little dive, but the food (and prices!) make up for it. The mango chicken was a little disappointing, but the tea leaf salad was awesome, as was our "server" who was super friendly (but in a nice, small restaurant kind of way, rather than a "Hi, I'm Marcia, and I'll be your server today!!!" kind of way), and patiently explained things on the menu to us. Props for being family owned too!

excerpts: (I moved out of the Mission, but I will drive around for parking or walk 20 blocks to pick-up take-out.
I never eat-in at Yamo
up.author: E L.
up.review:
Reason #2 not to be a vegetarian in 2008:

My mouth is watering just thinking about #19 with noodle, Curry Beef, #15  Yamo House Noodles with Beef, and #8 Coconut Noodle [Sublime] Soup with Chicken. I have this place programmed into my phone which is quite the honor. (I moved out of the Mission, but I will drive around for parking or walk 20 blocks to pick-up take-out. I never eat-in at Yamo (I'm delicate like that).)

Savoury noodles with that damned delicious umami and egg noodle texture perfection paired with succulent meats and various sauces. Curry Beef has just enough kick and can be spicy, greasy and peppers and onions complement the meat. House noodles have that, "Huh, what is that, uh, flavor?" that if you're an Asian child you are all too grateful about. And, my latest discovery #8 soup is a thick, pale-green broth teeming with sweetness of coconut and the savoury curry, spiked with cilantro and onions, noodle perfection and toppings coming separately so you can become the Asian soup scientist!

excerpts: If you can, call ahead for pick up.
It helps alot.
You may wait for 30 minutes before they even take your order.
But that's a small price to pay for cheap, good eats.
up.author: Jimmy L.
up.review:
So, since reading about Yamo, and visiting 3 times since my last review, I really think it deserves the 5 stars. The food is always good, always made to order, and the cost just really sets it over the top.  If i lived in the neighborhood, I'd be here once a week. But for now, I'm just heading to Yamo's once every two weeks. 

Be patient, it takes along to time to eat here. If you;re in a hurry, go somewhere else. If you can, call ahead for pick up. It helps alot. You may wait for 30 minutes before they even take your order. But that's a small price to pay for cheap, good eats.

excerpts: "over a 10 second period, that sums up Yamo.
I grew up on Chinese food and $3.95 rice plates the size of Texas.
I would suspect since most of the diners during my time there were White, Yamo would seem like highway robbery in terms of $5.25 since they did not grow up with Asian dive food.

although I should, was that on 12/17, the lady who prepares the food, not the cook, was sneezing up a storm and handling the food with her hands....if I get sick just in time for the weekend, I will have to wish you a large lump of coal in your stocking.
up.author: Garfield J.
up.review:
i had passed by this place a couple of times when going over to Weird Fish. It looked pretty promising with a small but interesting menu, plus they had lots of curry dishes and I love curry.

So I decided to try it the other day. 

Disclaimer: prior to trying it, I had no idea what the name of this place was so I could not check Yelp prior to my visit. 

The first thing I said to myself when I sat down and scanned the room and the patrons, was " this is a place which people on Yelp will go ape-shit for"  the elements were all there
a. it is in the Mission
b. it is a hole in the wall dive
c. it has sweet little Asian ladies working there
d. the diners were all round-eyed, not an Asian diner in sight.
e. the place just looked 'edgy', like the old days when you went to underground clubs in skanky wherehouse spaces, this was the food equivelent. 

OK,  so I decide on the chowder, since the Curry has deep fried  stuff in it and I don't like deep fried.

It was OK, (the best way to describe is to attempt to use words to verballize my feelings....OK, ...say strech the words "OK......BUT ....."over a 10 second period, that sums up Yamo.

the food was just warm, not hot, soup , chowder should be hot....the taste were too subtle. it was just OK, just a bit too bland for me....even the heftiness of the chowder was just fair, ...i have a love hate relationship with Coconut milk since it is so damn fattening, but I was begging for more in the Chowder.

there were a few take out orders going on when I was there....I was planning on doing some Curry take out for dinner just cause, just cause I like Curry, but noticed the portion sizes were pretty small . 

I get home and of course read Yelp since I now know what this placed is called and lo-and behold, this place is loved. See words like a 'bargain' super cheap, only $5.25, a steal! ....I can only explain that away as being Asian I grew up on Chinese food and $3.95 rice plates the size of Texas. ....I would suspect since most of the diners during my time there were White, Yamo would seem like highway robbery in terms of $5.25 since they did not grow up with Asian dive food.

Would I go back? I doubt it, I am positive I won't. Was the food bad, no way, it just I have had much better. ....

PS----I big minus and I will not go 2 stars although I should, was that on 12/17, the lady who prepares the food, not the cook, was sneezing up a storm and handling the food with her hands....if I get sick just in time for the weekend, I will have to wish you a large lump of coal in your stocking.

excerpts: This place is a station run by 4 moms yelling loudly over the woks, air vents on full blast, customers..etc so be assured they are cooking up & serving you what they feed their kids, which means the real deal - authentic burmese chinese grubs.
Dishes are wok up pretty fast.
When you sit down, one mom will slid you the menu and instantly said what you want?
up.author: Nancy L.
up.review:
Best tea leaf salad in the bay area! 
You don't really know what  hole in the wall place is until you come here...which is literally hole in the wall. This place is a station run by 4 moms yelling loudly over the woks, air vents on full blast, customers..etc so be assured they are cooking up & serving you what they feed their kids, which means the real deal - authentic burmese chinese grubs. 

These moms are nice but don't expect five star service from them. 0 ambiance. It's not a date place. Peeps come here for cheap, good food and get out. Everything in the menu is super cheap. Dishes are wok up pretty fast. When you sit down, one mom will slid you the menu and instantly said what you want? all efficiency.

After I had some of the awesome goodness that's their tea leaf salad, I'm ready to give Burma Superstar the boot.

excerpts: searched for $ and 4 stars and up came this burmese option.
hopped on over and grabbed 3 of the 11 seats.
up.author: Rosalee R.
up.review:
searched for $ and 4 stars and up came this burmese option. hopped on over and grabbed 3 of the 11 seats.
ordered the tea leaf salad, black bean fish, vegetables, garlic house noodles with chicken and pot stickers. could have left the veggie dish and the pot stickers but everything else was supreme. 
the atmosphere was entertaining with swaying, circling light fixtures, short asian women working full force tossing noddles around in a tiny galley kitchen.
the three of us stuffed our faces for under $25. we will be back.

excerpts: Fry it up, cant go wrong.
About a block away theres a El Salvadorean restaurant that specializes in Papusas...
i had a Pork and Queso
.. YUMMEHHHH!!!
$1.75each.
up.author: JASON L.
up.review:
You ladies are alright in there. Real nice and informal.
Real cheap eats here,  I just tried the Curry Fish w/ Noodles.. they were pretty good half way through, then my taste buds gave out on me.  The taste got old pretty quick.
They were fast, the place has "hole in the wall" charm, maybe the other food is more tasty!?!? The samosas and spring rolls looked great though, Fry it up, cant go wrong.
About a block away theres a El Salvadorean restaurant that specializes in Papusas... i had a Pork and Queso .. YUMMEHHHH!!! $1.75each.

excerpts: This is not a nose up in the air kind of place.
up.author: Michi R.
up.review:
This is a gem in the Mission!! If you are looking for good food at super dirt cheap prices,  this is your heaven.

Every entree on the menu is $5.25 and the appetizer are about $3.50. So, I usually get 2 apps, and 2 entrees for less than $20- can't beat that. For appetizers, I usually get potstickers, somosas or the spring rolls.  The potstickers are ridiculosly delicious, when you bite into them: the juice comes bursting out with a concotion of great flacors. For entrees, I really enjoy their yamo cold noddles w/chicken, the fish in black bean sauce and all of their curry dishes.  Also the chicken coconut soup is really good and hearty, perfect for a cold night.

 This is the tiniest and I mean tiniest hole-in-the-wall I've every seen.  They have about 9 stools where you sit overlooking where they cook and prep the food.   This is not a nose up in the air kind of place. The smallness of it is part of the charm to it.

Yamo is such an awsome place!!

excerpts: echo other yelpers' comments about small 8-person counter and 3 cantonese ladies yelling/dishing up people's orders, pretty cool to see.
def not a fancy place, and small and smoky.
$6 tea leaf salad + $6 house noodles with pork - mm!
i didn't think it was THAT greasy.
delicious with chilli..
up.author: Clarissa L.
up.review: delicious, cheap, awesome!! the tea leaf salad was somewhat different from the ones i've tried elsewhere, but still yummy. echo other yelpers' comments about small 8-person counter and 3 cantonese ladies yelling/dishing up people's orders, pretty cool to see. def not a fancy place, and small and smoky. $6 tea leaf salad + $6 house noodles with pork - mm! i didn't think it was THAT greasy. delicious with chilli..

excerpts: The food is inexpensive and was served up quick.
I had some sort of vegetable dish over rice and spring roll sans shrimp.
I got my food to go, so I cannot speak to the seating arrangement, however, it did appear to be somewhat cramped in there.
Bottom line, for the price, service, and all that
, Yamo (love the name) is a winner for your Burmese/Chinese food needs.
up.author: Brian S.
up.review: This place was pretty awesome. The food is inexpensive and was served up quick. I had some sort of vegetable dish over rice and spring roll sans shrimp. I got my food to go, so I cannot speak to the seating arrangement, however, it did appear to be somewhat cramped in there. Bottom line, for the price, service, and all that, Yamo (love the name) is a winner for your Burmese/Chinese food needs.

excerpts: Great place to chat up a conversation with ur neighbors.
You WILL be rubbing shoulders & elbows with em anyway.

Choy is 
awesome !
up.author: Rooibos T.
up.review:
What's not to love ?

Food - Awesome - Just the right level of spice. Esp good after a few beers. We had the black-bean fish, veggie stir-fry, samusas & Chicken with cold noodles. 
Total bill - $24

Warning: Samusas are not quite like Indian samosas which I prefer (good ones are hard to find), but they are ok here.

Space - 8 bar-stools - figure out seating for urself

Atmosphere - Choy (Burmese owner) yelling away orders a feet away from you. Great place to chat up a conversation with ur neighbors. You WILL be rubbing shoulders & elbows with em anyway. Choy is 
awesome !

excerpts: You might wind up waiting for a half hour (at most) outside while you wait - there is only enough space for those already seated, but its totally worth it.
up.author: Zachary K.
up.review:
Awesome hole in the wall.  No frills, no BS SE Asian food.  Wonderful greasy and cheap cuisine.

You must order the Tea salad - as Im sure you've gathered from others' reviews.. and if youre with two, well order a couple then.

You might wind up waiting for a half hour (at most) outside while you wait - there is only enough space for those already seated, but its totally worth it.

excerpts: I love to put the hot sauces in this soup to hike up the heat factor.
up.author: Anthony V.
up.review:
Yamo, yamo, yamo.  This place is legit.  I usually go at least once a week (either take out or sit at the tiny counter).  It's getting more and more popular so the off hours are better for a relaxed dining experience.  

I tend to get the Chicken Noodle Soup.  It sounds boring but it's anything but.  Quite possibly one of the best soups in the city.  Hearty, noodle filled and brimming with flavor (curryesque).  I love to put the hot sauces in this soup to hike up the heat factor. 

Go here and thank me later.

excerpts: the air is a little thick from the open kitchen behind the counter that takes up a majority of the place.
up.author: Ashley A.
up.review:
the food was decent and cheap. the best part was the atmosphere though. it's a tight squeeze. it's hot and smells of grease. the air is a little thick from the open kitchen behind the counter that takes up a majority of the place. and the women behind the counter spend the whole time yelling at each other in chinese (best guess). quite an experience. 

i'll be honest though, i didn't feel too sure about how sanitary it may be. 
*  shrug  *

excerpts: Everything is cooked fresh and you always end up with happy plate action.
My girl ordered coconut water and they chopped the top off a real life coconut!.
up.author: Richard J.
up.review:
Everything on the menu is $5.25! I always get the Mushroom Tofu with noodles. Everything is cooked fresh and you always end up with happy plate action.  My girl ordered coconut water and they chopped the top off a real life coconut!. That the shit. 



-non greasy feel after eating
-$5.25 menu
-frosty water
-bomb noodles
-small cutty place that makes you feel like your underground and better than anyone else
-ladies work so damn hard for your food

excerpts: We popped around the corner to Yamo, sat down at the bar, and watched the chefs whip up some tasty Burmese dishes right before our hungry eyes.
As we finished up, both Tony and I agreed we'd be back for more.
up.author: Katherine T.
up.review:
My friends are foodies. We love to eat. We love to talk about eating. We love to talk about eating while we're eating. So when my foodie friend Di, whose parents are from Burma told me this was her favorite Burmese spot in the city, I listened. 

I was out with another foodie friend Tony, trying to get into Minako, when we decided we'd rather not wait an hour for dinner. We popped around the corner to Yamo, sat down at the bar, and watched the chefs whip up some tasty Burmese dishes right before our hungry eyes. 

We got tofu garlic noodles because that's what the people next to us were having, and it looked pretty compelling (it was). Tea leaf salad, because that's just what you do in a Burmese restaurant. And shrimp curry too. Because a salad hardly even counts as a dish, yo. Everything was tasty and considerably lighter than a lot of the Burmese I've had in the past. As we finished up, both Tony and I agreed we'd be back for more.

excerpts: They'll package up the noodles and the chicken seperate from the broth
and then you basically have TWO delicious meals for under $5.
up.author: Elisa B.
up.review:
I used to live down the street from Yamo.  It was the only restaurant in the 'hood that I was willing to risk my life crusing down Mission Street to eat at.  

Order the Chicken Noodle Soup to go.  They'll package up the noodles and the chicken seperate from the broth and then you basically have TWO delicious meals for under $5.  I also like the cute little asian plastic spoons they give you, and can reuse them at home!

PERFECT first date spot if you get there early 'cause you can watch your meal prepared from scratch!  

Always order everything over noodles instead of rice.  They use these yellow Burmese noodles that have so much flavor, they make the rice or noodles? option a total no-brainer

excerpts: Party of 2, showed up at 8:30 pm on Tuesday, wait was 15-20 minutes.
up.author: Abid M.
up.review:
What an awesome place. The old ladies prepare every thing in front of you.

It's a really small place, with probably 10 seats on the counter, and that's it. Party of 2, showed up at 8:30 pm on Tuesday, wait was 15-20 minutes.

The big hit was the Yamo cold noodles with chicken. So much flavor.

We also ordered the Samosaz (appetizer) and the Black bean fish.  The fish was nice, but not as flavorful as the cold noodles.  The person beside us said the noodle soups were also good. That's the plan for next time.

Totally worth it.

excerpts: I will probably up the star later.
I am so excited about this place b/c
it's close by and is fantastically quirky.
I ended up eating the rest of the chicken/noodles for lunch the next day and they were superb on their own.
up.author: Christie C.
up.review:
I will probably up the star later.  I am so excited about this place b/c it's close by and is fantastically quirky.  I read all the reviews on Yelp before trying it, and I gotta say I was not disappointed.

I had the Chicken Noodle Soup because I've been sick this week and have been trying to find some comfort foods.  The chicken and noodles were fantastic, but the soup was ok.  I mean, it tasted good, but I didn't really like it.  For that reason, I will go back sometime (most likely soon!) and try other not-soup dishes.  The soup was some sort of coconut milk and curry concoction.  The noodles were kind of like chow mein noodles (the good kind) and the chicken was perfect, not too-dry, not raw.

I ordered take-out, the soup and the chicken/noodles came separate.  I ended up eating the rest of the chicken/noodles for lunch the next day and they were superb on their own.

This place is pretty hard to find, the pictures show a red sign, but there is no sign!!  Thank you Yelpers for the pictures that show the nail store next door, I wouldn't have been able to find it at all!  If you're eating in, it's literally just a counter right against the kitchen.

excerpts: I go there when I'm feeling a little bluesy, a little empty & in need of something to fill me up.
up.author: Mike G.
up.review:
Yamo is amazing, cheap, burmese soul food.  It might seem weird to classify it as such - soul food normally comes from the south, a long way from Burma - but that's how it seems to me.  I go there when I'm feeling a little bluesy, a little empty & in need of something to fill me up.  

I get the tea salad almost religiously.  I've been there maybe 25 times and can only remember one occasion where I didn't order the tea salad.  It is that good - spicy, crunchy, vinegary, amazing.

After that, I've tried everything.  And it's all good.  The noodles and curries tend to the greasy side, but oh-so-delicious.  One exception is the cold noodles, which make a light and delicious alternative to the curries or the other stir-fried dishes.  

Also, try the fish chowder.  Not really all that fishy, but rich and deep in flavor, and topped with crunchy fried beancake chips.  Orgasmic.

excerpts: But that hole is filled with 4 awesome ladys cookin great food up a storm and at a price you can't beat.
Thanks girls!
up.author: Bill N.
up.review: This place looks like a hole in the wall. And it is. But that hole is filled with 4 awesome ladys cookin great food up a storm and at a price you can't beat. Thanks girls!

excerpts: Cash only, which isn't awesome because as a bartender I always have cash and my boyfriend doesn't, thus I end up buying the Yamo.
Alas, it is worth it.
Check this place out if you live in the area.
up.author: Ericka J.
up.review: Amazing delicious greasy noodles. We always get the Yamo House noodles with Pork and maybe get some Spring Rolls. For the price it's super delicious and cheap. Call ahead to get take-out faster, as there isn't much room to stand inside. Cash only, which isn't awesome because as a bartender I always have cash and my boyfriend doesn't, thus I end up buying the Yamo. Alas, it is worth it. Check this place out if you live in the area.

excerpts: The staff doesn't take down a name or a phone number, so when you arrive to pick up, you need to dictate your order again, this time yelling over the counter.
up.author: Matt B.
up.review:
The tea salad is quite tasty, but this place is a little too chaotic for me to handle on a regular basis.

Takeout is a challenge here: ordering by phone connects you directly into the noisy kitchen, so there is a lot of "huh?" and "what?" before the order is done. The staff doesn't take down a name or a phone number, so when you arrive to pick up, you need to dictate your order again, this time yelling over the counter.

Everyone once and a while this is worth it for two things: the tea salad and the chicken noodle soup. The salad is nicely balanced with lots of crunchy bits like peanuts and fried garlic to keep things interesting. The chicken soup has a rich and hearty broth with coconut milk. The rest of the menu is not very memorable.

excerpts: You normally have to wait outside for seats to open up before you can go in, but that's because there are others who appreciate the quality
up.author: Alan C.
up.review:
Great little hole in the wall with tasty dishes for 5 bucks or less.  It's just a little kitchen run by these sweet old Asian ladies, with a counter and a few stools for customers.  You normally have to wait outside for seats to open up before you can go in, but that's because there are others who appreciate the quality, cheap eats that this place has to offer.

Their menu isn't anything fancy, but it doesn't try to be.  That's what's great about this place.  They have rice and noodle dishes, and some appetizers like egg rolls or vietnamese hand rolls.  I'll be back, for sure.

excerpts: yes, they messed up my order and gave me curry fish instead of what i wanted.
and yes, its also incredibly greasy, which was compounded by my choice of noodles instead of rice (soaks up the grease better).
and there is also close to no space in there and can get really warm.
and i almost felt sick when i finished my meal even though this was probably because i'd been doing the my-boyfriend-is-vegetarian
-so-i-guess-
up.author: Amanda C.
up.review:
yes, they messed up my order and gave me curry fish instead of what i wanted.  and yes, its also incredibly greasy, which was compounded by my choice of noodles instead of rice (soaks up the grease better).  and there is also close to no space in there and can get really warm.  and i almost felt sick when i finished my meal even though this was probably because i'd been doing the my-boyfriend-is-vegetarian-so-i-guess-i-am-too diet and had just eaten a ton of fried fish

whatever. its so damn cheap. and the service is so quick.

excerpts: The service is fast and friendly, although you will have to speak up to get a refill in your uber-tiny water glass!
Just thinking about Yamo makes me want to leave work early to head over there...
mmm...
up.author: Heather R.
up.review: Yamo is SF's best hole-in-the-wall, dive Chinese restaurant, with only a handful of seats available at the bar...but trust me, it's worth the very short wait! The food has spectacular flavor and is dirt cheap...just $6 for an entree.  The menu is on the small side, but it doesn't matter when I all ever order are my favorites...either the mango chicken or the stir fry veggies over rice!  (If you want a greasier option, you can go for the yummy noodles rather than rice.)  The service is fast and friendly, although you will have to speak up to get a refill in your uber-tiny water glass!  Just thinking about Yamo makes me want to leave work early to head over there...mmm...

excerpts: you can temporarily enjoy the chaos inside when you pick up.
up.author: eric f.
up.review:
yelp fans, good call on this one!

the chicken noodle soup is RIDICULOUSLY amazing.  shared the samusas as an appetizer, they were ...meh.

$5.25 though for most dishes.  the dishes arent huge but good portions so you arent forced to over eat.  most definitely a good value!!

the wait sucks, and getting a spot for more than 2 is being a little hopeful, we did manage to squeeze in 3 though.

forget eating at the counter and call-in! you can temporarily enjoy the chaos inside when you pick up.  i'm calling in and taking to-go next time...

overall good food and unique experience.

excerpts: On top of this, which is largely enough, the place is family owned and run entirely by women....big up!
up.author: Dario B.
up.review: If you ride the 33 you cannot help having a glimpse at this hole in the wall and its cute door decor. Curiosity grew and finally I opened the door to have: freshly prepared delicious spring rolls, a great tea salad and a fresh and balanced mango chicken. The entire meal was 14 dollars, 7 bucks each! "Bargain bite" is not fair, this is lovely food at its price. On top of this, which is largely enough, the place is family owned and run entirely by women....big up!

excerpts: so you are provided with an excuse to snuggle up close and
the hole-in-the-wall effect makes it an Alternate Universe-type feel.
Not to mention footing the bill would be an easy feat where meals are 5.25 a piece!
YAAYY YAMO!!!
up.author: Eri J.
up.review: This is a magical place :).  I (assume) and love that it is Woman-Owned and worked!!  Yamo is definitely a place worth providing business- the food is outrageously cheap and other than the oil used in cooking, everything is freshly chopped and prepared.  Really good first date material ;).  There isn't much room so you are provided with an excuse to snuggle up close and the hole-in-the-wall effect makes it an Alternate Universe-type feel.  Not to mention footing the bill would be an easy feat where meals are 5.25 a piece!  YAAYY YAMO!!!

excerpts: Stop in and saddle up to a bar stool and have a bowl of noodles - you won't be disappointed.
up.author: Anjali K.
up.review: Definitely order #15 with your choice of beef, chicken or shrimp.  I had the beef, but don't think you can go wrong any which way.  The noodles were delicious.  One bowl was definitely enough food for 1 person and in my opinion is shareable.  The food was cheap and just plain tasty.  I didn't try the tea salad, but heard good things from other patrons.  I plan on revisiting this nifty little spot on 18th street.  Stop in and saddle up to a bar stool and have a bowl of noodles - you won't be disappointed.

excerpts: you walk in and pick up the menu and decide to wait it out and see if it is worthwhile - and so it was.
up.author: Marina K.
up.review:
it was soooo thrilling finding Yamo-  it was one of those times when you almost walk past the place because its so obscure you would never think to peek inside - barely any sign that its the place you were looking for - staking your hopes on a satisfying meal to this little door with a light on a dark street - then you poke your head in and see that there's a person on every stool along the narrow 12 foot counter.  so this might have some promise after all.  you walk in and pick up the menu and decide to wait it out and see if it is worthwhile - and so it was.

we ordered the tea leaf salad, samusas, yamo house noodles with beef, and black bean fish.  I would recommend the tea leaf salad if you're interested in a surprisingly crunchy and spicy salad. the samusas are cute crispy mini-versions of samosas with a plum-chili(?) dipping sauce.  Yamo house noodles with beef were the prize-winning dish with great flavor moist beef and crisp veggies.  

to top it all off the price was better than most places in the mission as noted in articles on their door.  worth the adventure to find it & now i will definitely go back.

*********
makes me want to sing a little song to a reggae tune: 
"yamo get some yamo~
yamo be alright~" :)

excerpts: I suggest to pre-order and bring your cash to pay up front.
There's only 8 seats approximately.
up.author: Hebert J.
up.review: For cheap good hole in the wall spot, you've come to the right place. It's a really good treat for dinner. I suggest to pre-order and bring your cash to pay up front. There's only 8 seats approximately.

excerpts: I go straight from the 16th Street BART station to Yamo, where the aunties serve up steaming noodles that taste exactly like home.
After a year of sampling everything on the menu, I still love it all.
The soups, though, are my favorites.
Chicken noodle soup that makes you say, dear god, what would life be like without coconut milk?
up.author: Caricia C.
up.review: I travel a lot for work.  When I get back into SFO after a long trip, I call Yamo  and put in an order.  I go straight from the 16th Street BART station to Yamo, where the aunties serve up steaming noodles that taste exactly like home.  After a year of sampling everything on the menu, I still love it all.  The soups, though, are my favorites.  Chicken noodle soup that makes you say, dear god, what would life be like without coconut milk?

excerpts: The black bean fish eventually arrived shortly after they realized their blunder, but it wasn't delicious enough to make up for the ridiculously long wait we endured.
I want my 2 hours back!
up.author: Cynthia F.
up.review:
I'm no stranger to hole-in-the-wall restaurants and the lack of service it entails. That doesn't bother me. I don't mind the wait in line either. The food was decent, but as others have mentioned, not truly Burmese. That's ok though. If I was just rating this place based solely on its food and cheapness, I would definitely give it a 4 star rating. 
I really wanted to like Yamo, but I really resent the fact that it took my bf and I nearly 2 hours to get our food so I can't bring myself to rate this place any higher than a 2. 
We ordered samosas, tea leaf salad, the house noodles, and black bean fish. 2 guys sat next to us 15 minutes later, ordered, and received their food 5 minutes later as we sat there hungrily staring at the samosas sitting in the deep fryer basket. Eventually, we received everything except for the fish. Where is it?? Ah-ha! I see it now, plated and ready to serve, except it got dumped in a to-go box. WTF? I tried to remain calm, but since I can understand Cantonese, I heard everything the ladies were saying in regards to our order. Apparently, one of them spaced out and gave our black bean fish to someone else who ordered after us. Time ticks by as we patiently waited for our black bean fish to arrive. Meanwhile, the 2 guys next to us finished eating, paid, left, and another couple sat next to us. It wasn't until this couple ordered and received their food that the ladies realized that we're still waiting on our last dish. 
The black bean fish eventually arrived shortly after they realized their blunder, but it wasn't delicious enough to make up for the ridiculously long wait we endured. I want my 2 hours back!

excerpts: Note that they close at 9:30 and up till that point there will be (as I said) a line out the door.
This place is no longer hidden, I'm just being a flurry on Yelp
up.author: Jake H.
up.review: this is actually like a 4.5.  It's great...it's my new neighborhood place.  I shouldn't even write a review...there is already a line out the door.  My only drawback is that they have such a limited menu.  There's alot of overlap on tastes.  They have a menu of about 15 things and apparently they are all good.  I personally recco the yamo house noodles with pork and the tea salad.  Note that they close at 9:30 and up till that point there will be (as I said) a line out the door.  This place is no longer hidden, I'm just being a flurry on Yelp

excerpts: Some people might wonder how it stands up to more sophisticated fare, but they should be wondering about whatever happened to their souls?
up.author: Paul J.
up.review: This is that awesome food your mom made if you had a Burmese mom. Some people might wonder how it stands up to more sophisticated fare, but they should be wondering about whatever happened to their souls?

excerpts: Since ive been without a job Ive been extremely tight with my nightly drunken eats, that being said ive been a huge fan of the mexican taquerias here in the mission.. on my way to one of my usual suspects i saw a few elderly asian women slaving over a small stove- producing what appeared to be 5 star food in a dingy little cave, the equivalent of the red light district of asian grills, i remember many people huddled up waiting for the bar which sits about 6 to 8 people depending on your size and age.. after a half hour wait i come in and with one eye closed point to a coconut which i vaguely remember drinking and enjoying..
i proceed to eat a tea leaf salad, excessive amounts of noodles (which to this day i salivate when i think about) and leaving fully satisfied for less than 12 dollars!)
to sum this dive up- affordable fine dining in a dingy atmosphere with the perk of good looking asian women who don't fuck you about
up.author: Kyle B.
up.review: Since ive been without a job Ive been extremely tight with my nightly drunken eats, that being said ive been a huge fan of the mexican taquerias here in the mission.. on my way to one of my usual suspects i saw a few elderly asian women slaving over a small stove- producing what appeared to be 5 star food in a dingy little cave, the equivalent of the red light district of asian grills, i remember many people huddled up waiting for the bar which sits about 6 to 8 people depending on your size and age.. after a half hour wait i come in and with one eye closed point to a coconut which i vaguely remember drinking and enjoying..  i proceed to eat a tea leaf salad, excessive amounts of noodles (which to this day i salivate when i think about) and leaving fully satisfied for less than 12 dollars!) to sum this dive up- affordable fine dining in a dingy atmosphere with the perk of good looking asian women who don't fuck you about

excerpts: When that, plus the black bean fish, house noodles with chicken, samusas, fresh coconut juice, and a soda costs you just over $22, you end up wondering if you're still in the city.
Not the best tasting ever, but still fresh, very tasty and cheap.
Love it.
up.author: Maximillian M.
up.review: Probably one of the most awesome hole-in-the-wall joints in the entire city! The tea leaf salad is particularly awesome. When that, plus the black bean fish, house noodles with chicken, samusas, fresh coconut juice, and a soda costs you just over $22, you end up wondering if you're still in the city. Not the best tasting ever, but still fresh, very tasty and cheap. Love it.

excerpts: The tea salad didn't live up to others I have had.
The brightness of flavors wasn't there - it was more spicy than anything.
Food was good overall
and I will return when I am in the area.
I'd like to give them 3.5 stars.
up.author: T-Bone L.
up.review: The tea salad didn't live up to others I have had.  The brightness of flavors wasn't there - it was more spicy than anything.  Food was good overall and I will return when I am in the area.  I'd like to give them 3.5 stars.

excerpts: I liked the dingy, cramped environment, but you've got to back it up with good food.
If I want a low-cost, throw-down meal, Taqueria Cancun is right up the street for christsake!
Torn between 2 and 3 stars--the food was definitely 2 star, plus one for the quaintness, minus one for my disappointment.
up.author: ShivaMatt L.
up.review: I really wanted to like this place because I like to express my unique hipness and non-conformist attitude by frequenting little hole-in-the-wall dives, but alas, I think a hole in the wall in a Castro restroom might prove more satisfying.  The food was mediocre at best, though it was cheap and served in abundance.  I liked the dingy, cramped environment, but you've got to back it up with good food.  If I want a low-cost, throw-down meal, Taqueria Cancun is right up the street for christsake!  Torn between 2 and 3 stars--the food was definitely 2 star, plus one for the quaintness, minus one for my disappointment.

excerpts: This place is a giant unapologetically greasy kitchen with a counter that serves up a quick and tasty deal.
I loves it.
up.author: Yeeman N.
up.review: Who doesn't like cheap good eats?  Or hole in the wall spots run by little asian women who answer the phone loudly?  This place is a giant unapologetically greasy kitchen with a counter that serves up a quick and tasty deal.  I loves it.

excerpts: the fish curry chowder was watery and tasted like perfume (in a bad way), the house noodles were kinda greasy and bland, and the tea leaf salad was so-so (again, not up to par compared to other varieties i've had).
up.author: cristina s.
up.review: you know, i reallly reallllly wanted to love this place. the food is very inexpensive (pro), but was weak compared to other delicious burmese restaurants i've patronized. the fish curry chowder was watery and tasted like perfume (in a bad way), the house noodles were kinda greasy and bland, and the tea leaf salad was so-so (again, not up to par compared to other varieties i've had).

excerpts: nothing sriracha can't doctor up though.
up.author: Sheri N.
up.review:
the food is extremely budget friendly, and the portions reflect the price -- just enough to get you to the point of satiety, but you get what you pay for for $5.25.

their curry is a bit oily for my likings.  i do like their house noodles.  the tea leaf salad is gorgeous, and they will make it w/out the shrimp upon request.  i have yet to try their soups.  i thought that their black bean tofu dish was a bit bland.  nothing sriracha can't doctor up though.

excerpts: The place is really really small, so the room tends to fill up rather quickly.
It's a perfect place when you're with a friend and want something fairly fast and on the move.
up.author: Kevin D.
up.review: I love this place. I'll make it fast. It's cheap and the food is awesome!! I'm a fan of the curry chicken with noodles. Toss in freshly opened coconut juice and I'm totally happy(wallet too). The place is really really small, so the room tends to fill up rather quickly. It's a perfect place when you're with a friend and want something fairly fast and on the move.

excerpts: i always passed this up before cause its so small and on a side street off mission .... everything was very good .. and very fresh/hot off the oven ...
somosas were spice and good .. and the house noodles were some of the best ive ever had .
def going back !
up.author: Micah W.
up.review: great hole in the wall secret spot for cheap eats !! went here w my friend the other day .. i always passed this up before cause its so small and on a side street off mission .... everything was very good .. and very fresh/hot off the oven ... somosas were spice and good .. and the house noodles were some of the best ive ever had . def going back !

excerpts: At first i wanted fried rice but ended up ordering the Yamo house noodles.
The noodles were actually good, it looked like it was a tiny serving
but it actually filled me up.
I ordered the spring roll and saved it for a late night snack.
The lil old lady was pretty nice and quick when she took my order.
I took my fpod home cause the place was already full, i would def come back and try something else on the menu.
up.author: Lucky M.
up.review: As i walked to my regular smoke shop on the corner of mission and 18th, i was starving and wanted something quick and cheap. i stumbled by YAMO. I had no clue where the exact location of the place was until last night. The place is tiny, and i am serious, tiny. It fits about 8 people or less.
