The menu was small but cheap, i was shocked that they had spring/summer rolls(whatever you wanna call it). At first i wanted fried rice but ended up ordering the Yamo house noodles. The noodles were actually good, it looked like it was a tiny serving but it actually filled me up. I ordered the spring roll and saved it for a late night snack. The lil old lady was pretty nice and quick when she took my order. I took my fpod home cause the place was already full, i would def come back and try something else on the menu.

excerpts: I don't think it's anything special, but I'm rather biased since I've grown up eating Burmese food.
I feel like the only reason the restaurant is popular is because it's cheap and it's different.
If you don't know what real Burmese food is supposed to taste like, I think you'd like Yamo.
It's not bad, but not authentic or flavorful enough for my taste.
up.author: Jessica M.
up.review:
The Place:
I had a bit of trouble finding the place. When I first saw it, I thought the restaurant was condemned and closed for business. The entire place consisted of a room about half the size of a classroom with a bar in the middle. On one side there's eight seats (good luck number for Chinese people), and on the other side there are the elderly chefs. They don't spend any money on making the place fancy. I went on a Monday at around 5:00, and all the seats were filled (but like I said, there aren't many seats).

The Service:
I went for an early dinner so it wasn't crowded. One lady took my order, and she conversed with us in Burmese. Unfortunately speaking in Mandarin (no, it's NOT Cantonese) or Burmese does not get bigger portions or special treatment. Darn. The food was quick, though not much attention was paid towards the customers.

The Food:
I don't consider Yamo's food real Burmese food, but then again I don't think Burma Superstar's food is real Burmese food. Yamo's food is cheap and is geared towards an American audience. It's very cheap ($3.50 for appetizers and $5.25 for entrees), but the food is nothing special. Portions could be bigger. Their samusas were very small, the type you can find frozen at Ranch 99 or Pacific Super. The Yamo House Noodles (or garlic noodles, as I know them to be called) could have used more flavor. The presentation was lovely, but the taste was lacking. The mango chicken wasn't anything special either. It's on about the same level as Panda Express. I was a bit disappointed with the food and the limited selection, but I figure the chefs are friends from temple who decided to go into a little business together.

All in All:
I didn't have very high expectations, but Yamo was decent. It was cheap and pretty good for the price. I don't think it's anything special, but I'm rather biased since I've grown up eating Burmese food. I feel like the only reason the restaurant is popular is because it's cheap and it's different. If you don't know what real Burmese food is supposed to taste like, I think you'd like Yamo. It's not bad, but not authentic or flavorful enough for my taste.

excerpts: Keep in mind that we did show up at around 6pm on a Monday night when I'm guessing there are loads of lazy people (like us) who can't be arsed cooking!
We had to wait in line for about 25 minutes before we could even order.....
then when we finally got a chance to order, the girl answered the phone right in the middle of it and took someone elses order!
harumph.
They told us twenty minutes wait for the food
- it was more like 40....
it was really hot and sweaty inside but really cold outside (hellooooo san francisco).
The spring rolls were AWESOME - will definitely get those as a snacky when I'm walking home from work.
The rest of the food was alright - not very flavourful and didn't really hit the "i'm in a noodle mood" spot.........
Price was great - $36 for an order of potstickers (6), 3 orders of spring rolls (6), chicken curry, fried rice, chow mein, vege curry and house noodles..
up.author: B P.
up.review: Keep in mind that we did show up at around 6pm on a Monday night when I'm guessing there are loads of lazy people (like us) who can't be arsed cooking!  We had to wait in line for about 25 minutes before we could even order.....then when we finally got a chance to order, the girl answered the phone right in the middle of it and took someone elses order!  harumph. The rest of the food was alright - not very flavourful and didn't really hit the "i'm in a noodle mood" spot.........Price was great - $36 for an order of potstickers (6), 3 orders of spring rolls (6), chicken curry, fried rice, chow mein, vege curry and house noodles..

excerpts: i found yamo accidentally, cruising up mission to country station.
i had never even noticed it before, but there it was, a ghostly apparition.
it was a hole in the wall for sure, and i immediately felt like i was back in asia, where food is cheap, well seasoned, and satisfying.
up.author: pizzazz g.
up.review:
i found yamo accidentally, cruising up mission to country station. i had never even noticed it before, but there it was, a ghostly apparition. it was a hole in the wall for sure, and i immediately felt like i was back in asia, where food is cheap, well seasoned, and satisfying. the tea salad is definitely the standout dish, i order it every time i go there. with all its little crunchy, nutty surprises i could probably eat a few pounds of it before my mouth got bored. follow that with a sweet fresh coconut and you are good to go.

the ladies who work there are friendly and pretty fast. i've gotten there when it was full and thought, "oh, shit. this will take forever," but i've never had a really long wait like you would at the superstar. plus it's in my hood! and really, it is such a deal, you could order several dishes and totally pig out for less than $20. for two people! it's probably not for everyone, and it's definitely not gourmet, but it is good cheap eats.

excerpts: The salad looks small but fills you up fine.
Cheap and yummy- can be slow when place is full.
up.author: Leslie C.
up.review: I love YAMO! The tea leaf salad is an indescribable melange of delicious flavors, and the Yamo cold noodles aren't really cold at all. The salad looks small but fills you up fine. Cheap and yummy- can be slow when place is full.

excerpts: You can belly up to the counter and the two women that run the joint will make you feel right at home.
Everything tastes fresh and the quality of the food is high.
You get a lot of bang for your buck.
A great place with a comfy feel.
up.author: Ben V.
up.review: Truly awesome!  Little hole in the wall in the Mission.  You can belly up to the counter and the two women that run the joint will make you feel right at home.  Everything tastes fresh and the quality of the food is high.  You get a lot of bang for your buck.  A great place with a comfy feel.

excerpts: Mango chicken and prawn curry also get thumbs up.
Also, pot stickers are the best I've ever had especially when dipped in the spicy sauce.
up.author: Andy L.
up.review: Great comfort food. I was tired of having to schlep out to the sunset for some good asian food. Yamo house noodles can get greasy at times but the food is pretty consistent for a great price. Mango chicken and prawn curry also get thumbs up. Also, pot stickers are the best I've ever had especially when dipped in the spicy sauce.

excerpts: If you are in a rush, call in your order for pick up.
I do not recommend getting the noodles to go, as by the time you get them home, they are all sticky and dry.
up.author: Michael T.
up.review: So I come here as often as I can. Prices are $5.25 for each plate. The somosa are good as well. I have not had anything bad here. If you are in a rush, call in your order for pick up. I do not recommend getting the noodles to go, as by the time you get them home, they are all sticky and dry.

excerpts: A women promptly picked up the phone and yelled "yamo" at me, I said, "how late are you open?".
She replied, "9:30" and hung up.

We got on some bikes and road down to the mission with a 5 dollar bottle of sparkling Spanish wine from TJs, a corkscrew, and a couple yellow laminated paper cups: this blog might be recent (and sporadic) but I have been BYOBing all over this state for many years
and I think self-service is always a good call.
We got there in 7 minutes and secured the bikes to a locked gate of the adjacent storefront.
I think this is the way to go in this hood, on this rather dark un-traficked stretch of 18th.
There appears to be a pretty constant cluster of people waiting outside to sit down or pick up food, having the bike as close as possible to the entrance makes sense.
Denny's" it up for you shows a lack of sophistication and empathy.
up.author: Aaron Taylor H.
up.review:
Well, the three hundred and eleven Yelp reviews turn out to not be wrong.

After the first attempt was curbed by what seems to have been a random unscheduled closing we decided to give it another go but this time with a call ahead. A women promptly picked up the phone and yelled "yamo" at me, I said, "how late are you open?". She replied, "9:30" and hung up. We got on some bikes and road down to the mission with a 5 dollar bottle of sparkling Spanish wine from TJs, a corkscrew, and a couple yellow laminated paper cups: this blog might be recent (and sporadic) but I have been BYOBing all over this state for many years and I think self-service is always a good call. We got there in 7 minutes and secured the bikes to a locked gate of the adjacent storefront. I think this is the way to go in this hood, on this rather dark un-traficked stretch of 18th. There appears to be a pretty constant cluster of people waiting outside to sit down or pick up food, having the bike as close as possible to the entrance makes sense.

From the street Yamo is basically invisible, perhaps 8 feet of storefront with no signage. (There is a blank white panel where there should be a sign which makes a very effective signifier (in this case, Yamo is the "signified"); absolutely appropriate for a place that will probably be full via word-of-mouth no matter what they put out front.) We waited for about 15 minutes and popped the Lambrusco Dell'Emilia Bianco (see picture) it was pretty sweet but nice and bubbly, just fine for a paper cup and a concrete ledge.

Once inside we sat down mid bar and enjoyed the atmosphere. Yamo reminds me of Taipei in a major way, grimy and tiny with grumpy people yelling behind the counter. There was a giant sign on the wall saying "no outside alcohol", but that is where the opaque cups and the oversized shoulder bag come in handy. We had no problem with the under-counter fill ups. There was no pressure to order, which I thought was impressive for a tiny place with a line out front.

We ordered :
Fermented Tea Leaf Salad : It was phenomenally bright and tart. The cabbage was crispy and the nuts provided a fatty crunch that balanced the generous use of acids (lemon juice & rice vinegar?). I know that I will order this every time no matter what.
Fish Chowder: Had a definite curry undertone and a lovely, sort of powdery broth. There were little crispy bits in there too. I wouldn't miss this one either.
House Noodle, Chicken: So awesomely greasy with what I consider to to be the perfect asian noodle texture, sort of al-dente but totally slippery. I was a bigger fan of this than my partner in crime was. She preferred the soup.

The wine was actually a great, light compliment to the spicy/greasy-ness, we finished the bottle and felt great. The entire affair cost less than 30 bucks!

Read yelp for more on the food, or just go with your paper cups in the bag.

ATH


And, as a final thought: what is the deal with people complaining about staff at restaurants not smiling? I don't go into a place, especially a place like Yamo, looking for a new friend. The service here is efficient and aware. Our waters were refilled and when we left without drinking our jelly juice the lady behind the counter insisted we not forget a straw. When people are working they don't generally smile. To withhold an additional Yelp star because a two person restaurant staff, that is accomplishing all tasks involved in serving, prepping, and cleaning, doesn't "Denny's" it up for you shows a lack of sophistication and empathy.

excerpts: Since the seating is pretty limited, I'm a big fan of calling in an order and picking it up to eat at home.
up.author: A E.
up.review:
If you're longing to relive your experiences traveling through Southeast Asia, eating at a roadside where the bus stopped, this is the place.  I haven't been to any place in the states that takes me back in the same way.

Best bets on the menu, for me are the Salads (Mango or Chicken, I've never had the Tea leaf because its hard enough to choose between the two, I don't need a third option) and the Soups (Chicken Coconut Noodle or the Fish Chowder).

Since the seating is pretty limited, I'm a big fan of calling in an order and picking it up to eat at home.

excerpts: i wondered what the hype was whenever I walked home and saw a line - lives up!
up.author: Marisa W.
up.review: so awesome!!! and a great price!  i wondered what the hype was whenever I walked home and saw a line - lives up!

excerpts: I figured I'd asked the young helper what was up since she probably spoke better english, and she said (in broken english)...
Wait on vegetable's".
We didn't mind the wait since it was a nice night out
and we'd had a beer.
up.author: Malcolm K.
up.review: we ordered and I asked how long it would be and the old woman who yells instead of talks said it would be 15 min.  We went and had a beer and came back about 20 min later and it wasn't ready.  I figured I'd asked the young helper what was up since she probably spoke better english, and she said (in broken english)... "Wait on vegetable's".  We didn't mind the wait since it was a nice night out and we'd had a beer.  We ordered the mango salad, tea salad, and vegetable curry.  We were handed our food and left without checking that it was the right dishes.  We got home and discovered that we got both salads, but we got the vegetable stir fry instead, and she threw in and charged us for spring roles, which we didn't order. the salads were tasty, but they kind of made my stomach hurt, and the vegetable stirfry was nasty, fried, watery, oily, yuck.  All in all if I'm looking for some cheap eats I would not go back to this place, or at least I wouldn't order take out.

excerpts: The atmosphere, while cozy and quaint in that belly-up to the counter kind of way, was overrun by the heavy scent of deep fried oil air.
Yes, I"m talking stuff-ee.
The price was nice and low but for what we got I'd have been disappointed paying anything more.
I really would never go back there.
The greasy air spoiled it for me.
So for those of you who are bummed about the "hot on yelp" ruining your favorite spot, maybe you'll forgive me for not sharing in your Yamo joy.
All I can say is, you can have this favorite spot back, all to yourself, because I will not be returning.
up.author: Kelly S.
up.review: Ok, for those of you who love Yamo and it's your favorite spot please take no offense to my review. The beauty of Yelp is that we can all have our own opinions. I read about Yamo on yelp and since I love me some Burmese food I had to check it out, along with two of my foodie friends who have the utmost appreciation for divey-food. We didn't have high expectations but we were hopeful that we'd enjoy it. To be honest I was disappointed. The food was just not that great. The atmosphere, while cozy and quaint in that belly-up to the counter kind of way, was overrun by the heavy scent of deep fried oil air. Yes, I"m talking stuff-ee.  The price was nice and low but for what we got I'd have been disappointed paying anything more. I really would never go back there. The greasy air spoiled it for me. So for those of you who are bummed about the "hot on yelp" ruining your favorite spot, maybe you'll forgive me for not sharing in your Yamo joy. All I can say is, you can have this favorite spot back, all to yourself, because I will not be returning.

excerpts: I thought we were done, but ended up ordering some Samusas to go.
The sauce provided definitely had a kick to it!
We thought a yogurt based sauce might go nicer, but they were still quite good.
I'm definitely coming back here though!
up.author: Allan H.
up.review: The GF & I decided to stop by here for lunch based on the glowing reviews (and the fact that we were out in the Mission already).  We almost walked right by the place - it's a hole in the wall place, meant in the best way possible.  The awning of the place was barely legible but we could roughly make out Yamo on there.  We stepped inside and take a seat at the counter.  Almost everything on the menu (aside from drinks) is priced at $5.25 and $3.50 for appetizers.  One of the ladies behind the counter suggested the Yamo Cold Noodles, so I got that and the GF got the Yamo House Noodles.  We also got an order of the freshly made spring rolls.  I personally love places where you get to see what's going on in the kitchen and in this joint, you definitely have a front row seat.  The spring rolls were tasty, big & fresh!  The noodle dishes were very good too.  The taste of the Yamo House Noodles reminded me of noodles I would make at a Mongolian BBQ place.  My Yamo Cold Noodles had just enough spicy kick to keep you wanting more.  I thought we were done, but ended up ordering some Samusas to go.  The sauce provided definitely had a kick to it!  We thought a yogurt based sauce might go nicer, but they were still quite good.  I'm definitely coming back here though!

excerpts: Kelvin temperatures aside, the food Taiway dishes up is heavenly: healthy, colorful and o so delicioso.
I recommend the mango spring rolls.
They're practically a meal in themselves.
They're so of another world
I'd mug somebody for 'em.
Yup, that's right.
Stick em up" I'd say...
"And
give me some of that goodness in there with the mango and the beans and the crazy Thai sauces and all the spicey roots and shit
I'm not sure I'm even supposed to eat.
The curries are also delicious.

Taiway's always got a great flick on, so if your Match.com date turns out to be a dullard, you can watch some Bruce Lee classics and mentally work on your karate moves you've so diligently been practicing in the safety of your own room.
Secret: that last statement does not refer to me.
Secret: there is a lie somewhere in this review.
Secret: bring your own beer, and be ready to pour a little out for your homie behind the counter...
up.author: Cpt. Scallywag N.
up.review: "I would like one fire in my mouth please!" is what I say when I've got Yamo on the brain. This quaint little Mission Thai spot might be just be a miniature sun....cuz the food is packin heat! Kelvin temperatures aside, the food Taiway dishes up is heavenly: healthy, colorful and o so delicioso. I recommend the mango spring rolls. They're practically a meal in themselves. They're so of another world I'd mug somebody for 'em. Yup, that's right. "Stick em up" I'd say..."And give me some of that goodness in there with the mango and the beans and the crazy Thai sauces and all the spicey roots and shit I'm not sure I'm even supposed to eat." The curries are also delicious. Taiway's always got a great flick on, so if your Match.com date turns out to be a dullard, you can watch some Bruce Lee classics and mentally work on your karate moves you've so diligently been practicing in the safety of your own room. Secret: that last statement does not refer to me. Secret: there is a lie somewhere in this review. Secret: bring your own beer, and be ready to pour a little out for your homie behind the counter...

excerpts: i chatted with the ladies one time and found out they're from macau, former portuguese colony next to hong kong... which doesn't really clear it up all that much.
we always end up having the noodle soups here due to foggy sf nights.
get it to go if you're squeamish about not-super-clean interiors.
up.author: Angi C.
up.review: yumo yamo...where else can you find yummy noodle dishes for about $5 in the city? is it thai? is it burmese? who knows? i chatted with the ladies one time and found out they're from macau, former portuguese colony next to hong kong... which doesn't really clear it up all that much. we always end up having the noodle soups here due to foggy sf nights. get it to go if you're squeamish about not-super-clean interiors.

excerpts: Yes, if you phone in an order for take out, they don't even ask your name but just say, "thank you, bye" and hang up, and your order is rarely ever ready when you come to pick it up at the time they tell you, but so what?
What are you in such a big hurry for anyways?
up.author: Evan J.
up.review: Ok, there's really no good reason why I haven't written a review of this place months ago, as it is currently my favorite restaurant and has held the honor of that distinction longer than most. There is a "bad reason", however-a selfish one that I'm a little ashamed of: I'm not sure I want any more people going there! It's so small already, with literally no tables, just a counter with 7 or 8 seats. These seats are often full if you go at prime time; lunch hour or any time after 5 pm, although turn over is usually fast. I've since realized, though that the limited seating of this place is one of the aspects, along with a slight language/culture barrier, and a "smudginess" due to the exhaust from the cooking surfaces right behind the counter, that has allowed the prices at this place to remain low, and for it to keep off the mainstream restaurant radar, which is just fine with me. I'll gladly accept backless stools, huff a bit of grease-fire smoke, and sometimes wonder at momentarily non existent service (the only reason I didn't give it 5 stars), for truly wonderful and authentic Southeast Asian food and an almost transporting genuine asian street food style experience at dirt cheap prices. You go ahead and go to your fancy restaurants where they have actual tables and where you don't sit in the kitchen because I'll be just fine here where the fermented tea leaf salad kicks the frickin pants off the one at Burma Super Star, with it's array of way more exotic and tasty additions, like nuts I've never seen before and do not know the names of. Yes, if you phone in an order for take out, they don't even ask your name but just say, "thank you, bye" and hang up, and your order is rarely ever ready when you come to pick it up at the time they tell you, but so what? What are you in such a big hurry for anyways? Take some time to stop and smell the Yamo house noodles, man. Because I can tell you with dead certainty they're equally good with pork, beef, or chicken.

excerpts: I always end up ordering the house noodles, but have tried a couple other dishes.
up.author: Nadia T.
up.review: I went here a couple years ago for the first time with a friend, and have returned many times since then.  The tiny, almost hard-to-miss, place has a few seats and the food is cooked right in front of you.  It's hard to beat the prices and the deliciousness of the food.  I always end up ordering the house noodles, but have tried a couple other dishes.

excerpts: The only downside is that it has counter seating only and fills up fast -- try your luck and you might be rewarded with one of the tastiest and cheapest holes-in-the-wall in the Mission.
up.author: Dan I.
up.review: When I want a good bite, lunch or dinner, in the heart of the mission, this place is always high on the list -- the tea-leaf salad is tops and the noodles are fresh-to-order and garlicky good.  The only downside is that it has counter seating only and fills up fast -- try your luck and you might be rewarded with one of the tastiest and cheapest holes-in-the-wall in the Mission.

excerpts: Pull up to the bar, that is, if you get there early enough or you don't mind waiting in line so you'll eventually have your chance to experience the environment at its best.
Simple menu with excellent prices, tight quarters
so you better not mind sitting right next to others, only visuals are watching the 3 women proprietors knowing exactly where to find the particular food or drink item is that they need.
We order the House noodles with Chicken but needed to spice it up just a little with some hot sauce.
We also had the curry prawns with veggies.
It was not very "currish" which was ok because sometimes restaurants can use too much curry.
We ordered pot stickers that came out steaming hot and needed some cooling time so we could eat it
but we were a little impatient.
The people next to us got the Coconut chicken noodle soup and it looked/
smelt wonderful!
We'll be back....
but very early to make sure we get seated right away!
up.author: P G.
up.review: This is the "Cheers" of the Mission area, except NO alcohol! Pull up to the bar, that is, if you get there early enough or you don't mind waiting in line so you'll eventually have your chance to experience the environment at its best. Simple menu with excellent prices, tight quarters so you better not mind sitting right next to others, only visuals are watching the 3 women proprietors knowing exactly where to find the particular food or drink item is that they need. We order the House noodles with Chicken but needed to spice it up just a little with some hot sauce. We also had the curry prawns with veggies. It was not very "currish" which was ok because sometimes restaurants can use too much curry. We ordered pot stickers that came out steaming hot and needed some cooling time so we could eat it but we were a little impatient.  The people next to us got the Coconut chicken noodle soup and it looked/smelt wonderful! We'll be back....but very early to make sure we get seated right away!

excerpts: , tea leave salad (very spicy and delicious), black bean tofu, and black bean fish, but have to say I haven't tried much I didn't like here.
The simple meals and environment makes this one of the best place to grab a bite with anyone.
black bean tofu.author: Rad R.
black bean tofu.review: One of my favorite places in the city to eat. It has great service though a little terse lol. Everything on the menu is under 10 and you can easily get a great lunch for 7. My favorites on the menu are the House noddles, tea leave salad (very spicy and delicious), black bean tofu, and black bean fish, but have to say I haven't tried much I didn't like here. The simple meals and environment makes this one of the best place to grab a bite with anyone.

excerpts: My friend and I ordered tea leaf salad and black bean tofu.
The tea leaf salad arrived first, a paltry portion (about a 1/4-1/3 of a cup).
The salad lacked any of the complexity that is found in good renditions.
This salad's flavor was one-dimensional without pronounced textural contrasts.
We hoped the black bean tofu would taste better, but it was just bland and under salted.
Between the mediocre food, the surly service, and the dingy atmosphere, I won't return.
black bean tofu.author: Nina C.
black bean tofu.review: I was excited to have Burmese food again, but my excitement was short lived at Yamo. This restaurant is a small, independent restaurant with counter-only seating and an open kitchen. My friend and I ordered tea leaf salad and black bean tofu. The tea leaf salad arrived first, a paltry portion (about a 1/4-1/3 of a cup). The salad lacked any of the complexity that is found in good renditions. This salad's flavor was one-dimensional without pronounced textural contrasts. We hoped the black bean tofu would taste better, but it was just bland and under salted. Between the mediocre food, the surly service, and the dingy atmosphere, I won't return.

excerpts: Black bean tofu didn't really do much for me, meh.
black bean tofu.author: Shereen A.
black bean tofu.review:
Came here last night because I was trying to find something that would hit the spot. Luckily there were only 4 people ahead of us and two wanted take out. We asked how long the wait was, got a cold stare and no response. Okay then!! We waited for about 25 minutes for a seat.

Let me put this into perspective. There's 8 bar stools in a cramped little location almost the size of a long hallway. There's more kitchen space than there is seating (which is understandable). So as we are waiting, we are literally standing behind other people that are eating, hovering, really.

As we waited for a table, we placed our order so once seated they could start cooking right away. 

So let's chat about something else while we wait to be seated. Service. I could not stop laughing at the way these ladies bark and yell at people. SERIOUSLY! Someone walks in and asks to place a to go order, "WHATYOUWANT?????" Lady taking the order writes down whatever sloppily then YELLS the dollar amount. No smile, no thank you, nothing. You don't come here for customer service. They are just outright rude, totally curt, and I find it hilarious. Forget special treatment, no one here gets any treatment! 

In the meantime, there's one stool available and this guy dining on his own asks if he could take it. Sure, we are waiting for 2 stools anyways. As soon as he sits down, another barking lady yells at him to get out and wait in line because there are others in front of him (even though everyone in front of him is ordering takeout). He's finally seated when he gets to the front of the line.

Also, there's some kind of sticky dripping substance that falls from the ceiling periodically. If it falls into your hair, pretty much plan on cutting it. I'm not joking. After repeated hair washing, it's still stuck (and this is many hours later). I'll have to cut it for him once he gets back from work.

We finally sit down, and samosas follow within ten or so minutes. So freaking delicious. I'm not a huge fan of the chunky samosas filled with globs of potato and peas. The thin, crispy, perfectly folded triangles are my favorite. They were served HOT HOT HOT with some sweet and spicy chili sauce. I could have eaten double the order!

Next up, the tea leaf salad. While not as good as Burma Superstar (a bit sweeter) it was still delicious and had an awesome crunch. 

Black bean tofu didn't really do much for me, meh. I prefer the Burmese food here more than the Chinese.

The house noodles were my favorite. Such a simple dish, yet insanely flavorful, I couldn't stop eating it (and yes, we were sharing). Fresh noodles, garlicky, light, saucy, what more can you ask for? 

Didn't try any meat dishes this time around but if the vegetarian options are THIS good, I can't wait to come back and stuff my face with some fish, beef, and chicken.

Since you're practically sitting IN a kitchen, you will smell like grease when you leave, and for hours later. We ended up getting gelato and drinks after and apologized for being smelly to the people we hung out with. Your eyes will also burn for the duration of your stay since there's no ventilation but...it's all worth it, especially watching the barking staff yell at you and everyone who wants to eat their food.  "WHAT YOU WANT?? RAAAAA"

There's no shrimp, clearly indicated by the cartoon shrimp pictures hanging in three locations. If you ask for it, you will be yelled at, "NOSHRIMP!!!!!!! BAAH!! NOO SHRIMP!!!!"

This is America, no one puts up with crappy customer service. But trust me! Here, you will, it's such a scene!

"CASH ONLY, RAAAAAAAAAA!!!!"

excerpts: Me and my friend got vegetarian dishes which were mushroom tofu and the black bean tofu.
Both were good and came with rice.
We also got the tea leaf salad which a small but good.
It was a tad spicier for my friend, but we did like it.
I will say despite the spiciness, I have had a better version of this salad at another place.
The good thing is everything felt homemade.
black bean tofu.author: Andrew N.
black bean tofu.review:
My friend wanted to try this place during the slow times since there is no line. We actually were the only customers when we got there.

I will say that it felt like we were entering someone's house uninvited to ask for food. It was a unique vibe. The ladies weren't mean but weren't attentive at the same time. Again it's kind of like going to someone's house and waiting for food when you weren't expected to come. We did get our orders in and the food came out pretty quick after the ladies finished their prep.  When we were ordering, the lady made a joke that felt like it was an inside joke between the cooks about not giving me much vegetable as I requested extra. I sort of laughed but sort of got confused, so smh on that one.  I just laughed with them.

Me and my friend got vegetarian dishes which were mushroom tofu and the black bean tofu. Both were good and came with rice.  We also got the tea leaf salad which a small but good. It was a tad spicier for my friend, but we did like it. I will say despite the spiciness, I have had a better version of this salad at another place. The good thing is everything felt homemade. This place is definitely a mom and pop shop.

The biggest pro of this place is the prices are cheap, so that is what it has going. I would come back here again but not when there is a wait. If you want to try this place, I say go after 2 pm on a weekend.

excerpts: $19 for Yamo house noodles, tea leaf salad, and black bean tofu (all enough to feed 2 people).
black bean tofu.author: Stephanie T.
black bean tofu.review:
There's Burma Love, which is a pricey hipster amazing Burmese place in the Mission. A few blocks away: Burma Love's uglier, greasier, but cheaper sister. 

Cash only.
$19 for Yamo house noodles, tea leaf salad, and black bean tofu (all enough to feed 2 people).

This hole-in-the-wall spot is tiny, with just a few places to sit, making it ideal for a solo traveler wanting to get in/out, but more likely will suit the likes of take-out peeps. 

Get ready to blot your mouth (grease) and add some Sriracha (it's pretty mild) but as far as Burmese goes, this is definitely second-place to Burma Love. I have yet to try Burma Star, but will let you know how that one stacks-up once I know :)

excerpts: I ordered the black bean tofu take-out one afternoon for lunch.
It took a long time, the restaurant is cash only and the meal was very, very bland.
I don't like spicy food and this was so bland
I was searching all over for hot sauce to pour on it.
Based on this one meal, I wouldn't order or go to again.
However, you might have a different experience if you order what they're known for.
It is pretty cheap compared to many restaurants
so that's a plus.
black bean tofu.author: Hailey H.
black bean tofu.review:
I think this is the type of place where they have 1-2 AMAZING items (like the noodles) and you only order those when you go. 

I ordered the black bean tofu take-out one afternoon for lunch. It took a long time, the restaurant is cash only and the meal was very, very bland. I don't like spicy food and this was so bland I was searching all over for hot sauce to pour on it. Based on this one meal, I wouldn't order or go to again. However, you might have a different experience if you order what they're known for. It is pretty cheap compared to many restaurants so that's a plus.

excerpts: Yamo will always hold a special place in my heart as my First Meal in San Francisco - the potstickers and the black bean tofu entree, which I ordered to go and then ravenously ate in Dolores Park.
black bean tofu.author: Rachel H.
black bean tofu.review:
Yamo will always hold a special place in my heart as my First Meal in San Francisco - the potstickers and the black bean tofu entree, which I ordered to go and then ravenously ate in Dolores Park.

Terrible ventilation inside the restaurant (granted, my visit was during a "heat wave" of 82 degrees) and there is just counter space, but the food was tasty and the price was right.

excerpts: Husband got the black bean tofu, which was very good
but I like what I got more.
We also got the fresh spring rolls with peanut sauce.
Yum.
Nothing was too filling.
Perfect for lunch.
And the prices were LOW.
Would definitely go back.
black bean tofu.author: Kat R.
black bean tofu.review: If you're not looking for this place, you will never find it. It's a charming little hole in the wall, complete with swinging overhead lights as if a subway car was right above you, although it's quiet. Seating is a small bar that faces an open kitchen, where they cook everything fresh. The people that work there are courteous and sweet. I got the garlic house noodles. They were fabulous. Husband got the black bean tofu, which was very good but I like what I got more. We also got the fresh spring rolls with peanut sauce. Yum. Nothing was too filling. Perfect for lunch. And the prices were LOW. Would definitely go back.

excerpts: However, we also got the black bean tofu
black bean tofu.author: Rachel R.
black bean tofu.review:
Totally random stop in here and was a nice surprise.

Tiny, narrow restaurant that you can either pick up from or eat at the counter. While tiny, it seems like the seat turnover is fairly quick.

Recommendation - get the house noodles with pork! Super tasty and flavorful. However, we also got the black bean tofu and I was not very impressed with that dish.

Each main dish is $6 and that apparently includes tax - hurray!

P.S. I have the feeling this place is cash only. Lucky for you, you probably need no more than a $10 or a $20 if you feel like a banquet :)

excerpts: The  black bean tofu has a very tasty sauce and great tofu, though not much black bean taste.
My taste of the chicken mango was also better than expected, especially since this dish is usually too simple with low-quality chicken.
black bean tofu.author: Tom W.
black bean tofu.review:
As far as cheap hole-in-the-walls go, you can't do much better than Yamo.  For $5.25, you can get a wide range of dishes that taste better than you'd expect and are much fresher than you'd generally get at oily hole in the walls.  The menu is not as interesting as other Burmese restaurants, but the traditional options are very good for the price.  The tea leaf salad is very tasty, though not comparable to Burma Superstar's or Green Elephant Gourmet's.  The  black bean tofu has a very tasty sauce and great tofu, though not much black bean taste.  My taste of the chicken mango was also better than expected, especially since this dish is usually too simple with low-quality chicken.  Nothing tastes terribly unique, but it all tastes better than similar dishes.

There are about ten counter seats, so its not great for large groups.

excerpts: i love the cold house noodles and the black bean tofu.
dont go there with a big group or you will wait forever.
black bean tofu.author: Scott L.
black bean tofu.review: Soooo delicious.  i love the cold house noodles and the black bean tofu.  dont go there with a big group or you will wait forever.

excerpts: I almost always get the same thing: coconut soup with tofu or black bean tofu with noodles.
Man I wish that they would deliver...or have some sort of take out system that was efficient...
but I guess both of those would take away from the overall charm and unique experience that is Yamo.
black bean tofu.author: Jessie H.
black bean tofu.review:
I eat here once a week so basically this is like my other kitchen!  I almost always get the same thing: coconut soup with tofu or black bean tofu with noodles. 
Man I wish that they would deliver...or have some sort of take out system that was efficient...but I guess both of those would take away from the overall charm and unique experience that is Yamo.

excerpts: Black bean tofu could use more black bean sauce.
black bean tofu.author: Jack C.
black bean tofu.review:
Yamo is tucked away on a side street in the Mission district. This 8-seater, open kitchen boasts as a legit establishment for Burmese fast food. Inexpensive, filling, fresh. 

Black bean tofu could use more black bean sauce. 
Tea leaf salad has a nice flavor but it has too much oil for me. 

Interesting must have experience in The Mission. Suitable for quick meals, cheap eats and strange encounters. I met a patron who brings in his own eggs because according to him fried rice must have eggs in it.

excerpts: We ordered Samosas, Chow Mein (not too adventurous today), and Black Bean Tofu all for about $15.
All of them were really yummy.
Yamo made me say Yum-O.
(I know I'm quoting Rachel Ray
but it seems necessary here, no?).
If you don't mind sitting at the counter while they prepare your meal or if you want your food to go, check it out.
black bean tofu.author: Amy J.
black bean tofu.review: Now I know why there's a line out the door here. Every time we've tried to go here it was always on a Sunday and they're closed then. I'm glad we finally stopped in here. The ladies that work here work really hard to give you your food fast, tasty and hot. It's a tiny little hole in the wall, but it's definitely work seeking out. We ordered Samosas, Chow Mein (not too adventurous today), and Black Bean Tofu all for about $15. All of them were really yummy. Yamo made me say Yum-O. (I know I'm quoting Rachel Ray but it seems necessary here, no?). If you don't mind sitting at the counter while they prepare your meal or if you want your food to go, check it out.

excerpts: Try: tea salad, black bean tofu, veggie curry, fresh spring rolls (
black bean tofu.author: Suzanne S.
black bean tofu.review:
Yamo is not the best Burmese food around, but it's a great place for a no frills meal that is fresh, tasty, made to order, and *cheap*! It's a wonderful little oasis of tortilla-less cheap food in the mission.

The place is very unique, and some people may be turned off by the fact that it is literally a hole-in-the-wall.  For those people, I suggest taking it to go and eating it at home or in one of the nearby parks.

Despite the Tu-Lan-esque vibe, the food is always super fresh and not as greasy as you  might imagine (although I can't speak for meat dishes ) They make everything, even the fresh springrolls,  for you right in front of your eyes. And they've always agreed to make anything I've requested vegetarian for me, which means they fill it with a wonderful mix of familiar and unusual fresh veggies, herbs and/or tofu. yum.

Try: tea salad, black bean tofu, veggie curry, fresh spring rolls (peanut sauce is awesome), mango tofu, and fresh coconut juice!

All apps are $3.25 (and the spring rolls by themselves can be a great light lunch), entrees are $5.25. 

don't be turned off by the fact that it looks like it's closed or abandoned. it's definitely worth a try, especially if you live in the area.

excerpts: I ordered black bean tofu, it was good
but I think I will try something spicier next time.
I will definitely be back.
black bean tofu.author: Maddy F.
black bean tofu.review: Super yummy and the price is right!  I ordered black bean tofu, it was good but I think I will try something spicier next time.  I will definitely be back.

excerpts: The black bean tofu dish smelled so good too.
Really a fun place and cheap!
Not the best for a group of people.
black bean tofu.author: Sara D.
black bean tofu.review: A fantastic hole in the wall place with counter service. It really only fits about 10 people. The food is amazing. We got the curry, samosas, and noodles and they were all delicious. The black bean tofu dish smelled so good too. Really a fun place and cheap! Not the best for a group of people.

excerpts: i wasn't, like, utterly blown away by my black bean tofu dish, but i'll definitely go back again.
i'm curious about the house noodles.
black bean tofu.author: Elle B.
black bean tofu.review:
this cute hole-in-the-wall joint sells fresh, cheap food.  

i wasn't, like, utterly blown away by my black bean tofu dish, but i'll definitely go back again.  i'm curious about the house noodles.

excerpts: i thought that their black bean tofu dish was a bit bland.
black bean tofu.author: Sheri N.
black bean tofu.review:
the food is extremely budget friendly, and the portions reflect the price -- just enough to get you to the point of satiety, but you get what you pay for for $5.25.

their curry is a bit oily for my likings.  i do like their house noodles.  the tea leaf salad is gorgeous, and they will make it w/out the shrimp upon request.  i have yet to try their soups.  i thought that their black bean tofu dish was a bit bland.  nothing sriracha can't doctor up though.

excerpts: The black bean fish with noodles and a tea salad are hard to beat!
It is a very casual space and the women who work here make it a very homey atmosphere in a way where people are so comfortable with each other that they don't need to be polite.

If you bring outside beverages, sit too long (there's only a few bar stools and always a line of people waiting to sit), or do something else that isn't Yamo approved, then you will get yelled at to correct your behavior!
I personally love it and think they're doing a great job.
I always eat in vs getting take out to enjoy the experience.
The prices can't be beat for a big plate of tasty food.
black bean fish.author: Annelise P.
black bean fish.review: Love this spot, it is a go to quick meal in my neighborhood that never disappoints. The black bean fish with noodles and a tea salad are hard to beat! It is a very casual space and the women who work here make it a very homey atmosphere in a way where people are so comfortable with each other that they don't need to be polite. If you bring outside beverages, sit too long (there's only a few bar stools and always a line of people waiting to sit), or do something else that isn't Yamo approved, then you will get yelled at to correct your behavior! I personally love it and think they're doing a great job. I always eat in vs getting take out to enjoy the experience. The prices can't be beat for a big plate of tasty food.

excerpts: Black Bean Fish (4/5) -
Stir fried vegetables with black bean white fish, served with a bed of white rice.
As above, the wok hei flavor was legit.
Flavors were on deep and smokey.
Texture was crunchy and crispy.
black bean fish.author: Janice K.
black bean fish.review:
Chinese mom meets Seinfield's soup nazi. If you don't understand my Seinfield reference, go youtube this now. I assure you, it's hilarious. 

The Yamo experience is a mix of PTSD of every confusing childhood memory of being scolded combined with the pleasant memory of home cooked meals prepared by your Chinese mom. 

The food ranged from good to great (review below), but the experience of eating at Yamo was absolutely terrifying with a squeeze of comical. Upon entering the restaurant you'll be greeted by a very angry mama cook who seemly appears to yell at everyone: her daughter, the other mama cook and all patrons. Service is quick - you enter, you order your food while you wait to be seated - you get seated, and immediately the dishes you previously ordered are flung at you.  Yes, dishes are airborne for a few seconds before clattering loudly in front of you - maybe safe to have a napkin ready for the splash zone. 

Oh did you want to take a photo of your food? You better take it ninja style or ask permission to take "food photos only" because mama cook will scream at you from across the restaurant " NO PHOTOS". 

Did you want to enjoy your food over good conversation? Hopefully you've mastered the art of talking and inhaling food at the same time, otherwise, you'll get the stare down from mama cook if your chopsticks aren't forking food into your mouth while you're swallowing forcefully. Take a tip and skip the chewing because your bill will arrive in front of you shortly. After you pay - and remember cash only - you're thanked very loudly, but if you listen between the lines, mama cook's real thoughts are GTFO because you're holding up her business. 

We ate (each dish ~$6.25 pre tax): 

1. Tea Salad (2/5) - Burmese style salad mixed with fermented tea leaves. Salad comes premixed.The salad was more spicy and lemony than a typical Burmese tea salad, and peanuts were roasted/fried, but no longer crunchy. It was clear the salad was pre made and sitting in the fridge ready to be served. 

2. Mango Chicken (4/5) - Stir fried vegetables with mango and chicken, served with a bed of white rice. The "wok hei" or in english, "the breath of the wok"  was real- this dish had a complex smoky flavor that is only achieved by cooking fresh ingredients over extreme heat. The flavors of the chicken coated in sauce were deep, and the bell peppers and mango retained the textural crunch. Would have liked more than 3 pieces of chicken. 

3. Black Bean Fish (4/5) - Stir fried vegetables with black bean white fish, served with a bed of white rice. As above, the wok hei flavor was legit. Flavors were on deep and smokey. Texture was crunchy and crispy. Fish portion was could be larger. 

4. Yamo House Noodles (3/5) noodles mixed with garlic and a choice of beef, chicken or pork - ours was beef. Noodles were cooked almost al dante and heavily coated in oil, mixed with garlic and topped with a pinch of extremely salty beef crumbles. 

Overall: 

Food - 3.5/5 - Food here definitely has potential. On one hand the wok hei flavor is on point, on the other, portion sizes of protein is minimal and often too salty. Prices are cheap, which makes the value for food was a good bang for the buck in SF. 

Service 1/5- From my notes above, the experience at Yamo was conflicting. I was terrified from the moment I walked in, but also couldn't help uncontrollably laugh at the situation. There were some frequenters who came for take out and you can tell they've experienced the PTSD themselves and have learned better to just get take out. One after one, they'll come in and skip the banter, and just say the numbers of the dishes they wanted to order. Put down the money and with a slight bow retreat backwards out the door where they waited patiently until their meal was prepared. Pro tip: if you want to experience yamo without the PTSD, just come for take out. 

Environment 1/5- This rating is likely skewed from the notes above - but hard to enjoy a meal when you're feeling afraid. Minimal seating ~ 10, expect to wait 30+ mins if you come during regular meal hours. Definitely come on a pre laundry day because you'll walk out smelling like Yamo. 

Eat take out from here.

excerpts: My husband got the curry chicken, I got the black bean fish.
black bean fish.author: Jaki F.
black bean fish.review:
Best tea leaf salad I've ever had in my life & I know my way around a tea leaf salad. I think about this salad on a daily basis. Get the cold noodles. Melt in your mouth. How is it possible to eat well for less than $7 here? Idk but it is possible. Amazing. 

The girls behind the counter are quite rude, even if you're a regular. 

My husband got the curry chicken, I got the black bean fish. Both good but nothing to write home about. 

I'll be back next time I'm in town. Must visit!

excerpts: , tea leave salad (very spicy and delicious), black bean tofu, and black bean fish, but have to say I haven't tried much I didn't like here.
The simple meals and environment makes this one of the best place to grab a bite with anyone.
black bean fish.author: Rad R.
black bean fish.review: One of my favorite places in the city to eat. It has great service though a little terse lol. Everything on the menu is under 10 and you can easily get a great lunch for 7. My favorites on the menu are the House noddles, tea leave salad (very spicy and delicious), black bean tofu, and black bean fish, but have to say I haven't tried much I didn't like here. The simple meals and environment makes this one of the best place to grab a bite with anyone.

excerpts: Originally I wanted to order curry chicken with noodles, but after 10 seconds, I changed my mind and ordered black bean fish with rice, before they started cooking anything.
black bean fish.author: Jay J.
black bean fish.review:
I ate at Yamo twice. If I could give it a negative star, I would. 

Customer service. (-10)/5 star
Food.  2/5 star
Environment 1/5 star

At the first time, my frds and I decide to give Yamo a try because we saw the 4 star reviews 1500+. It can't be bad right? We were unpleasantly surprised by the small and smelly restaurant. The food was okay. We didn't think it was 4 star quality at all because the food was greasy and small in portion. 

As a well-traveled and well-educated foodie, I can only give it a maximum 2 star if you ask me. 
I think yelpers rate it higher than it should, probably because the food is cheap and they are surprised by the food made by two old burmese ladies working in a shitty-looking dump hole. 

Today in the afternoon, I was running errands in the mission district. I walked by Yamo and ordered takeout before I drove back to my studio. 

I was completely pissed off and upset about the customer service there. 

Originally I wanted to order curry chicken with noodles, but after 10 seconds, I changed my mind and ordered black bean fish with rice, before they started cooking anything.

The burmese lady with short gray hair was talking shit about me in burmese.  "Do you think he is chinese or taiwanese?" " He must be taiwanese because he was so annoying and troublesome." Shit talk went on.

I was completely shocked by how rude she was. Did I do something wrong? Did I do something unforgivable that she had to insult my ethnical background in Burmese? It was funny. They kept talking shit about customers because they thought I didn't understand their dialogue. 

I patiently waited outside Yamo for my food. When she was handing my takeout, I told her quietly,  "I actually understood what you said earlier. It was very rude." She rolled her eyes and gave me an offensive hand gesture. 
A middle-aged white customer asked me what happened. I told him briefly about what I heard and experienced from the burmese ladies.

The customer service was highly unprofessional, disrespectful and unbelievable. In the end, I was proud of myself confronting her in a polite manner. 

Food is supposed to bring happiness to people, not upset them. 

Never coming again.

excerpts:
Black Bean Fish: 3.5 stars
Pretty standard similar to Chinese restaurants, comforting.
black bean fish.author: Letitia L.
black bean fish.review:
Tiny, hole-in-wall place where you squeeze in, they whisk dishes away to signal for you to eat faster and 15 mins later you squeeze out.

Not as high quality food as the other famous Burmese restaurants in SF, but it's only $6 per dish. I also like that they have grass jelly drink!


---- DISHES ----

Tea Leaf Salad: 2.5 stars
Definitely not as good as Burma Love, Superstar. The good places use a concentrated tea leaf paste chock full of umami, this one was a watery tangy spicy sauce that missed the mark for me.

Fish Noodle Soup: 4.5 stars
(Mohinga curry) Comforting home cooked food.

Black Bean Fish: 3.5 stars
Pretty standard similar to Chinese restaurants, comforting. Would eat if ill.

Vegetable Curry: 3 stars
Bland but nice cardamom spice flavour. Good selection of veggies from zucchini to eggplant, mushroom okra cabbage broccoli carrot and green beans.

Cold Noodles: 3.5 stars
Spicy.

excerpts: Their Stir-Fried Black Bean Fish with Rice was good.
black bean fish.author: Tiffany D.
black bean fish.review:
Undeniably a hole in the wall that seats about 8-10 people for yummy, homely cooked Burmese entrees!  Just bring one other person with you!  It's impossible to fit a group together in here.

I felt like a compacted sardine while dining here at this grub spot, but the food was worthy to try!

The food is so cheap here - more or less 6 bucks each for appetizers or entrees.

I love their Tea Leaf Salad!  It was crunchy, tasty and unique.  Too bad the proportion of this salad is small.  It teased my palate.

Their Stir-Fried Black Bean Fish with Rice was good.  Spice it up with their side vinegar-ed, mini, chopped jalepenos and it will be smacking delicious!

As for their Yamo House Noodles with your choice of beef, chicken or pork, it was slurping good.  

My friend and I couldn't stay a bit to chat ever more after we finished our meals- we felt rushed with the fair line waiting outside!

excerpts: We got 2 tea leaf salads, 1 samosa order, 1 black bean fish with noodles, 1 house noodle, and 1 chicken curry.
black bean fish.author: Evelyn M.
black bean fish.review:
Amazing hole in the wall Burmese/Chinese food. We got 2 tea leaf salads, 1 samosa order, 1 black bean fish with noodles, 1 house noodle, and 1 chicken curry. All for $39 (not including tip).

I'd say the food is all around a 4 star rating, but the fact that it's run by 3 no-nonsense women, who are busting their butts with this small restaurant, makes it an overall 5 star for me.

They're also extremely nice, as my group of 4 walked in about 30 min until closing, and they encouraged us to stay like how an Asian grandma tells you to drink soup - kind of yell/command/talk tone. But, like the OGs they were, they got our orders, served our food, and we left with our bellies full. 

I'll be back!

excerpts: Ordered their Tea salad (of course), yamo house noodles with pork, fish chowder noodle soup, and black bean fish for our group of 3.
Yamo House noodles with pork was really simple.
Just noodles with stir fried pork.
There wasn't too much seasoning that I could see, but it was still rather tasty.
Fish chowder noodle soup was probably my favorite.
I don't know what was the crispy bit of the soup was, but it created a great texture contrast to the soup, which I loved.
The black bean fish dish was probably my least favorite of the 4.
It was good, but I think I'm used to the black beans not being so strong.
black bean fish.author: Mai K.
black bean fish.review:
This is how my visit to Yamo went down. 

Friend: Their Tea salad is great. Definitely recommend. 
Me: Out of all their items, you recommend a salad? 
Friend: It's really good. 

So we wait about 30 minutes to get into this place because it's basically a hole in the wall that seats 8 people at any one time at a bar like setting We order a few things to try since their pricing is quite reasonable. $4-6 per item if I remember correctly. 

Ordered their Tea salad (of course), yamo house noodles with pork, fish chowder noodle soup, and black bean fish for our group of 3. Tea salad was really delicious. It's comprised of a lot of deep fried onions, which gives the salad a nice crunch to it. You really have to just try it out. The dish is rather small so I'd get one for myself next time. Yamo House noodles with pork was really simple. Just noodles with stir fried pork. There wasn't too much seasoning that I could see, but it was still rather tasty. Fish chowder noodle soup was probably my favorite. I don't know what was the crispy bit of the soup was, but it created a great texture contrast to the soup, which I loved. The black bean fish dish was probably my least favorite of the 4. It was good, but I think I'm used to the black beans not being so strong. I prefer a more subtle taste. 

Our four dishes totaled up to $24 and for $8 per person, that's a pretty sweet deal.

excerpts: and I ordered the tea leaf salad, mango salad, house noodle with chicken, and black bean fish.
I liked the salads for their potent flavors, though I thought they were sort of drenched in their sauces.
I've had black bean fish/clams/veg at lots of places
and I thought this version was a little mild and bland - maybe it needed more garlic and more fermented beans?
The noodles were homey and simple.
black bean fish.author: Jean L.
black bean fish.review: First time here and I ordered the tea leaf salad, mango salad, house noodle with chicken, and black bean fish. I liked the salads for their potent flavors, though I thought they were sort of drenched in their sauces. I've had black bean fish/clams/veg at lots of places and I thought this version was a little mild and bland - maybe it needed more garlic and more fermented beans? The noodles were homey and simple. Food was 3.5 stars for me but the awesome (low) prices makes me round up!

excerpts: We ordered the tea salad, house noodles with chicken, black bean fish, and fried rice.
For me, everything was on the salty and oily side, and left me feeling a little greasy afterwards.
There weren't really any flavors that stuck out to me from the food.
I did like that many of the dishes were pretty spicy, but this may not always work out for those who do not eat spicy food.
However, for the price, this place isn't bad.
black bean fish.author: Karissa Y.
black bean fish.review:
I found this no frills, hole in the wall place mediocre in terms of food.

As they only seats about 10 people, my family of 5 opted to takeout. As expected for this type of place, the service wasn't anything great. The ladies working are no nonsense and abrupt, and expected us to wait outside while our food was cooking (which was understandable, given that it was a bit cramped inside). They were also reluctant to give us the amount of forks that we needed. 

Aside from the service and ambience, the food was okay, but nothing amazing. We ordered the tea salad, house noodles with chicken, black bean fish, and fried rice. For me, everything was on the salty and oily side, and left me feeling a little greasy afterwards. There weren't really any flavors that stuck out to me from the food. I did like that many of the dishes were pretty spicy, but this may not always work out for those who do not eat spicy food. However, for the price, this place isn't bad.

excerpts: I always order the house noodles, chicken noodle soup and black bean fish..
black bean fish.author: Maricar F.
black bean fish.review: My favorite Burmese place..fast and yummy. Always hits the spot! I always order the house noodles, chicken noodle soup and black bean fish..

excerpts: We knew what we wanted to order -- beef noodles, black bean fish, tea leaf salad, curry chicken, spring rolls.
There wasn't much meat in the noodles, but what meat there was, was great.
The tea leaf salad was definitely the winner, and the thing that'll bring us back.
Everything else was good but nothing to write home about.
Bang for you buck (it was $12 pp after tip) but you do deal with the wait, the unfriendly service, and the smell that lingers in your clothes and hair.
black bean fish.author: Vivian H.
black bean fish.review: We came here at 7pm on a Wednesday and didn't have to wait long for 3 ppl. We knew what we wanted to order -- beef noodles, black bean fish, tea leaf salad, curry chicken, spring rolls. There wasn't much meat in the noodles, but what meat there was, was great. The tea leaf salad was definitely the winner, and the thing that'll bring us back. Everything else was good but nothing to write home about. Bang for you buck (it was $12 pp after tip) but you do deal with the wait, the unfriendly service, and the smell that lingers in your clothes and hair.

excerpts: My fave dish is the black bean fish (there are maybe 3 black beans in it
black bean fish.author: Maryanna Q.
black bean fish.review:
Yamo is...what it is.

The service is terrible, but the food is decent and at $6 a meal the value for price is amazing.  I go to Yamo more often than I care to admit, and yes everytime the food tastes a smiddggeee different but i'm generally always happy.  My fave dish is the black bean fish (there are maybe 3 black beans in it but alas..) 

Feed yourself and a few friends for under $20 and have a very unique experience. thats Yamo.

Pro tip: call ahead for take out and skip the line

excerpts: Oh Yamo - I dream about your tea leaf salad and black bean fish.
black bean fish.author: C J.
black bean fish.review:
Oh Yamo - I dream about your tea leaf salad and black bean fish. 

In our fair city of overpriced Asian food (OSHA?!?) you are a true gem. 

Out the door, sated and sooo happy for 12.00. 

I must admit, I get a bit scared when those ladies wield the meat clever, but one firm swing and you have an open fresh young coconut in your hand. Bliss.

excerpts: But the black bean fish was nothing to write home about at all.
It was tasty but greasy and unoriginal.
I've had much better and fresher fare at Szechuan places.
black bean fish.author: Nene K.
black bean fish.review:
2.5.

After 4 years away from SF, it seems the trend of overrating new hole-in-the-walls has not yet subsided. Yamo is maybe 2 steps above a good Chinese takeout place. It is not stellar dining but a quick order and go type of place. 

The tea leaf salad was very interesting, slightly bitter, and unlike anything I tried before. But the black bean fish was nothing to write home about at all. It was tasty but greasy and unoriginal. I've had much better and fresher fare at Szechuan places. The other entrees don't appear to be any more original or novel. 

The prices are pretty cheap with nearly everything being $6. And they don't include tax. Cash only.

Highly, highly recommend ordering takeout. Honestly, I have no idea why Yamo even has seating. It is too small and it would be hard to enjoy your meal with the heat and smoke from the stove tops blowing into your face (and your hair, and your pores, and your clothes, etc. etc). 

Take a look at the menus posted outside and know what you want to order right away and then order. For the love of God, don't block the entryway staring at the menu for too long if you don't know what you want and don't try to ask the ladies questions about the orders. It is not that kind of restaurant. Once you've ordered and paid, stand by the doorway out on the street so that the ladies behind the counter can see you. They'll motion to you once your food is ready. Carry and go.

excerpts: I ordered the Yamo house noodles with beef, Friend 1 ordered pot stickers and Friend 2 ordered black bean fish with rice.
black bean fish.author: KD M.
black bean fish.review:
"Fuh heer o to go?"
"Wut u waan?"
"Sicteen dalluh."

The lady taking orders is so sassy! I love it. I went here with two friends for a snack after wandering around Mission. I ordered the Yamo house noodles with beef, Friend 1 ordered pot stickers and Friend 2 ordered black bean fish with rice. The service and food came quick cos they want y'all outta there! 

This place is pretty neat, hole in a wall kind but nothing too amazing. If you want quick, decent, cheap n' small meal, then give it a shot.

I do have two complaints though. Home girl chef uses hella oil. Now there's left over oil and then there's the you tilt your container and you see about 1/4 cup of oil kinda oil. Yikes. Also, the container of spicy sauce or something totally melted my friend's box of pot stickers. Double Yikes.

excerpts: My friend and I shared the spring rolls ($3.60), the tea leaf salad ($5.25), the black bean fish with wide rice noodles ($5.25), and the Yamo cold noodles with chicken ($5.25).
We had a satisfying meal of four dishes for a just over $21!
black bean fish.author: Liz T.
black bean fish.review:
Small, smoky, stools-only... It was love at first sight. I wish I lived in the Mission--I could have bacon donuts for breakfast, super burritos for lunch, and this incredible Burmese stuff for dinner. I would eventually grow out of everything I presently own, but what's a few inches and several pounds? TOTALLY. WORTH. THEM.

My friend and I shared the spring rolls ($3.60), the tea leaf salad ($5.25), the black bean fish with wide rice noodles ($5.25), and the Yamo cold noodles with chicken ($5.25).  We had a satisfying meal of four dishes for a just over $21! Insane for SF!

The rolls were made fresh and super refreshing--good because you're in a bathroom-sized restaurant with a hot kitchen before you. The tea leaf salad was small but scrumptious--I just love the textural contrast of the many ingredients. The fish was lightly fried and really tasty, but the rice noodles were a bit bland. The cold noodles were chewy and flavorful, but the chicken was rather dry. Next time I'll have to try the curry fish with rice and the Yamo house noodles with beef. And get a tea leaf salad just for my gluttonous myself. This is going to be a fat summer, but at least it will be a cheap and spicy one. Everything was mildly spicy except the rolls.

I wasn't crazy about Burmese food after Burma Superstar, after Mandalay, after Burmese Kitchen, but I am definitely a fan after Yamo. The food is so homey and delicious, the Asian ladies are so hard-working and sweet--I can't help but just adore this hole-in-the-wall. 

Although I ate here last night, in anticipation of eating here a lot, I will begin accepting dinner dates here for the rest of the summer starting right now. Don't all flood my inbox at once.

excerpts: Order up pan fried dumplings as an appetizer and black bean fish with rice as a main.
I bet the dumplings don't come till you finish the fish.
So fucking what?
The food is so good.
Quit your whining.
black bean fish.author: Ivan L.
black bean fish.review:
Yamo is one of my absolute favorites in the city. I don't know how I haven't reviewed it already.  This is superstar Burmese food.

Other reviewers have mentioned how small the counter is. So fucking what? The food is so good.
Other reviewers have mentioned the wait. So fucking what? The food is so good. 
Other reviewers have mentioned surly service from women old and young. So fucking what? The food is so good. 
Other reviewers have mentioned the yelling, the hot oppressive steam, and the dirty counters. So fucking what? The food is so good.

Quit your whining. Order up pan fried dumplings as an appetizer and black bean fish with rice as a main. I bet the dumplings don't come till you finish the fish. So fucking what? The food is so good. Quit your whining.

excerpts:
Tea leaf salad
mango chicken
chow mein
Black bean fish
black bean fish.author: Blue S.
black bean fish.review:
Hole in the wall
expect a line
order to go
Cash Only
and you'll be fine
every item is $6.00
no tax charged
call over the phone 
and you're food will be ready when you arrive
Tea leaf salad
mango chicken
chow mein
Black bean fish
All were delish.  

once you're finished 
Yamo will be missed.

excerpts: The house noodles with beef are so tasty and my friend really enjoyed his black bean fish.
The service leaves something to be desired, but it's worth it.
black bean fish.author: C.K. O.
black bean fish.review: Yamo is HOT and you will leave smelling of grease, but the food is delicious and incredibly well priced. The house noodles with beef are so tasty and my friend really enjoyed his black bean fish. The service leaves something to be desired, but it's worth it.

excerpts: I've had the potstickers, tea salad, black bean fish and all the tofu dishses (curry, black bean and mushroom) so far
black bean fish.author: Favoloso M.
black bean fish.review:
Cheap and cheerful is how i would describe this place.  90% of the time I have to wait for a seat along this miniscule establishment and its slim counter space.  The menu is small but everything I've had is tasty delicious.  I've had the potstickers, tea salad, black bean fish and all the tofu dishses (curry, black bean and mushroom) so far and they've all been good!

Cash only and be prepared to smell like cooking when you leave.

excerpts: The black bean fish is a close second.
black bean fish.author: Little C.
black bean fish.review:
I used to live right down the street from this place - which meant I could conveniently stop by when the lines for this tiny place were not so long (rarely). Even if you're not so lucky to avoid the lines - it's totally worth the wait. 

The tea salad is by far my favorite and I highly recommend it. The black bean fish is a close second. 

The women who run the place are also really great. Watching their process behind the counter is pretty impressive.

excerpts: We got the Chicken curry noodle and the black bean fish over rice.
I was definitely eyeing other peoples dishes (Curry noodle soup and various friend noodle and tofu dishes) and they all looked delish!
I will totally be back!
black bean fish.author: Nadiyah S.
black bean fish.review:
Love the hole in the wall joints!

You have probably passed by this restaurant many times and never even known its there.  The great thing about this place is that its intimate, delicious and cheap- one of my favorite combos.  You get a bar seat to the kitchen!

We got the Chicken curry noodle and the black bean fish over rice.  I was definitely eyeing other peoples dishes (Curry noodle soup and various friend noodle and tofu dishes) and they all looked delish!  I will totally be back!

excerpts: The black bean fish is totally not in my usual area
but I was almost licking the plate after the last succulent morsel went down my throat.
black bean fish.author: Steven R.
black bean fish.review:
This is quickly becoming one of my favorite lunch spots.

Let's say you're hungry and you're just kind of tired of burritos (hell, it's the Mission) but you want some awesome tasty hearty food.  You kinda have time to sit down but you don't want to plunk down $20 for lunch after it's all said and done.

This is what you've been looking for.

It's literally a hole in the wall but one that serves really good food.  You walk in, sit down and are given a menu and half of a greeting.  Whatever sounds good to you, you order.  That sounds wrong but I've been trying to find something here that I don't wolf down in minutes and have failed miserably.  The mango chicken is awesome as are any of the curries.  The black bean fish is totally not in my usual area but I was almost licking the plate after the last succulent morsel went down my throat.  On cold days, the chicken noodle soup here does the job.

If the great food wasn't enough, probably the prices are the best draw.  With no entree over $6, yet nearly each enough for one, this place is an incredible bargain for quality food.  Even if you're a hungry kid like me and must have two entrees (or just want to try more things on the menu), $12 for a guaranteed stomach fill is still a deal.

The only concern here is the line since this place holds 9-10 diners max but worst case scenario they do takeout which I can't see disappointing anybody.

In fact I'm already planning on having lunch here on Monday, maybe even Tuesday too.  Come say hi.

excerpts: We ordered the samusas (these were just OK), black bean fish, and the tea leaf salad (both were pretty delicious).
What didn't make sense was why the black bean fish and the tea leaf salad were both $6, but the portion of the salad was WAY smaller.
I'll be back to try some of there other dishes.
black bean fish.author: Cindy A.
black bean fish.review: Definitely not a place to bring a date, but DEFINITELY a place to get nomtastic, cheap food. Boyfriend and I came here yesterday and we were in and out the door in 30 minutes; the food comes out quick. We ordered the samusas (these were just OK), black bean fish, and the tea leaf salad (both were pretty delicious). What didn't make sense was why the black bean fish and the tea leaf salad were both $6, but the portion of the salad was WAY smaller.  I'll be back to try some of there other dishes.

excerpts: I have tried the Potstickers, Tea Leaf Salad, Fish Chowder Noodle Soup, Mango Chicken, Black Bean Fish, Yamo House Noodles with Beef, Chicken Noodle Soup, Yamo Cold Noodles and the Curry Tofu
and they were all great.
black bean fish.author: Joy L.
black bean fish.review:
This is a great little hole in the wall. The space itself is tiny, and your food is literally cooked in front of you. The food is great and the service is no-nonsense, but that doesn't mean they are unfriendly, they are just busy. Your best bet is to call in ahead of time and order take out if you don't want to wait for a seat. Also - since the place is so teeny tiny, the ventilation is quite poor, so take out may be your best option in that respect as well.  

Reasonable prices and I have no complaints about the food. Their portions are a little on the small side, but you can't expect more than what they give you for the price you are paying. Their menu is not huge, but what they offer, they do well. I have tried the Potstickers, Tea Leaf Salad, Fish Chowder Noodle Soup, Mango Chicken, Black Bean Fish, Yamo House Noodles with Beef, Chicken Noodle Soup, Yamo Cold Noodles and the Curry Tofu and they were all great. All of their noodle dishes are excellent. 

This is a Mission gem - it encompasses everything I love about San Francisco: Tiny little hole-in-the-wall places with yummy but dirt-cheap food.

excerpts: Black bean fish and mango chicken are pretty good, and for 6 bucks I can't complain.
Still, the amount of oil and salt is overwhelming.
black bean fish.author: C M.
black bean fish.review: Black bean fish and mango chicken are pretty good, and for 6 bucks I can't complain.   Still, the amount of oil and salt is overwhelming.

excerpts: I've known and loved the dishes at Yamo for awhile now, but tonight for the first time I experienced the greatness that is the Black Bean Fish dish.
Delicious!!
black bean fish.author: Trish A.
black bean fish.review: I've known and loved the dishes at Yamo for awhile now, but tonight for the first time I experienced the greatness that is the Black Bean Fish dish. Delicious!!

excerpts: We ordered the Yamo noodles with beef, the black bean fish, and the spring rolls.
I highly recommend the Yamo noodles, which are amazingly good.
Everything is made to order.
It's a great experience sitting at the counter watching one of the ladies make all the dishes and the other lady shouting out orders and managing the cash (no plastic here).
The huge flames arising from the gas stove is the reason why you eat out for food like this.
I noticed a number of people ordering take-out, which is a good idea.
I would do the same if I lived in the Mission.
A new favorite of mine in SF.
black bean fish.author: Annie Y.
black bean fish.review: The ladies manning this hole-in-the wall have got it down. This is the real deal. The line out the door is not a result of hype, it's because there are only eight seats at the counter and all the entrees are super delicious at $6. We ordered the Yamo noodles with beef, the black bean fish, and the spring rolls. I highly recommend the Yamo noodles, which are amazingly good. Everything is made to order. It's a great experience sitting at the counter watching one of the ladies make all the dishes and the other lady shouting out orders and managing the cash (no plastic here). The huge flames arising from the gas stove is the reason why you eat out for food like this. I noticed a number of people ordering take-out, which is a good idea. I would do the same if I lived in the Mission. A new favorite of mine in SF.

excerpts: My friends got the mushroom tofu and the black bean fish.
All yummy for $5.25 an entree.
Don't get too excited by the size of the rice wrappers for the spring rolls; they're small
black bean fish.author: Yan E.
black bean fish.review:
Oh, yelp, you did not steer me wrong. Yummy hole in the wall. 

4 of us came here at noon on Saturday = no line to wait. When we left though, there was a line out the door. It's just one counter; they cook behind it and you sit in front of it. Maybe 8 stools and luckily some coat hooks to hang your bags from. I got the cold noodles; it was spicy but not ice-cold like I was hoping for (hot day!). My friends got the mushroom tofu and the black bean fish. All yummy for $5.25 an entree. Don't get too excited by the size of the rice wrappers for the spring rolls; they're small but it's only $3.50.
