I commented that it was pretty clean for a hole in the wall. A exclaimed "What?!" Remember, it's hole in the wall standards. It is possible I was blinded by the cheap prices and yum-o (someone has to say it) food. What impressed me is there's a bathroom in the place. Apparently, it's hidden behind the wall.

excerpts: Due to suggestion from the gentleman next to me, I ordered the black bean fish.
It was good but not incredible.
black bean fish.author: Renee M.
black bean fish.review:
Wow, talk about the definition of hole in the wall.  The extent of this eatery is a single counter and some stools.  That being said, I was lucky to have my butt occupy one of those stools as a line out the door formed shortly afterward.  

The ambiance...wait what ambiance?  Ceiling lights were swinging, the outside of the restaurant was covered in graffiti, and the two ladies on the other side of the counter were scrambling to take orders, cook, package food, and take phone orders.  

Due to suggestion from the gentleman next to me, I ordered the black bean fish.  It was good but not incredible.  Then again, for less than $6 I really have no right to criticize.    

This is a cash only joint so be sure that you are armed with more than plastic if you plan on stopping by.

I don't recommend dining in at Yamo but for a cheap and quick meal to go, it doesn't get any better.

excerpts: I recommend trying everything on the menu but if you need someone to start you off, try: tea leaf salad, samosa, spring rolls, or pot stickers as an appetizer, and house noodles or black bean fish as an entree.
black bean fish.author: LIVE to E.
black bean fish.review:
hole in the wall, neighborhood gem, ... call it what you want, this place is amazing and a must try.  I recommend trying everything on the menu but if you need someone to start you off, try: tea leaf salad, samosa, spring rolls, or pot stickers as an appetizer, and house noodles or black bean fish as an entree.  All appetizers are $3.25 and entrees are $5.25.  

There is a bit of a language barrier thus service does suffer a little bit but who cares when food is this good!

excerpts: I had the black bean fish noodles.
Make sure you get them or live to regret it.
Our server-cook recommended against the curry prawns but they were pretty awesome, and they'll give you the spicy if you like.
black bean fish.author: Blake E.
black bean fish.review:
This is now the third incarnation of Yamo's I've seen, and it took me too long to make it to part III of the trilogy. Last time, it was eclectic and visually amusing. Before it was Anna the Thai Soup Nazi who was good for endless entertainment as she showed you pictures of her nieces she wanted you to marry.

But now as a Burmese restaurant, Yamo satisfies as well as ever. Insanely cheap entrees ($5.25 each!), nice spices and ingredients, and well-crafted rolls rarely go together.

I had the black bean fish noodles. Make sure you get them or live to regret it. Our server-cook recommended against the curry prawns but they were pretty awesome, and they'll give you the spicy if you like. Samusas and fresh spring rolls as appetizers? Yes please. They even make the spring rolls in front of your very eyes.

Service is with a smile, and an occasional forgotten item. But then the smile comes again and you just go back to eating your plate of deliciousness.

excerpts: The cold noodles are delish, the black bean fish was good and the curries are nice and spicy.
And for such a no-frills place, it's nice that they have an array of condiments.
black bean fish.author: Xtina C.
black bean fish.review:
I love nothing better than little ethnic hole-in-the-floor joints with great food for practically nothing.  Thus is Yamo.
Sure you leave smelling something of recycled grease, but the flavorful food and very friendly people behind the counter more than make up for it.
Make sure to try the tea salad (so many crunchy goodies mixed in).  The cold noodles are delish, the black bean fish was good and the curries are nice and spicy.
And for such a no-frills place, it's nice that they have an array of condiments.

excerpts: The black bean fish was pretty tasty though.
black bean fish.author: Lance D.
black bean fish.review:
This place is such a trip.  When I poked my head in here after finding this place on Yelp I was really blown away.  I definitely felt like I stepped into a different world. I hope they never renovate because SF definitely needs places unique places like Yamo to contrast the glitsy pretentious restaurants out there.  I definitely like this place and will go back again, I mean hey can't beat the prices but I can't really give it more than 3 stars.  Potstickers were pretty bad and I love potstickers...springrolls were also eh but better than the potstickers. Mango chicken was not nearly as good as I expected it to be since previous yelpers had reviewed it so glowingly. It was super spicy and I really had hoped they would have wanted more chicken with my plate of mango.  The black bean fish was pretty tasty though. 

So definitely check it out and keep going...decent enough food and I love the simple set-up. I really felt like I was back in the Philippines at times.

excerpts: * Black bean fish - good but not mind blowing.
It could have used a bit more flavor.
black bean fish.author: Melanie O.
black bean fish.review:
Yamo is a great place to start the night if you're looking for an adventure.  It is a random hole in the wall near the corner of 18th and Mission.  You walk in and you are immediately amazed how tiny the space is.  You sit at the counter and watch the bustle of the kitchen.

Highlights:
* Yamo House Noodles with Pork- delicious. Pork was thinly sliced and savory.  The noodles were a bit greasy but overall it was good.  Warning: Portions were small
* Black bean fish - good but not mind blowing.  It could have used a bit more flavor.  However, for $5.50, I'm not sure you could expect a lot more.

My overall takeaway with the place was it had good service and decent food, but I wouldn't wait to eat here.  If I had time I would rather go to Richmond or the East Bay for amazing Burmese food and pay $3-4 more dollars. Or I would go to another Chinese joint in the mission and pay the same price for food that has bigger portions and is more flavorful.

excerpts: I love the Yamo house noodles, mango chicken, and black bean fish.
I tried the chow mein and veggie curry - both were ok, but I prefer the above choices over these.
Also, I suggest getting an order of samosas to munch on while you wait for your food.
It's satisfying for my tummy and wallet!
black bean fish.author: Lynda N.
black bean fish.review:
The price and location are key reasons that keep me coming back again and again.  Big portions of Burmese food for $5.25?  Three blocks from my apt?  Awesome to-go containers I can reuse?  Counter seating ONLY?  Burmese women working hard to feed me some good ol homecookin?  It beats heading out to Burma Superstar (love me some burma superstar!) to wait in a loooong first come, first serve line (depending on how many are in your party, they have been known to bump smaller parties to seat larger ones! booooo to them for that!).

I love the Yamo house noodles, mango chicken, and black bean fish.  I tried the chow mein and veggie curry - both were ok, but I prefer the above choices over these.  Also, I suggest getting an order of samosas to munch on while you wait for your food.  It's satisfying for my tummy and wallet!

excerpts: ordered the tea leaf salad, black bean fish, vegetables, garlic house noodles with chicken and pot stickers.
could have left the veggie dish and the pot stickers but everything else was supreme.
the atmosphere was entertaining with swaying, circling light fixtures, short asian women working full force tossing noddles around in a tiny galley kitchen.
the three of us stuffed our faces for under $25.
we will be back.
black bean fish.author: Rosalee R.
black bean fish.review:
searched for $ and 4 stars and up came this burmese option. hopped on over and grabbed 3 of the 11 seats.
ordered the tea leaf salad, black bean fish, vegetables, garlic house noodles with chicken and pot stickers. could have left the veggie dish and the pot stickers but everything else was supreme. 
the atmosphere was entertaining with swaying, circling light fixtures, short asian women working full force tossing noddles around in a tiny galley kitchen.
the three of us stuffed our faces for under $25. we will be back.

excerpts: The curry beef is pretty solid too, and the black bean fish is ok.
black bean fish.author: Brett J.
black bean fish.review:
3.5 stars

What do I like about Yamo?  Well, it is called Yamo.  That's a pretty cool name.  Also, the food is good.  The tea salad is excellent.  Sounds like it won't be, but it is.  Definitely get it.   The curry beef is pretty solid too, and the black bean fish is ok.

The bad? Almost nowhere to sit.  Just ten or so seats at the counter.  Also, if they are cooking something that smells bad when cooking, you have to smell it too because, well, you are right there.  They also don't serve alcohol, which isn't really too big of a deal for me.

If you haven't been here, try it.  I wouldn't say go across town for it, but if you are near here, go here.

excerpts: We also ordered the Samosaz (appetizer) and the Black bean fish.
The fish was nice, but not as flavorful as the cold noodles.
The person beside us said the noodle soups were also good.
black bean fish.author: Abid M.
black bean fish.review:
What an awesome place. The old ladies prepare every thing in front of you.

It's a really small place, with probably 10 seats on the counter, and that's it. Party of 2, showed up at 8:30 pm on Tuesday, wait was 15-20 minutes.

The big hit was the Yamo cold noodles with chicken. So much flavor.

We also ordered the Samosaz (appetizer) and the Black bean fish.  The fish was nice, but not as flavorful as the cold noodles.  The person beside us said the noodle soups were also good. That's the plan for next time.

Totally worth it.

excerpts: I've gotten the black bean fish, but I can't not get the pork noodles.
In general everything can be made with noodles so don't even bother with the rice.
black bean fish.author: Kasey K.
black bean fish.review:
If there weren't already 75 reviews, I wouldn't yelp it.  About a dozen seats, 2-3 middle aged (presumably)Burmese women and sometimes a teenage relative, amazing noodles and fresh ingredients combine to create one of the tastiest, most reasonably priced places to eat in the Mission.  

Yamo was recommended to me by some vegan friends so I assume there are some good vegan options, but I wouldn't know anything about that.  I like to get the house noodles with pork(I have no idea what they do to the pork but it is incredibly tender) which I drench in Sriracha.  It doesn't need it, the dish is garlicky and also comes with fresh veggies - I am just a freak for Sriracha.

The spring rolls are also amazing.  I've gotten the black bean fish, but I can't not get the pork noodles.  In general everything can be made with noodles so don't even bother with the rice.

excerpts: The first time I ordered food from there I got the black bean fish.
It was good stuff and the portion was just right.
Today, however, is another day.
black bean fish.author: Miss T.
black bean fish.review:
YAMO be at some other place for lunch.  ( I bet all the Michael McDonald fans are smiling hehe). 

 The first time I ordered food from there I got the black bean fish.  It was good stuff and the portion was just right.  Today, however, is another day.  I wanted to try other yummy goodness from this place, but I was sadly disappointed.  

I ordered the house fried chow fun with chicken.  It was extremely oily, as in oil rig oily.  On top of that it was really bland.  I tried to put hot sauce on it, but the hot sauce wouldn't stick because of all the oil.  There was also a lot of bitter cabbage in it.  I am definitely never going to order that again.    My friend got the house noodles and that wasn't all that great either.  

On the plus sides: really fast take out and cute guys eating there.

excerpts: I love the black bean fish and the curry fish.
black bean fish.author: Kelly Kate W.
black bean fish.review:
cheap, greasy, and great. 

Love that they have fresh coconuts, although I always make a mess spooning out the fruit. 

Dishes may be a bit greasy, but all the veggies taste fresh and the food is fabulous overall. I love the black bean fish and the curry fish. 

Skip the appetizers.

excerpts: i love the black bean fish!
its crowded and its tiny but who lives around can enjoy the luxury of having nice homemade burmanese cuisine in the hood for as cheap as 5.25 ;)
black bean fish.author: Babs J.
black bean fish.review:
love yamo! as decent as it gets! hard worker family!
tip nicely they deserve it!
i love the black bean fish!
its crowded and its tiny but who lives around can enjoy the luxury of having nice homemade burmanese cuisine in the hood for as cheap as 5.25 ;)

excerpts: we ordered the tea leaf salad, samusas, yamo house noodles with beef, and black bean fish.
I would recommend the tea leaf salad if you're interested in a surprisingly crunchy and spicy salad.
the samusas are cute crispy mini-versions of samosas with a plum-chili(?) dipping sauce.

Yamo house noodles with beef were the prize-winning dish with great flavor moist beef and crisp veggies.  

to top it all off the price was better than most places in the mission as noted in articles on their door.
black bean fish.author: Marina K.
black bean fish.review:
it was soooo thrilling finding Yamo-  it was one of those times when you almost walk past the place because its so obscure you would never think to peek inside - barely any sign that its the place you were looking for - staking your hopes on a satisfying meal to this little door with a light on a dark street - then you poke your head in and see that there's a person on every stool along the narrow 12 foot counter.  so this might have some promise after all.  you walk in and pick up the menu and decide to wait it out and see if it is worthwhile - and so it was.

we ordered the tea leaf salad, samusas, yamo house noodles with beef, and black bean fish.  I would recommend the tea leaf salad if you're interested in a surprisingly crunchy and spicy salad. the samusas are cute crispy mini-versions of samosas with a plum-chili(?) dipping sauce.  Yamo house noodles with beef were the prize-winning dish with great flavor moist beef and crisp veggies.  

to top it all off the price was better than most places in the mission as noted in articles on their door.  worth the adventure to find it & now i will definitely go back.

*********
makes me want to sing a little song to a reggae tune: 
"yamo get some yamo~
yamo be alright~" :)

excerpts: We ordered samosas, tea leaf salad, the house noodles, and black bean fish.
2 guys sat next to us 15 minutes later, ordered, and received their food 5 minutes later as we sat there hungrily staring at the samosas sitting in the deep fryer basket.
Eventually, we received everything except for the fish.
Where is it??
Ah-ha!
I see it now, plated and ready to serve, except it got dumped in a to-go box.
WTF?
I tried to remain calm, but since I can understand Cantonese, I heard everything the ladies were saying in regards to our order.
Apparently, one of them spaced out and gave our black bean fish to someone else who ordered after us.
Time ticks by as we patiently waited for our black bean fish to arrive.
Meanwhile, the 2 guys next to us finished eating, paid, left, and another couple sat next to us.
It wasn't until this couple ordered and received their food that the ladies realized that we're still waiting on our last dish.
The black bean fish eventually arrived shortly after they realized their blunder, but it wasn't delicious enough to make up for the ridiculously long wait we endured.
I want my 2 hours back!
black bean fish.author: Cynthia F.
black bean fish.review:
I'm no stranger to hole-in-the-wall restaurants and the lack of service it entails. That doesn't bother me. I don't mind the wait in line either. The food was decent, but as others have mentioned, not truly Burmese. That's ok though. If I was just rating this place based solely on its food and cheapness, I would definitely give it a 4 star rating. 
I really wanted to like Yamo, but I really resent the fact that it took my bf and I nearly 2 hours to get our food so I can't bring myself to rate this place any higher than a 2. 
We ordered samosas, tea leaf salad, the house noodles, and black bean fish. 2 guys sat next to us 15 minutes later, ordered, and received their food 5 minutes later as we sat there hungrily staring at the samosas sitting in the deep fryer basket. Eventually, we received everything except for the fish. Where is it?? Ah-ha! I see it now, plated and ready to serve, except it got dumped in a to-go box. WTF? I tried to remain calm, but since I can understand Cantonese, I heard everything the ladies were saying in regards to our order. Apparently, one of them spaced out and gave our black bean fish to someone else who ordered after us. Time ticks by as we patiently waited for our black bean fish to arrive. Meanwhile, the 2 guys next to us finished eating, paid, left, and another couple sat next to us. It wasn't until this couple ordered and received their food that the ladies realized that we're still waiting on our last dish. 
The black bean fish eventually arrived shortly after they realized their blunder, but it wasn't delicious enough to make up for the ridiculously long wait we endured. I want my 2 hours back!

excerpts: When that, plus the black bean fish, house noodles with chicken, samusas, fresh coconut juice, and a soda costs you just over $22, you end up wondering if you're still in the city.
Not the best tasting ever, but still fresh, very tasty and cheap.
Love it.
black bean fish.author: Maximillian M.
black bean fish.review: Probably one of the most awesome hole-in-the-wall joints in the entire city! The tea leaf salad is particularly awesome. When that, plus the black bean fish, house noodles with chicken, samusas, fresh coconut juice, and a soda costs you just over $22, you end up wondering if you're still in the city. Not the best tasting ever, but still fresh, very tasty and cheap. Love it.

excerpts: Try the House Noodles and the Black Bean Fish.
Try as much as you like b/c it's only $5.25 ( tax included) for entrees and $3.50 for apps.
Not a first date kinda place unless your date likes hole in the wall restaurants and dive bars.
black bean fish.author: Huy N.
black bean fish.review: Burmese in the Mission and no crazy wait. The food is simple, tasty and cheap. Make sure you don't wear any fine threads cuz you will stink of cooking to high heaven. Try the House Noodles and the Black Bean Fish. Try as much as you like b/c it's only $5.25 ( tax included) for entrees and $3.50 for apps. Not a first date kinda place unless your date likes hole in the wall restaurants and dive bars.

excerpts: I like the black bean fish with noodles.
I don't know how 'authentic' it is
but it's a great quick lunch.
black bean fish.author: Alex S.
black bean fish.review: Cheap, well-portioned, noodley tastiness.  I like the black bean fish with noodles.  I don't know how 'authentic' it is but it's a great quick lunch.

excerpts: Food-wise, the black bean fish is very good, and pretty much everyone else's main entrees looked equally good - those would get 4 stars in my book.
I did get potstickers that seemed like the pork was still raw - luckily no food poisoning yet, and the spring rolls were just decent.
black bean fish.author: Lisa C.
black bean fish.review: I might be a little biased because I waited 20 minutes in the freezing cold to get a seat at this place.  It's your basic hole-in-the wall - good food, generous portions, maybe 10-15 stools to sit on total.  Everyone comes here just for the food, so if you want ambiance or great service, keep looking.  Food-wise, the black bean fish is very good, and pretty much everyone else's main entrees looked equally good - those would get 4 stars in my book.  I did get potstickers that seemed like the pork was still raw - luckily no food poisoning yet, and the spring rolls were just decent.

excerpts: i ordered the mushroom tofu.
i liked the flavors.
it was very well prepared.
can't complain about the food at all,  served with rice,  $6.50.
what a bargain!
mushroom tofu.author: cindy c.
mushroom tofu.review:
a regular little place. seats 7? at a, small counter. completely no  frills place... i saw two people waiting food so i walked in,  unsure if I'm getting anything just yet.  after i walked in,  someone else walked in to sit.  another walked in also to sit.  i ordered.  someone walked in to order a take out order.  a woman walked in to sit.  another woman came in to pick up her phone in order.  two people were waiting to sit as i left.  

i bring that up because it appears this place is a neighborhood favorite.  i didn't order spring rolls but i might need to,  since it sold out as i was there.  

i was a little sad to see they removed chow fun from their menu,  as I'm poultry intolerant.  as in i could stop breathing if ingested,  so rice noodles are safer than chow mein noodles. 

i ordered the mushroom tofu. i liked the flavors. it was very well prepared.  can't complain about the food at all,  served with rice,  $6.50. what a bargain! no wonder the neighbors flock here...

i would recommend you watch how they cook your food if you have any allergy.  i didn't mention mine but next time i certainly will. the cross contamination is a possibility with the chef using the same utensils on all the orders.  at the time i was there,  2 chicken orders!  but my tofu was simmering on its own and didn't use that cooking utensil,  yikes!

I'm forever wary of new places but i think I'll be back,  as long as i tell the chef about my allergy...

i liked the food.  i just need to tell the chef.  I'll be back.  4 stars for this little hidden find!

excerpts: Me and my friend got vegetarian dishes which were mushroom tofu and the black bean tofu.
Both were good and came with rice.
We also got the tea leaf salad which a small but good.
It was a tad spicier for my friend, but we did like it.
I will say despite the spiciness, I have had a better version of this salad at another place.
The good thing is everything felt homemade.
mushroom tofu.author: Andrew N.
mushroom tofu.review:
My friend wanted to try this place during the slow times since there is no line. We actually were the only customers when we got there.

I will say that it felt like we were entering someone's house uninvited to ask for food. It was a unique vibe. The ladies weren't mean but weren't attentive at the same time. Again it's kind of like going to someone's house and waiting for food when you weren't expected to come. We did get our orders in and the food came out pretty quick after the ladies finished their prep.  When we were ordering, the lady made a joke that felt like it was an inside joke between the cooks about not giving me much vegetable as I requested extra. I sort of laughed but sort of got confused, so smh on that one.  I just laughed with them.

Me and my friend got vegetarian dishes which were mushroom tofu and the black bean tofu. Both were good and came with rice.  We also got the tea leaf salad which a small but good. It was a tad spicier for my friend, but we did like it. I will say despite the spiciness, I have had a better version of this salad at another place. The good thing is everything felt homemade. This place is definitely a mom and pop shop.

The biggest pro of this place is the prices are cheap, so that is what it has going. I would come back here again but not when there is a wait. If you want to try this place, I say go after 2 pm on a weekend.

excerpts: *Mushroom Tofu - Delicious!
It's not only for vegetarians.
mushroom tofu.author: Nicole S.
mushroom tofu.review:
Cheap and yummy Burmese food!

After passing by Yamo after our Mission Chinese Food fail, my friend mentioned he wanted to try this place.  Two friends and I came here last Tuesday around 7pm and waited about 20-25 minutes to be seated.

WHAT TO KNOW:
*CASH ONLY!
*Hole in the wall place that seats only about 10 people 
*Bar seating so come with one or two people at max (if more, it'll be too difficult to seat everyone together)
*Entrees come with an option of noodles or rice
*Cheap! (6 dishes came out to $15/person including tip!)
*Expect your food to be greasy 

FOOD:
*Potstickers - Pass.  They're a bit doughy and tasted like Costco Ling Ling potstickers.
*Yamo House Noodle w/Beef - A must try and my favorite dish of the night!!  You have the option for pork, chicken or beef placed on top of somewhat oily noodles topped off with fried garlic and green onions.
*Mango Chicken - Good.  The flavorful dish consisted of chicken, snow peas, carrots, and onions and had diced mangos that added a slight sweetness to the dish.
*Mushroom Tofu - Delicious!  It's not only for vegetarians.  I love tofu and mushrooms and to have it together with saucy goodness was great.  

SERVICE:
Okay I guess. It's an Asian restaurant, stellar service isn't their focus.

PARKING:
Street parking which at most times is horrible. 

To sum it up, I can't wait to come back!

excerpts: The Mushroom Tofu with Broccoli: I expected silken white tofu, but instead it was deep fried.
The sauce was a thick brown sauce that reminded me of Chinese food.
mushroom tofu.author: Jess C.
mushroom tofu.review:
Ah, Yamo... I was hoping for more. I ordered take out, and waited ~10 minutes for my food (6pm on a Thurs), lucky me! When I placed my order, the waitress seemed angry at me, but no points docked here. I'll attribute that to the authentic Burmese vibe :)

House Noodles with Chicken Curry:  Not as chewy as I expected. Curry was decent, nothing out of the ordinary. I felt it was actually a little too heavy. Tiny portion. Perhaps you are better off with the beef or chicken.

The Mushroom Tofu with Broccoli: I expected silken white tofu, but instead it was deep fried. The sauce was a thick brown sauce that reminded me of Chinese food. I guess all their entrees come with rice, and like the previous dish the portion was small.

The spring rolls were pretty typical, I would probably get them again.

I was really hoping it was better than Burma Superstar, but Yamo is a good Burmese option for the Mission. I may return but definitely not wait in any line.

excerpts: Black bean mushroom tofu sauce was tasty, house noodles weren't horrible.
mushroom tofu.author: Judy C.
mushroom tofu.review:
Cheap burmese food. Minus the rice in the rice platter, small salad and entree portions. Black bean mushroom tofu sauce was tasty, house noodles weren't horrible. 

The restaurant is a hole in the wall, serves ~10 people max on the diner bar-like counter. i think people just come here because they are not asian, it's cheap, and food isn't bad. Service is ok, but the place is filthy.

excerpts:
- this was pretty tasty, but I prefer this dish at other Burmese restaurants
Samusas - actually really good and hot and fresh
Mushroom Tofu - ok, kind of lacking in flavor
Vegetable Curry over noodles - luke warm, but interesting -
I appreciated that okra was among the vegetables in the dish.
mushroom tofu.author: Rachana S.
mushroom tofu.review:
I was excited to try a hole in the wall Burmese restaurant and went with two other friends.  We waited maybe 10 minutes before being seated which wasn't bad at all.  As everyone else mentioned, it's super small, and you can watch all the food being prepared for you which is pretty cool.  But, the food was only ok to me.  I'm vegetarian so we ended up getting:

Tea-leaf salad - this was pretty tasty, but I prefer this dish at other Burmese restaurants
Samusas - actually really good and hot and fresh
Mushroom Tofu - ok, kind of lacking in flavor
Vegetable Curry over noodles - luke warm, but interesting - I appreciated that okra was among the vegetables in the dish.
Coconut Water - awesome, got to eat the coconut meat at the end as well, but not really special to Yamo
Green jelly drink - a canned drink that was ok

But, this place IS dirt cheap.  We got all of that for 25 bucks.  I wouldn't resist if someone wanted to come here for dinner, but I think I'd prefer most of the other Burmese restaurants around town (even if they're further out).

excerpts: Don't get me wrong, I love mine a lot, but she simply lacks the kitchen prowess to turn out bomb-ass mango chicken or mushroom tofu.
I'm willing to make the switch.
mushroom tofu.author: Christy J.
mushroom tofu.review:
Dear Ridiculously Hard-working Ladies Who Work At Yamo, 

Please be my new moms.  Don't get me wrong, I love mine a lot, but she simply lacks the kitchen prowess to turn out bomb-ass mango chicken or mushroom tofu.  I'm willing to make the switch.  Please come to my studio, which will remind you of your cooking space at Yamo because it's approximately the same size, and stir-fry up some of your house noodles with fried garlic and beef.  I could eat it all day, every day.  

Thank you very much.

- Christy

excerpts: My friends got the mushroom tofu and the black bean fish.
All yummy for $5.25 an entree.
Don't get too excited by the size of the rice wrappers for the spring rolls; they're small
mushroom tofu.author: Yan E.
mushroom tofu.review:
Oh, yelp, you did not steer me wrong. Yummy hole in the wall. 

4 of us came here at noon on Saturday = no line to wait. When we left though, there was a line out the door. It's just one counter; they cook behind it and you sit in front of it. Maybe 8 stools and luckily some coat hooks to hang your bags from. I got the cold noodles; it was spicy but not ice-cold like I was hoping for (hot day!). My friends got the mushroom tofu and the black bean fish. All yummy for $5.25 an entree. Don't get too excited by the size of the rice wrappers for the spring rolls; they're small but it's only $3.50. 

I commented that it was pretty clean for a hole in the wall. A exclaimed "What?!" Remember, it's hole in the wall standards. It is possible I was blinded by the cheap prices and yum-o (someone has to say it) food. What impressed me is there's a bathroom in the place. Apparently, it's hidden behind the wall.

excerpts: The mushroom tofu dish is amazing, the tea leaf salad also quite good!
mushroom tofu.author: Michael B.
mushroom tofu.review: Really small street vendor counter style service; only 8-10 customers fit in at a time.  Expect a short wait. Cheap, quick, friendly and funny service from older Burmese grandmother types who bicker and joke between themselves (probably about you).  The mushroom tofu dish is amazing, the tea leaf salad also quite good!

excerpts: Tried their mushroom tofu dish with noodles and their black bean dish..
YUM!
It's slightly oily but one will forget about that once the flavor kicks in the mouth.
The menu is simple...prices are extremely fair.
The place is small-bar stool seating.
mushroom tofu.author: Claude C.
mushroom tofu.review: A delicious mix of Burmese and Chinese food - honestly prepared! This is just the right place to eat at after work (lunch is advisable too if you don't mind the lingering smell of sauteed onions in sesame oil on you).  Tried their mushroom tofu dish with noodles and their black bean dish..YUM! It's slightly oily but one will forget about that once the flavor kicks in the mouth. The menu is simple...prices are extremely fair. The place is small-bar stool seating. But it doesn't matter,  the food comes out fast and not a place for chatting it up. Well...you're not gonna want to talk but eat and eat and eat.

excerpts: The mushroom tofu had lots of veggies in it, but was only decent.
mushroom tofu.author: Olivia C.
mushroom tofu.review:
I would give Yamo 3.5 stars if I could.  

The tea salad was delicious, as tea salad always is, but didn't include very many tea leaves which made me sad.  The curry chicken noodles were pretty good.  It's true that they don't give you much curry sauce if you order this to go, but if you put what sauce they do give you into a bowl/container with the noodles and give them a thorough tossing, I found that it was just enough curry sauce to give the noodles a light coating.  The mushroom tofu had lots of veggies in it, but was only decent.  All in all, Yamo is not bad and I'd definately come back.  

I love tea salad!

excerpts: I've had the prawn curry, cold noodles and mushroom tofu.
The noodles are so good!
mushroom tofu.author: Diem V.
mushroom tofu.review:
I love yamo, it's so cute. Cheap (although they did raise their prices), yummy food, good portions, small and cramped and dirty. I like it.

I've had the prawn curry, cold noodles and mushroom tofu. The noodles are so good!

excerpts: Order: House Noodles with Chicken, Curry Tofu, Curry Fish, Curry Vegetables, Yamo Cold Noodles (with chicken or tofu), Mushroom Tofu, Chicken Noodle Soup.
mushroom tofu.author: Crash O.
mushroom tofu.review:
I love this place so much, words cannot even express. I don't even know what to say to the Yamo Haters, except, haters gotta hate. But I LOVE. 

Order: House Noodles with Chicken, Curry Tofu, Curry Fish, Curry Vegetables, Yamo Cold Noodles (with chicken or tofu), Mushroom Tofu, Chicken Noodle Soup.

Bonus for vegetarians and other tofu-lovers: They will sub tofu for meat in pretty much any dish, even if it's not listed as an option on the menu. The fact that the ladies who work here are all-business and brusque-verging-on-rude can be off-putting, but don't be fooled. These ladies really just want to serve you some delicious food cheaply and efficiently. 

FEEL THE LOVE.

excerpts: I always get the Mushroom Tofu with noodles.
mushroom tofu.author: Richard J.
mushroom tofu.review:
Everything on the menu is $5.25! I always get the Mushroom Tofu with noodles. Everything is cooked fresh and you always end up with happy plate action.  My girl ordered coconut water and they chopped the top off a real life coconut!. That the shit. 



-non greasy feel after eating
-$5.25 menu
-frosty water
-bomb noodles
-small cutty place that makes you feel like your underground and better than anyone else
-ladies work so damn hard for your food

excerpts: I dig the chicken noodle soup and mushroom tofu.
mushroom tofu.author: Katrina M.
mushroom tofu.review: Yum!  This place is delish!  Teensey and busy, but well worth the wait.  Cheap, tasty, fast(ish), and just the perfect touch of greasey.  I dig the chicken noodle soup and mushroom tofu.

excerpts: I usually get the Yamo House Noodles which comes with a choice of chicken, beef, pork and something else.
The house noodles are prepared in a simple manner.
It is noodles, fried garlic, green onions with your choice of meat and is fried together really quickly.
yamo house noodles.author: Christopher L.
yamo house noodles.review:
There is usually a line here because the only seating they have is a bar which fits around 10 people, so it's pretty small. Your best chances of getting something from Yamo is if you get take out or if you come off peak eating hours.

The reason I love this place is because the value is really good for what you can get. I usually get the Yamo House Noodles which comes with a choice of chicken, beef, pork and something else. The house noodles are prepared in a simple manner. It is noodles, fried garlic, green onions with your choice of meat and is fried together really quickly. When you sit down, they have a variety of sauces to spice up your dish.

They serve various other noodle and rice dishes. Their tea salad is also pretty good too! I'd say this place is a mix of Burmese and Chinese food.

Yeah the prices are really good too, with most dishes costing less than $7 and they have appetizers for $3 - 5! So cheap! I come here when I want something quick, cheap and good to eat.

I've been here a few times and it used to be better before! I think it's gotten slightly worse since they've grown in popularity, but is still a decent place.

excerpts: We asked for the tea salad, fish chowder noodle soup, and yamo house noodles.
yamo house noodles.author: Justin C.
yamo house noodles.review:
I was told that this place had good, cheap food, but the people working there didn't speak English. I came by with my friends twice but there was a wait so we decided to come back the next day at 2pm... there was still a wait. After ten or so mins, the ladies working asked us what we wanted (in English) and were pretty friendly. So we put in our orders while we were still waiting which is pretty efficient of them. We asked for the tea salad, fish chowder noodle soup, and yamo house noodles. Each dish was $6.50. 

The only dish that stood out to me was the tea leaf salad. It was very fragrant. It's hard to describe but had two types of crunchiness one from some fried beans and some from the cabbage. The salad was slightly sweet, incredibly spicy but not too bad. There was a slight herbaciousness and had smokey Jasmine flavors. I really enjoyed this dish so extra stars for that. The others... not so much. I thought the house noodles were a bit bland but my friend really liked them. I remember it being a little light on the protein. The fish chowder soup had a weird flavor that I didn't quite enjoy nor could I place what was off about it. It was topped with some kind of crispy crackers? There was no actual fish in this dish. I wouldn't order this again

In all a pretty enjoyable experience but I wouldn't want to wait more than 10 mins for it... It really depends on how fast the people eat because this place is TINY. Hardly any space between the barline counter and the wall to exit the restaurant.

excerpts: We ordered the tea salad, yamo house noodles with beef, and curry chicken.
I am giving Yamo 2 stars for the food.
The tea salad was covered with too much sauce, so couldn't really figure out what I was eating with all the sweetness.
And it was a pretty small portion for tea salad.
The house noodles were a bit too stuck together, but the beef was pretty tasty.
And the curry chicken was a bit too bland for my taste.
But it was extremely cost affordable.
It was only $6 per dish..
so think it averaged $19?
So if you want a cost affordable meal, come here.
But if you want some good Burmese food, then I suggest going elsewhere.
Overall, a one time meal and will be getting my Burmese food elsewhere next time.
yamo house noodles.author: Jackie C.
yamo house noodles.review:
My friend and I were trying to find a cost-affordable take-out spot for our small group, and since Yamo was nearly, dropped by here. The seating area is small, so I would suggest take-out if you're a larger group. We were just coming to pick up food. We placed our order over the phone, and the lady was pretty abrupt with all our orders. Entering in, we saw that it was basically a two person show for taking orders and cooking, so can understand the abruptness especially during a busy dinner time.

We ordered the tea salad, yamo house noodles with beef, and curry chicken. I am giving Yamo 2 stars for the food. The tea salad was covered with too much sauce, so couldn't really figure out what I was eating with all the sweetness. And it was a pretty small portion for tea salad. The house noodles were a bit too stuck together, but the beef was pretty tasty. And the curry chicken was a bit too bland for my taste. But it was extremely cost affordable. It was only $6 per dish..so think it averaged $19? So if you want a cost affordable meal, come here. But if you want some good Burmese food, then I suggest going elsewhere. Overall, a one time meal and will be getting my Burmese food elsewhere next time.

excerpts: The Yamo House Noodles with Beef ($6.25) was also tasty and a really good bang for your buck!
yamo house noodles.author: MyTien P.
yamo house noodles.review:
Probably one of the cheapest meals you will ever eat when you're in SF, unless you're eating at a fast food joint, but you know what I mean!

Came here on a Wednesday evening at work and was surprised to see how TINY the shop was. It literally is a hole in the wall with 2 ladies working the kitchen/cashier and a counter space that can only fit 8 people. The ladies working in the kitchen really know how to cook fast and efficiently so getting a seat shouldn't take too long!

The Tea Leaf Salad ($6.25) was my favorite dish of the night and I found it really flavorful with the various nuts. This dish is definitely a must order if you're going to eat here! The Yamo House Noodles with Beef ($6.25) was also tasty and a really good bang for your buck!

I would suggest coming here with only one other person since this restaurant is so small and can't accommodate big groups. Also don't be thrown off if you hear the ladies working the kitchen yelling you at some foreign language. It's just a part of the experience eating here!

excerpts:
: This place is *CASH ONLY*.

MUST HAVE:
Yamo house noodles with pork 
Potstickers
Mohinga (fish chowder soup)

No-frills-and-get-down-to-business kinda place.
yamo house noodles.author: Payal B.
yamo house noodles.review:
The tiniest yet, the most comforting hole-in-the-wall Burmese goodness! Fast, cheap, and delicious, Yamo offers the most satisfying bowl of noodles for as less $6, which is unheard of in this city with skyrocketing prices. Mission Gem! 

Note: This place is *CASH ONLY*.

MUST HAVE:
Yamo house noodles with pork 
Potstickers
Mohinga (fish chowder soup)

No-frills-and-get-down-to-business kinda place.
The place is tiny, with just 10 countertop stools. 
So be prepared to wait in line. However, the line moves fast.
Not good for large groups, ideal for 1 or 2.
This place is run by two older ladies who speaks little English and not the best with manners. But don't let this scare you off. 
Service is fast and food will hit the right spot. 
The menu is limited, and the dishes are for $6.

excerpts: All the food is inexpensive and tasty, especially the Yamo House Noodles!
Juicy beef atop golden garlic noodles bursting with flavor!
A little bit too much sodium but not a deal breaker.
More than one customer ordered multiple servings of the house noodles while I was there.
The food comes ridiculously fast.
yamo house noodles.author: Stephen C.
yamo house noodles.review:
A hole in the wall, in every sense of the phrase. In a nondescript grimy alley you could unknowingly pass by a real gem of Burmese deliciousness. A tiny cave of a restaurant that sits about eight people directly in front of the kitchen.

All the food is inexpensive and tasty, especially the Yamo House Noodles! Juicy beef atop golden garlic noodles bursting with flavor! A little bit too much sodium but not a deal breaker. More than one customer ordered multiple servings of the house noodles while I was there.
The food comes ridiculously fast. Many people walked in, ordered to go, and left with their food in times that would put fast-food chains to shame.

A star gets docked for service. I suppose I shouldn't be too surprised that these ladies are only here to cook, serve, take your money, and move on. Don't expect a friendly demeanor. They are masters of the minimally civil passive aggressive attitude. "NO PICTURES!" the cashier screams deafeningly as I raise my camera to my food. The cook shrieks too, but not in any language I understand. All of the patrons in the restaurant and a passerby turn their focus to the commotion. Okay fine. Yes, chef. The camera is going away but couldn't you at least put a sign up or something? Not every picture taker wants to experience a Gordan Ramsay episode.
I took one anyway.

excerpts: Their yamo house noodles were pretty good with pork and we also tried their mango chicken along with it.
Definitely going to make my way back to this place again.
yamo house noodles.author: Luis T.
yamo house noodles.review: Definitely a diamond in the rough. Very small and only seats a few people in the restaurant. Would definitely recommend take out for this place. Everything on the menu is pretty cheap, but really good and full of flavor. Their yamo house noodles were pretty good with pork and we also tried their mango chicken along with it. Definitely going to make my way back to this place again.

excerpts: Yamo House Noodles (3/5) noodles mixed with garlic and a choice of beef, chicken or pork - ours was beef.
yamo house noodles.author: Janice K.
yamo house noodles.review:
Chinese mom meets Seinfield's soup nazi. If you don't understand my Seinfield reference, go youtube this now. I assure you, it's hilarious. 

The Yamo experience is a mix of PTSD of every confusing childhood memory of being scolded combined with the pleasant memory of home cooked meals prepared by your Chinese mom. 

The food ranged from good to great (review below), but the experience of eating at Yamo was absolutely terrifying with a squeeze of comical. Upon entering the restaurant you'll be greeted by a very angry mama cook who seemly appears to yell at everyone: her daughter, the other mama cook and all patrons. Service is quick - you enter, you order your food while you wait to be seated - you get seated, and immediately the dishes you previously ordered are flung at you.  Yes, dishes are airborne for a few seconds before clattering loudly in front of you - maybe safe to have a napkin ready for the splash zone. 

Oh did you want to take a photo of your food? You better take it ninja style or ask permission to take "food photos only" because mama cook will scream at you from across the restaurant " NO PHOTOS". 

Did you want to enjoy your food over good conversation? Hopefully you've mastered the art of talking and inhaling food at the same time, otherwise, you'll get the stare down from mama cook if your chopsticks aren't forking food into your mouth while you're swallowing forcefully. Take a tip and skip the chewing because your bill will arrive in front of you shortly. After you pay - and remember cash only - you're thanked very loudly, but if you listen between the lines, mama cook's real thoughts are GTFO because you're holding up her business. 

We ate (each dish ~$6.25 pre tax): 

1. Tea Salad (2/5) - Burmese style salad mixed with fermented tea leaves. Salad comes premixed.The salad was more spicy and lemony than a typical Burmese tea salad, and peanuts were roasted/fried, but no longer crunchy. It was clear the salad was pre made and sitting in the fridge ready to be served. 

2. Mango Chicken (4/5) - Stir fried vegetables with mango and chicken, served with a bed of white rice. The "wok hei" or in english, "the breath of the wok"  was real- this dish had a complex smoky flavor that is only achieved by cooking fresh ingredients over extreme heat. The flavors of the chicken coated in sauce were deep, and the bell peppers and mango retained the textural crunch. Would have liked more than 3 pieces of chicken. 

3. Black Bean Fish (4/5) - Stir fried vegetables with black bean white fish, served with a bed of white rice. As above, the wok hei flavor was legit. Flavors were on deep and smokey. Texture was crunchy and crispy. Fish portion was could be larger. 

4. Yamo House Noodles (3/5) noodles mixed with garlic and a choice of beef, chicken or pork - ours was beef. Noodles were cooked almost al dante and heavily coated in oil, mixed with garlic and topped with a pinch of extremely salty beef crumbles. 

Overall: 

Food - 3.5/5 - Food here definitely has potential. On one hand the wok hei flavor is on point, on the other, portion sizes of protein is minimal and often too salty. Prices are cheap, which makes the value for food was a good bang for the buck in SF. 

Service 1/5- From my notes above, the experience at Yamo was conflicting. I was terrified from the moment I walked in, but also couldn't help uncontrollably laugh at the situation. There were some frequenters who came for take out and you can tell they've experienced the PTSD themselves and have learned better to just get take out. One after one, they'll come in and skip the banter, and just say the numbers of the dishes they wanted to order. Put down the money and with a slight bow retreat backwards out the door where they waited patiently until their meal was prepared. Pro tip: if you want to experience yamo without the PTSD, just come for take out. 

Environment 1/5- This rating is likely skewed from the notes above - but hard to enjoy a meal when you're feeling afraid. Minimal seating ~ 10, expect to wait 30+ mins if you come during regular meal hours. Definitely come on a pre laundry day because you'll walk out smelling like Yamo. 

Eat take out from here.

excerpts: I'd highly recommend the tea leaf salad and Yamo house noodles!
yamo house noodles.author: Sean S.
yamo house noodles.review:
Food 5/5 stars 
Service 2-3/stars

That about sums up the place, if you can deal with the old ladies yelling at you about your order for the delicious food then you have yourself a solid lunch/dinner option. 
Also the restaurant is the definition of hole in the wall and cleanliness could be better. However it reminds me of eating good food in Asia so I'm not complaining. 

All the food here is mostly under $10 and is scrumptious. 
I'd highly recommend the tea leaf salad and Yamo house noodles!

excerpts: Has the Yamo house noodles with pork - super tasty pork and the noodles were like garlic noodles.
yamo house noodles.author: Traci H.
yamo house noodles.review:
Total hole in the wall goodness. 

If you get claustrophobic this place might not be for you but they do takeout. 

Has the Yamo house noodles with pork - super tasty pork and the noodles were like garlic noodles. I added some sriracha sauce to give it some spice. 

The fish chowder noodles were like a bowl of flavorful soup with rice noodles. 

Potstickers were super plump homemade tasting potstickers. Too much cabbage for my liking but you can't turn down homemade flavor (at least it tasted like it)

I want to try the cold noodles next time and the curry!

Super tiny spot on 18th that if there's no seats you'll be waiting out on the street

Drinks are from the fridge only, including bottled water (eg no water service)

Maybe 12 seats at the counter. So you watch them cook and do everything. Is it the most spotless kitchen well maybe not but if you have major food allergies you probably shouldn't go to little spots like this. 

I think there was a sign for the restroom but I didn't venture back there. 

Cash only.

excerpts: I got the Yamo House Noodles w/Beef.
They should rename it "Noodles from a box with beef jerky on top.
The noodles were overly cooked and mushy and cup o' noodles that were drained and stir fried would have tasted better.
The beef it came with could be compared to 5 tiny pieces of beef jerky.
yamo house noodles.author: Jennifer T.
yamo house noodles.review:
BEWARE of an Asian place that no Asians eat at!!!

The food is not good and that's the bottom line. I got the Yamo House Noodles w/Beef. They should rename it "Noodles from a box with beef jerky on top." The noodles were overly cooked and mushy and cup o' noodles that were drained and stir fried would have tasted better. The beef it came with could be compared to 5 tiny pieces of beef jerky. Just not good.......

Cherry on top? Expect 0 customer service. The ladies working there must hate life or something because they are pretty much rude to everyone that steps into that place. I am used to bad service in Asian restaurants, but Yamo takes it to a whole other level. They pretty much not only hate you, each other, they hate life in general.

You should pass on Yamo.

excerpts: * Yamo House Noodles made with noodles mixed with fried garlic, and a choice of meat.
I got the BEEF.
My favorite dish.
It's like garlic noodles topped with beef for a good price.
So YUMMY!
I can eat that everyday.
yamo house noodles.author: Sandy B.
yamo house noodles.review:
So glad I finally got to try this place. Small, definitely your "HOLE IN THE WALL", about 10 seats at the counter. As I was dining, I notice they mostly do take outs. FYI, if you expect good services, don't come here. Don't complain, they really don't care. I didn't think services is awful, well at least not to me. She smile once at me. They do charge you for everything when it's to go. Don't expect anything free here and it's CASH ONLY.  I wish I lived close by, it would be my go to restaurant. 

Food is YUMMY and you can't beat the price. Smaller portions but who needs super big ones anyways. Better for the waist. haha And you can try more things. I prefer more varieties anyways. "ASIA" style and I love it. 

**Potstickers are filled with pork, cabbage, and carrots. My friend was so amaze by them. Very soft and juicy on the inside. Not crispy, just a little to add in some texture. 
** Tea Salad are made with tea leave, cabbage, fresh tomato, onion, dried shrimp & variety of fried bean, nuts and sesame seeds. - Super small dish but love the flavors. It was really good but I think way too much onions. If you want more for the money, the other two salads are bigger in portion. 
** Yamo House Noodles made with noodles mixed with fried garlic, and a choice of meat. I got the BEEF. My favorite dish. It's like garlic noodles topped with beef for a good price. So YUMMY! I can eat that everyday. 
**Yamo Cold Noodles made with cold noodles mixed with house special flavor, onions, cabbage, cucumbers, and chicken. - FYI its not really cold noodle. Because they stir fry the chicken and veggies and place it on top of the noodles. Therefore making the noodles warm. I know but its so good. The sauce they use is amazing. And I notice lots of people do order that for take out.

I'm coming back for sure and try everything else. Everything I had was DELICIOUS! Drinks are like self serve, bottles and cans. $1.50 each. There can be a wait but not too bad because mostly everyone orders take out. It's hot inside and I went yesterday when it was 85 degrees at 730pm. I sat by the door but still hot. Can't wait to come back.

excerpts: The Yamo house noodles (chicken) and chow mein (chicken) are absolutely worth what might seem like harsh service.
Actually the staff are very nice, in their own way.
Do not miss this unique spot!
yamo house noodles.author: Max C.
yamo house noodles.review: The Yamo house noodles (chicken) and chow mein (chicken) are absolutely worth what might seem like harsh service. Actually the staff are very nice, in their own way. Do not miss this unique spot!

excerpts: I tried both the Yamo House Noodles and the Fish Noodle Soup.
Both dishes were well done and prepared quickly.
The wait was not too long, but I came here around 1:30PM.
However, the prices were incredibly cheap!
For less than $7, I left here with both a full and happy belly, and smelling like noodles.
So if you are not prepared to smell like food for the rest of the day, I would save coming here for another time.
Otherwise, this place does a great job making classic Burmese dishes when compared to more popular restaurants like Burmese Superstar.
yamo house noodles.author: Adeline C.
yamo house noodles.review: Pleasantly surprised by this hole-in-the-walk Burmese restaurant. To be clear, this is truly a hole in SF. There was only space to seat about 7-8 people along a bar right in front of the kitchen. I tried both the Yamo House Noodles and the Fish Noodle Soup. Both dishes were well done and prepared quickly. The wait was not too long, but I came here around 1:30PM. However, the prices were incredibly cheap! For less than $7, I left here with both a full and happy belly, and smelling like noodles. So if you are not prepared to smell like food for the rest of the day, I would save coming here for another time. Otherwise, this place does a great job making classic Burmese dishes when compared to more popular restaurants like Burmese Superstar.

excerpts: We ordered the Yamo House Noodles and Chicken Mango.
yamo house noodles.author: Jennifer L.
yamo house noodles.review:
Service here is speedy, snappy and sassy. Yamo's personality is really something else, even among hole in the wall places. 

Upon arrival you'll either be greeted by a long line or a single server barking "what do you want!?" as soon as you step foot in the doorway. 

Seating is extremely limited - a single bar strip facing the kitchen so take it to go if you have more than 3 people. 

The food is flavorful and tasty! Portions are more than fair for the price but you won't be full. Recommend ordering appetizers if you're hungry. 

We ordered the Yamo House Noodles and Chicken Mango. Chicken mango was spicy and noodles were nice and chewy! 

Come here with an open mind and don't take any of the snapping at personally! They run a tight ship here and each party will get ragged on for something different. For us it was asking twice for water, for the group after us it was asking for extra chili sauce. 

You'll have to look beyond the grease / rough edges and not sweat the little things here. All part of the Yamo experience! :)

excerpts: As for their Yamo House Noodles with your choice of beef, chicken or pork, it was slurping good.
yamo house noodles.author: Tiffany D.
yamo house noodles.review:
Undeniably a hole in the wall that seats about 8-10 people for yummy, homely cooked Burmese entrees!  Just bring one other person with you!  It's impossible to fit a group together in here.

I felt like a compacted sardine while dining here at this grub spot, but the food was worthy to try!

The food is so cheap here - more or less 6 bucks each for appetizers or entrees.

I love their Tea Leaf Salad!  It was crunchy, tasty and unique.  Too bad the proportion of this salad is small.  It teased my palate.

Their Stir-Fried Black Bean Fish with Rice was good.  Spice it up with their side vinegar-ed, mini, chopped jalepenos and it will be smacking delicious!

As for their Yamo House Noodles with your choice of beef, chicken or pork, it was slurping good.  

My friend and I couldn't stay a bit to chat ever more after we finished our meals- we felt rushed with the fair line waiting outside!

excerpts: I ordered the Yamo house noodles with beef to-go.
It took less than 4 minutes and I was on my way.
Noodles were tasty and I will definitely be going back to try something new.
yamo house noodles.author: Michael C.
yamo house noodles.review: Small place with just a few stool to sit at. I ordered the Yamo house noodles with beef to-go. It took less than 4 minutes and I was on my way. Noodles were tasty and I will definitely be going back to try something new.

excerpts: * Yamo House Noodles with Pork (Heaven)
Curry Prawns?
yamo house noodles.author: Paul D.
yamo house noodles.review:
I just don't get here as often as I should....

I first came here quite a number of years ago on a date and it was my first experience with Burmese food. It got me hooked.

I've been here quite a bit and I've never been disappointed. The food is always excellent, and the price is ridiculously cheap. Two people can eat for under twenty bucks. The place is small and they cook right in front of you so, expect to smell like a kitchen for the rest of the night.

I love the ladies that run this joint. While the whiny types think they're rude the fact is, they are working hard, making tons of orders, inside and take out, and they're just plain no-nonsense.

If you're lucky and they have fresh coconut, be careful before you order it. Seeing the little old lady hacking into it (and I mean HACKING into it) with a BIG f'ing cleaver left me with a mild case of PTSD. Holy cow!! and, I served in the Army...

My favs:

* Tea Leaf Salad, the bomb
* Mango Salad, Spicy (very much so)
* Yamo House Noodles with Pork (Heaven)
* Curry Prawns? NO SHRIMP!!!!!

Eating in, you need to have some etiquette. The place is small, really small, I mean really really small (like, you probably have a closet bigger than this restaurant). So, be prepared to scoot over to make room for people coming in. And for crying out loud, be a good sport about it. It's a down home friendly place so, you should be too.

excerpts: I really like the Yamo House Noodles.
yamo house noodles.author: Dang L.
yamo house noodles.review: I had high expectations from this place because it was recommended to me from an elite yelper friend.  Yamo definitely met those expectations.  Cheap for the quality and quantity of food that you get.  I really like the Yamo House Noodles.  It is simple but flavorful and fills you up.  The only thing that I did not like here is that it is really small and a bit cramped.  You sit on stools and eat at the counter in front of the kitchen.  It is kind of cool because you can watch them cook everything while you are waiting.  I came at that awkward hour between lunch and dinner so I got in right away.  However after I finished eating, there was a long line waiting to get in.  You get your own drinks in their refrigerator.  I would recommend getting soda because both the soda can and water bottle cost a dollar.

excerpts: $19 for Yamo house noodles, tea leaf salad, and black bean tofu (all enough to feed 2 people).
yamo house noodles.author: Stephanie T.
yamo house noodles.review:
There's Burma Love, which is a pricey hipster amazing Burmese place in the Mission. A few blocks away: Burma Love's uglier, greasier, but cheaper sister. 

Cash only.
$19 for Yamo house noodles, tea leaf salad, and black bean tofu (all enough to feed 2 people).

This hole-in-the-wall spot is tiny, with just a few places to sit, making it ideal for a solo traveler wanting to get in/out, but more likely will suit the likes of take-out peeps. 

Get ready to blot your mouth (grease) and add some Sriracha (it's pretty mild) but as far as Burmese goes, this is definitely second-place to Burma Love. I have yet to try Burma Star, but will let you know how that one stacks-up once I know :)

excerpts: We ordered the Tea Leaf Salad, the Yamo House Noodles with chicken and the Mango Chicken.
The tea leaf salad was really good - just the right levels of spicy and tangy.
The noodles and the mango chicken were also excellent.
yamo house noodles.author: Jessica Z.
yamo house noodles.review:
I stopped by Yamo last night with a friend and got seated almost immediately! 

We ordered the Tea Leaf Salad, the Yamo House Noodles with chicken and the Mango Chicken. The tea leaf salad was really good - just the right levels of spicy and tangy. The noodles and the mango chicken were also excellent. Definitely would get them again.

Sitting inside is a little stuffy and you will definitely smell like grease afterwards, so I would recommend getting it to go!

excerpts: We  ordered the tea leaf salad, Yamo house noodles, and mango chicken.
yamo house noodles.author: Nick J.
yamo house noodles.review:
Came in sat down to order while the bf went to the atm.  I was told to wait outside as soon as I told them we were a party of 2.  Luckily he came back from and we grabbed some seats.  We  ordered the tea leaf salad, Yamo house noodles, and mango chicken.  All tasted really good even though the mango chicken seemed off. 

Then we noticed that we were actually eating the girl next to us cold noodles, which were actually not cold. Since the girl next to us complained she received the wrong dish they slam the mango chicken on the counter next to us. Since we already started eating we ended up with both dishes. Then it got really awkward as the girl glares at us while we eat and they take forever to replace her food. 

Next up a odd couple comes in one singing and the other just kinda being loud with her request.  Some how her pot sticker sauce wasn't right for her.  Think she was expecting some type of sweet and sour sauce.  So she asked for another sauce, but basically told no.  Then she asked for the chili sauce calling it the sweet and spicy sauce and told no that's not sweet!  Then this is when It gets good. Then all the sudden she tells the lady at the counter there was a hair on the pot stickers.  Oh the look on the ladies face behind the counter.  She grabs the dish throws it out and says "No more!"  Tried so hard to keep it together.

We hurry get the check and notice we were charged for the dish we did not order, but we just decided let it go. So end of story really tasty food, angry service, very tight space, and I wouldn't recommend making any complaints.

excerpts: Ordered their Tea salad (of course), yamo house noodles with pork, fish chowder noodle soup, and black bean fish for our group of 3.
Yamo House noodles with pork was really simple.
Just noodles with stir fried pork.
There wasn't too much seasoning that I could see, but it was still rather tasty.
Fish chowder noodle soup was probably my favorite.
I don't know what was the crispy bit of the soup was, but it created a great texture contrast to the soup, which I loved.
The black bean fish dish was probably my least favorite of the 4.
It was good, but I think I'm used to the black beans not being so strong.
yamo house noodles.author: Mai K.
yamo house noodles.review:
This is how my visit to Yamo went down. 

Friend: Their Tea salad is great. Definitely recommend. 
Me: Out of all their items, you recommend a salad? 
Friend: It's really good. 

So we wait about 30 minutes to get into this place because it's basically a hole in the wall that seats 8 people at any one time at a bar like setting We order a few things to try since their pricing is quite reasonable. $4-6 per item if I remember correctly. 

Ordered their Tea salad (of course), yamo house noodles with pork, fish chowder noodle soup, and black bean fish for our group of 3. Tea salad was really delicious. It's comprised of a lot of deep fried onions, which gives the salad a nice crunch to it. You really have to just try it out. The dish is rather small so I'd get one for myself next time. Yamo House noodles with pork was really simple. Just noodles with stir fried pork. There wasn't too much seasoning that I could see, but it was still rather tasty. Fish chowder noodle soup was probably my favorite. I don't know what was the crispy bit of the soup was, but it created a great texture contrast to the soup, which I loved. The black bean fish dish was probably my least favorite of the 4. It was good, but I think I'm used to the black beans not being so strong. I prefer a more subtle taste. 

Our four dishes totaled up to $24 and for $8 per person, that's a pretty sweet deal.

excerpts: #5, the tea leaf salad and #15, the Yamo House noodles with beef.
These noodles are the best!
My comfort food!
And then afterwards, walk over two blocks to Bi-Rite and wash it down with the best ice cream in the city!
yamo house noodles.author: Amy X.
yamo house noodles.review:
This is for sure one of my favorite hidden gems in SF. Brought a friend from out of town to try and I think he was pretty impressed. He said he felt like he was eating in Asia. Can't really get this type of hole-in-the-wall experience elsewhere in city. 

Best time to come is the weird hour. Between lunch and dinner (3-4pm) so you don't have to wait. There's only about 10 counter-bar seats so you can imagine how quick this place could fill up during normal eating times. 

Order #5, the tea leaf salad and #15, the Yamo House noodles with beef. These noodles are the best! My comfort food! And then afterwards, walk over two blocks to Bi-Rite and wash it down with the best ice cream in the city!

excerpts: Or what he got at least (yamo house noodles chicken).
yamo house noodles.author: Kaitlyn E.
yamo house noodles.review:
I went here once before thinking it was the complete bombdiggity. I had received the tea leaf noodles, house noodles, samosas, and the fresh coconut juice. I also came during dinner time and had to wait a bit so maybe that's why I thought my first experience was just SOOO good. 

Came here again after forgetting the name of this hole in the wall and finally found it on yelp. I was SO excited to bring my boy here. 

Don't get me wrong, he actually loved this place. Or what he got at least (yamo house noodles chicken). The service however........

Is it because we came during lunch time rather than dinner when there was absolutely no line and ample seats for diners?

The service was just so mediocre. Everyone seemed sad, out of it, unattentive. Maybe it was just a bad day, but the food was good at least. Potstickers were a new try, wouldn't recommend. Also, didn't seem like they had an option to have the cut coconuts to drink from this time. But I didn't ask, they didn't offer sorta thang. So shrug. 

That's my take on it. I'd go again for a cheap quick delicious meal anytime. Just wasn't impressed this second time around.

excerpts: My two favorite entrees are the Yamo House Noodles and the Mango Chicken.
The noodles are very greasy and filled with tons of flavor and a light sauce.
The meat is also always tender and cooked very well.
The mango chicken also has tons of flavor, as there is nothing better than mixing the rice with the sauce and chicken.
yamo house noodles.author: Aaron W.
yamo house noodles.review:
Believe me when I say that this place is a legit hole in the wall. There's only approximately 10 seats at the counter, so you might have to wait at times. In spite of the cramped space though, Yamo seriously knows how to produce some delicious food. The women who work here know how to run this place efficiently, cost-effectively, and most importantly, deliciously. 

The food here is nice and incredibly flavorful (and oily). The tea leaf salad is a great starter. Although it's a little on the small side, it has great flavor and it's different from your typical tea leaf salad. My two favorite entrees are the Yamo House Noodles and the Mango Chicken. The noodles are very greasy and filled with tons of flavor and a light sauce. The meat is also always tender and cooked very well. The mango chicken also has tons of flavor, as there is nothing better than mixing the rice with the sauce and chicken. The chunks of fresh mango within the dish are generous and add a nice sweetness to the dish.

Yes, you may not be getting the best service nor the cleanest services, but it all adds to the unique hole-in-the-wall-type vibe. It always amazes me to see how fast they are able to cook despite the lack of space and dim lighting. Even more, all the dishes here are no more than $6! (I think they actually recently bumped it up to $6.25....but still, it's a bargain!) What more could you ask for?! Don't be intimidated by its exterior (or interior for that matter...) appearance - this place serves great food at a great price!

excerpts: My friends and I shared the garlic noodles, Yamo house noodles, and mango chicken.
All of them were delicious, but the Yamo house noodles were by far my favorite (got them with tofu).
yamo house noodles.author: Michelle K.
yamo house noodles.review:
Stopped in at 2pm on a weekday and was fortunate to find extra seats at the bar (granted it was a tight squeeze).  My friends and I shared the garlic noodles, Yamo house noodles, and mango chicken.  All of them were delicious, but the Yamo house noodles were by far my favorite (got them with tofu).

The bar only seats about 8-10 people, but there is a takeout option.  I've seen a massive line out here, so my only thought is to go at a very off-peak time.  Great little hole-in-the-wall.

excerpts: I had the yamo house noodles and tea salad.
yamo house noodles.author: Sam G.
yamo house noodles.review:
Phenomenal. I had the yamo house noodles and tea salad. Both are really good. 

The place is small and nothing fancy. The staff is pretty straight forward but the food is simply good.

excerpts: We had tea leaf salad, Yamo house noodles with pork, and Yamo cold noodles with chicken.
The flavors were so so, chicken and pork were on the tough side.
Really bad service.
We arrived at 12:00 PM, 6 seats were available.
We sat at the counter for at least 30 minutes watching the two women doing prep work that should have been done when they're opened at 11:00 AM, before our orders were taken.
The worse part was everything's very oily.
yamo house noodles.author: TopCat W.
yamo house noodles.review:
We had tea leaf salad, Yamo house noodles with pork, and Yamo cold noodles with chicken.  The flavors were so so, chicken and pork were on the tough side.  Really bad service.  We arrived at 12:00 PM, 6 seats were available.  We sat at the counter for at least 30 minutes watching the two women doing prep work that should have been done when they're opened at 11:00 AM, before our orders were taken.  The worse part was everything's very oily. After we left, we both smelled like old deep fried oil.

Will not return.

excerpts: We got the Yamo house noodles with chicken and the samusas, both of which were very tasty.
It was pretty clear that their takeout business is strong, so since the place itself is so small I would definitely recommend getting takeout.
yamo house noodles.author: Amy Y.
yamo house noodles.review: This little hole in the wall is the definition of home cooking. The ladies that work here are adorable and it's great to see them cooking as you sit at the bar. We got the Yamo house noodles with chicken and the samusas, both of which were very tasty. It was pretty clear that their takeout business is strong, so since the place itself is so small I would definitely recommend getting takeout.

excerpts: I had the Yamo House noodles with beef.
it was completely lackluster.
No sauce on the noodles except for some fried garlic and scallions.
The beef wasn't even marinated in anything and tasted like it was going bad.
yamo house noodles.author: Wen C.
yamo house noodles.review:
I was so excited to have my first Burmese food experience at this renowned hole in the wall or at least they say. I was so disappointed.

I had the Yamo House noodles with beef. it was completely lackluster. No sauce on the noodles except for some fried garlic and scallions. The beef wasn't even marinated in anything and tasted like it was going bad. I almost threw up even.

The catfish chowder was completely unsatisfying. I couldn't even taste the catfish. There were not even chunks or bits of fish. The flavors didn't grab me.

I definitely got what I paid for, all $12 of it. I should of just saved it for So wings and black bean noodles. They need to open before 4.

excerpts:
Yamo House Noodles, Chicken Chow Mein & Curry
Total:  $20.75
yamo house noodles.author: Genevieve Y.
yamo house noodles.review:
Date & Time:  Saturday November 21, 2009 @ 4:30pm
Company:  Michael
Crowd:  Neighborhood Peeps & Hipsters
Vibe:  Very Casual
Decor:  Hole-in-The-Wall w/ Counter-Seating
Service:  Nice & Efficient Asian Ladies 
Imbibe:  Fresh Coconut Drink
Devour:  Yamo House Noodles, Chicken Chow Mein & Curry
Total:  $20.75

excerpts:
Tea leaf salad
Yamo House Noodles
Yamo Cold Noodles
yamo house noodles.author: Moo C.
yamo house noodles.review:
If you like eating in a closet, come here!  I've only eaten IN the resto a couple of times, preferring to call in and pick up my order.  It's definitely a tight squeeze and the wait can be long at times. If you're there for the first time with your sweetie to keep you warm as you stand in line...go for it (but I digress)...the food is really good.

It's amusing to watch the ladies behind the counter do their thang.  Shouts all around, but it's a graceful symphony that results in an absolutely happy tummy.

Prices are very reasonable, and the food is served to you very quickly.  All of the dishes I've tried here have been good, but some faves:
Chicken noodle soup
Tea leaf salad
Yamo House Noodles
Yamo Cold Noodles

If you're having a meal there, ask for fresh coconut.  As you sip on the juice of a baby coconut cracked open just for you, enjoy the tastes, smells and sounds this Burmese eatery.

Oh, don't plan on going anywhere after because those scents stick ;)

excerpts: Yamo House Noodles mixed with fried garlic, and a choice of beef, chicken or pork - $6 - Greasy but so delightful!
Every bite is full of that garlic taste.
We got chicken and i absolutely LOVE the way that they prepare the chicken.
Crispy and crunchy on the outside and still juicy on the inside.
The noodles are the perfect amount of chewy and i really enjoy the sauce that they mix all together in this unique stir fry.
yamo house noodles.author: Sandy L.
yamo house noodles.review:
The perfectooooo greasy spoon and Burmese/Chinese food at that! We got lucky and there were a few empty seats, Tues 11am...you're thinking lines on a Tuesday? Yup, this is the type of place that does! Seats about 10 on the bar stool so try to go on your off-hour or you could be waiting for a while.  The better alternative would to actually get the food TO GO to avoid the long line situation altogether!

Chicken Noodle Soup coconut noodle soup with chicken, onions, and cilantro - $6 -  I've had traditional Burmese chicken noodle soup and this comes pretty freakin close!  It's not the best I've had but when you don't have the time to prep the broth 24 hours in advance, this is a good alternative.  They cook to order and the broth is creamy and full, the noodles are cooked to order and they have nice full flavors of coconut, garlic, onions and cilantro.   

Tea Salad tea leaves, cabbage, fresh tomato, onion, dried shrimp & variety of fried bean, nuts and sesame seeds - $6 - I'm not sure why there was no tea leaves??  It was GOOD but not GREAT.  Yes all very fresh ingredients but wish there was more tea leaves to bring out that strong bitter tea leaf taste.  ah well...  maybe they should RENAME this item because if i didn't expect tea leaves i would say this is quite an excellent salad!

Yamo House Noodles mixed with fried garlic, and a choice of beef, chicken or pork - $6 - Greasy but so delightful!  Every bite is full of that garlic taste.  We got chicken and i absolutely LOVE the way that they prepare the chicken.  Crispy and crunchy on the outside and still juicy on the inside.  The noodles are the perfect amount of chewy and i really enjoy the sauce that they mix all together in this unique stir fry.  This is MY GO TO ITEM.  

Next time I think I might call ahead to order TO GO but this was a good experience sitting in this little piece of Mission district heaven.

excerpts: Yamo House Noodles

(I like it with pork)
4)
yamo house noodles.author: Susan L.
yamo house noodles.review:
Yamo is a hole in the wall run by dragon ladies.  What to expect: great food and kind of intimidating service! 
  
1) wait in a long line.  (although if you come 45 mins before prime dining times, the wait will be really short! 11am, 6pm)
2) sit on a rocky stool at a greasy countertop
3) get yelled at if you don't order within 3 minutes
4) eat elbow to elbow with your neighbors and hear everyone's conversations
5) possibly get yelled at again: "are you done??!", at which point you will pay a ridiculously awesome price for all the food you got with cash only.
6) smell really disgusting after, so bad you would stink up the entire cartrain on bart.

What to eat, to share with one other:
1) Samusas
2) Tea salad (so delicious, best thing on the menu! better than burma superstar's)  You may need two orders. nommms
3) Yamo House Noodles (I like it with pork)
4) Fish chowder noodle soup (my burmese friends say its really good here!)

excerpts: - Yamo House Noodles with Beef:
Greasy stir-friend egg noodles with strips of tender beef.
Basic and filling.
Would order over and over.
- Fish Chowder: It's hard to beat street-side mohinga in Myanmar, but Yamo comes pretty close.
