Be weary of  bones, because this catfish stew has tons.
It's delightfully thick and spicy.
yamo house noodles.author: Linda T.
yamo house noodles.review:
So good upon first taste, came back again for dinner on the same day. Cash only, 10 spaces, bar seating, crammed and air full of frying grease = some of the best food I've had here in SF. And after being in Myanmar, the best Burmese food I've had outside of Burma.

- Tea Leaf Salad: Tiny portions, but full of flavor and texture. Fried beans, nuts, tangy perserved veggies with fresh shredded veggies. $6.
- Yamo House Noodles with Beef: Greasy stir-friend egg noodles with strips of tender beef. Basic and filling. Would order over and over.
- Fish Chowder: It's hard to beat street-side mohinga in Myanmar, but Yamo comes pretty close. Be weary of  bones, because this catfish stew has tons. It's delightfully thick and spicy. The owners claim it's a fantastic hangover cure.

I hope the prices remain low despite the surge in business this place will no doubt receive.

excerpts: Yamo house noodles are the BOMB.
Fresh noodles, delicious flavors.
I wanted a second bowl
but I still had potstickers coming.
Potstickers were moist inside, crunchy outside, and savory all around.
yamo house noodles.author: Fannie S.
yamo house noodles.review:
Holy cow. Total hole-in-a-wall place.  I mean there are barely 7 seats at the bar, and barely any walking room, and they manage to squeeze in a restroom in the back!  You're facing the kitchen, btw....

Food = delicious. It's a bit greasy but the flavors are great.  Yamo house noodles are the BOMB.  Fresh noodles, delicious flavors.  I wanted a second bowl but I still had potstickers coming.  Potstickers were moist inside, crunchy outside, and savory all around.  My sister's beef curry, I thought was boring, even if the potatoes are awesomely fried. 

Service = well, it's a tiny joint, so what you see is exactly what you get.  If you want water, ask.  If you want something else, just ASK.  

Prices = cheap.  $6.00 entrees and $4.25 appetizers, and they have a few beverages too. 

Overall, I'll be back...for take out!

excerpts: The Yamo house noodles are DIVINE, and the catfish chowder is great comfort food on a cold day.
yamo house noodles.author: David W.
yamo house noodles.review:
I would be surprised to find a better value anywhere else in the city. $6 a plate is an incredible deal, and everything I've tried so far has been delicious.

The Yamo house noodles are DIVINE, and the catfish chowder is great comfort food on a cold day. The tea leaf salad is another staple and a must-try.

Keep in mind that this is a hole-in-the-wall with bar-seating only, so it does get very crowded and can be hard to get a seat during peak hours. Also, the fact that it's very humid inside and the food is spicy, so you might not want to come on a hot day.

excerpts: Yamo house noodles: yummy!!!!!!!!
It's like yakisoba but Burmese style!
yamo house noodles.author: ASIANDIVAH A.
yamo house noodles.review:
4 Stars for very yummy, true blue Asian homecooking for dirt cheap price. This is what we had for $28: 
1. Tea leaf salad!! I have been to a few Burmese restaurants here in the Bay Area & I can safely say this one beats them all! I thought Burmese Kitchen in Larkin St got the crown but Yamo beats it hands-down! 

2. Fish Chowder Noodle: every sip brings me back to SE Asia!! Home sweet home!! I almost forgot to share it to my date :) A perfect blend of saltiness & spiciness. 

3. Spring Rolls : very fresh & I love watching one of the ladies make it from scratch in front of us:) 

4. Yamo house noodles: yummy!!!!!!!! It's like yakisoba but Burmese style! The chicken is so good! 

5.Mango Chicken: we both agreed that while the house noodles is yummy, this one is Yummier!! 

I find it ridiculous that ppl write poor reviews based on "ambiance"... Oh come on bitches! You expect five-star service for $6???? Now that is down-right stupid & self entitlement! 

If you are looking for very good Burmese-Chinese food with real SE Asian experience (ie old mamas yelling the orders, whipping up one meal after another, tiny crowded place), then Yoma is the go-to place.  

This is officially my new fave place here in Mission!

excerpts: I've had Curry Beef, Yamo House Noodles, and Mango Chicken
and they're all absolutely delicious.
You can't go wrong with anything on the menu.
Something you should definitely get is the tealeaf salad.
It's a definite must try.
The first time I had it, it tasted a lot better than the ones I got in the later visits for some reason :
yamo house noodles.author: Harriet W.
yamo house noodles.review:
Yamo, a little hole in the wall that is definitely worth a try. It has good food and the prices are really cheap. 
Sometimes there's a wait, but that's just a good indicator of good food.

I've had Curry Beef, Yamo House Noodles, and Mango Chicken and they're all absolutely delicious. You can't go wrong with anything on the menu. Something you should definitely get is the tealeaf salad. It's a definite must try. The first time I had it, it tasted a lot better than the ones I got in the later visits for some reason :\

I can't wait to go back and try the rest of the menu.

excerpts: (it's not as gourmet as Burma Superstar's, but cheaper); mushroom stir fry; yamo house noodles (does not have veggies tho).
yamo house noodles.author: Elizabeth T.
yamo house noodles.review:
I've come to Yamo twice. Both times, I did not wait in line because I came at slightly odd hours. There's only ~10 seats and no waiting area, so if you are not in immediately, you'd be standing outside.

Would it be worth waiting 30min-1hr to eat here? For me, NO, because I can make most of the dishes they make within a shorter amount of time.

But is it worth coming if there is at most 15 min wait? YES because it's cheap (~$7 meal), fast, and delicious. A little greasy, yes. Pretty much no service, yes, but because the ladies working here are really really busy.

Recommended: tea leaf salad (it's not as gourmet as Burma Superstar's, but cheaper); mushroom stir fry; yamo house noodles (does not have veggies tho).

excerpts: I called ahead and ordered the mango salad and the yamo house noodles with chicken.
They are definitely down to business in there.
I would challenge anyone to get a smile out of these ladies!
It's also hot and humid in there, I feel like I just walked into a restaurant in Burma.
Instantly I saw how they operated and thought, all dirty, poorly run places have great food
yamo house noodles.author: Audra H.
yamo house noodles.review:
Heard good things and took a bite of my friends dish a couple weeks ago. It was awesome, although very greasy. I went in today. I called ahead and ordered the mango salad and the yamo house noodles with chicken. They are definitely down to business in there. I would challenge anyone to get a smile out of these ladies! It's also hot and humid in there, I feel like I just walked into a restaurant in Burma. Instantly I saw how they operated and thought, all dirty, poorly run places have great food so I'll give it a chance. 

I asked for no onion on the noodles but what I got was just noodles and chicken... No biggie, it was still flavorful and I mixed my mango salad in with it. There should have been cilantro or something on my noodles but maybe they were just playing it safe and left my dish plain. I enjoyed the dishes but there was barely any mango in my salad and my noodles were pretty plain. I was slightly disappointed. 

What really left a bad taste in my mouth was how horrible my stomach felt a few hours after. I saw the way they stacked the bowls of noodles, they shuffled the to-go bowls around and then stacked them on top of each other, so the bottom of one bowl that was God-knows-where was now directly touching the noodles below it... And don't get me started with the FILTHY menus! They are so sticky you could press them against the wall and they would stick. Also, she took my money and started cooking without washing her hands. Lastly, I saw her pour the oil that she used to cook her chicken in a container on the ground. Is she re-using it? Is that for disposal? Who knows what made me sick but I feel terrible and I really wanted to give this place a chance... I really don't care about cleanliness because I enjoy authenticity but when it makes me sick it's a whole different story. I will give them one more chance and update my review accordingly.

excerpts: I ordered the Yamo house noodles with beef, Friend 1 ordered pot stickers and Friend 2 ordered black bean fish with rice.
yamo house noodles.author: KD M.
yamo house noodles.review:
"Fuh heer o to go?"
"Wut u waan?"
"Sicteen dalluh."

The lady taking orders is so sassy! I love it. I went here with two friends for a snack after wandering around Mission. I ordered the Yamo house noodles with beef, Friend 1 ordered pot stickers and Friend 2 ordered black bean fish with rice. The service and food came quick cos they want y'all outta there! 

This place is pretty neat, hole in a wall kind but nothing too amazing. If you want quick, decent, cheap n' small meal, then give it a shot.

I do have two complaints though. Home girl chef uses hella oil. Now there's left over oil and then there's the you tilt your container and you see about 1/4 cup of oil kinda oil. Yikes. Also, the container of spicy sauce or something totally melted my friend's box of pot stickers. Double Yikes.

excerpts:
YAMO HOUSE NOODLES w/ Beef, 6 bucks
Curry over egg noodle, 6 bucks
Pot sticker 8 for $4.50
yamo house noodles.author: Nobu K.
yamo house noodles.review:

Three Old Asian ladies,

In case, if you don't know anything about the place, Yamo is small, only counter seats about ...... 11? yeah, I think 11 or 12 seats. And 3 old Asian women were working their ass-off like Non-Stop, because people are keep coming one after another.

I have to say,

excerpts: Next time I'll have to try the curry fish with rice and the Yamo house noodles with beef.
And get a tea leaf salad just for my gluttonous myself.
This is going to be a fat summer, but at least it will be a cheap and spicy one.
yamo house noodles.author: Liz T.
yamo house noodles.review:
Small, smoky, stools-only... It was love at first sight. I wish I lived in the Mission--I could have bacon donuts for breakfast, super burritos for lunch, and this incredible Burmese stuff for dinner. I would eventually grow out of everything I presently own, but what's a few inches and several pounds? TOTALLY. WORTH. THEM.

My friend and I shared the spring rolls ($3.60), the tea leaf salad ($5.25), the black bean fish with wide rice noodles ($5.25), and the Yamo cold noodles with chicken ($5.25).  We had a satisfying meal of four dishes for a just over $21! Insane for SF!

The rolls were made fresh and super refreshing--good because you're in a bathroom-sized restaurant with a hot kitchen before you. The tea leaf salad was small but scrumptious--I just love the textural contrast of the many ingredients. The fish was lightly fried and really tasty, but the rice noodles were a bit bland. The cold noodles were chewy and flavorful, but the chicken was rather dry. Next time I'll have to try the curry fish with rice and the Yamo house noodles with beef. And get a tea leaf salad just for my gluttonous myself. This is going to be a fat summer, but at least it will be a cheap and spicy one. Everything was mildly spicy except the rolls.

I wasn't crazy about Burmese food after Burma Superstar, after Mandalay, after Burmese Kitchen, but I am definitely a fan after Yamo. The food is so homey and delicious, the Asian ladies are so hard-working and sweet--I can't help but just adore this hole-in-the-wall. 

Although I ate here last night, in anticipation of eating here a lot, I will begin accepting dinner dates here for the rest of the summer starting right now. Don't all flood my inbox at once.

excerpts: For my main dish I got the Yamo house noodles with beef as my choice of meat.
They also had chicken and pork, which my other two friends got.
yamo house noodles.author: Cat P.
yamo house noodles.review:
I would give Yamo four stars, but the service wasn't that great when we dined in. Which is why I HIGHLY recommend take out! Regardless of the service, I can see why Yamo had high reviews because it really is good for being a hole in the wall. 

Their Tea Salad was pretty good! Being someone that doesn't like salads, I enjoyed it. We also tried a fried curry appetizer but I forgot what it was called. For my main dish I got the Yamo house noodles with beef as my choice of meat. They also had chicken and pork, which my other two friends got. There was nothing really special about them, they were just like chow mien noodles. 

For four people dining in we were pushing it since they only had 10 seats, but together our bill came out to being only 34 dollars. You get exactly what you pay for so I don't have much to complain about.

excerpts: We waited outside for our Yamo House Noodles with Chicken, Egg Rolls (with amazing, homemade sweet and sour sauce), and Pot Stickers.
Even after BART-ing home the food was still warm and satisfying.
Not the best Chinese food I've ever had, but far from the worst.
yamo house noodles.author: Nan H.
yamo house noodles.review: After being overwhelmed by the club-scene that is Mission Chinese my friend and I opted for Yamo for take out instead. The place is quite literally a hole in the wall, I was certain we had the wrong address until we peeked inside. The ladies behind the counter are serious and curt, but they're busy boiling, frying and tossing dishes with about three inches of counter space in an chili oil sauna, so you really can't blame them. We waited outside for our Yamo House Noodles with Chicken, Egg Rolls (with amazing, homemade sweet and sour sauce), and Pot Stickers. Even after BART-ing home the food was still warm and satisfying. Not the best Chinese food I've ever had, but far from the worst.

excerpts: I can't help it but find myself always going back to ordering the **YAMO HOUSE NOODLES though.
It's oily, has clean distinct flavors and just makes me happy every time I get it.
I find myself craving these noodles whenever I'm in the vicinity of the restaurant
yamo house noodles.author: Dennis L.
yamo house noodles.review:
OKOK time for a Yamo update. It's still ridiculously cheap but after a couple years, I'm ready to lighten on the criticism. Lunch here was uneventful, perhaps because the female cook didn't have her screaming partner yet. The food is still a fusion of Burmese and Chinese food. 

The TEA LEAF SALAD has nearly the same taste as other places, but from the sight of it I can hardly make out the tea leaf. 

The CHICKEN NOODLE SOUP is delicious with pieces of sauteed chicken thrown into a coconut curry bowl of noodles. 

I can't help it but find myself always going back to ordering the **YAMO HOUSE NOODLES though. It's oily, has clean distinct flavors and just makes me happy every time I get it. I find myself craving these noodles whenever I'm in the vicinity of the restaurant so I couldn't give anything less than 5 stars.

Parking: metered close by and non-meter a small walk away
Wait: none if you go during lunch but be prepared for 30-45 min wait if there is a line
Crowd: hipster

excerpts: Try the Yamo house noodles with tofu & veggies, spring rolls, and mango salad!
Everything is less that $8 bucks, can't go wrong with cheap yummy food....
yamo house noodles.author: Caye Q.
yamo house noodles.review: I love love LOVE this place! Yes it's a little mouse hole, nobody speaks english & you can never get a spot at the counter but the food is AMAZING! Just stand outside, grab your cell and place an order to go. It's just as good on the run. Try the Yamo house noodles with tofu & veggies, spring rolls, and mango salad! Everything is less that $8 bucks, can't go wrong with cheap yummy food....

excerpts:
Tea leaf salad-AMAZING
Yamo House Noodles with Beef- Very soft and yummy noodles but bland.
Mango Chicken-
yamo house noodles.author: Jenn H.
yamo house noodles.review:
Tea leaf salad-AMAZING
Yamo House Noodles with Beef- Very soft and yummy noodles but bland.
Mango Chicken- This was okay, kind of bland IMO.


It's definitely the 'soup nazi' type of customer service here, so consider yourself warned.The main lady there (there's only 3) was super rude. I wasn't expecting to be catered to, but I also wasn't expecting to get yelled at! Not worth us coming back at all.

excerpts:
(http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=fbZj28B92VTTWV1jwGrSNA) 

Yamo house noodles with chicken ($5.25) - If you like garlic, you will love this dish.
yamo house noodles.author: Karen Y.
yamo house noodles.review:
I'm ecstatic to have found a Burmese hole-in-the-wall restaurant in my neighborhood. It's like a dream come true...AND the awesome ladies who run the place speak Cantonese which is perfect for me so I can chit-chat with them!

I've heard nothing but great things about Yamo so figured it was time to give it a try for dinner one night. It's diner-style with an tiny open kitchen (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=CWKicY2EvYWZccR0tNePjA) and a narrow counter space as the eating area that seats maybe a max of 10 people so expect to get cozy with your neighbor! Luckily, my friend Audrey L. got there a little earlier and was able to nab 2 seats towards the back. I was starving (and the portions are decent) so here's what we ordered:

spring rolls ($3.50) - 2 gigantic rolls loaded with basil, shrimp, vermicelli, and lettuce with a side of peanut dipping sauce. This wasn't the greatest and kinda bland...I would stick to getting spring rolls at Vietnamese places.

tea leaf salad ($5.25) - This was by far my favorite dish...don't be fooled by its mild appearance because it's spiiiicy! It contains a mixture of tea leaves, cabbage, onion, cilantro, and various fried beans and seeds to provide crunchiness. The combined tangy and spicy flavors ignite on your palate and are oh-so-delicious! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=fbZj28B92VTTWV1jwGrSNA) 

Yamo house noodles with chicken ($5.25) - If you like garlic, you will love this dish. It's pretty much just egg noodles (similar to thick ramen noodles in texture) covered with fried garlic pieces, chicken, and topped with green onions. It's a greasy and simple bowl of food but has that bite from the abundance of garlic. Yum! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=oIhBcY34GoprtwED1BuaNQ)

curry prawns with noodles ($5.25) - We saw the girls next to us order this and it looked so good, we couldn't resist getting it! They ran out of the flat rice noodles (choice of also rice or the egg noodles) so we chose the latter. It is stir-fried with mushrooms, onions, green bell peppers, spices/curry...a well-rounded dish with layers of flavor/heat and textures. The jumbo prawns were cooked and seasoned perfectly too. I give it a big thumbs up! (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=aAuG0KHwIMTJFTegFcSjXg)

I want to come back very soon!!

excerpts: Yamo House Noodles, Tea Leaf Salad, Mango Chicken, Samosa, anything curry.
yamo house noodles.author: Jonas T.
yamo house noodles.review:
One of my favorite hole in the walls in the city. The only Asian food that seems to be really cheap these days is Chinese food, but this little joint serves Burmese food at cheap Chinese food prices, averaging at about $3.5-$5.25 a dish. The quality doesn't compare to Burma Superstar's, but you definitely get more than your money's worth here.

Must orders: Yamo House Noodles, Tea Leaf Salad, Mango Chicken, Samosa, anything curry.

JONASAPPROVED!

excerpts: However, I think the Yamo House Noodles with Beef is what is making me "EH" about this place.
The beef was nice and tender.
However, the egg noodles were sauteed with not enough garlic and SERIOUSLY a quart of oil.
It was SOOOOOOOOOOOOOO FREAKEN greasy.
I've made noodles with more yummy garlic and less oil then what was in that bowl.
yamo house noodles.author: Rose J.
yamo house noodles.review:
I would give 5 stars for the "hole in the wall" atmosphere and the endearing two ladies sweating away in the kitchen area orchestrating five hot skillets and a boiling deep-fryer. 

In terms of food, I absolutely loved the Tea Salad (tea leaves, cabbage, tomato, onion, dried shrimp, and crunchy beans and sesame seeds). The beans were definitely the secret ingredient, adding a nice crunch and nutty flavor to the dish.  However, I think the Yamo House Noodles with Beef is what is making me "EH" about this place.  The beef was nice and tender.  However, the egg noodles were sauteed with not enough garlic and SERIOUSLY a quart of oil. It was SOOOOOOOOOOOOOO FREAKEN greasy. I've made noodles with more yummy garlic and less oil then what was in that bowl.  I felt pretty gross after that.  

It's a great place to go late at night after a few beers and you are HUNGRY...but if you already have a muffin top like me...go with caution. :)

excerpts: Also got the Mango Salad (good, but nothing extraordinary) and the Yamo House noodles (bland, nothing special).
yamo house noodles.author: Lillian W.
yamo house noodles.review:
The food was decent. The Mango Chicken was really good with snow peas, green bell pepper, mango, chicken, rice. The Mango Chicken was slightly spicy in a good way. The Tea Leaf Salad was perfectly crunchy and savory. Also got the Mango Salad (good, but nothing extraordinary) and the Yamo House noodles (bland, nothing special). Total was $24, $6 each item.

The ladies were very nice and the food came fast. Only downside is that the food was super oily and the place was small and crowded.

excerpts: I ordered fish curry with rice, Yamo house noodles with beef, and Yamo cold noodles with chicken.
We finished it all, as the portions weren't that big.
Or maybe we're just pigs.
The noodle dishes were great and we especially loved the tasty and tender beef slices that came with the House Noodles.
The food is on the greasy side, but it's real homecookin' you'd find in your Burmese friend's mom's kitchen.
yamo house noodles.author: Diane L.
yamo house noodles.review:
Wow, talk about a hole-in-the-wall establishment!  If Yamo doesn't epitomize hole-in-the-wall, I don't know what does.

There are normally 8 counter seats in this very narrow and tiny restaurant.  But sometimes there are 10, because 2 of them are pseudo counter seats right by the doorway.  It's really not a counter for eating, but a counter for ordering takeout.  But when you're hungry for cheap and good Burmese food, sitting anywhere is fine.  Even if it means sitting right in front of the open kitchen, making it much easier for your hair to smell like grease.  But it's all good because that means you have the best seat in the house to watch the chef lady bust out her multi-tasking culinary skills.

There were two older women and one young girl working the night we came here.  The SO and I were delighted to hear them talking to each other in Cantonese, so we bust out our Canto and made friendly conversation with everybody in our native tongue.  While we waited for our food, I just sat and watched in awe at how the three of them dealt with taking orders, cleaning up the counter, wrapping spring rolls, collecting customers' tabs, yelling out dishes to the chef lady, preparing ingredients for the chef lady to cook, packing up to-go orders, and answering the phone.  Even more amazing was that they did it with finesse.

Appetizers are $3.50 each, and all salads, soups, noodle soups, and entrees are $5.25.  The SO and I ordered fish curry with rice, Yamo house noodles with beef, and Yamo cold noodles with chicken.  We finished it all, as the portions weren't that big.  Or maybe we're just pigs.  The noodle dishes were great and we especially loved the tasty and tender beef slices that came with the House Noodles.  The food is on the greasy side, but it's real homecookin' you'd find in your Burmese friend's mom's kitchen.

excerpts: We ordered the Tea Leaf Salad, Pot Stickers, Yamo House Noodles with Beef, and Fish Chowder Noodle Soup which were perfect for 2.
Every dish had its unique flavors and none of dishes tasted what I expected.
Even the pot stickers surprised me.
Their use of fried broad beans to give the crunchy element is smart and inexpensive which is probably how they keep their cost down.
The use of ginger is ingenious to give that spiciness you need, but not the norm of spicy you expect.
If you crave for spicier, sriracha and other hot sauce condiments are available, but I would not suggest putting them on until you try a few bites and let the original flavors kick in.
Their portion are not for a growing boy so you might want to order doubles if you are super hungry.
I want to go back this weekend to try the other dishes.
yamo house noodles.author: Judy F.
yamo house noodles.review:
It doesn't get diver than this. Mostly everything on the menu is $6 except for the beverages. It is a tax inclusive, cash only, and no frills place with 3 ladies slaving over and keeping the kitchen in order. They have their system of running the establishment and serving your orders so you will get your food, but you should don't expect the conventional restaurant etiquette. If you keep that in mind, your "dining experience" will go great.

The food is yummmmyy!! I am impressed by the lightness of the dishes, and yet, I felt comforted and satisfied after I ate. The food was flavorful and hearty but without the guilt. We ordered the Tea Leaf Salad, Pot Stickers, Yamo House Noodles with Beef, and Fish Chowder Noodle Soup which were perfect for 2. Every dish had its unique flavors and none of dishes tasted what I expected. Even the pot stickers surprised me. Their use of fried broad beans to give the crunchy element is smart and inexpensive which is probably how they keep their cost down. The use of ginger is ingenious to give that spiciness you need, but not the norm of spicy you expect. If you crave for spicier, sriracha and other hot sauce condiments are available, but I would not suggest putting them on until you try a few bites and let the original flavors kick in. Their portion are not for a growing boy so you might want to order doubles if you are super hungry. I want to go back this weekend to try the other dishes.

excerpts: As far as food goes, I'm a huge fan of the Tea Salad, House Fried Chow Mein, and Yamo House Noodles.
yamo house noodles.author: Trevor U.
yamo house noodles.review:
Yamo's food quality deserves 3 stars, but the experience in itself deserves 4 stars.  

There is always a line at Yamo!  It might be because the hole in the wall that Yamo calls home is comparable in size to a muni car.  And let's be honest, riding muni during rush hour sucks.  You can never get a seat at the bar and you're constantly rubbing shoulders with people to order.  Once you do get your opportunity to order, you better do it correctly or else the intimidating Burmese women might let you have it.  

For starters, I'd recommend hitting up Yamo during non-peak hours.  If you do manage to get a seat at the bar, I'd recommend sitting as far away from the door as possible.  I'd also recommend getting a fresh coconut to sip on while you wait.  

As far as food goes, I'm a huge fan of the Tea Salad, House Fried Chow Mein, and Yamo House Noodles.  Don't expect much from these dishes in terms of size as everything on the menu is only $6.  

I highly recommend Yamo because it is a unique experience.  You probably won't be able to absorb another experience like this one anywhere else in San Francisco. 

*If you're looking to eat and beat the line, call your order in and pick it up 15 minutes later.  It definitely beats the crowd on a cold San Francisco night.

excerpts: I have tried the Potstickers, Tea Leaf Salad, Fish Chowder Noodle Soup, Mango Chicken, Black Bean Fish, Yamo House Noodles with Beef, Chicken Noodle Soup, Yamo Cold Noodles and the Curry Tofu
and they were all great.
yamo house noodles.author: Joy L.
yamo house noodles.review:
This is a great little hole in the wall. The space itself is tiny, and your food is literally cooked in front of you. The food is great and the service is no-nonsense, but that doesn't mean they are unfriendly, they are just busy. Your best bet is to call in ahead of time and order take out if you don't want to wait for a seat. Also - since the place is so teeny tiny, the ventilation is quite poor, so take out may be your best option in that respect as well.  

Reasonable prices and I have no complaints about the food. Their portions are a little on the small side, but you can't expect more than what they give you for the price you are paying. Their menu is not huge, but what they offer, they do well. I have tried the Potstickers, Tea Leaf Salad, Fish Chowder Noodle Soup, Mango Chicken, Black Bean Fish, Yamo House Noodles with Beef, Chicken Noodle Soup, Yamo Cold Noodles and the Curry Tofu and they were all great. All of their noodle dishes are excellent. 

This is a Mission gem - it encompasses everything I love about San Francisco: Tiny little hole-in-the-wall places with yummy but dirt-cheap food.

excerpts: I ordered the Tea leaf Salad, Yamo House noodles, the Yamo Cold Noodles, and the fish chowder noodle soup.
The Tea leaf salad was nice and spicy, make sure you have water to help with the spiciness.
My husband ate the Yamo cold noodles and the Yamo House noodles an thought they were nothing special and some of the sauces tasted like it was made with Ketchup.
I really liked the Fish Chowder soup- not too much of a fishy flavor and a mild curry flavor.
My husband ate the Yamo cold noodles and the Yamo House noodles an thought they were nothing special and some of the sauces tasted like it was made with Ketchup.
I really liked the Fish Chowder soup- not too much of a fishy flavor and a mild curry flavor.
yamo house noodles.author: Lily L.
yamo house noodles.review: I used to love this place and was introduced by a close friend of mine, but was not that impressed with this visit: some of the dishes I ordered and I'm wondering if it is because I ordered to go or I just ordered different dishes in the past. I ordered the Tea leaf Salad, Yamo House noodles, the Yamo Cold Noodles, and the fish chowder noodle soup.  The Tea leaf salad was nice and spicy, make sure you have water to help with the spiciness.  My husband ate the Yamo cold noodles and the Yamo House noodles an thought they were nothing special and some of the sauces tasted like it was made with Ketchup.  I really liked the Fish Chowder soup- not too much of a fishy flavor and a mild curry flavor.  I called ahead for my order and they said done in 15 minutes, by the time I got there the food was ready for me to pick up.  The have maybe 6-10 bar stools to sit and watch them cook,  and there is only 2 or 3 ladies working behind the small cooking area.  it is hard to get in so you usually will see people waiting outside the door to pick up their order or waiting for an open seat.  Cant beat the prices of their dishes though.

excerpts: We were two people and ordered the mango salad, cold Yamo noodles and the Yamo house noodles with chicken.
They were all great.
yamo house noodles.author: Sara-Lee R.
yamo house noodles.review:
Have only been here once and loved it. Cheap and tasty food. Entertaining Chinese service - don't expect it to be the American way. And don't expect to change an order, they will tell you what you want. It's very authentic.

A main dish is $6. We were two people and ordered the mango salad, cold Yamo noodles and the Yamo house noodles with chicken. They were all great.

excerpts: I usually get the Yamo House Noodles with Pork (its greasy garlic noodles with bacon, really), but decided to go for the fried curry fish instead because somehow i thought fried fish would be a healthy alternative to grilled pork.
yamo house noodles.author: Tom T.
yamo house noodles.review:
Everyone already knows Yamo is about the most badass eatery in the city, so why would I waste numb my fingers writing a review?  

Because I had the curry fish last night and it was so good that i think the only way i can get it off of my mind is to process the pleasure here.  SO GOOD.  I usually get the Yamo House Noodles with Pork (its greasy garlic noodles with bacon, really), but decided to go for the fried curry fish instead because somehow i thought fried fish would be a healthy alternative to grilled pork.  Whatever.  

So good.  The fish was stellar, fried but still softish, served with some veggies over noodles.  The curry was pretty hot and really tasty.  Blew my mind.

Oh!  And the ladies behind the counter were definitely the nicest they've ever been.

excerpts: I ordered the Yamo House Noodles.
yamo house noodles.author: Chris Y.
yamo house noodles.review:
I so badly wanted to like this place more.  So badly.

The prices, of course, are spot-on, however, when I received my order, it was exceedingly greasy.  (Even for Burmese/Vietnamese food)  I ordered the Yamo House Noodles.  Again, yes I expect an inherent amount of oiliness with this dish, but it was SOPPING.

The flavors were not well-blended and the grease just really did me in.  I NEVER throw out food, but it did cross my mind.  

What saved it from a 2-star rating is the women were very friendly and fun.  It has a great "hole-in-the-wall" vibe.

Next time, I think I'd try a soup or something as it looked/smelled really yummy.

excerpts: The Yamo House Noodles is a dish you should definitely try.
It's yellow noodles mixed with fried garlic and their sauce and choice of meat.
yamo house noodles.author: Peter N.
yamo house noodles.review:
I love this place! The wait can be horrendous as there are only about 8-10 seats available in this literally hole-in-the-wall. Your surroundings while sitting in this restaurant might scare you, but hey, the food is hella cheap and delicious! You can see the ladies working their butts off cooking your food right in front of you. If you're lucky enough, you'll sit where their dish dryer is at and get some vibration for your arms. 

The Yamo House Noodles is a dish you should definitely try. It's yellow noodles mixed with fried garlic and their sauce and choice of meat. Delicious!

The Yamo Cold noodles reminds me a lot of the infamous Burma SuperStar's Rainbow Salad, except less ingredients and much cheaper. The cold noodles are really mouthwatering. I probably prefer this dish over the House Noodles.

Did I mention the food here costs on average $5? Talk about Deal Steal!

excerpts: I'm so in love with the Yamo house noodles with beef.
I think I'm going to be here a lot more.
yamo house noodles.author: Lauren S.
yamo house noodles.review:
Wow $3.50 for all appetizers.
The main entrees are $5.25 each.
The ladies hell of ignore you.
The place is crazy small with just a counter space for people to sit in a row.
And one of their refrigerators is just a standard household one.
This place is cuuuuute.
I'm so in love with the Yamo house noodles with beef.
I think I'm going to be here a lot more.

excerpts: I would recommend the tea salad, curry prawn (spicy), and Yamo house noodles, WITH GRASS JELLY TEA.
yamo house noodles.author: Philina L.
yamo house noodles.review:
Yamo was an experience.  The restaurant is as wide as a hallway and as short as an elephant.  You sit at the front of the kitchen so you feel the heat, smell the food, and see the fire.  When you receive your entree and take your first bite you know that you are getting quantity and quality for a good price.  Each entree is $6- max.  

I would recommend the tea salad, curry prawn (spicy), and Yamo house noodles, WITH GRASS JELLY TEA. 

MM-MMM.

excerpts: and we ordered the tea salad, mango chicken, and yamo house noodles with chicken.
My favorite was the tea salad.
I didn't see them make it
but I think they have this mixture of nuts or something that goes really well with the salad.
yamo house noodles.author: Faye F.
yamo house noodles.review:
3.5 stars

I stumbled upon this restaurant when I was blog surfing. This past weekend, my boyfriend and I ventured down mission to find this hole in the wall. The food is absolutely delicious but you WILL have to wait awhile (depending on the number of cooks working and the line of customers) for it. When we arrived, there were 3 female cooks working their butts off for a small line. The place itself can hold maybe 10 sitting customers and the rest order to go. There's no order when serving their customers and it seemed like it's easy for them to forget your order, especially when there's a long line of customers. 

Anyway, my boyfriend and I hadn't eaten all day and we ordered the tea salad, mango chicken, and yamo house noodles with chicken. (You can also order fresh coconut drink, which they will cut up open for you on the spot!) The mango chicken with rice was very good. It didn't feel heavy in your stomach and the vegetables were pretty fresh. My favorite was the tea salad. I didn't see them make it but I think they have this mixture of nuts or something that goes really well with the salad. The house noodles were super garlicky and it was good! 

This is a good place to eat if you have a lot of patience waiting for food but I suggest not to go during lunch rush.

excerpts: Yamo house noodles w/beef.
Seriously.
yamo house noodles.author: Adrienne C.
yamo house noodles.review:
Yamo house noodles w/beef. For $5.25. Seriously. That's all you need to know.

Also...curry chicken, potstickers and samusas....YUMYUMYUM.

It's tiny, the wait is forever and there is no parking. Save yourself a headache and call ahead with your order for pick-up. Come in 30 minutes versus the 15 minutes they tell you, pick up the yummy, sesame oil-drenched noodle goodness and eat from the comforts of your home. You will be much happier if you do.

excerpts: Ordered the tea salad, mango chicken and Yamo house noodles with chicken.
The tea salad was the standout of the three dishes.
Nutty and crunchy.

Tea salad
+Price
-Slow service
-Limited seating
yamo house noodles.author: Daniel M.
yamo house noodles.review:
Came here last Saturday because my girlfriend wanted to try it. It's just a few blocks from the BART station but we had to walk through a pretty dirty and smelly portion of the Mission. I'm not sure I would have found it if I hadn't seen a picture of it before we came. Anyway, we arrived around 3pm and didn't have trouble finding a couple stools at the bar (there's only 10). 

Ordered the tea salad, mango chicken and Yamo house noodles with chicken. The tea salad was the standout of the three dishes. Nutty and crunchy. My house noodles were sort of bland but perked up when I added some hot sauce. The cooks were generally inattentive and the service was fairly slow. But you can't beat the $5.25 price for entrees!

Summary: 3.5/5 stars rounded down
+Tea salad
+Price
-Slow service
-Limited seating

excerpts: I had the Yamo house noodles with chicken and had some of the tea leaf salad.
yamo house noodles.author: Connie C.
yamo house noodles.review:
Yamo is the hole in the hole in the wall. Yes, it's so small you'll probably miss it if you blink. Nicole and I probably walked a good 2 blocks past it when we were trying to go there.

It's greasy, spicy, probably high in fat and cholesterol Burmese fast food, but it's yummy! The ladies that work there speak little English, and the cheap menu is no nonsense. If you can score one of the 8 seats at the counter, enjoy watching them prepare your food in minutes. Call ahead for take-out in case the place is packed. 

I had the Yamo house noodles with chicken and had some of the tea leaf salad. Each bite packs a punch, so don't be surprised if you start tearing up.

excerpts:
Favorites:
- Yamo House Noodles
- House Special Fried Rice
-
yamo house noodles.author: Linda C.
yamo house noodles.review:
HOLE IN THE WALL GOODNESS!!!

Favorites:
- Yamo House Noodles
- House Special Fried Rice
- Tea Leaf Salad

Call ahead and pick up your order because chances are, you won't be able to get one of the 8 seats at the counter. Service is slow, but you can't get mad at the 3 little ladies working in their limited amount of space while chopping and cooking up fresh ingredients two feet in front of you! Your patience will be rewarded with yummy food for $5.25! Oh, and if you do get a seat at the counter, be prepared to smell afterwards, but not as bad as Korean BBQ!

excerpts: I love having a baby coconut drink and having some Yamo House noodles (garlic noodles), tea leaf salad, and spring rolls in this tiny dive with maybe 8 stools.
Don't come here expecting an atmosphere that's romantic, private, or conducive to conversation -- it's loud, cramped, and hot.
You do get the advantage of all your food being made from scratch in front of you though.
yamo house noodles.author: Sid D.
yamo house noodles.review:
This restaurant may be Burmese, but the food tastes like good old fashioned comfort food to a Chinese-Am girl like me.  I love having a baby coconut drink and having some Yamo House noodles (garlic noodles), tea leaf salad, and spring rolls in this tiny dive with maybe 8 stools.  Don't come here expecting an atmosphere that's romantic, private, or conducive to conversation -- it's loud, cramped, and hot.  You do get the advantage of all your food being made from scratch in front of you though.  Yamo is definitely a hidden (or not so hidden now due to Yelp) jewel right off Mission Street.

Best part?  All entrees on the menu are $5.25, apps are even less!

excerpts: I enjoyed the YAMO house noodles with the chicken and the samasus (their spelling not mine)
yamo house noodles.author: Olivia W.
yamo house noodles.review:
talk about best bang for your buck! this is one of the best cheap eats ever and well worth the wait.  I'd almost be inclined to move to the mission for this place! now i did notice their health screening food card was a bit hidden, so it's just not worth thinking about. It's a total hole in the wall and really not good for groups. but the food was great, maybe a bit greasy for some people, but good portion size and the menu is awesome.

I enjoyed the YAMO house noodles with the chicken and the samasus (their spelling not mine) SOOOOOO GOOOD.

eaters beware, this is not the place if you are looking for a sit down meal, this is eat and go!!!!

I hope to come back real soon!!!!

excerpts: All you need to know is Yamo house noodles w/beef.
yamo house noodles.author: tramy n.
yamo house noodles.review:
Literally a hole in the wall.  
My New Fav. hole in the wall.. Everything is fresh, make in front of you... The line if pretty long, but its worth the wait.. No need to get all dolled up for this place..=)

All you need to know is Yamo house noodles w/beef. For $5.25. Seriously and fresh coconut juice... 
I can eat here morning , noon and night..

excerpts: I've had the Yamo house noodles with beef, and though i was looking for a bit more flavour, the beef was nice and tender
and I like the texture of the noodles.
I also had their curry with shrimp and noodles.
Likewise it was pretty good, needed to add some pepper oil for spiciness, but I had no problem finishing this dish.
yamo house noodles.author: Adrian L.
yamo house noodles.review:
I've been to Yamo a couple of time now and, though I can't say the food blows, or even knocks, my socks off, I can see myself returning here for many more meals.  First of all, the food is good, like I said, not lick my plate or bowl clean great, but solid.  I've had the Yamo house noodles with beef, and though i was looking for a bit more flavour, the beef was nice and tender and I like the texture of the noodles.  I also had their curry with shrimp and noodles.  Likewise it was pretty good, needed to add some pepper oil for spiciness, but I had no problem finishing this dish.  I have also eaten the potstickers and samosas, both OK.

What I love about this place is it's third world charm and simplicity.  I love restaurants that you walk into and feel like you've left the the country.  OK so you could say you feel like you've left the country just walking down Mission to 18th St.  This place feels like a grundgy, slapped together noodle shop you could find down some back alley in SE asia with enough grease built up on the front window to make a meal of if you were brave enough to lick it off (and I mean this in a good way).  I love the simplicity of the menu, all noodle dishes, the same price.  So what if you want chicken, beef, shrimp or veggies, same same same same.   And finally, that price is cheap!  

Summary: CHEAP, GOOD, and I'm sure there's one other thing I could annoyingly capitalize.

excerpts: The Yamo House noodles are pretty awesome.
yamo house noodles.author: Bobby C.
yamo house noodles.review:
$5.25 gets you plenty of *decent* food.  It's tasty, quick, and cheap.

Don't be fooled by the 4-star rating - this is not Burma Superstar wedged into a hallway, but it is definitely better than most anything else for the price.

The Yamo House noodles are pretty awesome.

excerpts: * Yamo House Noodles with Pork- delicious.
Pork was thinly sliced and savory.
The noodles were a bit greasy
but overall it was good.
Warning:
Portions were small
yamo house noodles.author: Melanie O.
yamo house noodles.review:
Yamo is a great place to start the night if you're looking for an adventure.  It is a random hole in the wall near the corner of 18th and Mission.  You walk in and you are immediately amazed how tiny the space is.  You sit at the counter and watch the bustle of the kitchen.

Highlights:
* Yamo House Noodles with Pork- delicious. Pork was thinly sliced and savory.  The noodles were a bit greasy but overall it was good.  Warning: Portions were small
* Black bean fish - good but not mind blowing.  It could have used a bit more flavor.  However, for $5.50, I'm not sure you could expect a lot more.

My overall takeaway with the place was it had good service and decent food, but I wouldn't wait to eat here.  If I had time I would rather go to Richmond or the East Bay for amazing Burmese food and pay $3-4 more dollars. Or I would go to another Chinese joint in the mission and pay the same price for food that has bigger portions and is more flavorful.

excerpts: I love the Yamo house noodles, mango chicken, and black bean fish.
I tried the chow mein and veggie curry - both were ok, but I prefer the above choices over these.
Also, I suggest getting an order of samosas to munch on while you wait for your food.
It's satisfying for my tummy and wallet!
yamo house noodles.author: Lynda N.
yamo house noodles.review:
The price and location are key reasons that keep me coming back again and again.  Big portions of Burmese food for $5.25?  Three blocks from my apt?  Awesome to-go containers I can reuse?  Counter seating ONLY?  Burmese women working hard to feed me some good ol homecookin?  It beats heading out to Burma Superstar (love me some burma superstar!) to wait in a loooong first come, first serve line (depending on how many are in your party, they have been known to bump smaller parties to seat larger ones! booooo to them for that!).

I love the Yamo house noodles, mango chicken, and black bean fish.  I tried the chow mein and veggie curry - both were ok, but I prefer the above choices over these.  Also, I suggest getting an order of samosas to munch on while you wait for your food.  It's satisfying for my tummy and wallet!

excerpts: I had the Yamo House Noodles here with pork and must say that this is definitely condiment intensive cuisine.
Not a lot of flavor going on but pretty good if you pile on the jalapenos, fish sauce, siracha, and whatnot.
For only $5.25 tax included per plate, it's not like you can complain.
The stir fried stuff looked like the kind of Chinese food you find at the mall, big slices of bell pepper etc.
yamo house noodles.author: matthew w.
yamo house noodles.review:
Really 3.75 stars.  I had the Yamo House Noodles here with pork and must say that this is definitely condiment intensive cuisine.  Not a lot of flavor going on but pretty good if you pile on the jalapenos, fish sauce, siracha, and whatnot.  
For only $5.25 tax included per plate, it's not like you can complain.  The stir fried stuff looked like the kind of Chinese food you find at the mall, big slices of bell pepper etc.

excerpts: Though we didn't order it, the customer sitting next to us order what I think (just guessing mind you) is the Yamo House Noodles.
That looked really good.
Basically several bite sized pieces of chicken (looking like it was cooked in a thick dark sauce) over a bed of the chow mein like noodles.
yamo house noodles.author: Tetsu N.
yamo house noodles.review:
Today was my very first experience eating Burmese food, and from what I'm told, everything here is very authentic, or at least authentic from the perspective that identically prepared delectable delights can be had over there.

Meeting a very old friend from back in NY who happened to be in town, we went to Yamo based on her SO's recommendation.

What a treat!  I love experiencing new kinds of food!

The restaurant itself is ridiculously small, with only some limited counter seating, maybe seating 10 or so.  The restaurant looks like it has been around for a while too, and was incredibly popular.  The line was constant and always out the door, tho luckily, it seems that most who get their food here have are well aware that getting takeout is a much wiser choice.  

And the prices!  Excellent prices for the cheap bastard in me.  My friend and I had three dishes, a coconut drink, and a soda for under $20.  For light eaters on a budget, one dish and a drink would be about $7 combined.  Big eaters won't go broke either.  

On to the food.

Tea Salad:  $5.25
 - 4.5 stars
 - Tea leave, cabbage, fresh tomato, oion, dried shrimp & variety of fried bean, nuts and sesame seeds.
 - Wow, by far my favorite dish of the day.  This taste and texture explosion is so good I wish they served it in meal portions, but alas, they only served it as a relatively small and light plate.  More like an appetizer.  It's got a variety of crunchy textures, including what feels like tiny croutons though with a saltier taste (I'm assuming it's the fried bean but might of been the dried shrimp), and the nuts (which I'm guessing may be peanuts), and the more raw veggie crunch of the cabbage.  There are also several software textures as well as the watery tomato texture.   And the taste?  Wow, there's a raw veggie tanginess to it, subtly to it, saltiness to it....Really, explosion is the only way to describe.  And it does this so cleanly and lightly that none of the tastes are overbearing.  This is a MUST ORDER at this small little hole in the wall.

Fish Chowder Noodle Soup $5.25
 - 2 stars
 - Soup chowder with rice noodles, shredded fish, and onions, garnished with Fried Yellowbeans and Cilantro
 - This wasn't bad, but it didn't strike me as very inspired.  The sauce was a thick reddish sauce reminiscent in texture of thick Chinese sauces poured over meats and rice.  Sorry, there should be a better explanation but I can't imagine what it is.  The noodles were very very well cooked and watery, almost like pho noodles, only it didn't seem to be the way these noodles were supposed to be.  The taste was subtle...almost too subtle.  Perhaps, tho, I'm being a little harsh because of the great tastes of the other dishes, but really, I wouldn't order this again.

Yamo Cold Noodles $5.25
 - 3.5 stars
 - Cold noodles mixed with house special flavor, onions, cabbage, cucumbers, and chicken
 - Pretty good dish.  The noodles are similar to chow mein noodles but without the glossy oiliness.  This was their spicy dish, but it's more tangy than spicy.  The chicken was covered in a thick, almost dry red sauce with lots of full sized peppers (like the dry peppers found in jars at the table at pizza restaurants).  This dish was also full of different flavors giving a nice complexity to the dish.  I would order this again.

Fresh Coconut $2.50
 - 4 stars
 - All my life, I thought coconuts had a stronger taste because coconut flakes used in cakes had such a strong flavor.  What a surprise to find the taste was so subtle, if you had told me it was a different fruit, I would have believed you.  So light, refreshing.  Loved it.  I also liked that it came in a full coconut rather than a glass.  It was fun to see, and we could scrape the inside for the thicker fruity part of the coconut.    Yeah, I'd order this again, just for the novelty of it.  

Grass Jelly drink $1.00
 - 2.5 stars
 - This is a can drink.  Not carbonated, with bits of jelly in it.  It's similar in taste to Chinese turtle shell gelatin desserts.  I'd drink it again if it was served, but probably wouldn't ever be my first choice.  Still, it tasted like it was probably a healthy drink.

Though we didn't order it, the customer sitting next to us order what I think (just guessing mind you) is the Yamo House Noodles.  That looked really good.  Basically several bite sized pieces of chicken (looking like it was cooked in a thick dark sauce) over a bed of the chow mein like noodles.  It sure as heck looked good.

All in all, this place was pretty good.  If I would have rated it a straight 3.5, I'd got to 4, but given that all the food combined average below a 3.5, I'll have to go with a 3 today.

Except...the price!  The price is so good, that adds a half star right there, pushing the average up and making this place an easy 4 stars.

So with that said, Yay!  I'm a fan!

excerpts: Our favorite menu items are: tea leaf salad, samosas, beef curry with rice, and Yamo house noodles with pork, and a coconut drink.
yamo house noodles.author: Julie C.
yamo house noodles.review:
Being that my family is half Burmese, I'm always on the search for authentic Burmese food. Yamo is your definition of an authentic "hole in the wall". $5 for every plate, delicious, and dirty. There are only 10 or so seats so it could definitely get crowded on a busy night. We prefer to get take out on a weeknight. You can call ahead and pick up 15 minutes later. You have to check your order though, since this place gets busy and sometimes they don't remember everything you ordered. This place is pretty authentic for the city, but doesn't necessarily have all of the offerings of true Burmese cuisine.

Our favorite menu items are: tea leaf salad, samosas, beef curry with rice, and Yamo house noodles with pork, and a coconut drink. 

Great place to dine on a budget and provides authentic food at an affordable price.

excerpts: The I had the potstickers and Yamo House noodles.
yamo house noodles.author: Philip N.
yamo house noodles.review:
The FUCKING bomb.

The I had the potstickers and Yamo House noodles. With a Kern's Mango Nectar it was $ 9.75.

This place is like a Burmese Disneyland for your mouth.

Tiny, tiny place. Definitely part of its charm. So is the authentic Burmese kitchen. Not for you anal, clean freak types, but like Disneyland, if you don't let your eyes wander too much, its fantastic.

If you're looking to put on a show or see one, go somewhere else. If you're ready to pack it in shoulder to shoulder really and get your grub on then this is a good spot.

The staff is "in the bubble," and won't pay you much mind. They are so busy cooking, they don't have time for ass kissing. Perhaps this is why the food is so cheap. They concentrate on efficiency rather than show.

The commis chef / waitress, "Mae," was quite nice once I got her attention. At the end of the meal she just told me and the guy next to me how much we owed and went back to wrapping shrimp and lettuce in rice paper.

Then some nice girls came in, pushed me out of my seat and I was done. This is going to be a regular spot for me now.

I went back again and had the Yamo Tofu noodles and spring rolls.
spring rolls were okay. The peanut sauce that came with them was 
good. The Yamo Tofu was really tasty!

excerpts: I ordered the Yamo House Noodles with chicken and it was exactly what I have been craving for a while.
I love the type of noodles they used.
Barely seen them in other places.
My friend got the chicken coconut noodle soup.
Both dishes were very delicious and all for $5.25 each.
yamo house noodles.author: Judy P.
yamo house noodles.review:
For a hole-in-the-wall place, the food was AWESOME! My two foodie best friends had mentioned this place twice before I actually ventured out to Yamo's with one of them. I must had been the end of lunch hour since it was packed when we got in there. You pretty much have to sit down and grab a seat right away. I ordered the Yamo House Noodles with chicken and it was exactly what I have been craving for a while. I love the type of noodles they used. Barely seen them in other places.  My friend got the chicken coconut noodle soup. Both dishes were very delicious and all for $5.25 each. We also got six samosas for $3.50. 

Another big thing is the tea salad. Didn't try it but might next time. Even though I hate bean sprouts.

Oh, and fresh coconut. Like an actual coconut. 

At these prices, I might be swayed to drive down there more often.

excerpts: The Yamo house noodles were bomb.
The noodles themselves are just so yummy.
They are chewy and fresh and not heavy.
yamo house noodles.author: Pet O.
yamo house noodles.review:
I ate at Yamo last night with my sister and it was so great! Cheap, quick, and delicious! I love noodles and they had a good variety of dishes. 

We had spring rolls, the chicken noodle soup, and the Yamo house noodle with pork. The spring rolls were nice and fresh, I saw the lady make them in front of me! And the chicken noodle soup was good, curry-ish. The Yamo house noodles were bomb. The noodles themselves are just so yummy. They are chewy and fresh and not heavy. The dish was a dry noodle with garlic, green onions, and pork- simple but definitely tasty. 

The place is TINY. We went on a Wednesday night so there was virtually no wait, even though every seat was filled when we got there. The women there are just so quick and great at what they do, you're in and out within 45 minutes. I will definitely come back here.

excerpts: I had the Yamo House Noodles with beef (also available with chicken or pork).
One of the women fried the beef with garlic and noodles, while the other thinly sliced red and green onions, cucumber, and cilantro into a small bowl.
yamo house noodles.author: Marcus W.
yamo house noodles.review:
Yamo is like flying home to Vancouver, visiting my mom, and having her whip up a quick bite to eat.

The menu is simple: four appetizers (samosas, spring rolls, egg rolls, and potstickers), three salads (shrimp & tea leaves, mango, chicken), and 15 entrees (five vegetarian options).    Everything is $5.25 except for the appetizers, which are $3.50.

I had the Yamo House Noodles with beef (also available with chicken or pork).  One of the women fried the beef with garlic and noodles, while the other thinly sliced red and green onions, cucumber, and cilantro into a small bowl.  Because the counter overlooks the prep and cooking area, they make it all right in front of you.

I'm telling you, it was heaven in a bowl.  The noodles were perfect and it was all nice and garlicky.  The raw veggies, which you mix in when they serve you, were still nice and crunchy.
 
If counter seating, cash-only, and dirty windows scare you, go some place else (since all of these yelps mean this place is probably hella busy at dinner, especially with a total of 9 seats).  But if you want a inexpensive, tasty meal, go to Yamo.

excerpts: Yamo House Noodles with Beef, and #8 Coconut Noodle [Sublime]
Soup with Chicken.
I have this place programmed into my phone which is quite the honor.
yamo house noodles.author: E L.
yamo house noodles.review:
Reason #2 not to be a vegetarian in 2008:

My mouth is watering just thinking about #19 with noodle, Curry Beef, #15  Yamo House Noodles with Beef, and #8 Coconut Noodle [Sublime] Soup with Chicken. I have this place programmed into my phone which is quite the honor. (I moved out of the Mission, but I will drive around for parking or walk 20 blocks to pick-up take-out. I never eat-in at Yamo (I'm delicate like that).)

Savoury noodles with that damned delicious umami and egg noodle texture perfection paired with succulent meats and various sauces. Curry Beef has just enough kick and can be spicy, greasy and peppers and onions complement the meat. House noodles have that, "Huh, what is that, uh, flavor?" that if you're an Asian child you are all too grateful about. And, my latest discovery #8 soup is a thick, pale-green broth teeming with sweetness of coconut and the savoury curry, spiked with cilantro and onions, noodle perfection and toppings coming separately so you can become the Asian soup scientist!

excerpts: Dish two, the Yamo house noodles with pork, was EXACTLY as tasty as it looked (it looked very tasty).
yamo house noodles.author: Jeremy G.
yamo house noodles.review:
Finally committed to the line while waiting for seats at the nearby Mission Street Food.  We ordered just two dishes to avoid spoiling our appetite.  

The sumosas were excellent, very crispy, with a great sweet/spicy chili sauce for dipping.  One of the chefs counted carefully to make sure there were 6 perfect isosceles triangles on our plate before delivering.  There was some discussion about going easy, maybe saving a few for lunch tomorrow.  The idea of a "to go" box was tossed around.  They'd probably re-heat well, we surmised.  It became apparent, however, that 0 of the 6 sumosas were going to make it past round two.  Yeah, they probably wouldn't have reheated well.  

Dish two, the Yamo house noodles with pork, was EXACTLY as tasty as it looked (it looked very tasty).  Greasy egg noodles, tender well-seasoned pork, and a bit of cilantro.

Yamo is one of those places that I can already feel myself starting to crave as I walk out the door.

excerpts: We always get the Yamo House noodles with Pork and maybe get some Spring Rolls.
For the price it's super delicious and cheap.
Call ahead to get take-out faster, as there isn't much room to stand inside.
yamo house noodles.author: Ericka J.
yamo house noodles.review: Amazing delicious greasy noodles. We always get the Yamo House noodles with Pork and maybe get some Spring Rolls. For the price it's super delicious and cheap. Call ahead to get take-out faster, as there isn't much room to stand inside. Cash only, which isn't awesome because as a bartender I always have cash and my boyfriend doesn't, thus I end up buying the Yamo. Alas, it is worth it. Check this place out if you live in the area.

excerpts: The deduction in star is a reflection of a more general view of Yamo's menu; having been a devotee of their tea leaf salad, noodle soups and Yamo House Noodles
, I've discovered I'm not entirely enamored with anything else.
I came by with my parents to introduce them to a more pure Mission dining experience and experimented with the beef curry, the mango chicken
and... it was okay.
What?
Only okay?
I know, I have to be fair though
and yes, I felt that past my exclaimed favorites mentioned in my first review, the rest of the menu is a bit lacking.
yamo house noodles.author: Jessica L.
yamo house noodles.review:
I still absolutely love Yamo. The deduction in star is a reflection of a more general view of Yamo's menu; having been a devotee of their tea leaf salad, noodle soups and Yamo House Noodles, I've discovered I'm not entirely enamored with anything else. I came by with my parents to introduce them to a more pure Mission dining experience and experimented with the beef curry, the mango chicken and... it was okay.
What? Only okay? I know, I have to be fair though and yes, I felt that past my exclaimed favorites mentioned in my first review, the rest of the menu is a bit lacking. I would generously approve of their fish chowder noodle soup and possibly their pot stickers but... beyond this, I'm not entirely sure.
Still, it hardly warrants a large deduction; but, with Yamo's increasing popularity seating at their infamous tiny food bar has become near impossible and as such, weighs further on the negative scale with a full star deduction.
I still really enjoy Yamo, and I still laud it's accomplishments to any who will listen, but have to be fair and numb a bit of the excitement and state the simple fact: if you have a Burmese-Chinese craving, order out. You will most certainly have a more satisfactory experience.

excerpts: we ordered the tea leaf salad, samusas, yamo house noodles with beef, and black bean fish.
I would recommend the tea leaf salad if you're interested in a surprisingly crunchy and spicy salad.
the samusas are cute crispy mini-versions of samosas with a plum-chili(?) dipping sauce.

Yamo house noodles with beef were the prize-winning dish with great flavor moist beef and crisp veggies.  

to top it all off the price was better than most places in the mission as noted in articles on their door.
yamo house noodles.author: Marina K.
yamo house noodles.review:
it was soooo thrilling finding Yamo-  it was one of those times when you almost walk past the place because its so obscure you would never think to peek inside - barely any sign that its the place you were looking for - staking your hopes on a satisfying meal to this little door with a light on a dark street - then you poke your head in and see that there's a person on every stool along the narrow 12 foot counter.  so this might have some promise after all.  you walk in and pick up the menu and decide to wait it out and see if it is worthwhile - and so it was.

we ordered the tea leaf salad, samusas, yamo house noodles with beef, and black bean fish.  I would recommend the tea leaf salad if you're interested in a surprisingly crunchy and spicy salad. the samusas are cute crispy mini-versions of samosas with a plum-chili(?) dipping sauce.  Yamo house noodles with beef were the prize-winning dish with great flavor moist beef and crisp veggies.  

to top it all off the price was better than most places in the mission as noted in articles on their door.  worth the adventure to find it & now i will definitely go back.

*********
makes me want to sing a little song to a reggae tune: 
"yamo get some yamo~
yamo be alright~" :)

excerpts: Noodles never really meant much too me until I discovered Yamo house noodles.
The house noodles with beef are unassuming with  very little sauce and a simple side of cabbage,peppers, and sriracha but watch out, these noodles are oozing with flavor.

I don't recommend Yamo if you don't like 'hole in the walls", or if your looking for a five star dining room experience, but if you like grubbing arm in arm with other diners and watching the ladies in the kitchen go to town
then Yamo is the place to be.
yamo house noodles.author: Kadecia W.
yamo house noodles.review: Noodles never really meant much too me until I discovered Yamo house noodles.  The house noodles with beef are unassuming with  very little sauce and a simple side of cabbage,peppers, and sriracha but watch out, these noodles are oozing with flavor. I don't recommend Yamo if you don't like 'hole in the walls", or if your looking for a five star dining room experience, but if you like grubbing arm in arm with other diners and watching the ladies in the kitchen go to town then Yamo is the place to be.

excerpts: I personally recco the yamo house noodles with pork and the tea salad.
yamo house noodles.author: Jake H.
yamo house noodles.review: this is actually like a 4.5.  It's great...it's my new neighborhood place.  I shouldn't even write a review...there is already a line out the door.  My only drawback is that they have such a limited menu.  There's alot of overlap on tastes.  They have a menu of about 15 things and apparently they are all good.  I personally recco the yamo house noodles with pork and the tea salad.  Note that they close at 9:30 and up till that point there will be (as I said) a line out the door.  This place is no longer hidden, I'm just being a flurry on Yelp

excerpts: The Yamo house noodles with fried garlic and fresh cabbage and onions was the perfect meal for a misty SF evening.
I can't wait to go back, I thought the Mission only had burritos
but I was wrong!
yamo house noodles.author: Suzanne V.
yamo house noodles.review: Delicious pile of food for under 6 bucks - an awesome deal.  The food is filling and comforting and tasty.  This isn't really the place you'd want to go for a fancy date but for a fun, intimate date, this tiny place is great - there is only room to sit at the counter.  The staff is attentive and sweet, refills your water and tea quickly and is very accomodating.  The Yamo house noodles with fried garlic and fresh cabbage and onions was the perfect meal for a misty SF evening.  I can't wait to go back, I thought the Mission only had burritos but I was wrong! ;)

excerpts: , i've gotten the yamo house noodles with pork
both times i've been here
and they give you so much meat for $5.95.
bottom line is, yamo gives you a good feeling in the tum after eating.
yamo house noodles.author: Melanie C.
yamo house noodles.review:
went with danny e. and melissa (right below me). delicious noodles, small space though, as there are only about 8 stools at the counter. danny and i went today and we had that type of meal where the food is so good, that you just don't talk to the person you are with because you are too busy stuffing your face with delicious egg noodle goodness. we tried the tea salad today and the fried garlic was so delicious! 

love the old ladies that work here and we ESPECIALLY love it when they are whacking away with a machete (not really, just a big ol' knife but machete is so much more fun to say!) at the coconut just to give you coconut milk to drink. the food comes fairly quick and it's super cheap too, i've gotten the yamo house noodles with pork both times i've been here and they give you so much meat for $5.95. bottom line is, yamo gives you a good feeling in the tum after eating.

excerpts: Everything is good here, but I always get the Yamo house noodles.
If I got this at other places it would prob coast me $10-13, but @ this place its half the price and just as good or even better.
The only down side to this place is that its very very small so prepare 2 wait or call in for your order before you come.
Sits about 10 people.
yamo house noodles.author: Jay S.
yamo house noodles.review: Yamo! What can I say? The price is right at this Burma Joint. Very good home style cookin. Everything is good here, but I always get the Yamo house noodles. If I got this at other places it would prob coast me $10-13, but @ this place its half the price and just as good or even better. The only down side to this place is that its very very small so prepare 2 wait or call in for your order before you come. Sits about 10 people.

excerpts: Then had the yellow curry chicken and an order of yamo house noodles (hot, with chicken).
Yamo noodles were my favorite (VERY flavorful).
Total bill $14.00.
yamo house noodles.author: Val U.
yamo house noodles.review: This is the Tu Lan of the Mission.  On a shady block, dirt cheap, awesome food, closed Sundays.  Went with wifey last night.  Ordered spring rolls (made fresh in front of you - good, not great).  Then had the yellow curry chicken and an order of yamo house noodles (hot, with chicken).  Yamo noodles were my favorite (VERY flavorful). Total bill $14.00.

excerpts: I love their prawn curry over noodles, mango chicken noodles, the yamo house noodles, veg curry, samosas, tea salad.
That's what I had so far.
I'm going to try everything on the menu.
It's also inexpensive too.
Parking is okay....
yamo house noodles.author: Miyoko N.
yamo house noodles.review: This place is super Burmese!  I love their prawn curry over noodles, mango chicken noodles, the yamo house noodles, veg curry, samosas, tea salad. That's what I had so far.  I'm going to try everything on the menu.  It's also inexpensive too.  Parking is okay....

excerpts: Loved the tea leaf salad and spring rolls (with shrimp- yum!) - but the highlight for me was the Yamo House Noodles (with beef).
Could definitely lead to a "Sally" moment in a restaurant....
almost don't want to share it ( :
yamo house noodles.author: Keri B.
yamo house noodles.review: Yamo.....yummo!!! It's like being at the breakfast nook of someone's kitchen! A little diamond of a dive- counter service only, cash only, and some of the entertainment is watching them make your meal! Loved the tea leaf salad and spring rolls (with shrimp- yum!) - but the highlight for me was the Yamo House Noodles (with beef). Could definitely lead to a "Sally" moment in a restaurant....almost don't want to share it ( :

excerpts: At first i wanted fried rice but ended up ordering the Yamo house noodles.
The noodles were actually good, it looked like it was a tiny serving
but it actually filled me up.
I ordered the spring roll and saved it for a late night snack.
The lil old lady was pretty nice and quick when she took my order.
I took my fpod home cause the place was already full, i would def come back and try something else on the menu.
yamo house noodles.author: Lucky M.
yamo house noodles.review: As i walked to my regular smoke shop on the corner of mission and 18th, i was starving and wanted something quick and cheap. i stumbled by YAMO. I had no clue where the exact location of the place was until last night. The place is tiny, and i am serious, tiny. It fits about 8 people or less. The menu was small but cheap, i was shocked that they had spring/summer rolls(whatever you wanna call it). At first i wanted fried rice but ended up ordering the Yamo house noodles. The noodles were actually good, it looked like it was a tiny serving but it actually filled me up. I ordered the spring roll and saved it for a late night snack. The lil old lady was pretty nice and quick when she took my order. I took my fpod home cause the place was already full, i would def come back and try something else on the menu.

excerpts: The Yamo House Noodles (or garlic noodles, as I know them to be called) could have used more flavor.
The presentation was lovely, but the taste was lacking.
The mango chicken wasn't anything special either.
It's on about the same level as Panda Express.
yamo house noodles.author: Jessica M.
yamo house noodles.review:
The Place:
I had a bit of trouble finding the place. When I first saw it, I thought the restaurant was condemned and closed for business. The entire place consisted of a room about half the size of a classroom with a bar in the middle. On one side there's eight seats (good luck number for Chinese people), and on the other side there are the elderly chefs. They don't spend any money on making the place fancy. I went on a Monday at around 5:00, and all the seats were filled (but like I said, there aren't many seats).

The Service:
I went for an early dinner so it wasn't crowded. One lady took my order, and she conversed with us in Burmese. Unfortunately speaking in Mandarin (no, it's NOT Cantonese) or Burmese does not get bigger portions or special treatment. Darn. The food was quick, though not much attention was paid towards the customers.

The Food:
I don't consider Yamo's food real Burmese food, but then again I don't think Burma Superstar's food is real Burmese food. Yamo's food is cheap and is geared towards an American audience. It's very cheap ($3.50 for appetizers and $5.25 for entrees), but the food is nothing special. Portions could be bigger. Their samusas were very small, the type you can find frozen at Ranch 99 or Pacific Super. The Yamo House Noodles (or garlic noodles, as I know them to be called) could have used more flavor. The presentation was lovely, but the taste was lacking. The mango chicken wasn't anything special either. It's on about the same level as Panda Express. I was a bit disappointed with the food and the limited selection, but I figure the chefs are friends from temple who decided to go into a little business together.

All in All:
I didn't have very high expectations, but Yamo was decent. It was cheap and pretty good for the price. I don't think it's anything special, but I'm rather biased since I've grown up eating Burmese food. I feel like the only reason the restaurant is popular is because it's cheap and it's different. If you don't know what real Burmese food is supposed to taste like, I think you'd like Yamo. It's not bad, but not authentic or flavorful enough for my taste.

excerpts: Yamo House Noodles w/Chicken is so f*ckin' good.
yamo house noodles.author: Clifford P.
yamo house noodles.review: OMG...Yamo House Noodles w/Chicken is so f*ckin' good.

excerpts: Yamo house noodles can get greasy at times but the food is pretty consistent for a great price.
yamo house noodles.author: Andy L.
yamo house noodles.review: Great comfort food. I was tired of having to schlep out to the sunset for some good asian food. Yamo house noodles can get greasy at times but the food is pretty consistent for a great price. Mango chicken and prawn curry also get thumbs up. Also, pot stickers are the best I've ever had especially when dipped in the spicy sauce.

excerpts: and the GF got the Yamo House Noodles.
We also got an order of the freshly made spring rolls.
I personally love places where you get to see what's going on in the kitchen and in this joint, you definitely have a front row seat.
The spring rolls were tasty, big & fresh!
The noodle dishes were very good too.
The taste of the Yamo House Noodles reminded me of noodles I would make at a Mongolian BBQ place.
yamo house noodles.author: Allan H.
yamo house noodles.review: The GF & I decided to stop by here for lunch based on the glowing reviews (and the fact that we were out in the Mission already).  We almost walked right by the place - it's a hole in the wall place, meant in the best way possible.  The awning of the place was barely legible but we could roughly make out Yamo on there.  We stepped inside and take a seat at the counter.  Almost everything on the menu (aside from drinks) is priced at $5.25 and $3.50 for appetizers.  One of the ladies behind the counter suggested the Yamo Cold Noodles, so I got that and the GF got the Yamo House Noodles.  We also got an order of the freshly made spring rolls.  I personally love places where you get to see what's going on in the kitchen and in this joint, you definitely have a front row seat.  The spring rolls were tasty, big & fresh!  The noodle dishes were very good too.  The taste of the Yamo House Noodles reminded me of noodles I would make at a Mongolian BBQ place.  My Yamo Cold Noodles had just enough spicy kick to keep you wanting more.  I thought we were done, but ended up ordering some Samusas to go.  The sauce provided definitely had a kick to it!  We thought a yogurt based sauce might go nicer, but they were still quite good.  I'm definitely coming back here though!

excerpts: Take some time to stop and smell the Yamo house noodles, man.
Because I can tell you with dead certainty they're equally good with pork, beef, or chicken.
yamo house noodles.author: Evan J.
yamo house noodles.review: Ok, there's really no good reason why I haven't written a review of this place months ago, as it is currently my favorite restaurant and has held the honor of that distinction longer than most. There is a "bad reason", however-a selfish one that I'm a little ashamed of: I'm not sure I want any more people going there!
