It's so small already, with literally no tables, just a counter with 7 or 8 seats. These seats are often full if you go at prime time; lunch hour or any time after 5 pm, although turn over is usually fast. I've since realized, though that the limited seating of this place is one of the aspects, along with a slight language/culture barrier, and a "smudginess" due to the exhaust from the cooking surfaces right behind the counter, that has allowed the prices at this place to remain low, and for it to keep off the mainstream restaurant radar, which is just fine with me. I'll gladly accept backless stools, huff a bit of grease-fire smoke, and sometimes wonder at momentarily non existent service (the only reason I didn't give it 5 stars), for truly wonderful and authentic Southeast Asian food and an almost transporting genuine asian street food style experience at dirt cheap prices. You go ahead and go to your fancy restaurants where they have actual tables and where you don't sit in the kitchen because I'll be just fine here where the fermented tea leaf salad kicks the frickin pants off the one at Burma Super Star, with it's array of way more exotic and tasty additions, like nuts I've never seen before and do not know the names of. Yes, if you phone in an order for take out, they don't even ask your name but just say, "thank you, bye" and hang up, and your order is rarely ever ready when you come to pick it up at the time they tell you, but so what? What are you in such a big hurry for anyways? Take some time to stop and smell the Yamo house noodles, man. Because I can tell you with dead certainty they're equally good with pork, beef, or chicken.

excerpts: After waiting for a bit, we had the Yamo House Noodles (which were not garlicy enough), vegetarian Spring Rolls (which completely lacked flavor, but
that's probably because my best friend thinks she's allergic to shrimp which is what is supposed to be in the Spring Rolls), and the Tea Leaf Salad (which was also a bit bland).
The food was filling and reasonably priced, but just not that flavorful.
Maybe we didn't order the right things.
I love the women who work there and boss you around while seeming to mock you for asking that the main ingredient of a dish be cut, it smells amazing, is right by my work, and is cheapish...
so I'll be back.
yamo house noodles.author: Mairead J.
yamo house noodles.review: I was super super super excited to go to Yamo last week. I had planned on saving my stomach for it, but this plan was undermined by an overabundance of free sandwiches at work, and the fact that I really wanted an omelette and had brunch (after my breakfast) at Balompie that morning. Anyways, naturally, I was still hungry by the time dinner rolled around. Yamo is teeny tiny and has about ten seats. After waiting for a bit, we had the Yamo House Noodles (which were not garlicy enough), vegetarian Spring Rolls (which completely lacked flavor, but that's probably because my best friend thinks she's allergic to shrimp which is what is supposed to be in the Spring Rolls), and the Tea Leaf Salad (which was also a bit bland). The food was filling and reasonably priced, but just not that flavorful. Maybe we didn't order the right things. I love the women who work there and boss you around while seeming to mock you for asking that the main ingredient of a dish be cut, it smells amazing, is right by my work, and is cheapish... so I'll be back.

excerpts: *Yamo Cold Noodles made with cold noodles mixed with house special flavor, onions, cabbage, cucumbers, and chicken.
- FYI its not really cold noodle.
Because they stir fry the chicken and veggies and place it on top of the noodles.
Therefore making the noodles warm.
I know
but its so good.
The sauce they use is amazing.
yamo cold noodles.author: Sandy B.
yamo cold noodles.review:
So glad I finally got to try this place. Small, definitely your "HOLE IN THE WALL", about 10 seats at the counter. As I was dining, I notice they mostly do take outs. FYI, if you expect good services, don't come here. Don't complain, they really don't care. I didn't think services is awful, well at least not to me. She smile once at me. They do charge you for everything when it's to go. Don't expect anything free here and it's CASH ONLY.  I wish I lived close by, it would be my go to restaurant. 

Food is YUMMY and you can't beat the price. Smaller portions but who needs super big ones anyways. Better for the waist. haha And you can try more things. I prefer more varieties anyways. "ASIA" style and I love it. 

**Potstickers are filled with pork, cabbage, and carrots. My friend was so amaze by them. Very soft and juicy on the inside. Not crispy, just a little to add in some texture. 
** Tea Salad are made with tea leave, cabbage, fresh tomato, onion, dried shrimp & variety of fried bean, nuts and sesame seeds. - Super small dish but love the flavors. It was really good but I think way too much onions. If you want more for the money, the other two salads are bigger in portion. 
** Yamo House Noodles made with noodles mixed with fried garlic, and a choice of meat. I got the BEEF. My favorite dish. It's like garlic noodles topped with beef for a good price. So YUMMY! I can eat that everyday. 
**Yamo Cold Noodles made with cold noodles mixed with house special flavor, onions, cabbage, cucumbers, and chicken. - FYI its not really cold noodle. Because they stir fry the chicken and veggies and place it on top of the noodles. Therefore making the noodles warm. I know but its so good. The sauce they use is amazing. And I notice lots of people do order that for take out.

I'm coming back for sure and try everything else. Everything I had was DELICIOUS! Drinks are like self serve, bottles and cans. $1.50 each. There can be a wait but not too bad because mostly everyone orders take out. It's hot inside and I went yesterday when it was 85 degrees at 730pm. I sat by the door but still hot. Can't wait to come back.

excerpts: The Yamo Cold Noodles and Fish Chowder Noodle Soup had visually stimulating color palette and great flavor!
The fish chowder could have used a little more fish, because I was fishing for fish the whole time, but I really liked the broth!
The people who were eating Garlic Noodles next to me made me want to get that next time.
yamo cold noodles.author: Shelley C.
yamo cold noodles.review:
The Yamo Cold Noodles and Fish Chowder Noodle Soup had visually stimulating color palette and great flavor! The fish chowder could have used a little more fish, because I was fishing for fish the whole time, but I really liked the broth! The people who were eating Garlic Noodles next to me made me want to get that next time. The ladies who run this place may seem stand-offish to others, but once you get over that, it's just a bit hilarious the wacky things they say and do. 

Customer next to me: " Can I have another plate to share this bowl of food?" 
Yamo lady: "No, you already have bowl."

Yamo lady *cutting carrots with her back to me*
Me *taking pictures of my surroundings*
Yamo lady without turning "No pictures."

Customer 2: "Can I have some water."
Yamo lady: "No water, only bottled water, $2."

excerpts: My dish was the Yamo Cold Noodles ($6) which contains onions, cabbage, cucumbers, and chicken.
The flavor of the chicken itself overpowers the dish but in a good way.
Because the noodles are fresh, they're still a little warm (not cold) when served, but I would still highly recommend this.
yamo cold noodles.author: Stefanie C.
yamo cold noodles.review:
Yamo is my favorite new gem in the Mission District. There is limited bar seating so the wait might be awhile, but the friendly service and incredibly flavorful Burmese food is worth every minute. They are super efficient with seating customers, and they usually take your order ahead of time if there is a wait. Check out the menu beforehand or while you are waiting.

My friend and I shared one appetizer and two entrees, which came out to be less than $20 total!! We first ordered the Mango Salad ($6) which has fresh mangoes, cabbage, onions, celery, and carrots. This is probably my favorite thing on the menu because it's fresh, sweet, and spicy.

My dish was the Yamo Cold Noodles ($6) which contains onions, cabbage, cucumbers, and chicken. The flavor of the chicken itself overpowers the dish but in a good way. Because the noodles are fresh, they're still a little warm (not cold) when served, but I would still highly recommend this. My friend ordered the Curry Chicken ($6) which I found tasty as well, and I'm not usually a huge fan of curry.

Lastly, I love the dynamic of the ladies that run Yamo. Makes me feel like I'm at home. This place is a must-try!

excerpts: We had tea leaf salad, Yamo house noodles with pork, and Yamo cold noodles with chicken.
The flavors were so so, chicken and pork were on the tough side.
Really bad service.
We arrived at 12:00 PM, 6 seats were available.
We sat at the counter for at least 30 minutes watching the two women doing prep work that should have been done when they're opened at 11:00 AM, before our orders were taken.
The worse part was everything's very oily.
yamo cold noodles.author: TopCat W.
yamo cold noodles.review:
We had tea leaf salad, Yamo house noodles with pork, and Yamo cold noodles with chicken.  The flavors were so so, chicken and pork were on the tough side.  Really bad service.  We arrived at 12:00 PM, 6 seats were available.  We sat at the counter for at least 30 minutes watching the two women doing prep work that should have been done when they're opened at 11:00 AM, before our orders were taken.  The worse part was everything's very oily. After we left, we both smelled like old deep fried oil.

Will not return.

excerpts: The Yamo Cold Noodles (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=LdOX74kqLs8Yps_6Y-rT-g).
Cold noodles, chicken, cabbage, onions and cucumbers with "House Special Flavor".
This flavor is a mixture of sweet sauce and chili flakes.
First taste might be odd.
But couple bites later, you'll be hooked.
yamo cold noodles.author: Marti L.
yamo cold noodles.review:
Love Yamo! One of the few places I don't mind waiting nor the lingering smell of grease hours after. 

Even though I don't usually go for greasy, oily foods, I always get the Yamo House Noodle with Beef (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=GVwiKtfXiq8KfiwTjeLshw) Screw you, irritable stomach! Something about the way they cook the beef, its so-dang-good. It's lean, yet tender and flavorful. Reminds me of rehydrated beef jerky, if that makes any sense at all.

New discovery: The Yamo Cold Noodles (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/D1-_5ff4aic1-7rLqzUd4g?select=LdOX74kqLs8Yps_6Y-rT-g). Cold noodles, chicken, cabbage, onions and cucumbers with "House Special Flavor". This flavor is a mixture of sweet sauce and chili flakes. First taste might be odd. But couple bites later, you'll be hooked. Great dish anytime!

Cash only. No delivery. And oh, those ladies love Chinese-speaking boys. lol.

excerpts:
Tea leaf salad
Yamo House Noodles
Yamo Cold Noodles
yamo cold noodles.author: Moo C.
yamo cold noodles.review:
If you like eating in a closet, come here!  I've only eaten IN the resto a couple of times, preferring to call in and pick up my order.  It's definitely a tight squeeze and the wait can be long at times. If you're there for the first time with your sweetie to keep you warm as you stand in line...go for it (but I digress)...the food is really good.

It's amusing to watch the ladies behind the counter do their thang.  Shouts all around, but it's a graceful symphony that results in an absolutely happy tummy.

Prices are very reasonable, and the food is served to you very quickly.  All of the dishes I've tried here have been good, but some faves:
Chicken noodle soup
Tea leaf salad
Yamo House Noodles
Yamo Cold Noodles

If you're having a meal there, ask for fresh coconut.  As you sip on the juice of a baby coconut cracked open just for you, enjoy the tastes, smells and sounds this Burmese eatery.

Oh, don't plan on going anywhere after because those scents stick ;)

excerpts: My friend and I shared the spring rolls ($3.60), the tea leaf salad ($5.25), the black bean fish with wide rice noodles ($5.25), and the Yamo cold noodles with chicken ($5.25).
We had a satisfying meal of four dishes for a just over $21!
yamo cold noodles.author: Liz T.
yamo cold noodles.review:
Small, smoky, stools-only... It was love at first sight. I wish I lived in the Mission--I could have bacon donuts for breakfast, super burritos for lunch, and this incredible Burmese stuff for dinner. I would eventually grow out of everything I presently own, but what's a few inches and several pounds? TOTALLY. WORTH. THEM.

My friend and I shared the spring rolls ($3.60), the tea leaf salad ($5.25), the black bean fish with wide rice noodles ($5.25), and the Yamo cold noodles with chicken ($5.25).  We had a satisfying meal of four dishes for a just over $21! Insane for SF!

The rolls were made fresh and super refreshing--good because you're in a bathroom-sized restaurant with a hot kitchen before you. The tea leaf salad was small but scrumptious--I just love the textural contrast of the many ingredients. The fish was lightly fried and really tasty, but the rice noodles were a bit bland. The cold noodles were chewy and flavorful, but the chicken was rather dry. Next time I'll have to try the curry fish with rice and the Yamo house noodles with beef. And get a tea leaf salad just for my gluttonous myself. This is going to be a fat summer, but at least it will be a cheap and spicy one. Everything was mildly spicy except the rolls.

I wasn't crazy about Burmese food after Burma Superstar, after Mandalay, after Burmese Kitchen, but I am definitely a fan after Yamo. The food is so homey and delicious, the Asian ladies are so hard-working and sweet--I can't help but just adore this hole-in-the-wall. 

Although I ate here last night, in anticipation of eating here a lot, I will begin accepting dinner dates here for the rest of the summer starting right now. Don't all flood my inbox at once.

excerpts: Yamo cold noodles + tea leaf salad = heaven.
Amazing hole in the wall.
Fun to come at an off-time and actually get a stool (limited).
yamo cold noodles.author: Kimberly D.
yamo cold noodles.review: Yamo cold noodles + tea leaf salad = heaven. Amazing hole in the wall. Fun to come at an off-time and actually get a stool (limited).

excerpts: I ordered fish curry with rice, Yamo house noodles with beef, and Yamo cold noodles with chicken.
We finished it all, as the portions weren't that big.
Or maybe we're just pigs.
The noodle dishes were great and we especially loved the tasty and tender beef slices that came with the House Noodles.
The food is on the greasy side, but it's real homecookin' you'd find in your Burmese friend's mom's kitchen.
yamo cold noodles.author: Diane L.
yamo cold noodles.review:
Wow, talk about a hole-in-the-wall establishment!  If Yamo doesn't epitomize hole-in-the-wall, I don't know what does.

There are normally 8 counter seats in this very narrow and tiny restaurant.  But sometimes there are 10, because 2 of them are pseudo counter seats right by the doorway.  It's really not a counter for eating, but a counter for ordering takeout.  But when you're hungry for cheap and good Burmese food, sitting anywhere is fine.  Even if it means sitting right in front of the open kitchen, making it much easier for your hair to smell like grease.  But it's all good because that means you have the best seat in the house to watch the chef lady bust out her multi-tasking culinary skills.

There were two older women and one young girl working the night we came here.  The SO and I were delighted to hear them talking to each other in Cantonese, so we bust out our Canto and made friendly conversation with everybody in our native tongue.  While we waited for our food, I just sat and watched in awe at how the three of them dealt with taking orders, cleaning up the counter, wrapping spring rolls, collecting customers' tabs, yelling out dishes to the chef lady, preparing ingredients for the chef lady to cook, packing up to-go orders, and answering the phone.  Even more amazing was that they did it with finesse.

Appetizers are $3.50 each, and all salads, soups, noodle soups, and entrees are $5.25.  The SO and I ordered fish curry with rice, Yamo house noodles with beef, and Yamo cold noodles with chicken.  We finished it all, as the portions weren't that big.  Or maybe we're just pigs.  The noodle dishes were great and we especially loved the tasty and tender beef slices that came with the House Noodles.  The food is on the greasy side, but it's real homecookin' you'd find in your Burmese friend's mom's kitchen.

excerpts: I love noodles especially Yamo Cold Noodles.
Love great mission eats.
yamo cold noodles.author: Deborah V.
yamo cold noodles.review: I love noodles especially Yamo Cold Noodles.  Love great mission eats.

excerpts: I have tried the Potstickers, Tea Leaf Salad, Fish Chowder Noodle Soup, Mango Chicken, Black Bean Fish, Yamo House Noodles with Beef, Chicken Noodle Soup, Yamo Cold Noodles and the Curry Tofu
and they were all great.
yamo cold noodles.author: Joy L.
yamo cold noodles.review:
This is a great little hole in the wall. The space itself is tiny, and your food is literally cooked in front of you. The food is great and the service is no-nonsense, but that doesn't mean they are unfriendly, they are just busy. Your best bet is to call in ahead of time and order take out if you don't want to wait for a seat. Also - since the place is so teeny tiny, the ventilation is quite poor, so take out may be your best option in that respect as well.  

Reasonable prices and I have no complaints about the food. Their portions are a little on the small side, but you can't expect more than what they give you for the price you are paying. Their menu is not huge, but what they offer, they do well. I have tried the Potstickers, Tea Leaf Salad, Fish Chowder Noodle Soup, Mango Chicken, Black Bean Fish, Yamo House Noodles with Beef, Chicken Noodle Soup, Yamo Cold Noodles and the Curry Tofu and they were all great. All of their noodle dishes are excellent. 

This is a Mission gem - it encompasses everything I love about San Francisco: Tiny little hole-in-the-wall places with yummy but dirt-cheap food.

excerpts: I ordered the Tea leaf Salad, Yamo House noodles, the Yamo Cold Noodles, and the fish chowder noodle soup.
The Tea leaf salad was nice and spicy, make sure you have water to help with the spiciness.
My husband ate the Yamo cold noodles and the Yamo House noodles an thought they were nothing special and some of the sauces tasted like it was made with Ketchup.
I really liked the Fish Chowder soup- not too much of a fishy flavor and a mild curry flavor.
My husband ate the Yamo cold noodles and the Yamo House noodles an thought they were nothing special and some of the sauces tasted like it was made with Ketchup.
I really liked the Fish Chowder soup- not too much of a fishy flavor and a mild curry flavor.
yamo cold noodles.author: Lily L.
yamo cold noodles.review: I used to love this place and was introduced by a close friend of mine, but was not that impressed with this visit: some of the dishes I ordered and I'm wondering if it is because I ordered to go or I just ordered different dishes in the past. I ordered the Tea leaf Salad, Yamo House noodles, the Yamo Cold Noodles, and the fish chowder noodle soup.  The Tea leaf salad was nice and spicy, make sure you have water to help with the spiciness.  My husband ate the Yamo cold noodles and the Yamo House noodles an thought they were nothing special and some of the sauces tasted like it was made with Ketchup.  I really liked the Fish Chowder soup- not too much of a fishy flavor and a mild curry flavor.  I called ahead for my order and they said done in 15 minutes, by the time I got there the food was ready for me to pick up.  The have maybe 6-10 bar stools to sit and watch them cook,  and there is only 2 or 3 ladies working behind the small cooking area.  it is hard to get in so you usually will see people waiting outside the door to pick up their order or waiting for an open seat.  Cant beat the prices of their dishes though.

excerpts: Yamo Cold Noodles is my favorite, very well balanced spices and a bit spicy.
Also like spring rolls and samosas.
The curry chicken could be a bit more spiced.
I will be a repeat customer here.
yamo cold noodles.author: Mpunkt H.
yamo cold noodles.review: Absolutely a little gem. Not that I have been in Burma, but you instantly feel that this place is authentic. Yamo Cold Noodles is my favorite, very well balanced spices and a bit spicy. Also like spring rolls and samosas. The curry chicken could be a bit more spiced. I will be a repeat customer here.

excerpts: esp yamo cold noodles, they are really fkin yummy.
yamo cold noodles.author: Matt N.
yamo cold noodles.review:
Yamo is really cheap and yummy.  I really love eating their food.  esp yamo cold noodles, they are really fkin yummy.

getting sick from all orifices is not yummy.

I always get the shits after yamo.  I figured it was because it was spicy.
But this morning around 4am was my second getting vomity sick after yamo. 

I am not a vomiter I don't normally vomit even on half a fifth of whiskey.
I'm fkin done.  can't do it.  

wtf yamo why  have you scorned me!

excerpts: The Yamo Cold noodles reminds me a lot of the infamous Burma SuperStar's Rainbow Salad, except less ingredients and much cheaper.
The cold noodles are really mouthwatering.
yamo cold noodles.author: Peter N.
yamo cold noodles.review:
I love this place! The wait can be horrendous as there are only about 8-10 seats available in this literally hole-in-the-wall. Your surroundings while sitting in this restaurant might scare you, but hey, the food is hella cheap and delicious! You can see the ladies working their butts off cooking your food right in front of you. If you're lucky enough, you'll sit where their dish dryer is at and get some vibration for your arms. 

The Yamo House Noodles is a dish you should definitely try. It's yellow noodles mixed with fried garlic and their sauce and choice of meat. Delicious!

The Yamo Cold noodles reminds me a lot of the infamous Burma SuperStar's Rainbow Salad, except less ingredients and much cheaper. The cold noodles are really mouthwatering. I probably prefer this dish over the House Noodles.

Did I mention the food here costs on average $5? Talk about Deal Steal!

excerpts: I tried the Yamo cold noodles and it just wasn't too satisfying.
It had a real similar taste to Great Khan's Mongolian BBQ that you can find in some shopping malls.
yamo cold noodles.author: Dustin W.
yamo cold noodles.review: This hole in the wall restaurant is an alright place to get your typical greasy Chinese food fix.  I tried the Yamo cold noodles and it just wasn't too satisfying.  It had a real similar taste to Great Khan's Mongolian BBQ that you can find in some shopping malls.

excerpts: My favorites are the yamo cold noodles with chicken (has a kick), chicken noodle soup (curry based) and the samosas.
Everything is $5.25 or less, and the portions are sized well.
yamo cold noodles.author: CQ N.
yamo cold noodles.review:
My old co-workers brought me to this charming hole-in-the wall a few years ago for a birthday lunch. There's an open kitchen and everything is cooked to order. My favorites are the yamo cold noodles with chicken (has a kick), chicken noodle soup (curry based) and the samosas. Everything is $5.25 or less, and the portions are sized well. Lots of people grab food to go here frequently, too. 

The women that run this place are so sweet, too. One time I accidentally forgot my leftovers and a cook ran out the door to catch me.

excerpts:
Yamo Cold Noodles $5.25
 - 3.5 stars
 - Cold noodles mixed with house special flavor, onions, cabbage, cucumbers, and chicken
 - Pretty good dish.
The noodles are similar to chow mein noodles but without the glossy oiliness.
This was their spicy dish, but it's more tangy than spicy.
The chicken was covered in a thick, almost dry red sauce with lots of full sized peppers (like the dry peppers found in jars at the table at pizza restaurants).
This dish was also full of different flavors giving a nice complexity to the dish.
yamo cold noodles.author: Tetsu N.
yamo cold noodles.review:
Today was my very first experience eating Burmese food, and from what I'm told, everything here is very authentic, or at least authentic from the perspective that identically prepared delectable delights can be had over there.

Meeting a very old friend from back in NY who happened to be in town, we went to Yamo based on her SO's recommendation.

What a treat!  I love experiencing new kinds of food!

The restaurant itself is ridiculously small, with only some limited counter seating, maybe seating 10 or so.  The restaurant looks like it has been around for a while too, and was incredibly popular.  The line was constant and always out the door, tho luckily, it seems that most who get their food here have are well aware that getting takeout is a much wiser choice.  

And the prices!  Excellent prices for the cheap bastard in me.  My friend and I had three dishes, a coconut drink, and a soda for under $20.  For light eaters on a budget, one dish and a drink would be about $7 combined.  Big eaters won't go broke either.  

On to the food.

Tea Salad:  $5.25
 - 4.5 stars
 - Tea leave, cabbage, fresh tomato, oion, dried shrimp & variety of fried bean, nuts and sesame seeds.
 - Wow, by far my favorite dish of the day.  This taste and texture explosion is so good I wish they served it in meal portions, but alas, they only served it as a relatively small and light plate.  More like an appetizer.  It's got a variety of crunchy textures, including what feels like tiny croutons though with a saltier taste (I'm assuming it's the fried bean but might of been the dried shrimp), and the nuts (which I'm guessing may be peanuts), and the more raw veggie crunch of the cabbage.  There are also several software textures as well as the watery tomato texture.   And the taste?  Wow, there's a raw veggie tanginess to it, subtly to it, saltiness to it....Really, explosion is the only way to describe.  And it does this so cleanly and lightly that none of the tastes are overbearing.  This is a MUST ORDER at this small little hole in the wall.

Fish Chowder Noodle Soup $5.25
 - 2 stars
 - Soup chowder with rice noodles, shredded fish, and onions, garnished with Fried Yellowbeans and Cilantro
 - This wasn't bad, but it didn't strike me as very inspired.  The sauce was a thick reddish sauce reminiscent in texture of thick Chinese sauces poured over meats and rice.  Sorry, there should be a better explanation but I can't imagine what it is.  The noodles were very very well cooked and watery, almost like pho noodles, only it didn't seem to be the way these noodles were supposed to be.  The taste was subtle...almost too subtle.  Perhaps, tho, I'm being a little harsh because of the great tastes of the other dishes, but really, I wouldn't order this again.

Yamo Cold Noodles $5.25
 - 3.5 stars
 - Cold noodles mixed with house special flavor, onions, cabbage, cucumbers, and chicken
 - Pretty good dish.  The noodles are similar to chow mein noodles but without the glossy oiliness.  This was their spicy dish, but it's more tangy than spicy.  The chicken was covered in a thick, almost dry red sauce with lots of full sized peppers (like the dry peppers found in jars at the table at pizza restaurants).  This dish was also full of different flavors giving a nice complexity to the dish.  I would order this again.

Fresh Coconut $2.50
 - 4 stars
 - All my life, I thought coconuts had a stronger taste because coconut flakes used in cakes had such a strong flavor.  What a surprise to find the taste was so subtle, if you had told me it was a different fruit, I would have believed you.  So light, refreshing.  Loved it.  I also liked that it came in a full coconut rather than a glass.  It was fun to see, and we could scrape the inside for the thicker fruity part of the coconut.    Yeah, I'd order this again, just for the novelty of it.  

Grass Jelly drink $1.00
 - 2.5 stars
 - This is a can drink.  Not carbonated, with bits of jelly in it.  It's similar in taste to Chinese turtle shell gelatin desserts.  I'd drink it again if it was served, but probably wouldn't ever be my first choice.  Still, it tasted like it was probably a healthy drink.

Though we didn't order it, the customer sitting next to us order what I think (just guessing mind you) is the Yamo House Noodles.  That looked really good.  Basically several bite sized pieces of chicken (looking like it was cooked in a thick dark sauce) over a bed of the chow mein like noodles.  It sure as heck looked good.

All in all, this place was pretty good.  If I would have rated it a straight 3.5, I'd got to 4, but given that all the food combined average below a 3.5, I'll have to go with a 3 today.

Except...the price!  The price is so good, that adds a half star right there, pushing the average up and making this place an easy 4 stars.

So with that said, Yay!  I'm a fan!

excerpts: Order: House Noodles with Chicken, Curry Tofu, Curry Fish, Curry Vegetables, Yamo Cold Noodles (with chicken or tofu), Mushroom Tofu, Chicken Noodle Soup.
yamo cold noodles.author: Crash O.
yamo cold noodles.review:
I love this place so much, words cannot even express. I don't even know what to say to the Yamo Haters, except, haters gotta hate. But I LOVE. 

Order: House Noodles with Chicken, Curry Tofu, Curry Fish, Curry Vegetables, Yamo Cold Noodles (with chicken or tofu), Mushroom Tofu, Chicken Noodle Soup.

Bonus for vegetarians and other tofu-lovers: They will sub tofu for meat in pretty much any dish, even if it's not listed as an option on the menu. The fact that the ladies who work here are all-business and brusque-verging-on-rude can be off-putting, but don't be fooled. These ladies really just want to serve you some delicious food cheaply and efficiently. 

FEEL THE LOVE.

excerpts: Three words: Yamo cold noodles.
yamo cold noodles.author: Dani M.
yamo cold noodles.review:
I saw Yamo across the street from my house but, for the longest time  was too scared to go into it. I did my research here on Yelp was was so glad I did! 

Three words: Yamo cold noodles. YUM! 

Large portions, fast service (always to go - too small to sit in) always tasty, always delicious.

excerpts: The big hit was the Yamo cold noodles with chicken.
yamo cold noodles.author: Abid M.
yamo cold noodles.review:
What an awesome place. The old ladies prepare every thing in front of you.

It's a really small place, with probably 10 seats on the counter, and that's it. Party of 2, showed up at 8:30 pm on Tuesday, wait was 15-20 minutes.

The big hit was the Yamo cold noodles with chicken. So much flavor.

We also ordered the Samosaz (appetizer) and the Black bean fish.  The fish was nice, but not as flavorful as the cold noodles.  The person beside us said the noodle soups were also good. That's the plan for next time.

Totally worth it.

excerpts: I went with a friend we had spring rolls which were excellent, samosas which were pretty good, the tea salad (great) and yamo cold noodles.
The noodles were super, spicy, crispy vegtables,  i could not get enough.
yamo cold noodles.author: Ashley T.
yamo cold noodles.review:
Yamo = YUMo

Don't be intimidated by the surroundings, this place has great food, at an awesome price! Take out seemed to be the choice of most patrons but i enjoyed sitting there watching the women work their magic behind the counter.

I went with a friend we had spring rolls which were excellent, samosas which were pretty good, the tea salad (great) and yamo cold noodles.  The noodles were super, spicy, crispy vegtables,  i could not get enough. I will be back to work my way through the menu. 

the 4 dishes + 2 drinks (non-alcoholic) = $21.... wow.

plus we had leftovers, it was easily enough food for 3, all in all, it was super.

excerpts: The tea leaf salad is an indescribable melange of delicious flavors, and the Yamo cold noodles aren't really cold at all.
yamo cold noodles.author: Leslie C.
yamo cold noodles.review: I love YAMO! The tea leaf salad is an indescribable melange of delicious flavors, and the Yamo cold noodles aren't really cold at all. The salad looks small but fills you up fine. Cheap and yummy- can be slow when place is full.

excerpts: One of the ladies behind the counter suggested the Yamo Cold Noodles, so I got that
My Yamo Cold Noodles had just enough spicy kick to keep you wanting more.
yamo cold noodles.author: Allan H.
yamo cold noodles.review: The GF & I decided to stop by here for lunch based on the glowing reviews (and the fact that we were out in the Mission already).  We almost walked right by the place - it's a hole in the wall place, meant in the best way possible.  The awning of the place was barely legible but we could roughly make out Yamo on there.  We stepped inside and take a seat at the counter.  Almost everything on the menu (aside from drinks) is priced at $5.25 and $3.50 for appetizers.  One of the ladies behind the counter suggested the Yamo Cold Noodles, so I got that and the GF got the Yamo House Noodles.  We also got an order of the freshly made spring rolls.  I personally love places where you get to see what's going on in the kitchen and in this joint, you definitely have a front row seat.  The spring rolls were tasty, big & fresh!  The noodle dishes were very good too.  The taste of the Yamo House Noodles reminded me of noodles I would make at a Mongolian BBQ place.  My Yamo Cold Noodles had just enough spicy kick to keep you wanting more.  I thought we were done, but ended up ordering some Samusas to go.  The sauce provided definitely had a kick to it!  We thought a yogurt based sauce might go nicer, but they were still quite good.  I'm definitely coming back here though!

excerpts: Since it was getting cold, I decided on the vegetable curry when I found a seat.
There are a good amount of vegetarian options.
vegetable curry.author: Carol W.
vegetable curry.review:
"What do you want?" I kept hearing, and wondered who was saying this.  I stood outside, and viewed the menu while watching for someone to leave the small counter so I could grab a seat. One could order food to go at the counter next to the door. 

I noticed someone I know leaving, who advised me what to eat. I previously ate the tea leaf salad (to go), and thought it was good. I wanted to try something new. She said to try the cold noodles over the house noodles for its combination of spices and textures. Since it was getting cold, I decided on the vegetable curry when I found a seat. There are a good amount of vegetarian options. Note: try to avoid the far corner of the counter, since one won't really have much counter space.

I was asked "What do you want?" by the server/prep cook/busser and told her. I watched the speediness of the cook, and my food arrived quickly. The curry had a good variety of vegetables, and flavorful sauce plus noodles. The guest next to me reached for a water bottle for me from the fridge. I learned that hot tea wasn't available when someone asked for it. A food item (perhaps #3) also wasn't available. 

What do you want? Cheap, good food is what you'll receive at Yamo.

excerpts: Well I tried the vegetable curry today & it is terrible here.
The first dish I really don't like.
vegetable curry.author: Scott F.
vegetable curry.review: Well I tried the vegetable curry today & it is terrible here. The first dish I really don't like.  Tea salad still rocked. The service is still wacky. And the price is still $6.25.

excerpts: Vegetable Curry:

3 stars
Bland but nice cardamom spice flavour.
vegetable curry.author: Letitia L.
vegetable curry.review:
Tiny, hole-in-wall place where you squeeze in, they whisk dishes away to signal for you to eat faster and 15 mins later you squeeze out.

Not as high quality food as the other famous Burmese restaurants in SF, but it's only $6 per dish. I also like that they have grass jelly drink!


---- DISHES ----

Tea Leaf Salad: 2.5 stars
Definitely not as good as Burma Love, Superstar. The good places use a concentrated tea leaf paste chock full of umami, this one was a watery tangy spicy sauce that missed the mark for me.

Fish Noodle Soup: 4.5 stars
(Mohinga curry) Comforting home cooked food.

Black Bean Fish: 3.5 stars
Pretty standard similar to Chinese restaurants, comforting. Would eat if ill.

Vegetable Curry: 3 stars
Bland but nice cardamom spice flavour. Good selection of veggies from zucchini to eggplant, mushroom okra cabbage broccoli carrot and green beans.

Cold Noodles: 3.5 stars
Spicy.

excerpts: Had vegetable curry and fish noodle soup there.
Idk why people said they tasted bad.
vegetable curry.author: Bianca N.
vegetable curry.review:
I'm lovin' the foods! Had vegetable curry and fish noodle soup there. Idk why people said they tasted bad. But for me and my sis, who grew up in south east asia and had our burmese grandma cooked for us, we loved the food. It's not salty but enough to make you thirsty. well, my tummy is satisfied!

Yes, the ladies were rude. Trust me, they were actually not that rude. We talked to one of them and she smiled often when responding to us.
Tip: don't take pictures there. They gonna be mad. Cash only, better give final amount and don't expect change.

excerpts: I ordered the vegetable curry over rice, and it took quite a while for the food to get to me.
In the meantime, I'm getting smoke blown directly at my face.
Don't sit in the seat closest to the door because that's where they stirfry their food and get smoke and spices all over you
T_T.
I did my best to ignore it, but there were times I had to lean back away from the counter cause the smoke was that bad.
I wonder how many complaints they've gotten from that.
Probably none cause the cook was pretty scary/kind of rude.
Anyway, I get my vegetable curry over rice.
Except it's more like hella salty/spicy vegetables with hella grease over rice.
The portion wasn't very big, but I felt like I had to eat most of it just not to be rude and leave the whole plate there.
Uggh it was so oily and salty
T___T. Not worth $6!!
Left pretty annoyed.
Why does this place have 4 stars??
vegetable curry.author: Betty W.
vegetable curry.review:
Yelp!! Why?? So I just ate here for lunch. I ordered the vegetable curry over rice, and it took quite a while for the food to get to me. In the meantime, I'm getting smoke blown directly at my face. Don't sit in the seat closest to the door because that's where they stirfry their food and get smoke and spices all over you T_T. I did my best to ignore it, but there were times I had to lean back away from the counter cause the smoke was that bad. I wonder how many complaints they've gotten from that. Probably none cause the cook was pretty scary/kind of rude. How could she not notice??

Anyway, I get my vegetable curry over rice. Except it's more like hella salty/spicy vegetables with hella grease over rice. The portion wasn't very big, but I felt like I had to eat most of it just not to be rude and leave the whole plate there. Uggh it was so oily and salty T___T. Not worth $6!! Left pretty annoyed. Why does this place have 4 stars?? WHY?

P.S. I didn't know that this place is literally just a counter. Also, their water tastes strangely minty.

excerpts:
- this was pretty tasty, but I prefer this dish at other Burmese restaurants
Samusas - actually really good and hot and fresh
Mushroom Tofu - ok, kind of lacking in flavor
Vegetable Curry over noodles - luke warm, but interesting -
I appreciated that okra was among the vegetables in the dish.
vegetable curry.author: Rachana S.
vegetable curry.review:
I was excited to try a hole in the wall Burmese restaurant and went with two other friends.  We waited maybe 10 minutes before being seated which wasn't bad at all.  As everyone else mentioned, it's super small, and you can watch all the food being prepared for you which is pretty cool.  But, the food was only ok to me.  I'm vegetarian so we ended up getting:

Tea-leaf salad - this was pretty tasty, but I prefer this dish at other Burmese restaurants
Samusas - actually really good and hot and fresh
Mushroom Tofu - ok, kind of lacking in flavor
Vegetable Curry over noodles - luke warm, but interesting - I appreciated that okra was among the vegetables in the dish.
Coconut Water - awesome, got to eat the coconut meat at the end as well, but not really special to Yamo
Green jelly drink - a canned drink that was ok

But, this place IS dirt cheap.  We got all of that for 25 bucks.  I wouldn't resist if someone wanted to come here for dinner, but I think I'd prefer most of the other Burmese restaurants around town (even if they're further out).

excerpts: I had the Vegetable Curry with rice, and it was certainly tasty!
It's not a curry dish in the traditional sense but rather a stir-fried veggie plate with a curry sauce.
Everything on the menu seems to be prepared in the style of Asian "street food.
vegetable curry.author: Anthony A.
vegetable curry.review:
Eating here is an experience in an of itself. I recommend trying to grab a seat if there's room (I believe there is only 10 seats in the whole place and most people order to-go). 

I had the Vegetable Curry with rice, and it was certainly tasty! It's not a curry dish in the traditional sense but rather a stir-fried veggie plate with a curry sauce. Everything on the menu seems to be prepared in the style of Asian "street food." 

I'm not sure how authentic this is, but I'm glad I gave it a try and I think everyone ought to drop by at least once to experience the unique atmosphere.

That said, I can't say that I will be back soon because unfortunately (and the reason I'm docking one star) the food is VERY salty. Be warned, you might be thirsty for the remainder of the night :P

excerpts: I love the vegetable curry noodles.
The veggies are cooked perfect (they are still somewhat crisp) and includes okra.
Yumo.
Flavors pop, appetizers rock.
vegetable curry.author: Maria D.
vegetable curry.review:
Yamo, Yamo where have you been all my life? So there are so many overpriced places in this town, and for the most part, they are not even close to being as good as this no-frills hole in the wall. So you put it on a fancy plate and serve it to me with a hot waiter in a crisp white shirt doesn't make the wallet assault any less insulting. 

At Yamo there is a short counter space at which you can plop down, the ambiance is hot Burmese kitchen and not hot SF hotspot, but the lovely ladies there cook up some gorgeous fresh plates of yumminess, AND they chop off the top of the fresh coconut entirely: so you can get at all the fresh coconutty goodness. Some places don't do this...why I ask you? It is like $2.50 for the coconut. $5.25 for each entre. I love the vegetable curry noodles. The veggies are cooked perfect (they are still somewhat crisp) and includes okra. Yumo. Flavors pop, appetizers rock. The tea salad, and fresh spring rolls. Go to Yamo and drink a coconut already. You will be glad you did.

excerpts: tea leaf salad is outstanding, but everything else was ok (fish chowder, vegetable curry, samusas)
vegetable curry.author: Cece L.
vegetable curry.review:
tea leaf salad is outstanding, but everything else was ok (fish chowder, vegetable curry, samusas)

I saw the chef drop a broccoli on the ground, then toss it back into the pan.. YUCK!

excerpts: I got the vegetable curry and it was way spicy.
It's a tiny hole-in-the-wall type place, so there's not many places to sit, either.
I just expect more from a solid 4-star place in SF.
vegetable curry.author: Amy S.
vegetable curry.review: I think I expected too much from Yamo is my problem. It's for sure a good noodle lunch place, but it's not something I'd seek out on a trip to the Mission (I act like it's such a hike, really it's a 20 min walk. Once again - lazy). I got the vegetable curry and it was way spicy. It's a tiny hole-in-the-wall type place, so there's not many places to sit, either. I just expect more from a solid 4-star place in SF.

excerpts: We had the vegetable curry and were both satisfied.
She was slightly alarmed by the grease on the wall
but, otherwise, this is a fantastic, cheap local spot.
The man next to us told us he was from Burma, an affirmation that Yamo attracts not only collegiate foodies on a budget but also customers who really know Burmese cuisine.
vegetable curry.author: Rebecca H.
vegetable curry.review: Went here a few days ago for my second time with a friend from LA. We had the vegetable curry and were both satisfied. She was slightly alarmed by the grease on the wall but, otherwise, this is a fantastic, cheap local spot. The man next to us told us he was from Burma, an affirmation that Yamo attracts not only collegiate foodies on a budget but also customers who really know Burmese cuisine.

excerpts: so far i've had the vegetable curry over noodles which is a giant plate loaded with veggies piled on top of noodles and the house noodles (which i ordered with veggies instead of meat), same same but different - huge serving of veggies piled over noodles.
just differently seasoned.
the line seems to range from turbo short to super long because there are only about 10 seats for eat-in
but it's well worth
whatever wait.
vegetable curry.author: Emily T.
vegetable curry.review: holy shit, it's cheap cheap cheap and so fucking good.  it's just hot, fast, vegetable-y noodle-y amazingness for $6.  so far i've had the vegetable curry over noodles which is a giant plate loaded with veggies piled on top of noodles and the house noodles (which i ordered with veggies instead of meat), same same but different - huge serving of veggies piled over noodles.  just differently seasoned.  the line seems to range from turbo short to super long because there are only about 10 seats for eat-in but it's well worth whatever wait.

excerpts: I ordered the vegetable curry to go.
The curry really wasn't a curry; it was more of a spiced oil...
it wasn't bad; it just wasn't good.
vegetable curry.author: Matt P.
vegetable curry.review: This place defines "hole-in-the-wall"... it is basically involves a long narrow space of which 2/3rds is dedicated to the cooking area and the other 1/3rd to the counter, barstools and walking space... cramped is an understatement.  I ordered the vegetable curry to go.  The curry really wasn't a curry; it was more of a spiced oil... it wasn't bad; it just wasn't good.

excerpts: We ordered the mango salad, tea salad, and vegetable curry.
We were handed our food and left without checking that it was the right dishes.
We got home and discovered that we got both salads, but we got the vegetable stir fry instead, and she threw in and charged us for spring roles, which we didn't order.
the salads were tasty, but they kind of made my stomach hurt, and the vegetable stirfry was nasty, fried, watery, oily, yuck.
All in all if I'm looking for some cheap eats I would not go back to this place, or at least I wouldn't order take out.
vegetable curry.author: Malcolm K.
vegetable curry.review: we ordered and I asked how long it would be and the old woman who yells instead of talks said it would be 15 min.  We went and had a beer and came back about 20 min later and it wasn't ready.  I figured I'd asked the young helper what was up since she probably spoke better english, and she said (in broken english)... "Wait on vegetable's".  We didn't mind the wait since it was a nice night out and we'd had a beer.  We ordered the mango salad, tea salad, and vegetable curry.  We were handed our food and left without checking that it was the right dishes.  We got home and discovered that we got both salads, but we got the vegetable stir fry instead, and she threw in and charged us for spring roles, which we didn't order. the salads were tasty, but they kind of made my stomach hurt, and the vegetable stirfry was nasty, fried, watery, oily, yuck.  All in all if I'm looking for some cheap eats I would not go back to this place, or at least I wouldn't order take out.

excerpts: Curry Tofu

+ Nice spice
4.
Potstickers (pork)
curry tofu.author: Chuck N.
curry tofu.review:
Friday, 8:00PM.
Note: Cash only. 

Limited seating, be prepared to wait.

Quickie:
* Food quality
+ Service
* Hygiene
+ Turnaround
+ Menu variety

And then...?
Get in, get your grease, get out. 

**********
Stuffed my face in:
1. Mango Chicken
     + Sweet n' salty with tender meat
2. Yamo Noodles (beef)
     - Grease is strong for this one, even for a greasy spoon
3. Curry Tofu
     + Nice spice
4. Potstickers (pork)
     - Amount of dough diluted most of the flavor

Constructive comments:
*Source ingredients
*Compost

excerpts: Entrees: All $6 - choice of curry beef, chicken, curry prawns, curry tofu or curry fish.
Everything goes over egg noodles or rice.
Don't like curry?
they make a house fried rice or a house pan fried noodle.
Other male diners (with bigger appetites!) went all out ordering potstickers, curry fish noodles and fried rice and curry tofu just for two people.
Some couples took out an order of the tea leaf salad on their way out.
Other male diners (with bigger appetites!) went all out ordering potstickers, curry fish noodles and fried rice and curry tofu just for two people.
Some couples took out an order of the tea leaf salad on their way out.
curry tofu.author: Joanna T.
curry tofu.review:
By chance, I noticed Yamo last week and now passing the place (with fast sinking blood sugar), I stopped and decided to give it a try.

First off, Yamo is a shoebox. But this place last week and tonight was full. Everyone sits at a counter on some funky, red vinyl covered stools. What caught my eye this time was a guy seated close to a door drinking from a straw that fed into a real coconut. I had to exam the menu in the window.

Appetizers: $4.95 - only 3 choices: samusas, egg rolls and potstickers. 
Salads:       $6      - tea leaf or chicken salad

Ahh, the samusa and tea leaf salad on the menu immediately screamed "Burmese" to me. 

Entrees: All $6 - choice of curry beef, chicken, curry prawns, curry tofu or curry fish. Everything goes over egg noodles or rice. Don't like curry? they make a house fried rice or a house pan fried noodle. You kind of get the drift that their repetoire is strictly enforced.

When I popped my head in, the main lady and the cook looked over the full row and then peeked over the counter and nodded me to the 1st stool right inside the door opposite the stoves. Umm, is this the best seat in the house? Or is this the worst seat?

I've got to say I like the fresh air coming into the door. Didn't like the closeness of the flames from the wok shooting up in the air from the stove.

Without being in a party, I chose only one dish: curry prawns with rice. I was fascinated watching the ladies' system. The head lady takes the orders, gathers ingredients and places items in a silver dish which she lines up by the cook and the cook stir-frys each dish up and gives it back to the head lady to deliver to the customer.

Back to the food: now dairy-based curry generally has a good sauce that goes good with rice. But when I was served up my dish, I found I had a reddish, oil based curry with the prawns. Foiled - not much sauce. The food was okay and definitely hot from the oven.

Other male diners (with bigger appetites!) went all out ordering potstickers, curry fish noodles and fried rice and curry tofu just for two people. Some couples took out an order of the tea leaf salad on their way out. Seems like a very popular dish.

It was really interesting to watch the interplay between the ladies busting themselves to get the food out. I watched the youngest of the ladies hack (with a cleaver) at the top of a fresh coconut to pierce the shell so a straw could be inserted. Amazing.

What else can I say? If in the area and hungry but on a budget, come for the food and stay for the show.

excerpts: I have tried the Potstickers, Tea Leaf Salad, Fish Chowder Noodle Soup, Mango Chicken, Black Bean Fish, Yamo House Noodles with Beef, Chicken Noodle Soup, Yamo Cold Noodles and the Curry Tofu
and they were all great.
curry tofu.author: Joy L.
curry tofu.review:
This is a great little hole in the wall. The space itself is tiny, and your food is literally cooked in front of you. The food is great and the service is no-nonsense, but that doesn't mean they are unfriendly, they are just busy. Your best bet is to call in ahead of time and order take out if you don't want to wait for a seat. Also - since the place is so teeny tiny, the ventilation is quite poor, so take out may be your best option in that respect as well.  

Reasonable prices and I have no complaints about the food. Their portions are a little on the small side, but you can't expect more than what they give you for the price you are paying. Their menu is not huge, but what they offer, they do well. I have tried the Potstickers, Tea Leaf Salad, Fish Chowder Noodle Soup, Mango Chicken, Black Bean Fish, Yamo House Noodles with Beef, Chicken Noodle Soup, Yamo Cold Noodles and the Curry Tofu and they were all great. All of their noodle dishes are excellent. 

This is a Mission gem - it encompasses everything I love about San Francisco: Tiny little hole-in-the-wall places with yummy but dirt-cheap food.

excerpts: Where was the spice in our spicy curry tofu?!
Where was that rich, the extra kick in flavor that usually accompanies curry?
It wasn't there.
It was all forgettable.
Took me almost an hour to even remember what we ordered...
The only good thing that I got out of it was how I paid under $15 for the entire bill.
If you're solely looking for a cheap-eat place, this is it.
curry tofu.author: Emily Y.
curry tofu.review:
What is wrong with you people?! Four stars?! C'mon, my grandma can cook up better food than this joint and she's not even that great! 

Came here with my boy toy and lucky us we didn't have to wait for 2 out of the 8 seats there total. This is truly a hole in the wall eatery. I love it! Great place to rub elbows with strangers, profess your love of cock sauce to the whole table, watch the women behind the counter cook up a fire and hear them yell in Cantonese (not Burmese as someone else stated) about how the bills are all mixed up. 

The lady recommended we get the mango chicken. A MISTAKE! Everyone knows that one of the basic rules in cooking is to season the food. What I got was a plate of uber blandness. At least the chicken was tender. I was tempted to pour soy sauce all over my dish and mind you, I rarely do such a foolish thing. 
Where was the spice in our spicy curry tofu?! Where was that rich, the extra kick in flavor that usually accompanies curry? It wasn't there. It was all forgettable. Took me almost an hour to even remember what we ordered...
The only good thing that I got out of it was how I paid under $15 for the entire bill. If you're solely looking for a cheap-eat place, this is it. If you're looking for real 'Asian' cuisine, try some place else. 

I'm a believer in second chances, I might give this place another shot and try their fish soup as someone else mentioned...

excerpts: Since I'm vegetarian, I only tried the samusas and curry tofu, both rocked!
curry tofu.author: Swetha G.
curry tofu.review:
I would give this place six stars if I could.

Unbelievable service and excellent quality of food.

I walked into Yamo three days ago to place a rather large order for a meeting we were having at my office.  Since I work at a non-profit and our food budget is limited, I'm not too flexible with how much we can spend, but I still have to find a way to feed everyone.  I wanted to order a couple entrees on the party platter menu but the total was something that I knew my organization did not have room to cover.  So then what?  Well first of all the staff rocks and went above and beyond to try to accomodate our hiccup.  Judy was awesome and did everything she could to get her boss Joseph (the owner) on the phone since he wasn't in at the time.  When we were able to get a hold of him, he was incredibly kind and really tried to work with me on the price.  In the end I was able to stay within budget and placed the food order.

Fast forward to two days later and all I can say is if you haven't been to Yamo, don't walk, run!  The food was such a hit at the meeting that a couple of us, including myself, couldn't restrain ourselves and got second and third servings.  If there weren't others around I probably would've kept going!  Since I'm vegetarian, I only tried the samusas and curry tofu, both rocked!  Others who had the pork chow mein, mango chicken, and beef curry only had raves to share.

This place is a little hole in the wall that is easy to overlook, but if you do happen to stop and go in, I guarantee, you will NOT be disappointed!

excerpts: Her soup looked delicious, and my curry tofu was just okay....
curry tofu.author: Jess R.
curry tofu.review:
Somewhere on 18th street, in a small dark closet that has a doorway, a couple of Burmese ladies are busting their butts serving up fresh and tasty food.

I was fluctuating between three and four, but the more I thought about it, the more I liked about this place than not.

As everyone has said, yes.  It is small.  I ventured in at 130 on a Saturday (actually, 138 because i was late...) and there were plenty of seats available for us.  

The first thing I did notice when I walked in was the heavy smell of oil.  I knew I was going to stink after I left which bummed me out because I was heading back to a party after...  Grr.

Anyhow, the menu had several options.  All of the dishes were under $6?!?  That's my kind of place!!!!

My friend who I came with was the professional...  She promptly ordered up the Tea Tree Salad and the Chicken Noodle soup.

I ended up ordering the Tofu Curry, they ask if you want it over noodles or rice.  I chose the noodles, and I'm glad I did!!!

I tried some of my friends Tea Tree salad and it was DELICIOUS.  I wish I just ordered three of them and had that as my meal.....

Her soup looked delicious, and my curry tofu was just okay....  It didn't have a whole lot of taste to it, but the noodles underneath it were DELICIOUS....

This place was definitely a good find.  The women working their are nice, and efficient!!!  She realized they had put my tofu over rice instead of the noodles before she even handed it to me and within only 2 minutes, problem remedied!!!

I look forward to trying a few more things they have to offer, and hopefully they can throw some tofu in their chicken noodle soup instead of chicken.  I would like that.  I also enjoyed watching them work.  Her wrapping a spring roll was the BEST!

excerpts: Order: House Noodles with Chicken, Curry Tofu, Curry Fish, Curry Vegetables, Yamo Cold Noodles (with chicken or tofu), Mushroom Tofu, Chicken Noodle Soup.
curry tofu.author: Crash O.
curry tofu.review:
I love this place so much, words cannot even express. I don't even know what to say to the Yamo Haters, except, haters gotta hate. But I LOVE. 

Order: House Noodles with Chicken, Curry Tofu, Curry Fish, Curry Vegetables, Yamo Cold Noodles (with chicken or tofu), Mushroom Tofu, Chicken Noodle Soup.

Bonus for vegetarians and other tofu-lovers: They will sub tofu for meat in pretty much any dish, even if it's not listed as an option on the menu. The fact that the ladies who work here are all-business and brusque-verging-on-rude can be off-putting, but don't be fooled. These ladies really just want to serve you some delicious food cheaply and efficiently. 

FEEL THE LOVE.

excerpts: I loved the curry tofu over noodles, and the fresh coconut drink is always delightful.
curry tofu.author: Pat E.
curry tofu.review:
This is a bare bones place when it comes to decor and presentation, but as a lunch counter sort of joint, it does the job well.

I loved the curry tofu over noodles, and the fresh coconut drink is always delightful.

Prices are beyond reasonable - two people can eat for $20, and eat well.

excerpts: We also ordered curry fish, which was not as flavorful to me, but the texture was soft and creamy.
curry fish.author: Urmila J.
curry fish.review:
Can't believe it took me 3 years in SF to try this. Yes, waiting to get a bar seat isn't so fun but dang those two ladies cook fast. I have never been happier to get yelled at to grab a seat. 

The tea salad is something I've never tried before, with crunchy pieces of what I believe were garlic cloves and shredded veggies. The papaya salad is more standard but still very good. We also ordered curry fish, which was not as flavorful to me, but the texture was soft and creamy. My friends seemed to really enjoy their red meat dishes.

All in all I hope to return ASAP. If you're in a rush, take out is quick!

excerpts: My lunch partner had nothing good to say about their house fried chow mein & curry fish (I don't think "tastes like fish nuggets" was a compliment.)
curry fish.author: Fancypants X.
curry fish.review:
Yamo, with its 10 counter seats, questionable ventilation, & curt service, reminds me of how SF restaurants used to be in the 80s. If I'm being kind, I'd say its got quintessential SF character. If I'm being real, I'd say I think it's their relatively cheap prices, not the food's flavor, that's kept them in business all these decades. 

My lunch partner had nothing good to say about their house fried chow mein & curry fish (I don't think "tastes like fish nuggets" was a compliment.) 

Tea leaf salad had no actual tea leaf flavor, tasted more like a spicy, vinegary cabbage slaw. As for serving size, you absolutely get what you pay for, not that we wanted more. 

My house noodles with chicken was greasy, but oh-so-bland. Every couple bites I might get a taste of fried garlic, but it wasn't enough to lend the flavor that the noodles were sorely missing. Surprisingly my favorite part of the dish were the bits of tender chicken breast. 

If you're looking for good Burmese food, look elsewhere. If you're looking to show your out of town friends the "edgy", grimy, or unique SF food scene, I guess Yamo would suffice as a decent example (with a disclaimer that there's much better Asian food in the city.)

Cash only.

excerpts: I ordered the house noodles and the curry fish - both were much closer to what I might get at an Americanized Chinese restaurant.

The house noodles tasted like oily pulled noodles (a bit like your standard lo mein type dish) with a sparse few bits of well cooked meat, and the curry fish had mushrooms and bell pepper, which I don't often see in Burmese curries.
Good value and generally satisfying though
curry fish.author: Neal B.
curry fish.review: I came here expecting some Burmese eats, but the menu options seemed pretty limited. I ordered the house noodles and the curry fish - both were much closer to what I might get at an Americanized Chinese restaurant. The house noodles tasted like oily pulled noodles (a bit like your standard lo mein type dish) with a sparse few bits of well cooked meat, and the curry fish had mushrooms and bell pepper, which I don't often see in Burmese curries. Good value and generally satisfying though

excerpts: The curry fish was over sauced and lacking the intensity of flavor that it should have.
curry fish.author: Eric P.
curry fish.review: I have been going here since they opened and the food quality has diminished in quality.(although it does depend on the cook). The fried rice used to be a great example of the dish. Today at lunch I was served clumps of wet rice with the spices not blended in entirely throughout. The curry fish was over sauced and lacking the intensity of flavor that it should have. The tea salad is still the best in town ( minus the small rock I had). The service is "unique" but Judy, the owner, is a very nice person.

Everything goes over egg noodles or rice.
Don't like curry?
they make a house fried rice or a house pan fried noodle.
Other male diners (with bigger appetites!) went all out ordering potstickers, curry fish noodles and fried rice and curry tofu just for two people.
Some couples took out an order of the tea leaf salad on their way out.
Other male diners (with bigger appetites!) went all out ordering potstickers, curry fish noodles and fried rice and curry tofu just for two people.
Some couples took out an order of the tea leaf salad on their way out.
